0.name: KOPILUWAK
0.uncertain_mes: [KOPILUWAK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1075) is a JavaScript-based reconnaissance tool that has been used for victim profiling and C2 since at least 2017.(Citation: Mandiant Suspected Turla Campaign February 2023)
0.profile: [profile]KOPILUWAK, also known as kopiluwak, is a JavaScript-based reconnaissance tool attributed to the Turla group and used for victim profiling and command and control (C2) since at least 2017. Its key technical behaviors include using JavaScript droppers like "Scr.js" and "appidpolicyconverter.js" to deploy payloads, often delivered via malicious documents such as PDF decoys mimicking embassy event agendas. The malware targets platforms through phishing emails and employs MSIL droppers as part of its infection chain, with infrastructure and supplementary activities linked to operations like QuietCanary and Andromeda.
0.profile_without_enhance: [profile]KOPILUWAK, also known as kopiluwak, is a malware attributed to the Turla group. It is delivered via malicious documents, often mimicking event agendas from embassies in phishing emails, and uses a JavaScript payload stored at C:\Windows\Temp\xpexplore.js for initial execution and reconnaissance.

2.name: ANDROMEDA
2.uncertain_mes: On 29 November 2017, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), in close cooperation with the Luneburg Central Criminal Investigation Inspectorate in Germany, Europolâ€™s European Cybercrime Centre (EC3), the Joint Cybercrime Action Task Force (J-CAT), Eurojust and private-sector partners, dismantled one of the longest running malware families in existence called Andromeda (also known as Gamarue).
2.profile: [profile]ANDROMEDA, also known as Gamarue, is a long-running malware family dismantled in a 2017 law enforcement operation. It is associated with Operation C-Major. Its technical behaviors include command and control (C2) communication via specific HTTP URLs (e.g., hxxp://huremoke[.]net/get.php). The malware primarily targets Windows platforms and has been observed in botnet operations alongside other malware like Cutwail and UrlZone.[/profile]
2.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ANDROMEDA, also known as Gamarue, is a long-running malware family dismantled in a 2017 law enforcement operation. It establishes persistence via the Windows Registry Run Keys (T1547.001) and uses command-and-control (C2) infrastructure at domains like anam0rph[.]su, huremoke[.]net, and votehad[.]su. Its primary target is the Windows platform, with observed payloads dropped to paths like C:\Temp\TrustedInstaller.exe.

11.name: persistence via Run Registry Key
11.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key. Adding an entry to the "run keys" in the Registry or startup folder will cause the program referenced to be executed when a user logs in.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) These programs will be executed under the context of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level. The following run keys are created by default on Windows systems: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce Run keys may exist under multiple hives.(Citation: Microsoft Wow6432Node 2018)(Citation: Malwarebytes Wow6432Node 2016) The HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx is also available but is not created by default on Windows Vista and newer. Registry run key entries can reference programs directly or list them as a dependency.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) For example, it is possible to load a DLL at logon using a "Depend" key with RunOnceEx: reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil[.]dll" (Citation: Oddvar Moe RunOnceEx Mar 2018) Placing a program within a startup folder will also cause that program to execute when a user logs in. There is a startup folder location for individual user accounts as well as a system-wide startup folder that will be checked regardless of which user account logs in. The startup folder path for the current user is C:\Users\\[Username]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup. The startup folder path for all users is C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\StartUp. The following Registry keys can be used to set startup folder items for persistence: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders The following Registry keys can control automatic startup of services during boot: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices Using policy settings to specify startup programs creates corresponding values in either of two Registry keys: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run Programs listed in the load value of the registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows run automatically for the currently logged-on user. By default, the multistring BootExecute value of the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager is set to autocheck autochk *. This value causes Windows, at startup, to check the file-system integrity of the hard disks if the system has been shut down abnormally. Adversaries can add other programs or processes to this registry value which will automatically launch at boot. Adversaries can use these configuration locations to execute malware, such as remote access tools, to maintain persistence through system reboots. Adversaries may also use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the Registry entries look as if they are associated with legitimate programs.
11.profile: [profile]Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder, identified as T1547.001, is a Persistence technique for Windows platforms. It involves adding entries to specific Registry keys (e.g., HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run) or placing executables in startup folders (e.g., C:\Users\[Username]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup) to automatically execute a referenced program or DLL when a user logs in, thereby maintaining access across reboots under the user's context.[/profile]
11.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "persistence via Run Registry Key" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder" (T1547.001) under the Persistence tactic for Windows platforms. This technique achieves persistence by adding a program reference to specific Windows Registry run keys, such as HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run or HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run, causing the referenced program to execute automatically when a user logs into the system. Adversaries may use commands like `reg add` to create these entries, often masquerading them as legitimate programs to evade detection.

12.name: Unknown_Threat_Actor
12.profile: [profile]This entity is currently designated as an unknown threat actor, indicating that its specific identity, origin, and affiliations have not been conclusively attributed. Further intelligence collection and analysis are required to determine its arsenal, tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), as well as its target sectors, regions, and underlying motivations.
12.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is strongly suspected to be APT34 (OilRig), also known as Helminth and Crambus. Its key malware includes the Helminth Trojan and a Browser Credential Dumper. Notable TTPs involve using malicious Office documents with macros, abusing Group Policy Extensions for persistence, and employing obfuscation and command-line evasion. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets organizations in the Middle East, particularly in Israel and Saudi Arabia, focusing on sectors like telecommunications, defense, and banking, with motivations aligned with espionage.[/profile]
12.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set, likely operating under the aliases 'APT-C-36' or 'Blind Eagle', is a financially motivated threat actor attributed to Colombia. Its operations primarily target Spanish-speaking individuals and organizations in Latin America, with a focus on sectors like government, finance, and telecommunications in Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela. The group is known for deploying custom malware such as the Delphi-based 'Octopus' or 'Bandook' RAT, often delivered via phishing campaigns that utilize malicious documents and social engineering. Its technical profile shows overlaps with other groups like 'Machete' and 'Sidewinder', and it is believed to be linked to campaigns such as 'Operation Spalax' and 'Operation Quicksand'.
12.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, whose standardized APT designation is currently unknown, is a suspected Chinese state-sponsored threat actor believed to be linked to the group tracked as APT41. It is also known by the aliases Barium and Winnti. Its operations are characterized by the use of key malware and tools such as the ShadowPad backdoor, the PoisonIvy RAT, and the PlugX loader. Its Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) include supply chain compromise and leveraging stolen code-signing certificates to sign its malware, enabling stealthy deployment. The group is attributed to China and primarily targets the technology, telecommunications, and video game sectors, with a global operational footprint. Its motivations are assessed to be cyber espionage and intellectual property theft, often conducted for strategic economic and military advantage.
12.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely APT34 (OilRig), also known as Helminth. Its key malware includes the Helminth Trojan and its variants (update.vbs, dns.ps1). Key TTPs involve using malicious Office documents (like Clayslide) with macros for initial access, DNS and HTTP beaconing for C2, and establishing persistence via scheduled tasks and registry modifications. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets entities in the Middle East, with a focus on Israeli high-tech and defense companies, Saudi Arabian organizations, and the regional financial and energy sectors. Its motivation is believed to be cyber espionage.[/profile]
12.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely APT34 (OilRig), also known as Helix Kitten, Twisted Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy. Its key malware includes the Helminth Trojan backdoor, delivered via malicious documents (e.g., Clayslide) and PowerShell scripts like dns.ps1, and it uses tools such as Mimikatz for credential access. Key TTPs involve DNS-based command and control, scheduled tasks for persistence, and exploitation of vulnerabilities like CVE-2017-0199. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets the Middle East, focusing on sectors including financial, government, energy, and telecommunications, with a motivation of cyber espionage aligned with Iranian state interests.[/profile]
12.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Iranian state-sponsored APT group known as OilRig (APT34). It is also known as Helminth and Crambus. The group's key malware includes the Helminth Trojan (and its variants like HerHer trojan and update.vbs), and it has used tools like Mimikatz. Its TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious documents (e.g., Clayslide), leveraging exploits like CVE-2017-0199, and using DNS tunneling and WMI queries for command and control and discovery. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets sectors in the Middle East, including Israeli companies, Saudi Arabian financial institutions, and Middle Eastern diplomatic and telecommunications entities. Its motivation is believed to be cyber espionage aligned with Iranian state interests.
12.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]This intrusion set is highly likely to be APT34, also known as OilRig, Helminth, and Cobalt Gypsy. Its key custom malware includes the Helminth Trojan (and its HerHer variant) and the Browser Credential Dumper. Its TTPs involve using malicious Office documents (Clayslide) with macros for initial access, DNS and HTTP for command and control, and establishing persistence via scheduled tasks and registry modifications. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets organizations in the Middle East, specifically Israel and Saudi Arabia, focusing on sectors like telecommunications, defense, and financial institutions. Its motivation is believed to be cyber espionage aligned with Iranian state interests.[/profile]
12.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, likely the Iranian state-sponsored group known as APT33 (also referred to as Elfin, Refined Kitten, or Holmium), employs custom tools like the .NET-based nmass RAT and uses malware components such as 1.vbs and malicious Office documents. Its key TTPs include exploiting vulnerabilities like CVE-2021-26858 in Microsoft Exchange, using watering hole attacks, and leveraging tools like Mimikatz for credential theft. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets the energy sector, diplomatic institutions, and companies in the Middle East, particularly in Saudi Arabia and Israel, with motivations centered on espionage and strategic intelligence gathering.
12.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]This intrusion set is strongly suspected to be APT34 (OilRig), also known as Helminth, Crambus, and Lyceum. It employs custom malware including the Helminth Trojan, a .NET-based RAT component, and tools like the Browser Credential Dumper. Key TTPs involve spearphishing with malicious Office documents containing macros, command line evasion, and obfuscation, while exploiting vulnerabilities like CVE-2021-26858 and CVE-2021-27065. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets organizations in the Middle East, with a focus on the telecommunications, defense, and banking sectors, as well as Israeli companies, for espionage and data theft.[/profile]
12.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is likely the APT34 (OilRig) group, also known as Helminth, Crambus, and Lyceum. Its key malware includes the Helminth Trojan backdoor, delivered via Clayslide documents and HerHer Trojan, and PowerShell scripts like dns1.ps1 for DNS tunneling. Key TTPs involve credential harvesting, reconnaissance, and DLL loading for defense evasion. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets the Middle East, with a focus on sectors including financial institutions, defense contractors, and Israeli companies, indicating a motivation for espionage and regional strategic intelligence gathering.
12.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]This intrusion set, believed to be APT34 (OilRig), is also known as Helminth, Crambus, and Lyceum. It primarily uses the Helminth Trojan backdoor for operations, delivered via malicious documents and utilizing DNS for command and control. Key TTPs include persistence through Office application startup mechanisms and targeting of vulnerabilities like CVE-2012-1889. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets the telecommunications and defense industries, with a specific focus on Israel. Its motivation is assessed as cyber espionage aligned with Iranian state interests.[/profile]
12.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, likely an Iranian state-sponsored group such as APT34 (OilRig), is also known as Helix Kitten or Cobalt Gypsy. It employs custom tools like a 'javascript analysis script' for multi-stage payload delivery and leverages infrastructure such as 'Playboy Club'. Key TTPs include abusing scheduled tasks for persistence and exploiting vulnerabilities like CVE-2021-26858. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets Israeli high-tech development companies, indicating a focus on cyber espionage in the Middle East, with motivations aligned with Iranian national interests.

13.name: RC4
13.profile: [profile]RC4 is a symmetric encryption algorithm referenced in MITRE ATT&CK techniques T1573.001 (Encrypted Channel: Symmetric Cryptography) under the Command and Control tactic, and T1048.001 (Exfiltration Over Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol) under the Exfiltration tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It is used by adversaries to manually encrypt command and control traffic or exfiltrated data, often layered over other protocols like HTTP or HTTPS, to conceal malicious communications. Groups such as APT28, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater have employed this method. The algorithm uses a single shared key for both encryption and decryption, and while common, its implementation in malware can sometimes be custom or flawed.
13.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RC4 is a symmetric encryption algorithm referenced in MITRE ATT&CK techniques for encrypting command and control traffic (T1573.001) and exfiltrated data (T1048.001). It functions by using a single shared key for both encryption and decryption. Adversaries may manually implement RC4 to add an encryption layer to network protocols, potentially creating multiple encryption layers even over already-encrypted channels like HTTPS.

14.name: QUIETCANARY
14.profile: [profile]QUIETCANARY, also known as quietcanary, is a .NET backdoor attributed to the Turla intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include handling encrypted commands from a hard-coded C2 server using RC4 encryption and Base64 encoding over HTTPS, and it lacks a built-in persistence mechanism, relying on external tools. The malware is known for the "Kapushka" artifact in its PDB path and uses a custom parsing routine for C2 commands.
14.profile_without_enhance: [profile]QUIETCANARY, also known as Tunnus and TunnusSched, is a malware attributed to the Turla group. It is a .NET backdoor that communicates with a hardcoded command and control server using RC4-encrypted and Base64-encoded HTTPS traffic, and it parses commands via a custom routine. The malware lacks a built-in persistence mechanism and often contains the artifact "Kapushka" in its PDB path. It targets Windows platforms and shares technical behaviors and infrastructure use, such as compromised WordPress sites, with related malware like KopiLuwak and Topinambour.[/profile]

15.name: Tunnus
15.profile: [profile]Tunnus is a malware associated with the Turla group, found on machines infected with KopiLuwak. It shares TTPs like the use of compromised WordPress sites and an identical RC4 implementation with the related malware families TunnusSched (also known as QUIETCANARY) and Topinambour. It also shares a PDB path with TunnusSched.[/profile]
15.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Tunnus, also known as TunnusSched and QUIETCANARY, is a malware attributed to the Turla intrusion set. It shares a PDB path and a specific RC4 encryption implementation with the related malware families TunnusSched (QUIETCANARY) and Topinambour. Key technical behaviors include using compromised WordPress sites for command and control (C2) infrastructure and employing RC4 for encrypted communications. It is found on machines infected with the KopiLuwak malware, indicating its target platform is Windows systems.[/profile]

16.name: DownloadCommand
16.profile: [profile]DownloadCommand is a technique for transferring files into a compromised environment, aligning with the Command and Control tactic. It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Technical mechanics involve using native utilities like `copy`, `certutil`, and PowerShell commands such as `IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString()` on Windows, and tools like `curl`, `scp`, `sftp`, and `wget` on Unix-based systems, including ESXi. Adversaries may also abuse package managers like `yum` or `winget` and cloud syncing services such as Dropbox for tool transfer. This technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including APT29, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.
16.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DownloadCommand is a technique within the broader MITRE ATT&CK framework, specifically aligning with the standard technique Ingress Tool Transfer (T1105) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. The technical mechanics involve adversaries using command-line utilities to download files into a compromised environment; common examples on Windows include PowerShell commands like `IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString()` and `Invoke-WebRequest`, or tools like `certutil`, while Linux/macOS adversaries often use `curl`, `wget`, `scp`, or `ftp`. This activity is frequently associated with numerous threat groups, including APT29, Lazarus Group, and FIN7.

17.name: UploadCommand
17.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may upload tools to third-party or adversary controlled infrastructure to make it accessible during targeting. Tools can be open or closed source, free or commercial. Tools can be used for malicious purposes by an adversary, but (unlike malware) were not intended to be used for those purposes (ex: [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029)). Adversaries may upload tools to support their operations, such as making a tool available to a victim network to enable [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105) by placing it on an Internet accessible web server.

Tools may be placed on infrastructure that was previously purchased/rented by the adversary ([Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583)) or was otherwise compromised by them ([Compromise Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584)).(Citation: Dell TG-3390) Tools can also be staged on web services, such as an adversary controlled GitHub repo, or on Platform-as-a-Service offerings that enable users to easily provision applications.(Citation: Dragos Heroku Watering Hole)(Citation: Malwarebytes Heroku Skimmers)(Citation: Intezer App Service Phishing)

Adversaries can avoid the need to upload a tool by having compromised victim machines download the tool directly from a third-party hosting location (ex: a non-adversary controlled GitHub repo), including the original hosting site of the tool.
17.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Upload Tool (T1608.002) under the tactic Resource Development. It involves adversaries placing legitimate or dual-use tools on third-party or adversary-controlled infrastructure, such as purchased/rented servers, compromised web servers, adversary-controlled GitHub repositories, or Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) applications like Heroku, to make them accessible for operations like Ingress Tool Transfer. This activity has been associated with threat groups like threat group-3390 and Medusa Group.
17.profile_without_enhance: [profile]UploadCommand is a technique for moving data or tools, often as part of Ingress Tool Transfer (T1105). Its technical mechanics involve placing files onto a remote system or accessible infrastructure, such as an adversary-controlled web server or cloud storage, to enable subsequent download and execution. This action supports broader adversary objectives like establishing persistence or enabling lateral movement. The technique is employed by groups including Threat Group-3390 and Medusa Group.

18.name: Base64
18.profile: [profile]Base64 is a specific implementation of the MITRE ATT&CK technique Data Encoding (T1132.001), categorized under the Command and Control tactic. It is a standard binary-to-text encoding scheme used by adversaries to obfuscate the content of command and control traffic, making it more difficult to detect. This technique is commonly employed by threat actors such as MuddyWater, Lazarus Group, and APT33 to encode C2 communications within protocol specifications. It can also be used in conjunction with other encoding or compression methods like MIME or gzip.[/profile]
18.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Base64 is a standard data encoding technique (T1132.001) used by adversaries to obfuscate command and control (C2) traffic, making it more difficult to detect. It functions as a binary-to-text encoding scheme that adheres to existing protocol specifications, converting binary data into a radix-64 representation. This technique is employed by groups like Lazarus, APT33, and MuddyWater to encode C2 information within standard network protocols.

19.name: TimeoutCommand
19.profile: [profile]TimeoutCommand is a technique adversaries use to evade detection by executing commands that ignore process interrupt signals, such as using `nohup` or PowerShell's `-ErrorAction SilentlyContinue` flag. This allows malicious processes to continue running despite events like user logoffs or terminated C2 connections, preventing defensive tools from halting execution. Unlike persistence mechanisms, this technique does not re-invoke the process after termination but focuses on maintaining immediate operational continuity.
19.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TimeoutCommand is an attack pattern where adversaries use commands like `sleep`, `ping`, or API hammering to introduce delays in malware execution. This technique, often associated with groups like Mustang Panda, aims to evade automated analysis environments by exceeding their time thresholds and blending malicious activity with benign system operations.

20.name: KillCommand
20.profile: [profile]KillCommand is a technique used by adversaries to disable security tools, such as by killing security software or event logging processes, to avoid detection of their malicious activities. This action aligns with the Defense Evasion tactic. The technique is referenced by the MITRE ATT&CK ID T1089 and is applicable across various platforms. It is associated with intrusion sets like Unknown_Threat_Actor.
20.profile_without_enhance: [profile]KillCommand is an attack pattern where adversaries terminate security software or event logging processes to disable security tools and avoid detection. This technique, which aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Defense Evasion, directly interferes with security scanning and event reporting mechanisms on affected systems.

21.name: HTTPS
21.profile: [profile]HTTPS is a sub-technique of Application Layer Protocol (T1071.001) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries abuse the HTTPS protocol to conceal malicious communications within normal web traffic, embedding commands and data within the various fields and headers of HTTP/S packets to avoid detection and network filtering by mimicking expected traffic. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and Turla.
21.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'HTTPS' is a sub-technique of Application Layer Protocol (T1071.001) within the Command and Control tactic. It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries abuse the HTTPS protocol to conceal malicious communications within normal web traffic, embedding commands and data within the various fields and headers of HTTP/S packets to blend in and avoid detection. This technique is commonly used by numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.

22.name: ClearCommand
22.profile: [profile]The entity "ClearCommand" is a technique aligned with MITRE ATT&CK ID T1070.003 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Linux, macOS, Windows, and network device platforms. It involves adversaries clearing command history logs to conceal their activities, such as using commands like `history -c` or `rm ~/.bash_history` on Linux/macOS, deleting the `ConsoleHost_history.txt` file on Windows PowerShell, or executing `clear history` on network devices via CLI. This action is commonly employed by threat actors including APT41, Lazarus Group, and TeamTNT to remove forensic evidence of executed commands.
22.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "ClearCommand" is a technique adversaries use to conceal their actions by clearing command history logs. On Linux and macOS, this involves clearing the history via commands like `history -c` or deleting the bash history file `~/.bash_history`. On Windows, adversaries may use PowerShell commands like `Clear-History` to flush session history or delete the `ConsoleHost_history.txt` file. Network devices may have their command history cleared using CLI commands such as `clear logging` or `clear history`. This technique is associated with groups like APT41, Lazarus Group, and Medusa Group.

23.name: ExeCommand
23.profile: [profile]ExeCommand is a technique where adversaries trick users into copying and pasting malicious commands for execution, often bypassing security filters. This aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique User Execution: Malicious File (T1204.004) under the Execution tactic. The method, known as "ClickFix," involves presenting fake error messages or CAPTCHA prompts on malicious websites or in phishing emails, instructing victims to paste obfuscated commands into a terminal or Run Dialog to establish an initial foothold.
23.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ExeCommand is a technique where adversaries trick users into copying and pasting malicious commands, often through social engineering like fake error messages or CAPTCHA prompts in a strategy known as "ClickFix." This method, which can bypass email filtering and browser sandboxes, typically involves obfuscated commands that, when executed in a command interpreter, establish an initial foothold on the victim's machine.

26.name: JavaScript
26.profile: [profile]JavaScript is a malware agent used by the Turla intrusion set and is associated with the IcedCoffee malware. It is also utilized by the EvilNum group as a core agent in versions 3.5, 3.6, and 4.0, and is referenced in the infrastructure of the Gootloader malware, attributed to Storm-0249, where it serves as initial and secondary payload files. The malware is delivered via JavaScript (JS) files and AutoIT-based stealers, targeting systems through malicious scripts for data exfiltration and further payload deployment.[/profile]
26.profile_without_enhance: [profile]JavaScript is a malware entity that functions as an agent, with documented versions including 4.0, 3.6, and 3.5. It is utilized as a component by other malware families such as IcedCoffee, attributed to the Turla group, for initial infection and execution. It is also referenced in the context of tools like Gootloader, associated with Storm-0249, where it serves as an initial or secondary payload file.

27.name: IcedCoffee
27.profile: [profile]IcedCoffee, also known as kopiluwak, cobra carbon system, and gazer, is attributed to the Turla group. It leverages malicious macros and JavaScript for initial infection and payload delivery. The malware targets Windows platforms and is associated with espionage activities, utilizing custom command and control infrastructure for data exfiltration and remote access.
27.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is named IcedCoffee. It is attributed to the Turla intrusion set and is associated with other malware like Wipbot. Key technical behaviors include being used as a JavaScript variant by Turla and acting as a downloader or loader component within multi-stage infection chains, often delivered via malicious Office macros. It primarily targets platforms like Microsoft Office documents for initial infection.[/profile]

28.name: malicious macro
28.profile: [profile]Malicious Macro is a technique used by malware families like Wipbot and IcedCoffee, and is associated with the intrusion set Turla. It is employed by groups such as OilRig, Gold Cabin, and Lunar Spider. The technique involves embedding malicious code within Office documents, such as Word files, which deobfuscates and executes upon user-enabled macro execution to distribute payloads like Emotet. Its primary target platform is Microsoft Office environments.
28.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious macro is a technique used for initial infection and execution, often delivered via documents like "National Day Reception (Dina Mersine Bosio Ambassador's Secretary).doc". It is employed by groups such as Turla (in tools like Wipbot and IcedCoffee), OilRig, Gold Cabin, and Lunar Spider. Key technical behaviors include deobfuscating macro code by removing character arrays to execute payloads, distributing malware like Emotet, and utilizing defense evasion techniques like marker strings (RTLO character) and XOR routines for custom encryption. Target platforms primarily include Windows via Microsoft Office applications.

29.name: XOR routine
29.profile: [profile]XOR routine is a custom cryptographic protocol (T1024) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It functions by using the XOR operation with a fixed key to obfuscate command and control traffic, producing a weak ciphertext that can be discovered through malware analysis. This technique is associated with the Turla intrusion set and can be used to archive data via custom methods, as referenced in activities by groups like Lazarus and UNC3886.[/profile]
29.profile_without_enhance: [profile]XOR routine is a custom encryption technique used by adversaries to obfuscate data or command and control traffic. It is referenced in MITRE ATT&CK sub-technique T1560.003 (Archive via Custom Method) under the Exfiltration tactic, and in technique T1024 (Custom Cryptographic Protocol) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. The method involves applying an XOR operation to plaintext with a fixed key, producing a weak ciphertext that can be implemented without external libraries. This approach is employed by groups like FIN6, Lazarus Group, and UNC3886 to hinder detection and analysis.

30.name: marker string
30.profile: [profile]Marker String is a technique used to evade detection by embedding specific strings within files or code to signal malicious activity only under certain conditions, often linked to malware like malicious macros. It operates within the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily on Windows platforms, by using benign-looking markers that trigger harmful actions when interpreted by the malware, allowing it to bypass security scans and appear legitimate until activated.
30.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "marker string" is a technique for defense evasion, specifically T1036.002 "Right-to-left Override" in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS. It involves abusing the non-printing Unicode right-to-left override (RTLO) character (U+202E) to reverse the display order of subsequent characters, disguising malicious file names like making "March 25 \u202Excod.scr" appear as "March 25 rcs.docx" to trick users into executing them. This technique is commonly used in spearphishing and malicious file attacks and has been employed by groups including Ferocious Kitten, Ke3chang, and BlackTech.
