31.profile: [profile]Wipbot, also known as WorldCupSec, TadjMakhal, or Tavdig, is a backdoor malware attributed to the Turla group. It was used as the primary backdoor in the Epic attacks, which involved exploits against older patched vulnerabilities, social engineering, and watering hole strategies. Its technical behaviors include acting as a backdoor for targeted attacks. The target platform is not specified in the provided data. Infrastructure or supplementary information is not detailed beyond its use in specific campaigns.
31.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity is named Wipbot, also known as WorldCupSec, TadjMakhal, and Tavdig. It is attributed to the intrusion set Turla. Key technical behaviors include acting as a primary backdoor used in attacks, often distributed via malicious Office macros that deobfuscate code to execute payloads. It primarily targets platforms like Microsoft Office documents for initial infection.[/profile]

32.name: National Day Reception (Dina Mersine Bosio Ambassador's Secretary).doc

33.name: LunarWeb
33.uncertain_mes: [LunarWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1141) is a backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2020 including in a compromise of a European ministry of foreign affairs (MFA) together with [LunarLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1143) and [LunarMail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1142). [LunarWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1141) has only been observed deployed against servers and can use [Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1001/002) to obfuscate command and control.(Citation: ESET Turla Lunar toolset May 2024)
33.profile: [profile]LunarWeb is a backdoor attributed to the Turla group, used since at least 2020. It has been observed in compromises such as a European ministry of foreign affairs, often deployed alongside LunarLoader and LunarMail. Its key technical behaviors include exclusive deployment against servers and the use of steganography to obfuscate command and control communications.
33.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LunarWeb, also known as lunarweb, is a backdoor attributed to the Turla group and used since at least 2020, including in a compromise of a European ministry of foreign affairs. Its key technical behaviors include using HTTP(S) for C&C communication, employing steganography to obfuscate C2, and utilizing Zlib-Compression, AES-256, and RSA-4096 for data handling and encryption. It is also associated with Lua Script Execution and uses tools like Systeminfo.exe and WMI Queries for discovery. It has only been observed deployed against servers.

34.name: LunarMail
34.uncertain_mes: [LunarMail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1142) is a backdoor that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2020 including in a compromise of a European ministry of foreign affairs (MFA) in conjunction with [LunarLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1143) and [LunarWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1141). [LunarMail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1142) is designed to be deployed on workstations and can use email messages and [Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1001/002) in command and control.(Citation: ESET Turla Lunar toolset May 2024)
34.profile: [profile]LunarMail is a backdoor attributed to the Turla APT group, used since at least 2020. It is designed for deployment on workstations and operates in conjunction with other tools like LunarLoader and LunarWeb. Its key technical behaviors include using email messages for command and control and employing steganography for communication. It has been observed in compromises targeting entities such as a European ministry of foreign affairs.[/profile]
34.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LunarMail, also known as lunarmail, is a backdoor attributed to the Turla group, used since at least 2020. It is designed for deployment on workstations and employs email messages and steganography for command and control, as seen in compromises like that of a European ministry of foreign affairs, often alongside LunarLoader and LunarWeb. Its infrastructure indicators include PNG, PDF, and the year 2020.[/profile]

37.name: Steganography
37.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may use steganography techniques in order to prevent the detection of hidden information. Steganographic techniques can be used to hide data in digital media such as images, audio tracks, video clips, or text files. [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) was an early example of malware that used steganography. It encrypted the gathered information from a victim's system and hid it within an image before exfiltrating the image to a C2 server.(Citation: Wikipedia Duqu) By the end of 2017, a threat group usedâ€¯Invoke-PSImageâ€¯to hide [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) commands in an image file (.png) and execute the code on a victim's system. In this particular case the [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) code downloaded another obfuscated script to gather intelligence from the victim's machine and communicate it back to the adversary.(Citation: McAfee Malicious Doc Targets Pyeongchang Olympics)
37.profile: [profile]Steganography is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1027.003, a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves hiding data within digital media like images, audio, video, or text files to prevent detection. Specific examples include the Duqu malware hiding encrypted stolen data in images for exfiltration and threat actors using tools like Invoke-PSImage to conceal and execute PowerShell commands from within a PNG file. It is also referenced in command and control obfuscation (T1001.002). Groups such as Earth Lusca, APT37, and Turla have been associated with its use.[/profile]
37.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Steganography is a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027.003) within the Defense Evasion tactic. It operates by hiding data within digital media such as images, audio, video, or text files to prevent detection. A specific technical example is the use of the Invoke-PSImage tool to conceal PowerShell commands within a PNG image file for execution. This method has been employed by malware like Duqu for data exfiltration and by threat groups for command and control, making network traffic and malicious files less conspicuous.

38.name: Spearphishing Email
38.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send spearphishing messages via third-party services in an attempt to gain access to victim systems. Spearphishing via service is a specific variant of spearphishing. It is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of third party services rather than directly via enterprise email channels. 

All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries send messages through various social media services, personal webmail, and other non-enterprise controlled services.(Citation: Lookout Dark Caracal Jan 2018) These services are more likely to have a less-strict security policy than an enterprise. As with most kinds of spearphishing, the goal is to generate rapport with the target or get the target's interest in some way. Adversaries will create fake social media accounts and message employees for potential job opportunities. Doing so allows a plausible reason for asking about services, policies, and software that's running in an environment. The adversary can then send malicious links or attachments through these services.

A common example is to build rapport with a target via social media, then send content to a personal webmail service that the target uses on their work computer. This allows an adversary to bypass some email restrictions on the work account, and the target is more likely to open the file since it's something they were expecting. If the payload doesn't work as expected, the adversary can continue normal communications and troubleshoot with the target on how to get it working.
38.profile: [profile]Spearphishing via Service, identified as T1566.003 under the Initial Access tactic, targets multiple platforms. This technique involves sending targeted phishing messages through third-party services like social media or personal webmail instead of direct enterprise email to bypass organizational security controls. Adversaries build rapport with targets using fake accounts, often under pretexts like job opportunities, before delivering malicious links or attachments via these less-secure channels, exploiting the target's trust and expectation to increase success rates.[/profile]
38.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spearphishing Email is a technique (T1566) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting Windows, macOS, and Linux. It involves sending tailored, deceptive emails to specific individuals or organizations to deliver malicious content, such as attachments (like Office documents or executables) or embedded links. The email employs social engineering to lure the recipient into opening the attachment or clicking the link, often requiring user execution to compromise the system, and may include instructions to bypass security controls.

39.name: AES-256
39.profile: [profile]AES-256 is a specific implementation of the symmetric cryptography technique (T1573.001) under the Command and Control tactic. It is a standard symmetric encryption algorithm that uses a single 256-bit key for both encryption and decryption of data. Adversaries employ it to manually encrypt network traffic, such as for data exfiltration over non-C2 protocols (T1048.001) or to create multiple layers of encryption (T1079) for obfuscation, often implemented within protocols like HTTP or HTTPS. It is commonly used by threat actors including MuddyWater, APT28, and Lazarus Group.
39.profile_without_enhance: [profile]AES-256 is a symmetric encryption algorithm, not a MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is a specific implementation of the standard AES cipher. Adversaries use it to conceal data in transit, such as for command and control traffic (as seen in T1573.001) or for data exfiltration over non-C2 protocols (as in T1048.001). It can also be layered with other encryption in multilayer encryption schemes (T1079) to create multiple obfuscation layers.

40.name: VBA Macro
40.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may hide malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) payloads embedded within MS Office documents by replacing the VBA source code with benign data.(Citation: FireEye VBA stomp Feb 2020) MS Office documents with embedded VBA content store source code inside of module streams. Each module stream has a PerformanceCache that stores a separate compiled version of the VBA source code known as p-code. The p-code is executed when the MS Office version specified in the _VBA_PROJECT stream (which contains the version-dependent description of the VBA project) matches the version of the host MS Office application.(Citation: Evil Clippy May 2019)(Citation: Microsoft _VBA_PROJECT Stream) An adversary may hide malicious VBA code by overwriting the VBA source code location with zeroâ€™s, benign code, or random bytes while leaving the previously compiled malicious p-code. Tools that scan for malicious VBA source code may be bypassed as the unwanted code is hidden in the compiled p-code. If the VBA source code is removed, some tools might even think that there are no macros present. If there is a version match between the _VBA_PROJECT stream and host MS Office application, the p-code will be executed, otherwise the benign VBA source code will be decompressed and recompiled to p-code, thus removing malicious p-code and potentially bypassing dynamic analysis.(Citation: Walmart Roberts Oct 2018)(Citation: FireEye VBA stomp Feb 2020)(Citation: pcodedmp Bontchev)
40.profile: [profile]VBA Stomping, identified as T1564.007 under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows platforms, is a technique where adversaries hide malicious VBA macros in Office documents by overwriting the readable source code with benign or null data while preserving the malicious compiled p-code in the PerformanceCache. This mismatch between source and p-code bypasses static analysis tools scanning for source code; the malicious p-code executes only if the host Office version matches the version specified in the document's _VBA_PROJECT stream, otherwise the benign source is recompiled, potentially evading dynamic analysis.
40.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VBA Macro is a technique (T1059.005) under Execution, primarily targeting Windows. It involves embedding Visual Basic for Applications code within Microsoft Office documents to automate malicious tasks. Adversaries use VBA macros in spearphishing attachments to execute commands, often employing evasion methods like VBA stomping to hide malicious p-code. Macros can also be inserted into Office templates for persistence.

41.name: RSA-4096
41.profile: [profile]RSA-4096 is a specific implementation of the Asymmetric Cryptography technique (T1573.002) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across multiple platforms, including Windows, Linux, and macOS. This technique uses the RSA public-key algorithm with a 4096-bit key to encrypt C2 traffic, ensuring only the intended recipient with the private key can decrypt it. It is employed by malware like LunarWeb for secure communication channels.
41.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RSA-4096 is a specific implementation of the Asymmetric Cryptography technique (T1573.002), used for Command and Control. It operates across multiple platforms. The technique uses a public/private keypair, where data encrypted with a recipient's public key can only be decrypted with their corresponding private key, ensuring confidentiality for C2 traffic or data exfiltration. It is commonly employed by groups like FIN6, APT28, and OilRig.

42.name: Zlib-Compression
42.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use compression to obfuscate their payloads or files. Compressed file formats such as ZIP, gzip, 7z, and RAR can compress and archive multiple files together to make it easier and faster to transfer files. In addition to compressing files, adversaries may also compress shellcode directly - for example, in order to store it in a Windows Registry key (i.e., [Fileless Storage](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/011)).(Citation: Trustwave Pillowmint June 2020)

In order to further evade detection, adversaries may combine multiple ZIP files into one archive. This process of concatenation creates an archive that appears to be a single archive but in fact contains the central directories of the embedded archives. Some ZIP readers, such as 7zip, may not be able to identify concatenated ZIP files and miss the presence of the malicious payload.(Citation: Perception Point)

File archives may be sent as one [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001) through email. Adversaries have sent malicious payloads as archived files to encourage the user to interact with and extract the malicious payload onto their system (i.e., [Malicious File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002)).(Citation: NTT Security Flagpro new December 2021) However, some file compression tools, such as 7zip, can be used to produce self-extracting archives. Adversaries may send self-extracting archives to hide the functionality of their payload and launch it without requiring multiple actions from the user.(Citation: The Hacker News)

[Compression](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/015) may be used in combination with [Encrypted/Encoded File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/013) where compressed files are encrypted and password-protected.
42.profile: [profile]Compression, identified as T1027.015 under the Defense Evasion tactic, is a technique adversaries use to obfuscate payloads and files on Windows, Linux, and macOS systems. It involves using formats like ZIP, gzip, 7z, and RAR to compress files or shellcode, sometimes storing it in the Windows Registry. To further evade detection, adversaries may create concatenated ZIP archives that appear as single files or distribute self-extracting archives via spearphishing. This technique is often combined with encryption and has been associated with groups like Gamaredon Group and TA2541.
42.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Zlib-Compression" is a specific implementation of the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1027.015 (Compression) under the Defense Evasion tactic. It operates across multiple platforms and involves using the zlib library to compress payloads, shellcode, or collected data, making them smaller and harder to detect. This technique is often employed for fileless storage, to facilitate data exfiltration, or to obfuscate malicious archives, and is associated with threat groups like Lazarus Group and Threat Group-3390.

43.name: WMI Queries
43.profile: [profile]WMI Queries is a technique used for Discovery (TA0007) on Windows platforms, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1047. It involves adversaries abusing Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to gather system information. The primary mechanism is using tools like `wmic.exe` or PowerShell to execute queries against the WMI infrastructure, which can retrieve data on processes, hardware, software, and other system components. This activity is often conducted locally or remotely via services like DCOM or WinRM. The technique is associated with malware like LunarWeb and numerous threat groups, including APT29 and MuddyWater.
43.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "WMI Queries" is a technique for Discovery (TA0007) on Windows platforms, identified as T1047. It involves adversaries using Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to query local or remote systems for information. This is executed via tools like `wmic.exe` or PowerShell to gather system data, and can be facilitated over network ports 135 (DCOM) or 5985/5986 (WinRM). The technique is commonly used by groups like APT29 and MuddyWater for reconnaissance.

44.name: Systeminfo.exe
44.profile: [profile]Systeminfo.exe is a legitimate Windows command-line tool used by adversaries for System Information Discovery (T1082) under the Discovery tactic on Windows platforms. It is employed to gather detailed OS and hardware data, including version, patches, and architecture, which informs follow-on attack decisions. The tool has been associated with malware like LunarWeb and various threat groups.
44.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Systeminfo.exe is a legitimate Windows command-line tool that adversaries abuse for System Information Discovery (T1082). It is used to gather detailed OS and hardware data, including version, patches, architecture, and hotfixes, which helps shape follow-on attack behaviors. This technique falls under the Discovery tactic and operates on the Windows platform.

45.name: Fileless Persistence
45.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may store data in "fileless" formats to conceal malicious activity from defenses. Fileless storage can be broadly defined as any format other than a file. Common examples of non-volatile fileless storage in Windows systems include the Windows Registry, event logs, or WMI repository.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)(Citation: SecureList Fileless) Shared memory directories on Linux systems (`/dev/shm`, `/run/shm`, `/var/run`, and `/var/lock`) and volatile directories on Network Devices (`/tmp` and `/volatile`) may also be considered fileless storage, as files written to these directories are mapped directly to RAM and not stored on the disk.(Citation: Elastic Binary Executed from Shared Memory Directory)(Citation: Akami Frog4Shell 2024)(Citation: Aquasec Muhstik Malware 2024)(Citation: Bitsight 7777 Botnet)(Citation: CISCO Nexus 900 Config).

Similar to fileless in-memory behaviors such as [Reflective Code Loading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1620) and [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055), fileless data storage may remain undetected by anti-virus and other endpoint security tools that can only access specific file formats from disk storage. Leveraging fileless storage may also allow adversaries to bypass the protections offered by read-only file systems in Linux.(Citation: Sysdig Fileless Malware 23022)

Adversaries may use fileless storage to conceal various types of stored data, including payloads/shellcode (potentially being used as part of [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003)) and collected data not yet exfiltrated from the victim (e.g., [Local Data Staging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1074/001)). Adversaries also often encrypt, encode, splice, or otherwise obfuscate this fileless data when stored. 

Some forms of fileless storage activity may indirectly create artifacts in the file system, but in central and otherwise difficult to inspect formats such as the WMI (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Wbem\Repository`) or Registry (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Config`) physical files.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)
45.profile: [profile]Fileless Persistence, also known as fileless storage (T1027.011), is a Defense Evasion technique used on Windows, Linux, and Network Device platforms. It involves storing data in non-file formats like the Windows Registry, WMI repository, or Linux shared memory directories (e.g., `/dev/shm`) to avoid detection by disk-based security tools. This method can conceal payloads for Persistence or staged data, often with additional obfuscation, and may bypass read-only file system protections.[/profile]
45.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Fileless Persistence is a technique within the Persistence tactic (TA0003) used on Windows, Linux, and Network Device platforms. It involves storing malicious code or configuration data in non-file system locations to evade detection. Common methods include embedding payloads within the Windows Registry, WMI repository, or event logs, and using Linux shared memory directories like `/dev/shm` where data is mapped directly to RAM. This approach bypasses traditional file-based security tools and can circumvent protections on read-only file systems.

46.name: Lateral Movement
46.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may transfer tools or other files between systems in a compromised environment. Once brought into the victim environment (i.e., [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) files may then be copied from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation.

Adversaries may copy files between internal victim systems to support lateral movement using inherent file sharing protocols such as file sharing over [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002) to connected network shares or with authenticated connections via [Remote Desktop Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/001).(Citation: Unit42 LockerGoga 2019)

Files can also be transferred using native or otherwise present tools on the victim system, such as scp, rsync, curl, sftp, and [ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095). In some cases, adversaries may be able to leverage [Web Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102)s such as Dropbox or OneDrive to copy files from one machine to another via shared, automatically synced folders.(Citation: Dropbox Malware Sync)
46.profile: [profile]Lateral Tool Transfer, identified as T1570, is a Lateral Movement technique used across multiple platforms. It involves transferring tools or files between compromised systems using inherent file sharing protocols like SMB/Windows Admin Shares or authenticated Remote Desktop Protocol connections. Adversaries also leverage native tools such as scp, rsync, curl, sftp, and FTP, or abuse web services like Dropbox and OneDrive via automatically synced folders to stage tools for further operations.
46.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Lateral Movement is a high-level tactic (TA0008) within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, representing the adversary's actions to move through a network after initial access. It is not a specific technique with a T-ID but an overarching category. The tactic involves using various techniques to access and control remote systems, such as transferring tools between systems via file sharing protocols like SMB or RDP (as seen in Lateral Tool Transfer, T1570), or by abusing local account credentials obtained through methods like OS Credential Dumping to pivot across the network.

47.name: Remote Registry Service
47.uncertain_mes: Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services. The information stored under a service's Registry keys can be manipulated to modify a service's execution parameters through tools such as the service controller, sc.exe, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086), or [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075). Access to Registry keys is controlled through Access Control Lists and permissions. (Citation: MSDN Registry Key Security) If the permissions for users and groups are not properly set and allow access to the Registry keys for a service, then adversaries can change the service binPath/ImagePath to point to a different executable under their control. When the service starts or is restarted, then the adversary-controlled program will execute, allowing the adversary to gain persistence and/or privilege escalation to the account context the service is set to execute under (local/domain account, SYSTEM, LocalService, or NetworkService). Adversaries may also alter Registry keys associated with service failure parameters (such as FailureCommand) that may be executed in an elevated context anytime the service fails or is intentionally corrupted.(Citation: TrustedSignal Service Failure)(Citation: Twitter Service Recovery Nov 2017)
47.profile: [profile]Service Registry Permissions Weakness, identified as T1058 under the Persistence and Privilege Escalation tactics, targets Windows. It exploits weak ACLs on service Registry keys under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services. Adversaries can modify the binPath/ImagePath to point to a malicious executable, which executes upon service start/restart, granting persistence and privilege escalation to the service account context (e.g., SYSTEM). They may also alter keys like FailureCommand to run code when a service fails.
47.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Remote Registry Service" is a Windows service that enables remote management of the Registry on other systems. It operates under the Tactic of Lateral Movement (TA0008) and the Platform Windows. Adversaries use this service, often in conjunction with tools like Reg.exe and access to SMB/Windows Admin Shares, to modify the Registry of a remote computer, which requires the service to be running on the target and typically Valid Accounts for authentication. This allows for remote execution, persistence, and defense evasion by altering system configuration.

49.name: Group Policy Extension
49.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may gather information on Group Policy settings to identify paths for privilege escalation, security measures applied within a domain, and to discover patterns in domain objects that can be manipulated or used to blend in the environment. Group Policy allows for centralized management of user and computer settings in Active Directory (AD). Group policy objects (GPOs) are containers for group policy settings made up of files stored within a predictable network path `\\SYSVOL\\Policies\`.(Citation: TechNet Group Policy Basics)(Citation: ADSecurity GPO Persistence 2016) Adversaries may use commands such as gpresult or various publicly available PowerShell functions, such as Get-DomainGPO and Get-DomainGPOLocalGroup, to gather information on Group Policy settings.(Citation: Microsoft gpresult)(Citation: Github PowerShell Empire) Adversaries may use this information to shape follow-on behaviors, including determining potential attack paths within the target network as well as opportunities to manipulate Group Policy settings (i.e. [Domain or Tenant Policy Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1484)) for their benefit.
49.profile: [profile]Group Policy Discovery, identified as T1615, is a Discovery tactic technique used on Windows platforms. It involves adversaries gathering information on Group Policy settings to identify privilege escalation paths and security measures within an Active Directory domain. Technical execution typically uses commands like `gpresult` or PowerShell functions such as `Get-DomainGPO` to query Group Policy Objects (GPOs) stored in the predictable network path `\\<DOMAIN>\SYSVOL\<DOMAIN>\Policies\`. The gathered intelligence shapes follow-on attacks, including potential policy modification. The threat actor Turla has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
49.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Group Policy Extension is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it likely refers to the mechanism for implementing settings via Group Policy Objects (GPOs) in Active Directory. GPOs are stored in the predictable SYSVOL network path (\\<DOMAIN>\SYSVOL\<DOMAIN>\Policies\). Adversaries may abuse this extension mechanism to modify GPO files, such as ScheduledTasks.xml or GptTmpl.inf, to deploy malicious configurations like scheduled tasks or alter user rights, enabling persistence and privilege escalation within a domain.[/profile]

64.name: HTTP(S) C&C Communication
64.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
64.profile: [profile]HTTP(S) C&C Communication, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1102.002 under the Command and Control tactic, operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries using legitimate external web services like social media platforms (e.g., Twitter) or cloud services (e.g., Google Docs) to host command instructions and receive output from compromised systems. This bidirectional communication leverages SSL/TLS encryption for stealth, with return traffic manifesting as forum comments, pull requests, or document updates. Groups such as Turla and malware like LunarWeb are associated with this technique, which exploits common, expected web traffic to evade detection.
64.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTP(S) C&C Communication is a sub-technique of Application Layer Protocol (T1071.001) within the Command and Control tactic. It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries use standard HTTP or HTTPS traffic to conceal command and control communications, embedding commands and exfiltrated data within the headers and fields of normal web traffic to blend in and avoid detection. This method is widely used by numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.

65.name: Lua Script Execution
65.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse Lua commands and scripts for execution. Lua is a cross-platform scripting and programming language primarily designed for embedded use in applications. Lua can be executed on the command-line (through the stand-alone lua interpreter), via scripts (.lua), or from Lua-embedded programs (through the struct lua_State).(Citation: Lua main page)(Citation: Lua state) Lua scripts may be executed by adversaries for malicious purposes. Adversaries may incorporate, abuse, or replace existing Lua interpreters to allow for malicious Lua command execution at runtime.(Citation: PoetRat Lua)(Citation: Lua Proofpoint Sunseed)(Citation: Cyphort EvilBunny)(Citation: Kaspersky Lua)
65.profile: [profile]Lua Script Execution (T1059.011) is a Command and Scripting Interpreter technique under the Execution tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries abusing the cross-platform Lua language by executing malicious commands via the standalone lua interpreter, through .lua script files, or by manipulating embedded Lua interpreters within applications to run code at runtime. This technique has been associated with the Turla intrusion set and LunarWeb malware.
65.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Lua Script Execution is mapped to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.011 (Command and Scripting Interpreter: Lua) under the Execution tactic and is cross-platform. Adversaries abuse the Lua language by executing malicious commands via the standalone interpreter, running .lua script files, or embedding and manipulating code within existing Lua-enabled applications using the lua_State structure to achieve runtime execution.

66.name: Unknown_Threat_Actor
66.profile: [profile]This threat actor is currently designated as "Unknown_Threat_Actor" due to a lack of conclusive attribution. Its specific arsenal, tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), origin, target sectors, and primary motivations remain unidentified, distinguishing it from more clearly defined advanced persistent threat (APT) groups. Further intelligence collection and analysis are required to characterize its operations and potential links to known cyber espionage or criminal campaigns.]
66.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is attributed to the Turla APT group, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the sophisticated rootkit Uroburos (Snake), the second-stage implant Comrat (ComRAT), the USB-spreading worm Agent.btz, and associated droppers and log files like msvcrtd.tlb and mskfp32.ocx. Key TTPs involve persistence via COM Object Hijacking and Named Pipes for inter-process communication, alongside standard techniques for command execution, file transfer, and information gathering. The group is believed to be of Russian origin and has historically targeted government and military sectors, particularly in the West, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.[/profile]
66.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]This intrusion set, likely associated with the advanced persistent threat group APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and STRONTIUM), is a highly active cyber espionage actor. It is attributed to Russia's military intelligence service, the GRU, and primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in North America, Europe, and former Soviet states. Its operations are characterized by the use of custom malware like X-Agent and X-Tunnel, spear-phishing campaigns, and credential-harvesting techniques, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and strategic geopolitical influence.
66.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set, likely operating as APT41 or one of its subgroups, is a sophisticated Chinese state-sponsored threat actor known for dual espionage and financially motivated cyber operations. It is also known as Barium, Winnti Group, and Double Dragon. Key malware and tools associated with the group include the Winnti backdoor, ShadowPad, and the PlugX trojan. Its key TTPs involve supply chain compromises, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and the use of stolen code-signing certificates. The group is attributed to China and shows overlaps with other Chinese clusters like APT10. It primarily targets high-tech, telecommunications, and video game industries globally, with a focus on Southeast Asia and the United States. Its motivation combines state-directed intellectual property theft and cybercrime for financial gain.
66.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]This intrusion set is attributed to the Turla advanced persistent threat (APT) group, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware and tools include the sophisticated rootkit Uroburos (Snake), the Comrat backdoor, and the Agent.btz worm. Characteristic TTPs involve the use of custom log files (mskfp32.ocx, msvcrtd.tlb) with specific XOR or non-ASCII keys, persistence via COM Object Hijacking, and leveraging Named Pipes for inter-process communication. The group is believed to be of Russian origin and has historically targeted government and military sectors, particularly in Europe and the United States, with motivations aligned with espionage and intelligence gathering.[/profile]
66.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is attributed to the Turla APT group, also known as Snake, Venomous Bear, and Waterbug. It employs a sophisticated malware suite including Uroburos (Snake), Comrat, and Agent.btz, with tools like droppers and log files (e.g., mskfp32.ocx, msvcrtd.tlb) using XOR and non-ASCII keys. Key TTPs involve persistence via COM Object Hijacking, execution through Named Pipes and Browser Process Communication, and data staging via File Upload/Download. Believed to be a Russian state-sponsored actor, Turla historically targets government, military, and diplomatic sectors globally, with motivations centered on espionage and strategic intelligence collection.
66.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]The entity is attributed to the Turla APT group, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the sophisticated rootkit Uroburos (Snake), the second-stage implant Comrat (ComRAT), and the USB-spreading worm Agent.btz. Core TTPs involve using droppers for deployment, establishing persistence via COM Object Hijacking and registry modifications, and employing named pipes for stealthy inter-process communication. The group is believed to be of Russian origin. It has historically targeted government and military sectors, particularly in Europe and the United States, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.
66.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]This intrusion set is attributed to the Turla APT group, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the sophisticated rootkit Uroburos (Snake), the USB-spreading worm Agent.btz, and the second-stage implant Comrat (ComRAT). Key TTPs involve establishing persistence through mechanisms like COM Object Hijacking, using Named Pipes for inter-process communication, and employing droppers that create specific log files (e.g., mskfp32.ocx, msvcrtd.tlb) with distinct encoding keys. The group is believed to be of Russian origin and has historically targeted government and military sectors, particularly in the West, with motivations aligned with cyber espionage and intelligence gathering.[/profile]
66.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is attributed to the Turla advanced persistent threat (APT) group, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the sophisticated rootkit Uroburos, the second-stage implant Comrat (ComRAT), and the USB-spreading worm Agent.btz. Key TTPs involve using droppers to deploy payloads, establishing persistence via mechanisms like COM Object Hijacking, and employing encoded log files (e.g., mskfp32.ocx, msvcrtd.tlb) with specific XOR or non-ASCII keys for stealth. The group is believed to be of Russian origin and has historically targeted government and military sectors, particularly in the West, with motivations aligned with espionage and intelligence gathering.[/profile]
66.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]This intrusion set is highly likely the Turla APT group, also known as Snake, Krypton, and Venomous Bear. Its key custom malware includes the sophisticated rootkit Uroburos (Snake), the second-stage implant Comrat (ComRAT), and the USB-spreading worm Agent.btz, often deployed via droppers. Key TTPs involve leveraging COM Object Hijacking for persistence, using custom log files like msvcrtd.tlb, and employing dual C2 channels including HTTP and Gmail. The group is attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors and primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.[/profile]
66.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is attributed to the Turla group, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the sophisticated rootkit Uroburos (Snake), the USB-spreading worm Agent.btz, and associated droppers. Key TTPs involve establishing persistence through mechanisms like modifying system files and using encoded log files (e.g., mskfp32.ocx, msvcrtd.tlb) with specific XOR or non-ASCII keys, alongside standard techniques for file download, command execution, and information gathering. The group is believed to be a Russian state-sponsored actor, historically targeting government, military, and diplomatic sectors, primarily in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.
66.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]This intrusion set, likely a distinct APT group, employs a custom dropper malware to deploy payloads and uses command execution for system control. Its infrastructure involves XML log files, and it uses an indicator named 'Xored Key'. The group's specific identity, aliases, origin, and primary targets remain unknown based on the provided data, but its operational focus appears to be on establishing persistence and executing multi-stage infection chains on Windows systems.[/profile]
66.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is strongly attributed to the Turla APT group, also known as Venomous Bear, Waterbug, and Uroburos. Its operations are characterized by the use of the Agent.btz worm for initial compromise and persistence, alongside sophisticated, low-level firmware tampering techniques. The group is believed to be of Russian origin and has historically targeted government and military sectors, particularly within the United States, with motivations aligned with espionage and intelligence gathering.[/profile]

67.name: Uroburos
67.uncertain_mes: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
67.profile: [profile]Uroburos, also known as Snake, is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool attributed to the Turla group, associated with Russia's FSB. Written in C, it has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and is typically deployed to external-facing nodes to further exploit internal networks. It has undergone constant upgrades since 2003 to remain viable after public disclosures.[/profile]
67.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Uroburos, also known as Snake, is a sophisticated malware attributed to the Turla intrusion set. It is related to other Turla malware families including Comrat, Agent.btz, and Agent.DNE. Its technical behaviors include conditional execution to install components only if they are not already present, a technique known as Install If Not Exists, to avoid detection and ensure persistence. The malware primarily targets Windows platforms.[/profile]

68.profile: [profile]Agent.btz, also known as agent.btz, is a worm primarily attributed to the Turla group. Its key technical behavior is spreading via removable USB drives, and it notably infected U.S. military networks in 2008. The malware is related to the Uroburos malware family.
68.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Agent.btz, also known as Agent.btz, is a worm attributed to the Turla intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is spreading via removable USB drives, and it is known for reportedly infecting U.S. military networks in 2008. It is related to other Turla-associated malware like Uroburos and primarily targets Windows platforms.[/profile]

69.name: Comrat
69.uncertain_mes: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
69.profile: [profile]ComRAT is a second-stage implant used by the Turla group and is a suspected descendant of Agent.btz. Key technical behaviors include using a Virtual FAT16 File System, being deployed via existing access like the PowerStallion PowerShell backdoor, and featuring two C2 channels: HTTP (using the same protocol as ComRAT v3) and email via the Gmail web interface for command reception and data exfiltration. Its installer is a PowerShell script that creates a scheduled task and stores an encrypted payload in the Registry, with version 4 including an orchestrator component injected into explorer.exe. The malware has been in development since at least 2007 and is associated with the Uroburos malware family.
69.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Comrat, also known as ComRAT, is a second-stage implant used by the Turla intrusion set, suspected of being a descendant of Agent.btz. Its key technical behaviors include using a Virtual FAT16 File System, being deployed via methods like the PowerStallion PowerShell backdoor, and employing dual command and control channels via HTTP (using the same protocol as ComRAT v3) and the Gmail web interface for receiving commands and data exfiltration. The malware, with versions like v4 featuring an orchestrator component injected into explorer.exe, primarily targets Windows platforms and is related to other Turla-associated malware such as Uroburos.[/profile]

71.name: COM Object Hijacking
71.uncertain_name: component object model and distributed com
71.uncertain_mes:
**This technique has been deprecated. Please use [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001).**

Adversaries may use the Windows Component Object Model (COM) and Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) for local code execution or to execute on remote systems as part of lateral movement. 

COM is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019) Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE).(Citation: Microsoft COM) DCOM is transparent middleware that extends the functionality of Component Object Model (COM) (Citation: Microsoft COM) beyond a local computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)

Permissions to interact with local and remote server COM objects are specified by access control lists (ACL) in the Registry. (Citation: Microsoft COM ACL)(Citation: Microsoft Process Wide Com Keys)(Citation: Microsoft System Wide Com Keys) By default, only Administrators may remotely activate and launch COM objects through DCOM.

Adversaries may abuse COM for local command and/or payload execution. Various COM interfaces are exposed that can be abused to invoke arbitrary execution via a variety of programming languages such as C, C++, Java, and VBScript.(Citation: Microsoft COM) Specific COM objects also exists to directly perform functions beyond code execution, such as creating a [Scheduled Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053), fileless download/execution, and other adversary behaviors such as Privilege Escalation and Persistence.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)(Citation: ProjectZero File Write EoP Apr 2018)

Adversaries may use DCOM for lateral movement. Through DCOM, adversaries operating in the context of an appropriately privileged user can remotely obtain arbitrary and even direct shellcode execution through Office applications (Citation: Enigma Outlook DCOM Lateral Movement Nov 2017) as well as other Windows objects that contain insecure methods.(Citation: Enigma MMC20 COM Jan 2017)(Citation: Enigma DCOM Lateral Movement Jan 2017) DCOM can also execute macros in existing documents (Citation: Enigma Excel DCOM Sept 2017) and may also invoke [Dynamic Data Exchange](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1173) (DDE) execution directly through a COM created instance of a Microsoft Office application (Citation: Cyberreason DCOM DDE Lateral Movement Nov 2017), bypassing the need for a malicious document.
71.profile: [profile]COM Object Hijacking is a deprecated technique, superseded by T1559.001 (Component Object Model) and T1021.003 (Distributed Component Object Model). It was a Windows-specific technique for persistence and privilege escalation. The technical mechanic involves adversaries modifying Windows Registry keys to replace references to legitimate COM objects with malicious code, which is then executed when the hijacked system component is invoked, allowing for stealthy persistence without significantly disrupting normal system functionality.[/profile]
71.profile_without_enhance: [profile]COM Object Hijacking, also known as Component Object Model Hijacking (T1546.015), is a persistence technique within the Defense Evasion and Privilege Escalation tactics for Windows. It involves modifying Windows Registry keys to replace references to legitimate COM objects, causing malicious code to execute when the hijacked system component is invoked. Attackers often target frequently used but non-critical COM objects to maintain stealth, and variations may abuse Type Libraries to redirect functionality to remote scripts.

73.name: Dropper
73.uncertain_mes: [SplatDropper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1232) is a loader that utilizes native windows API to deliver its payload to the victim environment.  [SplatDropper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1232) has been delivered through RAR archives and used legitimate executable for DLL side-loading.  [SplatDropper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1232) is known to be leveraged by [Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) and was first observed utilized in 2025.
73.profile: [profile]SplatDropper, also known as Dropper, is a loader that uses native Windows API for payload delivery, distributed via RAR archives and employing DLL side-loading with legitimate executables. It is attributed to the Mustang Panda group and was first observed in 2025. Key technical behaviors include delivering payloads to the victim environment. Target platforms are Windows-based systems, with infrastructure involving the use of RAR archives for initial delivery.
73.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Dropper is a malware component used to deploy other malicious payloads. It is associated with malware families like Disttrack, Agent.BTZ (attributed to the Turla group), and Revil (linked to Pinchy Spider). Key technical behaviors include installing files into directories like %APPDATA%\Microsoft\, establishing persistence via registry keys (e.g., HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID\{...}\InprocServer32), and being executed by rundll32.exe. It targets the Windows platform and is involved in multi-stage infection chains, often delivering components such as wiper modules, secondary payloads like shdocvw.tlp, or log files like Winview.ocx.[/profile]

75.name: credprov.tlb
75.profile: [profile]Credprov.tlb is a malware component, also known as the main payload of the Agent.BTZ malware attributed to the Turla group. It is installed by a dropper into %APPDATA%\Microsoft\ and executed via rundll32.exe to deploy a secondary file, shdocvw.tlp. Its key technical behavior involves leveraging the Windows Credential Provider infrastructure for persistence and execution.[/profile]
75.profile_without_enhance: [profile]credprov.tlb is a malware payload. It is installed by the Dropper malware, which is attributed to various threat actors including Unknown_Threat_Actor, hellsing, ice fog, pirate panda, rancor, ta428, tick, tonto team, karma panda, and pinchy spider. It is also specifically delivered by the Agent.BTZ malware, which is attributed to the Turla group. Its key technical behavior involves being installed as a file in the %APPDATA%\Microsoft\ directory and subsequently executed via rundll32.exe to deploy a secondary payload, such as shdocvw.tlp. The target platform is Windows.[/profile]

77.name: shdocvw.tlp
77.profile: [profile]shdocvw.tlp is a malware component, specifically a Microsoft Windows dynamic library (DLL). It is deployed by a Dropper and is associated with the Turla group. For persistence, it creates a registry key at HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\InprocServer32 to point to its file path (%APPDATA%\shdocvw.tlp), ensuring it executes during the infected machine's boot process. Its target platform is Microsoft Windows.
77.profile_without_enhance: [profile]shdocvw.tlp is a malware component, a Microsoft Windows dynamic library (DLL). It is delivered by the Dropper malware and is associated with persistence mechanisms, specifically by creating a registry key at HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\InprocServer32 to execute from %APPDATA% during system boot. It has been observed in activity involving the agent.btz malware and is linked to the Turla group.[/profile]

78.name: Check Older Version
78.profile: [profile]Check Older Version is a technique mapped to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1562.010 under the Impair Defenses tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries downgrading or using outdated, vulnerable versions of system features, such as command interpreters like PowerShell, to bypass security controls like Script Block Logging, or downgrading network protocols like HTTPS to HTTP to enable sniffing or man-in-the-middle attacks by exploiting backward compatibility.
78.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Check Older Version is a technique used by adversaries to identify and potentially exploit outdated software or system versions. It involves scanning for older, potentially vulnerable versions of operating systems, applications, or firmware on target devices. This reconnaissance can reveal weaker security controls, such as deprecated encryption or unpatched vulnerabilities, which adversaries may then leverage for initial access or to enable follow-on attacks like system image downgrades. The technique supports tactics like discovery and is applicable across various platforms.

79.name: Remove Older Version
79.profile: [profile]The entity "Remove Older Version" is a technique where adversaries delete or replace older instances of malware or tools on a compromised system to hinder forensic analysis and evade detection. This action is often performed by malware like Dropper during deployment to clean up initial payload artifacts. The technique is related to broader defense evasion and persistence tactics, as seen in similar behaviors like relocating malware to blend in or removing specific indicators from tools after detection. It serves to obscure the attack chain and reduce the footprint of malicious activity.
79.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Remove Older Version" is a technique for evading detection by deleting or replacing outdated malware components. This action can be triggered when adversaries believe their tools have been identified by security systems, allowing them to clean up artifacts and hinder forensic analysis. It is often executed in conjunction with other evasion methods, such as relocating the malware to a new location on the victim system.

80.name: Install If Not Exists
80.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may install SSL/TLS certificates that can be used during targeting. SSL/TLS certificates are files that can be installed on servers to enable secure communications between systems. Digital certificates include information about the key, information about its owner's identity, and the digital signature of an entity that has verified the certificate's contents are correct. If the signature is valid, and the person examining the certificate trusts the signer, then they know they can use that key to communicate securely with its owner. Certificates can be uploaded to a server, then the server can be configured to use the certificate to enable encrypted communication with it.(Citation: DigiCert Install SSL Cert)

Adversaries may install SSL/TLS certificates that can be used to further their operations, such as encrypting C2 traffic (ex: [Asymmetric Cryptography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1573/002) with [Web Protocols](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/001)) or lending credibility to a credential harvesting site. Installation of digital certificates may take place for a number of server types, including web servers and email servers. 

Adversaries can obtain digital certificates (see [Digital Certificates](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588/004)) or create self-signed certificates (see [Digital Certificates](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587/003)). Digital certificates can then be installed on adversary controlled infrastructure that may have been acquired ([Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583)) or previously compromised ([Compromise Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584)).
80.profile: [profile]Install Digital Certificate, identified as T1608.003, is a Resource Development technique where adversaries install SSL/TLS certificates on servers they control. The technical mechanics involve uploading certificate files to a web or email server and configuring the server software to use them, enabling encrypted communication for operations like securing command and control traffic or adding credibility to phishing sites. Certificates can be obtained (T1588.004) or self-signed (T1587.003) before installation on acquired or compromised infrastructure. The malware Uroburos is associated with this technique.[/profile]
80.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Install If Not Exists is a technique where adversaries check for the presence of a specific component, such as a malicious library or digital certificate, and only proceed with installation if it is not already present. This conditional execution is used to avoid duplicate artifacts, reduce detection risk, and ensure persistence mechanisms are correctly established. It can be applied across platforms during the Persistence or Defense Evasion tactics, often integrated into scripts or malware deployment routines.

81.name: Command Execution
81.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse utilities that allow for command execution to bypass security restrictions that limit the use of command-line interpreters. Various Windows utilities may be used to execute commands, possibly without invoking [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106). For example, [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193), the Program Compatibility Assistant (`pcalua.exe`), components of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), `Scriptrunner.exe`, as well as other utilities may invoke the execution of programs and commands from a [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059), Run window, or via scripts.(Citation: VectorSec ForFiles Aug 2017)(Citation: Evi1cg Forfiles Nov 2017)(Citation: Secure Team - Scriptrunner.exe)(Citation: SS64)(Citation: Bleeping Computer - Scriptrunner.exe) Adversaries may also abuse the `ssh.exe` binary to execute malicious commands via the `ProxyCommand` and `LocalCommand` options, which can be invoked via the `-o` flag or by modifying the SSH config file.(Citation: Threat Actor Targets the Manufacturing industry with Lumma Stealer and Amadey Bot)

Adversaries may abuse these features for [Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0005), specifically to perform arbitrary execution while subverting detections and/or mitigation controls (such as Group Policy) that limit/prevent the usage of [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) or file extensions more commonly associated with malicious payloads.
81.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Indirect Command Execution" (ID: T1202), categorized under the Defense Evasion tactic and applicable to Windows platforms. It involves abusing legitimate utilities like Forfiles, pcalua.exe, Windows Subsystem for Linux components, and Scriptrunner.exe to execute commands without invoking the standard command-line interpreter (cmd.exe), thereby bypassing security restrictions. The SSH client (ssh.exe) can also be abused via its ProxyCommand or LocalCommand options to run malicious commands. This technique has been associated with threat groups like Lazarus Group and Redcurl.[/profile]
81.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Command Execution is a foundational technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, broadly categorized under the Execution tactic (T1059) across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries leveraging command and scripting interpreters, such as the Windows Command Shell (cmd.exe), PowerShell, Unix shells, Python, JavaScript, or Visual Basic, to run arbitrary commands, scripts, or binaries. This execution can occur directly through interactive shells, via batch files, or embedded within initial access payloads and is commonly facilitated through remote services. The technique serves as a core method for adversaries to control systems and deploy further actions, with specific sub-techniques like Indirect Command Execution (T1202) detailing the abuse of utilities like Forfiles or ssh.exe to bypass security controls that restrict standard command-line interpreters.

82.name: File Download
82.profile: [profile]File Download is a technique (T1105) within the Command and Control tactic. It involves adversaries transferring tools or files into a compromised environment from an external system using the command and control channel or other protocols. Common utilities for this include `certutil`, `PowerShell` commands like `IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString()`, `curl`, `wget`, and `scp`. Adversaries may also abuse installers like `yum` or `winget` and cloud sync services such as Dropbox to facilitate the file transfer.
82.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "File Download" is a technique where adversaries transfer tools or files from an external system into a compromised environment, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK T1105 (Ingress Tool Transfer) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This is executed using native utilities and commands such as `copy`, `certutil`, PowerShell's `Invoke-WebRequest` or `IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString()` on Windows, and `curl`, `scp`, `wget`, or `rsync` on Unix-like systems, often via the C2 channel or protocols like FTP. Adversaries may also abuse installers like `yum` or `winget`, cloud sync services like Dropbox, or features like the Windows `search-ms` protocol to deliver payloads, frequently verifying file integrity with checks like `certutil -hashfile`.

83.name: File Upload
83.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may upload malware to third-party or adversary controlled infrastructure to make it accessible during targeting. Malicious software can include payloads, droppers, post-compromise tools, backdoors, and a variety of other malicious content. Adversaries may upload malware to support their operations, such as making a payload available to a victim network to enable [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105) by placing it on an Internet accessible web server.

Malware may be placed on infrastructure that was previously purchased/rented by the adversary ([Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583)) or was otherwise compromised by them ([Compromise Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584)). Malware can also be staged on web services, such as GitHub or Pastebin; hosted on the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), where decentralized content storage makes the removal of malicious files difficult; or saved on the blockchain as smart contracts, which are resilient against takedowns that would affect traditional infrastructure.(Citation: Volexity Ocean Lotus November 2020)(Citation: Talos IPFS 2022)(Citation: Guardio Etherhiding 2023)(Citation: Bleeping Computer Binance Smart Chain 2023)

Adversaries may upload backdoored files, such as software packages, application binaries, virtual machine images, or container images, to third-party software stores, package libraries, extension marketplaces, or repositories (ex: GitHub, CNET, AWS Community AMIs, Docker Hub, PyPi, NPM).(Citation: Datadog Security Labs Malicious PyPi Packages 2024) By chance encounter, victims may directly download/install these backdoored files via [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204). Masquerading, including typo-squatting legitimate software, may increase the chance of users mistakenly executing these files.
83.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Upload Malware" (T1608.001), a sub-technique of the Resource Development tactic. It involves adversaries staging malicious software like payloads or backdoors on accessible infrastructure, including adversary-controlled web servers, compromised services, or third-party platforms such as GitHub, Pastebin, Docker Hub, PyPI, and decentralized systems like IPFS or blockchain smart contracts to facilitate distribution and resist takedown. This activity supports follow-on actions like Ingress Tool Transfer and is associated with numerous threat groups including Mustang Panda, FIN7, and TA505.[/profile]
83.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "File Upload" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it is a general action often performed as part of other techniques. It involves placing files on a server or infrastructure, which can be used to stage malicious content like malware or tools for later transfer (e.g., Ingress Tool Transfer, T1105). This action can leverage adversary-controlled or compromised infrastructure, including web servers, code repositories (like GitHub), or decentralized storage systems (like IPFS), to host payloads for operational support.[/profile]

84.name: Winview.ocx
84.profile: [profile]Winview.ocx is a log file used by the Agent.BTZ malware, which is attributed to the Turla group. It is encrypted with an XOR mask and records threat activity and system information, such as timestamps, version numbers, configuration details, usernames, and machine architecture. The malware is delivered via a Dropper.
84.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Winview.ocx, also known as a component of the Dropper malware, is a file used to log threat activity, as seen in operations involving the agent.btz malware. It is attributed to groups including tonto team and turla. Its key technical behaviors involve being delivered by a Dropper component, which is often distributed via RTF document lures, and the winview.ocx log file itself is encrypted with a XOR mask. The target platform is Windows, specifically logging to the system32 directory.[/profile]

85.name: Information Gathering
85.profile: [profile]Information Gathering is a general reconnaissance phase, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It encompasses various tactics and techniques used to collect data about a target. This can include gathering host, network, identity, and organizational information through methods like active scanning, phishing for information, and searching open sources. The goal is to inform subsequent stages of an attack, such as developing capabilities or planning initial access.
85.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Information Gathering is a broad reconnaissance tactic, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It encompasses various techniques to collect data about a victim before an attack. This includes gathering details about the victim's host (T1592), identity (T1589), network (T1590), and organization (T1591). Adversaries perform this through methods like active scanning, phishing for information, and searching open sources to understand the target environment and shape follow-on operations.

86.name: Browser Process Communication
86.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse inter-process communication (IPC) mechanisms for local code or command execution. IPC is typically used by processes to share data, communicate with each other, or synchronize execution. IPC is also commonly used to avoid situations such as deadlocks, which occurs when processes are stuck in a cyclic waiting pattern. 

Adversaries may abuse IPC to execute arbitrary code or commands. IPC mechanisms may differ depending on OS, but typically exists in a form accessible through programming languages/libraries or native interfaces such as Windows [Dynamic Data Exchange](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/002) or [Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001). Linux environments support several different IPC mechanisms, two of which being sockets and pipes.(Citation: Linux IPC) Higher level execution mediums, such as those of [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s, may also leverage underlying IPC mechanisms. Adversaries may also use [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) to facilitate remote IPC execution.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)
86.profile: [profile]Browser Process Communication is a technique within the broader MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Execution (T1559). It involves adversaries abusing inter-process communication (IPC) mechanisms, which are native OS features for data sharing and synchronization between processes, to execute arbitrary code or commands locally. This can be achieved through various OS-specific interfaces like Windows Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) or Component Object Model (COM), or Linux mechanisms like sockets and pipes. More sophisticated attacks may use these IPC channels, such as named pipes, to facilitate communication between segmented malicious modules during process injection, aiding in evasion.
86.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Browser Process Communication" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to the abuse of inter-process communication (IPC) mechanisms specific to browser processes, often for code execution or command and control. This can involve techniques like process injection where adversaries use IPC channels such as named pipes to communicate between malicious modules, or browser session hijacking where extensions or injected code establish proxy connections to pivot traffic and assume the browser's authenticated sessions and permissions, potentially bypassing network defenses and two-factor authentication.

87.name: Named Pipes
87.profile: [profile]Named Pipes is a form of inter-process communication (IPC) used for local code or command execution, particularly on Windows and Linux platforms. It functions as a mechanism for processes to share data and synchronize execution. Adversaries abuse named pipes to execute arbitrary code, often as part of more sophisticated techniques like Process Injection (T1055), where they are used as a communication channel to segment modules and evade detection. This technique is associated with the Execution tactic.
87.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Named Pipes is a technique for Inter-Process Communication (IPC) used for local code or command execution, often to evade detection by masking execution under a legitimate process. It is categorized under MITRE ATT&CK as T1559.002 (Windows) within the Execution tactic. The technique involves using named pipes as a communication channel, particularly in sophisticated process injection scenarios where multiple injections segment modules. It is a platform-specific mechanism, with Windows utilizing it through interfaces like Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) and Component Object Model (COM).

88.name: mskfp32.ocx
88.profile: [profile]mskfp32.ocx is a log file created by malware execution, specifically associated with the Agent.BTZ and Uroburos malware families attributed to the Turla group. It is used in versions prior to 3.26 with a XOR key matching the dropper, while version 3.26 employs a new non-ASCII key for encoding. The log file is in an XML format and is stored alongside msvcrtd.tlb. It is deployed on Windows platforms.
88.profile_without_enhance: [profile]mskfp32.ocx is a log file created by the execution of the Turla group's Agent.BTZ and Uroburos malware. It is associated with versions of these malware families, where versions older than 3.26 use a specific XOR key matching the dropper, while version 3.26 employs a new non-ASCII key for its encoded XML log data.

89.name: msvcrtd.tlb
89.profile: [profile]msvcrtd.tlb is a log file created during the execution of the Turla-associated Agent.BTZ and Uroburos malware families. It is used alongside mskfp32.ocx for logging, and its encryption involves an XOR key that is identical to the dropper key in versions older than 3.26, while version 3.26 employs a new non-ASCII key. The malware is attributed to the Turla intrusion set and targets Windows systems.
89.profile_without_enhance: [profile]msvcrtd.tlb is a log file created during the execution of the Turla-associated malware families Agent.BTZ and Uroburos. It is used alongside mskfp32.ocx to record activity, with older versions (prior to 3.26) using the same XOR key as the dropper and version 3.26 employing a new non-ASCII key for encoding.

95.name: Dropper v3.26
95.profile: [profile]Dropper v3.26 is a malware dropper version, directly succeeding Dropper v3.25. It is associated with the Turla group, as indicated by shared MD5 hashes (0ae421450679ff6b27f65f49e79e88f6 for the dropper) across related entities like Agent.BTZ and Uroburos. Its technical behavior involves dropping payloads, with specific library components (lib1 and lib2) identified by their hashes. Target platforms are not specified in the provided data.[/profile]
95.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Dropper v3.26 is a malware dropper version directly succeeding Dropper v3.25. It is attributed to the Turla group, sharing infrastructure and specific MD5 hashes (0ae421450679ff6b27f65f49e79e88f6 for the dropper, 255118ac14a9e66124f7110acd16f2cd for lib1, b407b6e5b4046da226d6e189a67f62ca for lib2) with the Agent.BTZ and Uroburos malware families. Its key technical behavior is functioning as a dropper, and its target platform is Windows.[/profile]

96.name: Dropper v3.25
96.profile: [profile]Dropper v3.25 is a malware dropper version. It is associated with the Turla group, as indicated by its presence in the infrastructure of the Agent.BTZ and Uroburos malware families. Key technical indicators include specific MD5 hashes: 51e7e58a1e654b6e586fe36e10c67a73 for the dropper, e6ce1f962a47479a86ff2e67129f4ecc for lib1, and ec7e3cfaeaac0401316d66e964be684e for lib2. It is directly related to the subsequent version Dropper v3.26.[/profile]
96.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Dropper v3.25 is a malware dropper version, a predecessor to Dropper v3.26. It is associated with the Turla group, as indicated by shared file hashes with the Agent.BTZ and Uroburos malware families. Its key technical behavior involves dropping payloads, with specific library components identified as lib1 and lib2. The target platform is Windows, inferred from the context of related dropper versions and associated malware. Supplementary information includes its MD5 hash: 51e7e58a1e654b6e586fe36e10c67a73.[/profile]

97.name: Persistence Mechanism
97.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may clear artifacts associated with previously established persistence on a host system to remove evidence of their activity. This may involve various actions, such as removing services, deleting executables, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), [Plist File Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1647), or other methods of cleanup to prevent defenders from collecting evidence of their persistent presence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm) Adversaries may also delete accounts previously created to maintain persistence (i.e. [Create Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136)).(Citation: Talos - Cisco Attack 2022)

In some instances, artifacts of persistence may also be removed once an adversaryâ€™s persistence is executed in order to prevent errors with the new instance of the malware.(Citation: NCC Group Team9 June 2020)
97.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Clear Persistence, identified as T1070.009 under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. It involves adversaries removing artifacts of previously established persistence mechanisms, such as deleting malicious services, executables, registry keys, plist files, or user accounts, to eliminate evidence of their presence and prevent defender analysis.
97.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Persistence Mechanism is a broad attack pattern where adversaries establish long-term access to compromised systems. Specific techniques include modifying macOS property list files (e.g., `~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist`) to re-open malicious applications on reboot, abusing deprecated `/Library/StartupItems` directories to execute code as root during boot, and tampering with low-level firmware like BIOS or UEFI to embed malware below the operating system for stealth.

99.name: Uroburos Rootkit
