99.uncertain_mes: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
99.profile: [profile]Uroburos Rootkit, also known as Snake, is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool and rootkit attributed to the Turla intrusion set, associated with Russia's FSB. It is composed of a driver and an encrypted virtual file system, enabling it to take control of infected machines, execute arbitrary commands, hide system activities, steal files, and capture network traffic. The malware employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, and is typically deployed to external-facing network nodes to facilitate further internal exploitation.
99.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Uroburos Rootkit, also known as Snake, is a malware attributed to the Turla intrusion set. It is a rootkit composed of a driver and an encrypted virtual file system, capable of taking control of infected machines, executing arbitrary commands, and hiding system activities. It uses HTTP, HTTP2, and TCP protocols for encrypted command and control communication, can steal files and capture network traffic, and targets systems for data exfiltration and hands-on-keyboard intrusion activities.

100.name: Snake
100.uncertain_mes: Since January 2020, the CrowdStrikeÂ® Falcon OverWatchTM managed threat hunting team has observed an escalation in hands-on-keyboard activity. The COVID-19 pandemic has fundamentally shifted the way businesses are working, and adversaries are taking full advantage of businesses that fail to adapt their security postures in response.
100.profile: [profile]Snake, also known as Uroburos Rootkit, is attributed to the Turla intrusion set. It employs encrypted communication over HTTP, HTTP2, and TCP protocols, with operators capable of altering network-based signatures to evade detection. The malware functions as an implant for conducting hands-on-keyboard intrusion activities.
100.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Snake, also known as Uroburos Rootkit, is attributed to the Turla intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include being a rootkit composed of a driver and an encrypted virtual file system, taking control of infected machines, executing arbitrary commands, hiding system activities, stealing files, and capturing network traffic. It primarily targets Windows platforms and uses HTTP, HTTP2, and TCP for its network communications, with operators capable of changing network-based signatures.

101.name: agent.dne
101.profile: [profile]Agent.DNE, also known as Trojan.Win32.Agent.dne, is a backdoor attributed to the Turla intrusion set. Its C2 configuration is encrypted and it has been compiled as early as 2007, indicating long-term use. The malware is associated with the Uroburos malware family and its infrastructure has involved satellite-based internet links for command and control communications.
101.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Agent.DNE is a backdoor attributed to the Turla intrusion set, with aliases including Trojan.Win32.Agent.dne. It is related to other Turla malware like Uroburos (Snake). Its technical behavior involves using encrypted command and control (C&C) channels, with infrastructure that has included satellite-based internet links. The malware primarily targets Windows platforms.[/profile]

102.name: Hidden Cobra
102.uncertain_mes:
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) is a North Korean state-sponsored cyber threat group attributed to the Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB). (Citation: US-CERT HIDDEN COBRA June 2017) (Citation: Treasury North Korean Cyber Groups September 2019) [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has been active since at least 2009 and is reportedly responsible for the November 2014 destructive wiper attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment, identified by Novetta as part of Operation Blockbuster. Malware used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) correlates to other reported campaigns, including Operation Flame, Operation 1Mission, Operation Troy, DarkSeoul, and Ten Days of Rain.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster)

North Koreaâ€™s cyber operations have shown a consistent pattern of adaptation, forming and reorganizing units as national priorities shift. These units frequently share personnel, infrastructure, malware, and tradecraft, making it difficult to attribute specific operations with high confidence. Public reporting often uses â€œLazarus Groupâ€ as an umbrella term for multiple North Korean cyber operators conducting espionage, destructive attacks, and financially motivated campaigns.(Citation: Mandiant DPRK Laz Org Breakdown 2022)(Citation: Mandiant DPRK Groups 2023)(Citation: JPCert Blog Laz Subgroups 2025)
102.profile: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as Lazarus Group, APT38, and Bureau 121, is a North Korean state-sponsored cyber threat group attributed to the Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB) and active since at least 2009. Its arsenal includes malware and tools associated with campaigns such as Operation Blockbuster, Operation Flame, and DarkSeoul. The group is believed to be responsible for destructive attacks like the 2014 Sony Pictures Entertainment breach and financially motivated operations, frequently sharing personnel and infrastructure with other North Korean cyber units. Its targets span multiple sectors and regions, primarily motivated by espionage, financial gain, and disruptive objectives.
102.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Hidden Cobra, a cyber threat group widely attributed to North Korea and also known as the Lazarus Group, employs custom malware families such as Destover (and its variant Escad), Bankshot, and ProxySvc. Its key TTPs include the use of FakeTLS certificates for C2 communication, rich PE headers in malware, and operations like Operation GhostSecret which involved data collection and exfiltration. The group primarily targets the global financial sector, telecommunications, healthcare, critical infrastructure, and entertainment, with notable attacks against Turkish banks and Sony Pictures, and is believed to be state-sponsored with motivations centered on financial gain and espionage.
102.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as APT43, Kimsuky, and Thallium, is a North Korean state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key malware and tools include BabyShark, KimJongRAT, and the AppleSeed backdoor. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing, credential harvesting, and leveraging compromised infrastructure. The group is attributed to North Korea's Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB). It primarily targets government, defense, and research sectors in South Korea, the United States, and Japan, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and financial theft to support the regime.
102.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]Hidden Cobra is a cyber threat actor attributed to the Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB) of North Korea, also known as APT38, Lazarus Group, and Guardians of Peace. Its key malware and tools include the Brambul SMB worm, the DeltaCharlie DDoS bot, and the Joanap backdoor. Key TTPs involve the use of destructive wiper malware, such as Hermes, and the targeting of financial institutions for fraudulent SWIFT transactions. The group primarily targets the financial sector globally, with a focus on banks in Southeast Asia, and is motivated by financial gain and espionage, often overlapping with other North Korean state-sponsored clusters in its operations.
102.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]Hidden Cobra is a cyber espionage group widely attributed to North Korea and is also known as the Lazarus Group. Its key malware and tools include Bankshot, Destover (and its variants like Escad), and ProxySvc, which are used for remote access, data destruction, and command execution. The group employs TTPs such as establishing covert networks for data collection and launching further attacks, using FakeTLS for C2 communication, and leveraging exploits like CVE-2018-4878. It primarily targets the global financial sector (notably in Turkey and South Korea), critical infrastructure, healthcare, telecommunications, and entertainment, with high-profile incidents including the Sony Pictures breach and Operation GhostSecret, motivated by financial gain and strategic intelligence collection.[/profile]
102.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as the Lazarus Group, is a North Korean state-sponsored APT group. Its key malware and tools include the Destover family (including variants like Escad), Bankshot RAT, and ProxySvc. Its TTPs involve using FakeTLS for C2 communication, establishing covert networks for data collection, and leveraging exploits like CVE-2018-4878. The group is attributed to North Korea and primarily targets the global financial sector, critical infrastructure, telecommunications, and entertainment industries, with notable attacks against Sony Pictures and Turkish financial institutions, motivated by espionage and financial gain.[/profile]
102.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]Hidden Cobra is a cyber intrusion set widely attributed to the Lazarus Group, a North Korean state-sponsored actor. It is also known as APT38 and Zinc. The group is distinguished by its use of custom malware families including Destover (and its variant Escad), Bankshot, and ProxySvc, often employing FakeTLS for command-and-control communications. Its key TTPs involve establishing covert networks for data collection and launching further attacks, as seen in campaigns like Operation GhostSecret. The group primarily targets the global financial sector, critical infrastructure, telecommunications, and the entertainment industry, with notable attacks against Turkish banks and Sony Pictures, motivated by financial gain and strategic disruption.[/profile]
102.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as the Lazarus Group, is a North Korean state-sponsored APT group. Its key malware and tools include the Bankshot RAT, the Destover/Escad backdoor family, and the ProxySvc implant, often using FakeTLS certificates and Rich PE headers for command and control. The group's TTPs involve establishing covert networks for data collection and attacks, as seen in campaigns like Operation GhostSecret. It primarily targets the global financial sector, critical infrastructure, telecommunications, and entertainment, with notable attacks against Turkish banks and Sony Pictures, and is motivated by financial gain and espionage.
102.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as Lazarus Group, is a North Korean state-sponsored APT group. Its key malware includes the Destover family (including variants like Escad), Bankshot RAT, and ProxySvc, which use FakeTLS communications, rich PE headers, and process injection. The group's TTPs involve establishing covert networks for data collection and attacks, as seen in campaigns like Operation GhostSecret. It primarily targets the global financial sector (notably in Turkey), critical infrastructure, healthcare, telecommunications, and the entertainment industry (e.g., Sony Pictures), with operations focused on cyber espionage and financial theft.
102.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as the Lazarus Group, is a North Korean state-sponsored APT group. Its key malware and tools include Destover, Bankshot, ProxySvc, and Escad, which are used for remote access, data collection, and command execution. Its TTPs involve establishing covert networks, using FakeTLS certificates for C2, and conducting data exfiltration to code repositories, as seen in campaigns like Operation GhostSecret. The group is attributed to North Korea and primarily targets the global financial sector, critical infrastructure, and organizations in regions including Turkey and South Korea, with motivations centered on financial theft and espionage.[/profile]
102.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as the Lazarus Group, is a North Korean state-sponsored advanced persistent threat (APT) actor. Its key malware and tools include the Destover family (including the Escad variant), Bankshot, and ProxySvc, used for destructive attacks, remote access, and command execution. Its tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) involve establishing covert networks, data collection, and operations like GhostSecret, which use screen capture and exfiltration to code repositories. The group is attributed to North Korea and primarily targets the global finance, entertainment, and telecommunications sectors, as well as higher education organizations, with motivations centered on financial gain and espionage.[/profile]
102.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as the Lazarus Group, is a North Korean state-sponsored APT group. It is known for using custom malware such as the Bankshot RAT, which employs techniques like PE rich header manipulation, process injection, and HTTP-based C2. The group has conducted financially motivated attacks, notably targeting financial institutions in Turkey, and also engages in data collection activities. While infrastructure and targeting details suggest a broad operational scope, including potential interest in the healthcare sector, its primary attribution and motivation are linked to North Korean state objectives.
102.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]Hidden Cobra, also known as Lazarus Group and Scarlet Mimic, is a state-sponsored intrusion set attributed to North Korea. Its key malware includes Faketls (FakeM Custom SSL), which uses a FakeTLS method with a specific byte sequence header to disguise communications. The group's primary TTPs involve data collection, often through automated scripts to search for and copy specific files. It primarily targets the entertainment sector and has shown infrastructure overlaps with entities like Thammasat University. Its motivation is believed to be financial gain and espionage, consistent with North Korean state objectives.

103.name: Operation Ghostsecret
103.profile: [profile]Operation Ghostsecret is a cyber espionage campaign attributed to the Hidden Cobra intrusion set. The campaign employed techniques like screen capture (T1113) to gather information via utilities such as CopyFromScreen, xwd, or screencapture, exfiltration to code repository (T1567.001) to covertly transfer data using services like GitHub's API, and network share connection removal (T1126) to clean up traces using commands like net use /delete.[/profile]
103.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Operation Ghostsecret is a campaign, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, and is associated with the North Korean group Lazarus. The campaign involved the use of screen capture (T1113) to gather information, exfiltration to code repositories (T1567.001) to covertly transfer stolen data, and network share connection removal (T1126) to clean up traces post-compromise.

104.name: Bankshot
104.uncertain_mes: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first reported by the Department of Homeland Security in December of 2017. In 2018, [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used the [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) implant in attacks against the Turkish financial sector. (Citation: McAfee Bankshot)
104.profile: [profile]Bankshot is a remote access tool (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group (also known as Hidden Cobra). It was first reported in December 2017 and was used in 2018 against the Turkish financial sector. The malware exhibits code and behavioral overlaps with other Lazarus tools like WinorDLL64 and samples from Operation GhostSecret, indicating shared development or deployment infrastructure within the group's campaigns.
104.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bankshot, also known as the Bankshot implant, is a remote access tool (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group (Hidden Cobra). Its key technical behaviors include the use of PE rich header data, process manipulation, process injection, dynamic API loading, and command execution for control, alongside HTTP communication for command and control. It primarily targets Windows platforms and was used in attacks against financial institutions in Turkey, leveraging exploits like CVE-2018-4878 and associated with other Lazarus tools like GhostSecret and WinorDLL64.

105.name: Destover
105.profile: [profile]Destover is a malware family attributed to the Lazarus Group (also known as Hidden Cobra). It is a variant of the Backdoor.Escad malware and has been observed using TLS traffic for command and control communications. This malware primarily targets Windows systems, as indicated by its registry persistence mechanisms for automatic execution.[/profile]
105.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Destover is a malware family attributed to the Lazarus Group (Hidden Cobra). It is associated with the backdoor variant Escad, which was used in attacks like the Sony Pictures breach and Operation GhostSecret. Key technical behaviors include the use of FakeTLS certificates for secure command-and-control (C2) communication and the use of a "Rich PE header" as part of its infrastructure. Its target platform is Windows systems.[/profile]

106.name: ProxySvc
106.uncertain_mes: [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) is a malicious DLL used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) in a campaign known as Operation GhostSecret. It has appeared to be operating undetected since 2017 and was mostly observed in higher education organizations. The goal of [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) is to deliver additional payloads to the target and to maintain control for the attacker. It is in the form of a DLL that can also be executed as a standalone process. (Citation: McAfee GhostSecret)
106.profile: [profile]ProxySvc (alias Proxysvc) is a malicious DLL attributed to the Lazarus Group (also known as Hidden Cobra) and used in Operation GhostSecret. It operates as a backdoor, binding to port 443 to listen for and accept incoming commands from control servers (e.g., 193.248.247.59, 196.4.67.45 using a PolarSSL certificate) without initiating outbound connections, enabling payload delivery and persistent control. It primarily targets higher education organizations and has been active since at least 2017.[/profile]
106.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ProxySvc, also known as Proxysvc, is a malicious DLL attributed to the Lazarus Group, used in the Operation GhostSecret campaign. It functions as an implant that binds and listens on port 443 to accept and process incoming commands from a control server, enabling command execution and system information collection. It primarily targets higher education organizations and has used control servers at IP addresses 193.248.247.59 and 196.4.67.45 with a PolarSSL certificate fingerprint d0cb9b2d4809575e1bc1f4657e0eb56f307c7a76.[/profile]

107.name: Faketls
107.profile: [profile]Faketls is a malware family linked to the intrusion-set Hidden Cobra (Lazarus). It employs a FakeTLS technique, crafting a specific header using the byte sequence [0x17 0x03 0x01] to disguise its network traffic. This method has been historically associated with APT groups like Lazarus. The malware has also been referenced in relation to other tools like FakeM Custom SSL and Psylo, which are connected to groups such as Scarlet Mimic and Higaisa.
107.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Faketls, also known as FakeM Custom SSL, is a malware that employs a FakeTLS method, crafting a header using the byte sequence [0x17 0x03 0x01] to disguise its communications. This technique has been used by APT groups including Lazarus and Scarlet Mimic, and is related to other malware like Psylo.

108.name: Escad
108.profile: [profile]Escad, also known as a Destover backdoor variant, is attributed to the Hidden Cobra intrusion set (associated with Lazarus Group). It employs SSL certificates used by FakeTLS for its implants, a technique linked to infrastructure used in Operation GhostSecret. This malware was notably used in the attack against Sony Pictures.[/profile]
108.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Escad is a malware variant of the Destover backdoor family, also known as Backdoor.Destover. It is attributed to the Lazarus Group (also known as Hidden Cobra). Key technical behaviors include the use of SSL certificates and FakeTLS for command and control communications, and it shares infrastructure and development lineage with Destover. It was notably used in the 2014 Sony Pictures attack.[/profile]

116.name: Destover-like variant
116.profile: [profile]Destover-like variant, also known as Backdoor.Destover, is a malware variant associated with the Hidden Cobra intrusion set (also referred to as Lazarus Group). It is noted for its use of TLS traffic for communication, similar to behaviors seen in Backdoor.Escad. This variant targets systems for data exfiltration and backdoor access, with infrastructure and activities linked to campaigns like GhostSecret.[/profile]
116.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Destover-like variant, also known as Backdoor.Destover, is a variant of the Destover malware family attributed to the Lazarus Group. It exhibits TLS traffic for command and control communications and uses a Rich PE header as part of its infrastructure, targeting systems where these techniques are effective.

117.name: Satellite Link Hijacking
117.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send spearphishing emails with a malicious link in an attempt to gain access to victim systems. Spearphishing with a link is a specific variant of spearphishing. It is different from other forms of spearphishing in that it employs the use of links to download malware contained in email, instead of attaching malicious files to the email itself, to avoid defenses that may inspect email attachments. Spearphishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source.

All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this case, the malicious emails contain links. Generally, the links will be accompanied by social engineering text and require the user to actively click or copy and paste a URL into a browser, leveraging [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204). The visited website may compromise the web browser using an exploit, or the user will be prompted to download applications, documents, zip files, or even executables depending on the pretext for the email in the first place.

Adversaries may also include links that are intended to interact directly with an email reader, including embedded images intended to exploit the end system directly. Additionally, adversaries may use seemingly benign links that abuse special characters to mimic legitimate websites (known as an "IDN homograph attack").(Citation: CISA IDN ST05-016) URLs may also be obfuscated by taking advantage of quirks in the URL schema, such as the acceptance of integer- or hexadecimal-based hostname formats and the automatic discarding of text before an â€œ@â€ symbol: for example, `hxxp://google.com@1157586937`.(Citation: Mandiant URL Obfuscation 2023)

Adversaries may also utilize links to perform consent phishing/spearphishing campaigns to [Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)s that grant immediate access to the victim environment. For example, a user may be lured into granting adversaries permissions/access via a malicious OAuth 2.0 request URL that when accepted by the user provide permissions/access for malicious applications.(Citation: Trend Micro Pawn Storm OAuth 2017)(Citation: Microsoft OAuth 2.0 Consent Phishing 2021) These stolen access tokens allow the adversary to perform various actions on behalf of the user via API calls.(Citation: Microsoft OAuth 2.0 Consent Phishing 2021)

Similarly, malicious links may also target device-based authorization, such as OAuth 2.0 device authorization grant flow which is typically used to authenticate devices without UIs/browsers. Known as â€œdevice code phishing,â€ an adversary may send a link that directs the victim to a malicious authorization page where the user is tricked into entering a code/credentials that produces a device token.(Citation: SecureWorks Device Code Phishing 2021)(Citation: Netskope Device Code Phishing 2021)(Citation: Optiv Device Code Phishing 2021)
117.profile: [profile]Satellite Link Hijacking is a spearphishing technique (ID T1566.002) under the Initial Access tactic. It involves sending targeted emails containing malicious links to download malware or steal credentials, avoiding attachment-based defenses. The technique leverages user interaction, where clicking the link may lead to browser exploitation, malicious file downloads, or OAuth token theft via deceptive authorization pages. It is associated with groups like Turla and exploits unencrypted communication channels.
117.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Satellite Link Hijacking is an attack-pattern that exploits vulnerabilities like Unencrypted Packets to intercept or manipulate satellite communication channels. This technique can be used for Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium, allowing data transfer via an alternative, potentially less-secure network path such as a satellite link instead of the primary command and control channel. The method involves hijacking the communication session to redirect or capture data traffic.

119.name: 2018 Destover-like implant
119.profile: [profile]The malware is known as the 2018 Destover-like implant, a variant of Backdoor.Destover and Backdoor.Escad. It is attributed to the Hidden Cobra intrusion set, also known as the Lazarus Group. Key technical behaviors include using TLS traffic for communication and sharing an identical rich PE header signature with the 2014 Backdoor.Escad variant, indicating a high degree of code similarity and shared development lineage with earlier Destover malware used in operations like the Sony Pictures attack.[/profile]
119.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is known as the 2018 Destover-like implant, a variant of the Backdoor.Destover (Escad) family. It is attributed to the Lazarus Group. Key technical behaviors include the use of TLS traffic for communication and a high degree of code similarity (83%) to a 2015 variant, with an identical rich PE header signature to the 2014 Backdoor.Escad variant used in the Sony Pictures attack. This indicates a direct lineage and shared development infrastructure with earlier Destover malware.

123.name: advanced implants
123.profile: [profile]Advanced Implants is a set of malware attributed to the intrusion set Hidden Cobra. Its key technical behaviors include being orchestrated by an instrumentor, evolving over time, and being delivered via public web content publishing services like Blogspot to serve malicious payloads and thwart attribution.
123.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware known as 'advanced implants' is referenced in the context of campaigns attributed to groups like GoldDragon and TriangleDB. These campaigns demonstrate the use of public web services like Blogspot for command-and-control infrastructure to distribute and update the implants, a technique intended to hinder attribution. The implants are orchestrated by an instrumentor, indicating a structured deployment process.

125.name: control server infrastructure of Operation GhostSecret

126.name: establish covert networks to collect data and launch further attacks
126.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may create and cultivate accounts with services that can be used during targeting. Adversaries can create accounts that can be used to build a persona to further operations. Persona development consists of the development of public information, presence, history and appropriate affiliations. This development could be applied to social media, website, or other publicly available information that could be referenced and scrutinized for legitimacy over the course of an operation using that persona or identity.(Citation: NEWSCASTER2014)(Citation: BlackHatRobinSage)

For operations incorporating social engineering, the utilization of an online persona may be important. These personas may be fictitious or impersonate real people. The persona may exist on a single site or across multiple sites (ex: Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, Google, GitHub, Docker Hub, etc.). Establishing a persona may require development of additional documentation to make them seem real. This could include filling out profile information, developing social networks, or incorporating photos.(Citation: NEWSCASTER2014)(Citation: BlackHatRobinSage)

Establishing accounts can also include the creation of accounts with email providers, which may be directly leveraged for [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) or [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566).(Citation: Mandiant APT1) In addition, establishing accounts may allow adversaries to abuse free services, such as registering for trial periods to [Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583) for malicious purposes.(Citation: Free Trial PurpleUrchin)
126.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1585 "Establish Accounts", categorized under the Resource Development tactic and applicable to multiple platforms. It involves adversaries creating and cultivating accounts on services like social media, email providers, or cloud platforms to build fictitious or impersonated online personas. These accounts are used to support operations, including social engineering for phishing, abusing free trials to acquire infrastructure, and developing a credible presence across multiple sites to enhance the legitimacy of the persona for further attacks. Associated groups include APT17, Kimsuky, and Fox Kitten.[/profile]
126.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "establish covert networks to collect data and launch further attacks" is a cyber attack pattern. While it lacks a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID, its core technical mechanics involve compromising numerous third-party systems to create a botnet. This covert network is then used for coordinated malicious activities, including large-scale data collection and launching distributed attacks such as phishing or DDoS campaigns.

127.name: data collection
127.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may target user email to collect sensitive information. Emails may contain sensitive data, including trade secrets or personal information, that can prove valuable to adversaries. Emails may also contain details of ongoing incident response operations, which may allow adversaries to adjust their techniques in order to maintain persistence or evade defenses.(Citation: TrustedSec OOB Communications)(Citation: CISA AA20-352A 2021) Adversaries can collect or forward email from mail servers or clients.
127.profile: [profile]Email Collection is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1114 under the Collection tactic, applicable to Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. This technique involves adversaries targeting user email to gather sensitive data, including trade secrets or incident response details, by collecting or forwarding emails directly from mail servers or clients. It is associated with groups like Silent Librarian and Scattered Spider, and has sub-techniques for local (T1114.001) and remote (T1114.002) collection methods.
127.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "data collection" is a broad attack pattern within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, encompassing the adversary's gathering of information from a target network. It is associated with the Collection tactic (TA0009) and spans multiple platforms. Technical mechanics involve searching for and copying specific data, which can be automated using command interpreters or scripts to filter by criteria like file type or name. This process often incorporates other techniques such as File and Directory Discovery (T1083) and can target various sources including local files, cloud storage, email, and clipboard data.

129.name: Backdoor.escad
129.profile: [profile]Backdoor.Escad is a backdoor malware. It is associated with the Lazarus Group. Its control server traffic is nearly identical to that of the GhostSecret malware. It has been observed in operations since at least 2014.
129.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Backdoor.Escad is a malware backdoor. It is associated with the Lazarus Group. Its technical behaviors include using a 'Rich PE header' and its command and control server traffic is nearly identical to that used by the GhostSecret malware.

134.name: man-in-the-middle traffic interception
134.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique to support follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040), [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002), or replay attacks ([Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212)). By abusing features of common networking protocols that can determine the flow of network traffic (e.g. ARP, DNS, LLMNR, etc.), adversaries may force a device to communicate through an adversary controlled system so they can collect information or perform additional actions.(Citation: Rapid7 MiTM Basics)

For example, adversaries may manipulate victim DNS settings to enable other malicious activities such as preventing/redirecting users from accessing legitimate sites and/or pushing additional malware.(Citation: ttint_rat)(Citation: dns_changer_trojans)(Citation: ad_blocker_with_miner) Adversaries may also manipulate DNS and leverage their position in order to intercept user credentials, including access tokens ([Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)) and session cookies ([Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)).(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)(Citation: Token tactics) [Downgrade Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/010)s can also be used to establish an AiTM position, such as by negotiating a less secure, deprecated, or weaker version of communication protocol (SSL/TLS) or encryption algorithm.(Citation: mitm_tls_downgrade_att)(Citation: taxonomy_downgrade_att_tls)(Citation: tlseminar_downgrade_att)

Adversaries may also leverage the AiTM position to attempt to monitor and/or modify traffic, such as in [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). Adversaries can setup a position similar to AiTM to prevent traffic from flowing to the appropriate destination, potentially to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) and/or in support of a [Network Denial of Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498).
134.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Adversary-in-the-Middle" (T1557), a tactic for Credential Access and Collection. It operates by abusing network protocols like ARP, DNS, or LLMNR to intercept and redirect traffic between devices through an adversary-controlled system. This position enables follow-on actions such as network sniffing, credential theft (including tokens and cookies), and data manipulation. Techniques like DNS manipulation or TLS downgrade attacks are used to establish the interception point. It is associated with threat groups including Kimsuky, Sea Turtle, and Mustang Panda.[/profile]
134.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Man-in-the-Middle Traffic Interception is a technique for intercepting and potentially manipulating network communications. It aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Adversary-in-the-Middle (T1557) under the Collection tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. The technique works by positioning an adversary-controlled system between two communicating devices, often by abusing network protocols like ARP, DNS, or LLMNR to redirect traffic. This position enables follow-on actions such as network sniffing to capture credentials like access tokens and session cookies, or performing transmitted data manipulation. It is associated with threat groups including Kimsuky, Sea Turtle, and Mustang Panda.

135.name: http over ssl
135.profile: [profile]HTTP over SSL is a foundational communication method, not a distinct MITRE ATT&CK technique. It describes the use of HTTPS (HTTP secured by SSL/TLS) to encrypt network traffic. This encryption is commonly leveraged by adversaries in various techniques to protect their activities from detection, such as in Exfiltration Over Web Service (T1567) or to impersonate legitimate traffic in Protocol Impersonation (T1001.003). Its primary function is to provide a secure channel that can blend with normal, trusted web traffic.
135.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "http over ssl" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to the use of HTTPS (HTTP over SSL/TLS) as a component within other techniques. The retrieved information describes HTTPS as a common transport layer providing encryption for exfiltration over web services (T1567) or webhooks (T1567.004), and for blending malicious traffic with legitimate network communications. It is also mentioned in the context of protocol impersonation (T1001.003) and as a vector for SSL renegotiation attacks in service exhaustion floods (T1499.002).

136.name: command execution
136.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse utilities that allow for command execution to bypass security restrictions that limit the use of command-line interpreters. Various Windows utilities may be used to execute commands, possibly without invoking [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106). For example, [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193), the Program Compatibility Assistant (`pcalua.exe`), components of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), `Scriptrunner.exe`, as well as other utilities may invoke the execution of programs and commands from a [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059), Run window, or via scripts.(Citation: VectorSec ForFiles Aug 2017)(Citation: Evi1cg Forfiles Nov 2017)(Citation: Secure Team - Scriptrunner.exe)(Citation: SS64)(Citation: Bleeping Computer - Scriptrunner.exe) Adversaries may also abuse the `ssh.exe` binary to execute malicious commands via the `ProxyCommand` and `LocalCommand` options, which can be invoked via the `-o` flag or by modifying the SSH config file.(Citation: Threat Actor Targets the Manufacturing industry with Lumma Stealer and Amadey Bot)

Adversaries may abuse these features for [Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0005), specifically to perform arbitrary execution while subverting detections and/or mitigation controls (such as Group Policy) that limit/prevent the usage of [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) or file extensions more commonly associated with malicious payloads.
136.profile: [profile]Indirect Command Execution, also known as T1202, is a Defense Evasion technique for Windows platforms. It involves abusing trusted system utilities like Forfiles, pcalua.exe, Windows Subsystem for Linux components, or Scriptrunner.exe to execute commands without invoking the standard Windows command interpreter (cmd.exe). Adversaries may also misuse the ssh.exe binary via its ProxyCommand or LocalCommand options to run malicious commands, thereby bypassing security controls that restrict cmd usage or specific file extensions. This technique has been associated with threat groups like Lazarus Group and Redcurl.
136.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "command execution" is a core technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, broadly categorized under the Execution tactic (T1059) across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries leveraging command and scripting interpreters, such as cmd, PowerShell, or Unix shells, to run arbitrary commands, scripts, or binaries on a target system. This can be achieved through direct interactive use, embedded commands in payloads, or by abusing system utilities like Forfiles or ssh.exe to bypass security restrictions. The technique is fundamental for post-compromise activity, enabling further system manipulation and control.

137.name: Data Exfiltration
137.profile: [profile]Data Exfiltration is a technique within the Exfiltration tactic, applicable across multiple platforms, involving the unauthorized transfer of data from a victim's network. It is often executed via automated processes (T1020) and can utilize various channels for the transfer, including command and control channels (T1041), alternative protocols (T1048), webhooks (T1567.004), or physical media like USB devices (T1052.001). Prior to transfer, adversaries may compress or encrypt collected data (T1560) to evade detection, and schedule exfiltration (T1029) to blend with normal traffic. This technique is associated with threat actors such as APT10.
137.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Data Exfiltration is a technique within the Exfiltration tactic, applicable across multiple platforms, involving the unauthorized transfer of data from a victim's network to an adversary-controlled system. This process often employs specific sub-techniques for the transfer, such as Exfiltration Over C2 Channel (T1041) or Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol (T1048). Prior to transfer, collected data is frequently archived (T1560) using compression or encryption to obfuscate it and minimize network footprint. Exfiltration can be automated (T1020) or scheduled (T1029) to blend with normal traffic patterns.

138.name: system information collection
138.uncertain_mes: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture. Adversaries may use this information to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This behavior is distinct from [Local Storage Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1680) which is an adversary's discovery of local drive, disks and/or volumes. Tools such as [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) can be used to gather detailed system information. If running with privileged access, a breakdown of system data can be gathered through the systemsetup configuration tool on macOS. Adversaries may leverage a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to gather detailed system information (e.g. show version).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A) On ESXi servers, threat actors may gather system information from various esxcli utilities, such as `system hostname get` and `system version get`.(Citation: Crowdstrike Hypervisor Jackpotting Pt 2 2021)(Citation: Varonis) Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud providers such as AWS, GCP, and Azure allow access to instance and virtual machine information via APIs. Successful authenticated API calls can return data such as the operating system platform and status of a particular instance or the model view of a virtual machine.(Citation: Amazon Describe Instance)(Citation: Google Instances Resource)(Citation: Microsoft Virutal Machine API) [System Information Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082) combined with information gathered from other forms of discovery and reconnaissance can drive payload development and concealment.(Citation: OSX.FairyTale)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)
138.profile: [profile]System Information Discovery, identified as T1082, is a Discovery tactic used across Windows, macOS, Linux, and cloud platforms. It involves collecting detailed OS and hardware data like version, patches, and architecture to inform follow-on actions. Techniques include using the `systeminfo` command on Windows, the `systemsetup` tool on macOS, CLI commands like `show version` on network devices, and `esxcli` utilities on ESXi servers. In cloud environments, adversaries use provider APIs to query instance or VM information. This technique is distinct from local storage discovery and is employed by numerous threat groups including Lazarus Group, APT41, and FIN7.
138.profile_without_enhance: [profile]System Information Collection is a technique for gathering detailed OS and hardware data, including version, patches, service packs, and architecture. This information shapes follow-on actions. Tools like Systeminfo and macOS's `systemsetup` are used, along with network device CLIs (e.g., `show version`) and ESXi commands like `system hostname get`. Cloud APIs (AWS, GCP, Azure) can also provide instance details. This discovery, often part of reconnaissance, aids in payload development and is distinct from local storage discovery.[/profile]

139.name: File Deletion
139.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity. Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary (ex: [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how. Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint. There are tools available from the host operating system to perform cleanup, but adversaries may use other tools as well.(Citation: Microsoft SDelete July 2016) Examples of built-in [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) functions include del on Windows, rm or unlink on Linux and macOS, and `rm` on ESXi.
139.profile: [profile]File Deletion is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.004 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, macOS, and ESXi platforms. It involves adversaries removing non-native files like malware or tools to erase traces of intrusion, using built-in commands such as `del` on Windows, `rm` or `unlink` on Linux/macOS, and `rm` on ESXi, or tools like Windows Sysinternals SDelete. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups including APT28, Lazarus Group, and FIN6.[/profile]
139.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File Deletion is mapped to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.004 under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries removing files like malware or tools to erase traces of intrusion, using native OS commands such as `del` on Windows or `rm` and `unlink` on Linux/macOS, as part of post-intrusion cleanup to minimize their footprint.

140.name: Process Creation
140.profile: [profile]Process Creation is the foundational technique (T1057) within the Execution tactic, applicable across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries spawning new processes to run malicious code, often using system utilities like cmd's tasklist, PowerShell's Get-Process, or the native ps command. This activity is a prerequisite for more advanced techniques like Process Injection or Parent PID Spoofing, which manipulate the created processes to evade detection or elevate privileges.
140.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Process Creation is a foundational technique (T1057) within the Execution tactic, applicable across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries spawning new processes to run malicious code, often using native system utilities like cmd's tasklist, PowerShell's Get-Process, or the ps command. This activity can be used for discovery, to execute payloads, or as a precursor to more advanced behaviors like injection or privilege escalation, such as by creating processes with stolen tokens via CreateProcessWithTokenW.

141.name: Dynamic API Loading
141.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may obfuscate then dynamically resolve API functions called by their malware in order to conceal malicious functionalities and impair defensive analysis. Malware commonly uses various [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) functions provided by the OS to perform various tasks such as those involving processes, files, and other system artifacts.

API functions called by malware may leave static artifacts such as strings in payload files. Defensive analysts may also uncover which functions a binary file may execute via an import address table (IAT) or other structures that help dynamically link calling code to the shared modules that provide functions.(Citation: Huntress API Hash)(Citation: IRED API Hashing)

To avoid static or other defensive analysis, adversaries may use dynamic API resolution to conceal malware characteristics and functionalities. Similar to [Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), dynamic API resolution may change file signatures and obfuscate malicious API function calls until they are resolved and invoked during runtime.

Various methods may be used to obfuscate malware calls to API functions. For example, hashes of function names are commonly stored in malware in lieu of literal strings. Malware can use these hashes (or other identifiers) to manually reproduce the linking and loading process using functions such as `GetProcAddress()` and `LoadLibrary()`. These hashes/identifiers can also be further obfuscated using encryption or other string manipulation tricks (requiring various forms of [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140) during execution).(Citation: BlackHat API Packers)(Citation: Drakonia HInvoke)(Citation: Huntress API Hash)
141.profile: [profile]Dynamic API Loading is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1027.007 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows platforms. It works by obfuscating API calls to conceal malware functionality, commonly storing hashes of function names instead of literal strings. These hashes are then dynamically resolved at runtime using functions like `GetProcAddress()` and `LoadLibrary()` to manually link and load the required API, thereby avoiding static analysis and altering file signatures. This technique has been associated with groups like Lazarus Group and Mustang Panda.
141.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Dynamic API Loading is a technique used to conceal malicious API calls by resolving them at runtime instead of statically linking them. It operates within the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily on Windows platforms. The technique works by storing hashed or encrypted function names within the malware, which are then dynamically resolved using functions like `GetProcAddress()` and `LoadLibrary()` during execution. This process obfuscates the import address table and avoids leaving clear static artifacts, thereby impairing defensive analysis and changing file signatures.

142.name: Registry Manipulation
142.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may interact with the Windows Registry as part of a variety of other techniques to aid in defense evasion, persistence, and execution.

Access to specific areas of the Registry depends on account permissions, with some keys requiring administrator-level access. The built-in Windows command-line utility [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) may be used for local or remote Registry modification.(Citation: Microsoft Reg) Other tools, such as remote access tools, may also contain functionality to interact with the Registry through the Windows API.

The Registry may be modified in order to hide configuration information or malicious payloads via [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027).(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)(Citation: Avaddon Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Microsoft BlackCat Jun 2022)(Citation: CISA Russian Gov Critical Infra 2018) The Registry may also be modified to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562), such as by enabling macros for all Microsoft Office products, allowing privilege escalation without alerting the user, increasing the maximum number of allowed outbound requests, and/or modifying systems to store plaintext credentials in memory.(Citation: CISA LockBit 2023)(Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)

The Registry of a remote system may be modified to aid in execution of files as part of lateral movement. It requires the remote Registry service to be running on the target system.(Citation: Microsoft Remote) Often [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) are required, along with access to the remote system's [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002) for RPC communication.

Finally, Registry modifications may also include actions to hide keys, such as prepending key names with a null character, which will cause an error and/or be ignored when read via [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) or other utilities using the Win32 API.(Citation: Microsoft Reghide NOV 2006) Adversaries may abuse these pseudo-hidden keys to conceal payloads/commands used to maintain persistence.(Citation: TrendMicro POWELIKS AUG 2014)(Citation: SpectorOps Hiding Reg Jul 2017)
142.profile: [profile]Registry Manipulation, designated T1112, is a defense evasion, persistence, and execution technique primarily for Windows. It involves modifying the Windows Registry using tools like the built-in Reg utility or remote access tools via the Windows API. Specific technical mechanics include prepending registry key names with a null character to hide them, modifying keys to impair defenses (e.g., enabling Office macros), and altering remote registries for lateral movement, which requires the remote Registry service and often valid accounts with SMB share access. It is used by numerous threat groups including APT41, Wizard Spider, and Volt Typhoon.
142.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Registry Manipulation, identified as T1112 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a Defense Evasion and Persistence technique for Windows platforms. It involves adversaries using tools like the built-in Reg utility or remote access software to interact with the Windows Registry, modifying keys to hide configuration data, impair defenses by disabling security settings, enable execution of malicious payloads, or establish persistence. This can include actions like prepending key names with null characters to hide them from standard utilities.

143.name: Arbitrary Command Execution
143.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse utilities that allow for command execution to bypass security restrictions that limit the use of command-line interpreters. Various Windows utilities may be used to execute commands, possibly without invoking [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106). For example, [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193), the Program Compatibility Assistant (`pcalua.exe`), components of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), `Scriptrunner.exe`, as well as other utilities may invoke the execution of programs and commands from a [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059), Run window, or via scripts.(Citation: VectorSec ForFiles Aug 2017)(Citation: Evi1cg Forfiles Nov 2017)(Citation: Secure Team - Scriptrunner.exe)(Citation: SS64)(Citation: Bleeping Computer - Scriptrunner.exe) Adversaries may also abuse the `ssh.exe` binary to execute malicious commands via the `ProxyCommand` and `LocalCommand` options, which can be invoked via the `-o` flag or by modifying the SSH config file.(Citation: Threat Actor Targets the Manufacturing industry with Lumma Stealer and Amadey Bot)

Adversaries may abuse these features for [Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0005), specifically to perform arbitrary execution while subverting detections and/or mitigation controls (such as Group Policy) that limit/prevent the usage of [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) or file extensions more commonly associated with malicious payloads.
143.profile: [profile]Arbitrary Command Execution, known as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1202 (Indirect Command Execution), is a Defense Evasion tactic primarily targeting Windows platforms. It involves abusing trusted system utilities like Forfiles, pcalua.exe, Windows Subsystem for Linux components, and Scriptrunner.exe to execute commands without invoking the standard command-line interpreter (cmd.exe), thereby bypassing security restrictions and detection controls. Adversaries may also misuse ssh.exe via its ProxyCommand or LocalCommand options to run malicious commands. This technique has been associated with threat groups such as Lazarus Group and Redcurl.
143.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Arbitrary Command Execution is a technique where adversaries execute unauthorized commands on a target system, often as part of the Execution tactic. It typically leverages existing command and scripting interpreters or abuses legitimate utilities to bypass security controls. The mechanics involve invoking system commands or scripts through interfaces like PowerShell, Unix shells, or Windows utilities to run malicious payloads, enabling further system compromise and control. This behavior is fundamental for establishing initial code execution following system access.

144.name: Self-Deletion
144.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity. Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary (ex: [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how. Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint. There are tools available from the host operating system to perform cleanup, but adversaries may use other tools as well.(Citation: Microsoft SDelete July 2016) Examples of built-in [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) functions include del on Windows, rm or unlink on Linux and macOS, and `rm` on ESXi.
144.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "File Deletion" with ID T1070.004, categorized under the Defense Evasion tactic and applicable to Windows, Linux, macOS, and ESXi platforms. This technique involves adversaries deleting files left behind by intrusion tools or malware to remove forensic evidence and minimize their footprint. Specific technical mechanics include using native command-line functions like `del` on Windows, `rm` or `unlink` on Linux/macOS, and `rm` on ESXi, or employing tools like Windows Sysinternals SDelete for secure deletion. It is associated with numerous threat groups including APT29, Lazarus Group, and Wizard Spider.[/profile]
144.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Self-Deletion is a technique adversaries use to remove their own malicious files or tools from a compromised system to minimize their forensic footprint. This action, part of the Defense Evasion tactic, is executed using native OS commands like `del` on Windows or `rm` on Linux/macOS, or specialized tools such as Windows Sysinternals SDelete. It typically occurs post-intrusion to erase traces of activities like tool transfers.

145.name: Memory Inspection
145.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and used to conduct [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) using [Use Alternate Authentication Material](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550). As well as in-memory techniques, the LSASS process memory can be dumped from the target host and analyzed on a local system. For example, on the target host use procdump: * procdump -ma lsass.exe lsass_dump Locally, mimikatz can be run using: * sekurlsa::Minidump lsassdump.dmp * sekurlsa::logonPasswords Built-in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process exit mechanism can be abused to create a memory dump of `lsass.exe` through Windows Error Reporting (`WerFault.exe`).(Citation: Deep Instinct LSASS) Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into LSASS process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) The following SSPs can be used to access credentials: * Msv: Interactive logons, batch logons, and service logons are done through the MSV authentication package. * Wdigest: The Digest Authentication protocol is designed for use with Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Simple Authentication Security Layer (SASL) exchanges.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) * Kerberos: Preferred for mutual client-server domain authentication in Windows 2000 and later. * CredSSP: Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop Services.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection)
145.profile: [profile]LSASS Memory (T1003.001) is a Credential Access technique targeting the Windows platform. It involves accessing or dumping the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) process memory to harvest stored credential materials like hashes and plaintext passwords after user logon. Specific mechanics include using tools like procdump (`procdump -ma lsass.exe`), Mimikatz (`sekurlsa::Minidump`), or built-in Windows utilities like `comsvcs.dll` via `rundll32.exe` to create a memory dump. Adversaries may also abuse the silent process exit mechanism or modify Security Support Provider (SSP) Registry keys to load malicious DLLs into LSASS for credential capture. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups for lateral movement.
145.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Memory Inspection is a credential access technique where adversaries search process memory for sensitive data like passwords and keys. It targets operating system processes such as LSASS on Windows or uses the /proc filesystem on Linux to access virtual memory. Attackers employ tools like Mimikatz or commands like `grep` on `/proc/[pid]/mem` to extract cleartext credentials or hashes cached by the system or applications, facilitating lateral movement and privilege escalation.

146.name: File Enumeration
146.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may enumerate system and service logs to find useful data. These logs may highlight various types of valuable insights for an adversary, such as user authentication records ([Account Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1087)), security or vulnerable software ([Software Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1518)), or hosts within a compromised network ([Remote System Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1018)).

Host binaries may be leveraged to collect system logs. Examples include using `wevtutil.exe` or [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) on Windows to access and/or export security event information.(Citation: WithSecure Lazarus-NoPineapple Threat Intel Report 2023)(Citation: Cadet Blizzard emerges as novel threat actor) In cloud environments, adversaries may leverage utilities such as the Azure VM Agentâ€™s `CollectGuestLogs.exe` to collect security logs from cloud hosted infrastructure.(Citation: SIM Swapping and Abuse of the Microsoft Azure Serial Console)

Adversaries may also target centralized logging infrastructure such as SIEMs. Logs may also be bulk exported and sent to adversary-controlled infrastructure for offline analysis.

In addition to gaining a better understanding of the environment, adversaries may also monitor logs in real time to track incident response procedures. This may allow them to adjust their techniques in order to maintain persistence or evade defenses.(Citation: Permiso GUI-Vil 2023)
146.profile: [profile]File Enumeration, also known as log enumeration (T1654), is a Discovery technique used to collect and analyze system, service, and security logs for intelligence. Adversaries use host utilities like `wevtutil.exe` or PowerShell on Windows and `CollectGuestLogs.exe` in Azure cloud environments to access and export logs. They target centralized logging infrastructure like SIEMs, bulk exporting data to adversary-controlled systems for offline analysis to discover user accounts, software, and network hosts, and to monitor real-time incident response activities.[/profile]
146.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File Enumeration is a Discovery technique where adversaries enumerate files and directories to locate specific information within a file system. This is often performed using command shell utilities such as `dir`, `tree`, `ls`, `find`, and `locate` to list contents and search for data. The activity supports follow-on actions by identifying valuable files or understanding the system layout, and it is commonly associated with threat groups like Mustang Panda, Lazarus Group, and APT39.

147.name: SSL Communication
147.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
147.profile: [profile]SSL Communication, also known as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1102.002 "Web Service: Bidirectional Communication", falls under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across multiple platforms by leveraging legitimate external web services like social media or cloud platforms (e.g., Google, Twitter) for bidirectional C2. Infected systems send commands and receive output through these services, with return traffic manifesting as forum comments, document updates, or social media posts. This method provides cover by blending with normal traffic and benefits from the inherent SSL/TLS encryption used by these providers. Threat actors such as APT28, Lazarus Group, and FIN7 have been associated with this technique.[profile]
147.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SSL Communication is a technique used to secure adversary command and control (C2) traffic. It leverages the SSL/TLS encryption commonly used by legitimate web services, such as those from Google or Twitter, to hide malicious communications within expected network noise. This provides an added layer of protection by making C2 traffic blend in with normal encrypted web traffic, helping it bypass detection.

148.name: Lazarus
148.uncertain_mes:
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) is a North Korean state-sponsored cyber threat group attributed to the Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB). (Citation: US-CERT HIDDEN COBRA June 2017) (Citation: Treasury North Korean Cyber Groups September 2019) [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has been active since at least 2009 and is reportedly responsible for the November 2014 destructive wiper attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment, identified by Novetta as part of Operation Blockbuster. Malware used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) correlates to other reported campaigns, including Operation Flame, Operation 1Mission, Operation Troy, DarkSeoul, and Ten Days of Rain.(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster)

North Koreaâ€™s cyber operations have shown a consistent pattern of adaptation, forming and reorganizing units as national priorities shift. These units frequently share personnel, infrastructure, malware, and tradecraft, making it difficult to attribute specific operations with high confidence. Public reporting often uses â€œLazarus Groupâ€ as an umbrella term for multiple North Korean cyber operators conducting espionage, destructive attacks, and financially motivated campaigns.(Citation: Mandiant DPRK Laz Org Breakdown 2022)(Citation: Mandiant DPRK Groups 2023)(Citation: JPCert Blog Laz Subgroups 2025)
148.profile: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra, and the Guardians of Peace, is a North Korean state-sponsored cyber threat group attributed to the Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB) and active since at least 2009. The group is known for using a wide array of malware and tools, frequently executing payloads via rundll32 and abusing the Windows Update Client for persistence. Its key tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) are linked to major campaigns including Operation Blockbuster (the destructive 2014 Sony Pictures attack), Operation Dream Job, DarkSeoul, and Ten Days of Rain. Lazarus primarily targets sectors and regions globally for espionage, destructive attacks, and financially motivated operations, with its activities often serving North Korean national priorities. Public reporting frequently uses "Lazarus Group" as an umbrella term for multiple overlapping North Korean cyber operators, making precise attribution challenging.
148.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, BlueNoroff, Hidden Cobra, and Diamond Sleet, is a prolific North Korean state-sponsored intrusion set. Its key malware and tools include the Fallchill RAT, KillDisk destructive wiper, Nukesped (TigerRAT), and the use of protectors like Enigma Protector for obfuscation. Key TTPs encompass spear phishing, supply chain attacks, disk-wiping for impact, and multi-platform operations across Windows, Linux, and macOS. The group is attributed to North Korea and primarily targets the global financial sector, cryptocurrency exchanges, and fintech companies, with notable campaigns in Latin America and Ukraine. Its core motivation is financial theft and cyber sabotage to generate revenue for the regime.
148.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Lazarus Group, also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra, and Bluenoroff. It is a prolific, state-sponsored group attributed to North Korea, specifically the Reconnaissance General Bureau. Lazarus is known for its extensive and evolving malware arsenal, including custom backdoors and tools for persistence like malicious LNK files that abuse the Windows Update Client, and the use of rundll32 for payload execution. Its operations, such as Operation Dream Job, target a wide range of sectors globally, including finance, media, and critical infrastructure, primarily to conduct espionage and generate revenue through cybercrime to support the North Korean regime.
148.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The Lazarus Group, also known as APT38, BlueNoroff, Andariel, Hidden Cobra, and Nickel Gladstone, is a prolific North Korean state-sponsored threat actor. Its operations are distinguished by the use of custom malware families like AppleJeus and the targeting of the global financial sector, cryptocurrency exchanges, and critical infrastructure for financial gain and espionage. The group employs sophisticated TTPs including the abuse of the Windows Update Client for persistence, execution via rundll32, and complex supply chain attacks, as seen in campaigns such as Operation Dream Job. Its activities are primarily motivated by revenue generation for the North Korean regime.
148.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra, and Bluenoroff, is a prolific North Korean state-sponsored cyber espionage and sabotage group. Its key malware and tools include the Fallchill RAT, KillDisk disk wiper, and Nukesped downloader, often protected with obfuscators like Enigma Protector. The group employs TTPs such as spear phishing for initial access, supply chain attacks, and disk-wiping for destructive impact. It is attributed to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) and primarily targets the global financial sector, cryptocurrency exchanges, and defense contractors across regions including Central America, Mexico, and Ukraine, with motivations encompassing financial theft, espionage, and disruptive cyber operations.
148.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The Lazarus Group, also known as Hidden Cobra, APT38, and Bluenoroff, is a prolific North Korean state-sponsored intrusion set. Its key custom malware includes the Fallchill RAT, the Nukesped/TigerRAT downloader, the disk-wiping KillDisk malware, and the WannaCry ransomware. The group employs spear-phishing and supply chain attacks for initial access, uses code obfuscation tools like Enigma Protector for defense evasion, and conducts multi-platform operations. It is attributed to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) and primarily targets the global financial sector, cryptocurrency exchanges, and defense contractors, with campaigns also observed in Latin America and Europe. Its motivations are financially driven cybercrime to fund the regime, coupled with espionage and disruptive operations.
148.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra, and Bluenoroff, is a highly prolific intrusion set attributed to North Korea. Its key malware and tools include the Fallchill backdoor, the destructive KillDisk wiper, and the Nukesped (TigerRAT) downloader. The group employs spear phishing, supply chain attacks, and disk-wiping techniques, often using code obfuscation tools like VMProtect and Enigma Protector. Its operations are financially and strategically motivated, primarily targeting the global financial sector, cryptocurrency exchanges, and defense contractors, with significant campaigns observed in Ukraine, Mexico, and Central America.
148.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]The entity is the Lazarus Group, a highly prolific and sophisticated state-sponsored advanced persistent threat (APT) group also known as Hidden Cobra, APT38, and Andariel. It is attributed to North Korea and is known for its extensive, custom malware arsenal including the Fallchill RAT, KillDisk destructive wiper, and Nukesped (TigerRAT). Its key TTPs encompass supply chain attacks, spear-phishing for initial access, and the use of disk-wiping for destructive impact. The group primarily targets the global financial sector, cryptocurrency exchanges, and defense contractors across regions including Central America, Ukraine, and Poland, with motivations driven by financial theft, espionage, and cyber-sabotage to support the North Korean regime.
148.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]The Lazarus Group, also known as Hidden Cobra, APT38, and Bluenoroff, is a prolific North Korean state-sponsored intrusion set. Its key malware and tools include the Fallchill RAT, KillDisk destructive wiper, Nukesped (TigerRAT), and WannaCry ransomware. The group employs diverse TTPs such as spear phishing, supply chain attacks, disk-wiping for impact, and extensive code obfuscation using tools like VMProtect and Enigma Protector. It is attributed to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK). Lazarus primarily targets the global financial sector, cryptocurrency exchanges, and defense contractors, with notable attacks in Ukraine, Mexico, and Central America. Its motivations are financially driven cybercrime to fund the regime, coupled with espionage and disruptive cyber sabotage operations.
148.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, BlueNoroff, Hidden Cobra, and numerous other aliases, is a highly prolific cyber espionage and financially motivated intrusion set attributed to North Korea. Its key malware and tools include the Fallchill RAT, WannaCry ransomware, and the use of software protectors like Enigma Protector for obfuscation. The group's TTPs encompass sophisticated supply chain attacks, phishing campaigns, and code obfuscation for defense evasion. Primarily targeting the global financial sector, including cryptocurrency exchanges and fintech institutions, as well as entities in aerospace and telecommunications, Lazarus is believed to operate under the direction of the North Korean regime, with motivations spanning both financial gain and strategic intelligence collection.
148.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, BlueNoroff, Hidden Cobra, and Andariel, is a highly prolific intrusion set attributed to North Korea. Its key malware and tools include the disk-wiping malware KillDisk (Win32/killdisk.nbo), the cryptocurrency-focused Haobao malware, and malicious documents as a primary infection vector. The group employs TTPs such as spear phishing, disk-wiping for sabotage, and multi-platform attacks across Windows, Linux, and macOS. It is believed to operate on behalf of the North Korean regime, primarily targeting the financial sector globally, including institutions in Ukraine, Mexico, and Central America, with motivations centered on financial theft and cyber-sabotage.
148.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, BlueNoroff, and Hidden Cobra, is a prolific cyber espionage and financially motivated group attributed to North Korea. Its key malware includes the Fallchill RAT. The group's TTPs involve code obfuscation for defense evasion and leveraging tools like rundll32 for execution.
