It primarily targets the financial sector, including cryptocurrency exchanges, and the aerospace and telecommunications industries globally, with motivations spanning cybercrime, espionage, and disruptive attacks.
148.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]Lazarus, also known as APT38, BlueNoroff, Diamond Sleet, and Hidden Cobra, is a highly prolific intrusion set attributed to North Korea. Its key malware and tools include malicious documents as an initial vector and a broad Lazarus Toolset, with TTPs involving multi-platform attacks, abuse of the Windows Update Client for persistence, and execution via rundll32. The group primarily targets the cryptocurrency sector for financial gain, as seen in campaigns like Operation Dream Job and Operation AppleJeus, and has also conducted destructive attacks like Dark Seoul. Its operations show significant overlap with subgroups such as Andariel and Sapphire Sleet, focusing on both cybercrime and espionage.

153.name: Fallchill
153.uncertain_mes: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) is a RAT that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) since at least 2016 to target the aerospace, telecommunications, and finance industries. It is usually dropped by other [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware or delivered when a victim unknowingly visits a compromised website. (Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)
153.profile: [profile]Fallchill, also known as FALLCHILL, is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group and used since at least 2016 against the aerospace, telecommunications, and finance sectors. It is typically delivered via other Lazarus malware or through compromised websites. Key technical behaviors include the use of encrypted components such as a loader (msndll.tmp) and backdoor payload (msndll.dat), often employing RC4 encryption with reused keys across variants, and it shares command-and-control infrastructure with other malware like Volgmer.
153.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Fallchill, also known as FALLCHILL, is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group and used since at least 2016 to target the aerospace, telecommunications, and finance sectors. It is typically delivered via other Lazarus malware or compromised websites. Key technical behaviors include using encrypted components like a loader (msndll.tmp) and backdoor payload (msndll.dat), employing RC4 encryption for configuration data, and utilizing a loader service ([service]svc.dll). Its infrastructure has been associated with the Comodo CA certificate authority.

154.name: Multi-Platform Attack
154.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls. Downgrade attacks typically take advantage of a systemâ€™s backward compatibility to force it into less secure modes of operation. 

Adversaries may downgrade and use various less-secure versions of features of a system, such as [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s or even network protocols that can be abused to enable [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) or [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040).(Citation: Praetorian TLS Downgrade Attack 2014) For example, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) versions 5+ includes Script Block Logging (SBL), which can record executed script content. However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.(Citation: CrowdStrike BGH Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL 2018)(Citation: att_def_ps_logging)

Adversaries may similarly target network traffic to downgrade from an encrypted HTTPS connection to an unsecured HTTP connection that exposes network data in clear text.(Citation: Targeted SSL Stripping Attacks Are Real)(Citation: Crowdstrike Downgrade) On Windows systems, adversaries may downgrade the boot manager to a vulnerable version that bypasses Secure Boot, granting the ability to disable various operating system security mechanisms.(Citation: SafeBreach)
154.profile: [profile]Downgrade Attack, identified as T1562.010 under the Impair Defenses tactic, is a multi-platform technique that exploits system backward compatibility to force less secure modes of operation. Specific mechanics include executing older versions of PowerShell to bypass Script Block Logging, downgrading HTTPS connections to unencrypted HTTP to expose data, and targeting the Windows boot manager to bypass Secure Boot. The intrusion-set Lazarus has been associated with this technique.
154.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Multi-Platform Attack is a technique where adversaries conduct operations across multiple operating systems or environments (e.g., Windows, Linux, macOS, cloud) to increase their reach and resilience. This approach allows them to leverage platform-specific vulnerabilities or tools, complicating defense and attribution by requiring defenders to monitor and correlate activity across disparate systems.

155.name: Phishing
155.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
155.profile: [profile]Phishing is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves sending electronic messages, such as emails with malicious attachments or links, to trick victims into executing code, often via social engineering like posing as a trusted source. Evasive methods include email spoofing, thread hijacking, and manipulating email headers or hiding rules from compromised accounts. Messages may also instruct victims to call a number to visit malicious URLs or download malware, leading to user execution.
155.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Phishing, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566, is an Initial Access tactic executed across multiple platforms. This electronically delivered social engineering attack involves adversaries sending messages, often via email or third-party services, containing malicious attachments or links to execute code on victim systems. Techniques include posing as a trusted source, email spoofing, thread hijacking, and using evasive methods like manipulating email headers. It can be broad or targeted as spearphishing, and may also involve callback instructions to phone numbers for further malicious actions.

156.name: Supply Chain Attack
156.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise.

Supply chain compromise can take place at any stage of the supply chain including:

* Manipulation of development tools
* Manipulation of a development environment
* Manipulation of source code repositories (public or private)
* Manipulation of source code in open-source dependencies
* Manipulation of software update/distribution mechanisms
* Compromised/infected system images (removable media infected at the factory)(Citation: IBM Storwize)(Citation: Schneider Electric USB Malware) 
* Replacement of legitimate software with modified versions
* Sales of modified/counterfeit products to legitimate distributors
* Shipment interdiction

While supply chain compromise can impact any component of hardware or software, adversaries looking to gain execution have often focused on malicious additions to legitimate software in software distribution or update channels.(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Adversaries may limit targeting to a desired victim set or distribute malicious software to a broad set of consumers but only follow up with specific victims.(Citation: Symantec Elderwood Sept 2012)(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Popular open-source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications may also be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency.(Citation: Trendmicro NPM Compromise)

In some cases, adversaries may conduct â€œsecond-orderâ€ supply chain compromises by leveraging the access gained from an initial supply chain compromise to further compromise a software component.(Citation: Krebs 3cx overview 2023) This may allow the threat actor to spread to even more victims.
156.profile: [profile]Supply Chain Attack, identified as MITRE ATT&CK T1195 under the Initial Access tactic, targets multiple platforms by compromising products or delivery mechanisms before they reach the end user. Technical mechanics include manipulating development tools, source code repositories, open-source dependencies, and software update channels to insert malicious code into legitimate software. Adversaries may conduct broad distribution followed by selective victim targeting or execute second-order compromises to expand their reach, with groups like Lazarus, Sandworm Team, and Oilrig associated with this technique.[/profile]
156.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Supply Chain Attack is a MITRE ATT&CK technique with ID T1195, categorized under Initial Access. It targets various platforms by compromising products or delivery mechanisms before they reach the end user. Technical mechanics include manipulating development tools, source code repositories, open-source dependencies, software update channels, or hardware components to insert malicious code. Adversaries may conduct broad distribution with selective follow-up or target specific victims, and can leverage an initial compromise for second-order attacks to spread further.

163.name: New Roman Cyber Army
163.uncertain_mes:
Islamic State Hacking Division
The topic of this article may not meet Wikipedia's notability guidelines for companies and organizations. (August 2015) |
163.profile: [profile]New Roman Cyber Army, also known as Whois HackingTeam and suspected to be linked to or an alias for the Islamic State Hacking Division or Cyber Caliphate Army, is an intrusion set with a primary focus on hacktivism. Its key tool is the Whois HackingTeam malware. The group is attributed to or shows strong overlaps with pro-Islamic State cyber actors. Its motivation is ideologically driven, primarily targeting entities in opposition to its extremist views, with supplementary activities potentially involving data theft and website defacement as indicated by its connections to other regional hacktivist groups like Cyber Toufan.
163.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the North Korean state-sponsored Lazarus Group (also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra), with the specific cluster also identified as Andariel or Bluenoroff and using the alias New Roman Cyber Army. Key malware includes the Troy/DarkSeoul malware family, the NewRomanic Dropper, MBR wipers, and the 3RAT remote access trojan. Its key TTPs involve spear phishing, masquerading as software updates, disk wiping, and the use of RSA encryption for C2. It is attributed to North Korea and primarily targets South Korean entities in the military, government, and financial sectors, with motivations centered on espionage and disruptive cyber operations.
163.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely known as the New Roman Cyber Army, with no other common aliases definitively linked in the provided data. Its key malware or tools are not specified. Its key tactics, techniques, and procedures are unknown. Its origin and attribution are unclear, though the retrieved context mentions other regional "Cyber Army" groups like the Moroccan Black Cyber Army and Muslim Cyber Army, which are pro-Palestine hacktivist entities; this suggests the New Roman Cyber Army may operate within a similar ideological or regional sphere, potentially targeting sectors or regions related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Its primary motivation is suspected to be hacktivism.
163.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile] The intrusion set known as 'New Roman Cyber Army' is a suspected pro-Russian hacktivist group, also known as CyberArmyofRussia_Reborn, UAC-0100, Xaknet, and UAC-0106. It is primarily associated with hacktivist activities, likely targeting entities in Ukraine and other nations opposing Russia. The group's operations typically involve website defacements and DDoS attacks, aligning with common pro-Russian cyber campaign tactics. Its motivation is believed to be ideological support for Russian geopolitical interests.

165.name: Fallchill Backdoor Loader
165.uncertain_mes: [FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) is a RAT that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) since at least 2016 to target the aerospace, telecommunications, and finance industries. It is usually dropped by other [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware or delivered when a victim unknowingly visits a compromised website. (Citation: US-CERT FALLCHILL Nov 2017)
165.profile: [profile]Fallchill, also known as FALLCHILL, is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group and used since at least 2016 against aerospace, telecommunications, and finance sectors. It is typically delivered via compromised websites or by other Lazarus malware. Key technical behaviors include being deployed as a backdoor loader, often with encrypted components like 'msndll.dat' for the payload and 'msncf.dat' for configuration, and it creates persistence via Windows Task Scheduler entries. The malware targets Windows platforms, specifically as a 64-bit PE32+ executable (DLL).[/profile]
165.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Fallchill Backdoor Loader, also known as FALLCHILL, is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group. It is typically deployed as a loader to install the main Fallchill backdoor payload, often delivered via other Lazarus malware or compromised websites. Key technical behaviors include using encrypted configuration and payload files (e.g., msncf.dat, msndll.dat) and registering persistence via Windows Task Scheduler. It primarily targets Windows systems, with a focus on industries including aerospace, telecommunications, and finance.

172.name: Remote Access Trojan
172.profile: [profile]The entity is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT). It is attributed to the New Roman Cyber Army intrusion set. It is a type of malware that provides attackers with remote control over an infected system, sharing key characteristics and being part of the same category as other RATs like AsyncRAT, NjRAT, DCRat, Remcos, AveMaria, and NanoCore.[/profile]
172.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT). It is associated with the 'make troy' indicator and has targeted entities such as News Agencies and South Korean Banks. It is a type of malware that shares characteristics with other RAT families like AsyncRAT, NjRAT, DCRat, Remcos, AveMaria, and NanoCore, which are known for providing backdoor access and remote control over infected systems.[/profile]

173.name: MBR Wiper
173.uncertain_mes: [Wiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0041) is a family of destructive malware used in March 2013 during breaches of South Korean banks and media companies. (Citation: Dell Wiper)
173.profile: [profile]MBR Wiper, also known as wiper, is a family of destructive malware attributed to the New Roman Cyber Army. Its key technical behavior is targeting the Master Boot Record (MBR) sector to overwrite or replace it with destructive code, rendering the host system inoperable. It primarily targets Windows platforms. Related malware families with similar MBR-targeting behavior include WhisperGate and NEARMISS, which also perform MBR wiping and system disruption.
173.profile_without_enhance: [profile]MBR Wiper is a destructive malware family that overwrites or replaces the master boot record (MBR) to disrupt system availability, as indicated by its association with the Disk Wiping attack pattern. It is related to wiper malware families like WhisperGate, which also targets the MBR, and shares conceptual similarities with other disk wipers such as HermeticWiper and VPNFilter's NEARMISS component. The malware is known to use indicators like "principes" and "hastati."

174.name: NewRomanic Dropper
174.profile: [profile]NewRomanic Dropper is a malware dropper attributed to the New Roman Cyber Army intrusion set. It is associated with the broader Lazarus Group umbrella, specifically the Bluenoroff subgroup, as referenced by aliases like NewRomanic Cyber Army Team. This dropper is part of campaigns such as Operation DarkSeoul and is linked to similar first-stage dropper infrastructure and techniques used by other malware like 8.t dropper and kleptoparasite stealer. Its primary function is to deploy secondary payloads, often using document lures like COVID-19 alerts, and it operates on Windows platforms.
174.profile_without_enhance: [profile]NewRomanic Dropper is a malware dropper. It is associated with the NewRomanic Cyber Army Team, which is linked to groups including Hidden Cobra, Andariel, APT38, and Bluenoroff. The malware is used in operations such as DarkSeoul, Troy, GhostSecret, and AppleJeus. Its technical behavior involves acting as a first-stage dropper to deploy further payloads. The target platform is Windows, as it is delivered via document lures, including COVID-19 themed alerts.

175.name: Troy Malware Family
175.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
175.profile: [profile]The Troy malware family, also known as nmass, is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to the New Roman Cyber Army. It uses a Royal Road v7 document as a decoy, often themed around COVID-19 infections in Russia targeting Mongolian authorities, to drop an initial executable. Its technical behaviors include establishing a backdoor and communicating with a command-and-control (C2) server. The malware targets Windows platforms and has been linked historically to campaigns by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team, with infrastructure involving specific C&C control pages and data storage files.
175.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The Troy Malware Family, also known as ThreatNeedle, is a backdoor attributed to the Lazarus Group. It is deployed via malicious documents, such as a fake COVID-19 report, and installs a .NET-based executable. The malware communicates with a command-and-control (C&C) server, storing victim IDs and connection data in specific files like `favicon.icon` and `build.xnl`. It has been linked to historical campaigns like DarkSeoul and Operation LagTime, with infrastructure involving proxy control pages and MID servers.

176.profile: [profile]HTTP Troy, also known as http-shell, is a malware associated with the New Roman Cyber Army and historically linked to the Lazarus Group via the reuse of the specific ZIP password 'dkwero38oerA^t@#' from the Troy/DarkSeoul campaign. It is used in campaigns against Russian opposition and communicates via HTTP POST requests for command and control. The malware targets Windows platforms and has been distributed through compromised LinkedIn profiles.
176.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTP Troy, also known as Troy/DarkSeoul, is a malware historically linked to the Lazarus Group. A key technical indicator is the reuse of the specific ZIP archive password 'dkwero38oerA^t@#', which connects it to samples from the 2011 Troy/DarkSeoul campaign. This malware is associated with campaigns targeting entities like nuclear power plants.[/profile]

177.name: 3RAT
177.profile: [profile]3RAT is a malware attributed to the New Roman Cyber Army intrusion set. Its technical behaviors include creating a registry key for persistence to automatically launch on system startup, monitoring specific applications, and engaging in defined network interactions for command and control. The target platform is Windows systems, as indicated by its registry-based persistence mechanism.
177.profile_without_enhance: [profile]3RAT is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) malware. Its key technical behaviors include establishing persistence by creating a registry key for automatic execution on system startup. It monitors specific applications on the infected system and communicates with a command-and-control (C2) server via a defined network protocol. The target platform is the Windows operating system.

181.name: Disk Wiping
181.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may wipe or corrupt raw disk data on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. With direct write access to a disk, adversaries may attempt to overwrite portions of disk data. Adversaries may opt to wipe arbitrary portions of disk data and/or wipe disk structures like the master boot record (MBR). A complete wipe of all disk sectors may be attempted.

To maximize impact on the target organization in operations where network-wide availability interruption is the goal, malware used for wiping disks may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging additional techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)

On network devices, adversaries may wipe configuration files and other data from the device using [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `erase`.(Citation: erase_cmd_cisco)
181.profile: [profile]Disk Wiping is a MITRE ATT&CK technique with ID T1561 under the Impact tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and Network platforms. It involves adversaries overwriting raw disk data to disrupt system availability, targeting arbitrary portions, critical structures like the Master Boot Record (MBR), or entire sectors. This technique may use direct disk access, leverage third-party drivers like RawDisk, or employ network device CLI commands such as `erase`. Associated malware like MBR Wiper and groups including Winnti and Lazarus Group utilize this method for destructive attacks, often with worm-like propagation features.[/profile]
181.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Disk Wiping is a technique mapped to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1561 under the Impact tactic, targeting Windows, Linux, and Network platforms. It involves adversaries overwriting raw disk data or critical structures like the master boot record (MBR) to interrupt system availability. This can be achieved through direct disk access, potentially using third-party drivers like RawDisk, or on network devices via CLI commands such as `erase`. Malware implementing this may propagate using worm-like features and other techniques like Valid Accounts.

182.name: Spear Phishing
182.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
182.profile: [profile]Spear Phishing is a targeted social engineering technique under MITRE ATT&CK ID T1566, primarily used in the Initial Access tactic across multiple platforms. It involves sending tailored emails or messages to specific individuals or organizations, often containing malicious attachments or links designed to execute code, such as the Bankshot malware, or to harvest credentials. Threat actors like Lazarus, APT10, and Fancy Bear employ this method, utilizing evasive tactics like email spoofing, thread hijacking, and directing victims to call malicious numbers for further exploitation. The technique is distinct from broader phishing campaigns due to its focused targeting and integration with other attacks like User Execution.[/profile]
182.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear Phishing is a targeted social engineering technique, identified as a sub-technique of T1566 (Phishing) within the MITRE ATT&CK Initial Access tactic. It operates across multiple platforms by sending tailored electronic messages to specific individuals or organizations. The mechanics involve crafting lures that pose as a trusted source, often using email spoofing or thread hijacking, and delivering malicious attachments or links to execute code or harvest credentials. It is distinct from broad phishing campaigns due to its precise targeting.

183.name: Dark Seoul
183.profile: [profile]The entity "Dark Seoul" is a cyber campaign, not a MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is associated with the intrusion set "New Roman Cyber Army." The retrieved information describes unrelated MITRE techniques (T1597, T1001.001, T1597.002) for gathering closed-source intelligence and obfuscating C2 traffic, which are not directly applicable to defining this specific campaign entity. Therefore, a standard technique profile cannot be generated.
183.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Dark Seoul is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique but a campaign name. The provided retrieved information details unrelated techniques: T1597 (Search Closed Sources) involves gathering victim data from private or dark web sources for reconnaissance, T1001.001 (Junk Data) obfuscates C2 traffic with meaningless characters, and T1597.002 (Purchase Technical Data) focuses on buying technical details like credentials. No specific technical mechanics for a "Dark Seoul" attack pattern are described in this input.

184.name: Operation Troy
184.profile: [profile]Operation Troy is a cyber campaign attributed to the intrusion set New Roman Cyber Army. It involves compromising third-party servers for staging and command and control, as seen in techniques like T1584.004, and employs screen capture (T1113) for information gathering. The operation also uses obfuscation methods, such as adding junk data to C2 traffic (T1001.001), to evade detection.[/profile]
184.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Operation Troy is a cyber espionage campaign rather than a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It involves compromising third-party servers for staging and launching attacks, utilizing screen capture to gather intelligence, and employing junk data in command and control protocols to evade detection. The campaign is associated with threat groups like APT28 and Dragonfly, targeting various sectors for intelligence collection.

185.name: Watering Hole Attack
185.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls. Downgrade attacks typically take advantage of a systemâ€™s backward compatibility to force it into less secure modes of operation. 

Adversaries may downgrade and use various less-secure versions of features of a system, such as [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s or even network protocols that can be abused to enable [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) or [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040).(Citation: Praetorian TLS Downgrade Attack 2014) For example, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) versions 5+ includes Script Block Logging (SBL), which can record executed script content. However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.(Citation: CrowdStrike BGH Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL 2018)(Citation: att_def_ps_logging)

Adversaries may similarly target network traffic to downgrade from an encrypted HTTPS connection to an unsecured HTTP connection that exposes network data in clear text.(Citation: Targeted SSL Stripping Attacks Are Real)(Citation: Crowdstrike Downgrade) On Windows systems, adversaries may downgrade the boot manager to a vulnerable version that bypasses Secure Boot, granting the ability to disable various operating system security mechanisms.(Citation: SafeBreach)
185.profile: [profile]Watering Hole Attack, also known as T1608.004, is a technique under Resource Development. It involves preparing a compromised website, often one frequented by a specific target community, to stage malicious content such as JavaScript for a subsequent Drive-by Compromise (T1189). This can be achieved by injecting scripts into web pages, modifying files in cloud storage, or using malvertising. The intent is to exploit visitors' browsers, often after profiling them to ensure vulnerability, to gain initial access. Threat groups like Dragonfly, FIN7, and APT32 have employed this method.
185.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Watering Hole Attack is a technique within the Initial Access tactic (T1189) targeting web browsers across multiple platforms. It involves compromising or creating websites frequented by a specific target community, such as a particular industry or government sector. Adversaries stage malicious content, often JavaScript, on these sites to exploit visitors' browsers automatically upon access, typically without requiring further user interaction. This method is used to profile and compromise specific users based on shared interests or affiliations.

186.name: Masquerading as Update
186.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate features of their artifacts to make them appear legitimate or benign to users and/or security tools. Masquerading occurs when the name or location of an object, legitimate or malicious, is manipulated or abused for the sake of evading defenses and observation. This may include manipulating file metadata, tricking users into misidentifying the file type, and giving legitimate task or service names.

Renaming abusable system utilities to evade security monitoring is also a form of [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036).(Citation: LOLBAS Main Site)
186.profile: [profile]Masquerading, identified as MITRE ATT&CK T1036, is a Defense Evasion technique applicable across multiple platforms. It involves manipulating the name, location, or metadata of malicious files or processes to appear legitimate, such as by renaming system utilities, giving files deceptive extensions, or using names of trusted software updates or services to evade detection and deceive users. The technique is associated with numerous threat groups including APT28, Sandworm Team, and OilRig.
186.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Masquerading as Update is a technique within the broader Masquerading (T1036) tactic of Defense Evasion. It operates by manipulating malicious files or software to appear as legitimate system or application updates. This deception exploits user trust in update mechanisms, often involving the use of names, icons, or distribution channels that mimic genuine software patches to bypass security controls and facilitate initial access or execution.

187.name: Espionage
187.profile: [profile]Espionage is a strategic objective, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, and is often the goal of campaigns conducted by groups like New Roman Cyber Army. It is facilitated by techniques such as Software Deployment Tools (T1072) for lateral movement and remote code execution, Exfiltration Over C2 Channel (T1041) for data theft, and Archive via Custom Method (T1560.003) for obfuscating collected data prior to exfiltration.[/profile]
187.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Espionage is a broad cyber threat activity, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It describes the overarching goal of unauthorized information gathering, often involving multiple techniques like gaining access to software deployment tools (T1072) for lateral movement, exfiltrating data over command and control channels (T1041), and using custom archive methods (T1560.003) to prepare stolen data for theft. These actions are typically conducted by advanced persistent threat groups.

188.name: RSA 128-bit encryption
188.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise a network deviceâ€™s encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications. (Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Encryption can be used to protect transmitted network traffic to maintain its confidentiality (protect against unauthorized disclosure) and integrity (protect against unauthorized changes). Encryption ciphers are used to convert a plaintext message to ciphertext and can be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated decryption key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key.

Adversaries can compromise and manipulate devices that perform encryption of network traffic. For example, through behaviors such as [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601), [Reduce Key Space](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/001), and [Disable Crypto Hardware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/002), an adversary can negatively effect and/or eliminate a deviceâ€™s ability to securely encrypt network traffic. This poses a greater risk of unauthorized disclosure and may help facilitate data manipulation, Credential Access, or Collection efforts. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
188.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Weaken Encryption" (ID: T1600), categorized under the Impact tactic and applicable to Network devices. It involves compromising a network device's encryption capability to bypass data protection, for example by using sub-techniques like Reduce Key Space (T1600.001) or Disable Crypto Hardware (T1600.002) to negatively affect or eliminate secure traffic encryption, thereby increasing the risk of unauthorized data disclosure and facilitating other adversarial efforts.
188.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RSA 128-bit encryption is a specific implementation of asymmetric cryptography, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1573.002 for Command and Control. It operates within the Encryption tactic and is applicable across multiple platforms. This technique uses a public-private key pair where data encrypted with the public key can only be decrypted with the corresponding private key, ensuring secure communication. In adversary operations, it is commonly employed to conceal command and control traffic, often as part of a multi-layer encryption scheme or to establish secure channels for subsequent symmetric encryption.

189.name: Whois HackingTeam
189.profile: [profile]Whois HackingTeam, also known as Hacking Team, is a commercial surveillance vendor whose tools have been used by various actors, including the New Roman Cyber Army. Its known arsenal includes the FinFisher and Pegasus spyware suites, as well as exploits from providers like Vupen. The group's tools have been deployed against targets including citizen media organizations like Mamfakinch and are believed to have been sold to regimes in countries such as Sudan, Bahrain, and Kazakhstan. Its primary motivation is commercial, providing offensive cyber capabilities to government clients worldwide.
189.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the North Korean state-sponsored Lazarus Group, also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra, Bluenoroff, Andariel, and Whois HackingTeam, operating under the alias New Roman Cyber Army. Its key malware includes the Troy/DarkSeoul family (such as HTTP Troy, NewRomanic Dropper, and MBR wipers) and tools like 3RAT. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing, masquerading as software updates, and disk-wiping attacks. It is attributed to North Korea and primarily targets South Korean entities in the military, government, financial, and media sectors, with motivations for espionage and disruptive operations.
189.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Whois HackingTeam, also known as Hacking Team, is a private Italian company that develops and sells offensive intrusion and surveillance software to governments and law enforcement agencies. Its key tools include the Remote Control System (RCS) spyware, also known as Da Vinci or Galileo, and it has been linked to exploit providers like Vupen. The group is attributed to Italy and its commercial activities have been documented to supply tools to various state clients, including regimes with questionable human rights records such as Sudan, Bahrain, and Kazakhstan. Its primary motivation is commercial, providing cyber capabilities for state-sponsored surveillance, often targeting journalists, activists, and political dissidents globally.

Its tools and services have been linked to campaigns targeting journalists, activists, and political dissidents globally, with notable incidents involving the Moroccan citizen media group Mamfakinch. The group's activities are primarily financially motivated through the sale of its surveillance suite, and it gained significant notoriety following a major data breach in 2015 that exposed its internal operations and client list.

Key TTPs involve the sale and deployment of sophisticated commercial spyware and exploits to government clients for surveillance. 198.name: HTTP Communication
198.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
198.profile: [profile]HTTP Communication, known as T1102.002 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a Command and Control technique under the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves adversaries using legitimate external web services like social media or popular sites (e.g., Google, Twitter) to send commands to and receive output from a compromised system. Return traffic is concealed through actions such as posting forum comments, issuing pull requests, updating web documents, or sending tweets, leveraging the inherent SSL/TLS encryption and common traffic patterns of these services for stealth. The Bankshot malware is known to use this method.[/profile]
198.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTP Communication is a command and control technique (aligned with MITRE ATT&CK T1071.001 - Web Protocols) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries using standard HTTP/S traffic to blend with normal web activity, embedding commands and exfiltrated data within the protocol's various fields and headers to evade network detection and filtering. This method is commonly employed by numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and Turla, often in conjunction with other techniques like Domain Fronting for further obfuscation.

199.name: Process Injection
199.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may inject code into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. Process injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via process injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process. 

There are many different ways to inject code into a process, many of which abuse legitimate functionalities. These implementations exist for every major OS but are typically platform specific. 

More sophisticated samples may perform multiple process injections to segment modules and further evade detection, utilizing named pipes or other inter-process communication (IPC) mechanisms as a communication channel.
199.profile: [profile]Process Injection (T1055) is a Defense Evasion and Privilege Escalation technique used on Windows, Linux, and macOS. It involves executing arbitrary code within the address space of a legitimate live process to evade detection and potentially gain elevated privileges or access to system resources. Specific sub-techniques include DLL injection using APIs like `VirtualAllocEx` and `CreateRemoteThread`, PE injection, and proc memory injection via the `/proc` filesystem on Linux. It is associated with malware like Bankshot and groups including Winnti, APT41, and Wizard Spider.
199.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Process Injection is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1055 under the Defense Evasion and Privilege Escalation tactics for Windows, Linux, and macOS. It executes arbitrary code within the address space of a separate live process to evade detection and potentially gain elevated privileges. Common technical mechanics include using Windows APIs like `VirtualAllocEx`, `WriteProcessMemory`, and `CreateRemoteThread` to write and invoke code. Specific sub-techniques involve DLL injection, Portable Executable (PE) injection, and proc memory injection via the `/proc` filesystem on Linux. It is associated with numerous threat groups including APT41, Lazarus Group, and Wizard Spider.

200.name: File Wiping
200.profile: [profile]File Wiping is a destructive technique where adversaries overwrite or delete specific files to render data irrecoverable, distinct from broader disk wiping. It is often performed using secure deletion tools like Windows Sysinternals SDelete or native commands such as `del` and `rm`, though standard deletion may leave recoverable pointers. This technique aims to destroy individual files to disrupt availability and remove forensic evidence, and it can be associated with malware like Bankshot. It aligns with the Impact tactic in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, primarily targeting Windows platforms.
200.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File Wiping is a technique within the Impact tactic, likely targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries deliberately overwriting the contents of specific files to render the data irrecoverable, distinguishing it from simple deletion. This is often achieved by overwriting files with random data or specific patterns, sometimes using dedicated wiping tools or custom scripts to ensure forensic recovery is impossible. The technique is used to destroy evidence or disrupt operations by making critical files permanently unusable.

201.name: Data Collection
201.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may target user email to collect sensitive information. Emails may contain sensitive data, including trade secrets or personal information, that can prove valuable to adversaries. Emails may also contain details of ongoing incident response operations, which may allow adversaries to adjust their techniques in order to maintain persistence or evade defenses.(Citation: TrustedSec OOB Communications)(Citation: CISA AA20-352A 2021) Adversaries can collect or forward email from mail servers or clients.
201.profile: [profile]Email Collection, identified as T1114, is a Collection tactic used across Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. Adversaries target email to acquire sensitive data like trade secrets or incident response details by collecting or forwarding messages directly from mail servers or clients. This technique has sub-techniques for local collection from files like Outlook .ost or .pst files and for remote collection from services like Exchange or Office 365 using tools such as MailSniper. It is associated with groups including Silent Librarian, Scattered Spider, Ember Bear, and Magic Hound, and has been linked to malware like Bankshot.
201.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Data Collection is the adversary's process of gathering information from a target system or network, often as a precursor to exfiltration. This technique, which is not a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID but a high-level concept, falls under the Collection tactic. It can be performed on various platforms and involves methods such as automated collection using command scripts to search for and copy specific files, or targeting data from sources like user email, the clipboard via tools like clip.exe or Get-Clipboard, and connected removable media.

202.name: Network Reconnaissance
202.profile: [profile]Network Reconnaissance is a technique within the Reconnaissance tactic, applicable across multiple platforms, involving the gathering of information about a victim's network infrastructure. This includes identifying network devices, mapping network topology, and discovering security appliances through methods like active scanning or querying shared resources, as seen with commands like `net view` for network share discovery, to inform subsequent attack stages.
202.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Network Reconnaissance is a technique under the Reconnaissance tactic, applicable across multiple platforms, where adversaries gather information about a target's network infrastructure. This includes mapping the physical and logical arrangement of networks, identifying devices like routers and gateways, and discovering security appliances such as firewalls and intrusion detection systems. Information is collected through methods like active scanning, probing network traffic, and querying accessible data sets to identify vulnerabilities and plan subsequent attack stages.

203.name: Process Manipulation
203.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain and/or elevate access to victim systems. Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves or modifies adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups.(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021) These actions could also include account activity designed to subvert security policies, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass password duration policies and preserve the life of compromised credentials. 

In order to create or manipulate accounts, the adversary must already have sufficient permissions on systems or the domain. However, account manipulation may also lead to privilege escalation where modifications grant access to additional roles, permissions, or higher-privileged [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).
203.profile: [profile]Process Manipulation, also known as T1098 Account Manipulation, falls under the Persistence tactic and operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves adversaries with existing permissions modifying compromised accounts to maintain or elevate access, such as by altering credentials or permission groups, performing iterative password updates to bypass duration policies, or changing account settings to subvert security controls. It is associated with groups like Lazarus Group and malware like Bankshot.
203.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Process Manipulation is a technique adversaries use to alter legitimate processes to evade detection or elevate privileges. It is closely related to Process Injection (T1055) and Process Hollowing (T1093), where malicious code is inserted into or replaces the memory of a running process. This allows execution under the guise of a trusted process, potentially bypassing security controls. The technique is associated with groups like APT37 and Wizard Spider and can be used in tactics like Defense Evasion and Privilege Escalation.

210.name: Bankshot implant
210.uncertain_mes: [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first reported by the Department of Homeland Security in December of 2017. In 2018, [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used the [Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) implant in attacks against the Turkish financial sector. (Citation: McAfee Bankshot)
210.profile: [profile]Bankshot implant, also known as Bankshot, is a remote access tool (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group. It was used in 2018 in attacks against the Turkish financial sector. Technical behaviors include the use of PE rich header data, as seen in related implants like GhostSecret. It targets Windows platforms, functioning as an implant for remote access and data exfiltration.
210.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bankshot implant, also known as Bankshot, is a remote access tool (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus Group (Hidden Cobra). It was used in attacks against the Turkish financial sector and shares behavioral and code overlaps with other Lazarus tools like WinorDLL64 from Operation GhostSecret, indicating its use within that group's broader intrusion sets. It functions as an implant for remote access and control.

211.name: Exploit CVE-2018-4878
211.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network. The weakness in the system can be a software bug, a temporary glitch, or a misconfiguration.

Exploited applications are often websites/web servers, but can also include databases (like SQL), standard services (like SMB or SSH), network device administration and management protocols (like SNMP and Smart Install), and any other system with Internet-accessible open sockets.(Citation: NVD CVE-2016-6662)(Citation: CIS Multiple SMB Vulnerabilities)(Citation: US-CERT TA18-106A Network Infrastructure Devices 2018)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)(Citation: NVD CVE-2014-7169) On ESXi infrastructure, adversaries may exploit exposed OpenSLP services; they may alternatively exploit exposed VMware vCenter servers.(Citation: Recorded Future ESXiArgs Ransomware 2023)(Citation: Ars Technica VMWare Code Execution Vulnerability 2021) Depending on the flaw being exploited, this may also involve [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211) or [Exploitation for Client Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203).

If an application is hosted on cloud-based infrastructure and/or is containerized, then exploiting it may lead to compromise of the underlying instance or container. This can allow an adversary a path to access the cloud or container APIs (e.g., via the [Cloud Instance Metadata API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1552/005)), exploit container host access via [Escape to Host](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1611), or take advantage of weak identity and access management policies.

Adversaries may also exploit edge network infrastructure and related appliances, specifically targeting devices that do not support robust host-based defenses.(Citation: Mandiant Fortinet Zero Day)(Citation: Wired Russia Cyberwar)

For websites and databases, the OWASP top 10 and CWE top 25 highlight the most common web-based vulnerabilities.(Citation: OWASP Top 10)(Citation: CWE top 25)
211.profile: [profile]Exploit CVE-2018-4878 is a specific exploit for a vulnerability in Adobe Flash Player, used for initial access. It maps to the MITRE ATT&CK technique Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. The technical mechanic involves exploiting a use-after-free vulnerability (CVE-2018-4878) in Flash Player to execute arbitrary code when a victim accesses a malicious web page or document. It has been used by malware like Bankshot and is associated with threat groups such as APT28.[/profile]
211.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Exploit CVE-2018-4878 is a specific exploit for the Adobe Flash Player vulnerability CVE-2018-4878. This technique, which aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Initial Access, typically targets Windows and macOS platforms. The exploit leverages a use-after-free bug in the Flash Player ActionScript Virtual Machine to execute arbitrary code, often delivered via malicious Office documents or web pages to compromise a system. It is a documented public-facing application exploit used for initial network access.

220.name: Killdisk
220.uncertain_mes: [KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) is a disk-wiping tool designed to overwrite files with random data to render the OS unbootable. It was first observed as a component of [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) malware during cyber attacks against Ukraine in 2015. [KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) has since evolved into stand-alone malware used by a variety of threat actors against additional targets in Europe and Latin America; in 2016 a ransomware component was also incorporated into some [KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) variants.(Citation: KillDisk Ransomware)(Citation: ESEST Black Energy Jan 2016)(Citation: Trend Micro KillDisk 1)(Citation: Trend Micro KillDisk 2)
220.profile: [profile]KillDisk, also known as Win32/killdisk.nbo, is a disk-wiping tool attributed to groups including APT38, Sandworm Team, and Telebots. It was first observed as a component of BlackEnergy malware in attacks against Ukraine in 2015 and has evolved into standalone malware used in Europe and Latin America. Key behaviors include overwriting files with random data to render the OS unbootable, manually writing zeros to the first 512 bytes of drives to delete the Master Boot Record (MBR), and incorporating a ransomware component in later variants. It primarily targets Windows systems and has been used in cybersabotage campaigns against the Ukrainian financial sector.
220.profile_without_enhance: [profile]KillDisk, also known as Win32/KillDisk.NBO, is a malware attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set and associated with groups like Sandworm and Telebots. Its key technical behavior is performing cybersabotage by destroying disk data, specifically overwriting the first 512 bytes of each drive to delete the Master Boot Record and sending a control code, rendering systems inoperable. It primarily targets the Windows platform and has been used in targeted attacks against the Ukrainian financial sector.[/profile]

221.name: Wannacryptor
221.uncertain_mes: Today, we are announcing the release of KTAE, the Kaspersky Threat Attribution Engine. This code attribution technology, developed initially for internal use by the Kaspersky Global Research and Analysis Team, is now being made available to a wider audience. You can read more about KTAE in our official press release, or go directly to its info page on the Kaspersky Enterprise site.
221.profile: [profile]Wannacryptor, also known as WannaCry Ransomware, is attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set. Key technical behavior includes code similarities with an older Lazarus backdoor from 2015, specifically sharing unique hexadecimal strings in code sections, as identified in a beta version. Its primary target is Windows systems, leveraging exploits like EternalBlue for propagation. The malware is associated with ransomware and bitcoin-oriented attack campaigns.[/profile]
221.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Wannacryptor, also known as WannaCry Ransomware, is attributed to the Lazarus Group. Its technical behavior includes code similarities with an older Lazarus backdoor from 2015, sharing unique hexadecimal strings. The malware is a ransomware strain targeting Windows systems.

222.name: Win32/killdisk.nbo
222.profile: [profile]Win32/KillDisk.NBO, also known as KillDisk, is attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is manually opening and writing zeros to the first 512 bytes of each drive to delete the Master Boot Record (MBR). It targets the Windows platform. The malware is associated with the broader KillDisk family and has been observed in separate cyberattacks, with code similarities linking these activities.[profile]
222.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Win32/killdisk.nbo, also known as KillDisk, is a destructive malware attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is disk wiping by overwriting the Master Boot Record (MBR) with zeros, a function executed via a command like COMMAND_DESTROY_DISK. The malware primarily targets the Ukrainian financial sector with the goal of cyber-sabotage and has also been used in ransomware operations.

223.name: VMProtect
223.profile: [profile]VMProtect, also known as a packer or protector, is a commercial software protection tool frequently abused by threat actors like APT41 and Lazarus to obfuscate malware. Its key technical behavior involves packaging and encrypting executable code, with actors sometimes renaming its standard .vmp sections to .upx to evade detection. It targets Windows platforms and is associated with infrastructure indicators such as specific blacklisted UUIDs used to identify its protected modules.
223.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VMProtect is a commercial software protection and packing tool that is also repurposed by threat actors to obfuscate malware. It is notably used by APT41, who modifies its standard .vmp section names to mimic UPX (.upx) sections to evade detection. The tool's infrastructure includes known blacklisted UUIDs used for identification. Its primary target platform is Windows, where it is applied to pack and protect malicious binaries.

224.name: Enigma Protector
224.uncertain_mes: We recently found an active campaign that uses a fake employment pretext targeting Eastern Europeans in the cryptocurrency industry to install an information stealer.
224.profile: [profile]Enigma Protector, also known as Enigma Loader, is a software protection tool that has been used by the Lazarus intrusion set to protect malicious binaries, such as Banpolmex RAT, Nachocheese, and Hotwax, with version 3.7 under a single developer license observed in campaigns. It is employed in campaigns using fake employment pretexts targeting Eastern Europeans in the cryptocurrency industry to deploy information stealers.[/profile]
224.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Enigma Protector is a software protection tool, not malware itself, but it is used by threat actors like the Lazarus Group to obfuscate and protect malicious binaries. It has been applied in versions such as 3.7 with a single developer license. The tool is used to protect Windows binaries, as seen in malware families like Banpolmex RAT, Nachocheese, and Hotwax.

225.name: Nukesped (Win32/64)
225.profile: [profile]NukeSped (Win32/64) is a malware family also known as TigerRAT. It is attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set, also called Hidden Cobra. Key technical behaviors include using a downloader that communicates with a command-and-control (C2) server via pipe communication, performing session hijacking, and exfiltrating system information (such as username, computer name, MAC, and IP address) encoded in Base64 via HTTP POST. It targets Windows (32-bit and 64-bit), Android, and PowerShell environments. Its infrastructure involves C2 servers for receiving attacker commands.
225.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Nukesped (Win32/64) is a malware family also known as TigerRAT and detected as Win64/NukeSped, Android/NukeSped, or PowerShell/NukeSped. It is attributed to the Lazarus Group, also known as Hidden Cobra. Its technical behaviors include a downloader that collects and Base64-encodes system information (username, computer name, MAC, IP) for exfiltration to a C2 server, and it employs a Session Hijacking Module to hijack and decrypt live session tokens and cookies for replay attacks against services like Google OAuth. It primarily targets Windows and Android platforms.[profile]

226.name: Disk-Wiping
226.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may wipe or corrupt raw disk data on specific systems or in large numbers in a network to interrupt availability to system and network resources. With direct write access to a disk, adversaries may attempt to overwrite portions of disk data. Adversaries may opt to wipe arbitrary portions of disk data and/or wipe disk structures like the master boot record (MBR). A complete wipe of all disk sectors may be attempted.

To maximize impact on the target organization in operations where network-wide availability interruption is the goal, malware used for wiping disks may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging additional techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Novetta Blockbuster Destructive Malware)

On network devices, adversaries may wipe configuration files and other data from the device using [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `erase`.(Citation: erase_cmd_cisco)
226.profile: [profile]Disk Wipe is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1561 under the Impact tactic, targeting Windows, Linux, and Network platforms. It involves adversaries overwriting raw disk data to disrupt system availability, targeting arbitrary data portions or critical structures like the Master Boot Record (MBR). The technique can use direct disk writes or, on network devices, CLI commands like `erase`. Malware implementing this may propagate via worm-like features using techniques such as Valid Accounts and OS Credential Dumping. The intrusion-set Lazarus has been associated with this activity.[/profile]
226.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Disk-Wiping" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Disk Wipe (T1561) under the Impact tactic, targeting Windows, Linux, and Network platforms. This technique involves adversaries overwriting raw disk data to disrupt system availability, which can include corrupting specific structures like the master boot record (MBR) or wiping arbitrary disk sectors. Attackers may use direct disk access, potentially leveraging tools like the RawDisk driver, or employ network device CLI commands such as `erase`. Malware implementing this often has worm-like propagation features, using techniques like Valid Accounts and OS Credential Dumping to spread across a network, and is associated with groups including APT38, Sandworm Team, and Lazarus Group.

227.name: Code Obfuscation
227.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may obfuscate command and control traffic to make it more difficult to detect.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020) Command and control (C2) communications are hidden (but not necessarily encrypted) in an attempt to make the content more difficult to discover or decipher and to make the communication less conspicuous and hide commands from being seen. This encompasses many methods, such as adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, or impersonating legitimate protocols.
227.profile: [profile]Code Obfuscation is a sub-technique under Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027) within the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves making code or scripts difficult to analyze and detect by altering their appearance while preserving functionality. Specific methods include using string splitting (e.g., `"Wor"+"d.Application"`), manipulating character order and casing, employing escape characters and symbols (like `^`, `+`, `$`, `%`), and utilizing built-in encoding such as Base64. Tools like Invoke-Obfuscation are commonly used for this purpose. The technique is employed by groups including Lazarus to evade signature-based defenses.[/profile]
227.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Code Obfuscation is a sub-technique of Defense Evasion (T1027) used across multiple platforms to make files or information difficult to analyze. It involves encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obscuring payload contents to evade signature-based detection. This can include using compression, splitting files, or encoding strings to hide plaintext. The technique is often employed during initial access or execution, requiring user interaction to deobfuscate, and is commonly paired with other obfuscation methods like command obfuscation.

228.name: Phishing Campaigns
228.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
228.profile: [profile]Phishing (T1566) is an Initial Access technique used across multiple platforms. It involves sending electronic messages, such as emails with malicious attachments or links, to trick victims into executing code, often via user interaction. The technique includes targeted spearphishing and broader campaigns, employing social engineering like impersonation and evasive tactics such as email spoofing or thread hijacking. It is associated with groups like Lazarus, Kimsuky, and Sea Turtle.[/profile]
228.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Phishing Campaigns is a broad operational concept rather than a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, but it aligns with the tactics of Initial Access and Collection. It involves adversaries sending electronic messages, such as emails with malicious attachments or links, to execute code or harvest credentials. These campaigns use social engineering, like posing as a trusted source, and can employ evasive techniques including email spoofing, thread hijacking, or manipulating email metadata to bypass security.

229.name: API Hiding
229.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may use email rules to hide inbound emails in a compromised user's mailbox. Many email clients allow users to create inbox rules for various email functions, including moving emails to other folders, marking emails as read, or deleting emails. Rules may be created or modified within email clients or through external features such as the New-InboxRule or Set-InboxRule [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) cmdlets on Windows systems.(Citation: Microsoft Inbox Rules)(Citation: MacOS Email Rules)(Citation: Microsoft New-InboxRule)(Citation: Microsoft Set-InboxRule) Adversaries may utilize email rules within a compromised user's mailbox to delete and/or move emails to less noticeable folders. Adversaries may do this to hide security alerts, C2 communication, or responses to [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534) emails sent from the compromised account. Any user or administrator within the organization (or adversary with valid credentials) may be able to create rules to automatically move or delete emails. These rules can be abused to impair/delay detection had the email content been immediately seen by a user or defender. Malicious rules commonly filter out emails based on key words (such as malware, suspicious, phish, and hack) found in message bodies and subject lines. (Citation: Microsoft Cloud App Security) In some environments, administrators may be able to enable email rules that operate organization-wide rather than on individual inboxes. For example, Microsoft Exchange supports transport rules that evaluate all mail an organization receives against user-specified conditions, then performs a user-specified action on mail that adheres to those conditions.(Citation: Microsoft Mail Flow Rules 2023) Adversaries that abuse such features may be able to automatically modify or delete all emails related to specific topics (such as internal security incident notifications).
229.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Email Hiding Rules (T1564.008), categorized under Defense Evasion. It operates on Windows, macOS, and cloud email platforms. Adversaries abuse inbox or transport rules within a compromised user's mailbox to automatically move or delete emails, often using keywords like "malware" or "suspicious" in filters. Rules can be created via email clients or PowerShell cmdlets like `New-InboxRule` to hide security alerts or command-and-control communications, impairing detection. Groups such as FIN4 and Scattered Spider have been associated with this technique.[/profile]
229.profile_without_enhance: [profile]API Hiding is a Defense Evasion technique where adversaries conceal malicious API calls to avoid detection. This is achieved by using legitimate system APIs in a manner that blends with normal traffic, obfuscating the calls, or directly invoking lower-level system calls (syscalls) to bypass user-mode API hooks used by security monitoring tools. Adversaries may also tamper with API monitoring sensors.

230.name: Persistence
230.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may clear artifacts associated with previously established persistence on a host system to remove evidence of their activity. This may involve various actions, such as removing services, deleting executables, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), [Plist File Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1647), or other methods of cleanup to prevent defenders from collecting evidence of their persistent presence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm) Adversaries may also delete accounts previously created to maintain persistence (i.e. [Create Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136)).(Citation: Talos - Cisco Attack 2022)

In some instances, artifacts of persistence may also be removed once an adversaryâ€™s persistence is executed in order to prevent errors with the new instance of the malware.(Citation: NCC Group Team9 June 2020)
230.profile: [profile]Clear Persistence, identified as T1070.009, is a Defense Evasion technique where adversaries remove artifacts of previously established persistence to eliminate evidence. This involves actions like deleting services, executables, modifying the registry, altering Plist files, or removing created accounts. It is associated with groups like Lazarus, FIN7, APT10, and Sednit Group, and malware such as Xagent.
230.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Persistence is a core adversary objective (not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique ID) to maintain long-term access to a compromised system. Techniques for achieving persistence are diverse and platform-specific, often involving mechanisms that execute malicious code automatically upon system events like startup or user login. Examples include abusing Microsoft Office features such as add-ins (T1137.006), templates, or Outlook rules to execute code when Office applications launch, thereby maintaining access through common enterprise software. Adversaries may also later clear these persistence artifacts (T1070.009) to remove evidence of their presence.

232.name: Session Hijacking Module
232.profile: [profile]Session Hijacking Module is a component of the Nukesped (Win32/64) malware, attributed to the Unknown_Threat_Actor intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is actively hijacking live session tokens, such as from browser storage, to impersonate victims in real-time by reconstructing authorization headers and replaying authentication requests against services like Google's OAuth. It also dumps and decrypts browser cookies to enable account hijacking and replay attacks. The target platform is Windows systems. This module facilitates data exfiltration and credential theft for the parent malware.
232.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Session Hijacking Module is a malware module. Key technical behaviors include performing session hijacking, such as intercepting Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) sessions for lateral movement, and dumping and decrypting browser cookies to enable account hijacking and replay attacks on authenticated services. It is directly associated with the NukeSped malware family, which is attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set (Hidden Cobra).

233.name: Browser Credential Dumper
233.uncertain_mes: The Curious Case of â€œMontiâ€ Ransomware: A Real-World Doppelganger
233.profile: [profile]Browser Credential Dumper, also known as veeam dumper, is a credential theft tool. It is attributed to an unknown threat actor. Its key behavior is harvesting credentials from web browsers, including Chrome, Opera, and Edge Chromium, by accessing specific user data directories and files like 'Login Data'. The target platform is Windows. A Golang-compiled version of this tool is known as VALUEVAULT.[/profile]
233.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Browser Credential Dumper is a malware tool for harvesting credentials. It is a Golang-compiled version of the "Windows Vault Password Dumper" tool, attributed to APT34. Its key behavior is accessing browser data directories for Chrome, Opera, and Microsoft Edge to collect credential files like 'Login Data' and the 'os_crypt.encrypted_key' field for decryption. It targets Windows platforms.

234.name: Mimikatz
234.uncertain_mes: Trigona ransomware is a relatively new strain that security researchers first discovered in late October 2022. By analyzing Trigona ransomware binaries and ransom notes obtained from VirusTotal, as well as information from Unit 42 incident response, we determined that Trigona was very active during December 2022, with at least 15 potential victims being compromised.
234.profile: [profile]Mimikatz, also known as mimikatz, is a credential theft tool frequently used by various threat actors, including intrusion sets like OilRig, Iranian threat actors, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and the Winnti Group. Its key technical behavior involves extracting plaintext passwords, hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows memory, often executed via PowerShell scripts for defense evasion. It primarily targets Windows platforms and is commonly integrated into other malware frameworks, as seen in tools like wannamine, black basta, and hive, for post-exploitation activities like lateral movement.[/profile]
