234.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Mimikatz is a credential theft tool primarily used to extract plaintext passwords, hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows memory. It is frequently leveraged by threat actors for lateral movement and privilege escalation. Key techniques include using commands like "sekurlsa::pth" for Pass-the-Hash attacks and "privilege::debug" to enable necessary privileges, representing core tactics of Defense Evasion and Credential Access. It is commonly integrated into other malware frameworks and PowerShell scripts for post-exploitation activities on Windows systems.

235.name: RAdmin 3
235.profile: [profile]RAdmin 3 is a remote administration tool. It is referenced by other malware families like dharma and revil, which note its use for establishing remote connections to an IP address, but only if the RAdmin software is already installed on the target system. It is associated with an unknown threat actor and the criminal group Pinchy Spider. Its key technical behavior is enabling remote access, and it targets systems where the legitimate RAdmin software is present.
235.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RAdmin 3 is a legitimate remote administration tool (RAT) that can be misused for malicious purposes. It is referenced by threat actors like Pinchy Spider (associated with REvil) as a potential tool for establishing remote connections, specifically for connecting to a corresponding IP address, but this functionality only works if RAdmin is already installed on the target system.

236.name: LogMeIn
236.profile: [profile]LogMeIn is a legitimate cloud-based remote access software. The malware 'pyxie' contains commands to retrieve and clear LogMeIn credentials (!kill_lgmn_tokens, !get_lgmn_tokens), indicating it targets this software for credential theft. The threat actor 'Thrip' has been associated with potentially using LogMeIn for unauthorized access. The software is also listed among various remote access and financial tools targeted by credential-harvesting malware.
236.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LogMeIn is a legitimate cloud-based remote access software, but it has been targeted and abused by threat actors. The malware 'pyxie' contains commands specifically designed to retrieve and clear LogMeIn credentials from a compromised system, indicating its use in credential theft. The threat group Thrip has been observed in incidents potentially involving unauthorized access to LogMeIn accounts. This malware family primarily targets Windows systems to facilitate remote access and data exfiltration.

237.name: Browser Credential Dumping
237.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to dump credentials to obtain account login and credential material, normally in the form of a hash or a clear text password. Credentials can be obtained from OS caches, memory, or structures.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) Credentials can then be used to perform [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) and access restricted information.

Several of the tools mentioned in associated sub-techniques may be used by both adversaries and professional security testers. Additional custom tools likely exist as well.
237.profile: [profile]Browser Credential Dumping is a technique for Credential Access, typically on Windows, Linux, or macOS platforms. It involves extracting stored credentials from web browsers by reading specific local files or searching browser process memory. For example, on Windows, adversaries may read the Chrome 'Login Data' database file and execute a SQL query to retrieve encrypted credentials, which are then decrypted using functions like `CryptUnprotectData`. Similar methods target browsers like Firefox, Safari, and Edge to obtain plaintext passwords and usernames for lateral movement or privilege escalation.[/profile]
237.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Browser Credential Dumping is a credential access technique where adversaries extract saved website usernames and passwords from web browsers. They typically achieve this by reading and decrypting browser-specific local database files, such as the Chrome `Login Data` file, using SQL queries and Windows API functions like `CryptUnprotectData` that leverage the user's cached logon key. This method can be applied to various browsers including Firefox, Safari, and Edge, and adversaries may also search browser process memory for credential patterns.

238.name: Credential Dumping
238.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to dump credentials to obtain account login and credential material, normally in the form of a hash or a clear text password. Credentials can be obtained from OS caches, memory, or structures.(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix) Credentials can then be used to perform [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) and access restricted information.

Several of the tools mentioned in associated sub-techniques may be used by both adversaries and professional security testers. Additional custom tools likely exist as well.
238.profile: [profile]OS Credential Dumping, identified as T1003 under the Credential Access tactic, targets Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves extracting credential material like hashes or plaintext passwords from operating system structures, caches, and memory. Tools such as Mimikatz are commonly used to perform this dump, and the obtained credentials are frequently leveraged for subsequent Lateral Movement. The technique is associated with threat groups including APT28, APT29, and Mustang Panda.[/profile]
238.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credential Dumping is the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1003 under the Credential Access tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS. It involves adversaries extracting account login material like hashes or plaintext passwords from operating system components such as the Security Account Manager (SAM), Local Security Authority (LSASecrets), and memory using tools like Mimikatz. This enables lateral movement and privilege escalation, and is commonly leveraged by groups like APT28 and APT29.

239.name: Service Manipulation
239.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain and/or elevate access to victim systems. Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves or modifies adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups.(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021) These actions could also include account activity designed to subvert security policies, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass password duration policies and preserve the life of compromised credentials. 

In order to create or manipulate accounts, the adversary must already have sufficient permissions on systems or the domain. However, account manipulation may also lead to privilege escalation where modifications grant access to additional roles, permissions, or higher-privileged [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).
239.profile: [profile]Account Manipulation (T1098) is a persistence and privilege escalation technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, applicable across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves actions to preserve or modify access to a compromised account, such as altering credentials or permission groups. A specific technical method includes performing iterative password updates to bypass organizational password duration policies and extend the life of stolen credentials. This technique has been associated with threat actors including Lazarus Group, Scattered Spider, and HAFNIUM.
239.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Service Manipulation is a technique where adversaries alter system services to maintain persistence or elevate privileges. This can involve modifying service configurations, binaries, or registry entries to execute malicious code. The technique is associated with the Persistence and Privilege Escalation tactics in the MITRE ATT&CK framework and primarily targets Windows platforms.

240.name: Remote Access
240.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may use legitimate remote access tools to establish an interactive command and control channel within a network. Remote access tools create a session between two trusted hosts through a graphical interface, a command line interaction, a protocol tunnel via development or management software, or hardware-level access such as KVM (Keyboard, Video, Mouse) over IP solutions. Desktop support software (usually graphical interface) and remote management software (typically command line interface) allow a user to control a computer remotely as if they are a local user inheriting the user or software permissions. This software is commonly used for troubleshooting, software installation, and system management.(Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)(Citation: CrowdStrike 2015 Global Threat Report)(Citation: CrySyS Blog TeamSpy) Adversaries may similarly abuse response features included in EDR and other defensive tools that enable remote access.

Remote access tools may be installed and used post-compromise as an alternate communications channel for redundant access or to establish an interactive remote desktop session with the target system. It may also be used as a malware component to establish a reverse connection or back-connect to a service or adversary-controlled system.

Installation of many remote access tools may also include persistence (e.g., the software's installation routine creates a [Windows Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/003)). Remote access modules/features may also exist as part of otherwise existing software (e.g., Google Chromeâ€™s Remote Desktop).(Citation: Google Chrome Remote Desktop)(Citation: Chrome Remote Desktop)
240.profile: [profile]Remote Access Tools (T1219) is a Command and Control technique. It involves adversaries abusing legitimate software like desktop support or remote management tools (e.g., graphical or CLI interfaces, Chrome Remote Desktop) to establish interactive C2 channels, often post-compromise. These tools create sessions between hosts, allowing remote control as a local user, and their installation can include persistence mechanisms like Windows Services. It is associated with groups like Carbanak and MuddyWater.[/profile]
240.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Remote Access is a broad adversary behavior, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It encompasses the use of legitimate tools or services to establish interactive command and control. This includes software like remote desktop applications (e.g., Chrome Remote Desktop) and management tools, as well as hardware-based KVM-over-IP devices, which create sessions allowing remote control as a local user. These mechanisms are often installed post-compromise for persistent, redundant access and can be abused to bypass security controls, with associated groups including Carbanak, MuddyWater, and FIN7.[/profile]

241.name: File Manipulation
241.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain and/or elevate access to victim systems. Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves or modifies adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups.(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021) These actions could also include account activity designed to subvert security policies, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass password duration policies and preserve the life of compromised credentials. 

In order to create or manipulate accounts, the adversary must already have sufficient permissions on systems or the domain. However, account manipulation may also lead to privilege escalation where modifications grant access to additional roles, permissions, or higher-privileged [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).
241.profile: [profile]Account Manipulation, identified as T1098 under the Persistence tactic, operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS. Adversaries with sufficient permissions preserve or elevate access by modifying credentials or permission groups on a compromised account, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass password duration policies. This technique is associated with groups like Lazarus Group, Scattered Spider, and Hafnium.
241.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File Manipulation is a technique where adversaries insert, delete, or modify files to hide activity or influence outcomes. This can target stored data (T1492), such as Office files or databases, or data in transit (T1493). The specific mechanics depend on the file type and adversary goals, often requiring specialized access and expertise to impact business processes or decision-making.

242.name: VM Detection
242.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may leverage [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to log directly into accessible cloud hosted compute infrastructure through cloud native methods. Many cloud providers offer interactive connections to virtual infrastructure that can be accessed through the [Cloud API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/009), such as Azure Serial Console(Citation: Azure Serial Console), AWS EC2 Instance Connect(Citation: EC2 Instance Connect)(Citation: lucr-3: Getting SaaS-y in the cloud), and AWS System Manager.(Citation: AWS System Manager).

Methods of authentication for these connections can include passwords, application access tokens, or SSH keys. These cloud native methods may, by default, allow for privileged access on the host with SYSTEM or root level access. 

Adversaries may utilize these cloud native methods to directly access virtual infrastructure and pivot through an environment.(Citation: SIM Swapping and Abuse of the Microsoft Azure Serial Console) These connections typically provide direct console access to the VM rather than the execution of scripts (i.e., [Cloud Administration Command](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1651)).
242.profile: [profile]The entity "direct cloud vm connections" is formally known as T1021.008 under the Initial Access tactic, targeting cloud platforms. It involves adversaries using valid accounts to log directly into cloud-hosted virtual machines via native provider methods like the Azure Serial Console, AWS EC2 Instance Connect, or AWS System Manager, authenticating with passwords, tokens, or SSH keys. These connections grant direct console access, often with SYSTEM or root privileges, enabling environment pivoting without executing scripts.
242.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VM Detection, also known as T1497.001 (Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion: System Checks) under the Defense Evasion tactic, operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries execute system checks to identify artifacts of a virtual machine (VM) or sandbox environment, such as specific processes, files, registry keys, hardware properties (like fan or temperature sensors), or network adapter configurations. They may use WMI, PowerShell, or system information queries to perform these automated checks. If a VM is detected, the malware may alter its behavior to evade analysis, such as by exiting or withholding its core malicious payload.

244.name: Unknown_Threat_Actor
244.profile: [profile]This intrusion set is currently designated as an unknown threat actor, with no definitive attribution or standardized name available. Its operational characteristics and arsenal remain unconfirmed, lacking specific details on custom malware, tools, or key TTPs at this time. Similarly, its origin, target sectors, regions, and motivations are not yet identified, indicating it is under investigation or newly observed with limited public intelligence. Further analysis is required to classify and attribute this entity within the cyber threat landscape.
244.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set, likely a North Korean state-sponsored APT group, is known for targeting high-profile entities such as Sony Pictures Entertainment, from which it exfiltrated sensitive data including Social Security numbers. Its operations, possibly staged from locations like Bangkok and the St. Regis Hotel using high-speed wireless networks, employ initial access techniques like phishing and remote exploitation of public-facing applications, followed by data exfiltration and information leakage. The group's primary motivation is believed to be cyber espionage and data theft on behalf of North Korean interests.
244.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set, likely associated with the advanced persistent threat group APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and STRONTIUM), is attributed to Russia's military intelligence service (GRU). It is characterized by its use of custom malware such as X-Agent and X-Tunnel, alongside tools like Mimikatz and credential dumping techniques. Its primary tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) include spear-phishing, credential harvesting, and exploiting network vulnerabilities for lateral movement. The group primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in North America, Europe, and former Soviet states, with motivations centered on espionage, information theft, and geopolitical influence operations.
244.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, whose standardized APT group name is currently unknown, is a suspected threat actor. Based on the limited self-provided information, it is identified only as 'Unknown_Threat_Actor', indicating a lack of formal attribution or clear identifying characteristics. Without data on common aliases, key malware/tools, TTPs, origin, target sectors, or motivation, this profile represents a placeholder for an unclassified or emerging entity requiring further intelligence collection and analysis to define its operational footprint and distinguish it from known groups.
244.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]This intrusion set, likely the North Korean state-sponsored group known as Lazarus Group (also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra, and Zinc), is attributed to North Korea. It employs common initial access vectors like phishing and remote exploitation of public-facing applications, and its operations are characterized by high-impact data exfiltration and information leakage, often targeting sensitive data such as Social Security numbers. The group has been linked to major incidents, including the 2014 cyberattack on Sony Pictures Entertainment, and shows operational infrastructure overlaps with locations like Bangkok and the St. Regis Hotel. Its primary motivations are financial gain and strategic intelligence collection.
244.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set, strongly suspected to be the North Korean state-sponsored APT group known as Lazarus Group (also tracked as Hidden Cobra and Guardians of Peace), is attributed to North Korea. Its operations, such as the 2014 attack on Sony Pictures Entertainment in Bangkok, leverage high-speed wireless networks and infrastructure like the St. Regis Hotel for access. Key activities include remote exploitation of public-facing applications, sophisticated phishing for initial access, and subsequent data exfiltration, specifically targeting sensitive information such as Social Security numbers. The group's primary motivations are espionage and financial gain, focusing on high-profile corporate and entertainment sector targets.
244.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set, likely a North Korean state-sponsored APT group, is known for targeting high-profile entities like Sony Pictures Entertainment, with operations linked to infrastructure in Bangkok and the St. Regis Hotel. Its common aliases are not specified in the provided data. The group employs a range of techniques including phishing for initial access, remote exploitation of public-facing applications, and data exfiltration, specifically targeting sensitive information such as Social Security numbers. Its motivation is primarily attributed to espionage and disruptive operations, with a focus on the media and entertainment sector.
244.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]This intrusion set, likely associated with the North Korean state-sponsored APT group Lazarus, is also known as Hidden Cobra. It has been linked to the 2014 Sony Pictures Entertainment hack, where it used phishing and remote exploitation via open networks to breach systems, leading to the theft and leakage of sensitive data including Social Security numbers. The group's operations have involved infrastructure such as high-speed wireless networks and locations like Bangkok and the St. Regis Hotel. Key activities include data exfiltration and information leakage, with motivations attributed to cyber espionage and financial gain, targeting sectors like entertainment and media.
244.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, likely the North Korean state-sponsored group known as Lazarus Group (also APT38, Hidden Cobra), is attributed to North Korea and has been linked to high-profile attacks such as the 2014 breach of Sony Pictures Entertainment in Bangkok. Its key malware and tools include custom backdoors and destructive wipers, and it employs TTPs such as remote exploitation of internet-facing services, spear-phishing for initial access, and data exfiltration. The group primarily targets the entertainment, financial, and critical infrastructure sectors globally, with motivations centered on financial gain, espionage, and disruptive cyber operations.
244.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]This threat actor is likely the North Korean state-sponsored APT group known as Lazarus Group (also known as Hidden Cobra). Its key malware and tools are not specified here, but it employs TTPs including remote exploitation of open networks, phishing for initial access, and data exfiltration. The group is attributed to North Korea and has targeted entities such as Sony Pictures Entertainment, with operations linked to infrastructure like the St. Regis Hotel in Bangkok. Its primary motivations are believed to be financial gain and espionage, focusing on high-value corporate and entertainment sector targets to steal sensitive information like Social Security numbers.
244.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, likely the North Korean state-sponsored group Lazarus Group (also known as APT38, Hidden Cobra, and Zinc), is attributed to North Korea and has been linked to high-profile attacks such as the 2014 breach of Sony Pictures Entertainment in Bangkok. Its operations leverage custom malware and tools, and employ key tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) including remote exploitation via open networks, data exfiltration, and phishing for initial access. The group primarily targets the entertainment, financial, and government sectors globally, with motivations centered on financial theft, espionage, and disruptive cyber operations to support the regime's strategic interests.
244.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]This intrusion set, likely an advanced persistent threat (APT) group, is currently unnamed but has been observed targeting Sony Pictures Entertainment, indicating a focus on the media and entertainment sector. Its operational infrastructure includes high-speed wireless networks, and it has been linked to the exfiltration of sensitive personal data such as Social Security numbers. A primary initial access technique is the remote exploitation of vulnerabilities in internet-facing applications. The group's activity has been geolocated to Bangkok, suggesting potential operational ties to Southeast Asia, though definitive attribution remains uncertain.
244.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set, likely associated with the Lazarus Group (APT38), is also known as Hidden Cobra and Zinc. It employs sophisticated custom malware and tools, with its key TTPs including supply chain compromise through hardware manipulation (T1195.003) and extensive reconnaissance via open-source intelligence (T1593). The group is attributed to North Korea and has been linked to operations in locations like Bangkok, using infrastructure such as the St. Regis Hotel. Its primary motivation is financial gain, targeting high-value entities like Sony Pictures Entertainment to steal sensitive data, including Social Security numbers.

248.name: data exfiltration
248.profile: [profile]The entity is a high-level concept for data exfiltration, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, so it lacks a standard ID. It is associated with the Exfiltration tactic and can occur across multiple platforms. The process involves adversaries stealing data from a network, often using specific transport mechanisms like Exfiltration Over C2 Channel (T1041) or Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol (T1048). Data is frequently compressed or encrypted (T1560) prior to transfer, and exfiltration can be automated (T1020) or scheduled (T1029) to blend with normal traffic. Threat actors like UNC4210, Turla, and groups linked to similar techniques such as Gamaredon Group and Lazarus Group employ these methods.
248.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'data exfiltration' is a core adversary objective, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique with a unique ID. It represents the unauthorized transfer of data from a victim's network. This activity is a tactical goal within the Exfiltration tactic and can occur across various platforms. The actual mechanics depend on subordinate techniques, which define the specific methods such as automated transfer via scripts, using scheduled tasks, or employing protocols like C2 channels, webhooks, Bluetooth, or USB. Prior to transfer, data is often archived or encrypted using utilities like `clip.exe` or custom methods to obfuscate it.

249.name: information leakage
249.profile: [profile]Information Leakage is a technique where adversaries intentionally or inadvertently expose sensitive data. This can occur through misconfigured services, insecure data transfers, or by extracting and exposing information from repositories. The technique often facilitates further attacks like credential theft or lateral movement, and may involve compressing data before exfiltration or using platforms like code repositories for data transfer. It is associated with an unknown threat actor.
249.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Information Leakage is a technique where adversaries intentionally or inadvertently expose sensitive data. This can occur through misconfigured services, insecure data transmissions, or by extracting and revealing information from compromised systems. The leaked data often includes credentials, internal documents, or system details, which adversaries may use for further attacks like credential access or lateral movement. It is distinct from discovery techniques, focusing instead on the unauthorized disclosure of information already accessed.

250.name: remote exploitation via open networks
250.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may exploit remote services to gain unauthorized access to internal systems once inside of a network. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code.Â A common goal for post-compromise exploitation of remote services is for lateral movement to enable access to a remote system.

An adversary may need to determine if the remote system is in a vulnerable state, which may be done through [Network Service Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1046) or other Discovery methods looking for common, vulnerable software that may be deployed in the network, the lack of certain patches that may indicate vulnerabilities,  or security software that may be used to detect or contain remote exploitation. Servers are likely a high value target for lateral movement exploitation, but endpoint systems may also be at risk if they provide an advantage or access to additional resources.

There are several well-known vulnerabilities that exist in common services such as SMB(Citation: CIS Multiple SMB Vulnerabilities) and RDP(Citation: NVD CVE-2017-0176) as well as applications that may be used within internal networks such as MySQL(Citation: NVD CVE-2016-6662) and web server services.(Citation: NVD CVE-2014-7169)(Citation: Ars Technica VMWare Code Execution Vulnerability 2021) Additionally, there have been a number of vulnerabilities in VMware vCenter installations, which may enable threat actors to move laterally from the compromised vCenter server to virtual machines or even to ESXi hypervisors.(Citation: Broadcom VMSA-2024-0019)

Depending on the permissions level of the vulnerable remote service an adversary may achieve [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068) as a result of lateral movement exploitation as well.
250.profile: [profile]The entity maps to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1210, Exploitation of Remote Services, under the Lateral Movement tactic for Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves executing adversary-controlled code by exploiting software vulnerabilities in network-accessible services like SMB, RDP, MySQL, or VMware vCenter to gain unauthorized access to remote internal systems, often for lateral movement or privilege escalation. Adversaries may first use discovery techniques to identify vulnerable systems. Associated threat groups include APT28, MuddyWater, and Wizard Spider.[/profile]
250.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "remote exploitation via open networks" is a technique for initial access, likely aligning with MITRE ATT&CK's Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting platforms with internet-facing services. It involves exploiting software vulnerabilities or misconfigurations in exposed applications, such as web servers, databases, or network services, to execute adversary-controlled code and gain unauthorized entry into a network. This method is distinct from post-compromise lateral movement exploitation and focuses on internet-accessible attack surfaces.

251.name: Hacking
251.profile: [profile]The entity "Hacking" is a broad, non-specific term not directly mappable to a single MITRE ATT&CK technique ID or tactic. Based on retrieved context, it may encompass activities like manipulating hardware components in the supply chain to insert backdoors (T1195.003) or conducting reconnaissance by searching open websites, domains, and search engines (T1593, T1593.002) to gather victim information for subsequent attacks. These techniques are associated with groups like Kimsuky and Sandworm Team and support tactics including Initial Access and Reconnaissance across multiple platforms.[/profile]
251.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Hacking" is a generic attack-pattern term, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on retrieved context, it broadly encompasses activities like manipulating hardware in the supply chain (T1195.003) to insert backdoors into devices, and conducting reconnaissance by searching open websites/domains (T1593) or using search engines (T1593.002) to gather victim information for subsequent attacks.

256.name: Malicious Documents
256.profile: [profile]Malicious Documents is a malware delivery vector, also known as griffon or ave maria, and is attributed to groups including FIN7, Anthropoid Spider, Anunak, and the Lazarus Group. Key technical behaviors involve the use of initial malicious documents to deliver payloads, as seen in operations like OpBlockbuster, which utilize specific file hashes for initial infection stages. The primary target platform is Microsoft Office environments, leveraging document-based execution to compromise systems. Associated infrastructure and testing phases are documented in related campaign reports.
256.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Documents, also known as Initial Malicious Documents, is associated with groups including FIN7, Anthropoid Spider, Anunak, and Lazarus Group. It is used as an initial infection vector, often containing embedded payloads that are unpacked upon execution to deliver further malware components.

257.name: Haobao
257.profile: [profile]Haobao, also known as coredn, is attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set. It uses a hardcoded word "haobao" as a switch when executing from a Visual Basic macro. The malware is part of a sophisticated campaign targeting cryptocurrency and communicates with command and control infrastructure using specific PHP gateways like /API/hpb_gate[.]php.
257.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Haobao, also known as coredn, is a malware attributed to the Lazarus Group. It uses a hardcoded word "haobao" as a switch when executing from a Visual Basic macro. This malware is part of an ambitious campaign to establish sophisticated cryptocurrency cybercrime operations.

259.name: Bitcoin-Stealing Malware
259.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
259.profile: [profile]The malware, referred to as 'nmass' or 'Bitcoin-Stealing Malware', is a .NET-based Remote Access Trojan (RAT) attributed to the Lazarus intrusion set. Its key behaviors include using a malicious Royal Road v7 document as a decoy, dropping an initial executable (e.g., \os03C2.tmp), and establishing a backdoor. It specifically targets cryptocurrency, with capabilities for stealing Bitcoin wallets, and has been deployed in campaigns against Mongolian authorities using COVID-19-themed lures. Its infrastructure and technical execution show similarities to older campaigns associated with Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
259.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bitcoin-Stealing Malware, also known as Pony, is a credential and cryptocurrency stealer. It is associated with groups like FIN6 and FIN7. Its key behaviors include stealing passwords and Bitcoin wallets, and it can load additional malware. It targets cryptocurrency platforms, as indicated by its interaction with the 'HKCU\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt' registry key. Infrastructure and tooling for related campaigns can involve Cobalt Strike as a first-stage script.[/profile]

262.name: VBA Macro
262.profile: [profile]VBA Macro, also known as a Visual Basic for Applications Macro, is a technique used by threat actors like Unknown_Threat_Actor, APT28, Gold Cabin, Mummy Spider, and Mealybug. It is employed in malware such as Emotet, RTM, and Downdelph to deliver payloads via malicious documents (e.g., .doc, Excel files) that contain embedded macro code, often identified by strings like "_VBA_PROJECT". This method primarily targets Windows platforms to execute further malicious activities.[/profile]
262.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VBA Macro is a malware delivery mechanism, not a distinct family, used by groups like APT28, Gold Cabin, Mummy Spider, and Mealybug. It is embedded in malicious Microsoft Office documents (e.g., .doc, .xls) to execute payloads, often containing obfuscated code and strings like "_VBA_PROJECT". Its key behavior is leveraging social engineering to trick users into enabling macros, which then deploys secondary malware such as Emotet, RTM, or Downdelph onto Windows systems.

263.name: CoreDN
263.uncertain_mes:
This blog was written with support and contributions provided by Asheer Maholtra, Jessica Saavedra Morales, and Thomas Roccia.
McAfee Advanced Threat Research (ATR) analysts have discovered an aggressive Bitcoin-stealing phishing campaign by the international cybercrime group Lazarus that uses sophisticated malware with long-term impact.
263.profile: [profile]CoreDN (alias coredn) is attributed to the Lazarus Group. It is used in aggressive Bitcoin-stealing phishing campaigns, where it employs decoy documents such as Excel files named "CoreDn ~tmp001.xls" and utilizes the VBScript XOR macro technique for deployment. The malware is part of campaigns that also involve the PowerRatankba decoy document.
263.profile_without_enhance: [profile]CoreDN is a malware used in phishing campaigns by the Lazarus group. It is delivered via malicious Excel documents (e.g., CoreDn ~tmp001.xls) that employ VBScript XOR macro techniques, often as decoys alongside other malware like PowerRatankba. The campaigns are part of aggressive, long-term operations targeting Bitcoin theft.

264.name: Registry-Based Persistence
264.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may clear artifacts associated with previously established persistence on a host system to remove evidence of their activity. This may involve various actions, such as removing services, deleting executables, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), [Plist File Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1647), or other methods of cleanup to prevent defenders from collecting evidence of their persistent presence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm) Adversaries may also delete accounts previously created to maintain persistence (i.e. [Create Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136)).(Citation: Talos - Cisco Attack 2022)

In some instances, artifacts of persistence may also be removed once an adversaryâ€™s persistence is executed in order to prevent errors with the new instance of the malware.(Citation: NCC Group Team9 June 2020)
264.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Clear Persistence" (ID: T1070.009) under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows. It involves adversaries removing artifacts of previously established persistence mechanisms, such as deleting services, executables, or accounts, and modifying the Windows Registry or Plist files to eliminate evidence and prevent detection. This cleanup can also prevent errors when new malware instances execute. The technique is associated with an unknown threat actor.[/profile]
264.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Registry-Based Persistence is a technique for establishing persistence on Windows systems by modifying the Windows Registry. It aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK framework, though a specific ID is not provided in the input. The primary tactic is Persistence. Adversaries achieve this by creating or modifying specific registry keys, such as run keys or services, to execute malicious code automatically during system boot or user login. Examples from related content include abusing the "Office Test" registry key to load a DLL with Microsoft Office startup or using the Active Setup key to run a program specified in the StubPath value upon user logon.

265.name: Reflective DLL Injection
265.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may reflectively load code into a process in order to conceal the execution of malicious payloads. Reflective loading involves allocating then executing payloads directly within the memory of the process, vice creating a thread or process backed by a file path on disk (e.g., [Shared Modules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1129)).

Reflectively loaded payloads may be compiled binaries, anonymous files (only present in RAM), or just snubs of fileless executable code (ex: position-independent shellcode).(Citation: Introducing Donut)(Citation: S1 Custom Shellcode Tool)(Citation: Stuart ELF Memory)(Citation: 00sec Droppers)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL) For example, the `Assembly.Load()` method executed by [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) may be abused to load raw code into the running process.(Citation: Microsoft AssemblyLoad)

Reflective code injection is very similar to [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055) except that the â€œinjectionâ€ loads code into the processesâ€™ own memory instead of that of a separate process. Reflective loading may evade process-based detections since the execution of the arbitrary code may be masked within a legitimate or otherwise benign process. Reflectively loading payloads directly into memory may also avoid creating files or other artifacts on disk, while also enabling malware to keep these payloads encrypted (or otherwise obfuscated) until execution.(Citation: Stuart ELF Memory)(Citation: 00sec Droppers)(Citation: Intezer ACBackdoor)(Citation: S1 Old Rat New Tricks)
265.profile: [profile]Reflective DLL Injection is a sub-technique of Process Injection, identified as T1055.001, under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows platforms. It involves writing a self-mapping DLL into a target process's memory and manually performing the function of LoadLibrary to execute it, avoiding the need for the DLL file on disk. This method, including variations like reflective code loading (T1620), conceals execution within a legitimate process's own memory, evades process-based detection, and avoids file artifacts by keeping payloads encrypted in memory until runtime. It has been used by groups including Lazarus Group and Wizard Spider.
265.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Reflective DLL Injection is a sub-technique of Process Injection (T1055.001) under the Execution tactic, primarily targeting Windows. It involves writing a self-mapping DLL into the memory of a target process and manually performing the function of LoadLibrary to execute it, overcoming address relocation and avoiding the use of standard APIs like CreateRemoteThread. This method loads and executes the DLL entirely in memory, evading process-based detection by not creating a file on disk and allowing the payload to remain encrypted until runtime.

266.name: Decryption Routine
266.profile: [profile]Decryption Routine is a technique used by adversaries to reverse encryption or obfuscation applied to data, files, or command and control traffic. It functions as a core component for accessing concealed payloads, often implemented within malware or using system utilities like `certutil` or Windows `copy /b` commands. This process enables the execution of hidden malicious code and is associated with threat groups like Lazarus Group and MuddyWater.
266.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Decryption Routine is a technique used by adversaries to decrypt encrypted data or code, often as part of a broader execution or defense evasion strategy. It involves implementing specific algorithms or using system utilities to reverse encryption or obfuscation applied to malicious payloads or command and control traffic. This process is commonly associated with techniques like Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information (T1140) and Symmetric Cryptography (T1573.001), and is employed by numerous threat groups including Lazarus Group, APT28, and MuddyWater to reveal hidden malicious content.

267.name: Base64 Encoding
267.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may encode data with a standard data encoding system to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) information can be encoded using a standard data encoding system that adheres to existing protocol specifications. Common data encoding schemes include ASCII, Unicode, hexadecimal, Base64, and MIME.(Citation: Wikipedia Binary-to-text Encoding)(Citation: Wikipedia Character Encoding) Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.
267.profile: [profile]Base64 Encoding, identified as T1132.001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a sub-technique of Data Encoding under the Command and Control tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries using the standard Base64 binary-to-text encoding scheme to obfuscate command and control traffic, adhering to existing protocol specifications to make detection more difficult. This technique is commonly associated with threat groups such as Hafnium, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group.[/profile]
267.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Base64 Encoding is a sub-technique of Data Encoding (T1132.001) under the Command and Control tactic. It is a standard binary-to-text encoding scheme used to obfuscate command and control traffic by converting binary data into an ASCII string format, adhering to RFC 4648. This technique is employed by multiple threat groups, including Hafnium, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group, to evade detection by making malicious payloads appear as benign text within network protocols.[/profile]

268.name: XOR Encoding
268.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may encode data with a standard data encoding system to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) information can be encoded using a standard data encoding system that adheres to existing protocol specifications. Common data encoding schemes include ASCII, Unicode, hexadecimal, Base64, and MIME.(Citation: Wikipedia Binary-to-text Encoding)(Citation: Wikipedia Character Encoding) Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.
268.profile: [profile]The entity "XOR Encoding" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; the provided data strongly aligns with the technique "Standard Encoding" (T1132.001) under the Command and Control tactic. This technique involves encoding command and control traffic using common, protocol-compliant schemes like ASCII, Unicode, Base64, or MIME to obfuscate content and evade detection. It is distinct from non-standard or custom encoding methods and has been associated with groups including Hafnium, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group.
268.profile_without_enhance: [profile]XOR Encoding is a sub-technique for archiving collected data prior to exfiltration, identified as T1560.003. It falls under the Collection tactic and is platform-agnostic. The technique involves adversaries using a custom implementation of encryption, specifically applying XOR or stream ciphers to obfuscate data without relying on external libraries or utilities, as part of a custom archival method. It has been associated with groups like FIN6, Kimsuky, and Lazarus Group.

269.name: Process Enumeration Evasion
269.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may enumerate system and service logs to find useful data. These logs may highlight various types of valuable insights for an adversary, such as user authentication records ([Account Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1087)), security or vulnerable software ([Software Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1518)), or hosts within a compromised network ([Remote System Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1018)).

Host binaries may be leveraged to collect system logs. Examples include using `wevtutil.exe` or [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) on Windows to access and/or export security event information.(Citation: WithSecure Lazarus-NoPineapple Threat Intel Report 2023)(Citation: Cadet Blizzard emerges as novel threat actor) In cloud environments, adversaries may leverage utilities such as the Azure VM Agentâ€™s `CollectGuestLogs.exe` to collect security logs from cloud hosted infrastructure.(Citation: SIM Swapping and Abuse of the Microsoft Azure Serial Console)

Adversaries may also target centralized logging infrastructure such as SIEMs. Logs may also be bulk exported and sent to adversary-controlled infrastructure for offline analysis.

In addition to gaining a better understanding of the environment, adversaries may also monitor logs in real time to track incident response procedures. This may allow them to adjust their techniques in order to maintain persistence or evade defenses.(Citation: Permiso GUI-Vil 2023)
269.profile: [profile]The entity is a technique for Discovery, not Defense Evasion, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK ID T1654, named Log Enumeration, under the Discovery tactic and applicable to Windows and cloud platforms. It involves adversaries enumerating system, service, and security logs to gather intelligence, using native tools like `wevtutil.exe` or PowerShell on Windows and utilities such as Azure VM Agent's `CollectGuestLogs.exe` in cloud environments. This activity can reveal user authentication records, software details, and network hosts, and may also target centralized logging infrastructure like SIEMs for bulk export or real-time monitoring to track incident response.
269.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Process Enumeration Evasion is a Defense Evasion technique used on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries altering their behavior or using specific checks to avoid detection when enumerating system processes, a common precursor to activities like Process Injection (T1055). This evasion can include detecting debuggers via API calls like `IsDebuggerPresent()` or checking the PEB's `BeingDebugged` flag on Windows, and querying `/proc/self/status` on Linux to identify analysis environments, allowing malware to disengage or conceal its core functions.

271.name: 2017 Campaign
271.profile: [profile]The entity "2017 Campaign" is a campaign, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is associated with the identity "Sikorsky Military Programs" and potentially involves command and control (C2) infrastructure techniques. Related techniques include data obfuscation (T1001) to hide C2 traffic and the use of compromised virtual private servers (T1584.003) for infrastructure, as seen in campaigns by groups like Turla and Volt Typhoon.[/profile]
271.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "2017 Campaign" is an attack-pattern, but the provided information does not correspond to a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. The retrieved data describes distinct techniques: Data Obfuscation (T1001) conceals C2 traffic using junk data or steganography; Multilayer Encryption (T1079) tunnels custom encryption within protocols like HTTPS; and use of compromised Virtual Private Servers (T1584.003) for resilient infrastructure. The campaign's connection to identities like "Sikorsky Military Programs" suggests a targeted operation, but its specific technical mechanics are not detailed here.[/profile]

274.name: SofaCy group
274.profile: [profile]The Sofacy group, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Pawn Storm, Strontium, and TSAR Team, is a persistent cyber espionage threat active since at least 2008. Its arsenal includes custom tools like the OS X malware Komplex. The group is attributed to Russian state interests and primarily targets military and government entities in NATO countries, demonstrating a consistent focus on geopolitical intelligence collection.
274.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The Sofacy group is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, STRONTIUM, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, SedUploader, Zebrocy, and variants like SofacyCarberP. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing with malicious documents and macros, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and HTTPS-based command and control. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and media sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
274.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The Sofacy group, also widely known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, and STRONTIUM, is a highly active and persistent threat actor attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). It has been operational since at least 2008, primarily targeting military and government entities in NATO countries. The group employs a range of custom malware, including the OS X variant Komplex, and is known for its consistent use of spear-phishing and weaponized documents. Its campaigns are believed to be driven by espionage and geopolitical intelligence collection motives.
274.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The Sofacy group, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Pawn Storm, STRONTIUM, and Forest Blizzard, is a highly persistent intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence. It has been active since at least 2008, primarily targeting military and government entities in NATO countries. Its key malware includes the Komplex backdoor for OS X. The group is known for reusing and adapting its established toolset and attack methodologies in long-running campaigns, with its core motivation being strategic espionage.

Its key custom malware includes the X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, Zebrocy, Komplex, and the SofacyCarberp variant. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing with malicious macros, credential harvesting, and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and influence operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]

275.name: Fancy Bear
275.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
275.profile: [profile]Fancy Bear, also known as APT28, Sofacy, Sednit, and Pawn Storm, is a highly active Russian cyber espionage group attributed to the GRU's 85th Main Special Service Center (military unit 26165). It has been active since at least 2004 and is known for campaigns targeting political entities, such as the U.S. Democratic National Committee in 2016, and international organizations like the World Anti-Doping Agency. The group's arsenal includes tools like DownRage, and it frequently targets government, political, and sporting sectors, primarily motivated by strategic intelligence collection and geopolitical influence.
275.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) backdoor, X-Tunnel, Seduploader, and Zebrocy. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, political, and media organizations in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]

276.profile: [profile]APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, Pawn Storm, and STRONTIUM, is a cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's GRU Unit 26165, active since at least 2004. 278.name: Pawn Storm
278.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
278.profile: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, and STRONTIUM, is a Russian cyber espionage group attributed to the GRU's Unit 26165. Its arsenal includes custom malware like Sofacy and Sednit. The group employs spear-phishing, zero-day exploits, and large-scale brute-force credential attacks. It primarily targets government, political, and defense sectors in North America and Europe, including election-related entities and international organizations like WADA, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and geopolitical influence operations.
278.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Sofacy, Strontium, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular Xagent (X-Agent) backdoor, Seduploader, Xtunnel, and variants like Zebrocy. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and the use of encrypted command and control channels. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically units like 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations.[/profile]
278.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, and Sofacy, is a Russian state-sponsored intrusion set attributed to the GRU. The group primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage and information operations. Its activities show overlaps with other groups like APT29 in targeting patterns, and it has been observed in campaigns like Operation Pawn Storm, which involved widespread spear-phishing against think tanks and NGOs.

280.name: Carberp
280.uncertain_mes: The begining of spring seems to be an unsuccessful period of the year for cybercriminals in Eastern Europe. There is recent news referring to a neutralization of a group of hackers by joint cooperation between the Security Service of Ukraine with the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation (FSB) on the web. These hackers are responsible for the infamous Trojan called Carberp.
280.profile: [profile]Carberp, also known as Carberp Trojan, is a banking malware attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). Its key technical behaviors include modifying the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) to track payment software activity and exfiltrating data. The primary target platform is Windows, and it is associated with the JhuHugit malware family.
280.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Carberp, also known as Carberp Trojan, is a banking malware. It has specific functionality for modifying the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) and tracking payment software activity. Its source code has been reused by other malware, such as the reconnaissance malware Jhuhugit attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). The primary target platform is Windows systems.[/profile]
