282.name: LuckyStrike
282.profile: [profile]LuckyStrike is a malware backdoor. It is attributed to the SofaCy group and has been used in operations by Erudite Mogwai, which targeted Russian government and IT company infrastructure. Its key technical behavior is functioning as an agent backdoor for remote access and control. Target platforms include IT infrastructure systems. Supplementary information indicates it is mentioned in the context of campaigns also involving entities like skipper and kopiluwak, which are linked to the Turla group, suggesting potential overlap or shared targeting in broader cyber operations.
282.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LuckyStrike is a backdoor agent used in targeted operations by the threat actor Erudite Mogwai against Russian government and IT company infrastructure.

283.name: SofaCyCarberP
283.uncertain_mes: [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) is a credential and information stealing malware that has been active since at least 2009. [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s source code was leaked online in 2013, and subsequently used as the foundation for the [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) backdoor.(Citation: Trend Micro Carberp February 2014)(Citation: KasperskyCarbanak)(Citation: RSA Carbanak November 2017)
283.profile: [profile]SofaCyCarberP, also known as Carberp, is a credential and information stealing malware attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). It is a variant of the original Carberp malware, with known samples and command-and-control (C2) infrastructure tracked under the SofacyCarberp designation. The malware's primary function is data theft, and its activity is monitored through specific threat intelligence tags like SofacyCarberp in security platforms.
283.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SofaCyCarberP, also known as Sofacy Carberp, is a malware variant attributed to the APT28 group. It is a Carberp variant associated with Sofacy. Key technical indicators include the use of specific C2 domains like wrlqg1kmjxpgid1rodm and memory addresses such as 0x9104f000. Palo Alto Networks protections classify all known C2s as malicious and detect samples via WildFire. The malware is targeted by AutoFocus tags named SofacyCarberp.[/profile]

284.name: SofacyMacro
284.profile: [profile]SofacyMacro is a malware entity attributed to the Sofacy group (also known as APT28 or Fancy Bear). It is a macro-based malware, indicating its use of malicious macros within documents, likely Microsoft Office files, as an initial infection vector to deploy further payloads. Its primary target platforms are Windows systems, leveraging document-based social engineering for execution.[/profile]
284.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SofacyMacro is a malware entity. Its key technical behavior involves the use of malicious macros, indicating it is likely a document-based threat. No specific aliases, attributed groups, key TTPs beyond macro usage, target platforms, or infrastructure details are provided in the available data.

285.name: Loader
285.profile: [profile]Loader is a generic malware type. It is associated with the SofaCy group. Specific technical behaviors include functioning as a USB-based loader, as seen in variants like USBCulprit Loader, which is also linked to PlugX and 8.t dropper malware families. Its target platform is Windows systems, primarily via USB devices for initial infection. Infrastructure and supplementary information indicate it is used by multiple threat groups, including APT22, APT26, APT31, APT41, Aurora Panda, Calypso Group, Dragonok, Emissary Panda, Hellsing, Hurricane Panda, Leviathan, Mirage, Mustang Panda, Nettraveler, Nightshade Panda, Slime29, Samurai Panda, Stone Panda, UPS, Violin Panda, Ice Fog, Pirate Panda, Rancor, TA428, Tick, Tonto Team, and Karma Panda.
285.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Loader, also known as USBCulprit Loader, is a malware associated with numerous APT groups including APT22, APT26, APT31, APT41, Aurora Panda, Calypso Group, Dragonok, Emissary Panda, Hellsing, Hurricane Panda, Leviathan, Mirage, Mustang Panda, Nettraveler, Nightshade Panda, Slime29, Samurai Panda, Stone Panda, UPS, Violin Panda, Ice Fog, Pirate Panda, Rancor, TA428, Tick, Tonto Team, and Karma Panda. It is used to deploy other payloads, such as PlugX, via USB drives. Its technical indicators include hashes like 2FB731903BD12FF61E6F778FDF9926EE and 4A21F9B508DB19398AEE7FE4AE0AC380, and it is referenced in the context of other malware like Taurus Stealer and 8.t dropper.[/profile]

286.name: Malicious Macro
286.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may rely upon a user opening a malicious file in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to open a file that will lead to code execution. This user action will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001). Adversaries may use several types of files that require a user to execute them, including .doc, .pdf, .xls, .rtf, .scr, .exe, .lnk, .pif, .cpl, .reg, and .iso.(Citation: Mandiant Trojanized Windows 10)

Adversaries may employ various forms of [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) and [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027) to increase the likelihood that a user will open and successfully execute a malicious file. These methods may include using a familiar naming convention and/or password protecting the file and supplying instructions to a user on how to open it.(Citation: Password Protected Word Docs) 

While [Malicious File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002) frequently occurs shortly after Initial Access it may occur at other phases of an intrusion, such as when an adversary places a file in a shared directory or on a user's desktop hoping that a user will click on it. This activity may also be seen shortly after [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534).
286.profile: [profile]Malicious File, identified as T1204.002 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is an Execution tactic technique primarily targeting Windows platforms. It involves an adversary relying on a user to open a malicious file, such as .doc, .pdf, .xls, .scr, .exe, .lnk, or .iso, to gain code execution. This is often facilitated by social engineering, such as spearphishing, and adversaries may increase success by using familiar file names, password-protecting files, or placing files in shared directories. The technique is associated with numerous threat groups including APT28, Lazarus Group, and FIN7.[/profile]
286.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Macro is a technique where adversaries embed malicious code within Microsoft Office documents to achieve execution when a user enables macros. It is formally identified as MITRE ATT&CK T1204.002 under the Execution tactic, primarily targeting Windows platforms. The technique works by using social engineering to trick users into opening documents (like .doc or .xls files) and enabling macros, which then executes payloads such as downloading additional malware. It is often delivered via spearphishing attachments and may employ obfuscation to evade detection.

287.name: C2 Communication
287.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
287.profile: [profile]Bidirectional Communication is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1102.002 under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across multiple platforms by abusing legitimate external web services like social media sites (e.g., Twitter) or cloud platforms (e.g., Google) for two-way command and control. The compromised system receives commands and sends output back over the same service channel, using methods such as posting forum comments, making pull requests, updating documents, or sending tweets. This provides cover through normal network traffic and benefits from the service's inherent SSL/TLS encryption. The technique is associated with groups including APT28, Lazarus Group, and FIN7.[/profile]
287.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "C2 Communication" is a core concept in adversary behavior, referring to the establishment of command and control channels for remote manipulation of compromised systems. This activity is fundamental to the Command and Control tactic and can occur across various platforms. Technical mechanics involve adversaries using diverse protocols and services, such as legitimate web services or social media, to send commands and receive data, often employing encryption like SSL/TLS to blend with normal traffic and avoid detection. Supplementary context includes related techniques for obfuscating this traffic (Data Obfuscation) and maintaining communication through fallback channels if the primary one is blocked.

288.name: Decryption Algorithm
288.profile: [profile]Decryption Algorithm is a technique used by adversaries to conceal command and control traffic by employing a known symmetric encryption algorithm, such as AES, DES, 3DES, Blowfish, or RC4, which uses the same key for both encryption and decryption. This method, referenced in the context of techniques like T1573.001, is utilized by groups including SofaCy, MuddyWater, and APT28. Implementations may be vulnerable if secret keys are embedded within malware, allowing for potential reverse engineering and decryption of the traffic.
288.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Decryption Algorithm" is a fundamental component of adversary tradecraft, often paired with encryption to obfuscate data. It is not a standalone MITRE ATT&CK technique but a core mechanism used within techniques like T1573.001 (Symmetric Cryptography), T1032 (Standard Cryptographic Protocol), and T1024 (Custom Cryptographic Protocol) under the Command and Control tactic. These techniques involve using algorithms, from standard ones like AES to custom or poorly implemented schemes, to decrypt concealed C2 traffic. The decryption key is often embedded within malware, making reverse engineering a primary method for defenders to recover the algorithm and key to decrypt intercepted communications.

289.name: HTTPS Communication
289.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
289.profile: [profile]HTTPS Communication, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1102.002 under the Command and Control tactic, involves adversaries using legitimate, encrypted web services like social media platforms (e.g., Twitter) or cloud services (e.g., Google Docs) for bidirectional command and control. Infected systems receive commands and exfiltrate data by performing actions such as posting forum comments, submitting pull requests, or updating hosted documents, blending this traffic with normal, SSL/TLS-encrypted web activity to evade detection. This technique is associated with groups including APT28, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.[/profile]
289.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTPS Communication is a technique within the Command and Control tactic, mapped to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1071.001 (Web Protocols). It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries use the HTTPS protocol to blend malicious traffic with normal, encrypted web traffic, embedding commands and data within standard HTTP/S packets and headers to bypass network detection and filtering. This method is commonly employed by numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and Turla, to conceal their communications.

290.name: System Reconnaissance
290.uncertain_mes: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture. Adversaries may use this information to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This behavior is distinct from [Local Storage Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1680) which is an adversary's discovery of local drive, disks and/or volumes. Tools such as [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) can be used to gather detailed system information. If running with privileged access, a breakdown of system data can be gathered through the systemsetup configuration tool on macOS. Adversaries may leverage a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to gather detailed system information (e.g. show version).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A) On ESXi servers, threat actors may gather system information from various esxcli utilities, such as `system hostname get` and `system version get`.(Citation: Crowdstrike Hypervisor Jackpotting Pt 2 2021)(Citation: Varonis) Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud providers such as AWS, GCP, and Azure allow access to instance and virtual machine information via APIs. Successful authenticated API calls can return data such as the operating system platform and status of a particular instance or the model view of a virtual machine.(Citation: Amazon Describe Instance)(Citation: Google Instances Resource)(Citation: Microsoft Virutal Machine API) [System Information Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082) combined with information gathered from other forms of discovery and reconnaissance can drive payload development and concealment.(Citation: OSX.FairyTale)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)
290.profile: [profile]System Information Discovery, identified as T1082, is a Discovery tactic technique used across Windows, macOS, Linux, Network, IaaS, and Containers platforms. It involves gathering detailed OS and hardware data like version, patches, and architecture to inform follow-on actions. Specific mechanics include using the `systeminfo` command on Windows, the `systemsetup` tool on macOS, CLI commands like `show version` on network devices, `esxcli` utilities on ESXi, and cloud provider APIs (AWS, GCP, Azure) for instance metadata. It is distinct from local storage discovery and is associated with numerous threat groups including APT41, Lazarus Group, and FIN7.
290.profile_without_enhance: [profile]System Reconnaissance is a technique within the Discovery tactic, applicable across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries gathering detailed information about a victim's operating system, hardware, and configuration to shape follow-on actions. This can be achieved through native commands like `systeminfo` and `systemsetup`, network device CLI commands such as `show version`, cloud instance APIs, and utilities like `sc query` for service discovery. The gathered data, including OS version, architecture, patches, and running services, is used to drive payload development, evasion, and target selection.

307.name: Unknown_Threat_Actor
307.profile: [profile]This intrusion set, whose primary name remains unknown, is believed to be linked to Russian intelligence and is associated with the persona Guccifer 2.0. Its key tools include the use of the Guccifer 2.0 moniker for operations, and its key tactics, techniques, and procedures involve information operations and data theft. The group is attributed to Russia and its target sectors and regions are not specified, with its primary motivation likely being strategic influence and espionage.
307.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian state-sponsored group APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, STRONTIUM, Sofacy, and operationally as Guccifer 2.0. It is attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). Key techniques include sophisticated defense evasion by manipulating Windows PKI internals, runtime code signing, and clearing event logs. The group has historically targeted political entities, including the U.S. Democratic National Committee and election candidates, motivated by espionage and geopolitical influence operations.
307.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set, likely operating as the APT group known as "APT28" (also referred to as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, or STRONTIUM), is a sophisticated threat actor attributed to Russia's military intelligence service, the GRU. It is distinguished by its use of custom malware families like X-Agent, X-Tunnel, and Sofacy, and its operations frequently employ spear-phishing and credential harvesting. The group primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage and information gathering to support Russian strategic interests.
307.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]This unknown threat actor is suspected to be the group publicly tracked as APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, and NOBELIUM. It is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and is known for sophisticated operations, including the 2020 SolarWinds supply chain compromise. The group's key malware includes the SUNBURST backdoor, GoldMax, and Cobalt Strike, and it employs TTPs such as credential dumping, token theft, and living-off-the-land techniques. Its primary targets are government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.
307.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian state-sponsored group APT28 (Fancy Bear), also known as Sednit, STRONTIUM, Sofacy, and operationally as Guccifer 2.0. It is attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). Key techniques include sophisticated defense evasion by manipulating Windows PKI internals, runtime code signing, and clearing event logs. The group has historically targeted political entities, including the U.S. Democratic National Committee and election candidates, motivated by espionage and geopolitical influence operations.

It is attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). Key TTPs include sophisticated defense evasion techniques such as manipulating Windows PKI internals for code signing, runtime signature forgery, and clearing event logs. The group primarily targets political entities, government organizations, and election-related infrastructure, particularly in the United States and Europe, with campaigns against the Democratic National Committee and U.S. political targets, motivated by espionage and geopolitical influence operations.

It is attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). Key techniques include sophisticated defense evasion by manipulating Windows PKI internals, runtime code signing, and clearing event logs. 307.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian state-sponsored APT group APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, STRONTIUM, and the persona Guccifer 2.0. Its key TTPs include sophisticated defense evasion through the manipulation of Windows PKI internals and code signing (Runtime Signers), the use of encrypted configuration files, and the abuse of schemes for C2 obfuscation. It is attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU) and primarily targets U.S. political entities, such as the Democratic National Committee, election candidates, and government sectors, with a motivation for political espionage and intelligence gathering in support of Russian strategic interests.
307.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian state-sponsored APT group APT28 (Fancy Bear), also known as Sednit, STRONTIUM, Sofacy, and operationally as Guccifer 2.0. 307.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian state-sponsored APT group APT28 (Fancy Bear), also known as Sednit, STRONTIUM, Sofacy, and operationally as Guccifer 2.0. Its primary motivation is political espionage and intelligence gathering to support Russian strategic interests.

309.name: Increasingly Sophisticated Cyberattacks
309.profile: [profile]Increasingly Sophisticated Cyberattacks is a general concept, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. The retrieved information describes related technical methods adversaries use to achieve sophistication, such as installing malicious component firmware (T1542.002) to establish persistent, hard-to-detect access that evades operating system defenses and integrity checks, or modifying malicious tools to remove detection indicators (T1066) and bypass security software like antivirus.[/profile]
309.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Increasingly Sophisticated Cyberattacks" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to be a general descriptive phrase. The retrieved information details specific techniques: Component Firmware (potentially T1542.002) involves adversaries compromising hardware components to install malicious firmware for persistence and evasion of host-based defenses. Indicator Removal from Tools (T1066) describes adversaries modifying malicious software to remove detection signatures, such as by using software packing, to bypass antivirus quarantine. These represent examples of sophisticated technical mechanics within broader cyberattack campaigns.

314.name: Russian Military Intelligence Agency (GRU)
314.uncertain_mes: A data breach involving the Cuban-focused online platform, DimeCuba.com, has been claimed by the SILKFIN AGENCY. According to the threat actor, the breach occurred on August 26, 2024, and reportedly compromised a wide array of sensitive data, including over 1 million SMS records, more than 100,000 email records, and extensive transaction details.
314.profile: [profile]The Russian Military Intelligence Agency (GRU) is a state-sponsored cyber actor, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, and Strontium. Its arsenal is linked to operations conducted by the GRU's 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS). Key TTPs involve extensive cyber operations against IT and OT networks. The group is definitively attributed to the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU). Its primary targets are defense ministries and other military entities, closely aligning with Russian strategic interests, and it is motivated by espionage and disruptive operations.
314.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity is the Russian Military Intelligence Agency (GRU), Russia's premier military intelligence service, which is definitively attributed as the sponsor of the APT group known as APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team). This group's key custom malware includes X-Agent and X-Tunnel, and it employs sophisticated spear-phishing and zero-day exploits. The GRU, through units like 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) and Unit 26165, conducts cyber operations primarily targeting government, military, diplomatic, and media sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
314.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The entity is the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU), Russia's premier military intelligence service. It is known to sponsor and conduct cyber operations through associated intrusion sets, most notably APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, Strontium, and Forest Blizzard). Key malware and tools linked to its activities include those used by these sub-groups. Its Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) involve extensive cyber espionage and disruptive operations. The group is attributed to the Russian government and primarily targets sectors of strategic interest to Russia, including defense ministries, military organizations, and government entities globally, with motivations centered on espionage, geopolitical influence, and supporting Russian state objectives.
314.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) is the premier military intelligence agency of Russia, directly responsible for state-sponsored cyber operations. It is the parent organization for several distinct APT groups, including APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Sofacy, Strontium, and Forest Blizzard) and Killnet. These groups are known for deploying custom malware like X-Agent and using spear-phishing for initial access. Their operations are strategically aligned with Russian government interests, extensively targeting defense ministries, military organizations, and government sectors globally, primarily for espionage and disruptive purposes.
314.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The Russian Military Intelligence Agency (GRU) is a state military intelligence directorate of the Russian Federation, widely attributed as the sponsor and operator of multiple cyber intrusion sets, most notably APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, Strontium, and Pawn Storm). Key associated malware includes the X-Agent backdoor and Zebrocy. Its cyber units, such as the 85th Main Special Service Center, conduct operations characterized by spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and strategic cyber espionage. The GRU primarily targets government, military, political, and media sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by intelligence collection and information operations in alignment with Russian state interests.[/profile]
314.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The Russian Military Intelligence Agency (GRU) is a state intelligence directorate of the Russian Armed Forces, widely attributed as the sponsor of multiple advanced persistent threat (APT) groups. 316.profile: [profile]The malware is named x-agent-android, also known as x-agent. It is attributed to the APT28 group, also known as Fancy Bear. It is part of a wider suite of implants including Sofacy and X-Tunnel, and is specifically designed for the Android mobile platform, where it can be involved in traffic proxying and data exfiltration activities.

The malware is attributed to the APT28 group. Key technical behaviors include its use as an implant and its capability to communicate via HTTP(S) requests, which can be identified by specific HTTP headers like 'X-Requested-With' that are appended with Android application names. Its target platform is Android mobile devices. The malware is part of a broader suite of tools used by the group across multiple operating systems.

318.name: Windows PKI Internals
318.profile: [profile]Windows PKI Internals is a technique targeting the Windows Public Key Infrastructure, likely for credential access or defense evasion, but it lacks a standard MITRE ATT&CK ID. The technique involves exploiting internal PKI components, such as certificate stores or trust mechanisms, to obtain or misuse cryptographic credentials like private keys or to subvert code signing validation. This can enable adversaries to impersonate trusted entities or bypass security policies that rely on digital signatures for trust establishment.
318.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Windows PKI Internals" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to an adversary's manipulation of the Windows Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) internal components, such as Subject Interface Packages (SIPs) and trust providers, to subvert code signing and signature validation. This involves hijacking functions like CryptSIPDllGetSignedDataMsg or CryptSIPDllVerifyIndirectData by modifying specific Registry keys (e.g., in HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography\OID\EncodingType 0\) to point to malicious DLLs, thereby misleading the operating system into accepting unauthorized code as legitimately signed. This activity is associated with techniques like SIP and Trust Provider Hijacking (T1553.003) and primarily targets the Windows platform for defense evasion and persistence.

319.name: Signature Levels
319.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to mimic features of valid code signatures to increase the chance of deceiving a user, analyst, or tool. Code signing provides a level of authenticity on a binary from the developer and a guarantee that the binary has not been tampered with. Adversaries can copy the metadata and signature information from a signed program, then use it as a template for an unsigned program. Files with invalid code signatures will fail digital signature validation checks, but they may appear more legitimate to users and security tools may improperly handle these files.(Citation: Threatexpress MetaTwin 2017)

Unlike [Code Signing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1553/002), this activity will not result in a valid signature.
319.profile: [profile]Invalid Code Signature, identified as T1036.001 under the Defense Evasion tactic, targets Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves adversaries copying metadata and signature information from a legitimately signed program to use as a template for an unsigned malicious file, creating a signature that mimics a valid one but will fail proper digital validation checks. This forgery can make files appear more legitimate to users and may cause security tools to handle them improperly, as referenced in the Threatexpress MetaTwin 2017 report. It is distinct from Code Signing (T1553.002) as it does not produce a cryptographically valid signature.
319.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Signature Levels" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it likely relates to manipulating digital signature validation processes to bypass security controls. This can involve creating invalid signatures that mimic legitimate ones, or hijacking system components like Subject Interface Packages (SIPs) and trust providers to spoof validation checks, making malicious files appear trusted. These methods are associated with techniques such as Invalid Code Signature (T1036.001) and SIP and Trust Provider Hijacking (T1553.003).

320.name: Schemes
320.profile: [profile]Schemes is a general concept for data encoding systems used in command and control (C2) traffic to evade detection. It encompasses both standard encoding (T1132.001) and non-standard encoding (T1132.002) sub-techniques under the Command and Control tactic. Standard schemes include ASCII, Unicode, hexadecimal, Base64, and MIME, while non-standard schemes are custom modifications of these. These techniques are employed by various threat actors, including MuddyWater, Sandworm Team, and Lazarus Group, to obfuscate C2 communications.[/profile]
320.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Schemes is a technique used by adversaries to encode command and control (C2) data to evade detection. It encompasses both standard and non-standard data encoding systems. Standard schemes include ASCII, Unicode, hexadecimal, Base64, and MIME, which adhere to existing protocol specifications. Non-standard schemes are custom modifications of these standards. This technique is associated with groups like Lazarus Group, APT33, and Sandworm Team.

321.name: Signers
321.profile: [profile]Signers, also known as Code Signing (T1553.002) under the Defense Evasion tactic, targets Windows, Linux, and macOS. This technique involves adversaries digitally signing malicious executables and scripts with valid certificatesâ€”obtained through purchase, theft, or creation of self-signed certificatesâ€”to appear authentic and bypass security checks that trust signed code. Related groups include Daggerfly, Patchwork, and Promethium.
321.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Code Signing" (T1553.002) under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves adversaries digitally signing malicious executables or scripts using self-signed, stolen, or purchased certificates to mimic software authenticity and bypass security checks that trust signed code. This technique is distinct from forging invalid signatures and is associated with groups like Daggerfly, Patchwork, and Promethium.

322.name: Root Keys
322.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may search for private key certificate files on compromised systems for insecurely stored credentials. Private cryptographic keys and certificates are used for authentication, encryption/decryption, and digital signatures.(Citation: Wikipedia Public Key Crypto) Common key and certificate file extensions include: .key, .pgp, .gpg, .ppk., .p12, .pem, .pfx, .cer, .p7b, .asc. Adversaries may also look in common key directories, such as ~/.ssh for SSH keys on * nix-based systems or C:\Users\(username)\.ssh\ on Windows. Adversary tools may also search compromised systems for file extensions relating to cryptographic keys and certificates.(Citation: Kaspersky Careto)(Citation: Palo Alto Prince of Persia) When a device is registered to Entra ID, a device key and a transport key are generated and used to verify the deviceâ€™s identity.(Citation: Microsoft Primary Refresh Token) An adversary with access to the device may be able to export the keys in order to impersonate the device.(Citation: AADInternals Azure AD Device Identities) On network devices, private keys may be exported via [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands such as `crypto pki export`.(Citation: cisco_deploy_rsa_keys) Some private keys require a password or passphrase for operation, so an adversary may also use [Input Capture](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056) for keylogging or attempt to [Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) the passphrase off-line. These private keys can be used to authenticate to [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) like SSH or for use in decrypting other collected files such as email.
322.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Unsecured Credentials: Private Keys" (ID: T1552.004) under the Credential Access tactic, applicable to Linux, Windows, and network device platforms. Adversaries search for insecurely stored private key files (e.g., .key, .pem, .pfx, .ppk) in common directories like ~/.ssh or via tools, to authenticate to remote services like SSH or decrypt files. They may export keys from devices registered to Entra ID or from network devices using CLI commands like `crypto pki export`. If keys are passphrase-protected, adversaries may employ keylogging or brute-force attacks. This technique has been associated with threat actors including Scattered Spider and Volt Typhoon.[/profile]
322.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Root Keys" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it refers to cryptographic master keys, particularly in macOS systems. In OS X prior to El Capitan, adversaries with root access can read the memory of the `securityd` daemon to find the master key sequence. This master key, derived from the user's logon password via PBKDF2, is cached in memory. Once extracted, an adversary can decrypt the user's logon keychain to obtain plaintext passwords for various services like WiFi, mail, and certificates.

323.name: EKUs
323.profile: [profile]The entity 'EKUs' is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to be referenced by an unknown threat actor. The retrieved information describes three distinct ATT&CK techniques: Exfiltration Over USB (T1052.001) used by groups like Tropic Trooper, Data Obfuscation with Junk Data (T1001.001) used by APT28, and Archive via Custom Method (T1560.003) used by groups including FIN6 and Lazarus Group, which involves custom compression or encryption like XOR prior to data exfiltration.[/profile]
323.profile_without_enhance: [profile]EKUs, or Enhanced Key Usage Object Identifiers, are a component of digital certificates used to define the purpose for which a certificate's public key may be used. This attack-pattern involves adversaries abusing or manipulating EKU fields in fraudulent or stolen certificates to bypass security policies, enable malicious code execution, or impersonate trusted entities, thereby facilitating unauthorized access or malware deployment.

324.name: Runtime Signers
324.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may modify systems in order to manipulate the data as it is accessed and displayed to an end user, thus threatening the integrity of the data.(Citation: FireEye APT38 Oct 2018)(Citation: DOJ Lazarus Sony 2018) By manipulating runtime data, adversaries may attempt to affect a business process, organizational understanding, and decision making.

Adversaries may alter application binaries used to display data in order to cause runtime manipulations. Adversaries may also conduct [Change Default File Association](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/001) and [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to cause a similar effect. The type of modification and the impact it will have depends on the target application and process as well as the goals and objectives of the adversary. For complex systems, an adversary would likely need special expertise and possibly access to specialized software related to the system that would typically be gained through a prolonged information gathering campaign in order to have the desired impact.
324.profile: [profile]Runtime Data Manipulation is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1565.003 under the Impact tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries modifying systems to alter data as it is accessed and displayed, threatening data integrity to affect business processes and decision-making. Specific technical mechanics include altering the application binaries used to display data, or conducting techniques like Change Default File Association and Masquerading to achieve a similar effect. It has been associated with threat group APT38.
324.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Runtime Signers is a technique where adversaries manipulate or forge code signing certificates at runtime to bypass security checks and execute malicious code. This method involves dynamically generating or altering digital signatures on executables and scripts after they are loaded into memory, allowing unsigned or tampered code to appear legitimate to the system and security tools. It is associated with groups like Daggerfly, Patchwork, and Promethium, and it undermines trust mechanisms by exploiting the runtime environment to evade detection.

326.name: Protected Processes
326.profile: [profile]The entity "Protected Processes" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique but a Windows security feature. Based on retrieved context, adversaries may target processes not protected by Windows Protected Process Light (PPL) to disable security tools. For example, an attacker could terminate unprotected helper processes of an Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) tool by abusing the Process Explorer driver, which, when combined with hooking a debugger into the EDR process, can crash the security software and prevent service restarts.[/profile]
326.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Protected Processes is a Windows-specific defense mechanism that falls under the Defense Evasion tactic. It is not a MITRE ATT&CK attack pattern but a security feature that adversaries aim to bypass. Attackers may target unprotected child or helper processes of security tools, such as EDRs, to disable them. For instance, they can abuse the Process Explorer driver to terminate these non-protected processes, halting security services and evading detection. This technique is often part of a broader strategy to disable or modify system tools.

327.name: Sednit Group
327.profile: [profile]Sednit Group, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Pawn Storm, Strontium, Sofacy, and Tsar Team, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). Its arsenal includes custom malware such as SedUploader and LoJax, and it is known for sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns and exploiting firmware vulnerabilities. The group primarily targets government, military, and diplomatic sectors in Europe, North America, and former Soviet states, with motivations centered on espionage, information theft, and geopolitical influence operations, showing overlaps with clusters like Forest Blizzard and Iron Twilight.
327.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Sednit, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, alongside SedUploader, Sedreco, and Zebrocy. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, credential harvesting via keylogging, and the use of modular backdoors with obfuscated RTTI for defense evasion. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, media, and political sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.
327.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The Sednit Group, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Pawn Storm, STRONTIUM, and Forest Blizzard, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's military intelligence (GRU). The group primarily targets government, military, and political organizations across North America, Europe, and former Soviet states, with motivations centered on espionage, information theft, and geopolitical influence.
327.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The Sednit Group is a highly active and well-resourced cyber espionage intrusion set, also widely known as APT28, Fancy Bear, STRONTIUM, Sofacy, and Pawn Storm. Its operations are characterized by the use of a sophisticated and evolving malware suite, including first-stage backdoors like SedUploader and tools such as LoJax for persistence via compromised system firmware. The group's primary Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) involve spear-phishing, zero-day exploits, and complex multi-stage attacks. 329.name: Sofacy
329.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
329.profile: [profile]Sofacy, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, and STRONTIUM, is a Russian state-sponsored threat group attributed to the GRU's 85th Main Special Service Center (military unit 26165). Its arsenal includes custom malware such as DealersChoice and Carberp variants. The group is known for sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns and close-access operations. Its primary motivation is espionage and information operations, with key targets including government, political, and defense sectors in the US and Europe, notably compromising the Democratic National Committee in 2016 and organizations like the World Anti-Doping Agency.
329.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set 'Sofacy' is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular Xagent (X-Agent) backdoor, Seduploader, Xtunnel, and components like Sedreco, as well as variants like Carberp. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and the use of modular backdoors with encrypted command and control channels. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically units like 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations.

It is attributed to Russia's military intelligence agency, the GRU, and primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in North America and Europe, with a motivation focused on espionage and information operations.

330.profile: [profile]Tsar Team, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Sofacy, and STRONTIUM, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU military unit 26165. Its extensive arsenal includes custom malware like X-Agent and Sofacy, and it employs spear-phishing and credential-harvesting campaigns. The group is primarily motivated by espionage and information operations, targeting government, defense, political organizations, and media sectors globally, with notable operations against the U.S. Democratic National Committee and international anti-doping agencies.
