331.name: Xagent
331.profile: [profile]Xagent, also known as x-agent, is a malware attributed to the Sednit Group (APT28). Its key technical behaviors include the use of obfuscated Run-Time Type Information (RTTI) in its modules. The malware targets Windows and Linux platforms, with distinct versions developed for each, and has been associated with the xtunnel tool for network communications.
331.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Xagent, also known as X-Agent, is a malware attributed to APT28. It employs persistence mechanisms to maintain long-term access and uses TLS for command and control (C2) communication. The malware targets Windows and Linux platforms, with its modules featuring obfuscated Run-Time Type Information (RTTI) in later versions. Its infrastructure includes C&C servers for operations.[/profile]

332.name: Xtunnel
332.uncertain_mes: [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) a VPN-like network proxy tool that can relay traffic between a C2 server and a victim. It was first seen in May 2013 and reportedly used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) during the compromise of the Democratic National Committee. (Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) (Citation: Invincea XTunnel) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2)
332.profile: [profile]Xtunnel, also known as XTunnel, is a VPN-like network proxy tool attributed to the APT28 (Sednit Group) threat actor. It functions to relay command and control (C2) traffic between a server and a compromised victim. First observed in May 2013, it was notably used during the compromise of the Democratic National Committee. Its primary technical behavior is acting as a traffic relay for C2 communication.
332.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Xtunnel, also known as xtunnel, is a malware attributed to the APT28 group, with its oldest known sample dating back to 2013. Its key technical behavior is establishing command and control (C2) communication, utilizing infrastructure such as C&C Servers and employing the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol for its C2 channels.

333.name: Agentkernel
333.profile: [profile]AgentKernel is a malware component associated with the Sednit Group (also known as APT28). It functions as a core module facilitating communication between various malware plugins and the command-and-control server, using functions like giveMessage() and takeMessage() to relay data for components such as RemoteShell, FSModule, and RemoteKeylogger. Its infrastructure is linked to operations involving other Sednit tools like XTunnel.[/profile]
333.profile_without_enhance: [profile]AgentKernel is a malware component, also known as QUADAGENT, associated with APT groups APT28 (Sednit) and APT34 (OilRig/Greenbug). Its key technical behaviors include functioning as a communication kernel that facilitates message passing between modules like RemoteShell, FSModule, and RemoteKeylogger, and it connects to a C&C server over the internet. This malware targets Windows platforms and is part of broader espionage campaigns.

334.name: Sedreco
334.uncertain_mes:
The post contains malware samples analyzed in the APT28 reports linked below. I will post APT29 and others later.
List of References (and samples mentioned) listed from oldest to newest:
- APT28_2011-09_Telus_Trojan.Win32.Sofacy.A
- APT28_2014-08_MhtMS12-27_Prevenity
- APT28_2014-10_Fireeye_A_Window_into_Russia_Cyber_Esp.Operations
- APT28_2014-10_Telus_Coreshell.A
334.profile: [profile]Sedreco, also known as Trojan.Win32.Sofacy.A and Coreshell.A, is attributed to the Sednit Group (APT28). Its payload relies on a configuration stored in a registry key named 'Path' or a file named 'msd', initially embedded in its dropper, and creates a mutex named 'MutYzAz' or 'AZZYMTX'. It is deployed by other APT28 malware like Seduploader and Downdelph, and primarily targets the Windows platform.
334.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Sedreco, also known as Sofacy, is a malware attributed to the APT28 group. Its payload relies on a configuration stored in a registry key named 'Path' or in a file named 'msd', initially embedded in its dropper, and creates a mutex named 'MutYzAz' or 'AZZYMTX'. It is deployed via other malware like Seduploader and Downdelph and communicates with a C&C server.

335.name: Cryptrawpacket
335.profile: [profile]Cryptrawpacket is a data object used for encrypted communication, specifically as the output of the AgentKernel::translateToController() method in the Xtunnel malware, which is associated with APT28 (Sednit Group). Its buffer format includes a header with an agent ID and a checksum.
335.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Cryptrawpacket is a malware component. It is associated with the APT28 group and is used within the xtunnel malware framework. Its key technical behavior involves the encryption of communication data; specifically, the AgentKernel::translateToController() method encrypts a ModuleMsg object to produce a CryptRawPacket, which contains a buffer with a header comprising an agent ID and a checksum.

336.name: Mailchannel
336.profile: [profile]MailChannel is a malware component, also known as a communication channel object within the Xagent framework, used by the Sednit Group (APT28). Its key technical behavior is implementing a command-and-control (C2) channel over email, where messages are sent and received as email attachments. It is associated with spam bot operations for email templating and sender/subject spoofing, and it integrates with other malware like Gophe for managing email sending parameters and recipient filtering.
336.profile_without_enhance: [profile]MailChannel is a malware component that implements an Xagent communication channel over email, where messages are sent and received as email attachments, as referenced in the xtunnel malware associated with APT28. It is utilized for command and control (C2) operations.

344.name: Command and Control
344.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may communicate using a custom command and control protocol instead of encapsulating commands/data in an existing [Application Layer Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071). Implementations include mimicking well-known protocols or developing custom protocols (including raw sockets) on top of fundamental protocols provided by TCP/IP/another standard network stack.
344.profile: [profile]Custom Command and Control Protocol is formally identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1094 under the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves adversaries developing or mimicking custom protocols, including the use of raw sockets, on top of standard network stacks like TCP/IP to communicate with compromised systems, instead of using common application layer protocols. This method is associated with the Sednit Group and the Xtunnel malware. Related techniques for obscuring C2 traffic include Data Obfuscation (T1001), adding Junk Data (T1001.001), and using Multi-Stage Channels (T1104).[profile]
344.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Command and Control is a core adversarial tactic (TA0011) within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, representing the adversary's actions to communicate with and direct compromised systems. It encompasses various techniques for establishing and maintaining covert communication channels, such as employing custom protocols (T1094), using multi-stage channels (T1104) to obfuscate infrastructure, and obfuscating C2 traffic through methods like adding junk data (T1001.001) to blend with legitimate network activity and evade detection.

345.name: Modular Backdoor
345.profile: [profile]Modular Backdoor is a software backdoor technique (Tactic: Persistence, Platform: Linux, macOS) where adversaries modify system authentication components like PAM modules (e.g., pam_unix.so) to accept adversary-supplied credentials or harvest plaintext passwords, enabling unauthorized account access. This method is distinct from hardware supply chain compromises and is associated with groups like Sednit.
345.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Modular Backdoor" is a software-based attack pattern. It functions as a backdoor that is designed with a modular architecture, allowing adversaries to dynamically load and execute various malicious plugins or components to extend its functionality post-compromise. This modularity enables flexible and persistent remote access, command and control, and the deployment of additional tools or payloads on the victim system.

346.name: Keylogging
346.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may log user keystrokes to intercept credentials as the user types them. Keylogging is likely to be used to acquire credentials for new access opportunities when [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003) efforts are not effective, and may require an adversary to intercept keystrokes on a system for a substantial period of time before credentials can be successfully captured. In order to increase the likelihood of capturing credentials quickly, an adversary may also perform actions such as clearing browser cookies to force users to reauthenticate to systems.(Citation: Talos Kimsuky Nov 2021)

Keylogging is the most prevalent type of input capture, with many different ways of intercepting keystrokes.(Citation: Adventures of a Keystroke) Some methods include:

* Hooking API callbacks used for processing keystrokes. Unlike [Credential API Hooking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056/004), this focuses solely on API functions intended for processing keystroke data.
* Reading raw keystroke data from the hardware buffer.
* Windows Registry modifications.
* Custom drivers.
* [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601) may provide adversaries with hooks into the operating system of network devices to read raw keystrokes for login sessions.(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
346.profile: [profile]Keylogging, identified as T1056.001, is a Credential Access technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, primarily targeting Windows platforms. It functions by capturing user keystrokes to intercept credentials, often employed when OS credential dumping fails. Specific technical methods include hooking API callbacks for keystroke processing, reading raw data from the hardware buffer, modifying the Windows Registry, deploying custom drivers, or altering system images on network devices to gain access. This technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and Kimsuky.[/profile]
346.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Keylogging, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1056.001 under the Credential Access tactic, primarily targets Windows systems. It captures user keystrokes to intercept credentials, often used when credential dumping fails. Specific technical methods include hooking API callbacks for keystroke processing, reading raw data from the hardware buffer, modifying the Windows Registry, deploying custom drivers, and leveraging system image modifications on network devices. This technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and Kimsuky.

347.name: File Exfiltration
347.profile: [profile]File Exfiltration is a technique where adversaries transfer collected data out of a victim network. This technique, often associated with groups like Sednit, can involve automated processes and may utilize other methods for the actual transfer, such as Exfiltration Over C2 Channel or Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol. Data is frequently encrypted before exfiltration to avoid detection.
347.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File Exfiltration is a technique for stealing data from a compromised system, categorized under the Exfiltration tactic. It involves transferring files containing sensitive information out of the victim's network. This process often follows data collection and may be automated or scheduled to blend with normal traffic. The exfiltrated data is frequently encrypted before transfer using utilities like RAR or zip to evade detection, and the actual transfer can occur over various channels, including command and control or alternative protocols.

348.name: 0-day Exploits
348.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may develop exploits that can be used during targeting. An exploit takes advantage of a bug or vulnerability in order to cause unintended or unanticipated behavior to occur on computer hardware or software. Rather than finding/modifying exploits from online or purchasing them from exploit vendors, an adversary may develop their own exploits.(Citation: NYTStuxnet) Adversaries may use information acquired via [Vulnerabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588/006) to focus exploit development efforts. As part of the exploit development process, adversaries may uncover exploitable vulnerabilities through methods such as fuzzing and patch analysis.(Citation: Irongeek Sims BSides 2017)

As with legitimate development efforts, different skill sets may be required for developing exploits. The skills needed may be located in-house, or may need to be contracted out. Use of a contractor may be considered an extension of that adversary's exploit development capabilities, provided the adversary plays a role in shaping requirements and maintains an initial degree of exclusivity to the exploit.

Adversaries may use exploits during various phases of the adversary lifecycle (i.e. [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190), [Exploitation for Client Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203), [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068), [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211), [Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212), [Exploitation of Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1210), and [Application or System Exploitation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/004)).
348.profile: [profile]This entity, known as "Develop Capabilities: Exploits" with MITRE ID T1587.004, is a Resource Development technique. It involves adversaries developing their own exploits rather than acquiring them externally. The development process can leverage vulnerability information and employ methods like fuzzing and patch analysis to discover bugs. These custom exploits are then used across the attack lifecycle for purposes such as initial access, execution, and privilege escalation, and have been associated with groups like UNC3886, Volt Typhoon, and Leviathan.[/profile]
348.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "0-day Exploits" is a specific type of exploit targeting unknown vulnerabilities. It aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Exploitation for Client Execution" (T1203) under the Execution tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. These exploits take advantage of undisclosed software bugs to cause unintended behavior, enabling initial access or code execution. They are often developed in-house through methods like fuzzing or acquired exclusively, providing a significant advantage as no patch exists. Groups like UNC3886, Volt Typhoon, and Leviathan have been associated with such capabilities.

349.name: Mailchannel Communication
349.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
349.profile: [profile]Mailchannel Communication, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1102.002 under the Command and Control tactic, operates on multiple platforms. This technique leverages legitimate external web services like social media sites (e.g., Twitter) or cloud platforms (e.g., Google) for bidirectional command and control. Infected systems send and receive data by posting comments, updating documents, or sending tweets, using the service's inherent SSL/TLS encryption for stealth. It is associated with groups including APT28, Lazarus Group, and FIN7.[/profile]
349.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Mailchannel Communication" is an attack pattern not formally defined in the MITRE ATT&CK framework. Based on contextual analysis, it likely involves adversaries leveraging legitimate email channels or services for command and control (C2) or data exfiltration. This technique may use existing mail services to blend malicious communications with normal traffic, potentially employing encryption like SSL/TLS for added stealth, similar to how other web services are abused for C2. It could serve as a primary or fallback communication channel to maintain persistence and avoid detection.

350.name: LZW Algorithm
350.profile: [profile]The LZW Algorithm is a data compression algorithm referenced in the context of adversary techniques for compressing collected data prior to exfiltration (T1002) to minimize network footprint. It is also mentioned as an example of a standard encoding system (T1132.001) that can be used to obfuscate command and control traffic, with groups like MuddyWater and Lazarus Group employing such methods. The algorithm is associated with the Sednit intrusion set.
350.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "LZW Algorithm" is a data compression technique. It is used by adversaries to compress collected data (e.g., sensitive documents) prior to exfiltration, making the data more portable and reducing network traffic. This compression is performed separately from the exfiltration channel, often using a custom program or common utility, and can be a component of data encoding schemes that also result in compression.

351.name: GET/POST Requests
351.profile: [profile]The entity "GET/POST Requests" is a method used within the MITRE ATT&CK technique Internet Connection Discovery (T1016.001) under the Discovery tactic for Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries employ GET requests to websites to check for Internet connectivity on a compromised system, determining if it can communicate with their command and control servers before attempting to connect. This behavior is associated with groups including Sednit, APT29, and Hafnium.
351.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "GET/POST Requests" is a foundational network communication method, not a distinct MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is a core mechanism used within numerous techniques. For example, it is employed in Internet Connection Discovery (T1016.001), where adversaries use GET requests to websites to test for connectivity and bandwidth before contacting command and control servers. Similarly, it underpins Exfiltration to Code Repository (T1567.001), as adversaries use HTTPS-based GET/POST requests to interact with service APIs like GitHub's for data theft. This basic web protocol is a ubiquitous component of adversary tradecraft across various platforms.

352.name: t Initialization
352.profile: [profile]The entity 't Initialization' is a placeholder name. The retrieved information strongly indicates it refers to the MITRE ATT&CK technique 'Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts' (T1037). This technique, under the Persistence tactic, involves adversaries using scripts that automatically execute at system boot or user logon to establish persistence. These scripts, which vary by OS and deployment, can perform administrative functions like executing other programs or sending data to logging servers, and may run with higher privileges, enabling privilege escalation. The Sednit Group is a known user of this technique.
352.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "t Initialization" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved information, it is likely a reference to the technique "Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts" (T1037), which falls under the Persistence tactic and operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves adversaries using scripts that automatically execute at system boot or user logon to establish persistence, often to run other programs or send data to logging servers, and can be used for persistence or privilege escalation by threat groups like APT29 and APT41. The technique varies by operating system and deployment method.

353.name: Obfuscated RTTI
353.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encrypting, encoding, or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system or in transit. This is common behavior that can be used across different platforms and the network to evade defenses. 

Payloads may be compressed, archived, or encrypted in order to avoid detection. These payloads may be used during Initial Access or later to mitigate detection. Sometimes a user's action may be required to open and [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140) for [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204). The user may also be required to input a password to open a password protected compressed/encrypted file that was provided by the adversary. (Citation: Volexity PowerDuke November 2016) Adversaries may also use compressed or archived scripts, such as JavaScript. 

Portions of files can also be encoded to hide the plain-text strings that would otherwise help defenders with discovery. (Citation: Linux/Cdorked.A We Live Security Analysis) Payloads may also be split into separate, seemingly benign files that only reveal malicious functionality when reassembled. (Citation: Carbon Black Obfuscation Sept 2016)

Adversaries may also abuse [Command Obfuscation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/010) to obscure commands executed from payloads or directly via [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059). Environment variables, aliases, characters, and other platform/language specific semantics can be used to evade signature based detections and application control mechanisms. (Citation: FireEye Obfuscation June 2017) (Citation: FireEye Revoke-Obfuscation July 2017)(Citation: PaloAlto EncodedCommand March 2017)
353.profile: [profile]Obfuscated Files or Information is technique T1027 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves making files or executables difficult to detect and analyze by encrypting, encoding, compressing, or archiving their contents. Specific methods include using password-protected archives, splitting payloads into benign-seeming files for later reassembly, and employing command obfuscation with environment variables or aliases to evade signature-based defenses. The Sednit Group is a known user of this technique.[/profile]
353.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Obfuscated RTTI is a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027) within the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows platforms. It involves manipulating the Run-Time Type Information (RTTI) data within compiled C++ binaries to hide the true class names and inheritance structures of malicious objects, thereby evading static analysis and signature-based detection. This specific obfuscation complicates reverse engineering by stripping or altering metadata crucial for identifying object types.

361.name: Pawn Storm
361.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
361.profile: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Sofacy, and STRONTIUM, is a highly active cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's GRU military unit 26165. Its arsenal includes custom malware such as X-Agent, X-Tunnel, and Sofacy, and it employs spear-phishing, credential harvesting, and brute-force attacks. The group primarily targets government, defense, political organizations, and media sectors in North America and Europe, with a consistent motivation of intelligence gathering and political interference, notably demonstrated in operations against the 2016 U.S. elections and international bodies like the World Anti-Doping Agency.
361.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and Strontium, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence. It is distinguished by its use of custom malware like Sofacy/Sednit and X-Agent, and its exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities such as Java 0-days. Its key TTPs include sophisticated spear-phishing, credential harvesting, and deceptive tactics like misleading network administrators and tricking security researchers with decoys. The group primarily targets government, military, and diplomatic entities in NATO countries, the US, and Ukraine, with motivations centered on espionage and information gathering to support Russian strategic interests.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and STRONTIUM, is a sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU. Its key malware and tools include Sofacy, X-Agent, and X-Tunnel, and it is known for spear-phishing campaigns, credential harvesting, and exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities. The group primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage and information gathering. It shows overlaps with other Russian-affiliated groups and has been linked to high-profile election interference campaigns.
361.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and STRONTIUM, is a highly active cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's GRU. Its key malware and tools include Sofacy, X-Agent, and the X-Tunnel backdoor. The group's primary TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns, credential harvesting, and exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities. It primarily targets government, military, and diplomatic sectors in Europe, North America, and former Soviet states, with a clear motivation for strategic intelligence collection and political influence operations.
361.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28 and Fancy Bear, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. It is distinguished by its use of custom malware like X-Agent and Sofacy, as well as exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities such as Java 0-days. Its key TTPs include sophisticated spear-phishing, misleading network administrators by manipulating device configurations, and tricking security researchers with decoy artifacts. The group primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in NATO countries, the US, and Ukraine, with motivations centered on espionage and information operations to support Russian strategic interests.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, and Sofacy, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU. It employs custom malware like Sofacy/Sednit and X-Agent, alongside tools such as X-Tunnel and Zebrocy. Key TTPs include exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities (e.g., Java 0-day), conducting sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns, and employing decoys to trick security researchers and mislead network administrators. The group primarily targets government, military, and diplomatic entities in Europe and North America, with additional focus on NGOs and think tanks, driven by espionage and geopolitical intelligence collection motives. Its operations show overlaps with groups like APT29 in some campaigns, and it has evolved tactics from credential phishing to broader brute-force attacks over time.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and Strontium, is a highly active Russian state-sponsored cyber espionage group attributed to the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU). It is distinguished by its persistent targeting of government, military, and diplomatic entities globally, particularly in Europe, the US, and NATO member states, with motivations centered on geopolitical intelligence gathering. The group employs a sophisticated arsenal including custom malware like Seduploader and X-Agent, and is known for leveraging zero-day vulnerabilities (e.g., Java 0-day) and conducting credential phishing and brute-force campaigns. Its TTPs include the use of decoy domains (e.g., ausameetings.com) and advanced social engineering, such as tricking security researchers and misleading network administrators, to establish persistence and evade detection.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, and Sofacy, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. It is distinguished by its consistent targeting of government, military, and diplomatic entities globally, particularly in NATO countries and Ukraine, primarily for espionage and information operations. The group employs a sophisticated arsenal including custom malware like Sofacy/Sednit and X-Agent, and is known for leveraging zero-day vulnerabilities (e.g., in Java) and conducting large-scale credential phishing and brute-force campaigns. Its TTPs include the use of misleading decoys to trick administrators and researchers, and the operation of strategic infrastructure like spoofed domains (e.g., ausameetings.com). The group shows overlaps with clusters like Void Balaur in credential attack methodologies.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, and Sofacy, is a highly active cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. It is distinguished by its use of custom malware such as Sofacy/Sednit and X-Agent, and its exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities like the Java 0-day. Its key TTPs include sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns, misleading network administrators to redirect traffic, and tricking security researchers with decoy artifacts. The group primarily targets government, military, and diplomatic organizations in NATO countries, Ukraine, and Georgia, with motivations centered on geopolitical intelligence gathering and information operations. It shows overlaps with the credential phishing activity of Void Balaur.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, and Sofacy, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). It is distinguished by its use of custom malware such as Sofacy/Sednit and X-Agent, as well as exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities like Java 0-day. Its key TTPs include spear-phishing, credential harvesting, and deceptive tactics like misleading network administrators and tricking security researchers with decoys. The group primarily targets government, military, and diplomatic sectors in NATO countries, Eastern Europe, and former Soviet states, with motivations strongly aligned with espionage and information operations to support Russian geopolitical interests. It shows overlaps with other Russian-aligned groups like APT29 (Cozy Bear) and has been linked to campaigns such as Operation Pawn Storm.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, and Sofacy, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. It is known for its use of custom malware like Sofacy/Sednit and X-Agent, and for employing sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns, credential harvesting, and exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities (such as Java 0-days) to target government, military, and diplomatic organizations globally, particularly in Europe and NATO member states. Its primary motivation is espionage, with operations supporting Russian strategic interests, and it has shown overlaps with other groups like Void Balaur in credential phishing tactics.[/profile]
361.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and Strontium, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). It is distinguished by its consistent targeting of government, military, and diplomatic entities globally, particularly in Europe and NATO countries, with a primary motivation of espionage. The group employs a sophisticated arsenal including custom malware like Sednit/Sofacy and X-Agent, and is known for leveraging zero-day vulnerabilities (e.g., in Java) and conducting credential phishing campaigns. Its operations, such as those targeting political organizations, demonstrate a strategic focus on information gathering and geopolitical influence.
361.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, and Sofacy, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU. It is distinguished by its persistent use of custom malware like Sofacy, X-Agent, and X-Tunnel, alongside frequent exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities such as Java 0-days. Its key TTPs include sophisticated spear-phishing, credential harvesting, and the unique tactic of tricking security researchers with malicious decoys. The group primarily targets government, military, and diplomatic sectors in Europe, NATO countries, and the United States, with motivations strongly aligned with geopolitical espionage and information gathering.[/profile]

365.name: Misleading network administrators
365.profile: [profile]Misleading network administrators is a technique where adversaries manipulate network device configurations to redirect traffic or load unauthorized operating systems from malicious TFTP servers, often to establish backdoors or support further attacks like phishing. This technique is associated with the intrusion set Pawn Storm and involves compromising network infrastructure to enable malicious control while evading detection.
365.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Misleading network administrators is a technique where adversaries manipulate network device configurations to redirect traffic or load unauthorized operating systems from malicious TFTP servers, often as part of netbooting (TFTP Boot, T1542.005). This action supports objectives like establishing backdoors, enabling command and control through proxies, and maintaining persistence on compromised infrastructure, typically targeting network appliances and edge devices.

366.name: Tricking security researchers
366.profile: [profile]Tricking security researchers is a technique used by adversaries, such as the intrusion-set Operation Pawn Storm (also known as Pawn Storm), to target individuals in the cybersecurity field. The tactic falls under Initial Access, specifically within the realm of social engineering. The primary platform is any system where the target researcher operates. The technique involves creating fake personas or social media accounts to establish contact, then delivering malicious content disguised as legitimate research, such as a weaponized document or archive, to compromise the researcher's system. This method exploits the professional curiosity and collaborative nature of the security community to gain initial foothold.[/profile]
366.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Tricking security researchers" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is a tactic used by adversaries to deceive security professionals. This typically involves masquerading malicious artifacts as legitimate research tools or data, often by manipulating file names, metadata, or content to appear benign. The goal is to lure researchers into interacting with or analyzing the malicious payload, thereby compromising their systems. This activity is related to the broader technique of Masquerading (T1036). The neighbor info links this entity to the organization Trend Micro.[/profile]

368.name: Operation Pawn Storm
368.profile: [profile]Operation Pawn Storm, also known as APT28, APT29, and Cozy Bear, is a sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia. Its arsenal includes custom malware such as SeaDuke and tools like PowerDuke, employing spear-phishing campaigns and zero-day exploits. The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, and NGO sectors in the US and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and geopolitical intelligence gathering, showing overlaps with groups like Turla in some campaigns.
368.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Operation Pawn Storm is a cyber espionage campaign attributed to the Russian state-aligned APT group APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and Strontium). The group is known for employing custom malware and tools, and has specifically utilized Java 0-day vulnerabilities in its operations. A key tactic includes tricking security researchers by masquerading malicious artifacts as legitimate research to compromise targets. Its activities primarily target entities like NATO members and the White House, indicating a focus on Western political and governmental sectors. 372.name: Russian intelligence
372.profile: [profile]The entity is broadly attributed to Russian state intelligence, with specific operations and aliases linked to distinct sub-groups or clusters. It is known by aliases such as Killnet, Evilnum (also known as DeathStalker, Knockout Spider, TA4563, and JointWorm), and Callisto (also known as BlueCharlie, TAG-53, Seaborgium, UNC4057, Star Blizzard, Gossamer Bear, Iron Frontier, TA446, Blue Callisto, and ColdRiver). Key organizations believed to be involved include the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) with its Center 16 and Center 18, the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR), and the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) including the 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS). The SVR has been associated with the cluster tracked as COZY BEAR. The group's primary focus is cyber espionage and disruptive operations, often targeting IT and operational technology (OT) networks for strategic intelligence and geopolitical influence.
372.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely APT28 (Fancy Bear/Sofacy/STRONTIUM), also known as Guccifer 2.0 and attributed to the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU). Its key TTPs involve sophisticated defense evasion, including runtime code signing manipulation (Runtime Signers), clearing Windows event logs, and subverting Windows PKI internals for signature validation. The group primarily targets U.S. political entities and processes, such as political parties, election candidates, and government sectors like the Democratic National Committee and Wyoming State Government, with a motivation of political espionage and intelligence gathering.
372.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The entity is most likely a reference to the broader Russian state-sponsored cyber ecosystem rather than a single, discrete APT group. Common aliases for its constituent units include APT29 (Cozy Bear), APT28 (Fancy Bear), and groups like Callisto (Star Blizzard) and Evilnum. Key malware and tools vary by unit but include frameworks like Drovorub and Zebrocy. Key TTPs encompass sophisticated spear-phishing, credential harvesting, and supply chain compromises. The activity is attributed to Russian intelligence services, primarily the Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR), Federal Security Service (FSB), and Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU). Target sectors and regions are global, with a focus on government, diplomatic, defense, and critical infrastructure entities in NATO countries and Ukraine. The primary motivations are espionage, intellectual property theft, and the advancement of Russian geopolitical and strategic interests.
372.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely a composite reference to Russian state-sponsored cyber operations, commonly attributed to distinct APT groups linked to specific intelligence agencies: the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR), associated with APT29 (Cozy Bear); the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU), linked to APT28 (Fancy Bear); and the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB). Key malware and tools vary by subgroup, including frameworks like EVILNUM and SEABORGIUM. Their primary TTPs involve sophisticated cyber espionage and disruptive operations. The origin is firmly attributed to Russian intelligence services. Target sectors and regions are global, with a focus on government, defense, and critical infrastructure, particularly in NATO countries and Ukraine. The primary motivations are geopolitical intelligence gathering, strategic influence, and disruption.

373.name: adversary espionage techniques
373.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique to support follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040), [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002), or replay attacks ([Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212)). By abusing features of common networking protocols that can determine the flow of network traffic (e.g. ARP, DNS, LLMNR, etc.), adversaries may force a device to communicate through an adversary controlled system so they can collect information or perform additional actions.(Citation: Rapid7 MiTM Basics)

For example, adversaries may manipulate victim DNS settings to enable other malicious activities such as preventing/redirecting users from accessing legitimate sites and/or pushing additional malware.(Citation: ttint_rat)(Citation: dns_changer_trojans)(Citation: ad_blocker_with_miner) Adversaries may also manipulate DNS and leverage their position in order to intercept user credentials, including access tokens ([Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)) and session cookies ([Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)).(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)(Citation: Token tactics) [Downgrade Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/010)s can also be used to establish an AiTM position, such as by negotiating a less secure, deprecated, or weaker version of communication protocol (SSL/TLS) or encryption algorithm.(Citation: mitm_tls_downgrade_att)(Citation: taxonomy_downgrade_att_tls)(Citation: tlseminar_downgrade_att)

Adversaries may also leverage the AiTM position to attempt to monitor and/or modify traffic, such as in [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). Adversaries can setup a position similar to AiTM to prevent traffic from flowing to the appropriate destination, potentially to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) and/or in support of a [Network Denial of Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498).
373.profile: [profile]Adversary-in-the-Middle (AiTM) is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1557, categorized under Credential Access and Discovery, applicable to multiple platforms. It works by abusing network protocols like ARP, DNS, or LLMNR to intercept and redirect traffic between devices through an adversary-controlled system, enabling credential theft via token or cookie capture, data manipulation, or traffic monitoring. It is associated with threat groups like Kimsuky, Sea Turtle, and Mustang Panda.
373.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "adversary espionage techniques" is a broad category, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique with a standard ID. Based on retrieved information, it encompasses methods for acquiring and deploying capabilities to support espionage operations. This includes purchasing, stealing, or downloading malware, exploits, and software, as well as abusing enterprise software deployment tools like SCCM or Intune for lateral movement and broad system control to gather information.

375.name: Guccifer 2.0
375.uncertain_mes: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) is a suspected Russian group that has targeted government entities and multiple U.S. critical infrastructure sectors since at least December 2015. (Citation: US-CERT TA18-074A) (Citation: Symantec Dragonfly Sept 2017) There is debate over the extent of overlap between [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) and [Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035), but there is sufficient evidence to lead to these being tracked as two separate groups. (Citation: Fortune Dragonfly 2.0 Sept 2017)(Citation: Dragos DYMALLOY )
375.profile: [profile]Guccifer 2.0, also known as Dragonfly 2.0, is a suspected Russian cyber espionage group. Its operations are widely attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU), with strong links to APT28 (Fancy Bear). The group is most notorious for its role in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, having breached the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and subsequently leaking stolen documents. Key TTPs include the use of custom tools and infrastructure, with some malware believed to have been released by the threat actor The Shadow Brokers. Its primary motivation is geopolitical influence, specifically targeting political organizations and government entities, particularly in the United States, to conduct information operations and data theft.
375.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Guccifer 2.0 is most likely a persona or operation of APT28 (Fancy Bear/Sofacy/STRONTIUM), also known as Sednit, Pawn Storm, and Forest Blizzard. It is attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU). Key TTPs include sophisticated defense evasion such as runtime code signing manipulation, clearing Windows event logs, and subverting Windows PKI for signature validation. The group primarily targets U.S. political entities like the Democratic National Committee and election candidates, with a motivation of political espionage and intelligence gathering.
375.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Guccifer 2.0, also known as G0007, is a persona or intrusion set widely attributed to Russian military intelligence (GRU), specifically overlapping with or operated by the APT28 (Fancy Bear) group. Its key activity was the 2016 breach and leak of documents from the Democratic National Committee (DNC), using custom tools and infrastructure. The group is motivated by strategic information operations and espionage, primarily targeting U.S. political entities to influence electoral processes.
375.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]Guccifer 2.0, also known as Grizzly Steppe and UAC-0028, is a persona or intrusion set believed to be operated by Russian military intelligence (GRU) and is closely linked to the APT28 (Fancy Bear) group. Its key activity was the 2016 compromise and leak of documents from the Democratic National Committee (DNC) in the United States. The operation primarily used spear-phishing and credential theft, with the persona itself being publicly exposed through operational security failures that tied it to GRU infrastructure. Its motivation is assessed as geopolitical influence and information operations targeting Western political processes.]

377.name: Cozy Bear
377.uncertain_mes:
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR).(Citation: White House Imposing Costs RU Gov April 2021)(Citation: UK Gov Malign RIS Activity April 2021) They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: UK Gov UK Exposes Russia SolarWinds April 2021)

In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) to the SVR; public statements included citations to [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016), Cozy Bear, and The Dukes.(Citation: NSA Joint Advisory SVR SolarWinds April 2021)(Citation: UK NSCS Russia SolarWinds April 2021) Industry reporting also referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm.(Citation: FireEye SUNBURST Backdoor December 2020)(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike SUNSPOT Implant January 2021)(Citation: Volexity SolarWinds)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory SVR TTP May 2021)(Citation: Unit 42 SolarStorm December 2020)
377.profile: [profile]Cozy Bear, also known as APT29, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, NOBELIUM, UNC2452, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm, is a Russian cyber espionage group attributed to the SVR. Its key malware and tools include the SUNBURST backdoor and SUNSPOT implant from the SolarWinds campaign. The group demonstrates advanced post-exploitation techniques like authentication cookie theft for lateral movement in cloud environments. It primarily targets government networks in Europe and NATO countries, research institutes, and think tanks, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and political espionage, as seen in operations like the Democratic National Committee and SolarWinds compromises.
377.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most widely standardized as APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, Nobelium, and UNC2452, and is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its key custom malware includes SUNSPOT, SUNBURST, GoldMax, WellMess, WellMail, Sibot, Seadaddy, AdobeARM, and Minidionis, and it employs tools like Cobalt Strike and Sliver. Notable TTPs involve sophisticated software supply chain attacks (e.g., the SolarWinds compromise), credential access via private keys, stealthy command and control using Mutual-TLS and DNS, and defense evasion through virtual machine, debugger, and sandbox detection. The group originates from Russia and primarily targets government, diplomatic, energy, technology, healthcare, pharmaceutical, financial, media, think tanks, and research sectors in NATO member states, the US, UK, Europe, and across Asia and the Americas, with motivations centered on strategic espionage and intelligence collection for Russian state interests.
377.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Cozy Bear, also known as APT29, The Dukes, and UNC2452, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). The group is distinguished by its advanced post-exploitation tradecraft, particularly in cloud environments, where it has been observed using techniques like authentication cookie theft for lateral movement. Its operations are believed to be aligned with Russian state interests, historically targeting government, diplomatic, think tank, and healthcare sectors in the US, Europe, and NATO member states for espionage and intelligence collection.
377.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]Cozy Bear, also known as APT29, The Dukes, and UNC2452, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). It is distinguished by its use of custom malware like WellMess and WellMail, and has demonstrated advanced post-exploitation capabilities, particularly in targeting and moving within cloud environments using techniques like authentication cookie theft. The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, think-tank, healthcare, and energy sectors in the US and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and information gathering to support Russian state interests.
377.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]This intrusion set is most widely standardized as APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, Nobelium, and UNC2452, and is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its key custom malware includes SUNSPOT, SUNBURST, GoldMax, WellMess, WellMail, Sibot, Seadaddy, Minidionis, and AdobeARM. Notable TTPs involve sophisticated supply chain attacks (e.g., the SolarWinds compromise), credential access via stolen authentication cookies for cloud environment lateral movement, and advanced defense evasion through debugger, VM, and sandbox detection. The group originates from Russia and primarily targets government, diplomatic, defense, technology, energy, healthcare, and research sectors in the US, NATO members, and Western Europe, with motivations centered on strategic espionage and intelligence collection for Russian state interests.
