Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, SedUploader, Zebrocy, the Sofacy Carberp variant, and tools like AdvStoreShell and JhuHugit. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities (including Java and Flash), and the use of tools like WinRAR for data exfiltration. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically units like 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political organizations in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, STRONTIUM, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) backdoor, Azzy, JhuHugit (a Carberp-based variant), and Zebrocy. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing, credential harvesting, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities like CVE-2015-2590, and the use of multi-layered C2 infrastructure. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political organizations in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, Tsar Team, and Sofacy. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, Zebrocy, Seduploader, and the Sofacy Carberp variant, which includes the JhuHugit reconnaissance tool. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting and the exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, such as in Oracle Sun Java (CVE-2015-2590). The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455, and is believed to operate from Central Asia. It primarily targets government, military, political, and diplomatic organizations, including defense-related commercial entities and networks like the DNC, in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and information operations to support Russian strategic interests.[/profile]
445.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]The entity is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, Zebrocy, Seduploader, and the Sofacy Carberp variant. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities in software like Microsoft Office, and Sandbox Breakout techniques. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, political, and diplomatic organizations in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and information operations to support Russian strategic interests.[/profile]

446.name: wevtutil cl system
446.profile: [profile]The entity "wevtutil cl system" is a specific command for the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.001, Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs, under the Defense Evasion tactic on Windows platforms. It uses the native Windows utility wevtutil.exe with the "cl" (clear) parameter to erase the System event log, removing evidence of malicious activity. This technique is commonly employed by threat actors like APT28, APT32, and Volt Typhoon as part of post-compromise cleanup.
446.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "wevtutil cl system" is a specific command execution within the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.001 (Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs) under the Defense Evasion tactic, targeting Windows platforms. This command, executed with administrator privileges, clears the System event log to erase evidence of intrusion. It is commonly used alongside commands to clear Application and Security logs, and has been employed by groups including APT28, APT29, and Hafnium.[/profile]

447.name: wevtutil cl secure
447.profile: [profile]The entity "wevtutil cl secure" is a specific command within the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs" (T1070.001), under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows platforms. This command uses the native Windows utility wevtutil.exe to clear the Security event log, directly deleting its recorded entries to erase evidence of malicious activity. It is a common sub-technique employed by numerous threat groups, including APT28, APT38, and Volt Typhoon, as part of broader log-clearing operations.
447.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The command 'wevtutil cl secure' is a specific implementation of the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.001, 'Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs', under the Defense Evasion tactic on Windows platforms. It is a utility command that, when executed with administrator privileges, clears the Security Event Log to erase evidence of malicious activity. This technique is commonly employed by threat actors such as APT28, APT29, and Hafnium as part of post-compromise actions to hinder forensic analysis.[/profile]

448.name: coreshell
448.uncertain_mes: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) is a downloader used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). The older versions of this malware are known as SOURFACE and newer versions as CORESHELL.(Citation: FireEye APT28) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
448.profile: [profile]CORESHELL, also known as SOURFACE, is a downloader malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. It is delivered as a DLL file attached to documents and includes unused code to mimic legitimate instructions, likely for evasion. It functions to download and execute additional payloads on Windows systems.
448.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Coreshell, also known as SOURFACE, is a downloader malware attributed to APT28. It is typically delivered as a DLL file attached to documents and includes unused code to mimic legitimate instructions, potentially to bypass endpoint security. It targets the Windows platform.

449.name: splm
449.profile: [profile]SPLM, also known as XAgent, is attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include global distribution for data exfiltration, and its use by Sofacy was observed to wind down in 2018. The target platform is unspecified in the provided data. It is mentioned in the context of the Zebrocy malware campaign.]
449.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SPLM, also known as XAgent, is a malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. Its global detections have been observed winding down from 2018, indicating a shift in the group's operational use of this tool.

450.name: SourFace
450.profile: [profile]SourFace, also known as SOURFACE, is a first-stage implant and downloader attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. It is an older version of the CORESHELL malware family. Its key technical behavior involves establishing persistence by creating a system registry key for automatic execution on system startup. It has been used in cyber-espionage campaigns targeting Windows systems.
450.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SourFace, also known as SOURFACE, is a first-stage implant and downloader malware attributed to the APT28 group. It is an older version of the malware family that later evolved into CORESHELL. Historically used in cyber-espionage campaigns around 2011-2012, it shares similarities with earlier implants like Miniduke and functions as an initial access tool for the group.

451.name: chopstick
451.uncertain_mes: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) is a malware family of modular backdoors used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It has been used since at least 2012 and is usually dropped on victims as second-stage malware, though it has been used as first-stage malware in several cases. It has both Windows and Linux variants. (Citation: FireEye APT28) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017) (Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018) It is tracked separately from the [X-Agent for Android](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0314).
451.profile: [profile]CHOPSTICK is a modular backdoor malware family used by APT28 (also known as Sofacy) since at least 2012, often deployed as second-stage malware. It has both Windows and Linux variants and is part of a shared modularity and infrastructure ecosystem with related malware like X-Agent and Zebrocy, targeting entities in countries including Turkey, Kazakhstan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, Germany, Lithuania, and the Netherlands.
451.profile_without_enhance: [profile]CHOPSTICK is a modular backdoor malware family, also known as SPLM and XAgent, attributed to APT28. It has been used since at least 2012, deployed as both first and second-stage malware. Its key technical behaviors include modular functionality for backdoor access. The malware targets Windows and Linux platforms and shares infrastructure and modular design characteristics with other APT28 tools like X-Agent and Zebrocy.

452.name: jhuhugit
452.uncertain_mes: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
452.profile: [profile]JHUHUGIT, also known as jhuhugit, is a reconnaissance malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. It is based on the Carberp source code and was used as a first-stage implant in attacks, including those leveraging a Java zero-day (CVE-2015-2590) in July 2015. Its key behavior involves establishing persistence through registry key creation for automatic execution.[/profile]
452.profile_without_enhance: [profile]JHUHUGIT is a reconnaissance malware based on Carberp source code and is attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). Its key technical behaviors include serving as a first-stage implant for attacks and being deployed alongside Java exploits, such as CVE-2015-2590. The malware primarily targets systems vulnerable to Java-based exploits.[profile]

453.name: CosmicDuke
453.uncertain_mes: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
453.profile: [profile]CosmicDuke, also known as Cosmic Duke, is a malware attributed to the APT29 group, used from 2010 to 2015. It is part of the broader "Dukes" malware family, which includes related variants such as MiniDuke, CozyDuke, GeminiDuke, OnionDuke, CloudDuke, SeaDuke, HammerDuke, and PinchDuke. The malware is designed to target Windows platforms, with technical behaviors including simple Windows clipboard hijacking for data theft and persistence mechanisms. Its infrastructure and operations are associated with the Sofacy intrusion set.
453.profile_without_enhance: [profile]CosmicDuke, also known as cosmicduke, is a malware attributed to the APT29 (Sofacy) intrusion set. It is part of the broader "Duke" malware family toolset, which includes MiniDuke, OnionDuke, CozyDuke, CloudDuke, SeaDuke, HammerDuke, PinchDuke, and GeminiDuke. It targets Windows platforms and is associated with data theft, employing techniques like clipboard hijacking for persistence and stealing data.[/profile]

454.name: MiniDuke
454.uncertain_mes: [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. The [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) toolset consists of multiple downloader and backdoor components. The loader has been used with other [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) components as well as in conjunction with [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) and [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048). (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
454.profile: [profile]MiniDuke is a malware toolset used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, consisting of multiple downloader and backdoor components. Its aliases or related components include CosmicDuke, PinchDuke, OnionDuke, CozyDuke, CloudDuke, SeaDuke, HammerDuke, and GeminiDuke. It is attributed to the APT29 group, also known as Sofacy. Key technical behaviors involve a multi-stage architecture with distinct loader, stage 1, stage 2, and stage 3 components; the loader is modular and has been used with other MiniDuke components as well as with CosmicDuke and PinchDuke. Target platforms are Windows systems. Infrastructure and supplementary information include samples available for analysis such as miniduke_original.7z and miniduke_unpacked.7z on VirusTotal.
454.profile_without_enhance: [profile]MiniDuke is a malware attributed to the APT29 group and is part of the broader 'Duke' malware family, which includes variants like CosmicDuke, GeminiDuke, CozyDuke, OnionDuke, CloudDuke, SeaDuke, HammerDuke, and PinchDuke. Its technical behavior involves a multi-stage architecture with distinct loader and payload components. The primary target platform is Microsoft Windows systems.[/profile]

455.name: xagent
455.profile: [profile]Xagent, also known as X-Agent, is a malware attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include the use of obfuscated Run-Time Type Information (RTTI) in its modules. The malware targets Windows and Linux platforms, with specific versions like version 1 for Windows introduced in 2014 and version 3 for Linux and Windows introduced and updated in 2014-2015.[/profile]
455.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Xagent, also known as X-agent, is a malware attributed to APT28. Key technical behaviors include its modular design with versions for Windows and Linux platforms, and the use of obfuscated Run-Time Type Information (RTTI) in its modules. It is associated with the Xtunnel tool for network communications.]

456.name: azzy
456.profile: [profile]The malware known as AZZY, also referred to as AZZY 4.3, is attributed to the APT group Sofacy (APT28). Its key technical behaviors include the use of an installer to deploy implants, a dropped C&C helper DLL for command and control, and file collectors or USB stealers for data exfiltration. The malware targets Windows platforms, as indicated by its associated DLL components and its connection to related malware families like advstoreshell, netui, and eviltoss.
456.profile_without_enhance: [profile]AZZY, also known as ADVSTORESHELL, NETUI, and EVILTOSS, is a spying backdoor attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). It is used for long-term espionage and data exfiltration, with a technical lineage spanning multiple generations, including version 4.3. The malware targets Windows systems and is part of a broader arsenal including tools like CORESHELL and Xagent.[/profile]

457.name: advstoreshell
457.uncertain_mes: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) is a spying backdoor that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) from at least 2012 to 2016. It is generally used for long-term espionage and is deployed on targets deemed interesting after a reconnaissance phase. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2)
457.profile: [profile] ADVSTORESHELL, also known as AZZY, NETUI, EVILTOSS, and CHOPSTICK, is a spying backdoor attributed to APT28. It has been used for long-term espionage from at least 2012 to 2016, deployed on selected targets after reconnaissance. The malware is part of a broader arsenal including tools like CORESHELL and SPLM.
457.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Advstoreshell, also known as Azzy, Netui, and Eviltoss, is a spying backdoor malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) intrusion set. It is used for long-term espionage on targets of interest following reconnaissance and is part of a multi-generational toolset that includes other malware families like CORESHELL and SPLM (Xagent).[/profile]

458.name: netui
458.profile: [profile]NetUI is an alias for the Azzy backdoor (also known as ADVSTORESHELL, EVILTOSS), which is attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). It is a multi-generational Windows malware, part of an expanded toolset that includes backdoors like CORESHELL and SPLM. Its technical profile is directly linked to the Azzy malware family.[/profile]
458.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Netui is a malware alias associated with the Sofacy intrusion set (APT28). It is part of a cluster of related malware families that includes Azzy (also known as Advstoreshell and Eviltoss), spanning multiple generations. Its technical behaviors involve dropping a command and control (C&C) helper DLL and potentially utilizing associated file collectors or USB stealers. The malware targets the Windows platform, as indicated by its internal name 'netui.dll' which mimics a legitimate Microsoft system file.[/profile]

459.name: eviltoss
459.profile: [profile]Eviltoss, also known as ADVSTORESHELL, NETUI, and AZZY, is attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). It is a backdoor tool that spans multiple generations. Its key technical behaviors include functioning as part of an expanded malware arsenal. The target platform is unspecified. It is associated with the malware family AZZY.[/profile]
459.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Eviltoss is a malware family, also known as ADVSTORESHELL and NETUI, and is part of the AZZY malware toolset attributed to the Sofacy intrusion set (APT28). It spans across 4-5 generations of development and is connected to other malware families like Advstoreshell and Netui. Its key behaviors include dropping a command and control (C&C) helper DLL and utilizing associated file collectors or USB stealers as part of its toolset.[/profile]

461.name: USB stealers
461.uncertain_mes: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) is malware that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least 2005 to extract information from air-gapped networks. It does not have the capability to communicate over the Internet and has been used in conjunction with [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045). (Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014) (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy)
461.profile: [profile]USBStealer, also known as USB stealers, is a malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. It is designed to extract information from air-gapped networks, lacking internet communication capability, and has been used in conjunction with ADVSTORESHELL. Its primary target platform is Windows systems, and it operates by infecting USB drives to facilitate data theft from isolated networks.[/profile]
461.profile_without_enhance: [profile]USB stealers are a type of malware. They are referenced in technical analyses of other malware families including Coreshell, Sedreco, and X-Agent, which are associated with APT28. The primary technical behavior involves stealing data from USB-connected storage devices. The target platform is Windows systems. Infrastructure or supplementary details are not specified in the provided context.

468.name: Dealers Choice
468.uncertain_mes: [DealersChoice](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0243) is a Flash exploitation framework used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). (Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)
468.profile: [profile]Dealers Choice, also known as DealersChoice, is a Flash exploitation framework attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. Its key technical behavior is exploiting Adobe Flash to deliver malware. The framework is associated with operational techniques and command and control infrastructure overlaps observed in campaigns involving tools like Geminiduke, Zebrocy, and CozyDuke.[/profile]
468.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Dealers Choice is a malware entity associated with the APT28 group, as indicated by its mention in the Zebrocy context. It is referenced in discussions about operational overlaps in command and control infrastructure, specifically within analyses of campaigns involving tools like Geminiduke and Cozyduke, which suggest a potential shared supplier or operational link between actors targeting drug dealers and government entities.

469.name: Microsoft Office Encapsulated PostScript Type Confusion vulnerability

471.name: Gamefish
471.profile: [profile]Gamefish, also known as GAMEFISH, is a first-stage malware attributed to the Sofacy intrusion set (APT28). It is used to deploy secondary payloads like the X-AGENT RAT, which performs keylogging and file extraction. Its campaigns have targeted NATO, the Middle East, and Central Asia, with operations shifting eastward by late 2017.
471.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Gamefish, also known as GAMEFISH, is a first-stage malware used by APT28 in spearphishing campaigns targeting NATO, the Middle East, Central Asia, and regions further east. It is associated with activity subsets involving Zebrocy and SPLM, and it precedes the deployment of the X-AGENT RAT for keylogging and file extraction.

476.name: Spear-phishing via documents
476.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
476.profile: [profile]Spear-phishing via documents is a specific variant of spearphishing, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566.001 under the Initial Access tactic, primarily targeting Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. The technique involves sending targeted emails with malicious attachments, such as Microsoft Office documents, executables, PDFs, or archived files, which rely on user execution to deliver a payload. Adversaries often manipulate file extensions and icons to disguise executables as documents and may provide instructions to bypass security protections, such as supplying a password for a compressed attachment to evade email defenses.
476.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-phishing via documents is a specific variant of spearphishing, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566.001 under the Initial Access tactic, primarily targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves sending targeted emails with malicious attachments, such as Microsoft Office documents, PDFs, or archived files, that contain embedded malware or exploit code. Execution typically relies on user interaction to open the attachment, often requiring the victim to enable content or bypass protections, which then triggers the payload to compromise the system.

477.name: flash exploits
477.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may develop exploits that can be used during targeting. An exploit takes advantage of a bug or vulnerability in order to cause unintended or unanticipated behavior to occur on computer hardware or software. Rather than finding/modifying exploits from online or purchasing them from exploit vendors, an adversary may develop their own exploits.(Citation: NYTStuxnet) Adversaries may use information acquired via [Vulnerabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588/006) to focus exploit development efforts. As part of the exploit development process, adversaries may uncover exploitable vulnerabilities through methods such as fuzzing and patch analysis.(Citation: Irongeek Sims BSides 2017)

As with legitimate development efforts, different skill sets may be required for developing exploits. The skills needed may be located in-house, or may need to be contracted out. Use of a contractor may be considered an extension of that adversary's exploit development capabilities, provided the adversary plays a role in shaping requirements and maintains an initial degree of exclusivity to the exploit.

Adversaries may use exploits during various phases of the adversary lifecycle (i.e. [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190), [Exploitation for Client Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203), [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068), [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211), [Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212), [Exploitation of Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1210), and [Application or System Exploitation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/004)).
477.profile: [profile]The entity "Flash Exploits" is a specific application of the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Exploitation for Client Execution" (T1203) under the Execution tactic, targeting platforms like Windows that run Adobe Flash. These exploits leverage vulnerabilities in the Adobe Flash Player, often delivered via malicious documents or websites, to achieve arbitrary code execution on a victim's system. This method has been commonly used by adversaries to gain initial access, with groups like Sofacy linked to such activities.
477.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "flash exploits" is a specific instance of the MITRE ATT&CK technique Exploitation for Client Execution (T1203) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting platforms like Windows where Adobe Flash Player is installed. These exploits leverage vulnerabilities in the Adobe Flash Player software, often delivered as malicious objects embedded within documents like Microsoft Office files, to achieve arbitrary code execution when a user opens the file. This method has been historically used by numerous threat groups, including APT37, APT41, and Lazarus Group, to gain initial access to victim systems.

478.name: file stealer
478.profile: [profile]The entity "file stealer" is a technique for data theft, not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is associated with the intrusion set Sofacy and involves stealing files from a victim system. The retrieved information describes related credential theft techniques, such as extracting plaintext passwords from web browser databases like Google Chrome's 'Login Data' file using SQL queries and the Windows `CryptUnprotectData` API. This suggests the technique focuses on accessing and exfiltrating specific, often sensitive, files from a compromised host.
478.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File stealer is a technique for credential access, operating on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries stealing files from a victim's system to obtain sensitive data, such as credentials. Specific mechanics include reading browser credential stores; for example, on Windows, an adversary may read the Chrome database file at `AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Login Data` and execute a SQL query to extract encrypted credentials, which are then decrypted using functions like `CryptUnprotectData`. This activity is often conducted to facilitate lateral movement and privilege escalation.

479.name: keylogger
479.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may log user keystrokes to intercept credentials as the user types them. Keylogging is likely to be used to acquire credentials for new access opportunities when [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003) efforts are not effective, and may require an adversary to intercept keystrokes on a system for a substantial period of time before credentials can be successfully captured. In order to increase the likelihood of capturing credentials quickly, an adversary may also perform actions such as clearing browser cookies to force users to reauthenticate to systems.(Citation: Talos Kimsuky Nov 2021)

Keylogging is the most prevalent type of input capture, with many different ways of intercepting keystrokes.(Citation: Adventures of a Keystroke) Some methods include:

* Hooking API callbacks used for processing keystrokes. Unlike [Credential API Hooking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056/004), this focuses solely on API functions intended for processing keystroke data.
* Reading raw keystroke data from the hardware buffer.
* Windows Registry modifications.
* Custom drivers.
* [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601) may provide adversaries with hooks into the operating system of network devices to read raw keystrokes for login sessions.(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
479.profile: [profile]Keylogging (T1056.001) is a Credential Access technique where adversaries capture user keystrokes to steal credentials, often used when OS credential dumping fails. It operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Specific technical methods include hooking keyboard API callbacks, reading raw keystroke data from the hardware buffer, modifying the Windows Registry, deploying custom drivers, and potentially modifying system images on network devices to intercept login sessions. It is notably used to capture passwords for hardware tokens like smart cards to bypass multi-factor authentication. Associated threat groups include Sofacy, Kimsuky, and Lazarus Group.[/profile]
479.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Keylogger, identified as T1056.001 under the Credential Access tactic, primarily targets Windows and Linux platforms. It functions by intercepting user keystrokes to capture credentials, often employing methods like hooking API callbacks for keystroke processing, reading raw data from hardware buffers, or using custom drivers. This technique is particularly used when credential dumping fails and is prevalent among groups like APT28 and Lazarus for stealing passwords and bypassing multi-factor authentication by capturing token inputs.

480.name: remote shell
480.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may backdoor web servers with web shells to establish persistent access to systems. A Web shell is a Web script that is placed on an openly accessible Web server to allow an adversary to access the Web server as a gateway into a network. A Web shell may provide a set of functions to execute or a command-line interface on the system that hosts the Web server.(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)

In addition to a server-side script, a Web shell may have a client interface program that is used to talk to the Web server (e.g. [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020) Web shell client).(Citation: Lee 2013)
480.profile: [profile]The entity is a Web Shell, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1505.003 under the Persistence tactic, targeting web servers. It operates as a malicious script placed on an accessible web server, providing adversaries with a persistent gateway into the network. This shell can execute functions or provide a command-line interface on the host system and often includes a separate client program, such as China Chopper, for remote communication and control.
480.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "remote shell" is not a formally defined MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it broadly refers to the adversary action of establishing an interactive command-line interface on a remote system. This is commonly achieved by abusing legitimate remote access protocols like SSH (T1021.004) or by deploying persistent backdoors such as web shells (T1505.003). The core technical mechanic involves using valid credentials or exploiting vulnerabilities to execute a shell process (e.g., bash, sh, or PowerShell) that provides the attacker with remote command execution and control over the compromised host, facilitating further malicious activities.

481.name: 0day deployments
481.profile: [profile]The entity "0day deployments" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is associated with the intrusion set Sofacy. The retrieved information describes related techniques: Container and Resource Discovery (T1613) involves querying APIs to find resources like deployments and pods in container environments; Container Orchestration Job (T1053.007) involves abusing tools like Kubernetes CronJobs to schedule the deployment of malicious containers for execution and persistence. These techniques inform how adversaries might deploy and maintain malicious code in compromised environments.
481.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "0day deployments" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it may refer to the automated, scheduled deployment of malicious containers within a cluster. This is analogous to the known technique "Scheduled Task/Job: Container Orchestration Job" (T1053.007), which involves abusing tools like Kubernetes CronJobs to schedule and maintain deployments that execute malicious code at specific times, facilitating execution and persistence in containerized environments.

484.name: apt backdoor activity
484.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may employ various user activity checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.(Citation: Deloitte Environment Awareness)

Adversaries may search for user activity on the host based on variables such as the speed/frequency of mouse movements and clicks (Citation: Sans Virtual Jan 2016) , browser history, cache, bookmarks, or number of files in common directories such as home or the desktop. Other methods may rely on specific user interaction with the system before the malicious code is activated, such as waiting for a document to close before activating a macro (Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Nov 2018) or waiting for a user to double click on an embedded image to activate.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)
484.profile: [profile]User Activity Based Checks, identified as T1497.002 under the Defense Evasion tactic, operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique detects user presence or virtualized environments to evade analysis, altering malware behavior accordingly. Specific checks include monitoring mouse movement speed, browser history, and file counts in common directories, or delaying activation until a user closes a document or double-clicks an image. It has been associated with groups like Sofacy, FIN7, and DarkHotel.
484.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'apt backdoor activity' is a broad attack pattern associated with Advanced Persistent Threats (APT). It involves the deployment of a backdoor to establish persistent, covert access to a compromised system. This technique enables adversaries to maintain long-term presence, execute commands, exfiltrate data, and deliver additional payloads. Related techniques include manipulating hardware supply chains to implant backdoors, using junk data in command and control traffic to evade detection, and deleting files to remove forensic evidence of the intrusion.

485.name: cyber espionage
485.profile: [profile]Cyber Espionage is a strategic objective, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, and therefore lacks a standard T-ID, Tactic, and Platform. It describes clandestine intelligence-gathering operations, often conducted by groups like Hidden Lynx and Sofacy. Related activities include obtaining capabilities (T1588) such as malware or exploits from third parties, and adversaries monitoring threat intelligence reports (T1681) about their own campaigns to adapt their tactics and avoid detection.
485.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "cyber espionage" is a broad attack pattern not directly mapped to a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID or Tactic. Based on retrieved information, it involves adversaries obtaining capabilities such as malware or exploits through purchase, theft, or download to support operations. Adversaries may also monitor threat intelligence reports about their own or others' campaigns to adapt their behavior and avoid detection.

486.name: state-sponsored espionage
486.profile: [profile]The entity 'state-sponsored espionage' is a high-level threat activity, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, and is associated with the intrusion set Sofacy. It describes a persistent, resource-intensive campaign typically conducted by nation-states to steal sensitive information for strategic advantage. This activity often employs sophisticated techniques like process hollowing (T1055.012) to execute malicious code covertly, and adversaries may monitor threat intelligence reports (T1597.001) to adapt their operations and evade detection. The primary goal is long-term, stealthy data exfiltration rather than immediate disruption.
486.profile_without_enhance: [profile]State-Sponsored Espionage is a cyber attack pattern where adversaries conduct intelligence-gathering operations on behalf of a nation-state. The primary tactic is Collection, as the objective is to steal sensitive data, intellectual property, or state secrets. This activity typically targets Government and Private Sector platforms. Technical mechanics involve sophisticated, persistent campaigns that may utilize various techniques like malware deployment, social engineering, and network intrusion to maintain long-term access and exfiltrate information without detection.

490.name: CovFacy
490.profile: [profile]CovFacy, also known as Covfacy, is a file-stealing MSIL module attributed to the Zebrocy intrusion set, which is linked to APT28. It is deployed as a component within Zebrocy's toolset, with observed versions including v7.0. The malware's primary function is to steal files from compromised systems. Its target platform is Windows, leveraging MSIL for execution and potentially using registry keys for persistence. Infrastructure and deployment are managed through the broader Zebrocy campaign framework.
490.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Name: CovFacy. Aliases: file stealing MSIL modules. Attributed Groups: APT28 (Zebrocy). Key TTPs/Technical Behaviors: Deployed by Zebrocy as MSIL/.NET modules for file exfiltration, with versioning around 7.0-7.1. Target Platforms: Windows. Infrastructure/Supplementary Info: Described as an unexpected inclusion in the Zebrocy toolset.[/profile]

491.name: file stealing MSIL modules
491.profile: [profile]Name: file stealing MSIL modules. Aliases: CovFacy (a related module). Attributed Groups: APT28 (Zebrocy group). Key TTPs/Technical Behaviors: MSIL components deployed by Zebrocy, specifically modules that drop file-stealing functionality, with versioning noted as v7.0. Target Platforms: Windows (inferred from MSIL). Infrastructure/Supplementary Info: Part of the Zebrocy toolset, associated with data exfiltration activities.
491.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File stealing MSIL modules, also known as CovFacy or Covfacy, is attributed to the Zebrocy intrusion set linked to APT28. It is a component of the Zebrocy toolset, with observed versions including v7.0, and its key behavior is to steal files from compromised systems. The malware targets Windows platforms, as indicated by its MSIL nature and its deployment within the Zebrocy campaign infrastructure.

492.name: splm/x-agent modules
492.uncertain_mes:
The post contains malware samples analyzed in the APT28 reports linked below. I will post APT29 and others later.
List of References (and samples mentioned) listed from oldest to newest:
- APT28_2011-09_Telus_Trojan.Win32.Sofacy.A

- APT28_2014-10_Fireeye_A_Window_into_Russia_Cyber_Esp.Operations

492.profile: [profile]The malware is known as SPLM/X-Agent modules, with X-Agent as a common alias. It is attributed to the APT28 group, which is also referenced as Sofacy. Key technical behaviors include the development of large, fully functional modules that support the OS X platform. Infrastructure and supplementary information links it to samples and reports such as APT28_2011-09_Telus_Trojan.Win32.Sofacy.A, APT28_2014-08_MhtMS12-27_Prevenity, APT28_2014-10_Fireeye_A_Window_into_Russia_Cyber_Esp.Operations, and APT28_2014-10_Telus_Coreshell.A.
492.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is named SPLM/X-Agent modules, which are components of the X-Agent malware family, also known as Sofacy. It is attributed to the APT28 group. These modules are notable for being large, fully functional components that support the OS X platform, indicating cross-platform targeting capabilities as part of broader espionage operations.

493.name: TLV1
493.profile: [profile]TLV1 is a custom command and control protocol used by the intrusion set Sofacy. It operates within the Command and Control tactic, primarily on Windows platforms. The protocol avoids using standard application layer protocols, instead implementing custom communication, potentially over raw sockets, to blend in with network traffic. Adversaries may further obfuscate this protocol by adding junk data between significant characters to hinder traffic analysis and detection.[/profile]
493.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TLV1 is a custom command and control protocol technique (likely T1094) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates by implementing a custom protocol, which can mimic legitimate protocols or use raw sockets on top of standard TCP/IP network stacks, to evade detection that relies on known application layer protocol analysis. This method avoids encapsulating data in existing protocols.

494.name: HTTP
494.profile: [profile]HTTP is a common web protocol used by adversaries for command and control (C2) and data exfiltration, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK techniques T1071.001 (Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols) and T1048.003 (Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol). It operates under the Command and Control and Exfiltration tactics on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Attackers embed commands and stolen data within standard HTTP/S traffic, utilizing its numerous headers and fields to conceal communications and mimic normal activity. This method is frequently employed by groups like Turla, Sofacy, Lazarus, and APT33 to blend in with legitimate web traffic and evade network detection.[profile]
494.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTP is a common application layer protocol (T1071.001) used for Command and Control and Exfiltration (T1048.003) within the Application Layer Protocol tactic. Adversaries embed commands and stolen data within standard HTTP/S traffic and its numerous header fields to avoid detection by mimicking normal web traffic. This unencrypted protocol is also abused in Domain Fronting (T1172), where different domain names are used in the TLS and HTTP headers to obfuscate the true command and control destination.

495.name: TLSv1.2
495.profile: [profile]The entity "TLSv1.2" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is referenced as an underlying protocol encryption layer, specifically within the technique of multilayer encryption (T1079), where adversaries tunnel custom encryption within standard secure protocols like HTTPS. It is directly associated with the intrusion set Sofacy. The technical mechanics involve using TLSv1.2 to encapsulate and obfuscate command and control communications, blending with normal web traffic to avoid detection.[/profile]
495.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TLSv1.2 is a cryptographic protocol, not a MITRE ATT&CK attack pattern. It is a foundational component of secure web communications, often used as a transport layer for command and control (C2) to encrypt and obfuscate malicious traffic. Adversaries leverage it within broader techniques like Web Protocols (T1071.001) to blend C2 communications with legitimate HTTPS traffic, making detection more difficult.

496.name: SMTP
496.profile: [profile]The entity name is SMTP, which is not a standalone MITRE ATT&CK technique but a protocol referenced within techniques. It is primarily associated with the Application Layer Protocol technique (T1071.003) under the Command and Control tactic, where adversaries use SMTP to blend malicious communications with normal email traffic for stealth. SMTP is also referenced in Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol (T1048) for data theft. The protocol is commonly exploited by groups like APT28 and Turla to conceal command data within email packets or messages, leveraging its common presence in network environments to avoid detection.
496.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "SMTP" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique name. Based on the retrieved context, it likely refers to the use of the SMTP protocol for malicious purposes. The relevant MITRE technique is "Application Layer Protocol: Mail Protocols" (ID: T1071.003), which falls under the Command and Control tactic. Adversaries abuse protocols like SMTP to blend command and control or data exfiltration traffic with normal electronic mail delivery, embedding commands and data within protocol traffic or email messages to avoid detection. This is associated with groups like APT28, Turla, and Kimsuky.

499.name: visa applications
499.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse components of the Electron framework to execute malicious code. The Electron framework hosts many common applications such as Signal, Slack, and Microsoft Teams.(Citation: Electron 2) Originally developed by GitHub, Electron is a cross-platform desktop application development framework that employs web technologies like JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.(Citation: Electron 3) The Chromium engine is used to display web content and Node.js runs the backend code.(Citation: Electron 1)

Due to the functional mechanics of Electron (such as allowing apps to run arbitrary commands), adversaries may also be able to perform malicious functions in the background potentially disguised as legitimate tools within the framework.(Citation: Electron 1) For example, the abuse of `teams.exe` and `chrome.exe` may allow adversaries to execute malicious commands as child processes of the legitimate application (e.g., `chrome.exe --disable-gpu-sandbox --gpu-launcher="C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c calc.exe`).(Citation: Electron 6-8)

Adversaries may also execute malicious content by planting malicious [JavaScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/007) within Electron applications.(Citation: Electron Security)
499.profile: [profile]Electron Applications, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1218.015 under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms, involves abusing the Electron framework to execute malicious code. This is achieved by running malicious commands as child processes of legitimate Electron applications like `teams.exe` or `chrome.exe` using specific command-line arguments (e.g., `--gpu-launcher` to spawn `cmd.exe`), or by planting malicious JavaScript within the application. The intrusion set Sofacy has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
499.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "visa applications" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it may be a conceptual or specific instance of a broader technique like Exploitation for Client Execution (T1203), where adversaries exploit vulnerabilities in common client applications that users expect and trust, such as productivity or third-party software, to execute arbitrary code. This often involves targeting applications through phishing or drive-by compromises to gain initial access to a system.

500.name: border control management
500.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse control.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads. The Windows Control Panel process binary (control.exe) handles execution of Control Panel items, which are utilities that allow users to view and adjust computer settings. Control Panel items are registered executable (.exe) or Control Panel (.cpl) files, the latter are actually renamed dynamic-link library (.dll) files that export a CPlApplet function.(Citation: Microsoft Implementing CPL)(Citation: TrendMicro CPL Malware Jan 2014) For ease of use, Control Panel items typically include graphical menus available to users after being registered and loaded into the Control Panel.(Citation: Microsoft Implementing CPL) Control Panel items can be executed directly from the command line, programmatically via an application programming interface (API) call, or by simply double-clicking the file.(Citation: Microsoft Implementing CPL) (Citation: TrendMicro CPL Malware Jan 2014)(Citation: TrendMicro CPL Malware Dec 2013) Malicious Control Panel items can be delivered via [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) campaigns(Citation: TrendMicro CPL Malware Jan 2014)(Citation: TrendMicro CPL Malware Dec 2013) or executed as part of multi-stage malware.(Citation: Palo Alto Reaver Nov 2017) Control Panel items, specifically CPL files, may also bypass application and/or file extension allow lists. Adversaries may also rename malicious DLL files (.dll) with Control Panel file extensions (.cpl) and register them to HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Control Panel\Cpls. Even when these registered DLLs do not comply with the CPL file specification and do not export CPlApplet functions, they are loaded and executed through its DllEntryPoint when Control Panel is executed. CPL files not exporting CPlApplet are not directly executable.(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)
500.profile: [profile]Control Panel, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1218.002, is a Defense Evasion and Execution technique for Windows. It involves abusing the legitimate control.exe process or Control Panel items (.cpl files, which are renamed DLLs) to proxy malicious code execution. Adversaries can execute these items via command line, API calls, or by double-clicking, and may register malicious DLLs with a .cpl extension in the Windows Registry to be loaded via their DllEntryPoint when Control Panel runs, potentially bypassing application allow lists. The intrusion-set Sofacy has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
500.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "border control management" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it appears to be a conceptual adversary behavior for maintaining exclusive access to a compromised system, aligning with the MITRE technique Exclusive Control (T1668) under the Impact tactic. This involves actions like patching exploited vulnerabilities, disabling services, stripping account privileges, or removing other malware to prevent competing threat actors from accessing the same resource, thereby reducing operational noise and maximizing the adversary's control.

501.name: administrative instructions
501.profile: [profile]The entity "administrative instructions" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is associated with the Sofacy intrusion set and appears to be a general concept for command and control (C2) mechanisms. Related techniques include using one-way communication via external web services (T1102.003) to send commands without receiving output, employing multilayer encryption (T1079) to obfuscate C2 traffic, and abusing installer packages (T1546.016) with post-installation scripts to establish persistence with elevated privileges.[/profile]
501.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Administrative Instructions is a command and control technique (T1102.003) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates by using legitimate, one-way communication channels like popular websites or social media platforms to send commands to a compromised system without expecting a direct response over the same channel. This method provides significant cover by blending into normal network traffic to services like Google or Twitter, which often use SSL/TLS encryption for added protection.

514.name: Fancy Bear
514.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
514.profile: [profile]Fancy Bear, also known as APT28, Sednit, Sofacy, Pawn Storm, and STRONTIUM, is a cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's GRU Unit 26165. Its arsenal includes tools like DownRage. The group is known for spear-phishing and credential-harvesting campaigns, and has targeted government, political, and sporting organizations globally, including the U.S. Democratic National Committee and the World Anti-Doping Agency, primarily for intelligence gathering and political influence.
514.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Fancy Bear, also known as APT28, Sednit, Sofacy, Pawn Storm, Strontium, and Forest Blizzard, is a Russian cyber espionage group attributed to Unit 26165 of the GRU. Its key malware and tools include BlackEnergybot, and it employs spear phishing, SQL injection, and domain spoofing to target government entities, political organizations, and election infrastructure in regions like Ukraine, the United States, Germany, and Turkey. The group's motivation is primarily strategic intelligence collection and influence operations in support of Russian state interests.

525.name: Domain Spoofing
525.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.(Citation: rfc2131) The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 1. The client broadcasts a `DISCOVER` message. 2. The server responds with an `OFFER` message, which includes an available network address. 3. The client broadcasts a `REQUEST` message, which includes the network address offered. 4. The server acknowledges with an `ACK` message and the client receives the network configuration parameters. Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.(Citation: new_rogue_DHCP_serv_malware)(Citation: w32.tidserv.g) Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network. DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a INFORMATION-REQUEST (code 11) message to the All_DHCP_Relay_Agents_and_Servers multicast address.(Citation: rfc3315) Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations. Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, [Service Exhaustion Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002)) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a networkâ€™s DHCP allocation pool.
525.profile: [profile]The entity is MITRE ATT&CK technique DHCP Spoofing (T1557.003) under the Collection tactic, targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves an adversary operating a rogue DHCP server on a victim network to intercept and redirect client traffic. The technique works by spoofing DHCP messages (like DISCOVER, REQUEST, or DHCPv6 INFORMATION-REQUEST) to provide malicious network configurations, such as adversary-controlled DNS servers. This establishes an adversary-in-the-middle position to collect credentials and network communications, particularly from unencrypted protocols, and can enable follow-on sniffing or data manipulation. It is also abused for DHCP exhaustion attacks via broadcast floods. Associated threat actors include Fancy Bear.[/profile]
525.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Domain Spoofing is a technique where adversaries fake or impersonate legitimate domains to establish contact with victims under false pretenses, often by modifying email headers like the FROM field to appear as a trusted sender. This can succeed when the targeted domain lacks or has weak email authentication protocols such as SPF, DKIM, and DMARC, enabling phishing and impersonation attacks. It is commonly associated with the Initial Access tactic, targeting multiple platforms, and is a subset of broader spoofing behaviors used to deceive users and bypass security measures.

526.name: Anonymity Services
526.profile: [profile]Anonymity Services is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it is a resource (infrastructure) that adversaries may acquire or compromise to obscure their identity and location. This includes using services like Virtual Private Servers (VPS) from providers with minimal registration to enable more anonymous operations for activities like command and control. The intrusion-set Fancy Bear is linked to this entity.
526.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Anonymity Services is a technique leveraged by adversaries to obscure their infrastructure and identity, often by utilizing services like Tor, VPNs, or proxy networks. This method supports multiple tactics including Command and Control, Defense Evasion, and Initial Access. It operates across various platforms. Technically, adversaries route their malicious traffic through these intermediary services to hide the true source IP addresses and locations, making attribution and detection more difficult. This can involve renting or compromising Virtual Private Servers (VPS) from providers with minimal registration to enable more anonymous operations.

533.name: Threat Group 4127
533.uncertain_mes: [Threat Group-1314](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0028) is an unattributed threat group that has used compromised credentials to log into a victim's remote access infrastructure. (Citation: Dell TG-1314)
533.profile: [profile]Threat Group 4127, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Pawn Storm, SEDNIT, and SOFACY, is a highly active intrusion set attributed to the Russian government. Its arsenal and TTPs are not detailed in the provided data, but the group is known for sophisticated cyber operations. Its primary motivation is believed to be espionage, targeting sectors and regions aligned with Russian strategic interests, though specific victimology is not enumerated here. The group shows significant overlap with clusters like TG-1314, which uses compromised credentials for initial access.[/profile]
533.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, STRONTIUM, Pawn Storm, Tsar Team, and Threat Group-4127. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, SedUploader, and Zebrocy. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting, often using fake Google login pages and Bitly links, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and the use of Base64 encoding for obfuscation. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. It primarily targets government, military, diplomatic, and political organizations in NATO countries, Europe, and North America, with notable operations against entities like the Democratic National Committee and German parliament, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.[/profile]

Its operations are strategically motivated, primarily targeting government, military, and political organizations in North America, Europe, and former Soviet states to conduct espionage and influence operations.

543.name: SEDNIT
543.uncertain_mes:
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) 85th Main Special Service Center (GTsSS) military unit 26165.(Citation: NSA/FBI Drovorub August 2020)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory GRU Brute Force Campaign July 2021) This group has been active since at least 2004.(Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Ars Technica GRU indictment Jul 2018)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: FireEye APT28)(Citation: SecureWorks TG-4127)(Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Sofacy DealersChoice)(Citation: Palo Alto Sofacy 06-2018)(Citation: Symantec APT28 Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Zebrocy May 2019)

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
543.profile: [profile]SEDNIT, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and Pawn Storm, is a highly active cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Unit 26165. Its arsenal includes custom malware like SedUploader and the notable LoJax UEFI rootkit. The group's operations, which began around 2004, primarily target government, political, and defense sectors in North America and Europe, with a clear motivation for political interference and intelligence gathering, as evidenced by its compromise of the 2016 US Democratic National Committee and attacks against organizations like the World Anti-Doping Agency.
543.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, Tsar Team, and Threat Group 4127. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) and X-Tunnel backdoors, Seduploader, Zebrocy, and the UEFI rootkit LoJax. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and data exfiltration via tools like USBStealer. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, political, and diplomatic organizations in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations to support Russian state interests.[/profile]
543.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]SEDNIT is an alias for the Russian state-sponsored APT group more commonly known as APT28 (Fancy Bear, Sofacy Group, or STRONTIUM). It is known for using custom malware like SedUploader and the LoJax UEFI rootkit, and its campaigns have historically targeted government, military, and political organizations across North America and Europe, primarily for espionage and information operations.
543.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The entity SEDNIT is a primary alias for the Russian state-sponsored APT group more commonly standardized as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, STRONTIUM, and Pawn Storm. Its key custom malware includes SedUploader, a first-stage backdoor, and it is notably attributed with deploying LoJax, the first UEFI rootkit discovered in active use. The group's operations are believed to be conducted by Russia's military intelligence agency, the GRU (Unit 26165), primarily targeting government, military, and political organizations in North America and Europe for espionage and information operations aligned with Russian state interests.

Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing for credential harvesting and the exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities in software like Microsoft Office. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, political, and diplomatic organizations in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and information operations to support Russian strategic interests.[/profile]

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016) In 2018, the US indicted five GRU Unit 26165 officers associated with [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) for cyber operations (including close-access operations) conducted between 2014 and 2018 against the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA), the US Anti-Doping Agency, a US nuclear facility, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), the Spiez Swiss Chemicals Laboratory, and other organizations.(Citation: US District Court Indictment GRU Oct 2018) Some of these were conducted with the assistance of GRU Unit 74455, which is also referred to as [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034).
544.profile: [profile]PAWN STORM, also known as APT28, Fancy Bear, Sofacy, Sednit, and STRONTIUM, is a highly active threat group attributed to Russia's GRU Unit 26165. Its arsenal includes custom malware like Sofacy and is associated with Threat Group 4127. The group employs sophisticated spear-phishing, zero-day exploits, and widespread brute-force credential attacks. It primarily targets government, political, and diplomatic sectors in the US and Europe, as well as organizations like anti-doping agencies and think tanks, with motivations centered on espionage and geopolitical influence operations.

The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, political, and diplomatic organizations in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations to support Russian state interests.[/profile]

The group shows operational overlaps with APT29 (Cozy Bear) and has been linked to campaigns like Operation Pawn Storm.

545.name: Russian government
545.profile: [profile]The Russian government is a state-level actor, also known as Threat Group 4127 and Sofacy. Its arsenal includes the custom malware Cloudsorcerer. It is attributed to Russia and primarily targets government organizations within the Russian Federation itself. Its motivations are believed to be aligned with state interests, including potential domestic law enforcement and control, as suggested by legislative actions to seize cybercrime proceeds.

The group's operations show a focus on domestic governmental targets within the Russian Federation, distinguishing it from groups primarily targeting foreign entities.
