546.name: Spear-phishing
546.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
546.profile: [profile]Spear-phishing, identified as T1566, is a targeted Initial Access technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework applicable to multiple platforms. It involves sending tailored electronic messages, such as emails with malicious attachments or links, to specific individuals or organizations to execute code via user interaction. Evasive methods include email spoofing, thread hijacking, and manipulating email headers or metadata from compromised accounts. It is distinct from general phishing (T1566) and information-focused phishing (T1598), and is associated with groups like Threat Group 4127 and Sofacy.[/profile]
546.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-phishing is a targeted social engineering technique, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves sending tailored electronic messages, such as emails, to specific individuals or organizations to trick them into executing malicious code, often via malicious attachments or links, or divulging sensitive information. The technique relies on posing as a trusted source and may employ evasive methods like email spoofing or thread hijacking to increase success.

547.name: Intelligence Operation
547.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may obtain access to generative artificial intelligence tools, such as large language models (LLMs), to aid various techniques during targeting. These tools may be used to inform, bolster, and enable a variety of malicious tasks, including conducting [Reconnaissance](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0043), creating basic scripts, assisting social engineering, and even developing payloads.(Citation: MSFT-AI) 

For example, by utilizing a publicly available LLM an adversary is essentially outsourcing or automating certain tasks to the tool. Using AI, the adversary may draft and generate content in a variety of written languages to be used in [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566)/[Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) campaigns. The same publicly available tool may further enable vulnerability or other offensive research supporting [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587). AI tools may also automate technical tasks by generating, refining, or otherwise enhancing (e.g., [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027)) malicious scripts and payloads.(Citation: OpenAI-CTI) Finally, AI-generated text, images, audio, and video may be used for fraud, [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656), and other malicious activities.(Citation: Google-Vishing24)(Citation: IC3-AI24)(Citation: WSJ-Vishing-AI24)
547.profile: [profile]The entity is a technique named "Obtain Capabilities: Artificial Intelligence" with MITRE ATT&CK ID T1588.007 under the Resource Development tactic and applicable across multiple platforms. Adversaries use this technique by accessing generative AI tools, such as large language models (LLMs), to automate and enhance malicious tasks. Specifically, these tools can draft multilingual phishing content, generate or refine malicious scripts and payloads, conduct vulnerability research, and create synthetic media for impersonation and fraud, thereby outsourcing and scaling various stages of an attack.
547.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Intelligence Operation" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely describes adversarial reconnaissance activities involving the collection of information from threat intelligence sources. This includes searching private threat vendor data (T1597.001) for trends and successful TTPs, and specifically monitoring such sources for information about the adversary's own campaigns (T1681) to potentially alter their behavior or infrastructure in response to public reporting. The activity supports the Reconnaissance tactic and can involve both open and closed sources to gather actionable intelligence for future operations.

548.name: Base64-encoded string
548.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may encrypt or encode files to obfuscate strings, bytes, and other specific patterns to impede detection. Encrypting and/or encoding file content aims to conceal malicious artifacts within a file used in an intrusion. Many other techniques, such as [Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), [Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003), and [Embedded Payloads](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/009), share this same broad objective. Encrypting and/or encoding files could lead to a lapse in detection of static signatures, only for this malicious content to be revealed (i.e., [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140)) at the time of execution/use.

This type of file obfuscation can be applied to many file artifacts present on victim hosts, such as malware log/configuration and payload files.(Citation: File obfuscation) Files can be encrypted with a hardcoded or user-supplied key, as well as otherwise obfuscated using standard encoding schemes such as Base64.

The entire content of a file may be obfuscated, or just specific functions or values (such as C2 addresses). Encryption and encoding may also be applied in redundant layers for additional protection.

For example, adversaries may abuse password-protected Word documents or self-extracting (SFX) archives as a method of encrypting/encoding a file such as a [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) payload. These files typically function by attaching the intended archived content to a decompressor stub that is executed when the file is invoked (e.g., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: SFX - Encrypted/Encoded File) 

Adversaries may also abuse file-specific as well as custom encoding schemes. For example, Byte Order Mark (BOM) headers in text files may be abused to manipulate and obfuscate file content until [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) execution.
548.profile: [profile]Encrypted/Encoded File, identified as T1027.013 under the Defense Evasion tactic, operates across multiple platforms. This technique obfuscates file content, such as malware payloads or configuration data, using methods like encryption with a hardcoded key or standard encoding schemes like Base64. It can be applied to entire files or specific values like C2 addresses, often in redundant layers, and may involve abusing password-protected documents or self-extracting archives to conceal artifacts until execution reveals them. Groups like Sofacy and Threat Group 4127 are associated with its use.[/profile]
548.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Base64-encoded string is a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027) under the Defense Evasion tactic. It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. The technique involves using the Base64 binary-to-text encoding scheme to obfuscate strings, bytes, and other patterns within files or network traffic, such as malware configuration or C2 payloads, to impede static signature detection. It is commonly employed by threat groups like Lazarus Group and APT33.

549.name: Persistent Access
549.profile: [profile]Persistent Access is a deprecated technique, now represented by standard MITRE ATT&CK techniques such as Create Account (T1136), Web Shell (T1505.003), and External Remote Services (T1133) under the Persistence tactic. It involves maintaining network footholds through redundant mechanisms, including using multiple remote access tools with different C2 protocols, leveraging credentialed access via external VPNs or valid accounts, and deploying web shells on externally accessible servers to ensure continued access if one method is detected or removed. Associated intrusion sets include Sofacy and Threat Group 4127.[/profile]
549.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Persistent Access is a deprecated technique, with its functions now covered by standard MITRE ATT&CK techniques such as Create Account (T1136), Web Shell (T1505.003), and External Remote Services (T1133). It was used in the Persistence tactic across multiple platforms. The technique involved maintaining network access by deploying multiple remote access tools with different command and control protocols or by establishing credentialed access to external services like VPNs. This redundancy ensured that if one access method was detected and removed, the adversary could retain footholds using alternate channels, including cloud infrastructure or externally accessible web servers.[/profile]

552.name: Malware
552.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
552.profile: [profile]The malware is known as "nmass". It is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) and backdoor. It is deployed via a malicious Royal Road (v7) decoy document that is fake-signed by "A. Amarsaikhan" and pretends to be about COVID-19 infections in Russia, specifically targeting Mongolian authorities. The malware drops an initial executable named "os03C2.tmp". Its technical profile shows strong similarities to tools and campaigns historically used by threat groups tracked as Operation LagTime and Tonto Team. Neighboring intrusion sets in its context include Turla, Sofacy, and Threat Group 4127.[/profile]
552.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT), also known as nmass. It is deployed via a malicious Royal Road (v7) document posing as a COVID-19 report targeting Mongolian authorities. The infection chain drops an initial executable (e.g., os03C2.tmp) and exhibits similarities to campaigns historically linked to Operation LagTime or Tonto Team. Its primary targets are Windows systems.

554.name: Azzy
554.profile: [profile]Azzy is a malware attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include functioning as an installer for version 4.3 implants, dropping a C&C helper DLL, and deploying file collectors or USB stealers. It is associated with other malware families like AdvStoreShell, EvilToss, and NetUI, and is referenced in the context of related malware entities such as Coreshell and X-Agent.[/profile]
554.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Azzy, also known as AdvStoreShell, EvilToss, and NetUI, is attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) group. It functions as a spying backdoor for long-term espionage, part of a multi-generational toolset. Its key technical behaviors include remote access and control, with specific versions like AZZY 4.3 using installer files and dropped C&C helper DLLs. The primary target platform is Windows, and it is associated with other Sofacy tools like CORESHELL and Xagent.[/profile]

555.name: CoreShell
555.uncertain_mes: [CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) is a downloader used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). The older versions of this malware are known as SOURFACE and newer versions as CORESHELL.(Citation: FireEye APT28) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
555.profile: [profile]CoreShell, also known as SOURFACE for older versions, is a downloader malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. It is typically delivered as a .dll file attached to documents and includes unused code to mimic legitimate instructions, potentially for evasion. Its primary function is to download additional payloads onto compromised Windows systems.
555.profile_without_enhance: [profile]CoreShell is a malware downloader also known as SOURFACE. It is attributed to the APT28 group. Its key technical behaviors include being distributed as a .dll file attached to documents and containing unused code to mimic legitimate instructions and bypass security. It targets the Windows platform.

556.name: SPLM
556.profile: [profile]SPLM, also known as XAgent, is attributed to the Sofacy intrusion set (APT28). Its key technical behavior involves a global deployment pattern, with reporting indicating its use by Sofacy declined in 2018 as detections wound down. The malware's target platform is unspecified in the provided data, and no specific infrastructure details are available.]
556.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SPLM, also known as XAgent, is a malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. It was actively used in 2018, after which global detections began to decline. Its key technical behaviors include distribution mechanisms, though specific TTPs are not detailed in the provided context. The target platforms are unspecified. The malware's infrastructure and use are linked to the Sofacy group's operations.

557.name: XAgent
557.profile: [profile]XAgent, also known as x-agent, is a malware family attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. It has been developed in multiple versions, including version 1 for Windows in 2014 and version 3 for both Linux and Windows by 2015, with later Windows modules incorporating obfuscated Run-Time Type Information (RTTI). Its primary target platforms are Windows and Linux systems.[/profile]
557.profile_without_enhance: [profile]XAgent, also known as x-agent, is a malware attributed to APT28. It has versions for Windows and Linux platforms, with version 1 for Windows introduced in 2014 and version 3 for Linux and Windows introduced in 2014-2015. A key technical behavior is the use of modules with obfuscated Run-Time Type Information (RTTI) in later versions. It is associated with the tool XTunnel.

558.name: Chopstick
558.uncertain_mes: [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) is a malware family of modular backdoors used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It has been used since at least 2012 and is usually dropped on victims as second-stage malware, though it has been used as first-stage malware in several cases. It has both Windows and Linux variants. (Citation: FireEye APT28) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017) (Citation: DOJ GRU Indictment Jul 2018) It is tracked separately from the [X-Agent for Android](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0314).
558.profile: [profile]CHOPSTICK is a modular backdoor malware family used by APT28 (Sofacy) since at least 2012, typically deployed as second-stage malware. It has both Windows and Linux variants and is part of a shared infrastructure and modular framework with other APT28 malware like X-Agent and Zebrocy, targeting entities in multiple countries including Turkey, Kazakhstan, and Germany.[/profile]
558.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Chopstick, also known as CHOPSTICK, is a modular backdoor malware family used by APT28 since at least 2012, deployed as both first and second-stage malware with Windows and Linux variants. It is part of the SPLM/CHOPSTICK/XAgent modularity and infrastructure framework, sharing targeting and infrastructure patterns with related malware like X-Agent and Zebrocy, which have been used against targets in countries including Turkey, Kazakhstan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, Germany, Lithuania, and the Netherlands.

559.name: JhuHugit
559.uncertain_mes: [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) is malware used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007). It is based on Carberp source code and serves as reconnaissance malware. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: F-Secure Sofacy 2015) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 1) (Citation: FireEye APT28 January 2017)
559.profile: [profile]JHUHUGIT, also known as jhuhugit, is a reconnaissance malware attributed to APT28 (Sofacy). It is based on the Carberp source code and was used as a first-stage implant in Sofacy attacks, including in conjunction with a Java zero-day (CVE-2015-2590) in July 2015. Its key behavior is system reconnaissance, and it targets Windows platforms.
559.profile_without_enhance: [profile]JhuHugit, also known as JHUHUGIT, is reconnaissance malware attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). It is based on the Carberp source code and was used as a first-stage implant in attacks, including those exploiting a Java zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2015-2590). Its technical behaviors include creating a registry key for persistence. The malware primarily targets systems vulnerable to Java exploits.[profile]

560.name: Jkeyskw
560.profile: [profile]Jkeyskw, also known as JHUHUGIT, is a first-level implant used by the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. It serves as a reconnaissance and downloader component, often deployed as part of multi-backdoor packages alongside other implants like Seduploader for target confirmation and data exfiltration.
560.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Jkeyskw, also known as JHUHUGIT, is a malware implant used by the APT28 (Sofacy/Sednit) group. It functions as a first-stage implant and downloader for reconnaissance, often deployed in multi-backdoor packages. The malware is part of a toolkit that includes the Seduploader reconnaissance malware, which is used for target confirmation and consists of a dropper and a persistent payload.

561.name: AzzyTrojan
561.profile: [profile]AzzyTrojan, also known as AZZYTrojan, is attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. It is a first-level implant used in high-profile attacks, representing the latest evolution of the group's tools. The malware is characterized by its use within multi-backdoor packages, and it is associated with information-stealing capabilities similar to those of Azorult.
561.profile_without_enhance: [profile]AzzyTrojan, also known as AZZYTrojan, is attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). It is a first-level implant used in high-profile attacks, representing the latest evolution of the group's tools. It is part of multi-backdoor packages, with recurring characteristics of the group being speed. The malware is associated with information stealers like Azorult, and related groups include TA505 and Silence Group.

562.name: AdvStoreShell
562.uncertain_mes: [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) is a spying backdoor that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) from at least 2012 to 2016. It is generally used for long-term espionage and is deployed on targets deemed interesting after a reconnaissance phase. (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy) (Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2)
562.profile: [profile]AdvStoreShell, also known as AZZY, NETUI, EVILTOSS, and CHOPSTICK, is a spying backdoor attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. It has been used for long-term espionage from at least 2012 to 2016, deployed on high-value targets after reconnaissance. The malware's technical lineage spans 4-5 generations and it is part of an expanded arsenal that includes tools like CORESHELL and Xagent.[/profile]
562.profile_without_enhance: [profile]AdvStoreShell, also known as AZZY, NETUI, and EVILTOSS, is a spying backdoor attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. It is used for long-term espionage, deployed after reconnaissance on high-value targets. Key technical behaviors include the use of a dedicated installer and the deployment of file collectors or USB stealers. It is associated with other malware families like Coreshell and X-Agent.[/profile]

563.name: NetUI
563.profile: [profile]NetUI, also known as ADVSTORESHELL, EVILTOSS, and AZZY, is a backdoor attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). It is part of a broader arsenal that includes tools like CORESHELL, SPLM (Xagent/CHOPSTICK), and JHUHUGIT, with NetUI itself spanning 4-5 generations. Its key technical behaviors involve functioning as a backdoor for unauthorized access and control. The malware primarily targets Windows platforms, as indicated by its association with the legitimate netui.dll system file and related versioning information.[/profile]
563.profile_without_enhance: [profile]NetUI is a malware implant, also known as an alias for Azzy, AdvStoreShell, and EvilToss. It is attributed to the Sofacy group (APT28). Key technical behaviors include the use of a dedicated installer, dropping a Command & Control helper DLL, and deploying file collectors or USB stealers. It is associated with other malware families like Coreshell and X-Agent, and it targets the Windows platform.[/profile]

564.name: EvilToss
564.profile: [profile]EvilToss, also known as ADVSTORESHELL, NETUI, and AZZY, is a backdoor attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. It is part of a multi-generational toolset and is technically related to the Azzy malware. Its operations are associated with the criminal group Indrik Spider, also known as Twisted Spider, which is linked to ransomware activities like LockBit and FriedEx.[profile]
564.profile_without_enhance: [profile]EvilToss, also known as ADVSTORESHELL and NETUI, is a malware implant attributed to the Sofacy (APT28) intrusion set. It is part of a multi-generational arsenal that includes related malware families like Azzy, Coreshell, and X-Agent. Key technical behaviors involve the use of a dedicated installer, dropping a Command & Control helper DLL, and deploying file collectors or USB stealers. It targets Windows platforms and is associated with the broader Sofacy group's infrastructure and campaigns.[/profile]

565.name: USB Stealer
565.uncertain_mes: [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) is malware that has been used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) since at least 2005 to extract information from air-gapped networks. It does not have the capability to communicate over the Internet and has been used in conjunction with [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045). (Citation: ESET Sednit USBStealer 2014) (Citation: Kaspersky Sofacy)
565.profile: [profile]USB Stealer, also known as USBStealer, is a malware attributed to the APT28 (Sofacy) group. It is designed to extract information from air-gapped networks, lacking internet communication capability, and has been used alongside ADVSTORESHELL. Its key technical behavior involves retrieving serial numbers and product IDs of connected USB devices via the IOCTL_STORAGE_QUERY_PROPERTY system call, with a default fallback value of "undef". It primarily targets Windows systems and has been associated with campaigns since at least 2005, though its use declined after mid-2015.
565.profile_without_enhance: [profile]USB Stealer, also known as USBStealer, is a network tool designed to extract sensitive information from air-gapped networks. It is attributed to APT28 and operates by retrieving the serial numbers and product IDs of connected USB devices using the IOCTL_STORAGE_QUERY_PROPERTY system call, with a default fallback value of "undef" in case of failure.

567.name: 3DES
567.profile: [profile]3DES is a symmetric encryption algorithm used by adversaries to conceal command and control traffic, referenced under MITRE ATT&CK ID T1573.001. It operates within the Command and Control tactic and is platform-agnostic. The technique involves using the same key for both encryption and decryption of data, and it is commonly employed alongside other algorithms like AES and DES by groups such as Sofacy, MuddyWater, and APT28 to obfuscate network communications.[/profile]
567.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "3DES" is a symmetric encryption algorithm, referenced in the context of MITRE ATT&CK sub-technique T1573.001 (Encrypted Channel: Symmetric Cryptography) under the Command and Control tactic. It is used by adversaries to obfuscate C2 traffic by applying the same key for encryption and decryption, commonly listed alongside other algorithms like AES and DES. This method relies on the secrecy of the key, which can be compromised if embedded within malware.

568.name: XOR
568.profile: [profile]The entity "XOR" is a fundamental encryption technique, not a distinct MITRE ATT&CK attack pattern. It is referenced within techniques such as T1560.003 (Archive via Custom Method) and T1024 (Custom Cryptographic Protocol), where adversaries use XOR operations with a fixed key to obfuscate data for exfiltration or command and control. This method produces weak ciphertext that is often trivial to decode upon analysis. It has been employed by groups like Sofacy, Lazarus Group, and APT28 in custom implementations to avoid detection by standard tools.
568.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "XOR" is a fundamental bitwise operation often used as a weak, custom cryptographic technique within cyber attacks. It is referenced in MITRE ATT&CK techniques T1560.003 (Archive via Custom Method) for data obfuscation prior to exfiltration and T1024 (Custom Cryptographic Protocol) for hiding command and control traffic. Adversaries implement XOR with a fixed key as a simple, custom encryption scheme to bypass detection, though it produces weak ciphertext that is often reversible through malware analysis. Groups like FIN6, Lazarus Group, and UNC3886 have employed such methods.

569.name: WinINET API
569.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may interact with the native OS application programming interface (API) to execute behaviors. Native APIs provide a controlled means of calling low-level OS services within the kernel, such as those involving hardware/devices, memory, and processes.(Citation: NT API Windows)(Citation: Linux Kernel API) These native APIs are leveraged by the OS during system boot (when other system components are not yet initialized) as well as carrying out tasks and requests during routine operations. Adversaries may abuse these OS API functions as a means of executing behaviors. Similar to [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059), the native API and its hierarchy of interfaces provide mechanisms to interact with and utilize various components of a victimized system. Native API functions (such as NtCreateProcess) may be directed invoked via system calls / syscalls, but these features are also often exposed to user-mode applications via interfaces and libraries.(Citation: OutFlank System Calls)(Citation: CyberBit System Calls)(Citation: MDSec System Calls) For example, functions such as the Windows API CreateProcess() or GNU fork() will allow programs and scripts to start other processes.(Citation: Microsoft CreateProcess)(Citation: GNU Fork) This may allow API callers to execute a binary, run a CLI command, load modules, etc. as thousands of similar API functions exist for various system operations.(Citation: Microsoft Win32)(Citation: LIBC)(Citation: GLIBC) Higher level software frameworks, such as Microsoft .NET and macOS Cocoa, are also available to interact with native APIs. These frameworks typically provide language wrappers/abstractions to API functionalities and are designed for ease-of-use/portability of code.(Citation: Microsoft NET)(Citation: Apple Core Services)(Citation: MACOS Cocoa)(Citation: macOS Foundation) Adversaries may use assembly to directly or in-directly invoke syscalls in an attempt to subvert defensive sensors and detection signatures such as user mode API-hooks.(Citation: Redops Syscalls) Adversaries may also attempt to tamper with sensors and defensive tools associated with API monitoring, such as unhooking monitored functions via [Disable or Modify Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/001).
569.profile: [profile]The entity is a technique known as Native API (T1106) under the Execution tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries directly invoking low-level OS API functions or syscalls, such as NtCreateProcess or CreateProcess(), to execute binaries, commands, or load modules. This method provides a controlled interface to kernel services and can be used to subvert user-mode API hooks for evasion. The technique is associated with groups including Sofacy, Lazarus Group, and Turla.
569.profile_without_enhance: [profile]WinINET API is a native Windows API used for Internet-related functions, categorized under MITRE ATT&CK technique T1106. It operates within the Execution tactic on Windows platforms. Adversaries leverage this API to perform network communications, such as making HTTP/HTTPS requests, to interact with command and control servers or exfiltrate data. The API provides a programmatic interface for managing connections, handling cookies, and caching, enabling malware to blend in with legitimate browser traffic.

570.name: Multi-Layered Approach
570.profile: [profile]Multi-Layered Approach is a strategic concept rather than a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, often associated with intrusion sets like Sofacy. It describes a methodology where adversaries combine multiple distinct techniques to increase operational security and effectiveness. This can involve chaining proxies (T1188) to obscure traffic sources, employing multi-stage C2 channels (T1104) to obfuscate infrastructure, or layering encryption (T1079) within other protocols. The approach aims to complicate detection and analysis by creating a defense that requires defenders to counter several interconnected methods simultaneously.[/profile]
570.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Multi-Layered Approach is a technique for command and control (C2) where adversaries employ multiple distinct stages or protocols to obscure their communications and evade detection. This can involve chaining multiple proxies (T1188) to disguise traffic sources, creating separate multi-stage C2 channels (T1104) with different infrastructure for each stage, or splitting communications across different protocols (T1026) to bypass thresholds. The core technical mechanic is the deliberate segmentation and obfuscation of the C2 flow, making it more difficult for defenders to trace the full communication path or identify the original source.

571.name: Modularization
571.profile: [profile]Modularization is a software development technique where code is organized into separate, interchangeable modules. This approach is utilized by adversaries like the Sofacy intrusion-set to create malware with distinct components, such as separate modules for communication, data exfiltration, and payload delivery. This structure enhances stealth and maintainability, allowing attackers to update or replace specific functionalities without altering the entire malware suite, thereby evading detection and enabling persistent operations across various platforms.
571.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Modularization is a technique where adversaries split malicious code into separate, independent modules. This allows for flexible deployment, where core components can be downloaded on-demand to evade detection. Modules often handle distinct functions like communication or data theft, enabling the malware to update specific capabilities without replacing the entire payload.

572.name: Code Modification
572.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may modify code signing policies to enable execution of unsigned or self-signed code. Code signing provides a level of authenticity on a program from a developer and a guarantee that the program has not been tampered with. Security controls can include enforcement mechanisms to ensure that only valid, signed code can be run on an operating system. Some of these security controls may be enabled by default, such as Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) on Windows or System Integrity Protection (SIP) on macOS.(Citation: Microsoft DSE June 2017)(Citation: Apple Disable SIP) Other such controls may be disabled by default but are configurable through application controls, such as only allowing signed Dynamic-Link Libraries (DLLs) to execute on a system. Since it can be useful for developers to modify default signature enforcement policies during the development and testing of applications, disabling of these features may be possible with elevated permissions.(Citation: Microsoft Unsigned Driver Apr 2017)(Citation: Apple Disable SIP) Adversaries may modify code signing policies in a number of ways, including through use of command-line or GUI utilities, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), rebooting the computer in a debug/recovery mode, or by altering the value of variables in kernel memory.(Citation: Microsoft TESTSIGNING Feb 2021)(Citation: Apple Disable SIP)(Citation: FireEye HIKIT Rootkit Part 2)(Citation: GitHub Turla Driver Loader) Examples of commands that can modify the code signing policy of a system include bcdedit.exe -set TESTSIGNING ON on Windows and csrutil disable on macOS.(Citation: Microsoft TESTSIGNING Feb 2021)(Citation: Apple Disable SIP) Depending on the implementation, successful modification of a signing policy may require reboot of the compromised system. Additionally, some implementations can introduce visible artifacts for the user (ex: a watermark in the corner of the screen stating the system is in Test Mode). Adversaries may attempt to remove such artifacts.(Citation: F-Secure BlackEnergy 2014) To gain access to kernel memory to modify variables related to signature checks, such as modifying g_CiOptions to disable Driver Signature Enforcement, adversaries may conduct [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068) using a signed, but vulnerable driver.(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020)(Citation: GitHub Turla Driver Loader)
572.profile: [profile]Code Signing Policy Modification, identified as T1553.006 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a Defense Evasion technique applicable to Windows and macOS platforms. It involves altering system policies to bypass security controls that enforce code signature validation, enabling the execution of unauthorized code. Specific technical methods include using commands like `bcdedit.exe -set TESTSIGNING ON` on Windows or `csrutil disable` on macOS, modifying kernel memory variables such as `g_CiOptions`, or leveraging registry modifications and reboot into recovery modes. This technique has been associated with groups like Turla and APT39.[/profile]
572.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Code Modification is a technique where adversaries alter legitimate code to achieve malicious objectives, such as bypassing security controls, establishing persistence, or enabling unauthorized functionality. This can involve modifying system binaries, scripts, or configuration files. The technique is associated with groups like APT39 and Turla. Technical mechanics include using command-line utilities or kernel memory manipulation to change code execution policies, such as disabling driver signature enforcement on Windows via commands like `bcdedit.exe -set TESTSIGNING ON`. It is a foundational method for evading defenses and maintaining access within compromised environments.

573.name: Flash Zero-Day Vulnerability
573.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may scan victims for vulnerabilities that can be used during targeting. Vulnerability scans typically check if the configuration of a target host/application (ex: software and version) potentially aligns with the target of a specific exploit the adversary may seek to use.

These scans may also include more broad attempts to [Gather Victim Host Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1592) that can be used to identify more commonly known, exploitable vulnerabilities. Vulnerability scans typically harvest running software and version numbers via server banners, listening ports, or other network artifacts.(Citation: OWASP Vuln Scanning) Information from these scans may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190)).
573.profile: [profile]Flash Zero-Day Vulnerability is a specific instance of exploitation for client execution (T1203) within the initial access tactic, targeting platforms like Windows that use Adobe Flash. This technique involves adversaries exploiting an unknown vulnerability in Adobe Flash Player, often delivered via malicious files like Microsoft Office documents or through browser-based drive-by compromises, to execute arbitrary code on a victim's system without requiring user interaction beyond initial file opening or web page visitation. The intrusion-set Sofacy has been associated with this activity.
573.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Flash Zero-Day Vulnerability is an attack pattern where adversaries exploit previously unknown vulnerabilities in Adobe Flash Player to execute arbitrary code on a target system. This technique is often used for initial access, such as through spearphishing links or malicious documents, and is associated with client execution. It has been leveraged by numerous threat groups, including APT28, APT29, and Lazarus Group, to compromise systems by targeting this common third-party application.

574.name: Windows EOP Vulnerability
574.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may scan victims for vulnerabilities that can be used during targeting. Vulnerability scans typically check if the configuration of a target host/application (ex: software and version) potentially aligns with the target of a specific exploit the adversary may seek to use.

These scans may also include more broad attempts to [Gather Victim Host Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1592) that can be used to identify more commonly known, exploitable vulnerabilities. Vulnerability scans typically harvest running software and version numbers via server banners, listening ports, or other network artifacts.(Citation: OWASP Vuln Scanning) Information from these scans may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190)).
574.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Vulnerability Scanning" with ID T1595.002, categorized under the Reconnaissance tactic and applicable to multiple platforms. It involves adversaries scanning victims to identify exploitable vulnerabilities by checking software configurations, versions via server banners, listening ports, and other network artifacts. This information gathering can facilitate further reconnaissance, capability development, or initial access, as used by groups like APT41 and Sandworm Team.[/profile]
574.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Windows EOP Vulnerability is a technique for privilege escalation on Windows systems, identified as T1068 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework under the Privilege Escalation tactic. It involves exploiting flaws in the operating system or software to gain higher-level permissions. Specific mechanics can include leveraging unquoted service paths, where placing a malicious executable in a directory referenced by a vulnerable service path causes Windows to execute it instead of the legitimate program, or exploiting Component Object Model (COM) interfaces to invoke arbitrary code execution.

575.name: Sandbox Breakout
575.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.(Citation: Deloitte Environment Awareness)

Adversaries may use several methods to accomplish [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) such as checking for security monitoring tools (e.g., Sysinternals, Wireshark, etc.) or other system artifacts associated with analysis or virtualization. Adversaries may also check for legitimate user activity to help determine if it is in an analysis environment. Additional methods include use of sleep timers or loops within malware code to avoid operating within a temporary sandbox.(Citation: Unit 42 Pirpi July 2015)
575.profile: [profile]Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion, identified as T1497, is a Defense Evasion technique used across multiple platforms. It involves detecting analysis environments by checking for artifacts like security tools (e.g., Sysinternals, Wireshark), virtual machine indicators, or lack of legitimate user activity. Upon detection, malware may alter its behavior, disengage, or conceal core functions. Specific methods include using sleep timers or loops to avoid temporary sandboxes. Groups like Sofacy, DarkHotel, and Contagious Interview have employed this technique.[/profile]
575.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Sandbox Breakout is a technique within the broader MITRE ATT&CK framework, aligning with the tactic of Defense Evasion. It operates by detecting the presence of a virtual machine or sandbox environment through checks for specific artifacts, such as security monitoring tools, system properties, or the absence of legitimate user activity. Upon detection, the malware alters its behavior to evade analysis, which can include disengaging, concealing core functions, or using sleep timers to outlast temporary sandboxes. This technique is often employed by threat groups like Contagious Interview, Saint Bear, and DarkHotel.

599.name: SQL injection
599.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse SQL stored procedures to establish persistent access to systems. SQL Stored Procedures are code that can be saved and reused so that database users do not waste time rewriting frequently used SQL queries. Stored procedures can be invoked via SQL statements to the database using the procedure name or via defined events (e.g. when a SQL server application is started/restarted).

Adversaries may craft malicious stored procedures that can provide a persistence mechanism in SQL database servers.(Citation: NetSPI Startup Stored Procedures)(Citation: Kaspersky MSSQL Aug 2019) To execute operating system commands through SQL syntax the adversary may have to enable additional functionality, such as xp_cmdshell for MSSQL Server.(Citation: NetSPI Startup Stored Procedures)(Citation: Kaspersky MSSQL Aug 2019)(Citation: Microsoft xp_cmdshell 2017) 

Microsoft SQL Server can enable common language runtime (CLR) integration. With CLR integration enabled, application developers can write stored procedures using any .NET framework language (e.g. VB .NET, C#, etc.).(Citation: Microsoft CLR Integration 2017) Adversaries may craft or modify CLR assemblies that are linked to stored procedures since these CLR assemblies can be made to execute arbitrary commands.(Citation: NetSPI SQL Server CLR)
599.profile: [profile]SQL Stored Procedures, identified as T1505.001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a persistence technique under the Server Software Component tactic, primarily targeting Windows platforms. Adversaries craft malicious stored procedures that can be automatically invoked on database events like server restart. To execute operating system commands, they may enable extended functionalities such as `xp_cmdshell` in MSSQL or create/modify CLR assemblies linked to procedures, allowing arbitrary command execution within the database server context. The intrusion set Fancy Bear has been associated with this activity.[/profile]
599.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SQL injection, known as T1190 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is an Initial Access technique targeting web applications. It exploits security flaws where user input is not properly sanitized, allowing adversaries to insert malicious SQL statements into query fields. This can lead to unauthorized data access, manipulation, or deletion from backend databases, and may enable command execution on the underlying server.

600.name: Influence Operations
600.profile: [profile]Influence Operations is not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique but a strategic concept. It is associated with groups like Russian APT Group and Fancy Bear. These operations involve manipulating information, such as through data manipulation (T1565) or creating fake social media accounts (T1585.001), to affect public perception, organizational understanding, or decision-making processes. The goal is to achieve strategic objectives by compromising the integrity of information or exploiting social platforms.[/profile]
600.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Influence Operations is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, specifically identified as T1584. It falls under the Resource Development tactic and is applicable to PRE platforms. This technique involves adversaries compromising or establishing assets, such as social media accounts, to build personas for use in subsequent operations like social engineering or spearphishing. These personas are cultivated across platforms to create credible connections to targets, as seen in campaigns by groups like Star Blizzard and Kimsuky.

607.name: BlackEnergybot
607.profile: [profile]BlackEnergybot, also known as Ratjadidebot, is attributed to the Fancy Bear intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include using a specific C2 infrastructure at hxxps://darkforceteam.000webhostapp.com/SmartAccounts_Bot/bots/Ratjadidebot/index.php. It operates as a bot within a broader framework for malicious activities.
607.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BlackEnergybot is a malware entity with no specific aliases, attributed groups, or target platforms explicitly provided in the input. Key technical behaviors include its association with a command-and-control infrastructure at hxxps://darkforceteam.000webhostapp.com/SmartAccounts_Bot/bots/Ratjadidebot/index.php. This infrastructure is also referenced by other malware entities like telerat and irrat, indicating a shared or related C2 server for bot operations.

608.name: Acunetix
608.profile: [profile]Acunetix is a web vulnerability scanner used for legitimate security testing, but it has been leveraged by threat actors such as Fancy Bear (Unit 29155) for malicious reconnaissance. Specifically, it is used to identify open ports, services, and vulnerabilities in target networks as part of the active scanning technique T1595.002. Its primary target is web-based platforms and their underlying infrastructure.
608.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Acunetix is a web vulnerability scanner, not malware, but it has been leveraged by threat actors such as Unit 29155 for reconnaissance to identify open ports, services, and vulnerabilities on target networks, aligning with the T1595.002 technique.

609.name: SQLMAP
609.profile: [profile]SQLMAP is an open-source penetration testing tool, not malware, used for automated SQL injection detection, exploitation, and database takeover, capable of database fingerprinting and data fetching. It is utilized by groups such as Fancy Bear, Rocket Kitten, and Magic Hound, often alongside tools like Havij for SQL injection and Acunetix or Netsparker for web vulnerability scanning in malicious campaigns.
609.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SQLMAP is an open-source penetration testing tool, not malware, designed for automated detection and exploitation of SQL injection vulnerabilities. It performs database fingerprinting, data extraction, and can take over database servers. It is often referenced alongside other security tools like Havij, Acunetix, and Netsparker in contexts of vulnerability assessments and exploitation activities.

611.name: Russian APT Group
611.uncertain_mes: On May 6 and May 11, 2015, Unit 42 observed two targeted attacks, the first against the U.S. government and the second on a European media company. Threat actors delivered the same document via spear-phishing emails to both organizations.
611.profile: [profile]The entity is primarily known as APT28, also commonly referred to as Fancy Bear. It is attributed to the Russian military intelligence agency GRU. Its known arsenal includes the ShellClient malware. Its operations are characterized by spear-phishing campaigns, as observed in attacks against a U.S. government organization and a European media company in 2015. The group's primary motivation is cyberespionage.
611.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian APT group known as Fancy Bear (also known as APT28, APT49, BlueHornet, and AgainstTheWest). It is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency and is known for sophisticated cyberespionage operations. The group's activities include Influence Operations, where it builds compromised social media personas for social engineering. While distinct from groups like Turla or Vicious Panda, it shares the Russian state-sponsored context and targets sectors of geopolitical interest to the Russian government, primarily motivated by espionage and strategic influence.
611.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]This entity is most likely the Russian APT group known as Turla, also known as Snake and Uroburos. It is associated with the custom malware ShellClient. The group's activities are attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically linked to the Federal Security Service (FSB). Its primary targets are government, diplomatic, and research organizations globally, with a focus on espionage and intelligence gathering. Its operations show overlaps with other Russian-speaking threat clusters.
611.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian APT group Turla, also known as Snake and Uroburos. It is a sophisticated cyberespionage group attributed to Russian state interests, specifically linked to the FSB. Its key malware includes the Snake rootkit, the Kazuar backdoor, and the unique Penquin_x64 and Carbon backdoors. The group's TTPs are characterized by the use of compromised satellite internet connections as operational infrastructure and the deployment of watering hole attacks. It primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors across Europe and Central Asia, with motivations centered on long-term intelligence gathering and strategic espionage. The group shows overlaps with the actor known as Venomous Bear and is believed to be connected to the Kaspersky Lab hack.
611.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The entity is most likely the Russian APT group Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes ShellClient. The group employs Influence Operations to build credible personas for social engineering. It is attributed to Russian intelligence services, specifically linked to the FSB. Its operations are believed to target government, diplomatic, and defense sectors globally, primarily for cyberespionage. The group shows overlaps with clusters like Vicious Panda and is distinct from APT28 (Fancy Bear).
611.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian state-sponsored group known as APT28 (Fancy Bear), also commonly tracked as BlueHornet. It is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. Its activity is characterized by the use of Influence Operations (T1584) to build personas for social engineering. The group's targets and motivations are consistent with strategic cyberespionage and influence campaigns aligned with Russian state interests.
611.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian APT group known as Turla, also known as Malkamak and Vicious Panda (which is also aliased as SixLittleMonkeys). Its key malware includes ShellClient. The group's primary TTP involves Influence Operations, compromising assets to build credible personas for social engineering. It is attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically linked to the GRU, and is believed to target sectors and regions of geopolitical interest to Russia, with a core motivation of cyberespionage and information operations.
611.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]The entity is likely the Russian state-sponsored APT group Turla, also known as Uroburos, Venomous Bear, and Waterbug. Its key malware includes the ShellClient backdoor. The group's primary TTPs involve influence operations to establish credible personas for social engineering. It is attributed to Russian intelligence services, specifically linked to the FSB, and primarily targets government, diplomatic, and defense sectors in Europe and Central Asia for strategic cyberespionage.
611.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]The entity is most likely the Russian APT group Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the sophisticated Snake rootkit and the ShellClient backdoor. The group's TTPs encompass Influence Operations to build credible personas for social engineering. It is attributed to Russian intelligence, specifically the FSB, and primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors in Europe and Central Asia for strategic cyberespionage. The group shows overlaps with clusters like Vicious Panda and SixLittleMonkeys, and its tooling is distinct from groups like APT28 (Fancy Bear).
611.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]The entity is most likely the Russian APT group known as Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the ShellClient backdoor. Its operations are attributed to Russia and are believed to be linked to the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB). The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors in Europe and Central Asia for cyberespionage. It employs sophisticated custom malware and shows overlaps with other Russian-speaking threat clusters.
611.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Russian APT group Turla, also known as Uroburos, Waterbug, and Venomous Bear. Its key malware includes the sophisticated backdoor ShellClient, and it is known for conducting Influence Operations to build credible online personas for social engineering. The group is strongly attributed to Russian intelligence services, specifically the FSB, and primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors in Europe and Central Asia for strategic cyberespionage.
611.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian APT group known as Fancy Bear (also widely aliased as APT28 and BlueHornet). It is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. The group's operations are characterized by Influence Operations, using compromised assets to build credible online personas for social engineering. While distinct, its activities and Russian state affiliation show overlaps with other clusters like Turla. Its primary motivation is cyberespionage, targeting sectors and regions of geopolitical interest to the Russian state.
611.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Russian state-sponsored APT group known as Fancy Bear (also known as APT28, APT49, BlueHornet, and AgainstTheWest). It is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence agency. Its key techniques include Influence Operations, compromising assets to build personas for social engineering. The group's activities are believed to be aligned with Russian state interests, potentially targeting entities opposing these interests, as suggested by its connection to the AK Party identity.

612.name: WinnTI
612.uncertain_mes: [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) is a threat group that researchers have assessed as Chinese state-sponsored espionage group that also conducts financially-motivated operations. Active since at least 2012, [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has been observed targeting various industries, including but not limited to healthcare, telecom, technology, finance, education, retail and video game industries in 14 countries.(Citation: apt41_mandiant) Notable behaviors include using a wide range of malware and tools to complete mission objectives. [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) overlaps at least partially with public reporting on groups including BARIUM and [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044).(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Group IB APT 41 June 2021)
612.profile: [profile]APT41, also known as WinnTI, Winnti Group, BARIUM, Lead, and numerous other aliases including TA415 and Brass Typhoon, is a Chinese state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2012. Its arsenal includes the Winnti backdoor and tools like Fscan, WebScan, and Kerbrute. The group employs a wide range of malware and tools for its objectives, conducting both espionage and financially-motivated operations. It is believed to show overlaps with groups like BARIUM and Lead. APT41 targets a broad array of sectors globally, including healthcare, telecommunications, technology, finance, and the video game industry across at least 14 countries.
612.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set 'WinnTI' is most likely a reference to the Chinese state-sponsored APT group APT41, also known as Barium, Lead, Double Dragon, and Wicked Panda. Its key malware and tools include the signature Winnti backdoor, Cobalt Strike, Fscan, and Kerbrute. Key TTPs involve credential harvesting and lateral movement. The group is attributed to China's Ministry of State Security and exhibits dual espionage and financial motivations, targeting a global array of sectors including technology, telecommunications, government, and the video game industry.
612.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]WinnTI is a cyber espionage intrusion set, also known as Winnti, which is a primary alias used by multiple distinct threat groups. It is strongly associated with the deployment of the custom Winnti backdoor, a modular malware family for Windows and Linux systems, and its operators frequently utilize tools like Fscan, WebScan, Kerbrute, and LsassUnhooker for network reconnaissance and credential access. The group shows significant overlaps with clusters tracked separately as APT41 (also known as Barium, Double Dragon) and Earth Lusca, suggesting a complex, shared tooling ecosystem. It is attributed to China-based actors and primarily targets a wide range of sectors globally for intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering.
612.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set WinnTI is most likely a reference to the broader Winnti umbrella group, also known as APT41, Barium, Double Dragon, and Wicked Panda. Its key malware includes the Winnti backdoor and tools like Fscan, WebScan, and Kerbrute. Its TTPs involve deploying Linux and Windows backdoors for persistent access. The group is attributed to China and believed to be state-sponsored, primarily targeting sectors such as technology, telecommunications, and government entities globally, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and intellectual property theft. It shows overlaps with other clusters like Earth Lusca and Gallium.

Its key malware and tools include the signature Winnti backdoor, Cobalt Strike, Fscan, and Kerbrute. Key TTPs involve credential harvesting and lateral movement, often facilitated by supply chain compromises. The group is attributed to China's Ministry of State Security and exhibits dual espionage and financial motivations, historically targeting a global array of sectors including technology, telecommunications, government, and notably, the online video game industry.

614.uncertain_mes: [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) is a threat group that researchers have assessed as Chinese state-sponsored espionage group that also conducts financially-motivated operations. Active since at least 2012, [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has been observed targeting various industries, including but not limited to healthcare, telecom, technology, finance, education, retail and video game industries in 14 countries.(Citation: apt41_mandiant) Notable behaviors include using a wide range of malware and tools to complete mission objectives. [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) overlaps at least partially with public reporting on groups including BARIUM and [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044).(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Group IB APT 41 June 2021)
614.profile: [profile]APT41, also known as BARIUM, Winnti Group, Wicked Panda, and Double Dragon, is a Chinese state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2012. It uniquely conducts both espionage and financially-motivated operations, utilizing a wide malware arsenal including tools associated with the Winnti cluster. The group targets a broad range of sectors globally, including healthcare, telecommunications, technology, finance, and the video game industry across at least 14 countries.
614.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'Lead' is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored APT group widely tracked as APT41, also known as Barium, Winnti, Double Dragon, Wicked Panda, and WinnTI. Its key malware includes the signature Winnti backdoor and tools like Fscan, Kerbrute, and LsassUnhooker, often leveraging Cobalt Strike. Its key TTPs involve credential harvesting and lateral movement. The group is attributed to China's Ministry of State Security and is notable for its dual espionage and financial motivation, primarily targeting global sectors including technology, telecommunications, and the video game industry for intellectual property theft. It shows significant overlaps with clusters tracked separately as Earth Lusca and Gallium.

Active since at least 2012, [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has been observed targeting various industries, including but not limited to healthcare, telecom, technology, finance, education, retail and video game industries in 14 countries.(Citation: apt41_mandiant) Notable behaviors include using a wide range of malware and tools to complete mission objectives. 615.profile: [profile]Barium, also known as APT41, Winnti, and TA415, among other aliases like Double Dragon and Wicked Panda, is a Chinese state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2012. It is notable for operating with dual motivations, conducting both espionage and financially driven cyber operations. The group employs a wide range of custom malware and tools, though specific names are not detailed here. Its victimology is broad, targeting sectors including healthcare, telecommunications, technology, finance, and the video game industry across at least 14 countries. Barium shows significant overlaps with other reported clusters such as the Winnti Group.

Its key TTPs involve credential harvesting and lateral movement. The group is attributed to China's Ministry of State Security and is notable for its dual espionage and financial motivation, primarily targeting global sectors including technology, telecommunications, and the video game industry for intellectual property theft. It shows significant overlaps with clusters tracked separately as Earth Lusca and Gallium.
