618.name: Cobalt Strike
618.uncertain_mes:
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as â€œadversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actorsâ€. Cobalt Strikeâ€™s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
618.profile: [profile]Cobalt Strike is a commercial remote access tool and adversary simulation software used for post-exploitation activities, leveraging capabilities from tools like Metasploit and Mimikatz. It is associated with numerous threat groups including APT29, APT32, APT41, FIN6, FIN7, Wizard Spider, Mustang Panda, CopyKittens, DarkHydrus, Leviathan, Aquatic Panda, and others. Its key TTPs cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics within an integrated system, often using C2 servers like asureupdate.tech, akamaclouds.app, and cloudmetric.online. It targets various platforms and is linked to malware families like SUNSPOT and campaigns such as REvil, Conti, and Maze.[/profile]
618.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Cobalt Strike is a penetration testing tool and malware framework, also known as cobalt. It is associated with numerous threat groups including APT29, APT32, APT41, FIN6, FIN7, Mustang Panda, Wizard Spider, and Pinchy Spider. Its key technical behaviors involve serving as a command and control (C2) framework for post-exploitation activities, with infrastructure domains such as asureupdate.tech, akamaclouds.app, and cloudmetric.online. It targets Windows platforms and is linked to campaigns involving malware like SUNSPOT, REvil, Conti, and Maze.

619.name: Beef
619.profile: [profile]Beef is a malware entity associated with the intrusion set WinnTI. It is referenced in the context of the Sinowal malware, where a loader module writes the double-word 0xBEEFBEEF into a specific 'beef file', with additional data written by a manager module. The malware is also discussed in an Egyptian infection context involving the exfiltration of invoices and emails related to beef shipment logistics.[/profile]
619.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware 'Beef' is referenced in the context of the 'sinowal' malware family, where a loader module writes the double-word hex value 0xBEEFBEEF into a file referred to as the 'beef file'. This file has a specific structure and is further populated by a manager module. No attributed groups, specific TTPs, target platforms, or infrastructure details are provided in the available data.

624.name: credentials harvesting
624.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather credentials that can be used during targeting. Account credentials gathered by adversaries may be those directly associated with the target victim organization or attempt to take advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Adversaries may gather credentials from potential victims in various ways, such as direct elicitation via [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then add malicious content designed to collect website authentication cookies from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) (Citation: Register Deloitte)(Citation: Register Uber)(Citation: Detectify Slack Tokens)(Citation: Forbes GitHub Creds)(Citation: GitHub truffleHog)(Citation: GitHub Gitrob)(Citation: CNET Leaks) Where multi-factor authentication (MFA) based on out-of-band communications is in use, adversaries may compromise a service provider to gain access to MFA codes and one-time passwords (OTP).(Citation: Okta Scatter Swine 2022)

Credential information may also be exposed to adversaries via leaks to online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Search Engines](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/002), breach dumps, code repositories, etc.). Adversaries may purchase credentials from dark web markets, such as Russian Market and 2easy, or through access to Telegram channels that distribute logs from infostealer malware.(Citation: Bleeping Computer 2easy 2021)(Citation: SecureWorks Infostealers 2023)(Citation: Bleeping Computer Stealer Logs 2023)

Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133) or [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078)).
624.profile: [profile]Credentials, identified as T1589.001 within the Reconnaissance tactic, involves adversaries gathering account credentials for use in later attacks. This is achieved through methods like phishing, compromising websites to steal authentication cookies, purchasing credentials from dark web markets like Russian Market and 2easy, or exploiting data leaks from sources such as code repositories and breach dumps. The technique is associated with groups including APT28, Chimera, and Lapsus$.
624.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credentials Harvesting is a technique where adversaries gather authentication data for use in attacks. It maps to the Credential Access tactic and targets multiple platforms. Adversaries collect credentials through methods like phishing, compromising websites to steal cookies, purchasing from dark web markets, or extracting them from insecure storage locations such as plaintext files, the Windows Registry, web browser databases, and password manager memory. This enables follow-on actions like initial access or lateral movement.

625.name: lateral movement
625.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may transfer tools or other files between systems in a compromised environment. Once brought into the victim environment (i.e., [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) files may then be copied from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation.

Adversaries may copy files between internal victim systems to support lateral movement using inherent file sharing protocols such as file sharing over [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002) to connected network shares or with authenticated connections via [Remote Desktop Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/001).(Citation: Unit42 LockerGoga 2019)

Files can also be transferred using native or otherwise present tools on the victim system, such as scp, rsync, curl, sftp, and [ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095). In some cases, adversaries may be able to leverage [Web Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102)s such as Dropbox or OneDrive to copy files from one machine to another via shared, automatically synced folders.(Citation: Dropbox Malware Sync)
625.profile: [profile]Lateral Tool Transfer, identified as T1570 under the Lateral Movement tactic, operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves copying adversary tools or files between compromised internal systems to stage operations. Specific mechanics include using inherent file sharing protocols like SMB/Windows Admin Shares and authenticated Remote Desktop Protocol connections, as well as native system tools such as scp, rsync, curl, sftp, and ftp. Adversaries may also leverage synchronized web services like Dropbox or OneDrive for file transfers. It is associated with numerous threat groups including APT41, Turla, Volt Typhoon, and Sandworm Team.
625.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "lateral movement" is a high-level tactic within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, not a specific technique with a T-ID. It describes the adversary objective of moving through a network after initial access, using various techniques to access and control remote systems. The retrieved information highlights specific techniques that facilitate this tactic, such as Lateral Tool Transfer (T1570) for moving files between systems, abusing Local Accounts (T1078.003) for credential-based movement, and using removable media for command and control in disconnected environments (T1092). This tactic is platform-agnostic and is employed by numerous threat groups including APT41, Wizard Spider, and Volt Typhoon.

626.name: Winnti
626.uncertain_mes: [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) is a threat group that researchers have assessed as Chinese state-sponsored espionage group that also conducts financially-motivated operations. Active since at least 2012, [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has been observed targeting various industries, including but not limited to healthcare, telecom, technology, finance, education, retail and video game industries in 14 countries.(Citation: apt41_mandiant) Notable behaviors include using a wide range of malware and tools to complete mission objectives. [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) overlaps at least partially with public reporting on groups including BARIUM and [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044).(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Group IB APT 41 June 2021)
626.profile: [profile]Winnti, also known as APT41, BARIUM, and Wicked Panda, is a prolific Chinese state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2012, engaged in both espionage and financially motivated operations. Its arsenal includes the Winnti backdoor, Fscan, WebScan, and Kerbrute. The group employs a wide range of malware and tools to target a diverse set of sectors including healthcare, telecom, technology, finance, education, retail, and the video game industry across at least 14 countries. It shows overlaps with other reported clusters such as BARIUM and TG-2633.
626.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored APT group known as APT41 (also known as Wicked Panda, Barium, or Double Dragon), which operates the Winnti malware family. This group uses a suite of custom tools including the Winnti backdoor (with components like Spyder Loader, PRIVATELOG, and WINNKIT), the ListFileManager plugin, and credential harvesting tools like Netpass. Key TTPs include credential dumping, spear phishing for initial access, and extensive use of remote command execution and lateral movement via utilities like Net Use. The group is attributed to China and shows overlaps with clusters like Earth Lusca and Gallium. Its primary targets have historically included the gaming industry and software supply chains, with motivations encompassing both cyber-espionage and financially driven operations.
626.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored APT group known as Winnti, also commonly referenced as APT41, Barium, Double Dragon, and Wicked Panda. Its key malware includes the Winnti backdoor for both Windows and Linux systems, alongside tools like Fscan, WebScan, and Kerbrute. The group's TTPs involve leveraging these backdoors for initial access and credential theft. It is attributed to China and primarily targets a wide range of sectors globally, including technology, telecommunications, and video gaming, for both cyber espionage and financially motivated operations.
626.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most commonly known as Winnti, also referred to as APT41, Wicked Panda, Barium, and G0044. It employs a diverse arsenal of custom malware, including the Winnti backdoor for Windows and Linux systems, alongside tools like Fscan, WebScan, Kerbrute, and LsassUnhooker. The group's TTPs are sophisticated and adaptable, supporting both cyber-espionage and financially motivated operations. It is attributed to China, showing overlaps with groups like Earth Lusca and Gallium. Its targets are global and cross-sector, focusing on technology, telecommunications, and gaming industries. Its primary motivations are intellectual property theft and data exfiltration for strategic advantage, with supplementary activities involving cybercrime for profit.
626.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Winnti Group, also known as APT41, Barium, Wicked Panda, and Double Dragon. Its key malware includes the eponymous Winnti malware family (with components like Spyder Loader, WINNKIT, and DEPLOYLOG) and tools like the ListFileManager plugin. Characteristic TTPs involve establishing persistence in the Windows System32\\spool\\prtprocs directory, using stolen code-signing certificates, and employing credential harvesting tools like Netpass. The group is believed to be a Chinese state-sponsored actor, attributed to the Ministry of State Security. It primarily targets the gaming sector and other industries for cyber espionage and intellectual property theft, with additional financially motivated operations showing overlaps with other clusters like Earth Lusca.[/profile]
626.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set Winnti, also known as APT41, Wicked Panda, and Barium, is a sophisticated Chinese state-sponsored group. Its key custom malware includes the Winnti backdoor family, with components like Spyder Loader, WINNKIT, and the ListFileManager plugin. The group employs credential theft tools like Trojan-PSW.Win32.Certif.A and hacktools such as Netpass for lateral movement, alongside TTPs like spear phishing, remote command execution, and credential dumping. Believed to operate from China, Winnti primarily targets the gaming industry, technology firms, and telecommunications sectors globally, engaging in cyber espionage and financially motivated intrusions, distinguishing it through its dual espionage-and-crime operational model.[/profile]
626.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]Winnti, also known as APT41, Wicked Panda, and Barium, is a sophisticated Chinese state-sponsored threat group. Its key malware includes the eponymous Winnti malware family (with components like Spyder Loader and WINNKIT) and tools such as the ListFileManager plugin. Common TTPs involve credential dumping, remote command execution, and the use of stolen code-signing certificates for persistence. The group is believed to be based in China and has historically targeted the gaming industry, particularly certificate authorities and gaming companies, for intellectual property theft and cyber espionage, while also engaging in financially motivated operations.[/profile]
626.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored APT group known as APT41 (also known as Wicked Panda, Barium, and Winnti). Its key custom malware includes the Winnti backdoor family, with components like Spyder Loader, WINNKIT, and the ListFileManager plugin. Key TTPs involve credential dumping, reconnaissance, and lateral movement using tools like Netpass and commands like net use. The group is attributed to China and shows overlaps with clusters like Earth Lusca and Gallium. It primarily targets the gaming industry and other sectors for cyber espionage and financial gain, using stolen code-signing certificates for malware deployment.
626.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Winnti Group, also known as APT41, Wicked Panda, Barium, and Double Dragon. Its key malware includes the Winnti Malware family (with components like Spyder Loader, WINNKIT, and DEPLOYLOG), the ListFileManager plugin, and the credential-stealing Trojan-PSW.Win32.Certif.A. Key TTPs involve using stolen code-signing certificates for malware, establishing persistence in the Windows System32 spool directory, and employing spear phishing for initial access. The group is attributed to China and shows overlaps with clusters like Earth Lusca and Gallium. It primarily targets the gaming industry and technology sectors for cyber espionage and intellectual property theft, with a secondary motivation of financially motivated intrusions.[/profile]
626.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]The Winnti group, also known as APT41, Barium, and Double Dragon, is a prolific Chinese state-sponsored threat actor. Its key malware includes the eponymous Winnti backdoor family, with components like Spyder Loader and WINNKIT, and tools such as credential harvesters. Its TTPs encompass spear phishing for initial access, credential dumping, and the use of legitimate commands like `net user` for discovery. The group is attributed to China and has historically targeted the global gaming industry for intellectual property theft, though its operations have expanded to include espionage and financially motivated cybercrime against a broad range of sectors.
626.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as Winnti, which is also widely recognized as APT41, Barium, and Wicked Panda. Its operations are characterized by the use of custom malware such as the Winnti backdoor and tools like the credential-stealing Trojan-PSW.Win32.Certif.A and the Network Password Recovery Program (Netpass). Key TTPs include extensive reconnaissance, lateral movement via network share connections using commands like Net Use, and credential harvesting for espionage. The group is strongly attributed to China and is believed to be a state-sponsored actor. Its primary targets include the gaming industry and technology sectors, with a consistent motivation of cyber espionage and intellectual property theft, often overlapping with clusters like Earth Lusca and Gallium.[/profile]
626.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored group known as APT41, also referred to as Winnti, Barium, Wicked Panda, and Double Dragon. Its key malware includes the Winnti backdoor for Linux systems, alongside tools like Fscan, WebScan, and Kerbrute for network reconnaissance and credential attacks. The group employs TTPs such as using the `net user` command for account discovery. It is attributed to China and shows overlaps with clusters like Earth Lusca and Gallium. Its operations target a broad range of sectors globally, including technology and telecommunications, driven by motives of cyber espionage and, at times, financial gain.
626.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as Winnti, which is also known by aliases such as Barium, Wicked Panda, and APT41, and shows overlaps with groups like Earth Lusca and Gallium. Its key malware and tools include the Winnti backdoor (with Linux variants like WINNTI.D and WINNTI.E), Fscan, WebScan, Kerbrute, and LsassUnhooker. Key TTPs involve establishing remote access for command and control, often using tools like remote desktop applications post-compromise. The group is believed to be of Chinese origin, primarily targeting sectors such as technology, gaming, and telecommunications across global regions, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and intellectual property theft.[/profile]

629.name: Winnti Malware
629.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
629.profile: [profile]Winnti Malware, also known as nmass malware, is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to the Winnti Group. It is deployed via malicious Royal Road documents, such as a fake COVID-19 report targeting Mongolian authorities, and drops an initial executable (e.g., \os03C2.tmp). Its communication patterns are detectable in network traffic, and it shares similarities with campaigns linked to Operation LagTime or Tonto Team. The malware primarily targets Windows systems and is part of a broader arsenal that includes strains like DEPLOYLOG, Spyder Loader, PRIVATELOG, and WINNKIT.
629.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Winnti Malware, also known as Winnti, is a malware family attributed to the Winnti APT group (also referenced as APT17). It has evolved since at least 2013, with known components including Spyder Loader, PRIVATELOG, WINNKIT, and a newly documented strain called DEPLOYLOG. It establishes persistence via the System32\\spool\\prtprocs\\x64 directory, uses stolen code-signing certificates, and has distinct network communication patterns detectable in traffic. It primarily targets Windows platforms for backdoor access and data exfiltration.

630.name: Malicious Library
630.profile: [profile]Malicious Library, also known as libffmpeg.dylib, is a malicious macOS library attributed to the Lazarus Group and the Winnti intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include masquerading as legitimate software components, such as a video library or an ICO file, to evade detection. The primary target platform is macOS, and it is distributed through malicious installers as part of broader campaigns.]
630.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Library is a macOS malware family also known as libffmpeg.dylib, attributed to the Lazarus Group. It is delivered via malicious installers and ICO files, and it operates on the local network to perform lateral movement.

631.name: Rootkit
631.uncertain_mes: [Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0047) is a rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team as a method of persistence for remote access software. (Citation: TrendMicro Hacking Team UEFI)
631.profile: [profile]The malware is known as the Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit, a rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team. It is attributed to the Winnti intrusion set and functions as a method of persistence for remote access software by targeting the UEFI firmware. It is associated with customized hidden rootkits like Wingtb.sys and Winkbj.sys, and its loader uses XOR decryption to execute the rootkit in the target space.
631.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Rootkit is a general class of malware designed to conceal its presence and other malicious activities on a system. Specific instances include the Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit, developed by Hacking Team for persistence of remote access software, and rootkits associated with the Lazarus Group, such as Fudmodule, which uses XOR decryption and Vmprotect packing. Other examples are the user-mode Gaudox rootkit and the Tollbooth malware's customized hidden rootkits like Wingtb.sys and Winkbj.sys.

632.name: ListFileManager Plugin
632.profile: [profile]ListFileManager Plugin is a malware plugin, also known as Fmg2.o, attributed to the Winnti intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is listing and modifying files on the targeted machine, and it is a module within the Winnti malware framework. The target platform is Windows systems, and it is associated with the APT17 group.
632.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ListFileManager Plugin is a malware plugin, also known as the Winnti "ListFileManager" module or Fmg2.o. It is attributed to APT17 and possibly APT41, as it is referenced in relation to the Winnti and GodRAT malware families. Its key technical behavior is listing and modifying files on a compromised Windows machine.

633.name: ff.exe
633.profile: [profile]The malware entity 'ff.exe' is associated with the Winnti intrusion set. It is referenced in the context of the Cuba ransomware and the Biopass RAT, where it is listed as a file and its SHA256 hash is provided. Key technical behaviors include decompressing files from ZIP archives, creating scheduled tasks for persistence, and killing processes such as Everything.exe and ffmpeg.exe. The target platform is Windows, as indicated by the .exe file and the described behaviors. Infrastructure or supplementary information includes its connection to the Cuba ransomware ecosystem and its use in operations linked to APT41, as seen in the Biopass RAT context.
633.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware entity 'ff.exe' is a component associated with the Cuba ransomware, as indicated by its presence in a Cuba-related file list. It is also referenced in the context of the BIOPASS malware, which is attributed to APT41, and within Cobalt Strike descriptions used by multiple threat groups including APT29, APT32, and APT41. Key technical behaviors involve process manipulation, specifically killing processes like 'Everything.exe' and 'ffmpeg.exe', and establishing persistence via scheduled tasks. The target platform is Windows, as evidenced by the executable file format and the use of Windows-specific commands and task scheduling for persistence.

634.name: Bots
634.uncertain_mes: There are also the â€˜e-shopsâ€™ which include online stores and auction sites like Amazon, Apple store, Steam, E-bay and others.
634.profile: [profile]Bots, also known as Betabot, is a malware family associated with the Winnti intrusion set. It functions as a botnet, with a dashboard used to monitor infected systems, tracking metrics like new weekly infections, online bots, and platform distribution. The malware targets Windows systems and is used to steal data, including cryptocurrency wallet information via a clipper module, categorizing compromised hosts as home, researcher, or corporate bots for data exfiltration.
634.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bots is a generic term for compromised hosts controlled by a botnet, as referenced in the context of malware families like Megumin Trojan, Telerat, and ISFB. It is not attributed to a specific group. Key technical behaviors include being listed in a command-and-control dashboard for monitoring statistics like infected hosts, online status, and stolen cryptocurrency wallet data. Target platforms are typically Windows systems. Infrastructure involves C2 panels hosted on services like 000webhostapp.com for managing the botnet.

635.name: Batch File
635.profile: [profile]Batch File is a script type used as a component in malware operations. It is employed by groups including Winnti, APT41 (Emissary Panda, Leviathan), and Mummy Spider (associated with Emotet). Key technical behaviors include being dropped by malicious macros, often with highly obfuscated content, and executing commands to delete the original malware file and the batch script itself to cover tracks. Its target platform is Windows, as it is executed via cmd.exe. Supplementary infrastructure or tooling includes its use alongside specific malware like Ghostsocks and ZxShell.
635.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware entity 'Batch File' is a generic file type often used as a component or delivery mechanism by other malware families. It is referenced in operations involving Emotet, where a highly obfuscated batch file is dropped during VBA macro execution, and in ZXShell, where a batch file is executed to delete the original payload and itself. It is also associated with the tool GhostSocks. Its use is attributed to groups including Gold Cabin, Mummy Spider, Mealybug, APT41, Emissary Panda, and Leviathan. The primary target platform is Windows.

636.name: Trojan-PSW.Win32.Certif.A
636.profile: [profile]Trojan-PSW.Win32.Certif.A is a credential-stealing trojan attributed to the Winnti intrusion set. Its key behavior involves stealing passwords and certificates from compromised Windows systems. The malware is designed to target the Windows platform, operating as part of broader Winnti group campaigns to facilitate further unauthorized access and data theft.
636.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Trojan-PSW.Win32.Certif.A is a credential-stealing Trojan. Its primary function is to target and steal digital certificates and private keys. This malware is associated with the 'gold cabin' group, as indicated by its classification alongside QakBot variants. Its technical behavior is centered on harvesting sensitive authentication materials from compromised Windows systems. The target platform is Windows 32-bit environments. The malware's operational focus is on credential theft for subsequent unauthorized access or financial fraud.[/profile]

637.name: Network Password Recovery Program
637.profile: [profile]The entity is a Network Password Recovery Program, also known as Netpass. It is a legitimate hacktool used by threat actors, including the Winnti intrusion set and the Silent Chollima group, to facilitate lateral movement within compromised networks. Its key behavior is to recover and display stored credential information, such as for network shares, from an infected Windows system. The tool outputs this data, often in a list or JSON format, for subsequent use by attackers.
637.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Network Password Recovery Program, also known as Netpass, is a credential harvesting hacktool. It is used by threat groups like Silent Chollima to recover stored credentials, including those for Remote Desktop, Outlook, Messenger accounts, and network share passwords, from a compromised Windows system. The tool's primary function is to facilitate lateral movement within a victim's internal network by extracting and displaying these credentials. It is often deployed alongside other malware or tools following an initial system compromise.

645.name: Remote Command Line
645.profile: [profile]Remote Command Line is a technique used for command execution on remote systems, often through legitimate remote access tools or services like SSH, RDP, or VNC. It is associated with the intrusion-set Winnti. The technique involves using remote services to establish an interactive command and control channel, enabling adversaries to execute commands, perform lateral movement, and conduct follow-on actions such as file discovery or credential dumping from the compromised remote host.
645.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Remote Command Line, not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique, refers to the execution of commands on a remote system, often through legitimate remote access tools or services. It enables adversaries to perform actions like lateral movement, data discovery, or payload deployment by leveraging protocols such as SSH, RDP, or built-in administration interfaces like network device CLIs or ESXi guest management APIs. This method is foundational for remote control and is frequently associated with techniques like Remote Services (T1021) and Network Device CLI (T1059.008).

646.name: Shutdown Command
646.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may shutdown/reboot systems to interrupt access to, or aid in the destruction of, those systems. Operating systems may contain commands to initiate a shutdown/reboot of a machine or network device. In some cases, these commands may also be used to initiate a shutdown/reboot of a remote computer or network device via [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) (e.g. reload).(Citation: Microsoft Shutdown Oct 2017)(Citation: alert_TA18_106A) They may also include shutdown/reboot of a virtual machine via hypervisor / cloud consoles or command line tools. Shutting down or rebooting systems may disrupt access to computer resources for legitimate users while also impeding incident response/recovery. Adversaries may also use Windows API functions, such as `InitializeSystemShutdownExW` or `ExitWindowsEx`, to force a system to shut down or reboot.(Citation: CrowdStrike Blog)(Citation: Unit42 Agrius 2023) Alternatively, the `NtRaiseHardError`or `ZwRaiseHardError` Windows API functions with the `ResponseOption` parameter set to `OptionShutdownSystem` may deliver a â€œblue screen of deathâ€ (BSOD) to a system.(Citation: SonicWall)(Citation: NtRaiseHardError)(Citation: NotMe-BSOD) In order to leverage these API functions, an adversary may need to acquire `SeShutdownPrivilege` (e.g., via [Access Token Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1134)).(Citation: Unit42 Agrius 2023) In some cases, the system may not be able to boot again. Adversaries may attempt to shutdown/reboot a system after impacting it in other ways, such as [Disk Structure Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/002) or [Inhibit System Recovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1490), to hasten the intended effects on system availability.(Citation: Talos Nyetya June 2017)(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018)
646.profile: [profile]System Shutdown/Reboot (T1529) is an Impact tactic technique affecting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves using OS commands, network device CLIs like 'reload', or hypervisor tools to initiate shutdowns. Adversaries may also call Windows API functions such as `InitializeSystemShutdownExW`, `ExitWindowsEx`, or trigger a BSOD via `NtRaiseHardError` with `OptionShutdownSystem`, often requiring `SeShutdownPrivilege`. This action disrupts access and can compound effects when used after data destruction techniques.[/profile]
646.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Shutdown Command" is a technique adversaries use to interrupt system access or aid in destruction by leveraging built-in OS commands or Windows API functions like `InitializeSystemShutdownExW` or `ExitWindowsEx`. It aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1529 (System Shutdown/Reboot) under the Impact tactic, primarily affecting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Technical execution involves commands such as `shutdown` or `reload` for remote devices, and may require `SeShutdownPrivilege` via token manipulation. It is often employed after data destruction techniques to hasten availability loss and has been used by groups like Lazarus Group and APT37.

647.name: Dir
647.profile: [profile]The entity "Dir" refers to the Windows command-line utility `dir`, which is a specific implementation of the broader MITRE ATT&CK technique File and Directory Discovery (T1083) under the Discovery tactic, primarily on Windows platforms. The command lists files and directories on a system, enabling adversaries to gather information about the file system structure. It is notably used by groups like Winnti and is also referenced in techniques such as Backup Software Discovery (T1518.002) for identifying installed software.
647.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Dir" is a command-line utility used for file and directory discovery, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1083 under the Discovery tactic, primarily on Windows platforms. It functions by listing files and directories, often executed via command shells like cmd.exe to gather system information. The command is also referenced in the context of backup software discovery (T1518.002) to locate specific applications.

648.name: Net View
648.profile: [profile]Net View is a command-line utility within the Net tool used for network discovery. It is referenced in MITRE ATT&CK techniques such as T1135 (Network Share Discovery) and T1018 (Remote System Discovery). The primary command `net view \\\\remotesystem` queries a remote Windows system to enumerate available shared drives, aiding adversaries in identifying targets for lateral movement and information gathering. It is associated with threat groups like Winnti and Wizard Spider.
648.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Net View is a command-line utility within the Net suite (S0039) used for discovery. It maps to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1018 (Remote System Discovery) under the Discovery tactic on Windows platforms. The primary technical mechanic is using the `net view \\\\remotesystem` command to list accessible computers in a network domain or workgroup, aiding adversaries in identifying targets for lateral movement. It is also referenced in technique T1135 (Network Share Discovery) for enumerating shared drives on a remote system with the same command.

649.name: Netstat
649.profile: [profile]The entity "Netstat" is a command-line utility used for system network connections discovery (MITRE ATT&CK Technique T1049, Discovery tactic, Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms). It lists active network connections and listening ports, aiding adversaries in mapping a compromised system's network environment. The tool is commonly employed by groups like APT41 and MuddyWater. In cloud or virtualized environments like ESXi, standard network monitoring tools may not capture all traffic, but netstat remains a fundamental tool for initial network reconnaissance on a host.
649.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Netstat" is a software tool used within the MITRE ATT&CK technique "System Network Connections Discovery" (T1049), under the Discovery tactic. It operates on Windows, Linux, and Mac platforms to list active network connections and open ports on a compromised host. The command is commonly executed in command-line interfaces, and adversaries use it to map a victim's network, including cloud VPCs, by identifying established connections and listening services.

650.name: Net Use
650.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use alternate authentication material, such as password hashes, Kerberos tickets, and application access tokens, in order to move laterally within an environment and bypass normal system access controls. 

Authentication processes generally require a valid identity (e.g., username) along with one or more authentication factors (e.g., password, pin, physical smart card, token generator, etc.). Alternate authentication material is legitimately generated by systems after a user or application successfully authenticates by providing a valid identity and the required authentication factor(s). Alternate authentication material may also be generated during the identity creation process.(Citation: NIST Authentication)(Citation: NIST MFA)

Caching alternate authentication material allows the system to verify an identity has successfully authenticated without asking the user to reenter authentication factor(s). Because the alternate authentication must be maintained by the systemâ€”either in memory or on diskâ€”it may be at risk of being stolen through [Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0006) techniques. By stealing alternate authentication material, adversaries are able to bypass system access controls and authenticate to systems without knowing the plaintext password or any additional authentication factors.
650.profile: [profile]The entity "Net Use" is a command utility used within the broader MITRE ATT&CK technique "Use Alternate Authentication Material" (T1550) under the Lateral Movement tactic, primarily for Windows platforms. It is specifically employed to establish authenticated connections, such as to Windows Admin Shares (T1077), using valid credentials or stolen alternate authentication material like NTLM hashes. The command `net use \\system\share` is a key indicator, and the utility is also used post-compromise for cleanup via `net use /delete`. The Winnti intrusion set has been associated with related behaviors.]
650.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Net Use is a Windows command-line utility technique for establishing or managing network share connections, often associated with SMB/Windows Admin Shares (T1021.002) and Lateral Movement (TA0008) tactics. It operates on Windows platforms, enabling adversaries with valid credentials to map remote drives (e.g., using `net use \\system\share`) for file transfers and remote execution, or to clean traces by deleting connections with `/delete`. The utility is cited in techniques like Network Share Connection Removal (T1070.005/T1126).

651.name: Net User
651.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may rely upon specific actions by a user in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to execute malicious code by, for example, opening a malicious document file or link. These user actions will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from forms of [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566).

While [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) frequently occurs shortly after Initial Access it may occur at other phases of an intrusion, such as when an adversary places a file in a shared directory or on a user's desktop hoping that a user will click on it. This activity may also be seen shortly after [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534).

Adversaries may also deceive users into performing actions such as:

* Enabling [Remote Access Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1219), allowing direct control of the system to the adversary
* Running malicious JavaScript in their browser, allowing adversaries to [Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)s(Citation: Talos Roblox Scam 2023)(Citation: Krebs Discord Bookmarks 2023)
* Downloading and executing malware for [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)
* Coerceing users to copy, paste, and execute malicious code manually(Citation: Reliaquest-execution)(Citation: proofpoint-selfpwn)

For example, tech support scams can be facilitated through [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566), vishing, or various forms of user interaction. Adversaries can use a combination of these methods, such as spoofing and promoting toll-free numbers or call centers that are used to direct victims to malicious websites, to deliver and execute payloads containing malware or [Remote Access Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1219).(Citation: Telephone Attack Delivery)
651.profile: [profile]The entity "Net User" is a command-line utility used for system and domain account discovery, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1087 (Account Discovery). It falls under the Discovery tactic and operates on Windows platforms. The `net user` and `net localgroup` commands enumerate local system accounts, while `net user /domain` and `net group /domain` enumerate domain accounts, aiding adversaries in identifying users and groups for follow-on targeting and privilege escalation. This utility is commonly used by groups like Scattered Spider, LAPSUS$, and Volt Typhoon.
651.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Net User" is a command-line utility used for local and domain account discovery, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1087 (Account Discovery). It falls under the Discovery tactic and operates on Windows platforms. The `net user` command enumerates local accounts, while `net user /domain` enumerates domain accounts, providing adversaries with user listings to aid in targeting and privilege escalation. This utility is commonly used by groups like APT1, Volt Typhoon, and MuddyWater.

652.name: Reconnaissance
652.profile: [profile]Reconnaissance is a tactic in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, not a specific technique, representing the initial phase where adversaries gather information to plan operations. It involves activities like active scanning, where adversaries probe victim infrastructure via network traffic such as ICMP to identify vulnerabilities, and gathering employee names from sources like social media to craft targeted lures. This tactic supports subsequent stages like establishing operational resources and initial access.
652.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Reconnaissance is a foundational tactic in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, preceding initial access. It involves gathering information about a target to plan subsequent attacks. This includes active techniques like scanning victim infrastructure with network probes (e.g., using ICMP) to identify vulnerabilities, as well as passive methods like collecting employee names from social media or public websites to craft believable lures for phishing. Information gathered enables follow-on actions such as capability development or exploitation.

653.name: Cyber Espionage
653.profile: [profile]Cyber Espionage is a strategic objective rather than a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, often pursued by groups like Winnti. It involves activities such as stealing capabilities (T1588) like malware and exploits from third parties, monitoring threat intelligence reports (T1681) to track their own exposure and adapt operations, and conducting external defacement (T1491.002) to spread propaganda or set the stage for further attacks like drive-by compromises. These combined techniques enable sustained, clandestine information gathering.
653.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Cyber Espionage is a broad attack pattern not formally mapped to a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID or Tactic. It encompasses activities like external defacement (T1491.002) for messaging and propaganda, obtaining capabilities (T1588) by purchasing or stealing malware and exploits, and adversaries conducting reconnaissance via search threat vendor data (T1681) to monitor reports on their own campaigns and adjust their tactics.

667.name: Winnti Group
667.uncertain_mes: [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044) is a threat group with Chinese origins that has been active since at least 2010. The group has heavily targeted the gaming industry, but it has also expanded the scope of its targeting.(Citation: Kaspersky Winnti April 2013)(Citation: Kaspersky Winnti June 2015)(Citation: Novetta Winnti April 2015) Some reporting suggests a number of other groups, including [Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001), [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025), and [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004), are closely linked to [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044).(Citation: 401 TRG Winnti Umbrella May 2018)
667.profile: [profile]The Winnti Group, also known as Blackfly and closely linked to clusters like Axiom, APT17, and Ke3chang, is a Chinese-origin threat group active since at least 2010. Its arsenal includes the Winnti backdoor, stolen certificates for malware signing, and rootkits to modify server functionality. The group heavily targets the gaming industry and has expanded to other sectors, including universities in Hong Kong. Its primary motivation is cyber espionage and intellectual property theft.
667.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The Winnti Group, a China-aligned APT also known as APT41, BARIUM, and Wicked Panda, is a sophisticated intrusion set with a long history. Its key malware includes the Winnti backdoor, the PipeMon backdoor (which persists via print processors), and tools like AceHash. The group employs distinctive TTPs such as supply-chain compromises (e.g., against ASUS LiveUpdate and CCleaner), malicious print processor initialization for persistence, and the use of stolen code-signing certificates. It is attributed to China and primarily targets the video game industry for financial gain through in-game currency manipulation, as well as sectors like technology and academia, including Hong Kong universities. Its operations show overlaps with other groups like Earth Lusca and involve strategic cyber-espionage and financially motivated attacks.
667.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Winnti Group, also known as APT41, BARIUM, Wicked Panda, and LEAD. Its key malware includes the Winnti backdoor and tools like the ff.exe auxiliary program, and it is known for using stolen certificates to sign its malware and deploying rootkits to modify server functionality. The group is attributed to China and believed to be state-sponsored. It primarily targets sectors such as higher education, particularly in regions like Hong Kong, and its operations are motivated by cyber espionage and intellectual property theft, with some activity also linked to financially motivated cybercrime.
667.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The Winnti Group, also known as APT41, BARIUM, LEAD, Wicked Panda, and G0044, is a prolific Chinese state-sponsored threat actor. Its key malware includes the Winnti backdoor, for which the group is named, and it is known for using stolen digital certificates to sign its tools. Its TTPs involve deploying rootkits to modify server functionality and using auxiliary programs like ff.exe. The group is attributed to China and primarily targets sectors such as video game, technology, and telecommunications companies for intellectual property theft and espionage, though it has also conducted financially motivated operations. It shows significant overlaps with clusters tracked as Earth Lusca and other groups, indicating a complex and evolving umbrella of activity.

Characteristic TTPs involve supply-chain compromises (e.g., against ASUS LiveUpdate and CCleaner), the use of stolen code-signing certificates, and techniques like reflective loading and UAC bypass.
