672.name: PipeMon
672.uncertain_mes: [PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) is a multi-stage modular backdoor used by [Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044).(Citation: ESET PipeMon May 2020)
672.profile: [profile]PipeMon, also known as pipemon, is a multi-stage modular backdoor attributed to the Winnti Group. It persists as a Print Processor and was used in campaigns targeting video gaming companies in South Korea and Taiwan that develop MMO games. Its key technical behavior involves modular backdoor functionality for persistent access. The target platforms are Windows systems, as indicated by its persistence mechanism. Infrastructure or supplementary details include its use alongside other tools like HTran in some operations, as noted in related content.
672.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PipeMon, also known as pipemon, is a multi-stage modular backdoor attributed to the Winnti Group. It persists as a Print Processor and has been used in attacks against video gaming companies in South Korea and Taiwan that develop MMO games. Its technical behaviors include modular staging and persistence via print processors, targeting Windows platforms.[/profile]

673.name: ShadowPad
673.uncertain_mes: [ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) is a modular backdoor that was first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017. The malware was originally thought to be exclusively used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096), but has since been observed to be used by various Chinese threat activity groups. (Citation: Recorded Future RedEcho Feb 2021)(Citation: Securelist ShadowPad Aug 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky ShadowPad Aug 2017)
673.profile: [profile]ShadowPad is a modular backdoor first identified in the 2017 NetSarang supply chain compromise. It is used by various Chinese threat groups including APT41, Earth Lusca, RedEcho, Tropic Trooper, Mustang Panda, Bronze Butler, Tonto Team, and Aquatic Panda. Its key technical behavior involves a loader-payload architecture for deploying its modular capabilities. The malware targets Windows platforms and is associated with the Winnti Group.
673.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ShadowPad is a modular backdoor malware with loader and payload components. It is associated with multiple China-aligned APT groups, including APT23, APT41, APT17, Dagger Panda, Earth Lusca, Tonto Team, and Wet Panda. Its technical behavior involves a modular architecture for flexible payload delivery and execution.

674.name: AceHash
674.uncertain_mes: In February 2020, we discovered a new, modular backdoor, which we named PipeMon. Persisting as a Print Processor, it was used by the Winnti Group against several video gaming companies that are based in South Korea and Taiwan and develop MMO (Massively Multiplayer Online) games.
674.profile: [profile]AceHash, also known as PipeMon, is a modular backdoor attributed to the Winnti Group (APT41). It persists as a Print Processor and was used in campaigns against video game companies in South Korea and Taiwan developing MMO games. The malware is associated with infrastructure and tools like lowkey and XMRig, indicating potential cryptocurrency mining or additional payload delivery alongside its backdoor functionality.
674.profile_without_enhance: [profile]AceHash is a malware associated with APT41. It is linked to the Winnti Group's PipeMon backdoor campaign targeting video gaming companies in South Korea and Taiwan. Its infrastructure includes the use of a stolen certificate from Wemade IO. Technical indicators include specific hashes and connections to tools like Lowkey and XMRig, suggesting cryptocurrency mining or credential theft capabilities, primarily targeting Windows systems.[/profile]

675.name: HTRan
675.uncertain_mes:
Open-source toolset of an Ivanti CSA attacker
In recent incident responses where the root cause was an Ivanti CSA compromise, Synacktiv's CSIRT came across multiple open-source tools used by threat actors. This article dives into each of these tools, their functionalities and discusses efficient detection capabilities.
Table of Contents
675.profile: [profile]HTRan, also known as htran, is an open-source toolset used by threat actors such as Gallium and UPS, and is associated with the Winnti Group. It functions as a proxying tool to conceal the true location of command-and-control (C2) servers by forwarding traffic from an intermediate server to the actual C2, often employed in incidents involving Ivanti CSA compromises.
675.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTRan is a proxying tool used to conceal the true location of C2 servers by forwarding traffic from an intermediate server to the actual C2. It is an open-source toolset and has been used by threat actors including groups like Gallium, UPS, and Scarlet Mimic.

676.name: WinEggDrop
676.profile: [profile]WinEggDrop is a backdoor malware family attributed to the Winnti Group. It is known for creating persistence via Windows Registry keys to automatically launch copies of itself on system startup. The malware also monitors specific applications on the infected system, though the exact applications are not detailed in the provided context. The backdoor's primary target platform is the Windows operating system, and it is associated with other malware such as Maggie, which is authored by the same entity.
676.profile_without_enhance: [profile]WinEggDrop is a malware authoring entity, identified as the creator of the 'maggie' backdoor. No specific aliases, attributed groups, or detailed technical behaviors for WinEggDrop itself are provided in the context. The target platform is implied to be Windows-based systems, given the entity's name and its association with a backdoor. No further infrastructure or supplementary information is available from the provided data.

677.name: Netcat
677.profile: [profile]Netcat is a legitimate network utility tool, also known as 'nc', that is frequently repurposed by threat actors for malicious remote control and data exfiltration. It is notably used by the Winnti Group and has been referenced in the toolkits of other groups like APT10, APT32, Anunak, and Gallium. Its key behaviors include establishing bidirectional network connections, port mapping, and tunneling data, making it a versatile tool for post-exploitation activities on compromised systems.[/profile]
677.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Netcat, also known as nc, is a legitimate network utility tool that is often repurposed for malicious remote control and data exchange, as referenced in the context of tools like mimikatz and Ladon. It is used by various groups including APT10, APT32, Anunak, and Gallium. Its key technical behavior involves building network connections for data relay and port mapping, as exemplified by its use in tools like Terminator RAT for creating bidirectional tunnels. It targets general network platforms and its infrastructure use is typically through the deployment of its official binary, nc.exe, for establishing command-and-control channels.

679.name: Supply-Chain Attack
679.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise.

Supply chain compromise can take place at any stage of the supply chain including:

* Manipulation of development tools
* Manipulation of a development environment
* Manipulation of source code repositories (public or private)
* Manipulation of source code in open-source dependencies
* Manipulation of software update/distribution mechanisms
* Compromised/infected system images (removable media infected at the factory)(Citation: IBM Storwize)(Citation: Schneider Electric USB Malware) 
* Replacement of legitimate software with modified versions
* Sales of modified/counterfeit products to legitimate distributors
* Shipment interdiction

While supply chain compromise can impact any component of hardware or software, adversaries looking to gain execution have often focused on malicious additions to legitimate software in software distribution or update channels.(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Adversaries may limit targeting to a desired victim set or distribute malicious software to a broad set of consumers but only follow up with specific victims.(Citation: Symantec Elderwood Sept 2012)(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Popular open-source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications may also be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency.(Citation: Trendmicro NPM Compromise)

In some cases, adversaries may conduct â€œsecond-orderâ€ supply chain compromises by leveraging the access gained from an initial supply chain compromise to further compromise a software component.(Citation: Krebs 3cx overview 2023) This may allow the threat actor to spread to even more victims.
679.profile: [profile]Supply-Chain Attack is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1195 under the Initial Access tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves manipulating products or delivery mechanisms before consumer receipt to compromise data or systems. Specific mechanics include malicious additions to software updates, manipulation of open-source dependencies or development tools, and compromising system images or hardware. Adversaries may conduct broad distribution with selective follow-up or execute second-order compromises to extend access. Associated groups include Sandworm Team and Winnti Group.[/profile]
679.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Supply-Chain Attack is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, identified as T1195 under the Initial Access tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves compromising products or delivery mechanisms before they reach the end user to achieve system or data compromise. Technical mechanics include manipulating development tools, source code repositories, software update channels, or hardware components to insert malicious code. Adversaries may broadly distribute tainted software but only activate payloads for specific targets, and they can conduct second-order compromises by leveraging initial access to further infiltrate the software supply chain.

680.name: In-Game Currency Manipulation
680.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain and/or elevate access to victim systems. Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves or modifies adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups.(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021) These actions could also include account activity designed to subvert security policies, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass password duration policies and preserve the life of compromised credentials. 

In order to create or manipulate accounts, the adversary must already have sufficient permissions on systems or the domain. However, account manipulation may also lead to privilege escalation where modifications grant access to additional roles, permissions, or higher-privileged [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).
680.profile: [profile]The entity "In-Game Currency Manipulation" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided data, the self-info and retrieved content strongly indicate it is a mislabeled or uncertain reference to the standard technique "Account Manipulation" (T1098). This technique, under the Persistence tactic, involves actions like modifying account credentials or permissions to maintain access, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass security policies. It is used by groups including Lazarus Group and requires the adversary to already have sufficient permissions on the target system or domain.[/profile]
680.profile_without_enhance: [profile]In-Game Currency Manipulation is a technique where adversaries alter the value or flow of virtual currency within online games or platforms to gain financial advantage, launder money, or disrupt in-game economies. This manipulation can involve exploiting game mechanics, vulnerabilities in transaction systems, or using automated bots to artificially inflate or devalue currency. The tactic is primarily associated with financial gain and impacts online gaming platforms.

682.name: UAC Bypass
682.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may modify file attributes and subvert Gatekeeper functionality to evade user prompts and execute untrusted programs. Gatekeeper is a set of technologies that act as layer of Appleâ€™s security model to ensure only trusted applications are executed on a host. Gatekeeper was built on top of File Quarantine in Snow Leopard (10.6, 2009) and has grown to include Code Signing, security policy compliance, Notarization, and more. Gatekeeper also treats applications running for the first time differently than reopened applications.(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany Quarantine and the flag)(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany apple notarization )

Based on an opt-in system, when files are downloaded an extended attribute (xattr) called `com.apple.quarantine` (also known as a quarantine flag) can be set on the file by the application performing the download. Launch Services opens the application in a suspended state. For first run applications with the quarantine flag set, Gatekeeper executes the following functions:

1. Checks extended attribute â€“ Gatekeeper checks for the quarantine flag, then provides an alert prompt to the user to allow or deny execution.(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)

2. Checks System Policies - Gatekeeper checks the system security policy, allowing execution of apps downloaded from either just the App Store or the App Store and identified developers.

3. Code Signing â€“ Gatekeeper checks for a valid code signature from an Apple Developer ID.

4. Notarization - Using the `api.apple-cloudkit.com` API, Gatekeeper reaches out to Apple servers to verify or pull down the notarization ticket and ensure the ticket is not revoked. Users can override notarization, which will result in a prompt of executing an â€œunauthorized appâ€ and the security policy will be modified.

Adversaries can subvert one or multiple security controls within Gatekeeper checks through logic errors (e.g. [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211)), unchecked file types, and external libraries. For example, prior to macOS 13 Ventura, code signing and notarization checks were only conducted on first launch, allowing adversaries to write malicious executables to previously opened applications in order to bypass Gatekeeper security checks.(Citation: theevilbit gatekeeper bypass 2021)(Citation: Application Bundle Manipulation Brandon Dalton)

Applications and files loaded onto the system from a USB flash drive, optical disk, external hard drive, from a drive shared over the local network, or using the curl command may not set the quarantine flag. Additionally, it is possible to avoid setting the quarantine flag using [Drive-by Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189).
682.profile: [profile]UAC Bypass, identified as T1548.002, is a Defense Evasion technique targeting the Windows platform. It involves subverting Windows User Account Control (UAC) mechanisms to elevate process privileges without proper user consent. Methods include exploiting auto-elevation in trusted Windows programs like `eventvwr.exe`, using tools like UACME to load crafted DLLs for COM object elevation, injecting into trusted processes, or leveraging lateral movement with known administrator credentials to bypass the local security check. This technique has been used by groups including APT37, APT38, and MuddyWater.[/profile]
682.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bypass User Account Control, identified as T1548.002, is a defense evasion technique targeting the Windows platform. It involves subverting Windows User Account Control (UAC) mechanisms to elevate process privileges without user consent. Specific methods include exploiting auto-elevation in trusted programs like `eventvwr.exe`, using tools like rundll32 to load crafted DLLs that manipulate auto-elevated COM objects, and leveraging lateral movement with known administrator credentials where UAC is not enforced. The extensive UACME project catalogs numerous discovered bypass methods used by various threat groups.

683.name: Malicious Print Processor Initialization
683.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse print processors to run malicious DLLs during system boot for persistence and/or privilege escalation. Print processors are DLLs that are loaded by the print spooler service, `spoolsv.exe`, during boot.(Citation: Microsoft Intro Print Processors) Adversaries may abuse the print spooler service by adding print processors that load malicious DLLs at startup. A print processor can be installed through the AddPrintProcessor API call with an account that has SeLoadDriverPrivilege enabled. Alternatively, a print processor can be registered to the print spooler service by adding the HKLM\SYSTEM\\[CurrentControlSet or ControlSet001]\Control\Print\Environments\\[Windows architecture: e.g., Windows x64]\Print Processors\\[user defined]\Driver Registry key that points to the DLL. For the malicious print processor to be correctly installed, the payload must be located in the dedicated system print-processor directory, that can be found with the GetPrintProcessorDirectory API call, or referenced via a relative path from this directory.(Citation: Microsoft AddPrintProcessor May 2018) After the print processors are installed, the print spooler service, which starts during boot, must be restarted in order for them to run.(Citation: ESET PipeMon May 2020) The print spooler service runs under SYSTEM level permissions, therefore print processors installed by an adversary may run under elevated privileges.
683.profile: [profile]Malicious Print Processor Initialization is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1547.012 under the Persistence tactic for Windows. It involves abusing the print spooler service by installing a malicious DLL as a print processor to achieve execution during system boot with SYSTEM privileges. Installation is performed via the AddPrintProcessor API call with SeLoadDriverPrivilege or by creating a specific Registry key under HKLM\SYSTEM\Control\Print\Environments. The payload must reside in the system's print-processor directory, and the spooler service must be restarted for the change to take effect.[profile]
683.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Print Processor Initialization is a persistence and privilege escalation technique (T1547.012) under the Privilege Escalation and Persistence tactics, targeting Windows. It involves abusing the print spooler service (`spoolsv.exe`) by installing a malicious DLL as a print processor. This can be done via the `AddPrintProcessor` API call with `SeLoadDriverPrivilege` or by creating a specific Registry key under `HKLM\SYSTEM\...\Print Processors\` pointing to the DLL. The payload must reside in the system's print-processor directory, and the spooler service must be restarted to load the DLL, which then runs with SYSTEM-level permissions on boot. The threat group Earth Lusca has been associated with this method.

684.name: Reflective Loading
684.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may reflectively load code into a process in order to conceal the execution of malicious payloads. Reflective loading involves allocating then executing payloads directly within the memory of the process, vice creating a thread or process backed by a file path on disk (e.g., [Shared Modules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1129)).

Reflectively loaded payloads may be compiled binaries, anonymous files (only present in RAM), or just snubs of fileless executable code (ex: position-independent shellcode).(Citation: Introducing Donut)(Citation: S1 Custom Shellcode Tool)(Citation: Stuart ELF Memory)(Citation: 00sec Droppers)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL) For example, the `Assembly.Load()` method executed by [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) may be abused to load raw code into the running process.(Citation: Microsoft AssemblyLoad)

Reflective code injection is very similar to [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055) except that the â€œinjectionâ€ loads code into the processesâ€™ own memory instead of that of a separate process. Reflective loading may evade process-based detections since the execution of the arbitrary code may be masked within a legitimate or otherwise benign process. Reflectively loading payloads directly into memory may also avoid creating files or other artifacts on disk, while also enabling malware to keep these payloads encrypted (or otherwise obfuscated) until execution.(Citation: Stuart ELF Memory)(Citation: 00sec Droppers)(Citation: Intezer ACBackdoor)(Citation: S1 Old Rat New Tricks)
684.profile: [profile]Reflective Code Loading is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1620 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It works by allocating and executing payloads like compiled binaries or shellcode directly within a process's own memory, bypassing the need for a file on disk, as exemplified by abusing the `Assembly.Load()` method in PowerShell. This technique evades process-based detection by masking code execution within a legitimate process and avoids disk artifacts, often keeping payloads encrypted until runtime. It has been associated with groups including Lazarus Group, Gamaredon Group, FIN7, and Kimsuky.[/profile]
684.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Reflective Loading, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1620 under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows, involves allocating and executing payloads directly within a process's own memory to conceal malicious code execution. This technique avoids creating files on disk by loading compiled binaries, anonymous files, or position-independent shellcode into memory, often using methods like `Assembly.Load()` in PowerShell. It evades process-based detection by masking execution within a legitimate process and allows payloads to remain encrypted until runtime.

686.name: Module Injection
686.profile: [profile]Module Injection is a sub-technique of Process Injection (T1055), falling under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows platforms. It involves executing arbitrary code within a separate live process by writing a malicious module into its memory, often overwriting a legitimate module's entry point to conceal the activity. This allows adversaries to evade detection by masking execution under a trusted process and potentially gain access to its memory and privileges. The Winnti Group has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
686.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Module Injection is a sub-technique of Process Injection (T1055) under the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily for Windows. It involves injecting a malicious module into a legitimate process's address space to execute arbitrary code, often by overwriting a loaded module's AddressOfEntryPoint to conceal the malicious code behind a legitimate DLL file on disk, a method also known as Module Stomping or DLL Hollowing. This allows adversaries to evade detection by masking execution under a trusted process.

688.name: RC4 Encryption
688.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise a network deviceâ€™s encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications. (Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Encryption can be used to protect transmitted network traffic to maintain its confidentiality (protect against unauthorized disclosure) and integrity (protect against unauthorized changes). Encryption ciphers are used to convert a plaintext message to ciphertext and can be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated decryption key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key.

Adversaries can compromise and manipulate devices that perform encryption of network traffic. For example, through behaviors such as [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601), [Reduce Key Space](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/001), and [Disable Crypto Hardware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/002), an adversary can negatively effect and/or eliminate a deviceâ€™s ability to securely encrypt network traffic. This poses a greater risk of unauthorized disclosure and may help facilitate data manipulation, Credential Access, or Collection efforts. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
688.profile: [profile]RC4 Encryption is a symmetric encryption algorithm, referenced as a sub-technique under T1573.001 for Command and Control and T1048.001 for Exfiltration. It is used to conceal C2 or exfiltrated data by manually implementing the algorithm, often creating multiple encryption layers within protocols like HTTP or HTTPS. The technique involves using a shared secret key for both encryption and decryption of the data stream.
688.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RC4 Encryption is a symmetric stream cipher algorithm used by adversaries to conceal data. It is referenced as a specific method within broader MITRE ATT&CK techniques, particularly T1573.001 (Symmetric Cryptography) for encrypting command and control traffic and T1048.001 for exfiltrating data over encrypted non-C2 protocols. The algorithm uses a shared secret key for both encryption and decryption, allowing it to be manually implemented to create custom encrypted channels, potentially layered within other protocols like HTTPS.

689.name: XOR Encryption
689.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise a network deviceâ€™s encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications. (Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Encryption can be used to protect transmitted network traffic to maintain its confidentiality (protect against unauthorized disclosure) and integrity (protect against unauthorized changes). Encryption ciphers are used to convert a plaintext message to ciphertext and can be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated decryption key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key.

Adversaries can compromise and manipulate devices that perform encryption of network traffic. For example, through behaviors such as [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601), [Reduce Key Space](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/001), and [Disable Crypto Hardware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/002), an adversary can negatively effect and/or eliminate a deviceâ€™s ability to securely encrypt network traffic. This poses a greater risk of unauthorized disclosure and may help facilitate data manipulation, Credential Access, or Collection efforts. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
689.profile: [profile]XOR Encryption is a custom cryptographic protocol technique (T1024) used for Command and Control. It operates by applying the exclusive OR (XOR) operation to plaintext with a fixed key, producing a weak ciphertext that is simple to implement without external libraries. This method is often used to obfuscate C2 traffic, though its simplicity makes it vulnerable to analysis and reverse engineering. The technique is associated with groups like the Winnti Group and is also referenced in the context of data archiving prior to exfiltration.
689.profile_without_enhance: [profile]XOR Encryption is a custom cryptographic technique used by adversaries to obfuscate data and command and control traffic. It is a simple symmetric encryption method where plaintext is XORed with a fixed key, producing a weak ciphertext that is often implemented without external libraries. This technique is employed to conceal collected data prior to exfiltration, such as in archiving via custom methods, and to hide C2 communications. Associated groups include Lazarus Group, Mustang Panda, and APT28.

690.name: TLS over TCP
690.profile: [profile]TLS over TCP is a network protocol technique where adversaries use the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol over a standard TCP connection to encrypt command and control (C2) or exfiltration traffic, blending it with legitimate encrypted web traffic. This method provides an additional layer of protection for adversary communications and can help bypass network detection systems by mimicking common, trusted services that use ports like TCP/443. It is associated with groups like Winnti Group and is conceptually related to other encrypted exfiltration methods such as Exfiltration Over Web Service.
690.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TLS over TCP is a network communication technique where adversaries leverage the standard Transport Layer Security protocol over Transmission Control Protocol to encrypt command and control or data exfiltration traffic. This method provides an additional level of protection by securing communications with SSL/TLS encryption, allowing malicious traffic to blend in with legitimate HTTPS web service traffic. It is commonly used to bypass network detection by communicating over commonly used, trusted ports like TCP/443.

691.name: zlib Deflate
691.profile: [profile]zlib Deflate is a method for data compression, often used by adversaries to compress collected data prior to exfiltration, making it more portable and minimizing network traffic. It is associated with the technique Data Compressed (T1002) and is utilized by groups like the Winnti Group. The zlib library provides functionality for this compression, which is distinct from spawning command-line utilities and can be linked directly into malicious programs.
691.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "zlib Deflate" is a data compression technique used by adversaries, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK sub-technique T1002 (Data Compressed) under the Exfiltration tactic. It operates across multiple platforms. The technique involves using the zlib library to compress collected data, such as sensitive documents, prior to exfiltration. This compression makes the data more portable and reduces network traffic volume, aiding in evasion. The zlib library is a common third-party tool that can be linked into malicious programs to perform this compression separately from the exfiltration channel.

692.name: Network Communication
692.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
692.profile: [profile]This is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1102.002, "Bidirectional Communication", under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across common platforms. Adversaries use legitimate external web services like social media or cloud platforms for two-way command and control. Commands are sent to a compromised system via the service, and output is returned through the same channel, often by posting comments, updating documents, or sending tweets. This method blends with normal traffic and benefits from the service's inherent SSL/TLS encryption. Groups like APT28, Lazarus, and FIN7 have used this technique.[/profile]
692.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Network Communication" is a foundational concept in adversary tradecraft, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique with a designated ID. It broadly encompasses the methods adversaries use to establish and maintain command and control (C2) channels, exfiltrate data, and enable lateral movement within a compromised network. This includes leveraging standard protocols, abusing legitimate web services, using non-standard layers like ICMP or VMCI for stealth, and employing fallback channels for resilience. The core objective is to facilitate covert, persistent, and often encrypted communication to bypass network defenses and monitoring.

701.name: APT3
701.uncertain_mes: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) is a China-based threat group that researchers have attributed to China's Ministry of State Security.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: Recorded Future APT3 May 2017) This group is responsible for the campaigns known as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: FireEye Operation Double Tap) As of June 2015, the group appears to have shifted from targeting primarily US victims to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
701.profile: [profile]APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, Boyusec, TG-0110, and UPS, is a China-based threat group attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) and is associated with the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company. Its key campaigns include Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap. The group has historically targeted U.S. entities but shifted focus around 2015 to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong, indicating espionage and intelligence-gathering motivations aligned with state interests.
701.profile_without_enhance: [profile]APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, TG-0110, Red Sylvan, and Boron, is a Chinese state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key malware includes the PlugX (Kaba) remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and the historical exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities like CVE-2014-4113. The group is attributed to China and is strongly believed to be linked to the Ministry of State Security (MSS), with operational ties to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company (Boyusec). It has targeted government, defense, aerospace, high-tech, and transportation sectors, primarily in the U.S., Europe, and Asia, for intellectual property theft and state-sponsored espionage.
701.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, and TG-0110, is a China-nexus cyber espionage group. It has been linked to the use of custom malware and zero-day exploits, such as an Adobe Flash vulnerability used in Operation Clandestine Wolf. The group primarily targets sectors including technology, government, and defense in the United States, Europe, and Asia, with motivations centered on intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence collection for state-sponsored interests.
701.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile] APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, and TG-0110, is a Chinese state-sponsored threat group. Its key malware includes the Pirpi backdoor, utilized in campaigns like Operation Clandestine Wolf which employed Adobe Flash zero-days. The group's TTPs involve spear-phishing and leveraging zero-day exploits. It is attributed to China's Ministry of State Security and primarily targets sectors such as aerospace, defense, and technology across the United States, Europe, and Japan, with motivations centered on espionage and intellectual property theft.
701.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored group APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, TG-0110, Red Sylvan, and Boron. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing and the exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, notably CVE-2014-4113. It is attributed to China and is strongly believed to be linked to the Ministry of State Security (MSS) and operationally tied to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company (Boyusec). The group has historically targeted U.S. and Western entities in strategic sectors such as government, defense, aerospace, technology, and telecommunications for state-sponsored cyber espionage and intellectual property theft.

702.name: zero-day exploit
702.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network. The weakness in the system can be a software bug, a temporary glitch, or a misconfiguration.

Exploited applications are often websites/web servers, but can also include databases (like SQL), standard services (like SMB or SSH), network device administration and management protocols (like SNMP and Smart Install), and any other system with Internet-accessible open sockets.(Citation: NVD CVE-2016-6662)(Citation: CIS Multiple SMB Vulnerabilities)(Citation: US-CERT TA18-106A Network Infrastructure Devices 2018)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)(Citation: NVD CVE-2014-7169) On ESXi infrastructure, adversaries may exploit exposed OpenSLP services; they may alternatively exploit exposed VMware vCenter servers.(Citation: Recorded Future ESXiArgs Ransomware 2023)(Citation: Ars Technica VMWare Code Execution Vulnerability 2021) Depending on the flaw being exploited, this may also involve [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211) or [Exploitation for Client Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203).

If an application is hosted on cloud-based infrastructure and/or is containerized, then exploiting it may lead to compromise of the underlying instance or container. This can allow an adversary a path to access the cloud or container APIs (e.g., via the [Cloud Instance Metadata API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1552/005)), exploit container host access via [Escape to Host](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1611), or take advantage of weak identity and access management policies.

Adversaries may also exploit edge network infrastructure and related appliances, specifically targeting devices that do not support robust host-based defenses.(Citation: Mandiant Fortinet Zero Day)(Citation: Wired Russia Cyberwar)

For websites and databases, the OWASP top 10 and CWE top 25 highlight the most common web-based vulnerabilities.(Citation: OWASP Top 10)(Citation: CWE top 25)
702.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) under the Initial Access tactic, applicable to multiple platforms including Windows, Linux, macOS, and cloud. It involves exploiting software bugs, glitches, or misconfigurations in internet-facing systems like web servers, databases (e.g., SQL), and network services (e.g., SMB, SSH, SNMP) to gain initial network access. Exploitation can extend to cloud instances, containers, and edge devices, potentially enabling further actions like accessing cloud APIs or container host escape. Numerous threat groups, including APT28, APT29, and FIN7, have been associated with this technique.[/profile]
702.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Zero-day exploit is a tactic used for initial access, defense evasion, and privilege escalation, targeting various platforms. It involves exploiting a previously unknown software vulnerability for which no patch or fix is available at the time of use. Adversaries may acquire these exploits through purchase, theft, or development to bypass security controls and execute code. This technique is foundational to other exploitation tactics like Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) and Exploitation for Defense Evasion (T1211).

703.name: phishing emails
703.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
703.profile: [profile]Phishing, identified as T1566, is an Initial Access tactic executed via email, social media, or other electronic services. The technique involves sending messages containing malicious attachments or links to execute code, often using social engineering by posing as a trusted source. Evasive methods include email spoofing, thread hijacking, and manipulating email metadata from compromised accounts. It is distinct from T1598 (Phishing for Information), which focuses on credential harvesting rather than code execution.
703.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Phishing Emails is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, aligning with ID T1566 under the Initial Access tactic and applicable to multiple platforms. It involves sending deceptive emails containing malicious attachments or links to execute code on victim systems. This can be targeted (spearphishing) or broad, often employing social engineering by posing as a trusted source. Evasive methods include email spoofing, manipulating email headers, or hijacking existing email threads to enhance credibility and bypass security filters.

709.name: Flash exploit
709.profile: [profile]Flash exploit is a type of exploit targeting Adobe Flash Player vulnerabilities, including CVE-2014-0497, CVE-2015-8651, CVE-2016-1019, and CVE-2016-4117, which has been used in watering hole attacks. It is associated with groups such as APT3, ScarCruft (APT37), and Lazarus Group, and has been deployed in campaigns like StarCruft and Bankshot for initial access and exploitation.
709.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Flash exploit is a malware entity that leverages vulnerabilities in Adobe Flash Player, including CVE-2014-0497, CVE-2015-8651, CVE-2016-1019, and CVE-2016-4117, to execute malicious code. It has been deployed by APT groups such as ScarCruft (APT37) and Lazarus Group, often in watering hole attacks. Key technical behaviors include the use of Return-Oriented Programming (ROP) to bypass security protections like Data Execution Prevention (DEP) and Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR). The primary target platform is systems running vulnerable versions of Adobe Flash Player, frequently exploited through Flash video files (FLV).

710.name: backdoors
710.uncertain_mes:
Zscaler Blog
Get the latest Zscaler blog updates in your inbox
YiBackdoor: A New Malware Family With Links to IcedID and Latrodectus
Introduction
710.profile: [profile]YiBackdoor is a new malware family with links to IcedID and Latrodectus, also referred to as backdoors. It is attributed to the APT3 intrusion set. The malware exhibits backdoor capabilities and is designed to be stealthy, potentially avoiding listening on ports or pinging back to a Command and Control server, a technique associated with passive backdoors.
710.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malware Name: Backdoors. Aliases: None specified. Attributed Groups: The Gorgon Group (associated with AzorUlt), Red Menshen (associated with BPFDoor). Key TTPs/Technical Behaviors: Implements stealthy passive backdoor capabilities, avoiding listening on open ports or direct C2 pinging to evade detection. Target Platforms: Not specified. Infrastructure/Supplementary Info: Associated with malware families like Daxin, BPFDoor, and AzorUlt, which utilize these backdoor mechanisms.

716.name: Secret Fox
716.uncertain_mes: [Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) is threat actor with a suspected nexus to the Iranian government that has been active since at least 2017 against entities in the Middle East, North Africa, Europe, Australia, and North America. [Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has targeted multiple industrial verticals including oil and gas, technology, government, defense, healthcare, manufacturing, and engineering.(Citation: ClearkSky Fox Kitten February 2020)(Citation: CrowdStrike PIONEER KITTEN August 2020)(Citation: Dragos PARISITE )(Citation: ClearSky Pay2Kitten December 2020)
716.profile: [profile]Secret Fox, also known as Fox Kitten, is an intrusion set attributed to Iran, active since at least 2017. Its arsenal includes tools like ShroudedSnooper (aka Storm-0861, Scarred Manticore). The group's operations target a wide range of sectors globally, including oil and gas, technology, government, defense, healthcare, manufacturing, and engineering across the Middle East, North Africa, Europe, Australia, and North America, indicating a broad espionage and potentially disruptive motivation.
716.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Secret Fox is an intrusion set, also known as ShroudedSnooper, Storm-0861, and Scarred Manticore. It is attributed to the APT3 group and utilizes the custom backdoor malware ShotPut for persistence and remote access. Its key TTPs include spearphishing for initial access, employing one-time command and control infrastructure. The group is believed to be of Chinese origin and primarily targets victim organizations for espionage purposes, showing overlaps with other clusters like Mofang, Superman, and Bronze Walker.
716.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set known as Secret Fox is believed to be a Chinese state-sponsored APT group, also known as Mofang, Superman, and Bronze Walker. It is attributed to using custom malware such as ShroudedSnooper (also tracked as Storm-0861 or Scarred Manticore). The group's operations are primarily targeted against telecommunications and internet service providers in the Middle East, with motivations likely aligned with cyber espionage and intelligence gathering to support Chinese strategic interests.
716.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, likely the group publicly known as APT42 or UNC788, operates under the name Secret Fox and is also known by aliases including Mofang, Superman, and Bronze Walker. It is attributed to Iran and is believed to be a subset or closely linked to the state-sponsored group known as Charming Kitten (APT35). The group's operations are characterized by sophisticated spear-phishing campaigns, often leveraging custom malware and tools for espionage. Its primary motivation is intelligence collection, with a consistent focus on targeting government, academic, and think tank sectors in the Middle East, Europe, and North America.
716.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]Secret Fox is an intrusion set, also known as ShroudedSnooper, Storm-0861, and Scarred Manticore, with suspected overlaps with groups like Mofang, Superman, and Bronze Walker. It employs the custom backdoor malware ShotPut for remote access and persistence via Windows registry keys. Its primary initial access technique is the use of phishing emails, supported by one-time command and control infrastructure. The group is believed to be of Chinese origin, attributed to APT3, and primarily targets victim organizations, though specific sectors and regions are not detailed in the provided data. Its motivation appears to be cyber espionage.

717.name: ShotPut
717.uncertain_mes: [SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) is a custom backdoor used by [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022). (Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)
717.profile: [profile]ShotPut is a custom backdoor attributed to APT3. It is used for persistent access and data exfiltration, with its primary target platform being Windows systems. The malware establishes persistence through registry modifications and communicates with command-and-control servers. It is associated with the intrusion set Secret Fox.[/profile]
717.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ShotPut is a custom backdoor malware attributed to the APT3 group, used for remote access and control. Its key technical behaviors include establishing persistence via Windows registry keys to ensure automatic execution on system startup. The malware operates primarily on the Windows platform, leveraging backdoor capabilities to facilitate unauthorized access and command execution for the APT3 threat actor.

721.name: harvesting credentials
721.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather credentials that can be used during targeting. Account credentials gathered by adversaries may be those directly associated with the target victim organization or attempt to take advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Adversaries may gather credentials from potential victims in various ways, such as direct elicitation via [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then add malicious content designed to collect website authentication cookies from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) (Citation: Register Deloitte)(Citation: Register Uber)(Citation: Detectify Slack Tokens)(Citation: Forbes GitHub Creds)(Citation: GitHub truffleHog)(Citation: GitHub Gitrob)(Citation: CNET Leaks) Where multi-factor authentication (MFA) based on out-of-band communications is in use, adversaries may compromise a service provider to gain access to MFA codes and one-time passwords (OTP).(Citation: Okta Scatter Swine 2022)

Credential information may also be exposed to adversaries via leaks to online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Search Engines](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/002), breach dumps, code repositories, etc.). Adversaries may purchase credentials from dark web markets, such as Russian Market and 2easy, or through access to Telegram channels that distribute logs from infostealer malware.(Citation: Bleeping Computer 2easy 2021)(Citation: SecureWorks Infostealers 2023)(Citation: Bleeping Computer Stealer Logs 2023)

Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133) or [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078)).
721.profile: [profile]Harvesting Credentials, identified as T1589.001 under the Reconnaissance tactic, involves adversaries gathering account credentials for future targeting. This is performed across multiple platforms by exploiting user tendencies to reuse passwords. Specific technical mechanics include direct elicitation via phishing, compromising websites to steal authentication cookies, accessing leaked data from search engines or breach dumps, and purchasing credentials from dark web markets like Russian Market or via Telegram channels distributing infostealer logs. It is associated with groups including APT28, LAPSUS$, and Magic Hound.
721.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Harvesting Credentials" aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1589.001 (Credentials) under the Reconnaissance tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries gathering credentials through various methods, including direct elicitation via phishing, compromising websites to collect authentication cookies, or purchasing credentials from dark web markets. Credentials may also be exposed via online data leaks, breach dumps, or code repositories. This gathered information can enable further reconnaissance, resource establishment, and initial access.

722.name: planting backdoors
722.profile: [profile]Planting Backdoors is a technique for establishing persistence by implanting malicious code into cloud or container images, such as AWS AMIs, GCP Images, Azure Images, or Docker containers, within a victim's environment. This allows adversaries to maintain access if infrastructure provisioning tools use the latest, compromised image. The technique is distinct from simply uploading malware and can involve tools specifically developed for this purpose, potentially deploying web shells or other backdoors on compromised instances. It is associated with the broader tactic of Persistence and is a sub-technique of Implant Internal Image (T1525).[/profile]
722.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Planting Backdoors is a technique for establishing persistence by inserting malicious access points into systems. It can involve implanting backdoors into cloud or container images within a victim's environment, such as AWS AMIs or Docker images, to gain persistent access if infrastructure tools use the latest image. Adversaries may also manipulate hardware components in the supply chain to insert difficult-to-detect hardware backdoors into devices like servers or network infrastructure. Malware used for this purpose, including backdoors and C2 protocols, can be acquired from criminal marketplaces or other adversaries.

727.name: Return-Oriented Programming (ROP)
727.profile: [profile]Return-Oriented Programming (ROP) is a technique for hijacking execution flow, often used for code injection and privilege escalation. It is a method of proc memory injection (T1055.009), where adversaries craft a malicious payload by chaining together small instruction sequences, called gadgets, found within a target process's existing memory. This technique is used to execute arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process, such as by overwriting the process's stack via the /proc filesystem, to evade defenses like ASLR. It is associated with exploits like Flash exploit.[/profile]
727.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Return-Oriented Programming (ROP) is a technique for hijacking execution flow, often categorized under Defense Evasion and Privilege Escalation tactics. It works by chaining together small, pre-existing instruction sequences (gadgets) found in a program's memory to construct a malicious payload. This method is used to bypass security protections like Data Execution Prevention (DEP) and is commonly applied in process injection techniques, such as proc memory injection on Linux, where adversaries overwrite a target process's stack via the /proc filesystem to execute their ROP chain.

728.name: Shellcode
728.profile: [profile]Shellcode is a fundamental component used by various threat actors, including the Magic Hound intrusion set. It is often delivered via malicious LNK files in email campaigns, as observed in activity linked to the Higaisa group. The malware frequently employs XOR-encoded payloads. Shellcode exists in both 32-bit and 64-bit variants and is a core element for tools like Donut (a shellcode generator) and the GodRat malware associated with APT41, where it provides core execution functionality.[/profile]
728.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Shellcode is a low-level, platform-agnostic executable code often used as a payload stage. It is referenced in activities by groups like higaisa (via LNK file delivery) and APT41 (in tools like GodRat). It is commonly delivered as an XOR-encoded payload, which requires a decoder routine and a 32-bit XOR key for decryption, and is frequently observed in Windows-based attacks.[/profile]

729.name: XOR-encoded payload
729.uncertain_mes:
In this post we'll be focusing on a certain kind of malware: Linux/Xor.DDoS (also known as DDoS.XOR or Xorddos). As usual, we'll break the post down in several points:
Background
Diagnosis
729.profile: [profile]Name: Linux/Xor.DDoS, also known as DDoS.XOR or Xorddos. Aliases: XOR-encoded payload, xor ddos. Attributed Groups: Unknown. Key TTPs/Technical Behaviors: It is a Linux malware that uses XOR encoding for its payload and shellcode, with a decoder routine preceding a 32-bit XOR key to decode the payload size and the variable-length payload itself. Target Platforms: Linux. Infrastructure/Supplementary Info: The malware is associated with DDoS activities and its payload structure involves an initial shellcode decoder.
729.profile_without_enhance: [profile]XOR-encoded payload is a generic malware component. It is a shellcode payload, commonly used by threat actors like Magic Hound, Higaisa, and FIN8, and is a component of malware like GodRat. Its key technical behavior is being a variable-length, XOR-encoded executable fragment that is decrypted and executed directly in memory, often delivered via tools like Cobalt Strike and Donut. It primarily targets Windows platforms. Associated infrastructure includes 'Image'.

732.name: javascript analysis script
732.profile: [profile]Name: javascript analysis script. Aliases: None specified. Attributed Groups: Unknown_Threat_Actor. Key TTPs/Technical Behaviors: Used in initial stages to connect to a Command and Control server to download next-stage payloads, such as additional JavaScript and VBS scripts, and may involve obfuscation or analysis prevention techniques. Target Platforms: Systems executing HTA files or scripts. Infrastructure/Supplementary Info: Associated with malware like Mispadu and Gozi in delivery chains, and referenced in webshell code like Godzilla for data encoding and execution.[profile]
732.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware 'javascript analysis script' is a component used in multi-stage attacks, such as within the Mispadu campaign, where it is embedded in HTA files to connect to a Command and Control server and download subsequent payloads like VBS scripts. It employs obfuscation and custom encryption methods for analysis prevention. The script is associated with web-based threats and potentially interacts with webshells like Godzilla for command execution and data exfiltration.

733.name: UPS
733.uncertain_mes: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) is a China-based threat group that researchers have attributed to China's Ministry of State Security.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: Recorded Future APT3 May 2017) This group is responsible for the campaigns known as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: FireEye Operation Double Tap) As of June 2015, the group appears to have shifted from targeting primarily US victims to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
733.profile: [profile]APT3, also known as UPS, Gothic Panda, Buckeye, Boyusec, Red Sylvan, Bronze Mayfair, Group 6, Brocade Typhoon, TG-0110, Threat Group-0110, Pirpi, and Boron, is a threat group attributed to China's Ministry of State Security. Its key campaigns include Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap. The group has historically targeted US victims but shifted focus around 2015 to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong, indicating a motivation aligned with espionage and geopolitical interests.
733.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored group APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, Boyusec, TG-0110, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, Red Sylvan, and Boron. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor (Backdoor.APT.CookieCutter). Key TTPs involve spear-phishing and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, including CVE-2014-4113. The group is strongly attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) and is operationally linked to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company. It primarily targets government, defense, aerospace, technology, and transportation sectors in the United States and other regions, with motivations focused on state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.

Its key tools and TTPs are not detailed in the provided data. The group is attributed to China. Its target sectors and regions are unspecified. Its primary motivation is believed to be cyber espionage, aligning with common state-sponsored objectives.

Its operations have been attributed to China's Ministry of State Security. The group is known for conducting cyber espionage campaigns, historically targeting sectors such as technology, manufacturing, and government in the United States, Europe, and Asia to steal intellectual property and sensitive information.
