734.name: spear-phishing messages
734.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
734.profile: [profile]Spear-phishing Messages is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. This technique involves sending targeted electronic messages to specific individuals or organizations, often containing malicious attachments or links designed to execute code on victim systems. It employs social engineering, such as posing as a trusted source, and may use evasive methods like email spoofing, thread hijacking, or manipulating email headers from compromised accounts. Associated groups include APT3, Sea Turtle, and Kimsuky.[/profile]
734.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-phishing messages is a targeted social engineering technique, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1566.001 (Spearphishing Attachment) and T1566.002 (Spearphishing Link) under the Initial Access tactic, primarily targeting Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. It involves sending tailored electronic messages, often via email, to specific individuals or organizations, using lures containing malicious attachments or links to deliver payloads like malware. Attackers employ techniques like email spoofing, thread hijacking, and manipulating email headers to enhance credibility and evade detection, frequently posing as a trusted source to trick the recipient into executing code or divulging credentials.

737.name: spear-phishing campaigns
737.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
737.profile: [profile]Spear-phishing campaigns, identified as T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, target Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. This technique involves sending tailored electronic messages to specific individuals or organizations, often via email, to deliver malicious attachments or links that execute code. Attackers employ social engineering by posing as trusted sources and use evasive methods like email spoofing, thread hijacking, or manipulating email headers from compromised accounts to bypass security. Groups such as Turla have been associated with this activity, which can also direct victims to call phone numbers leading to malware downloads or remote tool installation.[/profile]
737.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-phishing campaigns, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, target specific individuals or organizations via electronic social engineering. The technical mechanics involve sending tailored emails containing malicious links or attachments to execute code, often leveraging social engineering to pose as a trusted source. This is distinct from broad phishing and may utilize evasive techniques like email spoofing or thread hijacking to bypass security.

738.name: secret Fox operation
738.profile: [profile]The entity "secret Fox operation" is associated with the APT3 intrusion set. Based on retrieved information, it involves the technique of acquiring credentials from cloud secrets management stores, identified as T1555.006 under the Credential Access tactic for cloud platforms. The technical mechanics involve using high-privileged cloud access to execute specific API commands like AWS's `get-secret-value`, GCP's `gcloud secrets describe`, or Azure's `az key vault secret show` to directly request secrets from managers such as AWS Secrets Manager, GCP Secret Manager, or Azure Key Vault, rather than through instance metadata.
738.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "secret Fox operation" aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1555.006 "Cloud Secrets Management Stores" under the Credential Access tactic, applicable to cloud platforms. This technique involves adversaries with sufficient cloud privileges, such as compromised high-level accounts or services, directly requesting secrets like passwords and API keys from cloud-native managers including AWS Secrets Manager, GCP Secret Manager, and Azure Key Vault using specific commands like `get-secret-value`, `gcloud secrets describe`, and `az key vault secret show`.

741.name: VBS script
741.profile: [profile]VBS script is a scripting language often used as a component or delivery mechanism in malware campaigns. It is associated with threat actors like Unknown_Threat_Actor, smoky spider (UAC-0006), and Cobalt Group. Key technical behaviors include heavy obfuscation with inserted spaces and long variable names to frustrate analysis, and it frequently executes PowerShell code to download secondary payloads like AndeLoader or other malware. It targets Windows platforms and is delivered via malicious documents or shortcut files.[profile]
741.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VBS script is a generic malware type, not a specific family. It is used as a downloader or initial execution script by other malware families, including Smokeloader (attributed to Smoky Spider/UAC-0006), Pony (attributed to Cobalt), and Cloudeye. Key technical behaviors include heavy obfuscation with inserted spaces and long variable names to hinder analysis, and it often executes PowerShell code to download the next-stage payload. Its primary target platform is Windows.

742.name: PowerShell command
742.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)
742.profile: [profile]PowerShell command is a sub-technique under T1059.001 (Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell) primarily used for Execution on Windows. It involves abusing the built-in PowerShell environment to run commands and scripts, such as using cmdlets like Start-Process to execute binaries or Invoke-Command for local and remote execution. Adversaries can download and run executables from the internet, often executing them directly in memory, and can bypass the powershell.exe binary by leveraging the System.Management.Automation assembly through .NET. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups and is integral to tools like Empire and PowerSploit.[/profile]
742.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PowerShell Command is a sub-technique (T1059.001) of Command and Scripting Interpreter, used for Execution on Windows. It involves abusing the PowerShell environment to run commands and scripts, including using cmdlets like Start-Process to launch executables and Invoke-Command for local or remote execution. It can download and run code from the internet, execute payloads directly in memory, and be invoked without the powershell.exe binary via the System.Management.Automation assembly.

743.name: Downloader payload
743.profile: [profile]The malware is identified as a Downloader payload. It is associated with an unknown threat actor. Based on retrieved context, it is similar to or functions as an IcedID downloader. It has been observed in multi-stage campaigns, where it acts as a first, second, or third-stage downloader to deliver final payloads such as the Gozi/URSNIF infostealer. It is also referenced in the context of other downloader components like Markirat and GrimPlant.
743.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is a Downloader payload. It is associated with or similar to the IcedID downloader. It has been observed as a component in campaigns delivering other malware, such as Gozi/URSNIF, where it functions as a multi-stage downloader. It is also referenced as a component in other malware like GrimPlant and MarkiRat.

754.name: malware component
754.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
754.profile: [profile]The malware, referred to as nmass, is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) targeting entities in Mongolia. It is deployed via a malicious Royal Road v7 document masquerading as a report on COVID-19 infections in Russia, which is fake-signed by "A. Amarsaikhan." The initial payload is dropped as a file named "os03C2.tmp." Its code shares similarities with older campaigns associated with Operation LagTime or Tonto Team, though the specific threat actor remains formally unattributed.
754.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware component is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) that is part of the nmass malware family. It is delivered via a malicious Royal Road document (v7) masquerading as a COVID-19 report targeting Mongolian authorities. Its key technical behaviors include dropping a primary executable (os03C2.tmp) to establish a backdoor. This component has been associated with campaigns attributed to Operation LagTime or Tonto Team. Its target platform is Windows systems via .NET.

755.name: Windows command " /c whoami
755.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution. The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems. The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands. The command prompt can be invoked remotely via [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [SSH](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/004).(Citation: SSH in Windows)

Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops. Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple systems.

Adversaries may leverage [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) to execute various commands and payloads. Common uses include [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) to execute a single command, or abusing [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) interactively with input and output forwarded over a command and control channel.
755.profile: [profile]Windows Command Shell, identified as T1059.003, is an execution technique under the Command and Scripting Interpreter tactic, primarily for Windows platforms. It involves abusing the native cmd.exe interpreter to execute commands, either as single instances, within batch files (.bat/.cmd), or interactively over a command and control channel. The shell can be invoked remotely via services like SSH. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and FIN7, to run payloads and conduct system manipulation.
755.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Windows command " /c whoami" is a specific instance of the MITRE ATT&CK technique System Owner/User Discovery (T1033), under the Discovery tactic, applicable to Windows platforms. It involves executing the `whoami` command via the Windows command shell (cmd.exe) with the `/c` parameter to identify the currently logged-in user account, a common step for adversaries to gather information about system ownership and user context for follow-on actions.

756.name: schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr c:\users\public\ /sc onlogon /ru "system"
756.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may use hidden users to hide the presence of user accounts they create or modify. Administrators may want to hide users when there are many user accounts on a given system or if they want to hide their administrative or other management accounts from other users. In macOS, adversaries can create or modify a user to be hidden through manipulating plist files, folder attributes, and user attributes. To prevent a user from being shown on the login screen and in System Preferences, adversaries can set the userID to be under 500 and set the key value Hide500Users to TRUE in the /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow plist file.(Citation: Cybereason OSX Pirrit) Every user has a userID associated with it. When the Hide500Users key value is set to TRUE, users with a userID under 500 do not appear on the login screen and in System Preferences. Using the command line, adversaries can use the dscl utility to create hidden user accounts by setting the IsHidden attribute to 1. Adversaries can also hide a userâ€™s home folder by changing the chflags to hidden.(Citation: Apple Support Hide a User Account) Adversaries may similarly hide user accounts in Windows. Adversaries can set the HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\UserList Registry key value to 0 for a specific user to prevent that user from being listed on the logon screen.(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021)(Citation: US-CERT TA18-074A) On Linux systems, adversaries may hide user accounts from the login screen, also referred to as the greeter. The method an adversary may use depends on which Display Manager the distribution is currently using. For example, on an Ubuntu system using the GNOME Display Manger (GDM), accounts may be hidden from the greeter using the gsettings command (ex: sudo -u gdm gsettings set org.gnome.login-screen disable-user-list true).(Citation: Hide GDM User Accounts) Display Managers are not anchored to specific distributions and may be changed by a user or adversary.
756.profile: [profile]The entity is a specific command-line example of the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Scheduled Task" (T1053.005), under the Execution tactic, targeting the Windows platform. This command, `schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr c:\users\public\ /sc onlogon /ru "system"`, creates a new scheduled task named "mysc" configured to run a payload from a public directory automatically upon user logon with SYSTEM privileges. This is a common method for establishing persistence. The provided context about "hidden users" (T1564.002) is a distinct technique for evasion and is not directly part of this specific task creation mechanic.
756.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity is a specific instance of the Scheduled Task/Job: Scheduled Task (T1053.005) technique, falling under the Execution and Persistence tactics on Windows. The command `schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr c:\users\public\ /sc onlogon /ru "system"` creates a new scheduled task named "mysc" that triggers on user logon (`/sc onlogon`) to run a payload from a public directory with SYSTEM-level privileges (`/ru "system"`), establishing persistence and potential privilege escalation.

758.name: SOCKS5 connection
758.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may check for Internet connectivity on compromised systems. This may be performed during automated discovery and can be accomplished in numerous ways such as using [Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097), tracert, and GET requests to websites, or performing initial speed testing to confirm bandwidth. Adversaries may use the results and responses from these requests to determine if the system is capable of communicating with their C2 servers before attempting to connect to them. The results may also be used to identify routes, redirectors, and proxy servers.
758.profile: [profile]The entity "SOCKS5 connection" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is likely a specific implementation of the MITRE technique "Proxy" (T1090) or "External Proxy" (T1090.002). The technical mechanics involve using the SOCKS5 protocol to act as an intermediary for network communications, redirecting command and control traffic to avoid direct connections to adversary infrastructure. This method can be used to manage C2 communications and obscure the destination of malicious traffic.[/profile]
758.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SOCKS5 connection is a sub-technique of Proxy (T1090.004) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates on multiple platforms, including Windows, Linux, and macOS. Adversaries use this method to relay network traffic through a SOCKS5 proxy server, which can tunnel various protocols like HTTP(S), DNS, or raw TCP to obfuscate the destination of command and control communications and avoid direct connections to their infrastructure.

763.name: scheduled task
763.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. There are multiple ways to access the Task Scheduler in Windows. The [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) utility can be run directly on the command line, or the Task Scheduler can be opened through the GUI within the Administrator Tools section of the Control Panel.(Citation: Stack Overflow) In some cases, adversaries have used a .NET wrapper for the Windows Task Scheduler, and alternatively, adversaries have used the Windows netapi32 library and [Windows Management Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047) (WMI) to create a scheduled task. Adversaries may also utilize the Powershell Cmdlet `Invoke-CimMethod`, which leverages WMI class `PS_ScheduledTask` to create a scheduled task via an XML path.(Citation: Red Canary - Atomic Red Team)

An adversary may use Windows Task Scheduler to execute programs at system startup or on a scheduled basis for persistence. The Windows Task Scheduler can also be abused to conduct remote Execution as part of Lateral Movement and/or to run a process under the context of a specified account (such as SYSTEM). Similar to [System Binary Proxy Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218), adversaries have also abused the Windows Task Scheduler to potentially mask one-time execution under signed/trusted system processes.(Citation: ProofPoint Serpent)

Adversaries may also create "hidden" scheduled tasks (i.e. [Hide Artifacts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564)) that may not be visible to defender tools and manual queries used to enumerate tasks. Specifically, an adversary may hide a task from `schtasks /query` and the Task Scheduler by deleting the associated Security Descriptor (SD) registry value (where deletion of this value must be completed using SYSTEM permissions).(Citation: SigmaHQ)(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task) Adversaries may also employ alternate methods to hide tasks, such as altering the metadata (e.g., `Index` value) within associated registry keys.(Citation: Defending Against Scheduled Task Attacks in Windows Environments)
763.profile: [profile]Scheduled Task is technique T1053.005 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, categorized under the Execution and Persistence tactics for Windows platforms. It involves abusing the Windows Task Scheduler for initial or recurring execution of malicious code using utilities like the command-line `schtasks`, a .NET wrapper, the netapi32 library, Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI), or the PowerShell Cmdlet `Invoke-CimMethod` with the `PS_ScheduledTask` WMI class. This technique can be used for persistence, lateral movement, and running processes under privileged contexts like SYSTEM, with adversaries also creating hidden tasks by deleting the associated Security Descriptor registry value or altering registry key metadata to evade detection. It is associated with numerous threat groups including OilRig, Lazarus Group, and APT29.[/profile]
763.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Scheduled Task is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1053.005 under the Execution and Persistence tactics, primarily for Windows. It involves abusing the Windows Task Scheduler via command-line `schtasks`, GUI, .NET wrappers, WMI, or the PowerShell `Invoke-CimMethod` cmdlet to schedule malicious code execution at startup or intervals for persistence, lateral movement, or privilege escalation. Adversaries can hide tasks by deleting the Security Descriptor registry value or altering registry key metadata to evade detection.

764.name: pirpi
764.uncertain_mes:
Operation Double Tap
Mandiant
Written by: Ned Moran, Mike Scott, Mike Oppenheim, Joshua Homan
764.profile: [profile]Pirpi is a malware family, also known as Pirpi.2014 and Pirpi.2015. It is attributed to the APT3 intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include using specific C2 communication protocols, offering a command set for remote control, and employing anti-disassembly techniques. The malware targets Windows platforms, as indicated by its use of the Windows registry for persistence. Infrastructure details include identified file hashes and command structures for operational control.
764.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Pirpi is a malware family with versions Pirpi.2014 and Pirpi.2015, attributed to the group UPS. Its key technical behaviors include anti-disassembly techniques and specific command structures. The malware communicates with command and control (C2) servers, as evidenced by similarities in C2 communications across its versions. Target platforms are unspecified in the provided data. Supplementary information includes a known file hash (0649A3DD632CDE57BC2E97B814BE81A7F45454FED2A73800DE476AA75CDBE8CD) and its association with Operation Double Tap as documented by Mandiant.

765.name: backdoor.apt.cookiecutter
765.profile: [profile]Backdoor.APT.CookieCutter, also known as Pirpi, is a malware attributed to the APT3 intrusion set. It functions as a secondary payload and has been observed using the filename newnotepad.exe. Its technical behavior involves connecting to known APT3 command and control domains. The malware is noted for sharing a backdoor switch mechanism with the older CookieTime malware family, which has also been associated with the Lazarus Group. This indicates potential code reuse or shared development lineage between these threat actors.]
765.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Backdoor.APT.CookieCutter, also known as Pirpi, is a backdoor malware. It has been associated with the Lazarus Group. Its technical behaviors include using a secondary payload named newnotepad.exe and connecting to known APT3 command-and-control domains. It is related to older malware families such as CookieTime, JessieConTea, and LCPDot. Target platforms are not specified in the provided data.

768.name: Download
768.profile: [profile]The entity "Download" aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1105 (Ingress Tool Transfer), under the Command and Control tactic for multiple platforms. This technique involves transferring tools or files from an external system into a compromised environment. Specific mechanics include using LNK shortcut files, where adversaries hide download commands within the icon location metadata field to smuggle payloads past filters and initiate downloads via command interpreters. Associated threat actors include APT3, Mustang Panda, Gamaredon Group, and Kimsuky.
768.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Download" is a foundational technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, though a specific ID is not provided in the input. It falls under the Resource Development tactic and is platform-agnostic. Technically, it involves adversaries acquiring malicious tools from the internet, third-party marketplaces, or other adversaries to support their operations. This can include obtaining payloads, backdoors, and C2 protocols. A specific application is seen in LNK Icon Smuggling, where adversaries hide download commands within Windows shortcut files, using the icon location field to reference and retrieve malicious payloads from external URLs upon execution.

769.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
769.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries. These interfaces and languages provide ways of interacting with computer systems and are a common feature across many different platforms. Most systems come with some built-in command-line interface and scripting capabilities, for example, macOS and Linux distributions include some flavor of [Unix Shell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/004) while Windows installations include the [Windows Command Shell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/003) and [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001).

There are also cross-platform interpreters such as [Python](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/006), as well as those commonly associated with client applications such as [JavaScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/007) and [Visual Basic](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005).

Adversaries may abuse these technologies in various ways as a means of executing arbitrary commands. Commands and scripts can be embedded in [Initial Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0001) payloads delivered to victims as lure documents or as secondary payloads downloaded from an existing C2. Adversaries may also execute commands through interactive terminals/shells, as well as utilize various [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) in order to achieve remote Execution.(Citation: Powershell Remote Commands)(Citation: Cisco IOS Software Integrity Assurance - Command History)(Citation: Remote Shell Execution in Python)
769.profile: [profile]Command and Scripting Interpreter (T1059) is an Execution tactic technique applicable to multiple platforms, where adversaries abuse built-in or cross-platform interpreters like Windows Command Shell, PowerShell, Unix Shell, Python, JavaScript, and Visual Basic to execute arbitrary commands. These commands can be embedded in initial access payloads, delivered via lure documents, or executed interactively or remotely to achieve execution on a target system. It is associated with numerous threat groups including APT3, Oilrig, and Fin7.[/profile]
769.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Command and Scripting Interpreter is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059 under the Execution tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries abusing built-in or cross-platform interpreters like Unix Shell, Windows Command Shell, PowerShell, Python, JavaScript, and Visual Basic to execute arbitrary commands and scripts. These can be delivered via initial access payloads, embedded in documents, or executed through interactive shells and remote services to achieve execution on a target system.

774.name: PlugX/Kaba
774.uncertain_mes: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) is a remote access tool (RAT) with modular plugins that has been used by multiple threat groups.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Fox Part 2)(Citation: New DragonOK)(Citation: Dell TG-3390)
774.profile: [profile]PlugX, also known as Kaba and Korplug, is a modular remote access trojan (RAT) first identified in 2012. It has been used by numerous threat groups, including APT3, Mustang Panda, APT41, DragonOK, and Threat Group-3390. Its key behaviors include acting as a backdoor and using command and control servers like walterclean[.]com. The malware primarily targets Windows platforms and has been associated with domains related to security software like 360.cn and baidu.com.[/profile]
774.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PlugX, also known as Kaba and Korplug, is a remote access trojan (RAT) often attributed to Chinese-speaking threat actors, including groups like APT41, Mustang Panda, and Emissary Panda. It has been used since at least 2012, maintaining consistent core techniques for system compromise. The malware establishes command and control through domains like walterclean[.]com and has been distributed via compromised software update mechanisms, including those associated with domains like 360safe.cn. Its primary target is the Windows platform, where it functions as a backdoor for remote access and data exfiltration.

775.name: zero-day exploits
775.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may develop exploits that can be used during targeting. An exploit takes advantage of a bug or vulnerability in order to cause unintended or unanticipated behavior to occur on computer hardware or software. Rather than finding/modifying exploits from online or purchasing them from exploit vendors, an adversary may develop their own exploits.(Citation: NYTStuxnet) Adversaries may use information acquired via [Vulnerabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588/006) to focus exploit development efforts. As part of the exploit development process, adversaries may uncover exploitable vulnerabilities through methods such as fuzzing and patch analysis.(Citation: Irongeek Sims BSides 2017)

As with legitimate development efforts, different skill sets may be required for developing exploits. The skills needed may be located in-house, or may need to be contracted out. Use of a contractor may be considered an extension of that adversary's exploit development capabilities, provided the adversary plays a role in shaping requirements and maintains an initial degree of exclusivity to the exploit.

Adversaries may use exploits during various phases of the adversary lifecycle (i.e. [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190), [Exploitation for Client Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203), [Exploitation for Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068), [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211), [Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212), [Exploitation of Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1210), and [Application or System Exploitation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/004)).
775.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Exploits" with ID T1587.004, categorized under Resource Development. It involves adversaries developing their own exploits in-house or via contractors, using methods like fuzzing and patch analysis to uncover vulnerabilities, rather than acquiring them externally. This self-developed capability provides exclusivity and is used across multiple attack phases, including initial access, execution, and privilege escalation.
775.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Zero-day exploits are vulnerabilities unknown to the vendor, lacking patches, which adversaries use to cause unintended behavior in software or hardware. They are leveraged across multiple tactics, including initial access, execution, privilege escalation, and defense evasion, to bypass security features. These exploits can be developed in-house, acquired from vendors, or stolen, and are a key resource for groups like Volt Typhoon and APT28.

776.name: social engineering
776.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may search social media for information about victims that can be used during targeting. Social media sites may contain various information about a victim organization, such as business announcements as well as information about the roles, locations, and interests of staff.

Adversaries may search in different social media sites depending on what information they seek to gather. Threat actors may passively harvest data from these sites, as well as use information gathered to create fake profiles/groups to elicit victimâ€™s into revealing specific information (i.e. [Spearphishing Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/001)).(Citation: Cyware Social Media) Information from these sources may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Establish Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1585) or [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [Spearphishing via Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/003)).
776.profile: [profile]Social Media, identified as T1593.001 under the Reconnaissance tactic, is a technique used across multiple platforms where adversaries search social media sites to passively harvest information about victim organizations and staff. This gathered intelligence, including business announcements and personal details like roles and interests, is used to craft targeted lures, create fake profiles for elicitation, and enable follow-on actions such as spearphishing or account compromise. Groups like OilRig, APT3, and Kimsuky have been associated with this method.[/profile]
776.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Social Engineering is a foundational adversarial approach, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, and thus lacks a standard T-ID. It underpins multiple tactics, primarily Initial Access and Reconnaissance, across all platforms. The technique involves psychological manipulation to deceive individuals into divulging confidential information, performing actions, or compromising security. This is executed through various vectors like spearphishing via email or social media services, voice calls (vishing), and the use of compromised or fabricated social media accounts to build trust and deliver malicious lures.

778.name: Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS)
778.uncertain_mes: [Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) is a group that has been active since at least 2010 and believed to be operating out of Iran. By 2014 [Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) transitioned from website defacement operations to malware-based cyber espionage campaigns targeting the US defense industrial base and Iranian users of anti-censorship technologies.(Citation: FireEye Operation Saffron Rose 2013)
778.profile: [profile]Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is a state-sponsored intrusion set, also known as APT3, Boyusec, CICIR, and Guangdong ITSEC. It is linked to individuals like Wu Shizhong and associated groups such as UNC5174 and APT31, which operate on its behalf. The group's arsenal includes custom tools for executing access operations. It is attributed to China and primarily targets government entities, parliamentarians, and defense industrial bases in regions including the UK and the US, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and intelligence gathering.
778.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is the primary state intelligence agency of China, assessed to direct and sponsor multiple distinct cyber espionage intrusion sets. These affiliated groups, also known as APT41, APT3 (Boyusec, Buckeye, Gothic Panda), APT31 (Zirconium, Judgment Panda), and others like UNC5174, operate on its behalf. Their collective activities employ diverse custom malware toolkits including PlugX and Pirpi, with key TTPs involving spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, and leveraging trusted relationships for access. These groups are attributed to acting for China, primarily targeting government, defense, aerospace, technology, and telecommunications sectors globally for state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.[/profile]
778.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is a state intelligence agency of China, also known to sponsor and task multiple distinct APT groups. These include APT31 (also known as Zirconium, Judgment Panda, and Bronze Vinewood), which is associated with the Wuhan Xiaoruizhi Science and Technology Company and has targeted government officials and parliamentarians internationally, and UNC5174 (also known as Uteus), which is focused on access operations. The MSS's cyber operations are attributed to China, with motivations encompassing espionage and geopolitical influence, targeting sectors and regions of strategic interest to the Chinese state.
778.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is the state intelligence agency of China, believed to sponsor and direct multiple distinct advanced persistent threat (APT) groups as part of its cyber espionage apparatus. These groups include APT31 (also known as Zirconium, Judgment Panda, and Violet Typhoon) and UNC5174 (also known as UTEUS). These subordinate groups conduct cyber operations on behalf of the MSS, targeting government entities, officials, and parliamentarians internationally, particularly in regions like the United Kingdom, to further Chinese state intelligence objectives.
778.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is a state intelligence agency directing and sponsoring multiple Chinese APT groups. It is operationally linked to groups including APT3 (Boyusec, Buckeye), APT10 (Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper), APT31 (Zirconium, Judgment Panda), APT41 (Double Dragon), CICIR (Lifting Zmiy), and UNC5174. These subordinate groups employ diverse malware like PlugX, Pirpi, and the Inception Framework, and utilize TTPs such as spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and zero-day exploitation. They are attributed to China and conduct cyber espionage targeting government, defense, technology, and telecommunications sectors globally, primarily for intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence collection in support of state interests.[/profile]
778.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]This entity is the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS), a state intelligence agency that sponsors and directs multiple distinct APT groups. These subordinate groups include APT3 (Boyusec, Buckeye), APT10 (Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper), APT31 (Zirconium, Judgment Panda), and CICIR (Lifting Zmiy). They employ a range of key malware such as PlugX, Pirpi, and the Inception Framework, and utilize TTPs like spear-phishing and strategic web compromises. The MSS is attributed to China and its associated groups primarily target government, defense, aerospace, and technology sectors in the US, Europe, and Asia, with motivations focused on state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.[/profile]
778.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]This entity is not a single APT group but the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS), a state intelligence agency believed to sponsor and direct multiple distinct cyber espionage intrusion sets. These subordinate groups, also known by various aliases, include APT3 (Boyusec, Buckeye), APT10 (Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper), APT31 (Zirconium, Judgment Panda), APT41 (Winnti, Double Dragon), CICIR (Lifting Zmiy), and UNC5174. Their collective key malware and tools feature custom backdoors like PlugX and Pirpi, as well as frameworks like Inception. Key TTPs commonly involve spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and exploitation of trusted relationships or zero-day vulnerabilities. The apparatus is attributed to China and primarily targets government, defense, aerospace, technology, and telecommunications sectors globally, with motivations focused on state-sponsored intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence collection.
778.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is the state intelligence agency of China, believed to sponsor and direct multiple distinct APT groups for cyber espionage. These subordinate groups include APT3 (also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, and Brocade Typhoon), APT31 (also known as Zirconium, Judgment Panda, and Violet Typhoon), APT41, APT10, and CICIR. These groups employ a diverse toolkit including custom malware like PlugX, Pirpi, and the Inception Framework, and utilize TTPs such as spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and zero-day exploitation. They are attributed to acting on behalf of China and primarily target government, defense, aerospace, technology, and telecommunications sectors globally, with motivations centered on state-sponsored intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence collection.
778.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]This entity is the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS), a state intelligence agency believed to sponsor and direct multiple distinct APT groups. These affiliated groups, which include APT3 (Boyusec, Buckeye), APT10 (Guangdong ITSEC), APT31 (Zirconium), APT41 (Wicked Panda), and CICIR, operate under its umbrella and share common tools and objectives. Key associated malware and toolkits across these groups include PlugX, Pirpi, and the Inception Framework, while common TTPs involve spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and zero-day exploitation. The MSS-sponsored apparatus conducts cyber espionage primarily targeting government, defense, technology, and telecommunications sectors in the United States, Europe, and Asia, with motivations centered on state-sponsored intelligence collection and intellectual property theft.
778.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]This entity is the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS), a state intelligence agency that sponsors and directs multiple distinct APT groups for cyber espionage. These subordinate groups include APT3 (Boyusec/Buckeye), APT10 (Guangdong ITSEC/Stone Panda), APT31 (Zirconium), CICIR, and UNC5174. Key malware and tools associated with its operations include the PlugX and Pirpi backdoors (APT3) and the Inception Framework (APT10). Common TTPs across its groups involve spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities. The MSS is attributed to China and its affiliated groups target government, defense, aerospace, technology, and telecommunications sectors globally, primarily for state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.[/profile]
778.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is the primary state intelligence and security agency of China, believed to be the ultimate sponsor and director of multiple distinct but operationally linked APT groups. These subordinate groups, which include APT3 (Boyusec), APT10 (Stone Panda), APT31 (Zirconium), APT41, and CICIR, operate under its broad mandate. Their collective key malware and tools encompass custom frameworks like Inception and backdoors like PlugX and Pirpi, while key TTPs involve spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and exploiting trusted relationships. The MSS apparatus is attributed to China and orchestrates cyber espionage campaigns primarily targeting government, defense, aerospace, and technology sectors globally, with motivations focused on the theft of intellectual property and strategic intelligence to advance state interests.
778.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is the state intelligence agency of China, overseeing and directing multiple state-sponsored APT groups for cyber espionage. It is operationally linked to groups including APT3 (Boyusec, Buckeye, Gothic Panda), APT31 (Zirconium, Judgment Panda), and UNC5174 (Uteus). 778.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]The Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) is the state intelligence agency of China, overseeing and directing multiple state-sponsored APT groups as part of its cyber espionage apparatus. It is operationally linked to groups including APT3 (also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, and Boyusec), APT31 (also known as Zirconium, Judgment Panda, and Violet Typhoon), and UNC5174. These subordinate groups employ key tools like the PlugX and Pirpi backdoors and TTPs such as spear-phishing and strategic web compromises. The MSS apparatus is attributed to China and primarily targets government, defense, technology, and telecommunications sectors in the United States, Europe, and Asia for state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.

779.name: Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company
779.uncertain_mes: [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) is a likely state-sponsored threat actor with advanced capabilities. From 2017 through 2018, the group led an espionage campaign called Operation Shaheen targeting government and military organizations in Pakistan.(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)
779.profile: [profile]Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company, also known as Boyusec, The White Company, Zombie Spider, Hound Spider, and Bamboo Spider, is a likely state-sponsored threat actor attributed to the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) and linked to Chinese telecom giant Huawei. It shows overlaps with APT3. The group is known for cyber-enabled theft of intellectual property, having targeted U.S. companies and, in Operation Shaheen from 2017-2018, government and military organizations in Pakistan, indicating a motivation for espionage.
779.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored group APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, TG-0110, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, Red Sylvan, and Boron. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor (Backdoor.APT.CookieCutter). Key TTPs involve spear-phishing and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, including CVE-2014-4113. The group is strongly attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) and is operationally linked to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company. It primarily targets government, defense, aerospace, technology, and transportation sectors in the United States and other regions, with motivations focused on state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.
779.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored APT group known as APT41, also referred to as Barium, Winnti, or Double Dragon. It is operationally linked to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company (Boyusec), which has been publicly connected to the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS). The group is known for its dual espionage and financially motivated operations, employing a wide arsenal of custom malware and tools. Its key malware includes the Winnti rootkit, along with other tools like PoisonIvy and PlugX. Its TTPs encompass supply chain attacks and the exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities. The group is believed to be based in China and primarily targets a broad range of sectors globally, including technology, telecommunications, and video gaming, for intellectual property theft and financial gain.
779.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is believed to be the Chinese state-sponsored APT group known as APT41 or Winnti, also known as Barium, Double Dragon, and the Boyusec group, with aliases including Zombie Spider, Hound Spider, and Bamboo Spider. It is attributed to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company (Boyusec), which has been publicly linked to the Chinese Ministry of State Security. The group's key malware includes the Winnti backdoor, and its operations primarily target intellectual property from companies in the United States and other regions, with motivations centered on cyber-espionage and theft for commercial and state advantage.

780.name: Boyusec
780.uncertain_mes: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) is a China-based threat group that researchers have attributed to China's Ministry of State Security.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: Recorded Future APT3 May 2017) This group is responsible for the campaigns known as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: FireEye Operation Double Tap) As of June 2015, the group appears to have shifted from targeting primarily US victims to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
780.profile: [profile]Boyusec, also known as APT3, Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, TG-0110, and Red Sylvan, is a cyber espionage group attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS). Its arsenal includes the Gh0st backdoor variant and Deed RAT malware. The group is known for campaigns such as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Double Tap, and Operation Clandestine Wolf. Initially targeting U.S. entities, it shifted focus around 2015 to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong, indicating a motivation aligned with state-sponsored intelligence gathering and political monitoring.
780.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored group APT3, also known as Boyusec, Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, TG-0110, Bronze Mayfair, and Brocade Typhoon. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities like CVE-2014-4113. The group is strongly attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) and is operationally linked to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company. It primarily targets government, defense, aerospace, technology, and transportation sectors in the United States and other regions, with motivations focused on state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.
780.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Boyusec, also known as APT3, Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, and TG-0110, is an intrusion set attributed to China. Its key malware includes the modified Gh0st backdoor and Deed RAT. The group's TTPs involve spear-phishing and exploiting network vulnerabilities for initial access and data exfiltration. It primarily targets sectors such as technology, government, and defense across North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intellectual property theft.
780.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]Boyusec, also known as APT3, Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, and TG-0110, is a Chinese state-sponsored intrusion set. It is attributed to China's Ministry of State Security and primarily targets sectors in the United States, Japan, and Hong Kong, with motivations centered on cyber espionage to gather political, economic, and technological intelligence.

781.name: Pirpi
781.uncertain_mes:
Operation Double Tap
Mandiant
Written by: Ned Moran, Mike Scott, Mike Oppenheim, Joshua Homan
781.profile: [profile]Pirpi, also known as pirpi, is a malware attributed to the APT3 intrusion set and potentially linked to the 'ups' group. Its key technical behaviors include anti-disassembly techniques and command execution capabilities, with distinct variants identified as Pirpi.2014 and Pirpi.2015 that share similarities in C2 communications. The malware targets Windows platforms, as indicated by its use of the Windows registry for persistence. Infrastructure details include specific file hashes, such as 0649A3DD632CDE57BC2E97B814BE81A7F45454FED2A73800DE476AA75CDBE8CD, associated with its samples.[/profile]
781.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Pirpi, also known as pirpi, is a malware family associated with the 'ups' group. It has distinct versions, including Pirpi.2014 and Pirpi.2015, which share similarities in C2 communications. The malware supports various commands and incorporates anti-disassembly techniques. Its functionality includes creating registry keys for persistence to automatically launch copies on system startup.

782.name: Dong Hao
782.profile: [profile]Dong Hao is an individual believed to be a founding member and executive of the Chinese cybersecurity company Boyusec, which has suspected links to the intrusion set APT3 (also known as Boyusec). This group has been associated with cyber espionage campaigns targeting U.S. companies in the manufacturing, financial, and aerospace sectors from at least 2011 to 2017. The group's activities are primarily motivated by intellectual property theft and state-sponsored espionage.
782.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'Dong Hao' is an alias and founding executive of the Chinese state-sponsored cyber espionage group APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, TG-0110, Red Sylvan, and Boron. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor, with key TTPs involving spear-phishing and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities like CVE-2014-4113. The group is strongly attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) and is operationally linked to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company (Boyusec). It primarily targets government, defense, aerospace, technology, and telecommunications sectors in the United States, Europe, and Asia for state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.
782.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set 'Dong Hao' is not a standardized APT group name but refers to an individual, Dong Hao, identified as a founding member and executive of the Chinese cybersecurity company Boyusec. This individual is linked to the group known as Zombie Spider, which is also associated with APT31 (aka Red Keres, Zirconium, Bronze Vinewood). The group's activities, as detailed in a U.S. indictment, are attributed to China and primarily targeted the U.S. manufacturing, financial, and aerospace sectors from 2011 to 2017, with motivations believed to be state-sponsored economic espionage.

783.name: Gothic Panda
783.uncertain_mes: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) is a China-based threat group that researchers have attributed to China's Ministry of State Security.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: Recorded Future APT3 May 2017) This group is responsible for the campaigns known as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: FireEye Operation Double Tap) As of June 2015, the group appears to have shifted from targeting primarily US victims to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
783.profile: [profile]Gothic Panda, also known as APT3, Buckeye, Red Sylvan, Bronze Mayfair, Group 6, UPS Team, Brocade Typhoon, Boyusec, TG-0110, UPS, Threat Group-0110, Pirpi, and Boron, is a China-based threat group attributed to China's Ministry of State Security. It has been responsible for campaigns including Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap. The group's victimology shifted around June 2015 from primarily targeting US victims to focusing on political organizations in Hong Kong.

784.name: TG-011
784.profile: [profile]TG-011 is an intrusion set, also known as lifting zmiy and brazenbamboo. It is linked to or overlaps with the APT3 group. Its operations involve the use of publicly available tools for lateral movement within victim infrastructure. The group's activities include the development and deployment of custom tools for Telegram (tg) monitoring, secret capture, and data exfiltration, as indicated by updates to its tooling for real-time monitoring and chat software integration. Its specific targets, origin, and primary motivations remain unclear from the provided data.
784.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored group APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Boyusec, TG-0110, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, Red Sylvan, and Boron. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor (Backdoor.APT.CookieCutter). Key TTPs involve spear-phishing and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities, including CVE-2014-4113. The group is strongly attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) and is operationally linked to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company. It primarily targets government, defense, aerospace, technology, and transportation sectors in the United States and other regions, with motivations focused on state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.
784.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]TG-011 is a suspected cyber espionage group, also known as lifting zmiy and brazenbamboo. Its key malware and tools include a custom Telegram monitoring and data capture utility, as indicated by development logs referencing "tg local real-time monitoring" and "tg secret capture." The group's primary TTPs involve leveraging publicly available tools for lateral movement within victim infrastructure. While its origin and specific targets are not definitively established in the provided data, its tooling suggests a focus on information theft, with a motivation likely aligned with cyber espionage.
784.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set known as TG-011, also referred to as BrazenBamboo, is a suspected Chinese state-aligned cyber espionage group. Its activity is characterized by the use of custom tools, including a Telegram monitoring and data capture utility referenced in its development logs. The group's operations show overlaps with the cluster tracked as Lifting Zmiy, which utilizes publicly available tools for lateral movement. TG-011 is believed to primarily target entities for intelligence collection, though specific sectors and regions remain unclear from available data.

785.name: spearphishing attacks
785.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send spearphishing messages via third-party services to elicit sensitive information that can be used during targeting. Spearphishing for information is an attempt to trick targets into divulging information, frequently credentials or other actionable information. Spearphishing for information frequently involves social engineering techniques, such as posing as a source with a reason to collect information (ex: [Establish Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1585) or [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)) and/or sending multiple, seemingly urgent messages.

All forms of spearphishing are electronically delivered social engineering targeted at a specific individual, company, or industry. In this scenario, adversaries send messages through various social media services, personal webmail, and other non-enterprise controlled services.(Citation: ThreatPost Social Media Phishing) These services are more likely to have a less-strict security policy than an enterprise. As with most kinds of spearphishing, the goal is to generate rapport with the target or get the target's interest in some way. Adversaries may create fake social media accounts and message employees for potential job opportunities. Doing so allows a plausible reason for asking about services, policies, and information about their environment. Adversaries may also use information from previous reconnaissance efforts (ex: [Social Media](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/001) or [Search Victim-Owned Websites](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1594)) to craft persuasive and believable lures.
785.profile: [profile]Spearphishing Service, identified as T1598.001 under the Reconnaissance tactic, operates on multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries sending targeted spearphishing messages through third-party services like social media or personal webmail to elicit sensitive information, often by posing as a trusted source with a plausible pretext such as a job opportunity. The method leverages these non-enterprise services due to their typically less-strict security policies to build rapport with the target and gather credentials or other actionable intelligence for future attacks.[/profile]
785.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spearphishing Attacks is a broad initial access technique (T1566) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting multiple platforms. It involves electronically delivered social engineering tailored to a specific individual, company, or industry to trick the target into performing an action, such as opening a malicious attachment (like Office documents or executables) or clicking a link. The link may lead to a site that exploits the browser or prompts a malicious download, often leveraging User Execution. This method is foundational to more specific sub-techniques like Spearphishing Attachment and Spearphishing Link.

786.name: remote access tools (RAT)
786.profile: [profile]The entity is a generic class of Remote Access Tools (RATs), also known as Remote Access Trojans, which are used for unauthorized system control. It is attributed to the intrusion set APT3. Specific malware families within this class include AsyncRAT, DCRat, Remcos, AveMaria, and NanoCore, which are listed in threat rankings. These tools typically provide backdoor access and can execute commands for remote shell access, file upload/download, and keylogging, as exemplified by the 'invisibleferret' variant's capabilities. The primary target platform is Windows systems.
786.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'remote access tools (RAT)' is a broad category of malware, not a specific family. Specific examples referenced include AsyncRAT, DCRat, Remcos, AveMaria, and NanoCore, which are all classified as Remote Access Trojans (RATs). These tools are designed to provide attackers with remote control over infected systems. The technical behaviors of such tools can include providing remote shell access, downloading and executing additional payloads, uploading files, and keylogging. They primarily target Windows platforms. Some RATs, like those in campaigns described, have been used in regional operations in Latin America, potentially linked to groups like Molerats, though attribution is not consistently specified for all variants.[/profile]

793.name: Chinese government
793.profile: [profile]The Chinese government is a state entity rather than a distinct APT group, but it is frequently attributed as the sponsor or ultimate beneficiary of numerous cyber espionage activities. It is linked to various intrusion sets, including APT3, and is referenced in the context of operations by groups like APT19, Quilted Tiger, and Mustang Panda. These groups, which target sectors such as government, defense, and strategic policy, are believed to conduct intelligence collection on behalf of Chinese state interests, with stolen information reportedly passed through military chains to national leadership.

797.name: Guangdong ITSEC
797.profile: [profile]Guangdong ITSEC, also known as Boyusec, is a Chinese cyber espionage group attributed to the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS). The group is linked to the Inception Framework malware suite and has shown overlaps with APT10, notably through personnel connections to a joint lab at the Guangdong subsidiary of CNITSEC. Its operations are believed to focus on cyber espionage, targeting entities for intelligence collection, though specific victim sectors are not detailed in the provided data.
797.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored APT group known as APT3, also known as Boyusec, Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, TG-0110, and Red Sylvan. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing and strategic web compromises. The group is strongly believed to be operationally tied to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company (Boyusec) and linked to the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS). YiBackdoor: A New Malware Family With Links to IcedID and Latrodectus
Introduction
799.profile: [profile]YiBackdoor is a new malware family with links to IcedID and Latrodectus. It is associated with the intrusion set Boyusec. Its technical behaviors include backdoor functionality, as indicated by detection names like Backdoor/JS.Akdoor, Backdoor/Win.Agent, Backdoor/Win.Akdoor, and Backdoor/Win.AppleSeed. The primary target platform is Windows. This malware is referenced in the context of other backdoor families such as AzorUlt and Outlook Backdoor, which are linked to groups like The Gorgon Group and Turla, respectively, though these are separate entities.

It is associated with groups such as Turla and The Gorgon Group. Its primary function is to provide unauthorized remote access, with technical behaviors including the use of specific detection names like Backdoor/Win.AppleSeed.C4646724. It primarily targets Windows platforms, as indicated by the 'Win' prefix in its variant names.[/profile]

805.name: joint active defense lab (ADUL)
805.profile: [profile]The entity is known as the Joint Active Defense Lab (ADUL), which is a collaborative initiative rather than a traditional APT group. It is directly linked to the Chinese state-sponsored threat actor Boyusec, with its activities also referenced in the context of APT10 (also known as Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, and Purple Typhoon). The lab's operational focus is on active defense, specifically involving techniques like TCC database monitoring. Its primary motivation appears to be cyber defense and intelligence gathering, aligning with the strategic interests of its associated state-linked entities.

Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor. The group has historically targeted government, defense, aerospace, and technology sectors, primarily in the United States, Europe, and Asia, for state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.[/profile]

Its primary motivation is intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering, with a historical focus on sectors like government, technology, and defense across North America, Europe, and Asia-Pacific regions. 806.name: Wu Shizhong
806.profile: [profile]Wu Shizhong is a key individual believed to be dual-hatted as the director of China's National Information Security Standards Committee (CNITSEC) and as the director of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) 13th Bureau. This individual is notably linked to the context of APT41 (also known as TA415, Amoeba, Winnti, and Leopard Typhoon), a prolific Chinese state-sponsored cyber espionage group. The group's arsenal includes custom malware families like Winnti and KEYPLUG, and it employs sophisticated TTPs for long-term network access. APT41 is attributed to China and primarily targets a wide range of sectors globally, including technology, telecommunications, and video gaming, for both espionage and financially motivated operations, reflecting a blended state and criminal nexus.

The group is attributed to China and is believed to be directed by the Ministry of State Security (MSS), with specific connections to former CNITSEC director Wu Shizhong. It conducts sophisticated cyber espionage primarily targeting international government entities and officials for intelligence collection in support of Chinese national interests.

807.uncertain_mes: [Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) is a group that has been active since at least 2010 and believed to be operating out of Iran. By 2014 [Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) transitioned from website defacement operations to malware-based cyber espionage campaigns targeting the US defense industrial base and Iranian users of anti-censorship technologies.(Citation: FireEye Operation Saffron Rose 2013)

808.name: CICIR
808.profile: [profile]CICIR, a Chinese state-sponsored intrusion set believed to be linked to the Ministry of State Security (MSS), is known for conducting cyber espionage operations. The group's specific malware arsenal and primary TTPs are not detailed in the provided data, though it is noted for using publicly available tools for lateral movement within victim infrastructure. Its target sectors and regions, as well as its core motivations, remain unspecified, but its activities are consistent with strategic intelligence collection objectives aligned with state interests.

Its operations are characterized by the use of key malware such as PlugX, Pirpi, and the Inception Framework, and its TTPs commonly involve spear-phishing, strategic web compromises, and vulnerability exploitation. 809.name: cyber activity
809.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may employ various user activity checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments. This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox. If the adversary detects a VME, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for VME artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Adversaries may use the information learned from [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors.(Citation: Deloitte Environment Awareness)

Adversaries may search for user activity on the host based on variables such as the speed/frequency of mouse movements and clicks (Citation: Sans Virtual Jan 2016) , browser history, cache, bookmarks, or number of files in common directories such as home or the desktop. Other methods may rely on specific user interaction with the system before the malicious code is activated, such as waiting for a document to close before activating a macro (Citation: Unit 42 Sofacy Nov 2018) or waiting for a user to double click on an embedded image to activate.(Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)
809.profile: [profile]User Activity Based Checks, identified as T1497.002 under the Defense Evasion tactic, operates on multiple platforms. This technique involves malware checking for indicators of a virtual machine or sandbox, such as specific artifacts, and altering its behavior to evade detection or disengage. It also includes monitoring for human presence through metrics like mouse movement speed, click frequency, browser history, or file counts in common directories, and may delay malicious actions until specific user interactions, like closing a document or double-clicking an image, occur. Groups like FIN7 and DarkHotel have been associated with its use.
809.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "cyber activity" is a generic term not corresponding to a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved information, it is associated with various distinct techniques. These include User Activity Based Checks (T1497.002) under the Discovery tactic, which involves detecting user interactions like mouse movements to evade analysis. It is also linked to Right-to-Left Override (T1036.002) for masquerading, Custom Command and Control Protocol (T1094) for communication, and External Defacement (T1491.002) for Impact. The technical mechanics involve specific behaviors like checking for virtual machine artifacts, using the Unicode RLO character to disguise filenames, employing non-standard C2 protocols, and modifying external websites to deliver messages.

811.name: malicious technology
811.profile: [profile]The entity 'malicious technology' is associated with the intrusion set Boyusec. It is referenced in the context of other malicious tools, including the Gustuff malware and the Sunburst backdoor, which is linked to APT29 (UNC2452). It is also mentioned in relation to the Darkside ransomware, which was deployed against corporate IT networks. This suggests the entity is a broad term or component used within cyber operations for malicious purposes, potentially encompassing tools or techniques deployed by these groups.[/profile]
811.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware known as 'malicious technology' is a threat actor tool. It is associated with groups such as APT 29 and UNC2452, as indicated by its contextual link to the Sunburst campaign, which uses domain monitoring for malicious activity detection. This malware targets information technology (IT) networks, as evidenced by its operational similarity to ransomware like DarkSide that compromises corporate IT infrastructure. Its key behavior involves conducting malicious cyber operations within enterprise environments.

812.name: boyusec
812.uncertain_mes: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) is a China-based threat group that researchers have attributed to China's Ministry of State Security.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: Recorded Future APT3 May 2017) This group is responsible for the campaigns known as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap.(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Wolf)(Citation: FireEye Operation Double Tap) As of June 2015, the group appears to have shifted from targeting primarily US victims to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong.(Citation: Symantec Buckeye)
812.profile: [profile]APT3, also known as Boyusec, Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, and TG-0110, is a China-based threat group attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS). Its key malware includes a modified Gh0st backdoor and Deed RAT. The group is responsible for campaigns such as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap. Historically targeting US victims, it shifted focus around 2015 to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong, indicating a motivation aligned with state-sponsored espionage and intelligence gathering.
812.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-sponsored group APT3, also known as Buckeye, Gothic Panda, UPS, Bronze Mayfair, Brocade Typhoon, TG-0110, Red Sylvan, Boron, and Boyusec. Its key malware includes the PlugX remote access trojan and the custom Pirpi backdoor. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing and exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities like CVE-2014-4113. The group is strongly attributed to China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) and is operationally linked to the Guangzhou Boyu Information Technology Company (Boyusec). It primarily targets government, defense, aerospace, technology, and manufacturing sectors in the United States, Europe, and Asia, with motivations focused on state-sponsored espionage and intellectual property theft.

The group's operations are attributed to China and primarily target sectors like technology, government, and defense in the United States and other Western nations, with motivations centered on espionage and intellectual property theft.
