813.name: China's Ministry of State Security (MSS)
813.uncertain_mes: [Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) is a group that has been active since at least 2010 and believed to be operating out of Iran. By 2014 [Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) transitioned from website defacement operations to malware-based cyber espionage campaigns targeting the US defense industrial base and Iranian users of anti-censorship technologies.(Citation: FireEye Operation Saffron Rose 2013)
813.profile: [profile]China's Ministry of State Security (MSS) is a state-sponsored cyber actor, also known as Ajax Security Team, UNC5174 (Uteus), and DragonBridge (Spamouflage Dragon). Its arsenal includes tools associated with the Boyusec group. Key TTPs involve malware-based cyber espionage campaigns, access operations, and the use of hacktivist contractors. The group is attributed to China and is believed to conduct intelligence collection. Its primary targets include the U.S. defense industrial base, Iranian anti-censorship technology users, and entities related to European political processes, with motivations centered on espionage and influence operations.

These groups primarily conduct state-sponsored espionage, targeting government, defense, aerospace, and technology sectors globally, with operations involving spear-phishing, web compromises, and access brokering.

817.name: SolarWinds compromise
817.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise third-party infrastructure that can be used during targeting. Infrastructure solutions include physical or cloud servers, domains, network devices, and third-party web and DNS services. Instead of buying, leasing, or renting infrastructure an adversary may compromise infrastructure and use it during other phases of the adversary lifecycle.(Citation: Mandiant APT1)(Citation: ICANNDomainNameHijacking)(Citation: Talos DNSpionage Nov 2018)(Citation: FireEye EPS Awakens Part 2) Additionally, adversaries may compromise numerous machines to form a botnet they can leverage.

Use of compromised infrastructure allows adversaries to stage, launch, and execute operations. Compromised infrastructure can help adversary operations blend in with traffic that is seen as normal, such as contact with high reputation or trusted sites. For example, adversaries may leverage compromised infrastructure (potentially also in conjunction with [Digital Certificates](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588/004)) to further blend in and support staged information gathering and/or [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) campaigns.(Citation: FireEye DNS Hijack 2019) Adversaries may also compromise numerous machines to support [Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090) and/or proxyware services or to form a botnet.(Citation: amnesty_nso_pegasus)(Citation: Sysdig Proxyjacking) Additionally, adversaries may compromise infrastructure residing in close proximity to a target in order to gain [Initial Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0001) via [Wi-Fi Networks](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1669).(Citation: Nearest Neighbor Volexity)

By using compromised infrastructure, adversaries may enable follow-on malicious operations. Prior to targeting, adversaries may also compromise the infrastructure of other adversaries.(Citation: NSA NCSC Turla OilRig)
817.profile: [profile]The entity "SolarWinds compromise" is an instance of the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1584, Compromise Infrastructure, under the Resource Development tactic. It involves adversaries taking over third-party infrastructure like servers, domains, or network devices to stage and launch operations, enabling them to blend malicious traffic with normal activity. In the specific SolarWinds campaign, this technique was executed by compromising the software build system of the SolarWinds Orion platform to distribute a malicious update, constituting a supply chain attack (T1195) that provided initial access to victim networks. The intrusion-set Russiaâ€™s Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) has been associated with this activity.[/profile]
817.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SolarWinds compromise is a supply chain attack technique (T1195) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting Windows and other platforms. It involves adversaries manipulating a software update mechanism, specifically by injecting malicious code into the legitimate SolarWinds Orion software build process, which is then distributed to victims through a trusted update channel. This technique enabled the creation of forged SAML tokens (T1606.002) to bypass authentication, as observed in the related campaign.

821.name: Cyber intrusions
821.profile: [profile]Cyber intrusions is a broad, non-specific term not directly mapped to a single MITRE ATT&CK technique ID. It generally describes unauthorized access to computer systems or networks. The provided neighbor info links this activity to Russiaâ€™s Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Retrieved information describes related but distinct techniques, including external defacement (T1491.002) for delivering messages or propaganda, hardware supply chain compromise (T1195.003) for inserting backdoors, and the abuse of compromised web services (T1584.006) for command and control or exfiltration.
821.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Cyber intrusions is a broad, non-specific attack pattern not formally mapped to a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique ID or Tactic. The retrieved information describes distinct, specific techniques: External Defacement (T1491.002) involves defacing external websites to spread disinformation or as a precursor to other attacks like drive-by compromises, as used by groups like Sandworm Team. Compromise Hardware Supply Chain (T1195.003) entails inserting backdoors into physical devices during manufacturing. Web Services (T1584.006) refers to adversaries compromising third-party services like GitHub or Google to use them for command and control or exfiltration, a tactic employed by groups including Turla.

824.name: Election interference
824.profile: [profile]The entity 'Election interference' is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique but a broader adversarial goal. The retrieved information describes related technical techniques for data manipulation, specifically MITRE ATT&CK techniques Data Manipulation (T1565) and its sub-techniques Stored Data Manipulation (T1565.001) and Transmitted Data Manipulation (T1565.002). These techniques fall under the Impact tactic and involve adversaries inserting, deleting, or altering data to influence outcomes, such as business processes or decision-making, which can be applied to election systems. The neighbor info suggests the Russiaâ€™s Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) is an intrusion set potentially associated with such activities.[/profile]

Based on retrieved context, it can involve the manipulation of data to influence outcomes and decision-making. Related technical mechanics from the ATT&CK framework include Data Manipulation (T1565) and its sub-techniques, Stored Data Manipulation (T1565.001) and Transmitted Data Manipulation (T1565.002), which involve inserting, deleting, or altering data at rest or in transit to disrupt processes. These actions threaten data integrity and require potential specialized access or prolonged reconnaissance to execute effectively against complex systems like those involved in electoral processes.

Groups such as Turla, Volt Typhoon, and Earth Lusca use these methods to host command and control or support operations like phishing and drive-by compromises, leveraging the trust and ubiquity of legitimate cloud services.

828.name: SVR
828.profile: [profile]SVR, also known as APT29, Cozy Bear, and The Dukes, is a cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its operations, active since at least 2008, are characterized by stealthy network intrusion tradecraft and the use of novel, custom tooling. The group primarily targets critical infrastructure organizations globally, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and geopolitical espionage.

Its key malware and tools include custom implants like SUNSPOT, SUNBURST, GoldMax, WellMess, and WellMail, alongside frameworks such as Cobalt Strike and Sliver. Key TTPs involve sophisticated software supply chain compromises (notably the SolarWinds campaign), credential access via unsecured private keys (T1552.004), and the use of trusted relationships, web shells, and DNS tunneling for command and control. The group is attributed to Russiaâ€™s Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and primarily targets government, diplomatic, defense, healthcare, and think-tank sectors in NATO member states, the US, and Europe for strategic espionage and intelligence collection.

829.name: KGBâ€™s First Chief Directorate
829.profile: [profile]The entity is primarily known as the KGBâ€™s First Chief Directorate, the historical foreign intelligence directorate of the Soviet KGB. Its direct successor in the knowledge graph is the SVR (Foreign Intelligence Service). Based on related content, the group is believed to be linked to the FSB, another successor agency, which has conducted cyber operations targeting the energy sector in the UK and U.S., as well as aviation, government, military, private organizations, and journalists. Its motivation is assessed as state-sponsored espionage and intelligence gathering aligned with Russian strategic interests.[/profile]

837.name: Exploitation
837.profile: [profile]The entity "Exploitation" is a foundational concept in cyber attacks, referring to the act of taking advantage of software vulnerabilities to execute adversary-controlled code. This core technique underpins numerous specific MITRE ATT&CK techniques across multiple tactics. It involves exploiting programming errors in applications, services, or operating systems to achieve objectives such as initial execution (e.g., T1203), privilege escalation (T1068), credential access (T1212), lateral movement via remote services (T1210), or denial of service (T1499.004). Adversaries, including groups like SVR, develop (T1587.004) or acquire (T1588.005) exploits to target these vulnerabilities on various platforms.[/profile]
837.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Exploitation" is a broad, non-standard attack pattern not directly mapped to a single MITRE ATT&CK ID. It fundamentally involves taking advantage of a programming error in software, a service, or an operating system to execute adversary-controlled code. This core mechanic is used across numerous specific techniques for various tactical purposes, including gaining initial access, escalating privileges, moving laterally, accessing credentials, or causing denial-of-service. Exploits can target client applications like browsers and office suites, remote services such as SMB and RDP, or operating system components, and they can be developed in-house or acquired from third parties.

838.name: Compromise
838.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise third-party infrastructure that can be used during targeting. Infrastructure solutions include physical or cloud servers, domains, network devices, and third-party web and DNS services. Instead of buying, leasing, or renting infrastructure an adversary may compromise infrastructure and use it during other phases of the adversary lifecycle.(Citation: Mandiant APT1)(Citation: ICANNDomainNameHijacking)(Citation: Talos DNSpionage Nov 2018)(Citation: FireEye EPS Awakens Part 2) Additionally, adversaries may compromise numerous machines to form a botnet they can leverage.

Use of compromised infrastructure allows adversaries to stage, launch, and execute operations. Compromised infrastructure can help adversary operations blend in with traffic that is seen as normal, such as contact with high reputation or trusted sites. For example, adversaries may leverage compromised infrastructure (potentially also in conjunction with [Digital Certificates](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588/004)) to further blend in and support staged information gathering and/or [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) campaigns.(Citation: FireEye DNS Hijack 2019) Adversaries may also compromise numerous machines to support [Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090) and/or proxyware services or to form a botnet.(Citation: amnesty_nso_pegasus)(Citation: Sysdig Proxyjacking) Additionally, adversaries may compromise infrastructure residing in close proximity to a target in order to gain [Initial Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0001) via [Wi-Fi Networks](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1669).(Citation: Nearest Neighbor Volexity)

By using compromised infrastructure, adversaries may enable follow-on malicious operations. Prior to targeting, adversaries may also compromise the infrastructure of other adversaries.(Citation: NSA NCSC Turla OilRig)
838.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Compromise Infrastructure" (T1584), categorized under Resource Development. It involves adversaries taking over third-party infrastructure like physical or cloud servers, domains, and network devices instead of acquiring them legitimately. This compromised infrastructure is used to stage, launch, and blend operations with normal traffic, such as supporting phishing campaigns or forming botnets for proxy services. The intrusion-set SVR is associated with this technique.
838.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Compromise" is a broad, non-specific attack pattern not directly mapped to a single MITRE ATT&CK ID. Based on the retrieved context, it generally refers to the adversarial act of gaining unauthorized access or control over a target, such as infrastructure, accounts, or software/hardware supply chains. Technical mechanics vary by specific technique but commonly involve exploiting vulnerabilities, injecting malicious code, or manipulating trusted systems and distribution channels to establish a foothold for further malicious operations.

839.name: Targeting
839.profile: [profile]Targeting is a preparatory tactic (TA0043) where adversaries gather information and select victims. It involves techniques like compromising third-party infrastructure such as Virtual Private Servers (T1584.003) to host malicious content, network devices (T1584.008) to harvest credentials or enable attacks like phishing, and software supply chains (T1195.002) to distribute tainted applications to specific victim sets. Groups like SVR, Volt Typhoon, and APT41 use these methods to enable subsequent intrusion stages.[/profile]
839.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Targeting" is a preparatory tactic within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, encompassing techniques for identifying and selecting victims. It involves gathering intelligence on individuals, organizations, or systems to inform subsequent attack stages. Specific methods include compromising third-party infrastructure like Virtual Private Servers (VPS) or network devices to use as operational platforms, as observed with groups like Turla and Volt Typhoon, and manipulating software supply chains to broadly distribute tainted applications for later selective exploitation, a technique used by groups including APT41 and Sandworm Team.

840.name: APT29
840.uncertain_mes:
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR).(Citation: White House Imposing Costs RU Gov April 2021)(Citation: UK Gov Malign RIS Activity April 2021) They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: UK Gov UK Exposes Russia SolarWinds April 2021)

In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) to the SVR; public statements included citations to [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016), Cozy Bear, and The Dukes.(Citation: NSA Joint Advisory SVR SolarWinds April 2021)(Citation: UK NSCS Russia SolarWinds April 2021) Industry reporting also referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm.(Citation: FireEye SUNBURST Backdoor December 2020)(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike SUNSPOT Implant January 2021)(Citation: Volexity SolarWinds)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory SVR TTP May 2021)(Citation: Unit 42 SolarStorm December 2020)
840.profile: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a Russian state-sponsored threat group attributed to the SVR (Foreign Intelligence Service). Its arsenal includes custom malware like the SUNBURST backdoor and the SUNSPOT implant, and it has used tools such as AdFind for network reconnaissance. Key TTPs include spearphishing with malicious attachments and the abuse of privileged accounts to replicate directory service data. The group primarily targets government networks in Europe and NATO countries, research institutes, and think tanks, with notable campaigns including the 2015 Democratic National Committee breach and the 2020 SolarWinds compromise, driven by espionage and intelligence-gathering objectives.

Notable TTPs involve sophisticated software supply chain attacks (e.g., the SolarWinds compromise), credential access via private keys, and stealthy command and control using Mutual-TLS and DNS. The group originates from Russia and primarily targets government, diplomatic, energy, technology, healthcare, and research sectors in NATO member states, the US, UK, and Europe, with motivations centered on strategic espionage and intelligence collection for Russian state interests.

841.name: The Dukes
841.uncertain_mes:
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR).(Citation: White House Imposing Costs RU Gov April 2021)(Citation: UK Gov Malign RIS Activity April 2021) They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: UK Gov UK Exposes Russia SolarWinds April 2021)

In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) to the SVR; public statements included citations to [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016), Cozy Bear, and The Dukes.(Citation: NSA Joint Advisory SVR SolarWinds April 2021)(Citation: UK NSCS Russia SolarWinds April 2021) Industry reporting also referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm.(Citation: FireEye SUNBURST Backdoor December 2020)(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike SUNSPOT Implant January 2021)(Citation: Volexity SolarWinds)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory SVR TTP May 2021)(Citation: Unit 42 SolarStorm December 2020)
841.profile: [profile]The Dukes, also known as APT29, Cozy Bear, Midnight Blizzard, Nobelium, and UNC2452, is a Russian cyber espionage group attributed to the SVR (Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service). Its arsenal includes custom malware like SUNBURST (used in the SolarWinds compromise) and tools such as PteroLNK. The group is known for sophisticated spearphishing campaigns and supply chain attacks. It primarily targets government networks in Europe and NATO countries, research institutes, and think tanks, with motivations centered on long-term intelligence gathering and political espionage, as evidenced by operations like the compromise of the Democratic National Committee.

845.name: Intelligence Collection
845.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may obtain access to generative artificial intelligence tools, such as large language models (LLMs), to aid various techniques during targeting. These tools may be used to inform, bolster, and enable a variety of malicious tasks, including conducting [Reconnaissance](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0043), creating basic scripts, assisting social engineering, and even developing payloads.(Citation: MSFT-AI) 

For example, by utilizing a publicly available LLM an adversary is essentially outsourcing or automating certain tasks to the tool. Using AI, the adversary may draft and generate content in a variety of written languages to be used in [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566)/[Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) campaigns. The same publicly available tool may further enable vulnerability or other offensive research supporting [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587). AI tools may also automate technical tasks by generating, refining, or otherwise enhancing (e.g., [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027)) malicious scripts and payloads.(Citation: OpenAI-CTI) Finally, AI-generated text, images, audio, and video may be used for fraud, [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656), and other malicious activities.(Citation: Google-Vishing24)(Citation: IC3-AI24)(Citation: WSJ-Vishing-AI24)
845.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Artificial Intelligence" (ID: T1588.007) under the Resource Development tactic. Adversaries obtain and use generative AI tools, such as large language models (LLMs), to automate and enhance malicious tasks. This includes drafting phishing content in multiple languages, generating or obfuscating malicious scripts and payloads, conducting vulnerability research, and creating synthetic media for impersonation and fraud. The intrusion set SVR has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
845.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Intelligence Collection is a pre-attack technique where adversaries gather information about targets to inform and enable future operations. It aligns with the Reconnaissance tactic (TA0043) and spans multiple platforms. This broad technique encompasses methods like searching threat intelligence vendor data (T1597.001) to discover successful TTPs and target industries, and adversaries may specifically search for reports on their own campaigns (T1681) to adapt and evade detection. Collection can be automated (T1119) using scripts or cloud APIs to systematically find and copy data based on set criteria.

847.name: StellarParticle
847.uncertain_mes:
Explore all the articles at the push of a button
View all articles
The next evolution of cyberespionage is here.
Unit 42 has just identified Phantom Taurus, a highly sophisticated Chinese nexus APT that uses custom, evasive malware to bypass traditional defenses and break high-value targets.
847.profile: [profile]StellarParticle, also known as UNC2452, is an intrusion set attributed to the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and is the activity cluster associated with the group commonly tracked as COZY BEAR (APT29). Its key malware includes the custom SUNSPOT monitoring tool, used to hijack software build processes like that of the SolarWinds Orion platform. The group primarily targets government and technology sectors in the United States and Europe, with motivations centered on cyberespionage and intelligence collection.
847.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most widely standardized as APT29 (Cozy Bear), also known as UNC2452, Nobelium, The Dukes, and StellarParticle. Its key custom malware includes SUNSPOT, SUNBURST, GoldMax (Windows and Linux variants), TrailBlazer, and TEARDROP. Notable TTPs involve sophisticated software supply chain attacks (e.g., the SolarWinds compromise), credential hopping and lateral movement via techniques like WMI persistence, and extensive post-exploitation in cloud and Active Directory environments using tools like DSInternals10. The group is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and primarily targets government, diplomatic, technology, and think-tank sectors in North America and Europe for strategic intelligence gathering.[/profile]
847.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set known as StellarParticle, also tracked by CrowdStrike, is believed to be linked to the financially motivated threat actor Evilnum (also known as DeathStalker, Knockout Spider, and TA4563). Its key operational distinction is the use of the custom backdoor and monitoring tool SUNSPOT, which was deployed to hijack software build processes, specifically targeting the Orion software. This activity indicates a focus on supply chain compromise, with motivations likely centered on espionage and financial gain, though specific target sectors and definitive origin attribution remain unclear from the provided data.
847.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]StellarParticle, also known as the StellarParticle activity cluster tracked by CrowdStrike, is an intrusion set responsible for the sophisticated SUNRISE/SUNSPOT supply chain attack against the SolarWinds Orion software. The group's key malware includes the SUNSPOT monitoring tool, which was used to hijack the software build process and implant a backdoor. Its primary TTP involves compromising the software development and build environment to conduct a widespread supply chain compromise. The group is strongly attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically the Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR), and is believed to overlap with or be synonymous with the groups tracked as APT29, Cozy Bear, and The Dukes. Its operations primarily target government and technology sectors in the United States and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.
847.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The intrusion set StellarParticle is most widely standardized as APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Nobelium, and UNC2452. Its key custom malware includes SUNSPOT, used to inject the SUNBURST backdoor into the SolarWinds Orion software, as well as GoldMax (Windows and Linux variants), TrailBlazer, and TEARDROP. Notable TTPs involve sophisticated supply chain attacks, credential hopping for lateral movement, and the abuse of cloud administration techniques like Office 365 Service Principal hijacking. The group is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and primarily targets government, diplomatic, technology, and think-tank sectors in North America and Europe for strategic intelligence gathering.[/profile]
847.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most widely standardized as APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, UNC2452, Nobelium, and The Dukes. Its key custom malware includes SUNSPOT, used to inject the SUNBURST backdoor via the SolarWinds supply chain, as well as GoldMax (Windows and Linux variants), TEARDROP, and TrailBlazer. Notable TTPs involve sophisticated software supply chain attacks, credential theft using tools like DSInternals10 for DCSync, lateral movement via SMB and cloud administration abuse, and persistence through WMI. The group is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and primarily targets government, diplomatic, technology, and think-tank sectors in North America and Europe for strategic intelligence gathering.[/profile]

Its key malware includes the custom SUNSPOT implant used to inject the SUNBURST backdoor in the SolarWinds supply chain attack, alongside GoldMax, TrailBlazer, and TEARDROP. Notable TTPs involve sophisticated software supply chain compromise, credential theft using tools like DSInternals10 for DCSync attacks, and command and control traffic masquerading. The group is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and primarily targets government, diplomatic, technology, and think-tank sectors in North America and Europe for strategic intelligence gathering.[/profile]

848.name: GoldMax (Linux variant)
848.uncertain_mes: [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go with Windows and Linux variants that are nearly identical in functionality. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) was discovered in early 2021 during the investigation into the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), and has likely been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least mid-2019. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) uses multiple defense evasion techniques, including avoiding virtualization execution and masking malicious traffic.(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: FireEye SUNSHUTTLE Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike StellarParticle January 2022)
848.profile: [profile]GoldMax, also known as GoldMax (Linux variant) and GoldMax (Windows variant), is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go. It is attributed to APT29 (also referenced as UNC2452 and StellarParticle). Key technical behaviors include using multiple defense evasion techniques such as avoiding virtualization execution and masking malicious traffic. It targets both Windows and Linux platforms, with the Linux variant identified as being deployed as early as mid-2019. The malware was notably used in the SolarWinds compromise campaign.[/profile]
848.profile_without_enhance: [profile]GoldMax (Linux variant) is a malware family attributed to the intrusion set StellarParticle and the group UNC2452. It operates as a backdoor and was deployed as early as mid-2019, predating its Windows variant. This malware targets both Windows and Linux platforms for system compromise.[/profile]

849.name: TrailBlazer
849.uncertain_mes: [TrailBlazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0682) is a modular malware that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2019.(Citation: CrowdStrike StellarParticle January 2022)
849.profile: [profile]TrailBlazer, also known as trailblazer, is a modular malware used by APT29 since at least 2019, as part of the StellarParticle campaign. It establishes persistence via WMI Event Subscription, executing when system uptime is between 180 and 480 seconds, and attempts to blend in by using a filename matching the system name. It targets Linux systems.[/profile]
849.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TrailBlazer is a modular malware used by APT29 (also known as UNC2452) since at least 2019. It establishes persistence via Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) Event Subscription, executing when system uptime is between 180 and 480 seconds, and attempts to blend in by using a filename that matches the system name. It has been deployed alongside a Linux variant of the GoldMax malware.

850.name: supply chain attack
850.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise.

Supply chain compromise can take place at any stage of the supply chain including:

* Manipulation of development tools
* Manipulation of a development environment
* Manipulation of source code repositories (public or private)
* Manipulation of source code in open-source dependencies
* Manipulation of software update/distribution mechanisms
* Compromised/infected system images (removable media infected at the factory)(Citation: IBM Storwize)(Citation: Schneider Electric USB Malware) 
* Replacement of legitimate software with modified versions
* Sales of modified/counterfeit products to legitimate distributors
* Shipment interdiction

While supply chain compromise can impact any component of hardware or software, adversaries looking to gain execution have often focused on malicious additions to legitimate software in software distribution or update channels.(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Adversaries may limit targeting to a desired victim set or distribute malicious software to a broad set of consumers but only follow up with specific victims.(Citation: Symantec Elderwood Sept 2012)(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Popular open-source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications may also be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency.(Citation: Trendmicro NPM Compromise)

In some cases, adversaries may conduct â€œsecond-orderâ€ supply chain compromises by leveraging the access gained from an initial supply chain compromise to further compromise a software component.(Citation: Krebs 3cx overview 2023) This may allow the threat actor to spread to even more victims.
850.profile: [profile]Supply Chain Compromise, identified as T1195, is an Initial Access tactic applicable across platforms. It involves adversaries manipulating products or delivery mechanisms before consumer receipt to compromise data or systems. This can occur through various methods including tampering with development tools, source code repositories, open-source dependencies, software update channels, or system images. Attackers may broadly distribute tainted software but selectively activate payloads against specific targets, and can also conduct "second-order" compromises by leveraging initial access to further infiltrate the supply chain. Associated groups include Sandworm Team, Ember Bear, and OilRig.
850.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Supply Chain Attack is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, identified as T1195, under the Initial Access tactic and applicable to multiple platforms. It involves compromising products or their delivery mechanisms before they reach the end user to enable data or system compromise. Specific methods include manipulating development tools, source code repositories, open-source dependencies, software update channels, or hardware components to insert malicious code, such as through infected system images or counterfeit products. This allows adversaries to gain execution and potentially conduct second-order compromises to spread further.

851.name: browser cookie theft
851.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may steal monetary resources from targets through extortion, social engineering, technical theft, or other methods aimed at their own financial gain at the expense of the availability of these resources for victims. Financial theft is the ultimate objective of several popular campaign types including extortion by ransomware,(Citation: FBI-ransomware) business email compromise (BEC) and fraud,(Citation: FBI-BEC) "pig butchering,"(Citation: wired-pig butchering) bank hacking,(Citation: DOJ-DPRK Heist) and exploiting cryptocurrency networks.(Citation: BBC-Ronin) 

Adversaries may [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586) to conduct unauthorized transfers of funds.(Citation: Internet crime report 2022) In the case of business email compromise or email fraud, an adversary may utilize [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656) of a trusted entity. Once the social engineering is successful, victims can be deceived into sending money to financial accounts controlled by an adversary.(Citation: FBI-BEC) This creates the potential for multiple victims (i.e., compromised accounts as well as the ultimate monetary loss) in incidents involving financial theft.(Citation: VEC)

Extortion by ransomware may occur, for example, when an adversary demands payment from a victim after [Data Encrypted for Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486) (Citation: NYT-Colonial) and [Exfiltration](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0010) of data, followed by threatening to leak sensitive data to the public unless payment is made to the adversary.(Citation: Mandiant-leaks) Adversaries may use dedicated leak sites to distribute victim data.(Citation: Crowdstrike-leaks)

Due to the potentially immense business impact of financial theft, an adversary may abuse the possibility of financial theft and seeking monetary gain to divert attention from their true goals such as [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) and business disruption.(Citation: AP-NotPetya)
851.profile: [profile]The entity "browser cookie theft" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is a specific method of credential access and initial access, likely aligning with the technique "Steal Web Session Cookie" (T1539). It operates by extracting authentication cookies from a victim's browser disk or memory, often via malicious browser extensions or injected JavaScript. These stolen cookies can then be imported into an adversary-controlled browser to hijack authenticated web sessions, bypassing multi-factor authentication to access sensitive information or perform actions as the user. Associated groups include Kimsuky, Star Blizzard, and Scattered Spider.
851.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Browser Cookie Theft is a technique aligned with MITRE ATT&CK ID T1539 (Steal Web Session Cookie) under the Credential Access tactic, primarily targeting web platforms. It involves stealing authentication cookies from disk, browser process memory, or network traffic to bypass multi-factor authentication. Methods include using malware to harvest local browser cookies, injecting malicious JavaScript to capture them via user execution, or deploying adversary-in-the-middle proxies like Evilginx2 in phishing campaigns to intercept session tokens.

853.name: Microsoft Service Principal manipulation
853.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain and/or elevate access to victim systems. Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves or modifies adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups.(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021) These actions could also include account activity designed to subvert security policies, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass password duration policies and preserve the life of compromised credentials. 

In order to create or manipulate accounts, the adversary must already have sufficient permissions on systems or the domain. However, account manipulation may also lead to privilege escalation where modifications grant access to additional roles, permissions, or higher-privileged [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).
853.profile: [profile]Microsoft Service Principal manipulation is a cloud-specific technique under the broader T1098 Account Manipulation tactic of Persistence and Privilege Escalation, primarily targeting Azure/Entra ID platforms. It involves adversaries with sufficient permissions, such as an Application Administrator role, adding new adversary-controlled credentials (like x509 keys or passwords) to a service principal. This action grants persistent access to the service principal's potentially elevated roles and permissions, which may differ from the attacker's original account, enabling continued access even if initial credentials are revoked. The intrusion-set StellarParticle has been associated with this activity.
853.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Microsoft Service Principal manipulation is a technique likely aligned with MITRE ATT&CK sub-technique T1098.001 (Account Manipulation: Additional Cloud Credentials) under the Persistence tactic, targeting cloud platforms like Azure/Entra ID. It involves adversaries with sufficient permissions, such as Application Administrator, adding adversary-controlled credentials (e.g., x509 keys or passwords) to a service principal. This grants persistent access to the service principal's roles and permissions, potentially enabling privilege escalation if those permissions differ from the attacker's original account. The manipulation can be performed via the Azure Portal, command-line interface, or PowerShell modules.

854.name: Credential hopping
854.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use credentials obtained from breach dumps of unrelated accounts to gain access to target accounts through credential overlap. Occasionally, large numbers of username and password pairs are dumped online when a website or service is compromised and the user account credentials accessed. The information may be useful to an adversary attempting to compromise accounts by taking advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Credential stuffing is a risky option because it could cause numerous authentication failures and account lockouts, depending on the organization's login failure policies.

Typically, management services over commonly used ports are used when stuffing credentials. Commonly targeted services include the following:

* SSH (22/TCP)
* Telnet (23/TCP)
* FTP (21/TCP)
* NetBIOS / SMB / Samba (139/TCP & 445/TCP)
* LDAP (389/TCP)
* Kerberos (88/TCP)
* RDP / Terminal Services (3389/TCP)
* HTTP/HTTP Management Services (80/TCP & 443/TCP)
* MSSQL (1433/TCP)
* Oracle (1521/TCP)
* MySQL (3306/TCP)
* VNC (5900/TCP)

In addition to management services, adversaries may "target single sign-on (SSO) and cloud-based applications utilizing federated authentication protocols," as well as externally facing email applications, such as Office 365.(Citation: US-CERT TA18-068A 2018)
854.profile: [profile]Credential Hopping, also known as Credential Stuffing (MITRE ID T1110.004), is a Credential Access technique where adversaries use username/password pairs from unrelated breach dumps to access target accounts by exploiting password reuse across services. It typically targets management services on common ports like SSH (22/TCP), RDP (3389/TCP), and HTTP/S (80/443), as well as cloud applications and SSO systems, but carries the risk of triggering account lockouts due to authentication failures. The intrusion set StellarParticle has been associated with this activity.[/profile]
854.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credential hopping is a technique for lateral movement where adversaries use captured credentials from one compromised account to authenticate to other systems or services within the same network environment. This method exploits password reuse across accounts and systems, allowing attackers to pivot without deploying additional malware. It is closely associated with credential access techniques like OS Credential Dumping (T1003) and the use of Local Accounts (T1078.003), enabling persistent access and privilege escalation across a network.

855.name: Office 365 (O365) Service Principal and Application hijacking
855.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may leverage Microsoft Office-based applications for persistence between startups. Microsoft Office is a fairly common application suite on Windows-based operating systems within an enterprise network. There are multiple mechanisms that can be used with Office for persistence when an Office-based application is started; this can include the use of Office Template Macros and add-ins.

A variety of features have been discovered in Outlook that can be abused to obtain persistence, such as Outlook rules, forms, and Home Page.(Citation: SensePost Ruler GitHub) These persistence mechanisms can work within Outlook or be used through Office 365.(Citation: TechNet O365 Outlook Rules)
855.profile: [profile]Office 365 Service Principal and Application Hijacking is a persistence technique (aligned with T1137 sub-techniques) within the Initial Access and Persistence tactics on Windows and Office 365 platforms. It involves adversaries compromising or creating malicious OAuth-integrated applications and their associated service principals in cloud environments like Microsoft Entra ID. By granting these applications high-privileged permissions, attackers maintain persistent access to victim data and resources, potentially bypassing multi-factor authentication using application access tokens, even if the original user account is disabled. The intrusion set StellarParticle has been associated with this method.
855.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Office 365 (O365) Service Principal and Application hijacking is a technique where adversaries compromise or create malicious OAuth-integrated applications and their associated service principals within cloud environments like Microsoft Entra ID to maintain persistence. This allows them to retain access to data and resources even after losing the original compromised user account, often bypassing multi-factor authentication by using application access tokens and enabling automated data exfiltration.

856.name: stealing browser cookies
856.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may forge web cookies that can be used to gain access to web applications or Internet services. Web applications and services (hosted in cloud SaaS environments or on-premise servers) often use session cookies to authenticate and authorize user access.

Adversaries may generate these cookies in order to gain access to web resources. This differs from [Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539) and other similar behaviors in that the cookies are new and forged by the adversary, rather than stolen or intercepted from legitimate users. Most common web applications have standardized and documented cookie values that can be generated using provided tools or interfaces.(Citation: Pass The Cookie) The generation of web cookies often requires secret values, such as passwords, [Private Keys](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1552/004), or other cryptographic seed values.

Once forged, adversaries may use these web cookies to access resources ([Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/004)), which may bypass multi-factor and other authentication protection mechanisms.(Citation: Volexity SolarWinds)(Citation: Pass The Cookie)(Citation: Unit 42 Mac Crypto Cookies January 2019)
856.profile: [profile]Stealing Browser Cookies, also known as Web Cookies (T1606.001), is a Credential Access technique for Windows, Linux, and macOS. Adversaries forge new session cookies to gain unauthorized access to web applications, differing from stealing existing cookies. This process requires obtaining secret values like passwords or private keys to generate the cookie, often using standardized tools for common applications. Once forged, these cookies can be used to authenticate to services, potentially bypassing multi-factor authentication. The intrusion set StellarParticle has been associated with this behavior.
856.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Stealing Browser Cookies" aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1539: Steal Web Session Cookie under the Credential Access tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries stealing session cookies from disk, browser process memory, or network traffic to gain authenticated access to web applications without credentials, often bypassing multi-factor authentication. Cookies can be stolen via malware, malicious JavaScript injection, or adversary-in-the-middle proxies like Evilginx2. Once acquired, these cookies enable adversaries to impersonate the user and perform actions within the compromised session.

857.name: Credential theft using Get-ADReplAccount
857.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may steal monetary resources from targets through extortion, social engineering, technical theft, or other methods aimed at their own financial gain at the expense of the availability of these resources for victims. Financial theft is the ultimate objective of several popular campaign types including extortion by ransomware,(Citation: FBI-ransomware) business email compromise (BEC) and fraud,(Citation: FBI-BEC) "pig butchering,"(Citation: wired-pig butchering) bank hacking,(Citation: DOJ-DPRK Heist) and exploiting cryptocurrency networks.(Citation: BBC-Ronin) 

Adversaries may [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586) to conduct unauthorized transfers of funds.(Citation: Internet crime report 2022) In the case of business email compromise or email fraud, an adversary may utilize [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656) of a trusted entity. Once the social engineering is successful, victims can be deceived into sending money to financial accounts controlled by an adversary.(Citation: FBI-BEC) This creates the potential for multiple victims (i.e., compromised accounts as well as the ultimate monetary loss) in incidents involving financial theft.(Citation: VEC)

Extortion by ransomware may occur, for example, when an adversary demands payment from a victim after [Data Encrypted for Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486) (Citation: NYT-Colonial) and [Exfiltration](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0010) of data, followed by threatening to leak sensitive data to the public unless payment is made to the adversary.(Citation: Mandiant-leaks) Adversaries may use dedicated leak sites to distribute victim data.(Citation: Crowdstrike-leaks)

Due to the potentially immense business impact of financial theft, an adversary may abuse the possibility of financial theft and seeking monetary gain to divert attention from their true goals such as [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) and business disruption.(Citation: AP-NotPetya)
857.profile: [profile]Credential theft using Get-ADReplAccount is a technique for OS Credential Dumping, specifically targeting Active Directory. It involves using the PowerShell cmdlet Get-ADReplAccount to perform a DCSync attack, retrieving password hashes for domain accounts directly from a Domain Controller by replicating the NTDS.dit database without needing to run code on the DC itself. This method is used by groups like StellarParticle for privilege escalation and lateral movement within a network.[/profile]
857.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credential theft using Get-ADReplAccount is a sub-technique of OS Credential Dumping (T1003.003) under the Credential Access tactic, targeting Windows platforms. It involves using the PowerShell cmdlet Get-ADReplAccount to perform a DCSync attack, which simulates a domain controller replication request to retrieve password hashes for all domain accounts directly from the NTDS.dit database on a domain controller. This method allows adversaries to steal credentials without requiring direct file access or Volume Shadow Copy.

859.name: COZY BEAR
859.uncertain_mes:
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR).(Citation: White House Imposing Costs RU Gov April 2021)(Citation: UK Gov Malign RIS Activity April 2021) They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: UK Gov UK Exposes Russia SolarWinds April 2021)

In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) to the SVR; public statements included citations to [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016), Cozy Bear, and The Dukes.(Citation: NSA Joint Advisory SVR SolarWinds April 2021)(Citation: UK NSCS Russia SolarWinds April 2021) Industry reporting also referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm.(Citation: FireEye SUNBURST Backdoor December 2020)(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike SUNSPOT Implant January 2021)(Citation: Volexity SolarWinds)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory SVR TTP May 2021)(Citation: Unit 42 SolarStorm December 2020)
859.profile: [profile]COZY BEAR, also known as APT29, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its arsenal includes custom tools and malware associated with campaigns like SolarWinds, and its key TTPs involve high-level post-exploitation techniques such as authentication cookie theft for lateral movement in cloud environments. The group primarily targets government networks in Europe and NATO countries, research institutes, and think tanks, with motivations aligned with strategic intelligence collection for the Russian state.
859.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This intrusion set is most widely standardized as APT29 (Cozy Bear), also known as The Dukes, SVR, Nobelium, UNC2452, Outlaw Spider, and StellarParticle. Its key malware includes the custom SUNSPOT implant used to inject the SUNBURST backdoor into SolarWinds Orion software, alongside tools like GoldMax, TEARDROP, TrailBlazer, and DSInternals10. Key TTPs involve sophisticated software supply chain compromises, credential hopping, and enumeration of Active Directory and Office 365 environments, with persistence mechanisms like WMI. The group is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and primarily targets government, diplomatic, technology, and consulting sectors globally for strategic espionage. It shows overlaps with clusters tracked as Evilnum and Predatory Sparrow.[/profile]
859.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]COZY BEAR, also known as APT29, The Dukes, and UNC2452, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). The group is distinguished by its use of custom malware like WellMess and WellMail, and its advanced post-exploitation tradecraft, including authentication cookie theft for lateral movement in cloud environments. Its operations primarily target government, diplomatic, and think-tank sectors in North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.

It is distinguished by its use of custom malware like WellMess and WellMail, and its advanced post-exploitation techniques, including authentication cookie theft for lateral movement in cloud environments. The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, and think-tank sectors in Europe and North America for espionage and intelligence gathering, demonstrating a high level of operational security and technical proficiency.
