The group is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and primarily targets government, diplomatic, technology, and think-tank sectors in North America and Europe for strategic intelligence gathering.[/profile]

860.name: credential hopping
860.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use credentials obtained from breach dumps of unrelated accounts to gain access to target accounts through credential overlap. Occasionally, large numbers of username and password pairs are dumped online when a website or service is compromised and the user account credentials accessed. The information may be useful to an adversary attempting to compromise accounts by taking advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Credential stuffing is a risky option because it could cause numerous authentication failures and account lockouts, depending on the organization's login failure policies.

Typically, management services over commonly used ports are used when stuffing credentials. Commonly targeted services include the following:

* SSH (22/TCP)
* Telnet (23/TCP)
* FTP (21/TCP)
* NetBIOS / SMB / Samba (139/TCP & 445/TCP)
* LDAP (389/TCP)
* Kerberos (88/TCP)
* RDP / Terminal Services (3389/TCP)
* HTTP/HTTP Management Services (80/TCP & 443/TCP)
* MSSQL (1433/TCP)
* Oracle (1521/TCP)
* MySQL (3306/TCP)
* VNC (5900/TCP)

In addition to management services, adversaries may "target single sign-on (SSO) and cloud-based applications utilizing federated authentication protocols," as well as externally facing email applications, such as Office 365.(Citation: US-CERT TA18-068A 2018)
860.profile: [profile]Credential Stuffing, identified as T1110.004 under the Credential Access tactic, involves adversaries using credentials from unrelated breach dumps to access target accounts by exploiting password reuse across personal and business accounts. This technique targets a wide range of management services on common ports like SSH (22/TCP), Telnet (23/TCP), FTP (21/TCP), SMB (445/TCP), RDP (3389/TCP), and HTTP/S (80/443/TCP), as well as cloud applications and SSO systems. It is a high-risk method that can trigger authentication failures and account lockouts. The intrusion set StellarParticle is linked to this activity.[profile]
860.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credential Hopping is a technique where adversaries use stolen or compromised credentials from one account to gain unauthorized access to other accounts, often leveraging password reuse across systems. It is associated with the Credential Access tactic and primarily targets Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. The method involves systematically testing obtained credentials against various services and accounts to move laterally within a network, exploiting weak authentication practices and credential overlap.

861.name: Secure Shell (SSH)
861.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to log into remote machines using Secure Shell (SSH). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

SSH is a protocol that allows authorized users to open remote shells on other computers. Many Linux and macOS versions come with SSH installed by default, although typically disabled until the user enables it. On ESXi, SSH can be enabled either directly on the host (e.g., via `vim-cmd hostsvc/enable_ssh`) or via vCenter.(Citation: Sygnia ESXi Ransomware 2025)(Citation: TrendMicro ESXI Ransomware)(Citation: Sygnia Abyss Locker 2025) The SSH server can be configured to use standard password authentication or public-private keypairs in lieu of or in addition to a password. In this authentication scenario, the userâ€™s public key must be in a special file on the computer running the server that lists which keypairs are allowed to login as that user (i.e., [SSH Authorized Keys](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1098/004)).
861.profile: [profile]Secure Shell (SSH) is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1021.004 under the Lateral Movement tactic, applicable to Linux, macOS, and ESXi platforms. It involves adversaries using valid accounts to log into remote machines via the SSH protocol to open remote shells and perform actions. The SSH server can be enabled on ESXi hosts using commands like `vim-cmd hostsvc/enable_ssh` and supports authentication via passwords or public-private keypairs, where authorized keys are stored in a specific server file. This technique is distinct from SSH Hijacking (T1563.001), which involves seizing an existing session, and has been used by groups like StellarParticle, FIN7, and Lazarus Group.
861.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Secure Shell (SSH)" is a network protocol, not a MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is the underlying service for techniques like T1021.004 (Remote Services: SSH) and T1563.001 (SSH Hijacking). SSH provides encrypted remote shell access, typically on Linux, macOS, and ESXi systems, using password or public-key authentication. Adversaries exploit it for lateral movement by logging in with valid credentials or by hijacking active sessions through compromised SSH agents or sockets.

862.name: Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP)
862.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to log into a computer using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

Remote desktop is a common feature in operating systems. It allows a user to log into an interactive session with a system desktop graphical user interface on a remote system. Microsoft refers to its implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) as Remote Desktop Services (RDS).(Citation: TechNet Remote Desktop Services) 

Adversaries may connect to a remote system over RDP/RDS to expand access if the service is enabled and allows access to accounts with known credentials. Adversaries will likely use Credential Access techniques to acquire credentials to use with RDP. Adversaries may also use RDP in conjunction with the [Accessibility Features](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/008) or [Terminal Services DLL](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1505/005) for Persistence.(Citation: Alperovitch Malware)
862.profile: [profile]Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) is technique T1021.001 under the Lateral Movement tactic, primarily for Windows. It allows adversaries with valid credentials to establish an interactive graphical session on a remote system to expand access. Attackers often acquire credentials via Credential Access techniques and may use RDP in conjunction with persistence methods like Accessibility Features. The technique is widely used by groups like FIN7 and Volt Typhoon.
862.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) is formally identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1021.001, a sub-technique of Remote Services under the Lateral Movement tactic, primarily for Windows platforms. It is a legitimate Microsoft protocol for graphical remote access, which adversaries abuse by using valid credentials to log into remote systems, thereby performing actions as the authenticated user to expand their access within a network.

871.name: Admin agent
871.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may create or modify launch agents to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. When a user logs in, a per-user launchd process is started which loads the parameters for each launch-on-demand user agent from the property list (.plist) file found in /System/Library/LaunchAgents, /Library/LaunchAgents, and ~/Library/LaunchAgents.(Citation: AppleDocs Launch Agent Daemons)(Citation: OSX Keydnap malware) (Citation: Antiquated Mac Malware) Property list files use the Label, ProgramArguments , and RunAtLoad keys to identify the Launch Agent's name, executable location, and execution time.(Citation: OSX.Dok Malware) Launch Agents are often installed to perform updates to programs, launch user specified programs at login, or to conduct other developer tasks. Launch Agents can also be executed using the [Launchctl](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/001) command. Adversaries may install a new Launch Agent that executes at login by placing a .plist file into the appropriate folders with the RunAtLoad or KeepAlive keys set to true.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) The Launch Agent name may be disguised by using a name from the related operating system or benign software. Launch Agents are created with user level privileges and execute with user level permissions.(Citation: OSX Malware Detection)(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X)
871.profile: [profile]Launch Agent, identified as T1543.001 within the Persistence tactic for macOS, involves adversaries placing malicious property list (.plist) files into specific directories like ~/Library/LaunchAgents. These files use keys such as RunAtLoad or KeepAlive set to true to ensure the payload executes automatically upon user login, often with the agent name disguised as benign software. The technique can be managed via the launchctl command and is associated with the intrusion set StellarParticle.[/profile]
871.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Admin Agent is a persistence technique where adversaries abuse legitimate administrative agents or services, such as Microsoft Exchange transport agents or macOS launch agents, to maintain access. These agents are configured to execute malicious tasks, like copying email attachments for exfiltration or running payloads at user login, by registering malicious .NET assemblies or property list (.plist) files. The technique operates on platforms like Windows Server (Exchange) and macOS, aligning with the Persistence tactic.

875.name: Helpdesk agent
875.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may create or modify launch agents to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. When a user logs in, a per-user launchd process is started which loads the parameters for each launch-on-demand user agent from the property list (.plist) file found in /System/Library/LaunchAgents, /Library/LaunchAgents, and ~/Library/LaunchAgents.(Citation: AppleDocs Launch Agent Daemons)(Citation: OSX Keydnap malware) (Citation: Antiquated Mac Malware) Property list files use the Label, ProgramArguments , and RunAtLoad keys to identify the Launch Agent's name, executable location, and execution time.(Citation: OSX.Dok Malware) Launch Agents are often installed to perform updates to programs, launch user specified programs at login, or to conduct other developer tasks. Launch Agents can also be executed using the [Launchctl](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/001) command. Adversaries may install a new Launch Agent that executes at login by placing a .plist file into the appropriate folders with the RunAtLoad or KeepAlive keys set to true.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) The Launch Agent name may be disguised by using a name from the related operating system or benign software. Launch Agents are created with user level privileges and execute with user level permissions.(Citation: OSX Malware Detection)(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X)
875.profile: [profile]Launch Agent (T1543.001) is a persistence technique within the Execution tactic for macOS. Adversaries create or modify property list (.plist) files in specific LaunchAgents directories, using keys like RunAtLoad or KeepAlive set to true to execute malicious payloads automatically upon user login. The agent name can be disguised as legitimate software and is executed via launchctl or by placing the file, running with user-level privileges. The intrusion-set StellarParticle has been associated with this method.
875.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Helpdesk agent is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it may refer to an adversary's abuse of legitimate remote desktop support software (like VNC, TeamViewer, AnyDesk, or LogMeIn) to establish a command and control channel. This activity is associated with the Remote Access Software technique (T1219.002) under the Command and Control tactic, primarily targeting Windows and macOS platforms. Adversaries use these tools for persistence and interactive control, often because they are whitelisted as legitimate support software within an environment.

876.name: Delegated Administration
876.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse ESXi administration services to execute commands on guest machines hosted within an ESXi virtual environment. Persistent background services on ESXi-hosted VMs, such as the VMware Tools Daemon Service, allow for remote management from the ESXi server. The tools daemon service runs as `vmtoolsd.exe` on Windows guest operating systems, `vmware-tools-daemon` on macOS, and `vmtoolsd ` on Linux.(Citation: Broadcom VMware Tools Services) 

Adversaries may leverage a variety of tools to execute commands on ESXi-hosted VMs â€“ for example, by using the vSphere Web Services SDK to programmatically execute commands and scripts via APIs such as `StartProgramInGuest`, `ListProcessesInGuest`,  `ListFileInGuest`, and `InitiateFileTransferFromGuest`.(Citation: Google Cloud Threat Intelligence VMWare ESXi Zero-Day 2023)(Citation: Broadcom Running Guest OS Operations) This may enable follow-on behaviors on the guest VMs, such as [File and Directory Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083), [Data from Local System](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1005), or [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003).
876.profile: [profile]Delegated Administration, also known as ESXi Administration Command (T1675), is a technique under the Execution tactic targeting ESXi platforms. It involves abusing ESXi administration services, such as the VMware Tools Daemon (vmtoolsd), to remotely execute commands on guest virtual machines. Adversaries may use the vSphere Web Services SDK and APIs like StartProgramInGuest to programmatically run scripts, enabling follow-on actions like file discovery or credential dumping. This technique has been associated with threat groups like UNC3886.
876.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Delegated Administration is a technique within the Trusted Relationship (T1199) tactic, focusing on cloud and enterprise environments. It involves adversaries compromising third-party provider accounts, such as Microsoft partners or resellers, to abuse existing delegated administrator permissions. This allows them to gain administrative control over a victim's Office 365 tenant or leverage cloud management services for remote command execution, effectively moving laterally through trusted connections without requiring direct initial access to the target network.

879.name: Account Abuse
879.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may circumvent mechanisms designed to control elevate privileges to gain higher-level permissions. Most modern systems contain native elevation control mechanisms that are intended to limit privileges that a user can perform on a machine. Authorization has to be granted to specific users in order to perform tasks that can be considered of higher risk.(Citation: TechNet How UAC Works)(Citation: sudo man page 2018) An adversary can perform several methods to take advantage of built-in control mechanisms in order to escalate privileges on a system.(Citation: OSX Keydnap malware)(Citation: Fortinet Fareit)
879.profile: [profile]Account Abuse, likely corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK T1548 "Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism" under the Privilege Escalation and Defense Evasion tactics for Windows, macOS, and Linux, involves circumventing native system controls like User Account Control (UAC) or sudo to gain higher privileges without proper authorization. Adversaries exploit these built-in mechanisms through specific methods, as referenced in malware like OSX Keydnap and Fareit. The intrusion set StellarParticle is associated with this behavior.
879.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Account Abuse is a technique where adversaries misuse legitimate user accounts to gain unauthorized access, maintain persistence, escalate privileges, or evade detection. This involves exploiting valid credentials for local, domain, or cloud accounts to bypass security controls. Attackers may leverage inactive accounts or pivot across systems using password reuse to expand their access within a network, often avoiding malware to blend in with normal activity.

880.name: Credential Reuse
880.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use credentials obtained from breach dumps of unrelated accounts to gain access to target accounts through credential overlap. Occasionally, large numbers of username and password pairs are dumped online when a website or service is compromised and the user account credentials accessed. The information may be useful to an adversary attempting to compromise accounts by taking advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Credential stuffing is a risky option because it could cause numerous authentication failures and account lockouts, depending on the organization's login failure policies.

Typically, management services over commonly used ports are used when stuffing credentials. Commonly targeted services include the following:

* SSH (22/TCP)
* Telnet (23/TCP)
* FTP (21/TCP)
* NetBIOS / SMB / Samba (139/TCP & 445/TCP)
* LDAP (389/TCP)
* Kerberos (88/TCP)
* RDP / Terminal Services (3389/TCP)
* HTTP/HTTP Management Services (80/TCP & 443/TCP)
* MSSQL (1433/TCP)
* Oracle (1521/TCP)
* MySQL (3306/TCP)
* VNC (5900/TCP)

In addition to management services, adversaries may "target single sign-on (SSO) and cloud-based applications utilizing federated authentication protocols," as well as externally facing email applications, such as Office 365.(Citation: US-CERT TA18-068A 2018)
880.profile: [profile]Credential Reuse, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1110.004 under the Credential Access tactic, is a technique where adversaries use credentials obtained from unrelated breach dumps to gain access to target accounts by exploiting password overlap across personal and business accounts. This credential stuffing is typically automated against management services on common ports like SSH (22/TCP), Telnet (23/TCP), FTP (21/TCP), SMB (445/TCP), RDP (3389/TCP), and HTTP/HTTPS (80/443/TCP), as well as against single sign-on (SSO), cloud applications, and external email services like Office 365. The associated group Chimera has been linked to this activity.[/profile]
880.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credential Reuse is a technique where adversaries leverage previously compromised or known credentials to gain unauthorized access to accounts or systems, exploiting the common practice of password repetition across different services. This tactic falls under Credential Access (TA0006) and can target multiple platforms. Attackers often use credentials obtained from data breaches, phishing, or OS credential dumping, then attempt to authenticate across various services like SSH, RDP, or web applications. Password reuse facilitates lateral movement and privilege escalation, as compromised credentials from low-privilege accounts may grant access to more critical systems or domain accounts.

881.name: WMI persistence
881.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may clear artifacts associated with previously established persistence on a host system to remove evidence of their activity. This may involve various actions, such as removing services, deleting executables, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), [Plist File Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1647), or other methods of cleanup to prevent defenders from collecting evidence of their persistent presence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm) Adversaries may also delete accounts previously created to maintain persistence (i.e. [Create Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136)).(Citation: Talos - Cisco Attack 2022)

In some instances, artifacts of persistence may also be removed once an adversaryâ€™s persistence is executed in order to prevent errors with the new instance of the malware.(Citation: NCC Group Team9 June 2020)
881.profile: [profile]The entity is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.009, named Clear Persistence, under the Defense Evasion tactic for Windows platforms. It involves adversaries removing artifacts of previously established persistence mechanisms, such as deleting services, executables, modifying the registry, altering Plist files, or deleting created accounts, to eliminate evidence of their activity and prevent detection. Groups like SeaDuke, COZY BEAR, StellarParticle, and APT29 have been associated with this behavior.
881.profile_without_enhance: [profile]WMI persistence is a technique where adversaries abuse Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to maintain access on a system, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Event Triggered Execution: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription (T1546.003) under the Persistence tactic for Windows platforms. It works by creating malicious WMI event subscriptions that execute arbitrary code when a defined event occurs, such as system startup or user login, often using compiled MOF files. This activity is proxied by the WMI Provider Host process (WmiPrvSe.exe) and is associated with threat groups like APT29 and Turla.

882.name: Lateral Movement via SMB
882.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may transfer tools or other files between systems in a compromised environment. Once brought into the victim environment (i.e., [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) files may then be copied from one system to another to stage adversary tools or other files over the course of an operation.

Adversaries may copy files between internal victim systems to support lateral movement using inherent file sharing protocols such as file sharing over [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002) to connected network shares or with authenticated connections via [Remote Desktop Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/001).(Citation: Unit42 LockerGoga 2019)

Files can also be transferred using native or otherwise present tools on the victim system, such as scp, rsync, curl, sftp, and [ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095). In some cases, adversaries may be able to leverage [Web Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102)s such as Dropbox or OneDrive to copy files from one machine to another via shared, automatically synced folders.(Citation: Dropbox Malware Sync)
882.profile: [profile]Lateral Tool Transfer is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1570 under the Lateral Movement tactic, primarily for Windows. It involves copying adversary tools or files between compromised systems to stage operations. This is achieved using inherent file sharing protocols like SMB/Windows Admin Shares (e.g., accessing C$ or ADMIN$), authenticated RDP sessions, or native system utilities such as scp, rsync, curl, sftp, and ftp. Adversaries may also leverage synced web services like Dropbox for file transfers. The technique is used by numerous threat groups including APT41, Wizard Spider, and Sandworm Team.[/profile]
882.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Lateral Movement via SMB is a technique for moving through a network using the Server Message Block protocol. It aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique SMB/Windows Admin Shares (T1021.002) under the Lateral Movement tactic, primarily for Windows platforms. Adversaries use valid accounts or stolen credentials to access hidden administrative shares like C$ or ADMIN$ over SMB, enabling remote file operations, command execution via tools like PsExec or WMI, and the transfer of tools for further compromise. This method often follows network share discovery and can be used in conjunction with pass-the-hash attacks for authentication.

883.name: GoldMax (Windows variant)
883.uncertain_mes: [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343) is a backdoor used for targeting Windows systems. The Linux version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
883.profile: [profile]GoldMax (Windows variant), also known as Exaramel for Windows, is a backdoor attributed to the Sandworm Team. It targets Windows systems and is the Windows counterpart to a separately tracked Linux variant. The malware's technical behaviors include functioning as a modular remote access Trojan (RAT) for intrusions, with infrastructure and deployment linked to the StellarParticle intrusion set.
883.profile_without_enhance: [profile]GoldMax (Windows variant) is a Windows-based malware variant, also known as GoldMax, attributed to the intrusion set StellarParticle and associated with the group UNC2452. It is the Windows counterpart to a Linux variant deployed earlier. The Windows variant was compiled in May 2020 and is part of a broader intrusion campaign targeting multiple platforms.

884.name: C2 traffic masquerading
884.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate features of their artifacts to make them appear legitimate or benign to users and/or security tools. Masquerading occurs when the name or location of an object, legitimate or malicious, is manipulated or abused for the sake of evading defenses and observation. This may include manipulating file metadata, tricking users into misidentifying the file type, and giving legitimate task or service names.

Renaming abusable system utilities to evade security monitoring is also a form of [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036).(Citation: LOLBAS Main Site)
884.profile: [profile]C2 Traffic Masquerading, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1036 under the Defense Evasion tactic, involves adversaries manipulating network traffic to appear legitimate and evade detection. This is distinct from general masquerading of files and is a Command and Control sub-technique. It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms by blending malicious communications with normal web service traffic, such as mimicking HTTPS or common cloud service protocols, and manipulating HTTP headers or SSL certificates to disguise the true C2 destination. This technique is used by groups like StellarParticle to hide their infrastructure and bypass security monitoring.
884.profile_without_enhance: [profile]C2 traffic masquerading is a technique where adversaries disguise their command and control communications to appear as legitimate or benign network traffic. This involves manipulating traffic characteristics, such as using common protocols like HTTP or HTTPS, mimicking trusted services like Google Drive or Gmail, and employing fake SSL/TLS handshakes or specific headers to blend in and evade detection by security tools.

885.name: Shellbags
885.profile: [profile]Shellbags is a technique used for defense evasion and persistence, likely on Windows platforms, involving the manipulation of Windows Shellbag registry entries to hide malicious files or folders. The intrusion set StellarParticle has been associated with this activity. The technique exploits how Windows stores user interface settings to conceal adversary presence and maintain access.
885.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Shellbags is a technique for collecting host data, specifically by accessing Windows Shellbag registry entries to gather details about a user's file explorer history, such as frequently accessed directories and network shares, which can be used for discovery and reconnaissance on a compromised system.

886.name: VBScript-based Active Directory enumeration toolkit
886.profile: [profile]VBScript-based Active Directory enumeration toolkit is a tool observed in use by the intrusion set StellarParticle (potentially linked to UNC2452). Its key technical behavior is enumerating Active Directory to collect information such as user accounts, member details, and computer data. The target platform is Windows Active Directory environments.
886.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is a VBScript-based Active Directory enumeration toolkit. It is associated with the threat groups APT28 and UNC2452, as observed in StellarParticle campaigns. Its key technical behavior involves enumerating user accounts, member information, and computers from Active Directory. The target platform is Windows environments utilizing Active Directory. Its use is linked to specific artifacts and campaigns, indicating deployment in targeted network reconnaissance operations.

887.name: Active Directory enumeration
887.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may enumerate system and service logs to find useful data. These logs may highlight various types of valuable insights for an adversary, such as user authentication records ([Account Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1087)), security or vulnerable software ([Software Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1518)), or hosts within a compromised network ([Remote System Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1018)).

Host binaries may be leveraged to collect system logs. Examples include using `wevtutil.exe` or [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) on Windows to access and/or export security event information.(Citation: WithSecure Lazarus-NoPineapple Threat Intel Report 2023)(Citation: Cadet Blizzard emerges as novel threat actor) In cloud environments, adversaries may leverage utilities such as the Azure VM Agentâ€™s `CollectGuestLogs.exe` to collect security logs from cloud hosted infrastructure.(Citation: SIM Swapping and Abuse of the Microsoft Azure Serial Console)

Adversaries may also target centralized logging infrastructure such as SIEMs. Logs may also be bulk exported and sent to adversary-controlled infrastructure for offline analysis.

In addition to gaining a better understanding of the environment, adversaries may also monitor logs in real time to track incident response procedures. This may allow them to adjust their techniques in order to maintain persistence or evade defenses.(Citation: Permiso GUI-Vil 2023)
887.profile: [profile]Active Directory Enumeration, also known as Log Enumeration (T1654), is a Discovery technique used to gather intelligence from system, service, and security logs. Adversaries use tools like `wevtutil.exe` or PowerShell on Windows and `CollectGuestLogs.exe` in Azure to access and export logs, which can reveal user accounts, software, and network hosts. They may also target centralized logging infrastructure like SIEMs for bulk export or real-time monitoring to track incident response. This technique is associated with groups like Volt Typhoon and StellarParticle.
887.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Active Directory enumeration, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1087.002 (Domain Account Discovery), is a Discovery tactic used on Windows platforms. It involves querying the Active Directory domain to list user and group accounts, often using built-in utilities like `net user /domain`, `net group /domain`, or PowerShell cmdlets such as `Get-ADUser` and `Get-ADGroupMember`. This reconnaissance helps adversaries map the domain structure and identify high-value accounts for subsequent targeting.

888.name: UserAssist
888.profile: [profile]UserAssist is a Windows persistence technique, likely mapped to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1547.004 or similar under the Boot or Logon Autostart Execution tactic for Windows platforms. It involves abusing the Windows UserAssist Registry keys, which track GUI application execution for features like the Start Menu, to automatically launch malicious executables or scripts when a user logs in. This method is used by groups like StellarParticle to establish persistence by planting entries that Windows Explorer will automatically execute.
888.profile_without_enhance: [profile]UserAssist is a Windows persistence technique (T1547.004) within the Privilege Escalation tactic. It operates by modifying the Windows Registry, specifically the UserAssist key, to automatically execute malicious code when a user logs in. This abuse leverages the Winlogon component's helper functionality to establish persistence, similar to the abuse of other Winlogon subkeys like Notify, Userinit, and Shell.

889.name: crontab persistence
889.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may clear artifacts associated with previously established persistence on a host system to remove evidence of their activity. This may involve various actions, such as removing services, deleting executables, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), [Plist File Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1647), or other methods of cleanup to prevent defenders from collecting evidence of their persistent presence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm) Adversaries may also delete accounts previously created to maintain persistence (i.e. [Create Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136)).(Citation: Talos - Cisco Attack 2022)

In some instances, artifacts of persistence may also be removed once an adversaryâ€™s persistence is executed in order to prevent errors with the new instance of the malware.(Citation: NCC Group Team9 June 2020)
889.profile: [profile]The entity "crontab persistence" is a technique for maintaining access on Unix-like systems, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Scheduled Task/Job: Cron (T1053.003) under the Persistence tactic. It operates by abusing the cron time-based job scheduler, where adversaries create or modify crontab files (e.g., `/etc/crontab` or user-specific crontabs) to execute malicious code at system startup or on a recurring scheduled basis, ensuring the code runs in the background without user interaction. The intrusion-set StellarParticle has been associated with this method.
889.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "crontab persistence" is a technique for maintaining access on Unix-like systems, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK ID T1053.003 under the Persistence tactic for Linux and macOS platforms. It works by abusing the cron utility to schedule malicious code execution at system startup or at recurring intervals by creating or modifying crontab files, such as `/etc/crontab` or user-specific crontabs. This method allows adversaries to run commands or scripts in the background without user interaction, providing a stealthy and automated persistence mechanism.

890.name: RecentApps
890.profile: [profile]RecentApps is a macOS persistence technique (T1547.007) under Privilege Escalation. It works by modifying the `com.apple.loginwindow.[UUID].plist` file in `~/Library/Preferences/ByHost/` to add a malicious application path, causing it to automatically execute when the user logs back in after selecting the system's "Reopen windows" option. This method is used by groups like StellarParticle.
890.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RecentApps is a macOS persistence technique (T1547.007) under the tactic Privilege Escalation. It operates by modifying the property list file `com.apple.loginwindow.[UUID].plist` in `~/Library/Preferences/ByHost/` to include a malicious application path. When a user logs out or restarts and selects "Reopen windows when logging back in," the system automatically launches the listed applications upon the next logon, enabling adversaries to execute their payloads.

891.name: Jump List
891.profile: [profile]Jump List is a Windows artifact used for persistence and lateral movement, identified as T1547.015 within the Credential Access and Persistence tactics. It operates by manipulating the automatic destinations and custom destinations folders to execute malicious shortcuts or files when a user interacts with the taskbar or start menu. This technique is associated with threat actors like StellarParticle, who exploit these lists to maintain access and move within a compromised network.
891.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Jump List is a technique for persistence and privilege escalation, identified as T1547.015 within the Credential Access and Persistence tactics, primarily on the Windows platform. It involves an adversary manipulating or creating custom Jump List files (.automaticDestinations-ms or .customDestinations-ms) to execute malicious code when a user interacts with the pinned application shortcut in the Windows Taskbar or Start Menu, thereby establishing persistence and potentially stealing credentials.

902.name: RDP sessions
902.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may hijack a legitimate userâ€™s remote desktop session to move laterally within an environment. Remote desktop is a common feature in operating systems. It allows a user to log into an interactive session with a system desktop graphical user interface on a remote system. Microsoft refers to its implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) as Remote Desktop Services (RDS).(Citation: TechNet Remote Desktop Services)

Adversaries may perform RDP session hijacking which involves stealing a legitimate user's remote session. Typically, a user is notified when someone else is trying to steal their session. With System permissions and using Terminal Services Console, `c:\windows\system32\tscon.exe [session number to be stolen]`, an adversary can hijack a session without the need for credentials or prompts to the user.(Citation: RDP Hijacking Korznikov) This can be done remotely or locally and with active or disconnected sessions.(Citation: RDP Hijacking Medium) It can also lead to [Remote System Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1018) and Privilege Escalation by stealing a Domain Admin or higher privileged account session. All of this can be done by using native Windows commands, but it has also been added as a feature in red teaming tools.(Citation: Kali Redsnarf)
902.profile: [profile]RDP Hijacking, identified as T1563.002 under the Lateral Movement tactic, primarily targets Windows platforms. This technique involves adversaries hijacking existing Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) sessions to move laterally without needing the user's credentials. The core technical mechanic is the use of the native Windows command `tscon.exe` with System permissions to attach to and control a specified active or disconnected user session, bypassing normal security prompts. It has been incorporated into tools like RedSnarf and is associated with threat groups such as Axiom and StellarParticle.
902.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "RDP sessions" is a general concept, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is the target of techniques like RDP Hijacking (T1563.002) under the Lateral Movement tactic. Adversaries hijack legitimate Remote Desktop Protocol sessions to move within a network. With SYSTEM permissions, they can use the native Windows command `tscon.exe` to steal an active or disconnected session without needing credentials or triggering user alerts, enabling privilege escalation and further discovery.

903.name: Microsoft Azure
903.profile: [profile]Microsoft Azure is a major cloud computing platform (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS) referenced in multiple MITRE ATT&CK techniques. It is used by adversaries for activities like cloud service discovery via its APIs (Microsoft Graph API, Azure Resource Manager API) and tools like Stormspotter, direct VM access via the Azure Serial Console, and command execution through its Cloud API and PowerShell modules. The intrusion-set StellarParticle is linked to this platform.[/profile]
903.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Microsoft Azure is a cloud platform, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. The retrieved information describes how adversaries interact with Azure services. Techniques include using the Azure Resource Manager API and Microsoft Graph API for cloud service discovery (T1526), leveraging the Azure Serial Console for direct cloud VM connections (T1021.008), and abusing Azure PowerShell or the Azure Cloud Shell via the Cloud API (T1059.009) to execute commands. These actions are typically part of the Discovery and Execution tactics.

905.name: ApplicationImpersonation9
905.profile: [profile]ApplicationImpersonation9 is a technique for gaining temporarily elevated access in cloud environments, specifically within Microsoft Exchange Online. It involves abusing the `ApplicationImpersonation` role, which allows a service account to impersonate and use the permissions of specified user accounts. This method is used for privilege escalation and can be part of broader cloud permission abuse, as seen in campaigns like StellarParticle, where adversaries exploit misconfigured permissions to access resources beyond their intended scope.
905.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ApplicationImpersonation9 is a cloud technique within the tactic of Privilege Escalation. It specifically exploits the `ApplicationImpersonation` role in Exchange Online, which allows a service account to temporarily act with the permissions of a specified user account. This enables adversaries to gain short-term, elevated access to email resources by abusing misconfigured permission structures, distinct from permanently assigned roles.

907.name: O365 Application Impersonation
907.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may impersonate a trusted person or organization in order to persuade and trick a target into performing some action on their behalf. For example, adversaries may communicate with victims (via [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598), [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566), or [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534)) while impersonating a known sender such as an executive, colleague, or third-party vendor. Established trust can then be leveraged to accomplish an adversaryâ€™s ultimate goals, possibly against multiple victims. 
 
In many cases of business email compromise or email fraud campaigns, adversaries use impersonation to defraud victims -- deceiving them into sending money or divulging information that ultimately enables [Financial Theft](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1657).

Adversaries will often also use social engineering techniques such as manipulative and persuasive language in email subject lines and body text such as `payment`, `request`, or `urgent` to push the victim to act quickly before malicious activity is detected. These campaigns are often specifically targeted against people who, due to job roles and/or accesses, can carry out the adversaryâ€™s goal.â€¯â€¯ 
 
Impersonation is typically preceded by reconnaissance techniques such as [Gather Victim Identity Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1589) and [Gather Victim Org Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1591) as well as acquiring infrastructure such as email domains (i.e. [Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583/001)) to substantiate their false identity.(Citation: CrowdStrike-BEC)
 
There is the potential for multiple victims in campaigns involving impersonation. For example, an adversary may [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586) targeting one organization which can then be used to support impersonation against other entities.(Citation: VEC)
907.profile: [profile]O365 Application Impersonation is a technique for gaining temporarily elevated access in cloud environments, specifically within Microsoft 365/Exchange Online. It involves abusing the `ApplicationImpersonation` role, which allows a service account to act with the permissions of specified user accounts, such as to access mailboxes via Exchange Web Services. This is a form of privilege abuse for lateral movement and data access, distinct from general social engineering impersonation. It is associated with the StellarParticle intrusion set.[/profile]
907.profile_without_enhance: [profile]O365 Application Impersonation is a cloud-specific technique for privilege escalation and lateral movement, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Privilege Escalation (TA0004) on the Office 365 platform. It involves a service account abusing the `ApplicationImpersonation` role in Exchange Online to temporarily act with the permissions of other user accounts, enabling actions like accessing mailboxes and sending emails on their behalf. This method exploits misconfigured cloud permissions to gain temporary, elevated access to resources beyond an account's standard privileges.

908.name: MFA
908.profile: [profile]The entity "MFA" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; the retrieved content describes related techniques for bypassing or disabling Multi-Factor Authentication. These include T1556.006 (Modify Authentication Process: Multi-Factor Authentication), which involves disabling MFA via policy changes or host file modifications to cause a fail-open condition. Technique T1621 (Multi-Factor Authentication Request Generation) bypasses MFA by spamming push notifications to induce user acceptance through fatigue. Technique T1111 (Multi-Factor Authentication Interception) targets hardware tokens or out-of-band codes via keyloggers or service compromise to capture one-time credentials. Associated threat actors include Scattered Spider, APT29, and LAPSUS$.[/profile]
908.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "MFA" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it is a general security concept (Multi-Factor Authentication) that adversaries target to bypass. Related ATT&CK techniques for compromising MFA include T1556.006 (Modify Authentication Process: Multi-Factor Authentication), which involves disabling MFA via host file modification or policy changes; T1621 (Multi-Factor Authentication Request Generation), which abuses push notifications to cause MFA fatigue; and T1111 (Multi-Factor Authentication Interception), which captures hardware token codes or intercepts one-time codes. These techniques are used by groups like Scattered Spider, APT29, and LAPSUS$ to maintain access to compromised accounts.

913.name: SeaDuke
913.uncertain_mes:
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR).(Citation: White House Imposing Costs RU Gov April 2021)(Citation: UK Gov Malign RIS Activity April 2021) They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: UK Gov UK Exposes Russia SolarWinds April 2021)

In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) to the SVR; public statements included citations to [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016), Cozy Bear, and The Dukes.(Citation: NSA Joint Advisory SVR SolarWinds April 2021)(Citation: UK NSCS Russia SolarWinds April 2021) Industry reporting also referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm.(Citation: FireEye SUNBURST Backdoor December 2020)(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike SUNSPOT Implant January 2021)(Citation: Volexity SolarWinds)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory SVR TTP May 2021)(Citation: Unit 42 SolarStorm December 2020)
913.profile: [profile]SeaDuke, also known as APT29, Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and NOBELIUM, is a Russian state-sponsored threat group attributed to the Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its arsenal includes custom malware such as SeaDuke, MiniDionis, and the SUNBURST backdoor used in the SolarWinds compromise. The group's key tactics involve sophisticated supply chain attacks and long-term intrusions. It primarily targets government networks in Europe and NATO countries, research institutes, and think tanks, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering for the Russian state.
913.profile_without_enhance: [profile]SeaDuke is a cyber espionage group, also known as APT29, Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium. It is attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and is a sophisticated, long-running threat actor. The group's key malware includes the Seaduke backdoor, MiniDionis, and CozyDuke. Its key TTPs involve the use of Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) for persistence, along with extensive spear-phishing campaigns. The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, think-tank, healthcare, and energy sectors in the US and Europe, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and cyber espionage to support Russian state interests.
913.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]SeaDuke, also known as MiniDionis, is a cyber espionage intrusion set believed to be a component or toolset used by the APT29 group (also known as Cozy Bear, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium). Its key malware is the SeaDuke backdoor, which is related to the MiniDionis malware family. The group's tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) involve the use of publicly available tools for lateral movement within victim infrastructure. It is attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, primarily targeting government, diplomatic, and political organizations in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and cyber espionage.
913.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]SeaDuke, also known as MiniDionis and linked to APT29 (Cozy Bear, The Dukes), is a sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). 914.name: tasklist.exe
914.profile: [profile]tasklist.exe is a legitimate Windows system utility used for process discovery, but it is frequently leveraged by threat actors like StellarParticle, Dragonok, and FIN8 as part of their malicious operations. Its key technical behavior involves executing commands such as 'tasklist.exe /v' to perform Process Discovery (T1057) and identify running processes like explorer.exe. It is also used in sequences for System Owner/User Discovery (T1033) and Permission Groups Discovery (T1069), often in conjunction with tools like whoami.exe and net.exe, primarily targeting Windows platforms as part of broader lateral movement and reconnaissance activities.[/profile]
914.profile_without_enhance: [profile]tasklist.exe is a legitimate Windows system utility used for process listing. It is referenced in the context of malicious activities by groups like FIN8 and Dragonok, who abuse it for discovery techniques such as Process Discovery (T1057) to enumerate running processes and find specific targets like explorer.exe. It is also listed among other system binaries in tools like Ragnarok, indicating its potential misuse in broader attack chains on Windows platforms.

915.name: DSInternals10
915.profile: [profile]DSInternals10 is a PowerShell module used for credential theft, specifically via the Get-ADReplAccount command to perform Active Directory replication attacks. It is employed by the intrusion set StellarParticle and has been used in campaigns attributed to UNC2452, such as the GOLDMAX operation, where actors deployed it on Domain Controllers after gaining initial access via VPN. Its functionality is related to tools like LaZagne for credential dumping and shares technical overlap with LDAP discovery methods seen in malware like Babuk.
915.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DSInternals10 is a PowerShell module used for credential theft, specifically via the Get-ADReplAccount command to perform Active Directory replication attacks, as observed in UNC2452 campaigns like GOLDMAN. It targets Windows environments, often deployed on Domain Controllers after initial access via VPN, to facilitate data exfiltration.

918.name: APT29
918.uncertain_mes:
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR).(Citation: White House Imposing Costs RU Gov April 2021)(Citation: UK Gov Malign RIS Activity April 2021) They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.(Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)(Citation: GRIZZLY STEPPE JAR)(Citation: Crowdstrike DNC June 2016)(Citation: UK Gov UK Exposes Russia SolarWinds April 2021)

In April 2021, the US and UK governments attributed the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024) to the SVR; public statements included citations to [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016), Cozy Bear, and The Dukes.(Citation: NSA Joint Advisory SVR SolarWinds April 2021)(Citation: UK NSCS Russia SolarWinds April 2021) Industry reporting also referred to the actors involved in this campaign as UNC2452, NOBELIUM, StellarParticle, Dark Halo, and SolarStorm.(Citation: FireEye SUNBURST Backdoor December 2020)(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike SUNSPOT Implant January 2021)(Citation: Volexity SolarWinds)(Citation: Cybersecurity Advisory SVR TTP May 2021)(Citation: Unit 42 SolarStorm December 2020)
918.profile: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, and Nobelium, is a Russian state-sponsored threat group attributed to the Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its key malware and tools include the SUNBURST backdoor and SUNSPOT implant from the SolarWinds campaign, and it has historically used spearphishing and tools like AdFind for network enumeration. The group primarily targets government networks in Europe and NATO countries, research institutes, and think tanks, with motivations centered on espionage, as evidenced by its compromise of the Democratic National Committee and the widespread SolarWinds supply-chain attack.
918.profile_without_enhance: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Nobelium, Midnight Blizzard, and Cloaked Ursa, is a sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). It is distinguished by its heavy use of fileless malware and living-off-the-land techniques, particularly leveraging Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) for persistence and execution, as seen in custom backdoors like PoshSpy. The group employs advanced tactics such as scheduled tasks, encrypted and encoded communications, and domain fronting for command and control. APT29 is known for high-profile campaigns, including the SolarWinds compromise, primarily targeting government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in the US and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.
918.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The group is most commonly known as APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium. It has employed custom malware and tools such as SeaDuke and Calypso RAT, and uses tools like AdFind for network reconnaissance. Its key TTPs include spearphishing with malicious attachments and the abuse of privileged accounts and domain controllers for lateral movement, as notably observed in the SolarWinds compromise. The group is widely attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its operations primarily target government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering.
918.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its key malware and tools include custom backdoors like SEADUKE and the use of legitimate tools such as AdFind for network reconnaissance. Key TTPs involve spearphishing with malicious attachments and the abuse of privileged access, as notably demonstrated in the SolarWinds supply chain compromise to replicate directory service data. The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence collection.
918.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Nobelium, Midnight Blizzard, and Cloaked Ursa, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). The group is distinguished by its extensive use of fileless malware, notably the PoshSpy backdoor, which leverages Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for execution and persistence. Key TTPs include living off the land with legitimate system tools, abusing WMI event subscriptions for stealth, and employing scheduled tasks at specific times. APT29 has historically targeted government, diplomatic, and think-tank sectors in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage, as exemplified by its role in the SolarWinds compromise.
918.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). It is distinguished by its use of custom fileless malware like PoshSpy, which leverages Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for stealthy execution and persistence, and its employment of advanced techniques such as WMI event subscription abuse and living-off-the-land tactics. The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in the US and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering, as notably demonstrated in the SolarWinds supply chain compromise.
918.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its key malware includes the fileless PowerShell backdoor PoshSpy and custom tools like Hammertoss. The group is distinguished by its extensive use of living-off-the-land techniques, particularly abusing Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) for event-triggered execution and persistence, alongside scheduled tasks and fileless execution to evade detection. It primarily targets government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering, as exemplified by its role in the SolarWinds compromise.
918.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). The group is distinguished by its advanced use of fileless malware and living-off-the-land techniques, particularly leveraging Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for stealthy execution and persistence, as seen in its custom PoshSpy backdoor. Key Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) include the abuse of WMI event subscriptions for persistence, scheduled tasks for execution, and the use of encrypted and encoded communications. APT29 primarily targets government, diplomatic, and think-tank sectors in Europe and North America, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence collection, notably demonstrated in campaigns like the SolarWinds compromise.
918.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). The group is distinguished by its heavy use of fileless malware and living-off-the-land techniques, particularly leveraging Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) for persistence and execution, as seen in its custom backdoor PoshSpy. Key TTPs include the abuse of WMI event subscriptions (FilterToConsumerBinding), encrypted and Base64-encoded payloads, and scheduled tasks for stealthy execution. APT29 primarily targets government, diplomatic, and think-tank sectors in North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering, as exemplified by its role in the SolarWinds compromise.
918.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its operations are characterized by the use of custom fileless malware like PoshSpy, which leverages Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for execution and persistence, often employing scheduled tasks and encrypted, base64-encoded communications for stealth. The group extensively uses spearphishing for initial access and tools like AdFind for network reconnaissance. APT29 primarily targets government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in the US and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering, as notably demonstrated in the SolarWinds supply chain compromise.
918.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). It is distinguished by its use of custom fileless malware like PoshSpy and Hammertos, which leverage Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI), PowerShell, and scheduled tasks for stealthy execution and persistence. The group's key TTPs include domain fronting for C2 obfuscation and the use of tools like AdFind for network reconnaissance. APT29 primarily targets government, diplomatic, and technology sectors in North America and Europe, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering, as evidenced by its role in major campaigns like the SolarWinds compromise.
918.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its key malware includes the fileless backdoor PoshSpy, which leverages Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for execution and evasion. The group's TTPs prominently feature the abuse of WMI for persistence and privilege escalation, as well as the use of tools like AdFind for network reconnaissance. APT29 is known for targeting government, diplomatic, and technology sectors globally, with high-profile campaigns like the SolarWinds compromise. Its primary motivation is cyber espionage to gather foreign intelligence.
918.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]APT29, also known as Cozy Bear, The Dukes, Midnight Blizzard, and Nobelium, is a highly sophisticated intrusion set attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). Its key malware includes the fileless backdoor PoshSpy, which leverages Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for execution and employs a Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA). The group's TTPs involve using WMI for persistence, as seen with the WMI FilterToConsumerBinding technique, and spearphishing for initial access. APT29 is known for targeting government, diplomatic, and IT sectors globally, notably in the 2020 SolarWinds compromise, and is primarily motivated by espionage.

919.name: PoshSpy
919.uncertain_mes: [POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) is a backdoor that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2015. It appears to be used as a secondary backdoor used if the actors lost access to their primary backdoors. (Citation: FireEye POSHSPY April 2017)
919.profile: [profile]PoshSpy, also known as POSHSPY, is a backdoor attributed to APT29, used since at least 2015 as a secondary backdoor for persistence. It is a fileless malware leveraging Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for execution, enabling command and control. The primary target platform is Windows systems.[/profile]
919.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PoshSpy, also known as poshspy, is a backdoor attributed to APT29. It is a fileless malware that leverages Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell for execution, evading traditional detection. Key technical behaviors include the use of a Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) for resilient command and control, and the manipulation of file signatures to masquerade its true type. It operates on Windows platforms and utilizes custom HTTP User-Agent strings and cookies to blend malicious traffic with legitimate web communications, while employing encryption like RSA and AES to secure its C2 channels and data.

922.name: Hammertos
922.uncertain_mes: [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) is a backdoor that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) in 2015. (Citation: FireEye APT29) (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
922.profile: [profile]Hammertoss, also known as Hammertos, is a backdoor attributed to the APT29 intrusion set. It was notably used by this group in 2015. The malware's specific technical behaviors and target platforms are not detailed in the provided context. No supplementary infrastructure information is available from the given data.[profile]
922.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Hammertos is a malware with no known aliases or attributed groups in this dataset. Its technical behaviors include creating a registry key for persistence to automatically launch a copy on each system startup, monitoring specific applications, and engaging in network interactions. The target platform is Windows, as indicated by its registry-based persistence mechanism. No further infrastructure or supplementary information is provided.]

923.name: off-the-shelf domain fronted backdoors
923.profile: [profile]The entity is a category of 'off-the-shelf domain fronted backdoors', a technique notably used by APT29 and other groups listed in relation to Cobalt Strike. This method involves malware, such as the SMOKEDHAM variant of FiveHands, using HTTPS to communicate with a command-and-control (C2) server by fronting a legitimate domain (e.g., a Microsoft CDN) to conceal the true, hard-coded C2 endpoint (e.g., an Azure Edge domain). The primary target platforms are systems where these commercial or custom backdoors are deployed, leveraging trusted infrastructure for obfuscation.[/profile]
923.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is known as off-the-shelf domain fronted backdoors. It is a type of backdoor that uses domain fronting, a technique to obfuscate its true command-and-control (C2) server by routing traffic through a legitimate content delivery network (CDN) or service. This technique has been observed in malware like SMOKEDHAM, which uses HTTPS for C2 communication with a hard-coded actual domain and a configured fronted domain. The method is also associated with tools such as Cobalt Strike, indicating its use by various threat groups for stealthy network communication.

924.name: Living off the Land
924.profile: [profile]Living off the Land is a strategic approach, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique ID. It describes adversaries leveraging legitimate system tools and software, like remote desktop applications (e.g., VNC, TeamViewer) or trusted scripts (e.g., SyncAppvPublishingServer.vbs), to blend in with normal activity for execution, persistence, and lateral movement, thereby evading detection by abusing trusted processes and binaries already present in the environment. Groups such as APT29 are known to employ this methodology.[/profile]
924.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Living off the Land is a strategic approach, not a single MITRE ATT&CK technique. It describes adversaries leveraging legitimate, pre-installed system tools and processes to execute malicious activities, thereby blending in with normal operations to evade detection. This concept underpins many specific techniques, such as using scripts like SyncAppvPublishingServer.vbs to proxy PowerShell commands or abusing remote desktop software for command and control, making malicious actions appear benign.

926.name: PowerShell backdoor code
926.uncertain_mes: powershell_web_backdoor This is a very simple powershell web backdoor Usage: hxxp://127.0.0.1:9999/backdoor/?cmd=<Insert Your powershell compatible base64 encoded command here
926.profile: [profile]PowerShell backdoor code, also known as powershell_web_backdoor, is a simple web-based backdoor attributed to APT29. It operates by accepting base64-encoded PowerShell commands via an HTTP GET parameter (e.g., ?cmd=) to a specified web server. Key behaviors include downloading and executing additional PowerShell code or Windows binaries, often using obfuscated commands for persistence. It targets Windows platforms and is associated with infrastructure referenced by groups like powerpool.
926.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PowerShell backdoor code, also known as POSHSPY, is attributed to APT 29. Its key technical behaviors include downloading and executing additional PowerShell code or Windows binaries via an EncodedCommand, and establishing persistence through a single obfuscated command. The malware targets Windows platforms and operates as a web backdoor, capable of receiving and executing base64-encoded commands from a remote server.

931.name: Fileless Malware
931.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may store data in "fileless" formats to conceal malicious activity from defenses. Fileless storage can be broadly defined as any format other than a file. Common examples of non-volatile fileless storage in Windows systems include the Windows Registry, event logs, or WMI repository.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)(Citation: SecureList Fileless) Shared memory directories on Linux systems (`/dev/shm`, `/run/shm`, `/var/run`, and `/var/lock`) and volatile directories on Network Devices (`/tmp` and `/volatile`) may also be considered fileless storage, as files written to these directories are mapped directly to RAM and not stored on the disk.(Citation: Elastic Binary Executed from Shared Memory Directory)(Citation: Akami Frog4Shell 2024)(Citation: Aquasec Muhstik Malware 2024)(Citation: Bitsight 7777 Botnet)(Citation: CISCO Nexus 900 Config).

Similar to fileless in-memory behaviors such as [Reflective Code Loading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1620) and [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055), fileless data storage may remain undetected by anti-virus and other endpoint security tools that can only access specific file formats from disk storage. Leveraging fileless storage may also allow adversaries to bypass the protections offered by read-only file systems in Linux.(Citation: Sysdig Fileless Malware 23022)

Adversaries may use fileless storage to conceal various types of stored data, including payloads/shellcode (potentially being used as part of [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003)) and collected data not yet exfiltrated from the victim (e.g., [Local Data Staging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1074/001)). Adversaries also often encrypt, encode, splice, or otherwise obfuscate this fileless data when stored. 

Some forms of fileless storage activity may indirectly create artifacts in the file system, but in central and otherwise difficult to inspect formats such as the WMI (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Wbem\Repository`) or Registry (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Config`) physical files.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)
931.profile: [profile]Fileless Storage, identified as T1027.011 under the Defense Evasion tactic, operates across Windows, Linux, and Network Device platforms. This technique conceals data in non-file formats to evade disk-based detection, storing payloads or staged data in locations like the Windows Registry, WMI repository, or Linux shared memory directories (e.g., `/dev/shm`), which are mapped directly to RAM. Adversaries, including groups like APT32 and Turla, often further obfuscate this stored data. While fileless, artifacts may persist in central system files like the WMI Repository, making forensic analysis challenging.[/profile]
931.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Fileless Malware is a technique where adversaries execute malicious code directly in system memory without writing files to disk, often to evade detection. It operates across Windows and Linux platforms, primarily under the Defense Evasion tactic. Technical mechanics involve leveraging in-memory execution via methods like reflective code loading (T1620) and process injection, storing payloads in non-file locations such as the Windows Registry, WMI repository, or Linux shared memory directories (e.g., /dev/shm). This approach bypasses traditional file-based antivirus scans and can be used for persistence and data staging, with groups like APT32 and Turla employing related fileless storage (T1027.011) to conceal activities.

932.name: encrypted and base64-encoded
932.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may encrypt or encode files to obfuscate strings, bytes, and other specific patterns to impede detection. Encrypting and/or encoding file content aims to conceal malicious artifacts within a file used in an intrusion. Many other techniques, such as [Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), [Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003), and [Embedded Payloads](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/009), share this same broad objective. Encrypting and/or encoding files could lead to a lapse in detection of static signatures, only for this malicious content to be revealed (i.e., [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140)) at the time of execution/use.

This type of file obfuscation can be applied to many file artifacts present on victim hosts, such as malware log/configuration and payload files.(Citation: File obfuscation) Files can be encrypted with a hardcoded or user-supplied key, as well as otherwise obfuscated using standard encoding schemes such as Base64.

The entire content of a file may be obfuscated, or just specific functions or values (such as C2 addresses). Encryption and encoding may also be applied in redundant layers for additional protection.

For example, adversaries may abuse password-protected Word documents or self-extracting (SFX) archives as a method of encrypting/encoding a file such as a [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) payload. These files typically function by attaching the intended archived content to a decompressor stub that is executed when the file is invoked (e.g., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: SFX - Encrypted/Encoded File) 

Adversaries may also abuse file-specific as well as custom encoding schemes. For example, Byte Order Mark (BOM) headers in text files may be abused to manipulate and obfuscate file content until [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) execution.
932.profile: [profile]Encrypted/Encoded File, designated as T1027.013 under the Defense Evasion tactic, is a technique applicable across multiple platforms where adversaries encrypt or encode files to obfuscate content and impede static detection. The technical mechanics involve applying encryption with hardcoded or user-supplied keys, or using standard encoding like Base64, to entire files or specific values like C2 addresses. This can be layered for redundancy and is exemplified by abusing password-protected documents or self-extracting archives to conceal payloads. The technique is associated with numerous threat groups including APT29, Lazarus Group, and OilRig.[/profile]
932.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Encrypted and Base64-encoded is a sub-technique for obfuscating files or information (T1027). It falls under the Defense Evasion tactic and applies across multiple platforms. The technique involves applying Base64 encoding, often in combination with encryption using a hardcoded or supplied key, to obscure malicious content within files like payloads, logs, or configuration data. This obfuscation can target entire files or specific values like C2 addresses and may be applied in redundant layers to impede static signature detection, requiring deobfuscation at runtime.

933.name: Scheduled Task (Mon/Tue/Thu/Fri/Sat 11:33 AM)
933.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. There are multiple ways to access the Task Scheduler in Windows. The [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) utility can be run directly on the command line, or the Task Scheduler can be opened through the GUI within the Administrator Tools section of the Control Panel.(Citation: Stack Overflow) In some cases, adversaries have used a .NET wrapper for the Windows Task Scheduler, and alternatively, adversaries have used the Windows netapi32 library and [Windows Management Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047) (WMI) to create a scheduled task. Adversaries may also utilize the Powershell Cmdlet `Invoke-CimMethod`, which leverages WMI class `PS_ScheduledTask` to create a scheduled task via an XML path.(Citation: Red Canary - Atomic Red Team)

An adversary may use Windows Task Scheduler to execute programs at system startup or on a scheduled basis for persistence. The Windows Task Scheduler can also be abused to conduct remote Execution as part of Lateral Movement and/or to run a process under the context of a specified account (such as SYSTEM). Similar to [System Binary Proxy Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218), adversaries have also abused the Windows Task Scheduler to potentially mask one-time execution under signed/trusted system processes.(Citation: ProofPoint Serpent)

Adversaries may also create "hidden" scheduled tasks (i.e. [Hide Artifacts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564)) that may not be visible to defender tools and manual queries used to enumerate tasks. Specifically, an adversary may hide a task from `schtasks /query` and the Task Scheduler by deleting the associated Security Descriptor (SD) registry value (where deletion of this value must be completed using SYSTEM permissions).(Citation: SigmaHQ)(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task) Adversaries may also employ alternate methods to hide tasks, such as altering the metadata (e.g., `Index` value) within associated registry keys.(Citation: Defending Against Scheduled Task Attacks in Windows Environments)
933.profile: [profile]Scheduled Task (Mon/Tue/Thu/Fri/Sat 11:33 AM) is a specific instance of the MITRE ATT&CK technique Scheduled Task (T1053.005) under the Execution and Persistence tactics for the Windows platform. It involves abusing the Windows Task Scheduler for recurring malicious code execution. Technical mechanics include using utilities like `schtasks`, .NET wrappers, or WMI via `Invoke-CimMethod` and the `PS_ScheduledTask` class. Adversaries can hide tasks by deleting the Security Descriptor registry value or altering registry key metadata to evade detection. This technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including APT29.[/profile]
933.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Scheduled Task (Mon/Tue/Thu/Fri/Sat 11:33 AM)" is a specific instance of the MITRE ATT&CK technique Scheduled Task (T1053.005) under the Execution tactic, primarily for Windows. This technique involves abusing the Windows Task Scheduler to execute malicious code at recurring times, as indicated by the schedule in its name.
