Services run with SYSTEM privileges, enabling privilege escalation, and can be hidden using commands like `sc sdset` to evade standard enumeration methods.

1076.name: Memory Patching
1076.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and used to conduct [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) using [Use Alternate Authentication Material](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550). As well as in-memory techniques, the LSASS process memory can be dumped from the target host and analyzed on a local system. For example, on the target host use procdump: * procdump -ma lsass.exe lsass_dump Locally, mimikatz can be run using: * sekurlsa::Minidump lsassdump.dmp * sekurlsa::logonPasswords Built-in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process exit mechanism can be abused to create a memory dump of `lsass.exe` through Windows Error Reporting (`WerFault.exe`).(Citation: Deep Instinct LSASS) Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into LSASS process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) The following SSPs can be used to access credentials: * Msv: Interactive logons, batch logons, and service logons are done through the MSV authentication package. * Wdigest: The Digest Authentication protocol is designed for use with Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Simple Authentication Security Layer (SASL) exchanges.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) * Kerberos: Preferred for mutual client-server domain authentication in Windows 2000 and later. * CredSSP: Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop Services.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection)
1076.profile: [profile]The entity "Memory Patching" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided data, the core subject is credential access from LSASS memory, which aligns with MITRE technique OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory (T1003.001). This technique falls under the Credential Access tactic and targets the Windows platform. Adversaries harvest credentials from the LSASS process memory using tools like Mimikatz (with commands such as `sekurlsa::logonPasswords`) or by creating memory dumps via utilities like Procdump (`procdump -ma lsass.exe`) or `comsvcs.dll`. The technique is widely used by numerous threat groups, including APT28, APT29, and Lazarus Group, for lateral movement.[/profile]
1076.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Memory Patching is a technique where adversaries modify the in-memory code of a legitimate process to alter its behavior or introduce malicious functionality, often to evade detection or disable security mechanisms. It is a sub-technique of Process Injection (T1055) within the Defense Evasion tactic. This method operates by directly writing to a process's allocated memory regions, such as overwriting function instructions or data structures, to redirect execution flow without touching the disk-based executable file. It is commonly used to bypass hooks, disable security software, or gain persistence within a compromised system.

1077.name: Code Injection
1077.profile: [profile]Code Injection is a technique where adversaries execute arbitrary code within a target system or process to evade defenses and potentially gain elevated privileges. It is a sub-technique of Process Injection (T1055) under the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily targeting Windows platforms. Technical mechanics involve writing malicious code into the virtual address space of a separate live process using Windows API calls like VirtualAllocEx and WriteProcessMemory, then invoking it via CreateRemoteThread to load and execute under the guise of a legitimate process, thereby masking the activity from security products.
1077.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Code Injection is a technique where adversaries introduce malicious code into a legitimate process or application to alter its execution flow, often to evade defenses or gain persistence. This can involve methods like Portable Executable (PE) injection using Windows API calls such as VirtualAllocEx and WriteProcessMemory, or DLL injection where a malicious dynamic-link library is loaded into a target process's address space via CreateRemoteThread. These injections allow execution within the context of a trusted process, potentially accessing its memory and resources while masking malicious activity.

1078.name: Process Execution Monitoring
1078.profile: [profile]Process Execution Monitoring is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to be a defensive concept or a potential detection method for adversarial techniques like Process Injection (T1055), Process Hollowing (T1055.012), Thread Execution Hijacking (T1055.003), and Process DoppelgÃ¤nging (T1055.013). These techniques involve executing malicious code within the address space of a legitimate process to evade detection, access system resources, and potentially elevate privileges. Monitoring process execution would therefore focus on detecting anomalous behaviors such as memory manipulation, unexpected thread creation, or the use of specific APIs like `CreateToolhelp32Snapshot`, `VirtualAllocEx`, and `SetThreadContext`.[/profile]
1078.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Process Execution Monitoring is a technique for observing the execution of processes, often to detect malicious activity. The retrieved information focuses on evasion techniques like process injection, hollowing, and doppelgÃ¤nging, where adversaries mask malicious code within legitimate processes to avoid detection. This suggests Process Execution Monitoring is a defensive countermeasure within the Discovery tactic, aimed at identifying these stealthy execution methods by analyzing process behavior and memory anomalies on Windows and other platforms.

1079.name: Command Line Monitoring
1079.profile: [profile]Command Line Monitoring is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; it is likely a defensive or detection concept. Based on the retrieved information, it is contextually related to adversary techniques that manipulate or execute commands to evade monitoring. These include command obfuscation (T1027.010) to hinder signature detection, clearing command history (T1070.003) to remove forensic evidence, indirect command execution (T1202) to bypass security controls, and process argument spoofing (T1564.010) to hide malicious command-line arguments in memory. These associated techniques demonstrate how adversaries actively subvert command-line monitoring defenses.
1079.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Command Line Monitoring is a technique for Discovery, identified as T1057.001 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries monitoring command-line activity on a system to gather information about user behavior, system configuration, and executed processes. This can be achieved by hooking APIs, parsing shell history files like `~/.bash_history` or PowerShell's `ConsoleHost_history.txt`, or using built-in system auditing tools to capture command arguments and sequences, providing insight for further malicious actions.

1084.name: REVIL
1084.uncertain_mes:
A team claiming, they can escalate privileges, among other services, but they do not work with ransomware developers and affiliates (auto-translated by Google from Russian)
Negotiators
1084.profile: [profile]REvil, also known as Sodinokibi, is a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation. It is attributed to the cybercriminal group Pinchy Spider, which has been identified by Russian authorities. The malware is known for its file encryption and data exfiltration capabilities, as evidenced by its file manipulation and logging activities on Windows systems. Its infrastructure and operations have been linked to criminal financial activities.[/profile]
1084.profile_without_enhance: [profile]REvil, also known as Sodinokibi, is a ransomware attributed to the Pinchy Spider group. It operates by deploying dropper files like agent.exe and encrypts victim files, appending extensions such as .4soa3, and leaves ransom notes. Its infrastructure involves encoded droppers and uses specific file paths for its operations, targeting Windows systems.

1085.name: DARKSIDE
1085.uncertain_mes: roughout the last two weeks, the entire cybersecurity community has been riveted by the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack. It is one of the most notable attacks on critical infrastructure of the past few years and has directly and indirectly impacted multiple industries in the U.S economy.
1085.profile: [profile]DARKSIDE, also known as DarkSide Ransomware or DarkSide Hand-Ransomware, is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) operated by the criminal group FIN7. Its key TTPs include establishing a RaaS model for other criminals, maintaining a data leak site for victim extortion, and using stolen funds for activities like charitable donations. It primarily targets critical infrastructure and various industries, with notable impact from the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack in 2021. Its operational timeline includes introduction in August 2020 and formal RaaS establishment by November 2020.[/profile]
1085.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware DARKSIDE, also known as DarkSide Ransomware or DarkSide Hand-Ransomware, is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS). Its key behaviors include operating a RaaS model, establishing a data leak site, and making charitable donations from stolen funds. Its primary target is critical infrastructure, as evidenced by the Colonial Pipeline attack. The group's activity timeline includes its introduction in August 2020 and the formal establishment of its RaaS in November 2020.

1086.name: BLACKMATTER
1086.uncertain_mes:
BlackMatter Ransomware v2.0
Contents
- BlackMatter Ransomware v2.0
-
Static Code Analysis
- Anti-Analysis: Dynamic API Resolving
- Anti-Analysis: String Encryption
- Anti-Analysis: String Comparison

- Command-line Arguments
- Pre-Encryption Setup
- Safe Mode Reboot
- Setting Ransom Wallpaper
- Run-Once Mutex

1086.profile: [profile]BLACKMATTER, also known as blackmatter, is a ransomware family. It is attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include anti-analysis techniques like dynamic API resolving and string encryption, command-line argument parsing, pre-encryption setup, safe mode rebooting, setting a ransom wallpaper, using a run-once mutex, wiping recycle bins, and deleting shadow copies via WMI. It targets Windows platforms, with a known Linux variant. It is related to or shares infrastructure with entities like Darkside and JSSLoader, with the latter also linked to the Anunak group.[/profile]
1086.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BLACKMATTER, also known as blackmatter, is a ransomware family with a Linux variant. Its technical behaviors include anti-analysis techniques like dynamic API resolving and string encryption, command-line argument parsing, pre-encryption setup, safe mode rebooting, setting a ransom wallpaper, using a run-once mutex, wiping recycle bins, and deleting shadow copies via WMI. It has been associated with the groups anunak and Darkside.

1087.name: ALPHV
1087.profile: [profile]ALPHV, also known as BlackCat, BlackCat Ransomware, ALPHV-ng, and Noberus, is a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation. It is associated with the intrusion set FIN7 and groups including Alpha Spider, RansomHub, and Vanilla Tempest. Its key technical behavior is file encryption for extortion. The malware is designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system by creating a registry key to automatically launch a copy on every system startup. Its target platforms are Windows systems.
1087.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ALPHV, also known as BlackCat, BlackCat Ransomware, ALPHV-ng, and Noberus, is a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) malware. It is attributed to groups including Alpha Spider, RansomHub, and Vanilla Tempest. Its key technical behavior is file encryption for extortion. It targets multiple platforms and operates as a hand-operated ransomware variant.

1088.name: POWERPLANT
1088.uncertain_mes:
FIN7 Power Hour: Adversary Archaeology and the Evolution of FIN7
Mandiant
Written by: Bryce Abdo, Zander Work, Ioana Teaca, Brendan McKeague
1088.profile: [profile]POWERPLANT is a malware attributed to the FIN7 cybercrime group. It is a custom backdoor used exclusively by FIN7, as assessed through operational merges. Its technical behaviors include establishing persistence and facilitating remote access for the group's intrusions, primarily targeting Windows-based systems in corporate environments for financial theft and data exfiltration.
1088.profile_without_enhance: [profile]POWERPLANT is a malware attributed to the FIN7 cybercriminal group. It is likely the only operator using this malware, as assessed from its usage patterns into 2021. This assessment is supported by analysis of related tools like BOATLAUNCH and TERMITE, which also link its activity to FIN7.

1089.name: CROWVIEW
1089.profile: [profile]CROWVIEW, also known as boatlaunch, is a malware attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include the ability to house an embedded payload, self-delete, support additional command-line arguments, and store a unique configuration. It is related to the BIRDWATCH malware family, from which it differs by these enhanced capabilities.[/profile]
1089.profile_without_enhance: [profile]CROWVIEW is a malware family related to BIRDWATCH (JssLoader) and attributed to the FIN7 threat group. It shares a codebase with BIRDWATCH but is a distinct .NET-based loader variant. Key technical behaviors include the ability to house an embedded payload, support self-deletion, accept additional command-line arguments, and store a slightly different configuration. Its target platform is Windows systems, and it functions as a loader to deploy further payloads.

1090.name: FOWLGAZE
1090.profile: [profile]FOWLGAZE, also known as JssLoader, is a malware attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. It operates as a data collection tool, gathering system information such as username, hostname, and elevated privilege status, formatting this data into a specific JSON structure. Its key technical behavior includes executing PowerShell commands to perform this reconnaissance. The malware targets Windows platforms, as indicated by its environment variable checks and command usage. It is directly connected to the BIRDWATCH malware within the same threat infrastructure.[/profile]
1090.profile_without_enhance: [profile]FOWLGAZE, also known as JssLoader, is a malware family attributed to the FIN7 threat group. It functions as a loader, collecting system information like username, hostname, and elevated privilege status into a JSON format for exfiltration, and is used to deploy additional payloads on targeted Windows systems.

1091.name: LOADOUT
1091.profile: [profile]LOADOUT, also known as boatlaunch, termite, and griffon, is a malware attributed to the FIN7 cybercriminal group. Its key technical behaviors are detailed in the 2020 Activity Brief titled "Heavy on the LOADOUT". The malware is associated with FIN7's intrusion campaigns.[/profile]
1091.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LOADOUT is a malware entity associated with the FIN7 cybercrime group, as indicated in activity briefs from 2020. It is linked to other malware tools such as BOATLAUNCH, TERMITE, and GRIFFON, which were part of the same campaign. The specific technical behaviors, target platforms, and infrastructure details for LOADOUT are not detailed in the provided context.

1092.name: GRIFFON
1092.uncertain_mes: [GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) is a JavaScript backdoor used by [FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046). (Citation: SecureList Griffon May 2019)
1092.profile: [profile]GRIFFON, also known as griffon, is a JavaScript backdoor attributed to the FIN7 cybercriminal group. It is used to establish command and control (C2) communication, with its infrastructure analysis revealing overlaps with fake company websites used for operational purposes. The malware targets systems where JavaScript can be executed, primarily for backdoor access and data exfiltration.
1092.profile_without_enhance: [profile]GRIFFON, also known as griffon, is a JavaScript backdoor attributed to the FIN7 cybercriminal group. It operates by establishing command and control (C2) infrastructure, with its infrastructure analysis revealing overlaps with fake company websites used as a front. The malware targets systems by creating persistence through Windows registry keys for automatic execution on system startup. Its primary platform is Windows-based systems.

1093.name: BEACON
1093.profile: [profile]BEACON is a payload associated with Cobalt Strike, a commercial penetration testing framework widely adopted by threat actors. It is attributed to the financially motivated group FIN7, among others. Its key technical behaviors include acting as a command and control (C2) beacon, communicating with infrastructure like fuvataren.com and using HTTP POST requests for data exfiltration. It targets Windows platforms and is linked to infrastructure such as IPs 162.223.31[.]184, 173.237.190[.]2, and 45.141.152[.]18.[/profile]
1093.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BEACON is a malware type associated with Cobalt Strike, used by various APT groups including APT29, APT32, APT41, UNC2452, and others like FIN6, FIN7, and Mustang Panda. It functions as a CnC beacon, communicating via HTTP and TCP protocols, and has been observed in infrastructure linked to SUNBURST and TEARDROP campaigns, indicating its use in sophisticated, multi-malware operations primarily targeting Windows platforms for data exfiltration and persistent remote access.

1094.name: CARBANAK
1094.uncertain_mes: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) is a full-featured, remote backdoor used by a group of the same name ([Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008)). It is intended for espionage, data exfiltration, and providing remote access to infected machines. (Citation: Kaspersky Carbanak) (Citation: FireEye CARBANAK June 2017)
1094.profile: [profile]CARBANAK, also known as Carbanak, is a full-featured remote backdoor used for espionage, data exfiltration, and remote access, attributed to the groups FIN7 and Carbanak. Key technical behaviors include its use as a backdoor and its association with related malware like Bateleur and Tinymet, which utilize SSL certificates and beacon to command-and-control infrastructure, primarily targeting financial institutions.
1094.profile_without_enhance: [profile]CARBANAK, also known as carbanak, is a malware attributed to the cybercriminal group FIN7, with earlier activity also linked to the group Anunak. It is associated with downloaders like Tinymet and backdoors such as Bateleur, which communicate via SSL-encrypted command and control (CnC) beacons to receive payloads. The malware primarily targets financial institutions for data exfiltration and financial theft.

1095.name: BOATLAUNCH
1095.uncertain_mes:
FIN7 Power Hour: Adversary Archaeology and the Evolution of FIN7
Mandiant
Written by: Bryce Abdo, Zander Work, Ioana Teaca, Brendan McKeague
1095.profile: [profile]BOATLAUNCH, also known as boatlaunch, is attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is to patch PowerShell processes on infected systems to bypass the Windows AntiMalware Scan Interface (AMSI), functioning as a helper module sent from FIN7 POWERPLANT controllers during intrusion operations. Its target platform is Windows.
1095.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BOATLAUNCH, also known as boatlaunch, is a utility attributed to the FIN7 group. Its key technical behavior is to bypass the Windows Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) by patching PowerShell processes on infected systems, a technique used for defense evasion during intrusion operations. It targets Windows platforms and is deployed from FIN7's POWERPLANT controllers as a helper module.

1096.name: EASYLOOK
1096.profile: [profile]EASYLOOK is a reconnaissance utility malware attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set, used since at least 2019. It captures a wide range of system data from infected hosts, including operating system version, registration key, system name, username, domain information, and hardware specifications.
1096.profile_without_enhance: [profile]EASYLOOK, also known as the EASYLOOK Module, is a reconnaissance utility attributed to the FIN7 cybercriminal group and used since at least 2019. Its key technical behavior is to capture a wide range of system data, including OS version, registration key, system name, username, domain information, and hardware specifications. It targets Windows systems and employs the defense evasion technique of Bypassing AMSI to prevent detection of its script-based components.

1097.name: BIRDWATCH
1097.profile: [profile]BIRDWATCH, also known as JssLoader, is a malware family attributed to the FIN7 threat group. It is a .NET-based loader with multiple variants, including the distinct CROWVIEW family. Its key technical behaviors involve loading and executing additional payloads, with infrastructure connections to related malware families like FOWLGAZE. It primarily targets Windows platforms.
1097.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BIRDWATCH, also known as JssLoader, is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to the criminal group FIN7. Its key technical behaviors include command-and-control (C2) communication via HTTP POST and GET requests, and it collects system information like username and hostname into JSON for exfiltration. The malware primarily targets the Windows platform. It is the foundational family for more advanced variants like CROWVIEW (boatlaunch/termite) and is associated with big game hunting ransomware campaigns, having been used alongside REvil and Darkside.[/profile]

1098.name: Maze
1098.uncertain_mes: [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) ransomware, previously known as "ChaCha", was discovered in May 2019. In addition to encrypting files on victim machines for impact, [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) operators conduct information stealing campaigns prior to encryption and post the information online to extort affected companies.(Citation: FireEye Maze May 2020)(Citation: McAfee Maze March 2020)(Citation: Sophos Maze VM September 2020)
1098.profile: [profile]Maze, also known as Maze Locker, MazeLocker, ChaCha, or ChaChaLocker, is a ransomware and doxware discovered in May 2019. It is attributed to groups including FIN7 and FIN6. Its key behaviors involve conducting information-stealing campaigns prior to file encryption and then posting stolen data online to extort victims. The malware is deployed via malicious links and attachments in emails, often facilitated by cybercriminal enterprises distributing banking trojans. Its infrastructure involves multiple download variants for file transfer.
1098.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Maze, also known as Maze Locker, MazeLocker, ChaCha, or ChaChaLocker, is a ransomware and doxware attributed to groups like FIN6 and TA2101. It is distributed via malicious links and attachments in email campaigns, often leveraging cybercriminal enterprises for initial access. Its key behavior involves encrypting files and exfiltrating data to pressure victims, with numerous download variants identified. The malware primarily targets Windows systems.]

1099.name: RYUK
1099.uncertain_mes: [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) is a ransomware designed to target enterprise environments that has been used in attacks since at least 2018. [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) shares code similarities with Hermes ransomware.(Citation: CrowdStrike Ryuk January 2019)(Citation: FireEye Ryuk and Trickbot January 2019)(Citation: FireEye FIN6 Apr 2019)
1099.profile: [profile]Ryuk is a ransomware targeting enterprise environments, active since at least 2018 and sharing code similarities with Hermes ransomware. It is attributed to groups including FIN6, Wizard Spider, Grim Spider, and UNC1878. Key technical behaviors involve using tools like AdFind for Active Directory reconnaissance, collecting files such as ad_users.txt and ad_computers.txt, and leveraging infrastructure like TrickBot for distribution. It primarily targets Windows platforms and is linked to the Conti ransomware through affiliate networks.[/profile]
1099.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RYUK, also known as ryuk, is a ransomware attributed to groups including FIN6, Grim Spider, UNC1878, and Wizard Spider. It is linked to the Conti ransomware family and was historically distributed via the TrickBot botnet. Key technical behaviors include using the AdFind tool for Active Directory reconnaissance, saving enumerated data such as users, computers, and trust relationships to temporary directories like %TEMP%\ryuk\af\. Its primary target is Windows environments, focusing on enterprise networks for data exfiltration and encryption.

1100.name: BIRDWATCH variant
1100.profile: [profile]BIRDWATCH variant is a malware family also known collectively as JssLoader, with distinct variants like CROWVIEW being tracked separately. It is attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set and is a .NET-based malware loader. Key technical behaviors include code differences from the prototypical BIRDWATCH that warrant separate clustering, and it operates on Windows platforms as part of FIN7's campaigns.
1100.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BIRDWATCH variant is a malware family also known collectively as JssLoader, with distinct variations tracked as separate code families such as CROWVIEW. It is attributed to groups including FIN7 and ANUNAK, and is a .NET-based loader with significant code differences between its variants.

1101.name: TAKEOUT
1101.profile: [profile]TAKEOUT is a malware family, also known as a PowerShell script used for in-memory execution, with variations differing in how they extract the next stage via a "$body" parameter. It is attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set (a financially motivated cybercrime group) and has also been associated with the Anunak group. Its key technical behavior involves executing a PowerShell script to load subsequent payloads directly into memory. Target platforms are Windows systems, leveraging PowerShell for execution.[profile]
1101.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TAKEOUT is a malware family, also referred to as a Takeout script. It is attributed to the Anunak group. Its key technical behavior involves being a PowerShell script that serves as a loader, extracting and executing the next stage payload in-memory, often by reading from an embedded "$body" parameter. The target platform is Windows systems.

1102.name: boutique PowerShell-based loaders
1102.uncertain_mes: powershell_web_backdoor This is a very simple powershell web backdoor Usage: hxxp://127.0.0.1:9999/backdoor/?cmd=<Insert Your powershell compatible base64 encoded command here
1102.profile: [profile]Boutique PowerShell-based loaders are a class of malware, also known as powershell_web_backdoor, attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. Key technical behaviors include using simple web backdoors that execute base64-encoded PowerShell commands via HTTP GET requests to a specified URL (e.g., hxxp://127.0.0.1:9999/backdoor/?cmd=). These loaders are a dominant tool for on-system interactions within FIN7 operations, targeting Windows platforms through PowerShell execution.
1102.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Boutique PowerShell-based loaders are custom loaders used by the FIN7 threat group, which demonstrates a strong operational preference for these tools during on-system interactions. They are associated with campaigns like Boatlaunch and are used as variants for other malware families like Remcos and AzorUlt, which are linked to groups including APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050. These loaders primarily target Windows platforms via PowerShell execution.

1103.name: PowerShell
1103.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)
1103.profile: [profile]PowerShell is a Windows command-line interface and scripting environment, designated as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.001 under the Execution tactic. Adversaries abuse it to execute code, download and run executables from the internet, and perform discovery. It can be invoked directly via powershell.exe or indirectly through the System.Management.Automation DLL. Common cmdlets include Start-Process to run executables and Invoke-Command for local or remote execution, with offensive frameworks like Empire and PowerSploit built upon it.[/profile]
1103.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "PowerShell" is a Windows command-line and scripting environment, officially mapped to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.001 under the Execution tactic. Adversaries abuse it to execute code, perform discovery, and download payloads, using cmdlets like Start-Process and Invoke-Command for local or remote execution. It can run scripts directly from memory, bypassing disk, and its functionality can be invoked without powershell.exe via the System.Management.Automation DLL. Numerous threat groups, including APT29 and Lazarus, utilize this technique, often employing tools like Empire and PowerSploit.

1104.name: software supply chain compromise
1104.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate application software prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise. Supply chain compromise of software can take place in a number of ways, including manipulation of the application source code, manipulation of the update/distribution mechanism for that software, or replacing compiled releases with a modified version.

Targeting may be specific to a desired victim set or may be distributed to a broad set of consumers but only move on to additional tactics on specific victims.(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011)
1104.profile: [profile]The technique "Compromise Software Supply Chain" is identified as MITRE ATT&CK T1195.002 under the Initial Access tactic. It involves adversaries manipulating application software before it reaches end-users to compromise systems or data. Specific technical mechanics include tampering with the application's source code, hijacking its update or distribution mechanism, or replacing legitimate compiled releases with maliciously modified versions. This technique is associated with threat groups such as FIN7, APT41, and Sandworm Team, and it can be broadly distributed but often activates further malicious actions only on specific, intended victims.
1104.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Software Supply Chain Compromise is a technique identified as T1195.002 under the Initial Access tactic, targeting multiple platforms. It involves adversaries manipulating application software before it reaches the end user to achieve compromise. This is executed by tampering with the application's source code, hijacking its update or distribution mechanisms, or substituting legitimate compiled releases with maliciously modified versions. Attackers may broadly distribute tainted software but only activate follow-on actions against specific, intended victims. Groups like APT41, Sandworm Team, and FIN7 have been associated with this method.

1105.name: stolen credentials
1105.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather credentials that can be used during targeting. Account credentials gathered by adversaries may be those directly associated with the target victim organization or attempt to take advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Adversaries may gather credentials from potential victims in various ways, such as direct elicitation via [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then add malicious content designed to collect website authentication cookies from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) (Citation: Register Deloitte)(Citation: Register Uber)(Citation: Detectify Slack Tokens)(Citation: Forbes GitHub Creds)(Citation: GitHub truffleHog)(Citation: GitHub Gitrob)(Citation: CNET Leaks) Where multi-factor authentication (MFA) based on out-of-band communications is in use, adversaries may compromise a service provider to gain access to MFA codes and one-time passwords (OTP).(Citation: Okta Scatter Swine 2022)

Credential information may also be exposed to adversaries via leaks to online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Search Engines](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/002), breach dumps, code repositories, etc.). Adversaries may purchase credentials from dark web markets, such as Russian Market and 2easy, or through access to Telegram channels that distribute logs from infostealer malware.(Citation: Bleeping Computer 2easy 2021)(Citation: SecureWorks Infostealers 2023)(Citation: Bleeping Computer Stealer Logs 2023)

Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133) or [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078)).
1105.profile: [profile]Stolen Credentials (T1589.001) is a Reconnaissance technique used across multiple platforms. Adversaries gather credentials for initial access or other operations by phishing for information, compromising websites to steal authentication cookies, purchasing them from dark web markets like Russian Market and 2easy, or harvesting them from public data leaks and infostealer malware logs. Groups such as APT28, LAPSUS$, and Chimera have used this technique, which can enable follow-on actions like establishing Valid Accounts for access.[/profile]
1105.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "stolen credentials" is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, primarily associated with the Credential Access tactic. It involves adversaries obtaining authentication materials, such as passwords or hashes, through various means including phishing, purchasing from dark web markets, or extracting them from compromised systems via tools like Mimikatz. These credentials are then used for initial access, lateral movement, or privilege escalation within a target network.

1106.name: phishing techniques
1106.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
1106.profile: [profile]Phishing, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, is an electronically delivered social engineering attack targeting various platforms. It involves sending messages with malicious attachments or links to execute code, often employing email spoofing, thread hijacking, or directing victims to call numbers for malware download. Evasive techniques include manipulating email headers from compromised accounts. Groups like FIN7, Sea Turtle, and Kimsuky are known to use this method.[/profile]
1106.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Phishing Techniques is a broad category of electronically delivered social engineering attacks, not a single MITRE ATT&CK technique. It encompasses tactics like Initial Access and Credential Access. Common technical mechanics include sending emails with malicious attachments or links, using third-party services like social media, spoofing sender identities, and employing "callback phishing" where victims are directed to call a number to download malware or divulge information. It often involves evasive actions such as manipulating email headers or hijacking existing email threads.

1107.name: data theft extortion
1107.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may steal monetary resources from targets through extortion, social engineering, technical theft, or other methods aimed at their own financial gain at the expense of the availability of these resources for victims. Financial theft is the ultimate objective of several popular campaign types including extortion by ransomware,(Citation: FBI-ransomware) business email compromise (BEC) and fraud,(Citation: FBI-BEC) "pig butchering,"(Citation: wired-pig butchering) bank hacking,(Citation: DOJ-DPRK Heist) and exploiting cryptocurrency networks.(Citation: BBC-Ronin) 

Adversaries may [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586) to conduct unauthorized transfers of funds.(Citation: Internet crime report 2022) In the case of business email compromise or email fraud, an adversary may utilize [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656) of a trusted entity. Once the social engineering is successful, victims can be deceived into sending money to financial accounts controlled by an adversary.(Citation: FBI-BEC) This creates the potential for multiple victims (i.e., compromised accounts as well as the ultimate monetary loss) in incidents involving financial theft.(Citation: VEC)

Extortion by ransomware may occur, for example, when an adversary demands payment from a victim after [Data Encrypted for Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486) (Citation: NYT-Colonial) and [Exfiltration](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0010) of data, followed by threatening to leak sensitive data to the public unless payment is made to the adversary.(Citation: Mandiant-leaks) Adversaries may use dedicated leak sites to distribute victim data.(Citation: Crowdstrike-leaks)

Due to the potentially immense business impact of financial theft, an adversary may abuse the possibility of financial theft and seeking monetary gain to divert attention from their true goals such as [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) and business disruption.(Citation: AP-NotPetya)
1107.profile: [profile]Financial Theft, designated T1657, is an adversary objective within the Impact tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves stealing monetary resources through methods like unauthorized fund transfers via compromised accounts, social engineering such as business email compromise to deceive victims into sending money, and ransomware extortion where payment is demanded after data encryption and exfiltration, often with threats to leak data via dedicated leak sites. Associated groups include FIN7, Scattered Spider, and INC Ransom.[/profile]
1107.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Data Theft Extortion is a technique where adversaries steal sensitive data and then threaten to release it publicly unless a ransom is paid. This tactic is commonly executed as part of ransomware campaigns, where stolen data is used as additional leverage after encrypting victim systems. The process involves the exfiltration of data, often over command and control channels, followed by extortion demands, with adversaries sometimes using dedicated leak sites to publish the data to coerce payment.

1108.name: ransomware deployment
1108.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gain access to and use centralized software suites installed within an enterprise to execute commands and move laterally through the network. Configuration management and software deployment applications may be used in an enterprise network or cloud environment for routine administration purposes. These systems may also be integrated into CI/CD pipelines. Examples of such solutions include: SCCM, HBSS, Altiris, AWS Systems Manager, Microsoft Intune, Azure Arc, and GCP Deployment Manager.  

Access to network-wide or enterprise-wide endpoint management software may enable an adversary to achieve remote code execution on all connected systems. The access may be used to laterally move to other systems, gather information, or cause a specific effect, such as wiping the hard drives on all endpoints.

SaaS-based configuration management services may allow for broad [Cloud Administration Command](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1651) on cloud-hosted instances, as well as the execution of arbitrary commands on on-premises endpoints. For example, Microsoft Configuration Manager allows Global or Intune Administrators to run scripts as SYSTEM on on-premises devices joined to Entra ID.(Citation: SpecterOps Lateral Movement from Azure to On-Prem AD 2020) Such services may also utilize [Web Protocols](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/001) to communicate back to adversary owned infrastructure.(Citation: Mitiga Security Advisory: SSM Agent as Remote Access Trojan)

Network infrastructure devices may also have configuration management tools that can be similarly abused by adversaries.(Citation: Fortinet Zero-Day and Custom Malware Used by Suspected Chinese Actor in Espionage Operation)

The permissions required for this action vary by system configuration; local credentials may be sufficient with direct access to the third-party system, or specific domain credentials may be required. However, the system may require an administrative account to log in or to access specific functionality.
1108.profile: [profile]The entity "Software Deployment Tools" is mapped to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1072 under the Execution tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and Cloud platforms. Adversaries abuse centralized enterprise software suites like SCCM, Microsoft Intune, or AWS Systems Manager to achieve remote code execution on all connected systems, enabling lateral movement, data gathering, or destructive actions such as mass file encryption for ransomware deployment. This is distinct from application deployment software (T1017) and is associated with groups like APT32 and Sandworm Team.[/profile]
1108.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "ransomware deployment" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; it is a high-level concept. Based on the retrieved context, it involves the malicious installation of ransomware, which is a specific application of software deployment. This action is typically part of the Impact tactic, with the goal of encrypting victim data (as described in T1486) to extort payment. Deployment mechanics can include abusing enterprise application deployment systems (like T1017) to achieve remote code execution across a network, often requiring administrative access. The ransomware payload itself then performs data encryption for impact.

1109.name: intrusion tradecraft
1109.profile: [profile]The entity "intrusion tradecraft" is a broad, non-standard term not directly mapped to a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique ID. Based on retrieved context, it encompasses adversary actions to minimize their footprint during or after an intrusion. This includes deleting files left by malware or tools using OS commands like `del` on Windows or `rm` on Linux, a practice associated with groups like FIN7. It also involves techniques like adding junk data to command and control traffic to hinder detection.[/profile]
1109.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "intrusion tradecraft" is a broad attack pattern not directly mapped to a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID. Based on retrieved context, it encompasses adversary actions to minimize their footprint and evade detection during or after an intrusion. This includes techniques like deleting files (e.g., using `del` or `rm` commands) to remove traces of malware or tools, and adding junk data to command and control traffic to obscure its content and hinder analysis.

1110.name: modus operandi
1110.profile: [profile]The entity "modus operandi" is a general concept describing an actor's characteristic methods, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is associated with the intrusion set FIN7. The related content describes technical capabilities that could form part of an actor's modus operandi, including using custom archival methods like XOR encryption for data (T1560.003), employing custom command and control protocols (T1094), and developing in-house malware or exploits (T1587). These techniques illustrate the tailored, self-reliant operational patterns typical of advanced persistent threats.
1110.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "modus operandi" is a general concept for describing an adversary's characteristic methods of operation, rather than a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique with a designated ID. It encompasses the recurring tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) that define an attacker's behavior. Based on related content, this can involve developing custom capabilities like malware or protocols (as seen in T1587 and T1094) and employing unique data manipulation methods such as custom compression or encryption for exfiltration (as in T1560.003), which are often reused across campaigns by specific threat groups.

1111.name: TTPs
1111.profile: [profile]The entity "TTPs" is a general concept referring to Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures used by adversaries. Based on retrieved information, specific related techniques include Environmental Keying (T1480.001), a sub-technique of Execution Guardrails, which uses cryptography to constrain malware execution by deriving decryption keys from target-specific environmental values like network shares, software versions, or IP addresses to evade detection and analysis. This technique has been associated with groups like APT41 and Equation. Another related technique is multilayer encryption (T1079) for command and control, tunneling custom encryption within protocols like HTTPS. The general concept is linked to intrusion sets such as FIN7 and APT34.[/profile]
1111.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The provided entity name "TTPs" is a generic category, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. The retrieved information describes three distinct techniques: multilayer encryption (T1079) for command and control, threat intelligence vendor data search (T1597.001) for reconnaissance, and environmental keying (T1480.001) for execution guardrails. Each uses specific technical mechanics, such as tunneling custom encryption within standard protocols, querying private vendor feeds, or deriving cryptographic keys from target-specific system values to constrain payload execution and evade analysis.

1112.name: Phishing campaigns
1112.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
1112.profile: [profile]Phishing, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, operates across multiple platforms. This technique involves sending electronic messages, such as emails with malicious attachments or links, to execute code on victim systems. It employs social engineering by posing as a trusted source and uses evasive methods like email spoofing or thread hijacking. The intrusion-set FIN7 is associated with this technique. It is distinct from T1598 (Phishing for Information), which focuses on credential harvesting rather than code execution.[/profile]
1112.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Phishing campaigns, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566 under the Initial Access tactic, target multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries sending fraudulent electronic messages, often via email or social media, containing malicious attachments or links to execute code. Campaigns can be broad or targeted (spearphishing), employ social engineering by posing as trusted sources, and use evasive methods like email spoofing or thread hijacking to increase success rates.

1113.name: unique PowerShell commands
1113.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)
1113.profile: [profile]This is the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.001, named Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell, under the Execution tactic for Windows. It involves abusing the built-in PowerShell environment to execute commands and scripts, using cmdlets like Start-Process and Invoke-Command to run executables or commands locally and remotely. It can download and run payloads from the internet, execute them directly in memory, and can be run without the powershell.exe binary by leveraging the underlying System.Management.Automation DLL. It is associated with numerous threat groups, including FIN7.[/profile]
1113.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "unique PowerShell commands" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it refers to the adversarial use of PowerShell for execution, which aligns with the standard technique Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell (T1059.001). This technique falls under the Execution tactic on Windows platforms. Adversaries leverage PowerShell's capabilities, such as using cmdlets like Start-Process to run executables or Invoke-Command for local/remote command execution, to perform actions including code execution and information discovery. It can also be used to download and run payloads from the internet, often executed directly in memory to avoid disk artifacts. Execution can occur without the powershell.exe binary by interfacing with the underlying System.Management.Automation assembly.

1114.name: Bypass AMSI
1114.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may modify file attributes and subvert Gatekeeper functionality to evade user prompts and execute untrusted programs. Gatekeeper is a set of technologies that act as layer of Appleâ€™s security model to ensure only trusted applications are executed on a host. Gatekeeper was built on top of File Quarantine in Snow Leopard (10.6, 2009) and has grown to include Code Signing, security policy compliance, Notarization, and more. Gatekeeper also treats applications running for the first time differently than reopened applications.(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany Quarantine and the flag)(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany apple notarization )

Based on an opt-in system, when files are downloaded an extended attribute (xattr) called `com.apple.quarantine` (also known as a quarantine flag) can be set on the file by the application performing the download. Launch Services opens the application in a suspended state. For first run applications with the quarantine flag set, Gatekeeper executes the following functions:

1. Checks extended attribute â€“ Gatekeeper checks for the quarantine flag, then provides an alert prompt to the user to allow or deny execution.(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)

2. Checks System Policies - Gatekeeper checks the system security policy, allowing execution of apps downloaded from either just the App Store or the App Store and identified developers.

3. Code Signing â€“ Gatekeeper checks for a valid code signature from an Apple Developer ID.

4. Notarization - Using the `api.apple-cloudkit.com` API, Gatekeeper reaches out to Apple servers to verify or pull down the notarization ticket and ensure the ticket is not revoked. Users can override notarization, which will result in a prompt of executing an â€œunauthorized appâ€ and the security policy will be modified.

Adversaries can subvert one or multiple security controls within Gatekeeper checks through logic errors (e.g. [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211)), unchecked file types, and external libraries. For example, prior to macOS 13 Ventura, code signing and notarization checks were only conducted on first launch, allowing adversaries to write malicious executables to previously opened applications in order to bypass Gatekeeper security checks.(Citation: theevilbit gatekeeper bypass 2021)(Citation: Application Bundle Manipulation Brandon Dalton)

Applications and files loaded onto the system from a USB flash drive, optical disk, external hard drive, from a drive shared over the local network, or using the curl command may not set the quarantine flag. Additionally, it is possible to avoid setting the quarantine flag using [Drive-by Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189).
1114.profile: [profile]Bypass AMSI is a Windows-specific defense evasion technique (T1562.001) within the MITRE ATT&CK framework. It subverts the Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) by patching its in-memory functions, using reflective DLL loading, or obfuscating script content to prevent signature-based detection. Associated malware includes BOATLAUNCH and EASYLOOK, and it has been used by the FIN7 intrusion set. The technique allows malicious scripts, particularly PowerShell, to execute without being scanned or blocked by AMSI-integrated security products.
1114.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bypass AMSI is a defense evasion technique (T1562.001) targeting Windows systems. It works by disabling or interfering with the Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) to prevent script-based malware detection. Methods include patching AMSI.dll in memory, using reflection to modify the AMSI context, or employing obfuscation to bypass signature checks, allowing malicious PowerShell, .NET, or VBScript to execute undetected.

1115.name: System Information Collection
1115.uncertain_mes: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture. Adversaries may use this information to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This behavior is distinct from [Local Storage Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1680) which is an adversary's discovery of local drive, disks and/or volumes. Tools such as [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) can be used to gather detailed system information. If running with privileged access, a breakdown of system data can be gathered through the systemsetup configuration tool on macOS. Adversaries may leverage a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to gather detailed system information (e.g. show version).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A) On ESXi servers, threat actors may gather system information from various esxcli utilities, such as `system hostname get` and `system version get`.(Citation: Crowdstrike Hypervisor Jackpotting Pt 2 2021)(Citation: Varonis) Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud providers such as AWS, GCP, and Azure allow access to instance and virtual machine information via APIs. Successful authenticated API calls can return data such as the operating system platform and status of a particular instance or the model view of a virtual machine.(Citation: Amazon Describe Instance)(Citation: Google Instances Resource)(Citation: Microsoft Virutal Machine API) [System Information Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082) combined with information gathered from other forms of discovery and reconnaissance can drive payload development and concealment.(Citation: OSX.FairyTale)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)
1115.profile: [profile]System Information Discovery (T1082) is a Discovery tactic technique used across Windows, macOS, Linux, Network, IaaS, and Containers platforms. It involves adversaries collecting detailed OS and hardware data like version, patches, and architecture to inform follow-on actions. Specific technical mechanics include using tools like Systeminfo on Windows, the `systemsetup` command on macOS, CLI commands like `show version` on network devices, and `esxcli` utilities on ESXi servers. Cloud instance metadata can be gathered via provider APIs. This technique is employed by numerous threat groups, including FIN7.
1115.profile_without_enhance: [profile]System Information Collection is the technique of gathering detailed OS and hardware data, including version, patches, and architecture, to inform follow-on actions. This can be achieved using tools like `systeminfo` on Windows, the `systemsetup` configuration tool on macOS with privileged access, or network device CLI commands like `show version`. On ESXi servers, commands such as `system hostname get` and `system version get` are used, while cloud APIs (AWS, GCP, Azure) can be queried for instance and virtual machine information.

1116.name: Windows process chains
1116.profile: [profile]Windows Process Chains is a technique used to execute malicious code by chaining together legitimate Windows processes, often to evade detection. It involves creating sequences of processes where each process spawns the next, masking the execution of malicious payloads within seemingly benign process trees. This method can bypass security tools that monitor individual processes but not their parent-child relationships. The intrusion-set FIN7 has been associated with using this technique.
1116.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Windows process chains" is not a formally defined MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to describe a behavior where adversaries chain together multiple Windows processes to execute malicious code, often for evasion and persistence. This is conceptually related to techniques like Process Injection (T1055) and Process Hollowing (T1055.012), which involve masking execution within legitimate processes. The technical mechanics involve creating or manipulating process sequences, potentially using system utilities or API calls, to obscure the attack chain and maintain a foothold on a compromised Windows system.

1131.name: JssLoader
1131.uncertain_mes: In 2020, CARBON SPIDER began conducting big game hunting (BGH) ransomware campaigns with PINCHY SPIDERâ€™s REvil before introducing Darkside. The adversary later opened up Darkside to affiliates through a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) program, allowing other actors to use the ransomware while paying CARBON SPIDER a portion of the received ransom.
1131.profile: [profile]JSSLoader, also known as jssloader, is a .NET remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to the criminal group FIN7. Its key technical behaviors include command and control (C2) communication via HTTP POST and GET requests. The primary target platform is Windows, as indicated by signatures for Win32/jssLoader. It is associated with the group Anunak and has been actively tracked in infection waves since late 2020.
1131.profile_without_enhance: [profile]JssLoader, also known as BIRDWATCH, is a malware family attributed to the FIN7 threat group. It is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) and loader. Key technical behaviors include command-and-control (C2) communication via HTTP POST and GET requests, as detailed in specific ET and ETPRO signatures. Its primary function is to deploy additional payloads within targeted Windows systems.

1132.name: Discovery
1132.profile: [profile]The entity "Discovery" is a broad tactic within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, encompassing techniques for gathering information about a system or network. Specific techniques include Account Discovery (T1087), Process Discovery (T1057), and Software Discovery (T1518), which involve using commands like `ps`, `Get-Process`, or APIs to enumerate users, running processes, and installed applications. Other related techniques cover discovering internet connectivity, permission groups, cloud storage objects, and peripheral devices, all aimed at understanding the environment for follow-on actions.
1132.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The input refers to the MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Discovery, which is not a specific technique but a category (TA0007) encompassing techniques for gathering system and network information. This tactic includes sub-techniques like Account Discovery (T1087), Process Discovery (T1057), and Software Discovery (T1518), which adversaries use to understand the environment, identify security measures, and shape follow-on actions such as lateral movement or privilege escalation. Common methods involve built-in OS commands (e.g., `ps`, `tasklist`, `Get-Process`) and cloud APIs to enumerate users, running processes, and installed software.

1133.name: Collection
1133.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may target user email to collect sensitive information. Emails may contain sensitive data, including trade secrets or personal information, that can prove valuable to adversaries. Emails may also contain details of ongoing incident response operations, which may allow adversaries to adjust their techniques in order to maintain persistence or evade defenses.(Citation: TrustedSec OOB Communications)(Citation: CISA AA20-352A 2021) Adversaries can collect or forward email from mail servers or clients.
1133.profile: [profile]Email Collection, designated as T1114, is a Collection tactic technique used across multiple platforms. Adversaries target email from mail servers or clients to gather sensitive data, including trade secrets or incident response details, which can inform their ongoing operations. Specific sub-techniques involve collecting local Outlook data files (.ost, .pst) or accessing remote services like Exchange, Office 365, or Google Workspace, often using tools like MailSniper for automated searching. This technique has been associated with groups including Silent Librarian, Scattered Spider, Ember Bear, and Magic Hound.
1133.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Collection is a high-level adversary tactic within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, encompassing the stage where adversaries gather target data prior to exfiltration. It involves various specific techniques for acquiring information from systems, such as automated collection using scripts to search for and copy data based on criteria like file type, or targeting specific data sources like email from local files (e.g., Outlook .ost/.pst files) or remote servers (e.g., Exchange, Office 365). Adversaries may also search connected removable media for files of interest. This gathered data is often subsequently processed for automated exfiltration.

1135.name: Darkside
1135.uncertain_mes: roughout the last two weeks, the entire cybersecurity community has been riveted by the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack. It is one of the most notable attacks on critical infrastructure of the past few years and has directly and indirectly impacted multiple industries in the U.S economy.
1135.profile: [profile]Darkside, also known as DarkSide, is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) operation. It has been associated with the FIN7 intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is operating as a RaaS platform for affiliates. It was notably used in the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack against critical infrastructure in the United States.[/profile]
1135.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Darkside, also known as DarkSide, is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) operation. It has been used by an unnamed group and is notably linked to the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack. Its key behavior is operating as a hand-ransomware for data exfiltration and encryption for ransom. The target platform is primarily Windows systems. Its infrastructure operates on a RaaS model, providing malware to affiliates for attacks.

1136.profile: [profile]BlackMatter is a ransomware, also known as BlackMatter Ransomware v2.0. It is attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. Key technical behaviors include anti-analysis techniques like dynamic API resolving and string encryption, command-line argument parsing, pre-encryption setup, safe mode rebooting, setting a ransom wallpaper, using a run-once mutex, wiping recycle bins, and deleting shadow copies via WMI. It targets Windows platforms and has a known Linux variant. Associated infrastructure includes the domain paymenthacks[.]com.
1136.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BlackMatter is a ransomware family, also known as BlackMatter Ransomware v2.0. It is associated with the criminal group Anunak. Key technical behaviors include anti-analysis techniques like dynamic API resolving and string encryption, command-line argument parsing, pre-encryption setup actions such as wiping recycle bins and deleting shadow copies via WMI, and setting a ransom wallpaper. It targets Windows platforms, with a known Linux variant. Infrastructure includes the domain paymenthacks[.]com.

1137.profile: [profile]Ransomware, also known as ransomexx, is associated with the intrusion set FIN7. Key technical behaviors include data encryption for extortion, with variants like Maze (ChaCha), Defray777, WastedLocker, and DoppelPaymer. It primarily targets Windows platforms, utilizing techniques such as HTTP-based command and control. The ransomware family is linked to the group Gold Dupont and shares operational similarities with other ransomware like Moisha, which is detected by security vendors under names such as Trojan.Encoder.35760 and Ransom:Win32/Moisha!MSR.
1137.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Ransomware, a broad category of malware, includes specific families such as Moisha Ransomware (also known as Moisha Doxware, detected as Trojan.Encoder.35760, MSIL/Filecoder.Hamster.A, or HEUR:Trojan-Ransom.MSIL.Crypmod.gen) and LockBit (including versions 4.0 and 5.0). Other associated ransomware families are Akira, Anubis Backdoor, Apos, Beast, Bert, BianLian, Black Shrantac, BlackByte, BlackSuit, Brain Cipher, Cactus, Cephalus, Chaos, Cl0p, Cloak, Kyber, Lotok, Lynx, Medusa Locker, Medusa, Morpheus, Nightspire, Nitrogen, OblivionTea, Obscura, PEAR, PSAUX, and Pay2Key. These malware families primarily target Windows systems to encrypt files and demand ransom.

1138.name: BadUSB Devices
1138.profile: [profile]BadUSB Devices is a physical attack vector. It is attributed to the cybercriminal group FIN7, which has used these devices to target US companies for initial access, often to subsequently deploy ransomware. A related capability, seen in malware like MagicRAT, involves enumerating and deleting files from specific paths like LOCAL_APPDATA\GDIFONTC, indicating post-compromise data manipulation. The primary target platform is Windows systems via physical USB ports.
1138.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BadUSB Devices are physical USB devices used for initial access and payload delivery, notably by the cybercriminal group FIN7 (also known as Anunak) to target US companies and install ransomware. Related malware like MagicRAT, attributed to Lazarus Group and Silent Chollima, demonstrates USB-based capabilities for file enumeration and deletion, indicating potential shared TTPs for data exfiltration and destruction via compromised USB storage. The primary target platform is Windows systems, leveraging physical media for initial compromise.

1139.name: LilyGO-Branded BadUSB Device
1139.profile: [profile]The LilyGO-Branded BadUSB Device is a malicious USB device. It is associated with the intrusion sets Unknown_Threat_Actor and FIN7. Its key technical behavior is a USB Dump capability that allows attackers to enumerate and delete files at the specific path "LOCAL_APPDATA\GDIFONTC". This capability is also shared by the malware families MagicRat and TigerRat, which are linked to groups like Lazarus Group and Silent Chollima. The device targets systems via physical USB interface.[/profile]
1139.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LilyGO-Branded BadUSB Device is a BadUSB device. It is associated with the Silent Chollima and Lazarus groups. Its key technical behaviors include a USB Dump capability that allows attackers to enumerate and delete files, specifically targeting the path "LOCAL_APPDATA\GDIFONTC". This capability is shared with other malware like MagicRAT and Tiger RAT, which are also linked to the same threat groups.

1140.name: Malicious USB Devices
1140.profile: [profile]Malicious USB Devices, also known as a technique for USB and Removable Media Infection, is a method attributed to groups like FIN7. Key technical behaviors include using malicious USB accessories to install applications on non-jailbroken iOS devices and enumerating or deleting files from specific directories such as "LOCAL_APPDATA\GDIFONTC" as seen in tools like MagicRat. The primary target platforms are iOS and Windows systems, leveraging physical USB connections for initial access and data theft.
1140.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious USB Devices is a malware entity that leverages USB connections and removable media for infection and data theft. It is referenced in the context of other malware families, including WireLurker, which demonstrated proof-of-concept attacks on non-jailbroken iOS devices via malicious USB accessories, and Xtinyloader, which also uses USB and removable media for infection. The malware is associated with groups like Lazarus Group and Silent Chollima through the MagicRat family, which includes a "USB Dump" capability to enumerate and delete files from specific local directories. Its primary targets include iOS and Windows systems, utilizing USB-based vectors for initial access and data exfiltration.

1147.name: Imitating HHS
1147.profile: [profile]Imitating HHS is a technique where adversaries impersonate the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to conduct social engineering attacks. This behavior is a specific form of Impersonation (T1656) within the Initial Access tactic, typically targeting organizations across multiple platforms. Attackers, such as the group Storm-1811, leverage this masquerade to increase the credibility of phishing or other fraudulent communications, often as a precursor to deploying malware, stealing credentials, or conducting financial theft. The technique exploits trust in the legitimate HHS brand to bypass target skepticism and facilitate initial compromise.
1147.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Imitating HHS" is an attack-pattern. Based on related content, this technique involves adversaries masquerading as the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to conduct social engineering. This impersonation is a specific form of broader masquerading tactics, where attackers use the trusted identity of HHS, potentially in phishing or fraudulent communications, to deceive targets and facilitate further malicious activities like credential theft or malware deployment.

1148.name: Referencing COVID-19 Guidelines
1148.profile: [profile]The entity "Referencing COVID-19 Guidelines" is a technique where adversaries exploit public health directives, such as those related to COVID-19, as a lure in social engineering or phishing campaigns to increase the credibility and success rate of their initial access attempts. This approach is commonly associated with the FIN7 intrusion-set, which uses these topical guidelines to trick targets into opening malicious attachments or links, thereby deploying payloads like Python scripts (T1059.006) for execution. The technique leverages current events to bypass user suspicion and establish a foothold.
1148.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Referencing COVID-19 Guidelines" is an attack pattern where adversaries leverage COVID-19-related public health guidelines or information as a lure in social engineering campaigns. This technique is a form of Spearphishing Link (T1566.002) or Spearphishing Attachment (T1566.001) under the Initial Access tactic, primarily targeting the Windows platform. Attackers embed malicious links or attachments within emails or documents that appear to contain legitimate COVID-19 safety updates, health advisories, or government directives, exploiting public concern to trick victims into compromising their systems.

1149.name: Imitating Amazon
1149.profile: [profile]The entity "Imitating Amazon" is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, specifically identified as T1656.001 (Impersonation: Brand Impersonation) under the Initial Access tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries creating malicious online resources, such as domains, social media accounts, or advertisements, that closely mimic the branding, logos, and naming conventions of the legitimate Amazon company to deceive victims. This masquerading is used to lend credibility to phishing campaigns, malicious downloads, or fraudulent sites, tricking users into interacting with the adversary's infrastructure under the false pretense of engaging with a trusted entity. The technique is associated with threat actors like FIN7 and is conceptually related to other masquerading methods for accounts and resources.
1149.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Imitating Amazon" is a technique where adversaries mimic the Amazon brand to deceive victims.
