This aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1036.005 (Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location) under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. The core technical mechanic involves creating malicious resources, such as backdoored cloud images or online advertisements, that are named or designed to appear as legitimate Amazon services or products. This masquerade increases the likelihood of users mistakenly deploying these resources, thereby facilitating initial access or execution without raising suspicion, as seen in cloud attacks using malicious Amazon Machine Images (AMIs) and in malvertising campaigns that spoof trusted brands.

1150.name: Fraudulent Thank-You Letter
1150.profile: [profile]Fraudulent Thank-You Letter is a technique where adversaries send deceptive letters or emails to victims, often following a prior interaction or donation, to build trust and enable follow-on malicious activities. This social engineering method is used by threat actors like FIN7 to establish a credible pretext. The technique supports objectives such as credential harvesting or delivering malicious attachments by exploiting the victim's expectation of legitimate communication, thereby increasing the success rate of subsequent attacks.[/profile]
1150.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Fraudulent Thank-You Letter" is an attack-pattern. Based on the retrieved context, this technique likely involves social engineering, where adversaries send deceptive thank-you letters to manipulate or phish victims, potentially as part of a broader campaign to establish trust or deliver malicious payloads. The specific technical mechanics and MITRE ATT&CK mapping (ID, Tactic, Platform) cannot be definitively confirmed from the provided information.

1151.name: Counterfeit Gift Card
1151.profile: [profile]Counterfeit Gift Card is a technique where adversaries create or distribute fraudulent gift cards to enable unauthorized transactions or financial fraud. It is associated with intrusion sets like FIN7. The technique involves generating valid-looking card numbers and PINs, often through brute-force algorithms or data breaches, to bypass point-of-sale or online payment systems. These cards are then monetized through purchases or resale, exploiting weaknesses in gift card issuance and validation processes.[/profile]
1151.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Counterfeit Gift Card is a technique where adversaries create or distribute fraudulent gift cards to facilitate unauthorized transactions or monetize stolen data. It operates within the Resource Development tactic, targeting platforms like Windows, macOS, Linux, and cloud services. The method involves generating fake card details or manipulating legitimate ones to bypass payment systems, often used in financial fraud schemes to launder money or directly obtain goods/services without payment.

1152.name: BadUSB Attack
1152.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls. Downgrade attacks typically take advantage of a systemâ€™s backward compatibility to force it into less secure modes of operation. 

Adversaries may downgrade and use various less-secure versions of features of a system, such as [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s or even network protocols that can be abused to enable [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) or [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040).(Citation: Praetorian TLS Downgrade Attack 2014) For example, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) versions 5+ includes Script Block Logging (SBL), which can record executed script content. However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.(Citation: CrowdStrike BGH Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL 2018)(Citation: att_def_ps_logging)

Adversaries may similarly target network traffic to downgrade from an encrypted HTTPS connection to an unsecured HTTP connection that exposes network data in clear text.(Citation: Targeted SSL Stripping Attacks Are Real)(Citation: Crowdstrike Downgrade) On Windows systems, adversaries may downgrade the boot manager to a vulnerable version that bypasses Secure Boot, granting the ability to disable various operating system security mechanisms.(Citation: SafeBreach)
1152.profile: [profile]The entity "BadUSB Attack" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; the provided information conflates it with unrelated techniques. The Self Info and Similar Entity describe "Downgrade Attack" (T1562.010, Impair Defenses), which exploits backward compatibility to use less secure system features, such as running older PowerShell versions to bypass Script Block Logging or downgrading HTTPS to HTTP to expose data. The neighbor and one Content Related entity link to intrusion-set FIN7, which has used malicious USB devices for Input Injection (T1674) to simulate keystrokes and execute scripts, a method conceptually related to BadUSB attacks. Supplementary context notes exfiltration over USB (T1052.001) as a separate data theft method.
1152.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BadUSB Attack is a technique where adversaries use malicious USB devices to simulate Human Interface Device (HID) inputs, such as keystrokes, on a victim's computer. This allows them to execute commands, launch interpreters like PowerShell, and download malware, effectively bypassing traditional software-based defenses by exploiting the inherent trust in physical hardware interfaces.

1153.name: Keyboard Emulation
1153.profile: [profile]Keyboard Emulation, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1674 (Input Injection) under the Collection tactic, involves adversaries simulating keystrokes on a victim's computer to perform actions on behalf of the user. This can be achieved through pre-programmed tooling that monitors system events, like detecting specific browser URLs to inject malicious JavaScript via simulated keystrokes, or via physical devices like malicious USB drives that emulate keystrokes to launch PowerShell for malware execution. The intrusion-set FIN7 has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1153.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Keyboard Emulation is a technique where adversaries simulate keystrokes to perform actions on a victim's computer, such as launching a command interpreter via shortcuts, typing scripts, or interacting with GUI applications. This can be achieved through preprogrammed tooling or physical devices like Human Interface Devices (HIDs). For instance, tooling can monitor the Windows message loop to detect specific URLs and then inject keystrokes to execute malicious JavaScript in a browser, or malicious USB devices can emulate keystrokes to launch PowerShell for malware download and execution.

1154.name: Automated Keystrokes
1154.uncertain_mes:
Once established within a system or network, an adversary may use automated techniques for collecting internal data. Methods for performing this technique could include use of a [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) to search for and copy information fitting set criteria such as file type, location, or name at specific time intervals. 

In cloud-based environments, adversaries may also use cloud APIs, data pipelines, command line interfaces, or extract, transform, and load (ETL) services to automatically collect data.(Citation: Mandiant UNC3944 SMS Phishing 2023) 

This functionality could also be built into remote access tools. 

This technique may incorporate use of other techniques such as [File and Directory Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083) and [Lateral Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570) to identify and move files, as well as [Cloud Service Dashboard](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1538) and [Cloud Storage Object Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1619) to identify resources in cloud environments.
1154.profile: [profile]The entity "Automated Keystrokes" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; the provided data primarily describes MITRE technique T1119 "Automated Collection" for the Collection tactic on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Its technical mechanics involve using command interpreters or cloud APIs to automatically search for and copy data based on criteria like file type or name, often incorporating discovery techniques. The intrusion-set FIN7 is a related actor. The name "Automated Keystrokes" may be a misinterpretation, as related content describes simulated keystrokes (T1674) for UI interaction, which is a distinct action.
1154.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Automated Keystrokes" is a technique for simulating user keystrokes to perform actions on a victim's computer, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Input Injection (T1674) under the Execution tactic for Windows platforms. Technical mechanics involve using adversary tooling or physical devices like Human Interface Devices (HIDs) to programmatically generate keystrokes, such as launching a command interpreter via keyboard shortcuts, pasting and executing malicious scripts in a browser, or initiating PowerShell downloads from controlled servers. This method enables direct interaction with GUI applications and automated execution of commands without manual input.

1155.name: PowerShell Commands
1155.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)
1155.profile: [profile]PowerShell (T1059.001) is a Command and Scripting Interpreter technique under the Execution tactic, targeting the Windows platform. Adversaries abuse its cmdlets like Start-Process and Invoke-Command for local or remote code execution, and it can download and run executables from the internet directly in memory. Execution can also occur without powershell.exe by leveraging the System.Management.Automation DLL via .NET. It is associated with numerous threat groups, including FIN7, and tools like Empire and PowerSploit.[/profile]
1155.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This entity maps to the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell" (T1059.001) under the Execution tactic for Windows platforms. It involves adversaries abusing the PowerShell environment to execute malicious commands and scripts, including using cmdlets like Start-Process and Invoke-Command to run executables or commands locally and remotely. The technique also enables downloading and executing payloads from the internet, often directly in memory, and can be performed without invoking powershell.exe by leveraging the underlying System.Management.Automation assembly.

1156.name: Administrative Privilege Escalation
1156.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may exploit software vulnerabilities in an attempt to elevate privileges. Exploitation of a software vulnerability occurs when an adversary takes advantage of a programming error in a program, service, or within the operating system software or kernel itself to execute adversary-controlled code. Security constructs such as permission levels will often hinder access to information and use of certain techniques, so adversaries will likely need to perform privilege escalation to include use of software exploitation to circumvent those restrictions.

When initially gaining access to a system, an adversary may be operating within a lower privileged process which will prevent them from accessing certain resources on the system. Vulnerabilities may exist, usually in operating system components and software commonly running at higher permissions, that can be exploited to gain higher levels of access on the system. This could enable someone to move from unprivileged or user level permissions to SYSTEM or root permissions depending on the component that is vulnerable. This could also enable an adversary to move from a virtualized environment, such as within a virtual machine or container, onto the underlying host. This may be a necessary step for an adversary compromising an endpoint system that has been properly configured and limits other privilege escalation methods.

Adversaries may bring a signed vulnerable driver onto a compromised machine so that they can exploit the vulnerability to execute code in kernel mode. This process is sometimes referred to as Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD).(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020) Adversaries may include the vulnerable driver with files delivered during Initial Access or download it to a compromised system via [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105) or [Lateral Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570).
1156.profile: [profile]Exploitation for Privilege Escalation, identified as T1068 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, falls under the Privilege Escalation tactic and targets Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves exploiting software vulnerabilities in operating system components or high-permission software to execute adversary-controlled code and elevate privileges from user to SYSTEM or root levels. A specific sub-technique, Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD), involves delivering and exploiting a signed vulnerable driver to achieve kernel-mode execution. Groups such as FIN7, APT28, and APT29 are known to employ this method, which may utilize Ingress or Lateral Tool Transfer for driver delivery.[/profile]
1156.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Administrative Privilege Escalation is a technique used within the Privilege Escalation tactic on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves an adversary leveraging administrative access, often obtained via compromised local or domain accounts, to elevate privileges on a system. This can be achieved through methods like exploiting software vulnerabilities in high-privilege components or abusing legitimate administrative tools to bypass security controls and gain higher-level permissions such as SYSTEM or root.

1157.name: Ransomware Deployment
1157.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gain access to and use centralized software suites installed within an enterprise to execute commands and move laterally through the network. Configuration management and software deployment applications may be used in an enterprise network or cloud environment for routine administration purposes. These systems may also be integrated into CI/CD pipelines. Examples of such solutions include: SCCM, HBSS, Altiris, AWS Systems Manager, Microsoft Intune, Azure Arc, and GCP Deployment Manager.  

Access to network-wide or enterprise-wide endpoint management software may enable an adversary to achieve remote code execution on all connected systems. The access may be used to laterally move to other systems, gather information, or cause a specific effect, such as wiping the hard drives on all endpoints.

SaaS-based configuration management services may allow for broad [Cloud Administration Command](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1651) on cloud-hosted instances, as well as the execution of arbitrary commands on on-premises endpoints. For example, Microsoft Configuration Manager allows Global or Intune Administrators to run scripts as SYSTEM on on-premises devices joined to Entra ID.(Citation: SpecterOps Lateral Movement from Azure to On-Prem AD 2020) Such services may also utilize [Web Protocols](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/001) to communicate back to adversary owned infrastructure.(Citation: Mitiga Security Advisory: SSM Agent as Remote Access Trojan)

Network infrastructure devices may also have configuration management tools that can be similarly abused by adversaries.(Citation: Fortinet Zero-Day and Custom Malware Used by Suspected Chinese Actor in Espionage Operation)

The permissions required for this action vary by system configuration; local credentials may be sufficient with direct access to the third-party system, or specific domain credentials may be required. However, the system may require an administrative account to log in or to access specific functionality.
1157.profile: [profile]Ransomware Deployment is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. The provided data describes the abuse of enterprise software deployment tools (T1072) for lateral movement and remote code execution, which can be a precursor to ransomware impact. This involves gaining access to centralized suites like SCCM, Intune, or AWS Systems Manager, often requiring administrative credentials, to push and execute malicious payloads across connected systems, enabling broad network compromise. The intrusion-set FIN7 is linked to this behavior.[/profile]
1157.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Ransomware Deployment is a technique within the Impact tactic, targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves the malicious installation and execution of ransomware, often using enterprise software deployment systems like SCCM or Intune for broad remote code execution. This deployment facilitates the subsequent encryption of victim data (T1486) to disrupt availability and extort payment, with adversaries potentially using administrative credentials to propagate the malware across a network.

1158.name: Metasploit
1158.profile: [profile]Metasploit is a penetration testing framework used to generate payloads and exploit security vulnerabilities. It is utilized by threat actors, including the FIN7 intrusion set, to deliver shellcode and backdoors such as Meterpreter, SWRORT, and other trojans for Windows systems. The framework supports various attack stages from initial infection to lateral movement and system control, and its open-source nature makes it widely accessible for malicious purposes, as seen in campaigns by groups like APT33, Lazarus, and Kimsuky.
1158.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Metasploit is a penetration testing framework used for security assessments and by threat actors. It is referenced in relation to various malware families like AsyncRAT, DarkComet, and AppleSeed, where its components, particularly Metasploit Shellcode and the Meterpreter payload, are utilized. These payloads are associated with backdoors such as Backdoor.Win32.SWRORT.SMB and Trojan.Win32.METERPRETER.GAJC. The framework is employed by groups including APT33, Lazarus Group, and Kimsuky for activities like initial infection, credential theft, and lateral movement, primarily targeting Windows platforms.

1159.name: PowerShell Scripts
1159.uncertain_mes: powershell_web_backdoor This is a very simple powershell web backdoor Usage: hxxp://127.0.0.1:9999/backdoor/?cmd=<Insert Your powershell compatible base64 encoded command here
1159.profile: [profile]The malware is named PowerShell Scripts, also known as powershell_web_backdoor. It is attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. Its key technical behavior involves acting as a simple web backdoor that executes commands received via HTTP GET requests, where the command parameter is a Base64-encoded PowerShell command. The primary target platform is Windows systems. It is also referenced in the context of other malware families like Xenorat, Moonpeak, and Emotet, which utilize PowerShell scripts for payload download and execution, often employing obfuscation techniques.
1159.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PowerShell Scripts, also known as powershell_web_backdoor, is a tool leveraged by groups like Gold Cabin, Mummy Spider, and Mealybug (associated with Emotet). Key technical behaviors include acting as a simple web backdoor that executes commands via HTTP GET parameters with base64 encoding, and being invoked to download payloads, often using multiple layers of obfuscation to hide its activity. Its target platform is primarily Windows systems. Infrastructure involves remote servers for script hosting and command-and-control via web protocols.[/profile]

1160.name: DICELOADER
1160.uncertain_mes:
From pentest to APT attack: cybercriminal group FIN7 disguises its malware as an ethical hackerâ€™s toolkit
The article was prepared by BI.ZONE Cyber Threats Research Team
1160.profile: [profile]DICELOADER, also known as diceloader, is a malware attributed to the cybercriminal group FIN7. Its key technical behavior involves being deployed as a final payload by the STONEBOAT loader, which uses an intermediary, open-source loader called DAVESHELL to execute it; this specific implementation of DAVESHELL shellcode loading DICELOADER was unique to a small cluster of threat activity. The malware is disguised as an ethical hacker's toolkit. No specific target platforms are detailed in the provided information.[/profile]
1160.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DICELOADER, also known as diceloader, is a malware payload attributed to the cybercriminal group FIN7. It is deployed via a unique implementation of the open-source DAVESHELL loader, which executes DICELOADER as a final payload within clusters of threat activity, including the STONEBOAT campaign. This loader chain is distinct to a small set of operations.

1161.name: TIRION
1161.profile: [profile]TIRION, also known as Lizar, is a malicious tool attributed to the FIN7 intrusion set. It functions as an exfiltration tool, distributed via infected USB drives since at least July 2020. Its key technical behavior is data exfiltration, and it is part of the FIN7 malware arsenal alongside Carbanak. The target platform is Windows, indicated by its registry persistence mechanism for automatic startup.
1161.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TIRION, also known as Lizar, is a malicious code and exfiltration tool used by the FIN7 (Anunak) group since at least July 2020. It is distributed via infected USB drives and is part of the FIN7 arsenal alongside malware like Carbanak. Its key technical behavior is data exfiltration.

1162.name: REvil
1162.uncertain_mes:
A team claiming, they can escalate privileges, among other services, but they do not work with ransomware developers and affiliates (auto-translated by Google from Russian)
Negotiators
1162.profile: [profile]REvil, also known as Sodinokibi, is a ransomware-as-a-service operation attributed to the Pinchy Spider criminal group. It is a ransomware that encrypts files, appends extensions like ".4soa3", and leaves ransom notes. The group has been documented by Russian law enforcement for illicit financial activities. Its infrastructure and operations are distinct from groups like FIN7.
1162.profile_without_enhance: [profile]REvil, also known as Sodinokibi, is a ransomware attributed to the Pinchy Spider group. Its technical behaviors include using dropper files like agent.exe and agent.crt, and it operates by encrypting files and appending extensions such as .4soa3 to victim data. The malware targets Windows platforms, as indicated by its file paths and DLL components like mpsvc.dll.

1164.name: Amazon Thank-You Letter Phishing
1164.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
1164.profile: [profile]Amazon Thank-You Letter Phishing is a specific spearphishing technique (T1566) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting users via emails that impersonate Amazon to deliver malicious attachments or links. It leverages social engineering by posing as a trusted source, such as a customer service notification or order confirmation, to trick recipients into executing code. The intrusion-set FIN7 has been associated with this method.
1164.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Amazon Thank-You Letter Phishing is a spearphishing technique (aligned with T1566.002) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting users via email. It employs a specific lure: emails disguised as Amazon order confirmations or thank-you letters, which contain malicious links or attachments designed to steal credentials or deliver malware. This method exploits trust in a legitimate brand to increase the success rate of the phishing attempt.

1165.name: HHS COVID-19 Alert Spoofing
1165.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.(Citation: rfc2131) The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 1. The client broadcasts a `DISCOVER` message. 2. The server responds with an `OFFER` message, which includes an available network address. 3. The client broadcasts a `REQUEST` message, which includes the network address offered. 4. The server acknowledges with an `ACK` message and the client receives the network configuration parameters. Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.(Citation: new_rogue_DHCP_serv_malware)(Citation: w32.tidserv.g) Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network. DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a INFORMATION-REQUEST (code 11) message to the All_DHCP_Relay_Agents_and_Servers multicast address.(Citation: rfc3315) Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations. Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, [Service Exhaustion Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002)) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a networkâ€™s DHCP allocation pool.
1165.profile: [profile]The entity "HHS COVID-19 Alert Spoofing" is a specific instance of the MITRE ATT&CK technique DHCP Spoofing (T1557.003) under the tactic Credential Access, applicable to multiple platforms. The technical mechanism involves an adversary operating a rogue DHCP server on a victim network to intercept and redirect client traffic, often by providing malicious DNS server configurations. This establishes an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position to collect credentials from unencrypted communications. The intrusion-set FIN7 has been associated with this technique. The technique can also be abused for DHCP exhaustion attacks by flooding the network with DISCOVER messages.[/profile]
1165.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HHS COVID-19 Alert Spoofing is a specific social engineering technique where adversaries spoof sender identities to impersonate legitimate health authority communications, such as fake COVID-19 alerts from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). This technique falls under the broader Tactic of Initial Access, specifically leveraging Phishing (T1566) through email spoofing (T1672). The attack works by modifying email headers to forge the sender address, exploiting weak or absent email authentication policies (like DMARC, DKIM, or SPF) to make malicious messages appear legitimate. This spoofing is used to establish contact with victims under false pretenses, often as a precursor to delivering malware or conducting financial theft.

1167.name: LNK Files
1167.uncertain_mes:
Zscaler Blog
Get the latest Zscaler blog updates in your inbox
Steal-It Campaign
Introduction
1167.profile: [profile]LNK Files, also known as mocky lnk, is a file type used as a malicious downloader. It has been attributed to groups including APT28 and FIN7. Key technical behaviors involve its use in spam campaigns, where malicious ZIP attachments contain LNK files masquerading as documents (e.g., Label.doc.lnk, InvoiceAug5.doc.lnk) to download malware like TrickBot, QakBot, and RokRAT. It primarily targets Windows platforms through social engineering. Infrastructure includes its distribution via email and its role in campaigns such as Steal-It.[/profile]
1167.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LNK Files is a malware delivery mechanism, not a distinct malware family. It is used as a downloader by various threat groups, including APT28, TA505/UNC1878/Wizard Spider (associated with TrickBot), Gold Cabin (associated with QakBot), and APT37/ScarCruft (associated with RokRAT). It typically arrives via spam emails containing ZIP archives with malicious LNK files masquerading as documents (e.g., Label.doc.lnk, Invoice.pdf.lnk) to trick users into execution, which then downloads the primary payload.

1168.name: VBScript Execution
1168.profile: [profile]VBScript Execution is a technique for executing malicious code, likely corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1059.005 under the Execution tactic on Windows platforms. It involves using the VBScript engine, often via interpreters like cscript.exe or wscript.exe, or by embedding scripts in HTA files for mshta.exe execution. The FIN7 intrusion-set has been observed using this method, which can bypass application controls by leveraging trusted Windows utilities to run scripts that may download payloads, execute commands, or perform other malicious actions.[/profile]
1168.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VBScript Execution is a technique within the Execution tactic, identified as T1059.005, targeting Windows platforms. It involves the abuse of the VBScript scripting language, a default component on Windows, to execute malicious commands. This is commonly achieved by embedding VBScript within HTML Application (HTA) files, which can be run using utilities like `mshta.exe` to bypass application controls, or by including it in malicious documents delivered via spearphishing attachments to automate task execution on the host.

1169.name: User Execution
1169.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may rely upon specific actions by a user in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to execute malicious code by, for example, opening a malicious document file or link. These user actions will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from forms of [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566).

While [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204) frequently occurs shortly after Initial Access it may occur at other phases of an intrusion, such as when an adversary places a file in a shared directory or on a user's desktop hoping that a user will click on it. This activity may also be seen shortly after [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534).

Adversaries may also deceive users into performing actions such as:

* Enabling [Remote Access Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1219), allowing direct control of the system to the adversary
* Running malicious JavaScript in their browser, allowing adversaries to [Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)s(Citation: Talos Roblox Scam 2023)(Citation: Krebs Discord Bookmarks 2023)
* Downloading and executing malware for [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)
* Coerceing users to copy, paste, and execute malicious code manually(Citation: Reliaquest-execution)(Citation: proofpoint-selfpwn)

For example, tech support scams can be facilitated through [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566), vishing, or various forms of user interaction. Adversaries can use a combination of these methods, such as spoofing and promoting toll-free numbers or call centers that are used to direct victims to malicious websites, to deliver and execute payloads containing malware or [Remote Access Tools](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1219).(Citation: Telephone Attack Delivery)
1169.profile: [profile]User Execution, identified as T1204, is an Execution tactic technique that operates across Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. It relies on social engineering to trick a user into performing an action that leads to code execution, such as opening a malicious document or link, enabling a remote access tool, running malicious browser JavaScript, or manually copying and pasting malicious code. This technique is commonly a follow-on from phishing campaigns and is associated with groups like FIN7, Scattered Spider, and Lapsus$.[/profile]
1169.profile_without_enhance: [profile]User Execution is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1204 under the Execution tactic for Windows, macOS, and Linux. It relies on a user performing specific actions to execute malicious code, such as opening a malicious document file or link delivered via social engineering like Phishing. This can also involve deceiving users into enabling Remote Access Tools, running malicious JavaScript in their browser, or manually copying and pasting malicious code. The technique is commonly associated with groups like Scattered Spider and LAPSUS$.

1171.name: Credential Theft
1171.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may steal monetary resources from targets through extortion, social engineering, technical theft, or other methods aimed at their own financial gain at the expense of the availability of these resources for victims. Financial theft is the ultimate objective of several popular campaign types including extortion by ransomware,(Citation: FBI-ransomware) business email compromise (BEC) and fraud,(Citation: FBI-BEC) "pig butchering,"(Citation: wired-pig butchering) bank hacking,(Citation: DOJ-DPRK Heist) and exploiting cryptocurrency networks.(Citation: BBC-Ronin) 

Adversaries may [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586) to conduct unauthorized transfers of funds.(Citation: Internet crime report 2022) In the case of business email compromise or email fraud, an adversary may utilize [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656) of a trusted entity. Once the social engineering is successful, victims can be deceived into sending money to financial accounts controlled by an adversary.(Citation: FBI-BEC) This creates the potential for multiple victims (i.e., compromised accounts as well as the ultimate monetary loss) in incidents involving financial theft.(Citation: VEC)

Extortion by ransomware may occur, for example, when an adversary demands payment from a victim after [Data Encrypted for Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486) (Citation: NYT-Colonial) and [Exfiltration](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0010) of data, followed by threatening to leak sensitive data to the public unless payment is made to the adversary.(Citation: Mandiant-leaks) Adversaries may use dedicated leak sites to distribute victim data.(Citation: Crowdstrike-leaks)

Due to the potentially immense business impact of financial theft, an adversary may abuse the possibility of financial theft and seeking monetary gain to divert attention from their true goals such as [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) and business disruption.(Citation: AP-NotPetya)
1171.profile: [profile]The entity "Credential Theft" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; the provided data describes Financial Theft (T1657). Financial Theft is an adversary objective under the Impact tactic, targeting various platforms. It involves stealing monetary resources through methods like ransomware extortion, business email compromise (BEC), and cryptocurrency exploitation. Technical execution often relies on preceding techniques such as compromising accounts or data encryption to enable unauthorized fund transfers or extortion demands.[/profile]
1171.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credential Theft is a broad adversarial objective, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique ID. It encompasses various methods to steal authentication material, such as passwords, hashes, or tokens, to gain unauthorized access. Specific techniques include OS Credential Dumping (T1003) to extract credentials from system memory, targeting the Windows Credential Manager (T1555.004) for stored application and network passwords, and performing Credential Stuffing (T1110.004) to exploit reused passwords across accounts. Stolen credentials are often used for initial access, lateral movement, and privilege escalation, supporting objectives like financial theft or data exfiltration.

1172.name: Financial Data Extraction
1172.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may steal monetary resources from targets through extortion, social engineering, technical theft, or other methods aimed at their own financial gain at the expense of the availability of these resources for victims. Financial theft is the ultimate objective of several popular campaign types including extortion by ransomware,(Citation: FBI-ransomware) business email compromise (BEC) and fraud,(Citation: FBI-BEC) "pig butchering,"(Citation: wired-pig butchering) bank hacking,(Citation: DOJ-DPRK Heist) and exploiting cryptocurrency networks.(Citation: BBC-Ronin) 

Adversaries may [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586) to conduct unauthorized transfers of funds.(Citation: Internet crime report 2022) In the case of business email compromise or email fraud, an adversary may utilize [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656) of a trusted entity. Once the social engineering is successful, victims can be deceived into sending money to financial accounts controlled by an adversary.(Citation: FBI-BEC) This creates the potential for multiple victims (i.e., compromised accounts as well as the ultimate monetary loss) in incidents involving financial theft.(Citation: VEC)

Extortion by ransomware may occur, for example, when an adversary demands payment from a victim after [Data Encrypted for Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486) (Citation: NYT-Colonial) and [Exfiltration](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0010) of data, followed by threatening to leak sensitive data to the public unless payment is made to the adversary.(Citation: Mandiant-leaks) Adversaries may use dedicated leak sites to distribute victim data.(Citation: Crowdstrike-leaks)

Due to the potentially immense business impact of financial theft, an adversary may abuse the possibility of financial theft and seeking monetary gain to divert attention from their true goals such as [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) and business disruption.(Citation: AP-NotPetya)
1172.profile: [profile]Financial Theft, identified as T1657, is an adversary technique focused on the Impact tactic to steal monetary resources. It encompasses methods like extortion via ransomware, business email compromise (BEC) fraud using Impersonation (T1656) to deceive victims into sending funds, and unauthorized transfers from Compromised Accounts (T1586). The technique is associated with groups including FIN7, Scattered Spider, and INC Ransom, and can also serve as a diversion for objectives like Data Destruction (T1485).[/profile]
1172.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Financial Data Extraction is a technique where adversaries target and collect sensitive financial information from systems. This can involve querying databases like MySQL or PostgreSQL for financial records, staging the data locally, and then exfiltrating it, often using automated methods. The ultimate goal is typically financial theft, where the stolen data is used for fraud, extortion, or unauthorized fund transfers.

1173.name: System Information Discovery
1173.uncertain_mes: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture. Adversaries may use this information to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions. This behavior is distinct from [Local Storage Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1680) which is an adversary's discovery of local drive, disks and/or volumes. Tools such as [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) can be used to gather detailed system information. If running with privileged access, a breakdown of system data can be gathered through the systemsetup configuration tool on macOS. Adversaries may leverage a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) on network devices to gather detailed system information (e.g. show version).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A) On ESXi servers, threat actors may gather system information from various esxcli utilities, such as `system hostname get` and `system version get`.(Citation: Crowdstrike Hypervisor Jackpotting Pt 2 2021)(Citation: Varonis) Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud providers such as AWS, GCP, and Azure allow access to instance and virtual machine information via APIs. Successful authenticated API calls can return data such as the operating system platform and status of a particular instance or the model view of a virtual machine.(Citation: Amazon Describe Instance)(Citation: Google Instances Resource)(Citation: Microsoft Virutal Machine API) [System Information Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082) combined with information gathered from other forms of discovery and reconnaissance can drive payload development and concealment.(Citation: OSX.FairyTale)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)
1173.profile: [profile]System Information Discovery (T1082) is a Discovery tactic technique used across Windows, macOS, Linux, Network, IaaS, and Containers platforms. Adversaries gather detailed OS and hardware data like version, patches, and architecture to inform follow-on actions. Specific mechanics include using the `systeminfo` command on Windows, the `systemsetup` tool on macOS, CLI commands like `show version` on network devices, `esxcli` utilities on ESXi, and cloud instance metadata APIs from AWS, GCP, and Azure. It is associated with numerous threat groups including FIN7 and APT10.[/profile]
1173.profile_without_enhance: [profile]System Information Discovery is the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1082 under the Discovery tactic, applicable to Windows, macOS, Linux, and cloud platforms. It involves adversaries gathering detailed OS and hardware data like version, patches, and architecture to inform follow-on actions. Specific mechanics include using the `systeminfo` command on Windows, the `systemsetup` tool on macOS, CLI commands like `show version` on network devices, and `esxcli` utilities on ESXi servers. In cloud environments, adversaries leverage IaaS APIs (e.g., AWS, GCP, Azure) to query instance metadata. This information is often combined with other discovery results for payload development and target selection.

1183.name: JavaScript Payloads
1183.profile: [profile]JavaScript Payloads, also known as JavaScript Backdoor, is a stager used by groups including FIN7 and Cobalt to deploy additional payloads. It establishes persistence via registry keys and is executed by launching an SCT (scriptlet COM object) through regsvr32.exe. The payloads target Windows platforms and are associated with webshell delivery, as seen in tools like Chinachopper.
1183.profile_without_enhance: [profile]JavaScript Payloads, also referred to as JavaScript Backdoor, is a stager malware used to deploy additional payloads. It is associated with groups including cobalt, eggs, fin6, and venom spider. Its key technical behaviors involve establishing persistence through registry key settings and being executed via regsvr32.exe by loading a scriptlet COM object (SCT). It primarily targets Windows platforms.

1184.name: LNK File
1184.uncertain_mes:
Zscaler Blog
Get the latest Zscaler blog updates in your inbox
Steal-It Campaign
Introduction
1184.profile: [profile]Name: LNK File (alias mocky lnk). Attributed to APT28 and FIN7. Key TTPs include using malicious LNK files to initiate infection chains, often containing obfuscated commands within the file's Target property to download or execute further payloads. This technique is employed by various malware families like Astaroth, Evilnum, and Black Basta, indicating a common initial access vector across different threat groups. Target platforms are Windows systems via shortcut file execution.[/profile]
1184.profile_without_enhance: [profile]LNK File is a file format often exploited as an initial infection vector by various malware families. It is notably used by the Steal-It campaign attributed to APT28, and by malware families including Astaroth, Evilnum, and Black Basta. Key technical behaviors involve embedding and executing obfuscated commands within the .lnk file's Target property to initiate malicious payloads. It primarily targets Windows platforms through shortcut file execution.

1185.name: Command Line Evasion
1185.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers. Debuggers are typically used by defenders to trace and/or analyze the execution of potential malware payloads.(Citation: ProcessHacker Github) Debugger evasion may include changing behaviors based on the results of the checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a debugged environment. Similar to [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497), if the adversary detects a debugger, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for debugger artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary. On Windows, this may involve [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as IsDebuggerPresent() and NtQueryInformationProcess(), or manually checking the BeingDebugged flag of the Process Environment Block (PEB). On Linux, this may involve querying `/proc/self/status` for the `TracerPID` field, which indicates whether or not the process is being traced by dynamic analysis tools.(Citation: Cado Security P2PInfect 2023)(Citation: Positive Technologies Hellhounds 2023) Other checks for debugging artifacts may also seek to enumerate hardware breakpoints, interrupt assembly opcodes, time checks, or measurements if exceptions are raised in the current process (assuming a present debugger would â€œswallowâ€ or handle the potential error).(Citation: hasherezade debug)(Citation: AlKhaser Debug)(Citation: vxunderground debug) Malware may also leverage Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to detect debuggers by throwing an exception and detecting whether the process is suspended. SEH handles both hardware and software expectations, providing control over the exceptions including support for debugging. If a debugger is present, the programâ€™s control will be transferred to the debugger, and the execution of the code will be suspended. If the debugger is not present, control will be transferred to the SEH handler, which will automatically handle the exception and allow the programâ€™s execution to continue.(Citation: Apriorit) Adversaries may use the information learned from these debugger checks during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors. Debuggers can also be evaded by detaching the process or flooding debug logs with meaningless data via messages produced by looping [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as OutputDebugStringW().(Citation: wardle evilquest partii)(Citation: Checkpoint Dridex Jan 2021)
1185.profile: [profile]The entity "Command Line Evasion" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided data, it is likely a reference to the technique "Debugger Evasion" (ID: T1622) under the Defense Evasion tactic, targeting Windows and Linux platforms. This technique involves detecting debuggers to alter malware behavior, using methods such as checking the Windows PEB's BeingDebugged flag via IsDebuggerPresent(), querying Linux /proc/self/status for TracerPID, leveraging Structured Exception Handling (SEH), or flooding debug logs with OutputDebugStringW() calls. Groups like Mustang Panda and FIN7 have been associated with its use.[/profile]
1185.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Command Line Evasion is a Defense Evasion technique where adversaries manipulate command-line arguments to bypass detection. This can involve overwriting the Process Environment Block (PEB) in memory after a process is spawned with benign arguments, using functions like WriteProcessMemory, to replace them with malicious ones before execution resumes. It is often combined with other evasion tactics like Parent PID Spoofing.

1186.name: Obfuscation
1186.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may obfuscate command and control traffic to make it more difficult to detect.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020) Command and control (C2) communications are hidden (but not necessarily encrypted) in an attempt to make the content more difficult to discover or decipher and to make the communication less conspicuous and hide commands from being seen. This encompasses many methods, such as adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, or impersonating legitimate protocols.
1186.profile: [profile]Data Obfuscation, known as T1001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a Command and Control tactic applicable across multiple platforms. It involves hiding C2 communications to evade detection by adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, or impersonating legitimate protocols. The technique is notably associated with threat groups like Gamaredon and FIN7.[/profile]
1186.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Obfuscation is a broad technique for evading detection by hiding the true intent of code, data, or communications. It encompasses specific sub-techniques like T1027 Obfuscated Files or Information, which involves encrypting, encoding, or splitting files to hinder analysis, and T1027.010 Command Obfuscation, which uses syntax tricks, encoding, and tools like Invoke-Obfuscation to make commands and scripts difficult to signature. Another variant, T1001 Data Obfuscation, hides command-and-control traffic through methods like steganography or adding junk data. These techniques are employed across multiple platforms by numerous threat groups to bypass security controls.

1187.name: FIN8
1187.uncertain_mes:
FIN8 Uses Revamped Sardonic Backdoor to Deliver Noberus Ransomware
Financially motivated cyber-crime group continues to develop and improve tools and tactics.
Symantecâ€™s Threat Hunter Team, a part of Broadcom, recently observed the Syssphinx (aka FIN8) cyber-crime group deploying a variant of the Sardonic backdoor to deliver the Noberus ransomware.
1187.profile: [profile]FIN8, also known as Syssphinx or unidentified 103, is a financially motivated cyber-crime group. It has been observed deploying a revamped Sardonic backdoor to deliver Noberus ransomware and has previously utilized the PUNCHTRACK malware to scrape payment card data from point-of-sale (POS) systems.
1187.profile_without_enhance: [profile]FIN8, also known as Syssphinx, is a financially motivated cyber-crime group that develops and deploys tools like the Sardonic backdoor and the PUNCHTRACK point-of-sale (POS) malware to scrape payment card data, and has been observed using these tools to deliver Noberus ransomware.

1188.name: Application Whitelist Bypass
1188.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may modify file attributes and subvert Gatekeeper functionality to evade user prompts and execute untrusted programs. Gatekeeper is a set of technologies that act as layer of Appleâ€™s security model to ensure only trusted applications are executed on a host. Gatekeeper was built on top of File Quarantine in Snow Leopard (10.6, 2009) and has grown to include Code Signing, security policy compliance, Notarization, and more. Gatekeeper also treats applications running for the first time differently than reopened applications.(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany Quarantine and the flag)(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany apple notarization )

Based on an opt-in system, when files are downloaded an extended attribute (xattr) called `com.apple.quarantine` (also known as a quarantine flag) can be set on the file by the application performing the download. Launch Services opens the application in a suspended state. For first run applications with the quarantine flag set, Gatekeeper executes the following functions:

1. Checks extended attribute â€“ Gatekeeper checks for the quarantine flag, then provides an alert prompt to the user to allow or deny execution.(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)

2. Checks System Policies - Gatekeeper checks the system security policy, allowing execution of apps downloaded from either just the App Store or the App Store and identified developers.

3. Code Signing â€“ Gatekeeper checks for a valid code signature from an Apple Developer ID.

4. Notarization - Using the `api.apple-cloudkit.com` API, Gatekeeper reaches out to Apple servers to verify or pull down the notarization ticket and ensure the ticket is not revoked. Users can override notarization, which will result in a prompt of executing an â€œunauthorized appâ€ and the security policy will be modified.

Adversaries can subvert one or multiple security controls within Gatekeeper checks through logic errors (e.g. [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211)), unchecked file types, and external libraries. For example, prior to macOS 13 Ventura, code signing and notarization checks were only conducted on first launch, allowing adversaries to write malicious executables to previously opened applications in order to bypass Gatekeeper security checks.(Citation: theevilbit gatekeeper bypass 2021)(Citation: Application Bundle Manipulation Brandon Dalton)

Applications and files loaded onto the system from a USB flash drive, optical disk, external hard drive, from a drive shared over the local network, or using the curl command may not set the quarantine flag. Additionally, it is possible to avoid setting the quarantine flag using [Drive-by Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189).
1188.profile: [profile]Application Whitelist Bypass (T1553.001) is a Defense Evasion technique for macOS platforms. It specifically subverts Apple's Gatekeeper security by manipulating file attributes or exploiting logic errors. The primary method involves avoiding or removing the quarantine flag (`com.apple.quarantine` extended attribute) set on downloaded files, which prevents Gatekeeper's execution prompt. Adversaries can also write malicious code into previously opened applications to bypass code signing and notarization checks that were only enforced on first launch prior to macOS 13. This technique has been associated with threat actors like FIN7.[/profile]
1188.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Application Whitelist Bypass is a defense evasion technique where adversaries circumvent software restriction policies. This can be achieved by abusing trusted, signed system utilities like CMSTP.exe with malicious INF files to execute code, or by hijacking a binary's LC_MAIN entry point to run malicious code while maintaining a legitimate filename, thereby evading application whitelisting controls.

1189.name: String Concatenation (WOR+D.APPLICATION)
1189.profile: [profile]String Concatenation (WOR+D.APPLICATION) is a command obfuscation technique (T1027.010) under the Defense Evasion tactic, used on Windows platforms. It works by manually splitting a string, such as "Word.Application", into concatenated parts like "Wor"+"d.Application" to avoid signature-based detection. This specific method has been observed in use by the FIN7 intrusion set.
1189.profile_without_enhance: [profile]String Concatenation (WOR+D.APPLICATION) is a command obfuscation technique (T1027.010) under the Defense Evasion tactic. It operates by manually splitting a string, such as "Word.Application", into concatenated parts like "Wor"+"d.Application" to evade signature-based detection while maintaining the command's intended functionality. This method is used by adversaries to obscure malicious commands during execution via scripting interpreters.

1190.name: Eval String Conversion
1190.profile: [profile]Eval String Conversion is a technique used by adversaries to obfuscate malicious code, often within scripts, by converting strings to different representations to evade detection. It is associated with the intrusion set FIN7 and is conceptually related to other obfuscation and defense evasion methods like right-to-left override (T1036.002), standard encoding (T1132.001), and browser fingerprint spoofing (T1036.012). The technique involves manipulating string data to bypass security mechanisms that scan for known malicious patterns.
1190.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Eval String Conversion is a technique for obfuscating malicious code, likely aligned with the Defense Evasion tactic. It involves converting strings or code into alternative representations, such as using character encoding like Base64 or Unicode manipulation, to evade static detection. This method may be used to disguise malicious scripts or commands within seemingly benign data, requiring decoding or evaluation at runtime to execute.

1191.name: Character Replacement
1191.profile: [profile]Character Replacement is a technique used by adversaries to disguise malicious strings or filenames by substituting characters to make them appear benign, often leveraging Unicode control characters like the Right-to-Left Override (RLO, U+202E) to reverse the display order of subsequent text. For example, an executable named "March 25 \u202Excod.scr" is displayed as "March 25 rcs.docx". This method is commonly employed in spearphishing and malicious file delivery to evade detection by users and security tools, and has been associated with groups like FIN7. The technique aligns with the Defense Evasion tactic.[/profile]
1191.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Character Replacement is a technique where adversaries manipulate characters, such as using the right-to-left override (RTLO) Unicode character (U+202E), to disguise malicious file names and strings by reversing their displayed order. For example, a file named "March 25 \u202Excod.scr" appears as "March 25 rcs.docx" to trick users into executing it, commonly leveraged in spearphishing and malicious file attacks to evade detection by both users and security tools.

1192.name: Command Obfuscation
1192.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may obfuscate content during command execution to impede detection. Command-line obfuscation is a method of making strings and patterns within commands and scripts more difficult to signature and analyze. This type of obfuscation can be included within commands executed by delivered payloads (e.g., [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) and [Drive-by Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189)) or interactively via [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059).(Citation: Akamai JS)(Citation: Malware Monday VBE) For example, adversaries may abuse syntax that utilizes various symbols and escape characters (such as spacing, `^`, `+`. `$`, and `%`) to make commands difficult to analyze while maintaining the same intended functionality.(Citation: RC PowerShell) Many languages support built-in obfuscation in the form of base64 or URL encoding.(Citation: Microsoft PowerShellB64) Adversaries may also manually implement command obfuscation via string splitting (`â€œWorâ€+â€œd.Applicationâ€`), order and casing of characters (`rev <<<'dwssap/cte/ tac'`), globing (`mkdir -p '/tmp/:&$NiA'`), as well as various tricks involving passing strings through tokens/environment variables/input streams.(Citation: Bashfuscator Command Obfuscators)(Citation: FireEye Obfuscation June 2017) Adversaries may also use tricks such as directory traversals to obfuscate references to the binary being invoked by a command (`C:\voi\pcw\..\..\Windows\tei\qs\k\..\..\..\system32\erool\..\wbem\wg\je\..\..\wmic.exe shadowcopy delete`).(Citation: Twitter Richard WMIC) Tools such as Invoke-Obfuscation and Invoke-DOSfucation have also been used to obfuscate commands.(Citation: Invoke-DOSfuscation)(Citation: Invoke-Obfuscation)
1192.profile: [profile]Command Obfuscation (T1027.010) is a Defense Evasion technique used across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves manipulating command strings to hinder signature-based detection and analysis. Specific mechanics include using symbols and escape characters (e.g., ^, +, $, %), employing built-in encoding like base64 or URL encoding, performing string splitting and character reordering, using globing patterns, and abusing directory traversals to obscure binary paths. Tools like Invoke-Obfuscation and Invoke-DOSfucation automate this process, and the technique is commonly associated with groups like FIN7 and MuddyWater.[/profile]
1192.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Command Obfuscation is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1027.010 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves making command strings and patterns difficult to signature and analyze. Specific technical mechanics include abusing syntax with symbols and escape characters (e.g., ^, +, $, %), using built-in encoding like base64, performing string splitting, manipulating character order and casing, using globing, and employing directory traversals to obscure binary paths. Tools like Invoke-Obfuscation are commonly used, and the technique is associated with numerous threat groups including Fin7, MuddyWater, and Wizard Spider.

1193.name: Data Encoding
1193.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may encode data to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) information can be encoded using a standard data encoding system. Use of data encoding may adhere to existing protocol specifications and includes use of ASCII, Unicode, Base64, MIME, or other binary-to-text and character encoding systems.(Citation: Wikipedia Binary-to-text Encoding) (Citation: Wikipedia Character Encoding) Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.
1193.profile: [profile]Data Encoding is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1132 under the Command and Control tactic. It involves adversaries encoding command and control traffic to evade detection by using standard data encoding systems like ASCII, Unicode, Base64, MIME, or other binary-to-text schemes, which may also provide data compression such as with gzip. This technique is associated with groups like Velvet Ant and FIN7.
1193.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Data Encoding is a command and control technique under MITRE ATT&CK ID T1132, categorized within the Exfiltration tactic and applicable across multiple platforms. It involves encoding C2 traffic using standard systems like ASCII, Unicode, Base64, MIME, or hexadecimal to evade detection, with some methods like gzip also providing compression. This technique is employed by groups such as Velvet Ant, with sub-techniques for both standard (T1132.001) and non-standard (T1132.002) encoding schemes.

1194.name: Word.Application COM Object
1194.uncertain_name: component object model and distributed com
1194.uncertain_mes:
**This technique has been deprecated. Please use [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1559/001).**

Adversaries may use the Windows Component Object Model (COM) and Distributed Component Object Model (DCOM) for local code execution or to execute on remote systems as part of lateral movement. 

COM is a component of the native Windows application programming interface (API) that enables interaction between software objects, or executable code that implements one or more interfaces.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019) Through COM, a client object can call methods of server objects, which are typically Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL) or executables (EXE).(Citation: Microsoft COM) DCOM is transparent middleware that extends the functionality of Component Object Model (COM) (Citation: Microsoft COM) beyond a local computer using remote procedure call (RPC) technology.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)

Permissions to interact with local and remote server COM objects are specified by access control lists (ACL) in the Registry. (Citation: Microsoft COM ACL)(Citation: Microsoft Process Wide Com Keys)(Citation: Microsoft System Wide Com Keys) By default, only Administrators may remotely activate and launch COM objects through DCOM.

Adversaries may abuse COM for local command and/or payload execution. Various COM interfaces are exposed that can be abused to invoke arbitrary execution via a variety of programming languages such as C, C++, Java, and VBScript.(Citation: Microsoft COM) Specific COM objects also exists to directly perform functions beyond code execution, such as creating a [Scheduled Task/Job](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053), fileless download/execution, and other adversary behaviors such as Privilege Escalation and Persistence.(Citation: Fireeye Hunting COM June 2019)(Citation: ProjectZero File Write EoP Apr 2018)

Adversaries may use DCOM for lateral movement. Through DCOM, adversaries operating in the context of an appropriately privileged user can remotely obtain arbitrary and even direct shellcode execution through Office applications (Citation: Enigma Outlook DCOM Lateral Movement Nov 2017) as well as other Windows objects that contain insecure methods.(Citation: Enigma MMC20 COM Jan 2017)(Citation: Enigma DCOM Lateral Movement Jan 2017) DCOM can also execute macros in existing documents (Citation: Enigma Excel DCOM Sept 2017) and may also invoke [Dynamic Data Exchange](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1173) (DDE) execution directly through a COM created instance of a Microsoft Office application (Citation: Cyberreason DCOM DDE Lateral Movement Nov 2017), bypassing the need for a malicious document.
1194.profile: [profile]Word.Application COM Object is a deprecated technique; its functionality is now covered by standard MITRE techniques Component Object Model (T1559.001) for local execution and Distributed Component Object Model (T1021.003) for lateral movement. As a specific COM object within the Windows API, it can be abused to invoke arbitrary code execution through methods exposed by Microsoft Office applications, such as executing macros or shellcode remotely via DCOM, typically requiring administrative privileges for remote activation. The intrusion-set FIN7 has been associated with leveraging COM/DCOM for lateral movement.
1194.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Word.Application COM Object is a specific instance of Component Object Model (COM) abuse, likely aligning with MITRE ATT&CK sub-technique T1559.001 (Component Object Model) under the Execution tactic on Windows platforms. It involves programmatically creating and manipulating a Microsoft Word COM object (e.g., via VBScript or PowerShell) to execute arbitrary code or commands, often for fileless execution or lateral movement by invoking methods like `Run` or executing macros. This technique exploits the trusted Office application interface to bypass application control and perform malicious actions directly in memory.

1196.name: Syntax %X:@=%
1196.profile: [profile]The entity name "Syntax %X:@=%" does not correspond to a known MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved information, the content describes the technique of credential dumping from Apple's securityd memory, which is formally known as "Securityd Memory" and maps to MITRE ID T1555.002 under the Credential Access tactic for macOS. The technique involves an adversary with root access scanning the memory of the securityd daemon to find a master key, which is the user's logon password encrypted with PBKDF2, and then iterating over other stored keys to decrypt the user's keychain and obtain plaintext passwords for various services. The intrusion-set FIN7 is a known user of related credential access methods.[/profile]
1196.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Syntax %X:@=%" is an attack pattern, but it does not correspond to a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique based on the provided information. The retrieved context describes unrelated techniques for credential access, specifically targeting the OS X `securityd` memory (T1555.002) and the deprecated `source` command (T1153). No technical mechanics or specific details for "Syntax %X:@=%" are present in the input, indicating it may be a non-standard or incorrectly named pattern.

1198.name: Registry Run Keys
1198.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key. Adding an entry to the "run keys" in the Registry or startup folder will cause the program referenced to be executed when a user logs in.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) These programs will be executed under the context of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level. The following run keys are created by default on Windows systems: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce Run keys may exist under multiple hives.(Citation: Microsoft Wow6432Node 2018)(Citation: Malwarebytes Wow6432Node 2016) The HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx is also available but is not created by default on Windows Vista and newer. Registry run key entries can reference programs directly or list them as a dependency.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) For example, it is possible to load a DLL at logon using a "Depend" key with RunOnceEx: reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil[.]dll" (Citation: Oddvar Moe RunOnceEx Mar 2018) Placing a program within a startup folder will also cause that program to execute when a user logs in. There is a startup folder location for individual user accounts as well as a system-wide startup folder that will be checked regardless of which user account logs in. The startup folder path for the current user is C:\Users\\[Username]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup. The startup folder path for all users is C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\StartUp. The following Registry keys can be used to set startup folder items for persistence: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders The following Registry keys can control automatic startup of services during boot: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices Using policy settings to specify startup programs creates corresponding values in either of two Registry keys: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run Programs listed in the load value of the registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows run automatically for the currently logged-on user. By default, the multistring BootExecute value of the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager is set to autocheck autochk *. This value causes Windows, at startup, to check the file-system integrity of the hard disks if the system has been shut down abnormally. Adversaries can add other programs or processes to this registry value which will automatically launch at boot. Adversaries can use these configuration locations to execute malware, such as remote access tools, to maintain persistence through system reboots. Adversaries may also use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the Registry entries look as if they are associated with legitimate programs.
1198.profile: [profile]Registry Run Keys is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1547.001 under the Persistence tactic for Windows. It achieves persistence by adding entries to specific Registry keys or startup folders to execute a referenced program during user logon or system boot. Default keys include HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run and HKLM equivalents, while startup folders are C:\Users\[Username]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup and C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\StartUp. A specific example is using the RunOnceEx key with a "Depend" value to load a DLL, such as via the command `reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil.dll"`. This technique is used by groups like FIN7 and Lazarus Group.
1198.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Registry Run Keys, also known as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1547.001, is a persistence tactic for Windows platforms. It involves adding entries to specific Windows Registry keys, such as HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run or HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run, to cause a referenced program or DLL to execute automatically upon user logon or system boot. This technique can also utilize RunOnceEx keys with dependencies, for example using a command like `reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil.dll"` to load a malicious DLL. Adversaries often combine this with masquerading to make the entries appear legitimate.[/profile]

1199.name: Phishing Lures
1199.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)
