Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
1199.profile: [profile]Phishing, identified as T1566, is an Initial Access tactic used across multiple platforms. It involves sending deceptive electronic messages, such as emails with malicious attachments or links, to trick victims into executing code. Techniques include spearphishing for specific targets, using social media platforms, spoofing sender identities, and employing evasive methods like manipulating email headers. The objective is to gain system access, often leading to malware execution or credential theft.
1199.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Phishing Lures is a social engineering technique used within broader phishing attacks (T1566) under the Initial Access tactic, targeting multiple platforms. The technical mechanics involve crafting deceptive messages, often via email, that impersonate trusted sources to trick victims into clicking malicious links, opening infected attachments, or divulging credentials. These lures are tailored using reconnaissance data to increase believability and may employ urgency, thread hijacking, or spoofed sender identities to bypass security controls.

1200.name: Bypass Techniques
1200.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may modify file attributes and subvert Gatekeeper functionality to evade user prompts and execute untrusted programs. Gatekeeper is a set of technologies that act as layer of Appleâ€™s security model to ensure only trusted applications are executed on a host. Gatekeeper was built on top of File Quarantine in Snow Leopard (10.6, 2009) and has grown to include Code Signing, security policy compliance, Notarization, and more. Gatekeeper also treats applications running for the first time differently than reopened applications.(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany Quarantine and the flag)(Citation: TheEclecticLightCompany apple notarization )

Based on an opt-in system, when files are downloaded an extended attribute (xattr) called `com.apple.quarantine` (also known as a quarantine flag) can be set on the file by the application performing the download. Launch Services opens the application in a suspended state. For first run applications with the quarantine flag set, Gatekeeper executes the following functions:

1. Checks extended attribute â€“ Gatekeeper checks for the quarantine flag, then provides an alert prompt to the user to allow or deny execution.(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X)(Citation: 20 macOS Common Tools and Techniques)

2. Checks System Policies - Gatekeeper checks the system security policy, allowing execution of apps downloaded from either just the App Store or the App Store and identified developers.

3. Code Signing â€“ Gatekeeper checks for a valid code signature from an Apple Developer ID.

4. Notarization - Using the `api.apple-cloudkit.com` API, Gatekeeper reaches out to Apple servers to verify or pull down the notarization ticket and ensure the ticket is not revoked. Users can override notarization, which will result in a prompt of executing an â€œunauthorized appâ€ and the security policy will be modified.

Adversaries can subvert one or multiple security controls within Gatekeeper checks through logic errors (e.g. [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211)), unchecked file types, and external libraries. For example, prior to macOS 13 Ventura, code signing and notarization checks were only conducted on first launch, allowing adversaries to write malicious executables to previously opened applications in order to bypass Gatekeeper security checks.(Citation: theevilbit gatekeeper bypass 2021)(Citation: Application Bundle Manipulation Brandon Dalton)

Applications and files loaded onto the system from a USB flash drive, optical disk, external hard drive, from a drive shared over the local network, or using the curl command may not set the quarantine flag. Additionally, it is possible to avoid setting the quarantine flag using [Drive-by Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189).
1200.profile: [profile]Gatekeeper Bypass, identified as T1553.001, is a defense evasion technique targeting macOS platforms. It involves subverting Apple's Gatekeeper security by removing or avoiding the quarantine flag (the `com.apple.quarantine` extended attribute) on downloaded files to prevent user execution prompts. Adversaries may also exploit logic errors, such as writing malicious code into previously opened applications to bypass code signing and notarization checks that were only enforced on first launch prior to macOS 13. Execution can be achieved via files from external media or network shares that do not set the flag.[/profile]
1200.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bypass Techniques is a broad, non-standard MITRE ATT&CK category encompassing various methods to evade security controls. The retrieved information details specific techniques like Gatekeeper Bypass (T1553.001) on macOS, which involves manipulating file quarantine attributes and exploiting logic errors in code signing checks, and Bypass User Account Control (T1548.002) on Windows, which leverages auto-elevated processes like `eventvwr.exe` or COM objects. Other methods include Mark-of-the-Web Bypass (T1553.005) using container files and abusing trusted binaries like CMSTP (T1218.003) to execute malicious code and bypass application whitelisting.

1201.name: Tactics
1201.profile: [profile]The entity "Tactics" is a high-level concept representing adversary goals and objectives, such as those defined in the MITRE ATT&CK framework. It is directly associated with intrusion sets like Unknown_Threat_Actor. Related content describes specific techniques adversaries use to achieve these tactics, including mining valuable data from various databases like MySQL and Snowflake for lateral movement or exfiltration, employing multilayer encryption for command and control, and using multiband communication to bypass network restrictions, though the latter technique is deprecated.
1201.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Tactics" is a high-level concept in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, not a specific technique with a T-ID. It refers to the adversary's tactical goals, such as Lateral Movement, Command and Control, or Exfiltration, which are achieved through specific techniques. The retrieved information describes distinct techniques like Data from Information Repositories (T1213.006), which targets databases for data collection, and Multi-Stage Channels (T1026) and Encrypted Channel (T1079), which are deprecated and active techniques respectively for command and control communications.

1203.name: Magic Hound
1203.uncertain_mes: [Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) is an Iranian-sponsored threat group that conducts long term, resource-intensive cyber espionage operations, likely on behalf of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. They have targeted European, U.S., and Middle Eastern government and military personnel, academics, journalists, and organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO), via complex social engineering campaigns since at least 2014.(Citation: FireEye APT35 2018)(Citation: ClearSky Kittens Back 3 August 2020)(Citation: Certfa Charming Kitten January 2021)(Citation: Secureworks COBALT ILLUSION Threat Profile)(Citation: Proofpoint TA453 July2021)
1203.profile: [profile]Magic Hound, also known as APT35, Charming Kitten, TA453, Mint Sandstorm, Phosphorus, and Cobalt Illusion, is an Iranian-sponsored threat group attributed to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. Its operations, active since at least 2014, involve complex social engineering and a toolset capable of keylogging, using RDP for lateral movement, and deploying malicious scripts like CacheTask.bat while modifying registry settings to evade security tools. The group primarily targets government, military, academic, and media sectors across Europe, the United States, and the Middle East, including organizations like the World Health Organization, as part of long-term cyber espionage campaigns.
1203.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Magic Hound is an intrusion set, also known as APT35, Mint Sandstorm, Charming Kitten, and Phosphorus. It is attributed to Iran and primarily targets the energy, government, and technology sectors in the Middle East. Its key custom malware includes Magichound.Leash (MPK Bot) and Magic Unicorn, and it leverages tools like Pupy RAT and its loader. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious Microsoft Office documents, PowerShell exploitation for in-memory execution, and establishing persistence via Autorun Registry keys. The group's motivation is cyber espionage.[/profile]
1203.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Magic Hound is an intrusion set attributed to the Iranian state-sponsored APT35 group (also known as Charming Kitten, Phosphorus, and Newscaster). It employs a custom toolset for keylogging, uses RDP for lateral movement, and employs tactics such as naming malicious scripts to mimic legitimate tasks (e.g., CacheTask.bat) and modifying Registry settings to evade security tools. The group primarily targets sectors and regions of interest to Iran, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft.]
1203.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]Magic Hound is a cyber espionage group, also known as APT35, Charming Kitten, Newscaster Team, and Phosphorus, and shows overlaps with Rocket Kitten. It is attributed to Iran and primarily targets sectors such as government, defense, and academia across the Middle East and globally. The group's key malware and tools include custom keyloggers and scripts like CacheTask.bat, and its TTPs involve using RDP for lateral movement, creating deceptive local accounts, and modifying registry settings to evade security tools. Its motivation is believed to be intelligence gathering in support of Iranian state interests.
1203.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]Magic Hound, also known as APT35, Charming Kitten, and Phosphorus, is an Iranian state-sponsored intrusion set. Its key malware includes the MPK Bot family (Magichound.Leash, Fetch, Rollover, Retriever), the Magichound.Dropit dropper, and the use of open-source tools like Pupy RAT and Magic Unicorn. Its TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious Office documents, PowerShell exploitation, and persistence via registry keys. It is attributed to Iran and primarily targets the Government, Technology, and Energy sectors in the Middle East for espionage and data theft.[/profile]

The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets the Middle East, with a focus on the Energy, Government, and Technology sectors, indicating a motivation for espionage and strategic intelligence gathering.

1207.name: Microsoft Office Documents
1207.profile: [profile]Microsoft Office Documents is a file type commonly exploited as an initial infection vector. It is directly associated with the Magic Hound intrusion set and the Magichound.Dropit malware. Malicious variants are known to be crafted using the EPPlus software library instead of native Microsoft Office tools, a technique used by the Gorgon Group to potentially evade detection. These documents are a primary target for data theft by ransomware groups like BlackCat (associated with Alpha Spider and others), which specifically enumerate and steal them, along with other file types, while avoiding system directories.
1207.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Microsoft Office Documents is a malware delivery vector, not a malware family itself. It is used by various threat actors, including Magic Hound (with links to Rocket Kitten, APT33, APT35, and OilRig), The Gorgon Group, Alpha Spider, RansomHub, and Vanilla Tempest. The primary technique is embedding malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros within documents (like .doc, .xls) to execute arbitrary commands when enabled, often delivered via spearphishing. Documents are sometimes crafted using tools like EPPlus software to evade detection. This vector primarily targets Windows systems to download or drop other malware, such as Magichound.Dropit, and is associated with campaigns against sectors like energy in the Middle East.[/profile]

1208.name: Malicious Macros
1208.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office templates to obtain persistence on a compromised system. Microsoft Office contains templates that are part of common Office applications and are used to customize styles. The base templates within the application are used each time an application starts. (Citation: Microsoft Change Normal Template) Office Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros (Citation: MSDN VBA in Office) can be inserted into the base template and used to execute code when the respective Office application starts in order to obtain persistence. Examples for both Word and Excel have been discovered and published. By default, Word has a Normal.dotm template created that can be modified to include a malicious macro. Excel does not have a template file created by default, but one can be added that will automatically be loaded.(Citation: enigma0x3 normal.dotm)(Citation: Hexacorn Office Template Macros) Shared templates may also be stored and pulled from remote locations.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) Word Normal.dotm location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\Normal.dotm Excel Personal.xlsb location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Excel\XLSTART\PERSONAL.XLSB Adversaries may also change the location of the base template to point to their own by hijacking the application's search order, e.g. Word 2016 will first look for Normal.dotm under C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\, or by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key. By modifying the GlobalDotName registry key an adversary can specify an arbitrary location, file name, and file extension to use for the template that will be loaded on application startup. To abuse GlobalDotName, adversaries may first need to register the template as a trusted document or place it in a trusted location.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) An adversary may need to enable macros to execute unrestricted depending on the system or enterprise security policy on use of macros.
1208.profile: [profile]Office Template Macros, identified as T1137.001, is a persistence technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework under the Persistence tactic, targeting Windows and macOS platforms. It involves inserting malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros into Microsoft Office base templates, such as Word's Normal.dotm or Excel's Personal.xlsb, to execute code automatically when the respective application starts. Adversaries can modify these default template files, store shared templates remotely, or hijack the template search order by altering the GlobalDotName registry key to point to a malicious file. This method may require enabling macros based on security policies and has been associated with groups like MuddyWater.
1208.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Macros is a technique where adversaries embed malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) code within Microsoft Office documents (like .doc, .xls) to execute arbitrary commands when a user enables macros. This technique is part of the Initial Access and Execution tactics, primarily targeting Windows platforms. The malicious code is often delivered via spearphishing attachments and can be hidden using methods like VBA Stomping, which replaces source code with benign data while leaving compiled p-code intact. Attackers rely on social engineering to trick users into enabling macros, which bypasses security policies and leads to code execution.

1209.name: Portable Executable (PE) Payloads
1209.profile: [profile]Portable Executable (PE) Payloads, also referred to as PE injection, are a common malware delivery mechanism where a Windows PE file is mapped into memory and executed, often after being reconstructed, decompressed, and decrypted by a preceding shellcode loader. This technique is employed by threat groups like Magic Hound, Gold Cabin, and Lunar Spider in malware families such as IcedID, ISFB, and FinFisher RAT to target Windows systems.
1209.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Portable Executable (PE) Payloads is a malware entity representing a class of malicious payloads. It is associated with groups including Gold Cabin, Lunar Spider, and unknown groups. Its key technical behavior involves the use of a shellcode loader to map and execute the PE file in memory, often after the payload is reconstructed, decompressed, and decrypted. This technique is used by specific malware families like IcedID, ISFB, and FinFisher RAT.

1210.name: .NET Framework PE Files
1210.uncertain_mes: Lightning Framework is a new undetected Swiss Army Knife-like Linux malware that has modular plugins and the ability to install rootkits.
1210.profile: [profile]The malware is known as Lightning Framework, a modular Swiss Army Knife-like Linux malware with plugins and rootkit installation capabilities. It is attributed to the Magic Hound intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include using a .NET Framework PE file structure, where functionality is encoded within .NET-specific structures, and it leverages Windows paths related to .NET Framework cache optimization. The primary target platform is Linux. Infrastructure or supplementary details involve the malware being undetected and utilizing the PE file format for .NET assemblies.
1210.profile_without_enhance: [profile].NET Framework PE Files, also known as .NET assemblies, are executable file formats that re-use the standard Windows Portable Executable (PE) structure but encode their core functionality within .NET-specific metadata and structures, allowing them to be loaded and executed by the Microsoft Windows PE loader when the .NET Framework runtime is present; they are not a specific malware family but a file format commonly leveraged by various malicious actors to develop and deploy malware on the Windows platform, with associated cache optimization files stored in system directories.]

1211.name: IRC Bots
1211.profile: [profile]IRC Bots, also known as perlbot or tntbotinger, are attributed to the intrusion set Magic Hound. They function as DDoS bots, using IRC protocol for command and control, with commands including NICK, SERVER, IRC, DISABLE, ENABLE, KILL, and VERSION to manage client nicknames, servers, packeting, and termination. They primarily target systems for distributed denial-of-service attacks.[/profile]
1211.profile_without_enhance: [profile]IRC Bots, also known as IRC-based malware, are a class of malware that operate as bots controlled via Internet Relay Chat (IRC) channels. They are commonly used by threat actors for distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, as exemplified by variants like Tsunami. Key technical behaviors include receiving commands from an IRC server to perform actions such as changing the client's nickname, switching servers, enabling or disabling packet-sending functions, and terminating the client process. They primarily target networked systems to create botnets for coordinated attacks.[/profile]

1212.name: Pupy RAT
1212.uncertain_mes:
- Home
- APT
- Breaking News
- Cyber warfare
- Hacking
- Intelligence
- Iranian hackers behind the Magic Hound campaign linked to Shamoon
Pierluigi Paganini
1212.profile: [profile]Pupy RAT, also known as Pupy or PUPYRAT, is an open-source, cross-platform Remote Administration Tool (RAT) written in Python, capable of targeting Windows, Linux, OSX, and Android. It is associated with Iranian APT groups APT33, APT35, OilRig, and Rocket Kitten, and has been used in cyber espionage campaigns like Magic Hound. Its key behaviors include in-memory execution to minimize footprint and the use of encrypted payloads for command and control.
1212.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Pupy RAT, also known as Pupy or PUPYRAT, is an open-source, cross-platform Remote Administration Tool (RAT) and post-exploitation framework written in Python. It has been attributed to Iranian APT groups APT33, APT35, OilRig, and Rocket Kitten, used in cyber espionage operations such as a 2020 campaign against a European energy organization. Key technical behaviors include all-in-memory execution to leave a low forensic footprint and the use of encrypted payloads. It targets multiple platforms including Windows, Linux, OSX, and Android.

1213.name: Pupy Loader
1213.uncertain_mes:
- Home
- APT
- Breaking News
- Cyber warfare
- Hacking
- Intelligence
- Iranian hackers behind the Magic Hound campaign linked to Shamoon
Pierluigi Paganini
1213.profile: [profile]Pupy Loader, also known as Pupy, is a loader component for the Pupy RAT. It is attributed to APT groups such as APT33, APT35, OilRig, and Rocket Kitten, and has been used in the Magic Hound campaign. Its key technical behavior is providing default loaders, including 32-bit and 64-bit DLLs, to deploy the RAT. It targets multiple platforms including Windows, OSX, and Linux. Associated infrastructure and configurations have been observed in samples linked to these threat actors.[/profile]
1213.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Pupy Loader, also known as Pupy, is a loader component for the Pupy RAT, used by threat groups including APT33, APT35, OilRig, Rocket Kitten, and Magic Hound. It employs default 32-bit and 64-bit DLL loaders to deploy the RAT on target platforms such as Windows, OSX, and Linux. The loader is associated with the broader Magic Hound campaign and facilitates remote access and control for these actors.

1214.name: DLL Loader
1214.profile: [profile]DLL Loader is a malware type used to load malicious drivers or DLLs, attributed to the intrusion set Magic Hound. It is associated with or similar to entities like Vetta Loader, Slingshot, Pyxie, and Lojax, with Lojax specifically linked to APT28. Key technical behaviors include loading drivers and DLLs, as indicated by SHA256 hashes for loader DLL samples. Its target platform is Windows, leveraging driver loading for persistence or evasion.[profile]
1214.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DLL Loader is a malware component. It is also known as a driver loader, with related entities including Vetta Loader, Slingshot, Pyxie, and Lojax. It has been used by APT28 in operations involving Lojax. Its key technical behavior is to load malicious dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) or drivers onto a system. It targets both 32-bit and 64-bit Windows platforms, as indicated by its associated infrastructure.

1217.name: Magichound.Fetch
1217.profile: [profile]Magichound.Fetch, also known as leash, mpkbot, and pupy, is attributed to the Magic Hound intrusion-set. It is a modular malware that communicates with its command-and-control server over HTTP and uses AES encryption for its communications. The malware is designed to target Windows systems for data exfiltration and remote access.[/profile]
1217.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Magichound.Fetch, also known as Leash, MPKBot, and Pupy, is a malware attributed to groups including Magic Hound, Rocket Kitten, APT33, APT35, and OilRig. Its key technical behaviors involve remote access and command execution capabilities, functioning as a modular backdoor. It primarily targets Windows platforms and is associated with espionage campaigns in the Middle East, utilizing infrastructure for command and control.

1218.name: Magichound.Dropit
1218.profile: [profile]Magichound.Dropit, also known as leash, mpkbot, and pupy, is attributed to the Magic Hound intrusion set, with some reports also linking it to Rocket Kitten, APT33, APT35, and OilRig. Its key behaviors involve using Microsoft Office documents as a delivery mechanism, typically as a dropper to deploy further payloads. The target platform is Windows systems. Infrastructure and supplementary information indicate it is part of a broader toolset used in campaigns by these associated groups.[/profile]
1218.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Magichound.Dropit, also known as Dropit, is a malicious dropper associated with the intrusion set Magic Hound. It is delivered via malicious Microsoft Office documents, which are crafted using the EPPlus software library instead of native Microsoft Office to evade detection. This dropper serves as a primary vector for delivering other malware families, including Azorult, BlackCat, and Mailto, across various criminal and state-sponsored groups.[/profile]

1219.name: Magichound.Leash
1219.uncertain_mes: Unit 42 has discovered a persistent attack campaign operating primarily in the Middle East dating back to at least mid-2016 which we have named Magic Hound. This appears to be an attack campaign focused on espionage. Based upon our visibility it has primarily targeted organizations in the energy, government, and technology sectors that are either based or have business interests in Saudi Arabia.
1219.profile: [profile]Magichound.Leash, also known simply as Leash, is a malware component associated with the Magic Hound intrusion set. It is part of a persistent espionage campaign active since at least 2016, targeting the energy, government, and technology sectors, particularly those with interests in Saudi Arabia. Its command and control infrastructure has included domains such as service.chrome-up[.]date, msservice[.]site, and microsoftexplorerservices[.]cloud, and IP address 45.56.123[.]129. It is related to other malware like MPK Bot and MAGICHOUND.FETCH.
1219.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Magichound.Leash, also known as MagicHound.Leash, is attributed to the Magic Hound intrusion set. It is related to the MPK Bot malware, which communicates with a C2 server via private messages to an "mpk" account. Associated infrastructure includes domains like service.chrome-up[.]date, msservice[.]site, and microsoftexplorerservices[.]cloud, and IP addresses such as 45.56.123[.]129 and syn.timezone[.]live. It is also connected to indicators like 'agkrhfpdbvhdhrkj' and 'ver command'.[/profile]

1220.name: Magichound.Rollover
1220.profile: [profile]Magichound.Rollover, also known as MPKBot, is a malware associated with the Magic Hound intrusion set. It communicates with command-and-control servers at 45.56.123[.]129 (syn.timezone[.]live) and 45.58.37[.]142, and a sample has the SHA256 hash d08d737fa59edbea4568100cf83cff7bf930087aaa640f1b4edf48eea4e07b19. It is part of the broader Magic Hound toolset.[/profile]
1220.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Magichound.Rollover, also known as MPKBot, is a malware associated with the Magic Hound and Rocket Kitten threat groups. It communicates with command-and-control servers at IP addresses 45.56.123[.]129 and 45.58.37[.]142, and uses the domain syn.timezone[.]live. The tool is part of the Magic Hound toolset, with a known sample hash of d08d737fa59edbea4568100cf83cff7bf930087aaa640f1b4edf48eea4e07b19.

1221.name: Magichound.Retriever
1221.profile: [profile]Magichound.Retriever, also known as mpkbot, leash, and pupy, is attributed to the Magic Hound intrusion set, with potential links to Rocket Kitten, APT33, APT35, and OilRig. It functions as a remote access trojan (RAT) capable of keylogging, screen capturing, and data exfiltration, often using HTTP for command and control communication. Its target platforms include Windows systems, and it is associated with broader cyber espionage campaigns in the Middle East.
1221.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Magichound.Retriever, also known as mpkbot and leash, is a malware associated with groups including Magic Hound, Rocket Kitten, APT33, APT35, and OilRig. It functions as a remote access trojan (RAT) with capabilities for system reconnaissance, data exfiltration, and remote command execution, often using HTTP for command-and-control communication.]

1222.name: Magic Unicorn
1222.uncertain_mes: The J-magic show: Magic packets and where to find them
1222.profile: [profile]Magic Unicorn, also known as j-magic, is a malware associated with the intrusion set Magic Hound. Its key technical behavior involves building a buffer to store and execute shellcode via a created thread, a technique also found in the source code of related malware like mpkbot and leash used in Magic Hound delivery documents. Target platforms are not explicitly specified in the provided data. Infrastructure or supplementary information is not detailed beyond its connection to the Magic Hound group's operations.
1222.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Magic Unicorn is a malware tool, also referenced in the context of Magic Hound delivery documents. It is associated with groups like Magic Hound and Rocket Kitten. Its key technical behavior involves using shellcode stored in a buffer and creating a thread to execute it, with its source code linked to tools like mpkbot and leash. It primarily targets Windows systems, leveraging PowerShell scripts for execution to run arbitrary commands and payloads directly in memory.

1223.name: PowerShell Scripts
1223.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)
1223.profile: [profile]PowerShell Scripts is the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.001 under the Execution tactic for the Windows platform. It involves abusing the PowerShell command-line interface for execution, including running executables via cmdlets like Start-Process and Invoke-Command, downloading and executing payloads from the internet, and operating tools like Empire and PowerSploit. Execution can occur without the powershell.exe binary by leveraging the System.Management.Automation assembly through the .NET framework. It is widely used by numerous threat groups including APT29, Lazarus Group, and FIN7.[/profile]
1223.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PowerShell Scripts is a technique corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1059.001 within the Execution tactic, primarily for Windows. It involves abusing the built-in PowerShell environment to execute arbitrary commands, scripts, and binaries, often for discovery and code execution. Key mechanics include using cmdlets like Start-Process and Invoke-Command to run processes locally or remotely, and downloading/executing payloads from the internet directly in memory to avoid disk. Execution can also occur without the powershell.exe binary by interfacing with the underlying System.Management.Automation assembly via .NET. This technique is leveraged by numerous threat groups and tools like Empire and PowerSploit.

1224.name: MPK Bot
1224.uncertain_mes: [Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) is a .NET downloader that has been used by [Saint Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1031) since at least March 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Saint Bot April 2021)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 OutSteel SaintBot February 2022 )
1224.profile: [profile]MPK Bot, also known as Saint Bot, is a .NET downloader malware attributed to the Saint Bear (also known as Ember Bear) intrusion set and associated with Magic Hound. It communicates with its command and control server via private messages to an "mpk" account and has been used in phishing attacks involving compromised or spoofed government email addresses.
1224.profile_without_enhance: [profile]MPK Bot, also known as Magichound.Leash, is a malware attributed to the Magic Hound intrusion set. It communicates with command and control servers at domains including service.chrome-up[.]date, msservice[.]site, and microsoftexplorerservices[.]cloud, and IP address 45.56.123[.]129. It is related to the malware MAGICHOUND.FETCH.[/profile]

1225.name: Meterpreter
1225.uncertain_mes: Web servers are vulnerable to attacks because they are publicly accessible to a wide range of users for the purpose of delivering web services. This accessibility makes them a prime target for threat actors. AhnLab Security Emergency response Center (ASEC) is monitoring attacks targeting vulnerable web servers that have not been patched or are poorly managed.
1225.profile: [profile]Meterpreter is a payload within the Metasploit framework used for post-exploitation. It is associated with groups like Magic Hound and has been used by or with tools like Bumblebee and Cobalt Strike, which are linked to numerous threat actors including APT29, APT32, APT41, FIN6, FIN7, and Mustang Panda. Its key technical behaviors include providing a command shell on compromised systems, enabling file operations, privilege escalation, and network pivoting, primarily targeting Windows platforms but with extensions for other systems like Linux, Android, and PHP. It leverages vulnerable or poorly managed web servers for initial access and deployment.[/profile]
1225.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Meterpreter, also known as meterpreter, is a payload and post-exploitation tool often associated with threat groups like APT29, APT32, APT41, FIN6, FIN7, and Mustang Panda, as well as criminal actors such as Exotic Lily and TA578. It operates as a memory-resident, extensible payload that provides a command and control (C2) shell on compromised systems, enabling attackers to execute commands, upload/download files, and perform lateral movement. Primarily targeting Windows platforms, it is frequently deployed alongside other frameworks like Cobalt Strike and Bumblebee loader.

1226.name: Backdoors
1226.uncertain_mes:
Zscaler Blog
Get the latest Zscaler blog updates in your inbox
YiBackdoor: A New Malware Family With Links to IcedID and Latrodectus
Introduction
1226.profile: [profile]YiBackdoor is a new malware family with links to IcedID and Latrodectus. It is a backdoor and is associated with the intrusion sets APT10 and Magic Hound. Its technical behavior involves backdoor capabilities, and it may be designed as a stealthy passive backdoor to avoid detection by not listening on ports or pinging a C2 server. Target platforms are unspecified. Supplementary infrastructure or groups from retrieved content include potential links to Daxin, BPFdoor (associated with Red Menshen), and Azorult (associated with The Gorgon Group).[/profile]
1226.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Backdoors is a general malware category. Specific examples include Daxin, which provides backdoor capabilities, and BPFdoor, a stealthy passive backdoor implant that avoids listening on ports or pinging a C2 server. The Azorult malware also functions as a backdoor. These are associated with various groups like Red Menshen and The Gorgon Group.

1227.name: Obfs3
1227.profile: [profile]Obfs3 is a network traffic obfuscation technique used to hide command and control (C2) communications, making them more difficult to detect and analyze. It is associated with the intrusion-set Magic Hound and leverages the Tor Project infrastructure. The technique functions by applying multiple layers of obfuscation, which can include adding junk data to protocol traffic, to disguise malicious communications within otherwise legitimate-looking network protocols like TCP. This method is a specific implementation of broader adversary behaviors for data obfuscation and multilayer encryption in C2 channels.[/profile]
1227.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Obfs3 is a network traffic obfuscation technique used to disguise command and control (C2) communications, making them more difficult to detect and analyze. It operates by adding junk data to protocol traffic and employing multiple layers of encryption, often tunneling a custom encryption scheme within a standard protocol like TCP. This method allows adversaries to blend malicious traffic with legitimate network activity, such as standard TCP communications on common ports, to evade security monitoring.[/profile]

1228.name: TCP
1228.profile: [profile]TCP is a fundamental network transport protocol, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK attack pattern. It serves as the underlying layer for many command and control techniques, such as custom protocols (T1094) or communication over commonly used ports (T1043), where adversaries use TCP to encapsulate malicious traffic and blend with legitimate network activity on standard ports like 80, 443, or 22.
1228.profile_without_enhance: [profile]TCP is a foundational network protocol used for reliable, connection-oriented communication. It is not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique but the transport layer for many techniques. Adversaries leverage TCP to encapsulate custom command and control (C2) protocols, operate over both standard and non-standard ports to blend with normal traffic or bypass defenses, and conduct activities like credential stuffing against management services (e.g., SSH on 22/TCP, RDP on 3389/TCP). It serves as the underlying transport for obfuscation methods like Obfs3.[/profile]

1235.name: Windows PowerShell Exploitation
1235.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution. PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system.(Citation: TechNet PowerShell) Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code. Examples include the Start-Process cmdlet which can be used to run an executable and the Invoke-Command cmdlet which runs a command locally or on a remote computer (though administrator permissions are required to use PowerShell to connect to remote systems). PowerShell may also be used to download and run executables from the Internet, which can be executed from disk or in memory without touching disk. A number of PowerShell-based offensive testing tools are available, including [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363), [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194), [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378), and PSAttack.(Citation: Github PSAttack) PowerShell commands/scripts can also be executed without directly invoking the powershell.exe binary through interfaces to PowerShell's underlying System.Management.Automation assembly DLL exposed through the .NET framework and Windows Common Language Interface (CLI).(Citation: Sixdub PowerPick Jan 2016)(Citation: SilentBreak Offensive PS Dec 2015)(Citation: Microsoft PSfromCsharp APR 2014)
1235.profile: [profile]Windows PowerShell Exploitation, identified as T1059.001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a Command and Scripting Interpreter technique primarily used for Execution on Windows platforms. It involves abusing the built-in PowerShell environment to run malicious commands and scripts, including using cmdlets like `Start-Process` and `Invoke-Command` for local or remote code execution. Adversaries can download and run payloads directly in memory, bypassing disk, and can execute scripts without invoking `powershell.exe` by leveraging the underlying `System.Management.Automation` assembly through .NET interfaces. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups, including Magic Hound, and is associated with offensive tools like Empire and PowerSploit.[/profile]
1235.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Windows PowerShell Exploitation" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell (T1059.001), categorized under Execution and primarily affecting the Windows platform. This technique involves adversaries abusing the powerful PowerShell environment to execute malicious commands and scripts, including using cmdlets like `Start-Process` and `Invoke-Command` to run executables or commands locally and remotely. It enables in-memory execution to avoid disk writes and can be invoked indirectly through the `System.Management.Automation` assembly DLL or by proxying execution via signed scripts like `SyncAppvPublishingServer.vbs` to bypass restrictions.

1237.name: Spear-Phishing Attacks
1237.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
1237.profile: [profile]Spear-Phishing Attacks, identified as MITRE ATT&CK T1566, is an Initial Access tactic used across multiple platforms. It involves sending targeted electronic messages to specific individuals or organizations, often via email with malicious attachments or links, to execute code or harvest credentials. Techniques include posing as a trusted source, email spoofing, thread hijacking, and using third-party services. The intrusion-set Magic Hound has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1237.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-Phishing Attacks correspond to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1566.001 (Spearphishing Attachment) under the Initial Access tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. This targeted social engineering attack involves sending emails to specific individuals or organizations with malicious attachments, such as Microsoft Office documents or executables, often disguised with manipulated file extensions. Execution relies on the victim opening the attachment, potentially exploiting a vulnerability or directly running a payload, with emails frequently providing instructions to bypass security protections or decrypt files to evade detection.

1240.name: Autorun Registry Key
1240.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may reduce the level of effort required to decrypt data transmitted over the network by reducing the cipher strength of encrypted communications.(Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Adversaries can weaken the encryption software on a compromised network device by reducing the key size used by the software to convert plaintext to ciphertext (e.g., from hundreds or thousands of bytes to just a couple of bytes). As a result, adversaries dramatically reduce the amount of effort needed to decrypt the protected information without the key.

Adversaries may modify the key size used and other encryption parameters using specialized commands in a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) introduced to the system through [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601) to change the configuration of the device. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
1240.profile: [profile]Autorun Registry Key, also known as Boot or Logon Autostart Execution (T1547.001), is a Persistence technique for Windows. Adversaries achieve persistence by adding program references to specific Windows Registry "run keys," such as HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run or HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run, which cause the referenced program to execute automatically upon user login or system boot. This method is used by groups like Magic Hound to maintain access through reboots, often by referencing malware or remote access tools directly or via dependencies like DLLs loaded through RunOnceEx keys.
1240.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Autorun Registry Key is a persistence technique where adversaries add entries to Windows Registry "run keys" to automatically execute malicious programs upon user login or system boot. Standard run keys include HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run. This method, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK T1547.001 under the Persistence tactic for Windows, allows execution under the user's context and permissions to maintain access.

1241.name: AES Encryption
1241.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise a network deviceâ€™s encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications. (Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Encryption can be used to protect transmitted network traffic to maintain its confidentiality (protect against unauthorized disclosure) and integrity (protect against unauthorized changes). Encryption ciphers are used to convert a plaintext message to ciphertext and can be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated decryption key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key.

Adversaries can compromise and manipulate devices that perform encryption of network traffic. For example, through behaviors such as [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601), [Reduce Key Space](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/001), and [Disable Crypto Hardware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/002), an adversary can negatively effect and/or eliminate a deviceâ€™s ability to securely encrypt network traffic. This poses a greater risk of unauthorized disclosure and may help facilitate data manipulation, Credential Access, or Collection efforts. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
1241.profile: [profile]The entity "AES Encryption" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to the misuse of symmetric encryption, such as AES, for command and control or data exfiltration, as seen in techniques like T1573.001 (Symmetric Cryptography). This involves adversaries using shared-key algorithms to conceal malicious traffic within protocols like HTTPS or HTTP, potentially creating multiple encryption layers to evade detection. Related threat groups include APT28, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.
1241.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "AES Encryption" is a symmetric encryption algorithm used to conceal data. It maps to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1573.001 (Symmetric Cryptography) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. The technique involves using the same key for both encryption and decryption of plaintext, commonly employed to obfuscate command and traffic or for data exfiltration over non-command and control protocols, potentially creating multiple encryption layers.

1242.name: HTTP Request
1242.profile: [profile]HTTP Request is a fundamental web protocol (T1071.001) used for Command and Control, blending malicious traffic with legitimate web activity. Adversaries embed commands and data within standard HTTP/S packet fields and headers to evade detection. Specific techniques include spoofing the User-Agent header (T1036.012) to mimic legitimate browser fingerprints and conducting HTTP flood attacks (T1499.002) to exhaust web service resources for denial-of-service. The intrusion-set Magic Hound is known to employ this protocol.[/profile]
1242.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTP Request is a fundamental web protocol (T1071.001) used for communication. Adversaries leverage it to blend malicious traffic with normal web activity, embedding commands and data within standard HTTP/S fields and headers to evade detection. It is also a core mechanism for conducting denial-of-service attacks, such as simple HTTP floods that overwhelm servers by exhausting resources with a high volume of requests.

1244.name: Social Engineering Tactics
1244.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may search social media for information about victims that can be used during targeting. Social media sites may contain various information about a victim organization, such as business announcements as well as information about the roles, locations, and interests of staff.

Adversaries may search in different social media sites depending on what information they seek to gather. Threat actors may passively harvest data from these sites, as well as use information gathered to create fake profiles/groups to elicit victimâ€™s into revealing specific information (i.e. [Spearphishing Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/001)).(Citation: Cyware Social Media) Information from these sources may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Establish Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1585) or [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [Spearphishing via Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/003)).
1244.profile: [profile]Social Media, identified as T1593.001 under the Reconnaissance tactic, involves adversaries searching platforms like LinkedIn or Facebook to passively harvest victim information. This includes gathering business announcements, staff roles, and personal interests. The collected data is used to craft targeted lures, such as creating fake profiles for spearphishing, and enables follow-on actions like establishing accounts or conducting further technical reconnaissance. Groups like Kimsuky have employed this technique.[/profile]
1244.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Social Engineering Tactics is a broad category of adversarial techniques focused on psychological manipulation to deceive individuals into divulging confidential information or performing actions that compromise security. It is not a single MITRE ATT&CK technique but an overarching concept encompassing methods like spearphishing via service (T1598.001) and voice (T1598.004), which use tailored lures sent through third-party services or phone calls, and the compromise of social media accounts (T1586.001) to establish trusted personas. These tactics are primarily used in the Reconnaissance and Initial Access phases to gather intelligence, establish footholds, and facilitate credential theft.

1245.name: Decoy Executable
1245.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may inject portable executables (PE) into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. PE injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. PE injection is commonly performed by copying code (perhaps without a file on disk) into the virtual address space of the target process before invoking it via a new thread. The write can be performed with native Windows API calls such as VirtualAllocEx and WriteProcessMemory, then invoked with CreateRemoteThread or additional code (ex: shellcode). The displacement of the injected code does introduce the additional requirement for functionality to remap memory references. (Citation: Elastic Process Injection July 2017) Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via PE injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process.
1245.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Process Injection: Portable Executable Injection" (ID: T1055.002) under the Defense Evasion and Privilege Escalation tactics, primarily for Windows. It works by copying a portable executable (PE) into a target process's virtual address space using Windows API calls like `VirtualAllocEx` and `WriteProcessMemory`, then executing it via `CreateRemoteThread` to run code under a legitimate process, evading detection and potentially gaining elevated privileges. It has been associated with groups like Gorgon Group and Rocke.
1245.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Decoy Executable is a technique where adversaries create or rename malicious files to appear as legitimate executables, often using names similar to common system or application files to evade detection and trick users into executing them. This method is typically associated with the Defense Evasion tactic and commonly targets Windows platforms. The technique involves placing these deceptive files in directories where users or automated processes are likely to encounter and run them, such as through phishing attachments or network shares, thereby facilitating initial access or execution.

1246.name: Evasion Tactic
1246.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers. Debuggers are typically used by defenders to trace and/or analyze the execution of potential malware payloads.(Citation: ProcessHacker Github) Debugger evasion may include changing behaviors based on the results of the checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a debugged environment. Similar to [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497), if the adversary detects a debugger, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for debugger artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary. On Windows, this may involve [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as IsDebuggerPresent() and NtQueryInformationProcess(), or manually checking the BeingDebugged flag of the Process Environment Block (PEB). On Linux, this may involve querying `/proc/self/status` for the `TracerPID` field, which indicates whether or not the process is being traced by dynamic analysis tools.(Citation: Cado Security P2PInfect 2023)(Citation: Positive Technologies Hellhounds 2023) Other checks for debugging artifacts may also seek to enumerate hardware breakpoints, interrupt assembly opcodes, time checks, or measurements if exceptions are raised in the current process (assuming a present debugger would â€œswallowâ€ or handle the potential error).(Citation: hasherezade debug)(Citation: AlKhaser Debug)(Citation: vxunderground debug) Malware may also leverage Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to detect debuggers by throwing an exception and detecting whether the process is suspended. SEH handles both hardware and software expectations, providing control over the exceptions including support for debugging. If a debugger is present, the programâ€™s control will be transferred to the debugger, and the execution of the code will be suspended. If the debugger is not present, control will be transferred to the SEH handler, which will automatically handle the exception and allow the programâ€™s execution to continue.(Citation: Apriorit) Adversaries may use the information learned from these debugger checks during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors. Debuggers can also be evaded by detaching the process or flooding debug logs with meaningless data via messages produced by looping [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as OutputDebugStringW().(Citation: wardle evilquest partii)(Citation: Checkpoint Dridex Jan 2021)
1246.profile: [profile]Debugger Evasion is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1622 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows and Linux platforms. It involves detecting debugger artifacts to alter malware behavior or avoid analysis. Specific technical mechanics include Windows API calls like IsDebuggerPresent(), checking the PEB's BeingDebugged flag, querying Linux /proc/self/status for TracerPID, using Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to test for process suspension, enumerating hardware breakpoints, and flooding logs with OutputDebugStringW() calls. The intrusion-set Magic Hound has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1246.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Evasion Tactic is a broad adversarial approach within the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It encompasses specific techniques like Debugger Evasion (T1622) and Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion (T1497). Technical mechanics involve checking for analysis artifacts, such as using Windows API calls like `IsDebuggerPresent()` or querying Linux `/proc/self/status`, and altering malware behavior or using sleep timers to avoid detection in monitored environments. Related methods include modifying tools to remove detection indicators after security software discovery.

1247.name: Binder
1247.profile: [profile]Binder is a technique for custom command and control protocol (T1094) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across multiple platforms, including Windows, Linux, and macOS. The technique involves adversaries implementing a unique communication protocol instead of using standard application layer protocols. This can involve mimicking legitimate protocols or developing entirely new ones using raw sockets or other low-level network stack features. The intrusion-set Magic Hound has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1247.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Binder is a technique where adversaries embed malicious code within legitimate data streams or protocols to evade detection and establish command and control. This involves encapsulating commands or payloads inside standard application-layer protocols or custom protocols, effectively hiding malicious traffic within normal network communications. The method can be used across various platforms to facilitate initial access, execution, and persistence by blending with benign traffic.

1250.name: Rocket Kitty
1250.uncertain_mes: [edit]In November 2015, security errors by Rocket Kitten allowed the firm Check Point to gain password-less root access to "Oyun", the hackers' back-end database.
1250.profile: [profile]Rocket Kitty, also known as Rocket Kitten, Thamar Reservoir, Timberworm, Temp.Beanie, Operation Woolen Goldfish, and Operation Woolen-Goldfish, is an intrusion set. Its arsenal includes the back-end database "Oyun," which was compromised in 2015 due to security errors. The group is believed to be linked to or overlaps with APT32 (OceanLotus), as suggested by the similar naming convention "Cobalt Kitty" used in an APT32 campaign. Its primary motivation is cyber espionage, targeting proprietary business information, with a noted focus on corporations in Asia.
1250.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set "Rocket Kitty" is believed to be a moniker for the advanced persistent threat group APT32, also known as OceanLotus, APT-C-00, and SeaLotus. This group is attributed to Vietnam and is known for Operation Cobalt Kitty, a large-scale cyber espionage campaign targeting a global corporation in Asia to steal proprietary business information. Its key tools and TTPs are not detailed in the provided data, but its primary motivation is cyber espionage, focusing on corporate and potentially governmental targets in the Asia-Pacific region.

This group is attributed to Vietnam and is a cyber espionage actor. Its activities, such as the campaign dubbed Operation Cobalt Kitty, target corporations in Asia to steal proprietary business information. The group employs custom tools and malware, with its key TTPs and motivations aligning with state-sponsored intelligence gathering.

Its key motivations are espionage and intellectual property theft, primarily focusing on corporate and governmental sectors in the Asia-Pacific region.

1253.name: Unknown_Threat_Actor
1253.profile: [profile]This entity is currently designated as an unknown threat actor, indicating a lack of definitive attribution or standardized naming within public threat intelligence. Its operational profile, including specific malware, tools, tactics, techniques, procedures (TTPs), origin, target sectors, and primary motivations, remains uncharacterized and requires further investigation for identification and classification.
1253.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as "Shamoon" (also known as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy). Its key malware includes the Disttrack dropper and the Disttrack/Shamoon wiper. Its primary TTPs involve data destruction via direct disk access, lateral movement using SMB shares (e.g., net use), and establishing persistence through Windows services like "drdisk." The group is strongly attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors and has historically targeted the energy sector, particularly in Saudi Arabia. Its primary motivation is disruptive and destructive attacks against critical infrastructure.
1253.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]This intrusion set, likely associated with the Chinese state-sponsored APT group Mustang Panda (also known as RedDelta, BRONZE PRESIDENT, or Temp.Hex), primarily uses the PlugX malware (and its variant Hodur) for backdoor access and data exfiltration, often delivered via spear-phishing and malicious documents. Its operations are attributed to China and frequently target government, diplomatic, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) across Southeast Asia, Europe, and the United States, with motivations centered on espionage and information gathering aligned with Chinese state interests.
1253.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set, whose standardized APT designation is currently unknown, is a suspected Chinese state-sponsored threat actor that has been active since at least 2019. It is also known as Earth Lusca and TA423. The group's operations are characterized by the use of custom malware families such as Spyder Loader and the China Chopper web shell, alongside publicly available tools like Cobalt Strike. Its key TTPs include spear-phishing with geopolitical lures and exploiting public-facing applications (e.g., Microsoft Exchange, Confluence) for initial access. The group is believed to originate from China and primarily targets government, education, and media sectors across Southeast Asia, particularly Taiwan, Hong Kong, and the Philippines, with motivations centered on espionage and information gathering aligned with Chinese state interests.
1253.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as Shamoon (also known as Disttrack, Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy). Its key malware is the Disttrack/Shamoon wiper, which uses a dropper component and a modified Eldos RawDisk driver for direct disk access. Key TTPs include data destruction by overwriting files with images, worm-like propagation via SMB shares, and establishing persistence through services like "drdisk". The group is attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors and primarily targets organizations in the Middle East, especially the energy sector in Saudi Arabia, with a clear motivation for disruptive and destructive cyber operations.
1253.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is highly likely the APT group known as Shamoon, also referred to as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its operations are distinguished by the use of the Disttrack wiper malware (also called Shamoon), which employs a dropper component and a modified Eldos RawDisk driver for destructive file overwriting and local network spreading via SMB. Key TTPs include creating a "drdisk" service for persistence, using NetScheduleJobAdd for remote task scheduling, and performing network reconnaissance with techniques like Enumerate /24 Networks and NetRemoteTOD. The group is attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors and has historically targeted the energy sector in Saudi Arabia, with a primary motivation of data destruction and disruptive impact.
1253.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is highly likely the APT group known as "Shamoon" (also known as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy). Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper (Shamoon), which uses a dropper component and a modified Eldos RawDisk driver for direct disk access to destroy data. Key TTPs include worm-like behavior for lateral movement via SMB shares, data destruction via file overwriting, and defense evasion through techniques like disabling UAC remote restrictions and decrypting drivers with a custom XOR key. The group is attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors and primarily targets the energy sector and other organizations in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with a clear motivation for disruptive and destructive cyber operations.
1253.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]This intrusion set is attributed to the APT group known as Shamoon, also referred to as Timberworm, Magic Hound, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its operations are distinguished by the use of the Disttrack (Shamoon) destructive wiper malware, which employs a dropper component to deploy a wiper module and a modified Eldos RawDisk driver for direct disk access to overwrite files with politically oriented images like "Alan Kurdi." Key TTPs include data destruction (T1485), lateral movement via SMB shares, and persistence through Windows service creation (e.g., "drdisk"). The group is believed to be state-sponsored and originates from Iran, with a consistent focus on targeting the energy sector and other critical infrastructure in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, primarily motivated by espionage and disruptive cyber operations.

Key TTPs include local network spreading via SMB shares, data destruction, and the use of custom decryption (e.g., a 226-byte XOR key). The group is attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors and primarily targets organizations in the energy sector, particularly in Saudi Arabia, with a clear motivation for disruptive and destructive attacks.

1254.name: Disttrack
1254.uncertain_mes:
View Only
Feb 27, 2017 09:11 AM
Recent attacks involving the destructive malware Shamoon (W32.Disttrack.B) were launched by attackers conducting a much wider campaign in the Middle East. While the attackers have compromised multiple targets in the region, only selected targets in Saudi Arabia were infected with Shamoon.
1254.profile: [profile]Disttrack, also known as W32.Disttrack and Shamoon, is a destructive wiper malware. It has been associated with groups such as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key behaviors include using a dropper component, a communications component, and the Eldos RawDisk driver to facilitate its destructive wiping actions. The malware primarily targets organizations in the Middle East, with notable attacks against selected targets in Saudi Arabia. Its distribution system has been linked to the Magic Hound campaign, and it is detected under various signatures including W32.Disttrack.B and Trojan.Filerase.
1254.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Disttrack, also known as Shamoon, is a destructive wiper malware family attributed to groups including Shamoon, Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key technical behaviors include data destruction via file overwriting, local network spreading using SMB shares, and the use of a modified Eldos RawDisk Driver for raw disk access. It targets Windows platforms and is delivered via dropper components, with its distribution system linked to the Magic Hound group.[/profile]

1255.name: Wiper
1255.uncertain_mes: [Wiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0041) is a family of destructive malware used in March 2013 during breaches of South Korean banks and media companies. (Citation: Dell Wiper)
1255.profile: [profile]Wiper is a family of destructive malware used in March 2013 during breaches of South Korean banks and media companies. It is associated with the intrusion set Unknown_Threat_Actor and is related to malware families like Disttrack and Eldos RawDisk Driver. Its key technical behavior is data destruction, targeting platforms such as Windows systems involved in the South Korean incidents. Infrastructure and supplementary information includes potential connections to other wiper variants like Bruh Wiper, Cry Wiper, Endurance, and Fantasy, as indicated by shared hash lists in related content.[/profile]
1255.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Wiper is a family of destructive malware, with a notable variant known as Disttrack (also called W32.Disttrack, W32.Disttrack.B, and Trojan.Filerase). It is attributed to the Shamoon intrusion set and linked to groups like Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key behavior is data destruction, using components like a dropper, a wiper module, and the Eldos RawDisk driver for low-level disk access to target partition tables and registry keys. It primarily targets organizations, with a noted focus on the Middle East and South Korea, and has been used in campaigns since at least 2013.
