1256.profile: [profile]Disttrack Dropper, also known as Disttrack, is a component of the Shamoon destructive malware family. It is associated with groups like Shamoon, Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key technical behavior is acting as a dropper that extracts and coordinates the execution of embedded tools, including separate communications and wiper modules, with samples identified for both x86 and x64 architectures. It primarily targets systems in the Middle East, specifically in Saudi Arabia.[/profile]
1256.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Disttrack Dropper, also known as Disttrack, is a component of the Shamoon destructive malware family, attributed to groups such as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key technical behavior is to act as a dropper that extracts and coordinates the execution of embedded tools, including separate communication and wiper modules, from its resources. It targets Windows platforms, with distinct x86 and x64 variants, and is associated with wider campaigns in the Middle East, particularly against selected targets in Saudi Arabia.

1257.name: Communication Module
1257.profile: [profile]Communication Module is a malware component. It is associated with the Unknown_Threat_Actor intrusion set. It is referenced as a module-specific communication component by the Icedid malware, which is linked to groups like Gold Cabin and Lunar Spider. It is also referenced as a communication protocol by the Keymarble malware, associated with the Lazarus Group. The Triton malware, linked to Xenotime, references specific Tricon Communication Module (TCM) hardware models in its code. Its key technical behavior is facilitating command and control or data exchange. Target platforms are not specified.[/profile]
1257.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware 'Communication Module' is a component of the IcedID banking trojan, which is attributed to threat groups like Gold Cabin and Lunar Spider. Its key technical behavior is to handle module-specific communication for the parent malware. The target platform is Windows systems, as part of the IcedID infection chain. This module facilitates command-and-control and data exfiltration operations for the trojan.

1264.name: Worm-like Behavior
1264.profile: [profile]Worm-like Behavior is a characteristic of malware used to propagate across a network to maximize impact, particularly in operations aiming for network-wide availability interruption. This behavior is often employed in conjunction with destructive techniques like Disk Content Wipe (T1488). To achieve propagation, the malware leverages additional techniques such as Valid Accounts (T1078), OS Credential Dumping (T1003), and Windows Admin Shares (T1077) to spread from system to system.
1264.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Worm-like Behavior is a characteristic of malware designed for network-wide propagation and impact, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is referenced as a feature of destructive malware that wipes disk content, as seen in techniques like Disk Content Wipe (T1488). This behavior enables malware to spread across a network by leveraging techniques such as Valid Accounts, OS Credential Dumping, and Windows Admin Shares to maximize disruption and availability interruption.

1265.name: Data Destruction
1265.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may destroy data and files on specific systems or in large numbers on a network to interrupt availability to systems, services, and network resources. Data destruction is likely to render stored data irrecoverable by forensic techniques through overwriting files or data on local and remote drives.(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018) Common operating system file deletion commands such as del and rm often only remove pointers to files without wiping the contents of the files themselves, making the files recoverable by proper forensic methodology. This behavior is distinct from [Disk Content Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/001) and [Disk Structure Wipe](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/002) because individual files are destroyed rather than sections of a storage disk or the disk's logical structure. Adversaries may attempt to overwrite files and directories with randomly generated data to make it irrecoverable.(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018) In some cases politically oriented image files have been used to overwrite data.(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017) To maximize impact on the target organization in operations where network-wide availability interruption is the goal, malware designed for destroying data may have worm-like features to propagate across a network by leveraging additional techniques like [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078), [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), and [SMB/Windows Admin Shares](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002).(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)(Citation: Talos Olympic Destroyer 2018). In cloud environments, adversaries may leverage access to delete cloud storage objects, machine images, database instances, and other infrastructure crucial to operations to damage an organization or their customers.(Citation: Data Destruction - Threat Post)(Citation: DOJ - Cisco Insider) Similarly, they may delete virtual machines from on-prem virtualized environments.
1265.profile: [profile]Data Destruction is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1485 under the Impact tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and cloud platforms. It aims to render files irrecoverable by overwriting them with random data or specific images, going beyond simple deletion commands like `del` or `rm`. Malware implementing this, such as Disttrack, may propagate using worm-like features and techniques like Valid Accounts. It is distinct from disk-level wipes and is associated with groups like APT38 and Sandworm Team.
1265.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Data Destruction, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1485, is an Impact tactic executed across Windows, Linux, and cloud platforms. It aims to render files irrecoverable by overwriting them with random data or specific files, moving beyond simple deletion commands like `del` or `rm`. The technique can be incorporated into worm-like malware that propagates via Valid Accounts and SMB shares, and in cloud environments, it targets storage objects and virtual infrastructure.

1266.name: Local Network Spreading
1266.profile: [profile]Local Network Spreading is a technique for Lateral Movement. It involves propagating malware within a local network segment, often using tools like the Disttrack malware. This activity is associated with an unknown threat actor. The method focuses on moving between systems on the same internal network to expand access and control.
1266.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Local Network Spreading is a technique for Lateral Movement, likely targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries moving from a compromised host to other systems within the same local network segment. This is achieved by abusing legitimate remote administration tools and protocols, such as Windows Admin Shares (SMB) with commands like `net use` and `psexec`, or by exploiting remote services. The goal is to expand control across the network using credentials obtained through prior attacks.

1267.name: Extract Other Tools
1267.profile: [profile]Extract Other Tools is a technique where adversaries gather legitimate software tools, such as remote access or deployment tools like PsExec, from external sources like adversary-controlled web servers or third-party repositories (e.g., GitHub) to facilitate their operations. These tools are then made accessible for transfer into a victim network to support activities like lateral movement or command and control, often using compromised or purchased infrastructure for staging.
1267.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Extract Other Tools" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to describe an adversary action within the broader context of tool management. This involves uploading tools to accessible infrastructure, such as adversary-controlled web servers or third-party services like GitHub or Heroku, to facilitate their transfer into a victim network during operations like Ingress Tool Transfer. This action supports follow-on activities by staging necessary utilities.

1268.name: Coordinates When to Save and Execute
1268.profile: [profile]Coordinates When to Save and Execute is a technique where adversaries schedule the timing of data exfiltration or malicious execution to blend with normal activity. It is related to the Scheduled Transfer (T1029) technique, which involves performing data transfers at specific times or intervals. This method can be used to evade detection by aligning malicious traffic with legitimate patterns, often employing other exfiltration methods like C2 channels for the actual data transfer.
1268.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Coordinates When to Save and Execute is a technique for scheduling data exfiltration, aligning with Tactic Exfiltration (TA0010). It involves adversaries timing the transfer of stolen data to blend with normal network activity or operational schedules. This scheduling is often used in conjunction with other exfiltration methods like Exfiltration Over C2 Channel. The technique has been associated with the threat group Higaisa.

1269.name: Communicates with C2 Server
1269.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may buy, lease, rent, or obtain physical serversÂ that can be used during targeting. Use of servers allows an adversary to stage, launch, and execute an operation. During post-compromise activity, adversaries may utilize servers for various tasks, such as watering hole operations in [Drive-by Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189), enabling [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) operations, or facilitating [Command and Control](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0011). Instead of compromising a third-party [Server](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584/004) or renting a [Virtual Private Server](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583/003), adversaries may opt to configure and run their own servers in support of operations. Free trial periods of cloud servers may also be abused.(Citation: Free Trial PurpleUrchin)(Citation: Freejacked) 

Adversaries may only need a lightweight setup if most of their activities will take place using online infrastructure. Or, they may need to build extensive infrastructure if they want to test, communicate, and control other aspects of their activities on their own systems.(Citation: NYTStuxnet)
1269.profile: [profile]The entity "Communicates with C2 Server" is a generic description of adversary command and control activity, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. The provided data primarily describes the MITRE technique "Server" (T1583.004) under the Resource Development tactic, where adversaries acquire physical servers to stage operations, conduct watering hole attacks, enable phishing, or facilitate C2. This can involve buying, leasing, or abusing free cloud server trials to build infrastructure. Associated threat groups include Earth Lusca, Mustard Tempest, and Kimsuky.[/profile]
1269.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Communicates with C2 Server is a Command and Control tactic, designated T1071, operating across Windows, Linux, and Mac platforms. It involves malware establishing a network connection to an adversary-controlled server to receive instructions and exfiltrate data, using standard protocols like HTTP, HTTPS, DNS, or SMTPS. This activity enables remote control of compromised systems and is a core post-compromise behavior for maintaining persistence.

1270.name: Performs Wiper Functions
1270.profile: [profile]Performs Wiper Functions is a technique where adversaries deploy malware designed to destroy or irreversibly corrupt data on targeted systems, often as part of a disruptive or destructive attack campaign. This action is associated with the intrusion-set Unknown_Threat_Actor. The technique involves specific functions within malicious code that overwrite, delete, or encrypt files with no recovery option, aiming to render systems inoperable and cause operational damage.[/profile]
1270.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Performs Wiper Functions is a technique where adversaries deploy malware designed to destroy or render inaccessible data on targeted systems, often as part of a disruptive or destructive attack. This is achieved by executing functions that overwrite, delete, or corrupt files, master boot records, or entire disk partitions. The technique is associated with the Impact tactic and typically targets Windows and Linux platforms, aiming to cause operational damage and data loss.

1271.name: Obtain System's IP Address
1271.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may buy and/or steal capabilities that can be used during targeting. Rather than developing their own capabilities in-house, adversaries may purchase, freely download, or steal them. Activities may include the acquisition of malware, software (including licenses), exploits, certificates, and information relating to vulnerabilities. Adversaries may obtain capabilities to support their operations throughout numerous phases of the adversary lifecycle.

In addition to downloading free malware, software, and exploits from the internet, adversaries may purchase these capabilities from third-party entities. Third-party entities can include technology companies that specialize in malware and exploits, criminal marketplaces, or from individuals.(Citation: NationsBuying)(Citation: PegasusCitizenLab)

In addition to purchasing capabilities, adversaries may steal capabilities from third-party entities (including other adversaries). This can include stealing software licenses, malware, SSL/TLS and code-signing certificates, or raiding closed databases of vulnerabilities or exploits.(Citation: DiginotarCompromise)
1271.profile: [profile]The entity "Obtain System's IP Address" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is a reconnaissance action to gather a victim's IP addresses, which can be used for targeting and to infer details like organizational size and location. This information can be collected via methods such as Active Scanning (T1595) or Phishing for Information (T1598), or sourced from open technical databases. Acquiring IP addresses supports follow-on activities like further reconnaissance, infrastructure acquisition, or initial access.[/profile]
1271.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Obtain System's IP Address" is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries gather a victim's IP address information for targeting. This can be achieved through direct actions like Active Scanning (T1595.001) or by querying open technical databases. The gathered IP addresses, which may be allocated in blocks, reveal details about organizational infrastructure and can enable follow-on activities such as further network discovery using commands like `ipconfig` or `ifconfig`, or initial access via external services.

1272.name: Enumerate /24 Networks
1272.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gain initial access to target systems by connecting to wireless networks. They may accomplish this by exploiting open Wi-Fi networks used by target devices or by accessing secured Wi-Fi networks â€” requiring [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) â€” belonging to a target organization.(Citation: DOJ GRU Charges 2018)(Citation: Nearest Neighbor Volexity) Establishing a connection to a Wi-Fi access point requires a certain level of proximity to both discover and maintain a stable network connection. 

Adversaries may establish a wireless connection through various methods, such as by physically positioning themselves near a Wi-Fi network to conduct close access operations. To bypass the need for physical proximity, adversaries may attempt to remotely compromise nearby third-party systems that have both wired and wireless network connections available (i.e., dual-homed systems). These third-party compromised devices can then serve as a bridge to connect to a targetâ€™s Wi-Fi network.(Citation: Nearest Neighbor Volexity)

Once an initial wireless connection is achieved, adversaries may leverage this access for follow-on activities in the victim network or further targeting of specific devices on the network. Adversaries may perform [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) activities for [Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0006) or [Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0007).
1272.profile: [profile]The entity "Enumerate /24 Networks" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided text, it appears to describe a method for gaining initial access by connecting to wireless networks, which aligns with the concept of MITRE technique T1669 (Wi-Fi Networks). This tactic falls under Initial Access. The technical mechanics involve exploiting open networks or accessing secured ones using valid accounts, requiring physical proximity or the compromise of a dual-homed third-party system to bridge the connection. Once connected, adversaries may perform network sniffing or adversary-in-the-middle attacks for credential access or discovery. The technique has been associated with APT28.[/profile]
1272.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Enumerate /24 Networks is a network discovery technique within the Discovery tactic. It involves scanning a contiguous block of 256 IP addresses (a /24 subnet) to identify active hosts and services, often using tools like ping sweeps or port scanners. This method provides adversaries with a map of the target's local network infrastructure to shape follow-on attacks.

1273.name: Start RemoteRegistry Service
1273.profile: [profile]Start RemoteRegistry Service is a technique mapped to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1543.003 (Windows Service) under the Persistence tactic, targeting Windows platforms. It involves adversaries starting the legitimate RemoteRegistry service, which allows remote access to the registry, to enable or facilitate remote Registry modification for persistence or data collection. This action can be performed using utilities like sc.exe or PowerShell with commands such as `sc start RemoteRegistry`. The technique is linked to an unknown threat actor.
1273.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Start RemoteRegistry Service is a Windows-specific technique where adversaries manually start the Windows Remote Registry service to enable remote interaction with the Registry on a target system. This action, often performed using commands like `sc start RemoteRegistry` or `net start RemoteRegistry`, facilitates follow-on activities such as remote Registry modification for persistence or discovery. It falls under the Execution tactic, allowing adversaries to execute code or commands remotely by leveraging a legitimate but often disabled system service.

1274.name: Disable UAC Remote Restrictions
1274.profile: [profile]Disable UAC Remote Restrictions is a Windows-specific technique within the Privilege Escalation tactic, where adversaries modify the User Account Control (UAC) configuration to allow remote execution of processes with elevated privileges without triggering the standard local UAC prompt. This is achieved by setting the `LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy` registry key, which removes UAC restrictions for remote users in the local Administrators group, enabling lateral movement and remote code execution with high integrity.
1274.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Disable UAC Remote Restrictions is a Windows-specific technique under the Defense Evasion tactic. It involves modifying the Windows Registry to disable the User Account Control (UAC) remote restrictions, specifically by setting the `LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy` registry key to 1. This change allows remote users, including those in the local administrators group, to perform administrative tasks over the network without encountering UAC prompts, effectively bypassing a key security boundary for remote lateral movement.

1275.name: Connect to Remote System (NetUseAdd)
1275.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of other systems by IP address, hostname, or other logical identifier on a network that may be used for Lateral Movement from the current system. Functionality could exist within remote access tools to enable this, but utilities available on the operating system could also be used such as [Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097), net view using [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039), or, on ESXi servers, `esxcli network diag ping`. Adversaries may also analyze data from local host files (ex: C:\Windows\System32\Drivers\etc\hosts or /etc/hosts) or other passive means (such as local [Arp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0099) cache entries) in order to discover the presence of remote systems in an environment. Adversaries may also target discovery of network infrastructure as well as leverage [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) commands on network devices to gather detailed information about systems within a network (e.g. show cdp neighbors, show arp).(Citation: US-CERT-TA18-106A)(Citation: CISA AR21-126A FIVEHANDS May 2021)
1275.profile: [profile]The entity "Connect to Remote System (NetUseAdd)" is a technique for Lateral Movement, likely corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1021. It operates on Windows platforms by using the `net use` command with valid credentials or NTLM hashes to establish authenticated connections to remote Windows administrative shares (such as C$, ADMIN$, and IPC$) over the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol. This connection enables follow-on actions like remote file transfer and remote execution, including via Scheduled Tasks or Windows Management Instrumentation.
1275.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Connect to Remote System (NetUseAdd) is a technique for lateral movement. It involves using the Windows Net utility with the `net use` command to establish authenticated connections to remote systems via SMB, often targeting administrative shares like C$ or ADMIN$. This allows adversaries to map network drives, facilitating remote file operations and subsequent execution of payloads on the accessed system.

1276.name: Check Administrator Privileges
1276.profile: [profile]Check Administrator Privileges is a technique used to verify if a process or user has administrative rights on a system, often as a precursor to privilege escalation. It is associated with the tactic of Privilege Escalation and primarily targets the Windows platform. The technical mechanics involve querying system information or using commands like `whoami /groups` or checking for membership in the Administrators group. This action is commonly performed by threat actors, including Unknown_Threat_Actor, to determine if higher-level access can be achieved or if methods like bypassing User Account Control (UAC) are necessary for further exploitation.
1276.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Check Administrator Privileges is a technique where adversaries verify if the current user has administrator-level permissions, typically as a precursor to privilege escalation or lateral movement. This reconnaissance step often involves using native system commands or APIs, such as `whoami /groups` on Windows or checking group memberships on Unix-like systems, to assess the level of access available before attempting further exploitation.

1277.name: HTTP GET Request
1277.profile: [profile]The entity "HTTP GET Request" is a fundamental web protocol technique, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK ID T1071.001 (Web Protocols) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries abuse this standard protocol to conceal command and control traffic within normal web traffic, embedding data within HTTP request fields and headers to blend in and evade detection. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups, including APT28, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.
1277.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "HTTP GET Request" is a fundamental technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, primarily categorized under Command and Control (C2) as T1071.001 (Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols). It operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Adversaries abuse this standard web protocol to blend malicious C2 traffic with normal network activity by embedding commands and data within the standard fields and headers of HTTP GET requests. This technique is widely used by numerous threat groups to evade detection by mimicking legitimate web traffic.

1278.name: Hardcoded Host Server
1278.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may buy, lease, rent, or obtain physical serversÂ that can be used during targeting. Use of servers allows an adversary to stage, launch, and execute an operation. During post-compromise activity, adversaries may utilize servers for various tasks, such as watering hole operations in [Drive-by Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1189), enabling [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) operations, or facilitating [Command and Control](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0011). Instead of compromising a third-party [Server](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584/004) or renting a [Virtual Private Server](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583/003), adversaries may opt to configure and run their own servers in support of operations. Free trial periods of cloud servers may also be abused.(Citation: Free Trial PurpleUrchin)(Citation: Freejacked) 

Adversaries may only need a lightweight setup if most of their activities will take place using online infrastructure. Or, they may need to build extensive infrastructure if they want to test, communicate, and control other aspects of their activities on their own systems.(Citation: NYTStuxnet)
1278.profile: [profile]The entity "Server" is a sub-technique under MITRE ATT&CK ID T1583.004 within the Resource Development tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries acquiring physical servers to stage, launch, and execute operations, such as hosting watering holes for drive-by compromises, enabling phishing, or facilitating command and control. This can be done by purchasing, leasing, or abusing free cloud server trials instead of compromising third-party infrastructure. Associated threat groups include Earth Lusca, Mustard Tempest, and Kimsuky.
1278.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Hardcoded Host Server is a technique where adversaries embed a specific server address directly into malware or tools for command and control (C2). This method establishes a direct communication channel to a predetermined host, bypassing the need for dynamic DNS resolution. It is commonly used to ensure reliable C2 connectivity, often observed in malware that connects to a fixed IP or domain for data exfiltration or receiving instructions.

1279.name: Hardcoded URL category/page.php
1279.profile: [profile]Hardcoded URL category/page.php is a technique where adversaries embed a specific, unchanging URL (e.g., category/page.php) within malicious code or resources. This URL serves as a link target, typically pointing to an adversary-controlled page used in spearphishing campaigns to harvest credentials or deliver malware. The hardcoded nature means the destination is static and may be part of cloned legitimate login pages or malicious HTML designed for execution upon user interaction, facilitating initial access or information gathering.
1279.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Hardcoded URL category/page.php" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to be a specific implementation detail, likely a hardcoded web path (e.g., "page.php") used within malicious infrastructure. This could serve as a link target for spearphishing campaigns to host credential harvesting pages or malware, as seen in techniques like Spearphishing Link (T1566.002) and Malicious Link (T1204.001). The hardcoded URL may be part of a cloned legitimate site or malicious script deployed by threat actors.

1280.name: Hardcoded Shinu Parameter
1280.profile: [profile]Hardcoded Shinu Parameter is a technique where adversaries embed fixed, predetermined parameters within malware or scripts to control its behavior, often to specify command and control server addresses, encryption keys, or execution paths. This method allows for consistent malicious operations without requiring external configuration, but it can be a forensic indicator as the static values may be discovered through code analysis. The technique is associated with an unknown threat actor.[/profile]
1280.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Hardcoded Shinu Parameter is an attack-pattern with no direct MITRE ATT&CK mapping based on the provided data. The retrieved information describes unrelated techniques: PubPrn.vbs (T1216.001) for proxy execution, junk data in C2 (T1001.001) to hinder detection, and exploiting file/path exclusions (T1564.012) to hide artifacts. Without specific context for the named technique, its technical mechanics and standard classification cannot be determined from this input.

1281.name: Hardcoded User Agent
1281.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may create or modify launch agents to repeatedly execute malicious payloads as part of persistence. When a user logs in, a per-user launchd process is started which loads the parameters for each launch-on-demand user agent from the property list (.plist) file found in /System/Library/LaunchAgents, /Library/LaunchAgents, and ~/Library/LaunchAgents.(Citation: AppleDocs Launch Agent Daemons)(Citation: OSX Keydnap malware) (Citation: Antiquated Mac Malware) Property list files use the Label, ProgramArguments , and RunAtLoad keys to identify the Launch Agent's name, executable location, and execution time.(Citation: OSX.Dok Malware) Launch Agents are often installed to perform updates to programs, launch user specified programs at login, or to conduct other developer tasks. Launch Agents can also be executed using the [Launchctl](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1569/001) command. Adversaries may install a new Launch Agent that executes at login by placing a .plist file into the appropriate folders with the RunAtLoad or KeepAlive keys set to true.(Citation: Sofacy Komplex Trojan)(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) The Launch Agent name may be disguised by using a name from the related operating system or benign software. Launch Agents are created with user level privileges and execute with user level permissions.(Citation: OSX Malware Detection)(Citation: OceanLotus for OS X)
1281.profile: [profile]The entity "Hardcoded User Agent" is a technique for evading detection by setting a static, legitimate-looking User-Agent string in malicious web traffic. This falls under Defense Evasion (T1036.012) and targets web clients. The technique involves adversaries crafting HTTP requests with a fixed, common browser identifier (e.g., mimicking Chrome or Firefox) to bypass security controls that filter or log traffic based on anomalous user-agent headers, thereby blending in with normal network activity. It is distinct from macOS persistence mechanisms like Launch Agent (T1543.001).
1281.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Hardcoded User Agent is a technique where adversaries embed a static, predetermined User-Agent string within malware or tools to blend in with legitimate web traffic, often as part of Application Layer Protocol (T1071) for Command and Control. This spoofing, related to Browser Fingerprinting (T1036.012), helps evade detection by mimicking common browsers or systems identified through System Information Discovery. The hardcoded string is used in HTTP requests to avoid standing out from normal network activity.

1282.name: Render Inoperable
1282.profile: [profile]Render Inoperable is a technique used in the Impact tactic. It involves actions to disable or destroy system functionality. Technical mechanics include overwriting or corrupting device firmware, such as system BIOS, to prevent booting and deny availability. Adversaries may also stop or disable critical system services to make them unavailable to users, which can facilitate further destructive actions like data destruction.[/profile]
1282.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Render Inoperable is a general adversarial objective to deny availability, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. The retrieved context describes several distinct techniques that achieve this goal. These include Firmware Corruption (T1495), which involves overwriting system BIOS or device firmware to prevent booting, and Service Stop (T1489), where critical services are disabled to make systems or applications unavailable. The action targets system and device functionality to cause operational disruption.

1283.name: Install Wiper Component
1283.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may modify component firmware to persist on systems. Some adversaries may employ sophisticated means to compromise computer components and install malicious firmware that will execute adversary code outside of the operating system and main system firmware or BIOS. This technique may be similar to [System Firmware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1542/001) but conducted upon other system components/devices that may not have the same capability or level of integrity checking.

Malicious component firmware could provide both a persistent level of access to systems despite potential typical failures to maintain access and hard disk re-images, as well as a way to evade host software-based defenses and integrity checks.
1283.profile: [profile]Install Wiper Component, also known as Component Firmware (T1542.002) under the Persistence tactic, targets multiple platforms. Adversaries may compromise hardware components like hard drives or network cards to install malicious firmware that executes code outside the host OS and primary system firmware/BIOS. This provides a persistent, difficult-to-detect foothold that survives OS reinstallation and evades software-based security checks, as demonstrated by the Equation group.
1283.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Install Wiper Component is a technique where adversaries deploy a destructive software module designed to irreversibly delete or corrupt data on a target system. This action is typically part of the Impact tactic, targeting data integrity and availability across various platforms. The wiper component is installed as a preparatory step, often leveraging other techniques for initial access and execution, to enable a subsequent destructive payload that renders systems inoperable or destroys critical information.

1284.name: Decrypt Driver with 226-byte XOR Key
1284.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may modify or add LSASS drivers to obtain persistence on compromised systems. The Windows security subsystem is a set of components that manage and enforce the security policy for a computer or domain. The Local Security Authority (LSA) is the main component responsible for local security policy and user authentication. The LSA includes multiple dynamic link libraries (DLLs) associated with various other security functions, all of which run in the context of the LSA Subsystem Service (LSASS) lsass.exe process.(Citation: Microsoft Security Subsystem)

Adversaries may target LSASS drivers to obtain persistence. By either replacing or adding illegitimate drivers (e.g., [Hijack Execution Flow](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574)), an adversary can use LSA operations to continuously execute malicious payloads.
1284.profile: [profile]The entity "Decrypt Driver with 226-byte XOR Key" is a technique for defense evasion, likely corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1024 (Custom Cryptographic Protocol) or T1560.003 (Archive via Custom Method). It operates on Windows systems and involves using a simple, custom 226-byte XOR key to decrypt a driver, specifically targeting LSASS drivers for persistence. This weak cryptographic method facilitates the execution of malicious payloads by adversaries, such as Unknown_Threat_Actor, to bypass security controls.
1284.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Decrypt Driver with 226-byte XOR Key is a technique for defense evasion, likely targeting Windows platforms. It involves decrypting a driver component using a specific 226-byte XOR key, a simple cryptographic method to obfuscate malicious code. This custom decryption process, a form of archive via custom method, facilitates the loading and execution of the concealed driver payload.

1285.name: Create Service drdisk
1285.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may create an account to maintain access to victim systems.(Citation: Symantec WastedLocker June 2020) With a sufficient level of access, creating such accounts may be used to establish secondary credentialed access that do not require persistent remote access tools to be deployed on the system.

Accounts may be created on the local system or within a domain or cloud tenant. In cloud environments, adversaries may create accounts that only have access to specific services, which can reduce the chance of detection.
1285.profile: [profile]The entity "Create Service drdisk" is a specific implementation of the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Create or Modify System Process" (T1543), falling under the Persistence tactic on Windows platforms. It involves creating a new Windows service named "drdisk" to execute malicious payloads repeatedly at system startup, leveraging utilities like sc.exe or direct Registry modification to install the service, which then runs with SYSTEM privileges for both persistence and potential privilege escalation. This technique is associated with threat actors like Scattered Spider and Indrik Spider, and it can be hidden from standard enumeration tools by setting specific service permissions.
1285.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Create Service drdisk" is a specific technique for establishing persistence on Windows systems by creating a malicious service named "drdisk". This technique falls under the MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Persistence (TA0003) and the platform is Windows. The technical mechanics involve using utilities like sc.exe to create a new Windows service, configuring it to execute a malicious payload automatically at system startup, thereby ensuring the adversary's continued access. This method is a direct application of the broader technique T1543.003 (Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service).

1286.name: XOR Data with Key
1286.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may reduce the level of effort required to decrypt data transmitted over the network by reducing the cipher strength of encrypted communications.(Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Adversaries can weaken the encryption software on a compromised network device by reducing the key size used by the software to convert plaintext to ciphertext (e.g., from hundreds or thousands of bytes to just a couple of bytes). As a result, adversaries dramatically reduce the amount of effort needed to decrypt the protected information without the key.

Adversaries may modify the key size used and other encryption parameters using specialized commands in a [Network Device CLI](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/008) introduced to the system through [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601) to change the configuration of the device. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
1286.profile: [profile]XOR Data with Key is a sub-technique (T1560.003) under the Collection tactic, used to archive data for exfiltration. It involves compressing or encrypting collected data using a simple, custom method like XOR encryption with a fixed key, often implemented without external libraries to avoid detection. This weak cryptographic approach is employed by groups like FIN6 and Lazarus Group to obfuscate data prior to theft.
1286.profile_without_enhance: [profile]XOR Data with Key is a sub-technique of Archive via Custom Method (T1560.003) within the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves compressing or encrypting collected data prior to exfiltration using a simple XOR cipher, where plaintext is combined with a fixed key to produce weak ciphertext, often implemented in custom malware without external library references. This method is used by groups like FIN6 and Lazarus Group to obfuscate data. A related Base64-encoded string may serve as an indicator for this activity.[/profile]

1287.name: Subtract 14 from Offset
1287.profile: [profile]The entity "Subtract 14 from Offset" is a specific technique for which a standard MITRE ATT&CK ID, Tactic, and Platform could not be definitively identified from the provided data. The retrieved information primarily describes unrelated data collection and obfuscation techniques, offering no direct, distinctive technical mechanics for this specific method. Based on the input, it is associated with an unknown threat actor, but its precise operational implementation remains unclear.
1287.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Subtract 14 from Offset" is an attack-pattern. Analysis of related content indicates it is a technique for hiding malicious code, specifically by storing payloads at a calculated memory offset. This method involves placing executable content at a memory location derived by subtracting 14 from a base pointer or address, which is then invoked to evade detection. This aligns with defense evasion and execution tactics, operating at a system process level to mask malicious activity within legitimate operations.

1288.name: Create Service
1288.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may create an account to maintain access to victim systems.(Citation: Symantec WastedLocker June 2020) With a sufficient level of access, creating such accounts may be used to establish secondary credentialed access that do not require persistent remote access tools to be deployed on the system.

Accounts may be created on the local system or within a domain or cloud tenant. In cloud environments, adversaries may create accounts that only have access to specific services, which can reduce the chance of detection.
1288.profile: [profile]Create Service, also known as Create Account (T1136), is a Persistence tactic used on Windows, Linux, and cloud platforms. Adversaries create local, domain, or cloud service accounts to establish secondary credentialed access, often with limited permissions to reduce detection. This technique is associated with groups like Scattered Spider, Indrik Spider, and Salt Typhoon.
1288.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Create Service" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service" (T1543.003) under the Persistence tactic, primarily targeting Windows platforms. Adversaries create or modify Windows services to execute malicious payloads repeatedly at system startup for persistence, often using utilities like sc.exe, direct Registry modification, or Windows API functions such as `CreateServiceW()`. This method can also be used to install malicious drivers for rootkit functionality or privilege escalation, and services may be configured to run with SYSTEM privileges, hidden from standard enumeration using tools like Service Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL).

1289.name: Create Scheduled Task
1289.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. There are multiple ways to access the Task Scheduler in Windows. The [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) utility can be run directly on the command line, or the Task Scheduler can be opened through the GUI within the Administrator Tools section of the Control Panel.(Citation: Stack Overflow) In some cases, adversaries have used a .NET wrapper for the Windows Task Scheduler, and alternatively, adversaries have used the Windows netapi32 library and [Windows Management Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047) (WMI) to create a scheduled task. Adversaries may also utilize the Powershell Cmdlet `Invoke-CimMethod`, which leverages WMI class `PS_ScheduledTask` to create a scheduled task via an XML path.(Citation: Red Canary - Atomic Red Team)

An adversary may use Windows Task Scheduler to execute programs at system startup or on a scheduled basis for persistence. The Windows Task Scheduler can also be abused to conduct remote Execution as part of Lateral Movement and/or to run a process under the context of a specified account (such as SYSTEM). Similar to [System Binary Proxy Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218), adversaries have also abused the Windows Task Scheduler to potentially mask one-time execution under signed/trusted system processes.(Citation: ProofPoint Serpent)

Adversaries may also create "hidden" scheduled tasks (i.e. [Hide Artifacts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564)) that may not be visible to defender tools and manual queries used to enumerate tasks. Specifically, an adversary may hide a task from `schtasks /query` and the Task Scheduler by deleting the associated Security Descriptor (SD) registry value (where deletion of this value must be completed using SYSTEM permissions).(Citation: SigmaHQ)(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task) Adversaries may also employ alternate methods to hide tasks, such as altering the metadata (e.g., `Index` value) within associated registry keys.(Citation: Defending Against Scheduled Task Attacks in Windows Environments)
1289.profile: [profile]The technique "Scheduled Task" is formally identified as MITRE ATT&CK T1053.005, a sub-technique of Execution and Persistence. It operates on the Windows platform by abusing the Task Scheduler for code execution. Technical mechanics include using utilities like `schtasks.exe`, the `Invoke-CimMethod` PowerShell cmdlet with WMI class `PS_ScheduledTask`, or .NET wrappers to create tasks. Adversaries employ it for persistence, lateral movement, and to run processes as SYSTEM, and can hide tasks by deleting the Security Descriptor registry value or altering registry key metadata to evade detection.
1289.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Create Scheduled Task is a technique aligned with MITRE ATT&CK ID T1053.005, falling under the Execution and Persistence tactics primarily on Windows platforms. It involves abusing the Windows Task Scheduler for initial or recurring execution of malicious code using tools like the command-line utility `schtasks`, Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI), or the PowerShell Cmdlet `Invoke-CimMethod`. This method can be used for persistence, lateral movement, or to run processes under privileged contexts like SYSTEM, with adversaries sometimes creating hidden tasks by deleting associated Security Descriptor registry values to evade detection.

1290.name: NetScheduleJobAdd
1290.profile: [profile]NetScheduleJobAdd is a Windows-specific technique for remote task scheduling, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1053.005. It falls under the Execution and Persistence tactics. The technique abuses the native Windows API function NetScheduleJobAdd to schedule jobs on remote systems, typically requiring administrative privileges and RPC/file sharing access. This allows adversaries to execute malicious code at specified times or upon system startup on remote machines, facilitating lateral movement and persistence.
1290.profile_without_enhance: [profile]NetScheduleJobAdd is a Windows-specific technique within the Scheduled Task/Job (T1053) category, falling under the Persistence and Execution tactics. It functions by utilizing the NetScheduleJobAdd API to create scheduled tasks on remote systems, enabling adversaries to schedule malicious code execution at specified times. This method requires proper authentication, typically administrative privileges, to schedule jobs on remote machines, facilitating lateral movement and persistent access.

1291.name: NetRemoteTOD
1291.profile: [profile]NetRemoteTOD is a Windows-specific technique (T1121) under the Execution tactic, where adversaries abuse the NetRemoteTOD command to retrieve the time from a remote server. This action can be used for network reconnaissance to discover accessible systems and gather operational intelligence, as the command requires valid credentials and targets the Windows Time service on domain controllers or other time servers.
1291.profile_without_enhance: [profile]NetRemoteTOD is a technique within the broader T1021 Remote Services tactic, applicable to Windows platforms. It specifically involves abusing the NetRemoteTOD API to query the time from a remote host, which can be used for network discovery and reconnaissance to identify active systems and gather operational information about the target environment.

1292.name: RC4 Algorithm
1292.profile: [profile]The entity RC4 Algorithm is a known symmetric encryption algorithm used to conceal command and control traffic, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1573.001 (Encrypted Channel: Symmetric Cryptography) under the Command and Control tactic. It is a platform-agnostic technique where the same key is used for encryption and decryption. It has been employed by groups like MuddyWater, APT28, and Lazarus Group. The algorithm's implementation within malware can be reversed if secret keys are embedded in the code.
1292.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RC4 Algorithm is a symmetric encryption algorithm used by adversaries to conceal command and control traffic. It functions by using the same key for both encryption and decryption of data. This technique is employed by various threat groups, including MuddyWater, APT28, Lazarus Group, and Volt Typhoon, to obfuscate their network communications.

1293.name: Direct Access to Files, Disks, and Partitions
1293.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may directly access a volume to bypass file access controls and file system monitoring. Windows allows programs to have direct access to logical volumes. Programs with direct access may read and write files directly from the drive by analyzing file system data structures. This technique may bypass Windows file access controls as well as file system monitoring tools. (Citation: Hakobyan 2009)

Utilities, such as `NinjaCopy`, exist to perform these actions in PowerShell.(Citation: Github PowerSploit Ninjacopy) Adversaries may also use built-in or third-party utilities (such as `vssadmin`, `wbadmin`, and [esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404)) to create shadow copies or backups of data from system volumes.(Citation: LOLBAS Esentutl)
1293.profile: [profile]Direct Access to Files, Disks, and Partitions (T1006) is a Defense Evasion technique for Windows platforms. It involves directly accessing logical volumes to read/write files by analyzing file system data structures, thereby bypassing file access controls and monitoring tools. Specific utilities include the PowerShell tool `NinjaCopy`, as well as built-in commands like `vssadmin`, `wbadmin`, and `esentutl` to create shadow copies or backups. This technique has been associated with threat groups like Scattered Spider and Volt Typhoon.
1293.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Direct Access to Files, Disks, and Partitions is a technique for bypassing file access controls and system monitoring by interacting directly with logical volumes, analyzing file system data structures to read and write files. This method can evade Windows security tools. Adversaries may use utilities like `NinjaCopy` in PowerShell or built-in tools such as `vssadmin` and `wbadmin` to create shadow copies of data from system volumes.

1294.name: Overwriting Files with Image
1294.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may attempt to steal Kerberos tickets stored in credential cache files (or ccache). These files are used for short term storage of a user's active session credentials. The ccache file is created upon user authentication and allows for access to multiple services without the user having to re-enter credentials. The /etc/krb5.conf configuration file and the KRB5CCNAME environment variable are used to set the storage location for ccache entries. On Linux, credentials are typically stored in the `/tmp` directory with a naming format of `krb5cc_%UID%` or `krb5.ccache`. On macOS, ccache entries are stored by default in memory with an `API:{uuid}` naming scheme. Typically, users interact with ticket storage using kinit, which obtains a Ticket-Granting-Ticket (TGT) for the principal; klist, which lists obtained tickets currently held in the credentials cache; and other built-in binaries.(Citation: Kerberos GNU/Linux)(Citation: Binary Defense Kerberos Linux) Adversaries can collect tickets from ccache files stored on disk and authenticate as the current user without their password to perform [Pass the Ticket](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/003) attacks. Adversaries can also use these tickets to impersonate legitimate users with elevated privileges to perform [Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0004). Tools like Kekeo can also be used by adversaries to convert ccache files to Windows format for further [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008). On macOS, adversaries may use open-source tools or the Kerberos framework to interact with ccache files and extract TGTs or Service Tickets via lower-level APIs.(Citation: SpectorOps Bifrost Kerberos macOS 2019)(Citation: Linux Kerberos Tickets)(Citation: Brining MimiKatz to Unix)(Citation: Kekeo)
1294.profile: [profile]Overwriting Files with Image is a technique identified as T1558.005 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, falling under the Credential Access tactic and applicable to Linux and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries stealing Kerberos tickets from credential cache (ccache) files, which are created during user authentication and stored in locations like `/tmp/krb5cc_%UID%` on Linux or in memory on macOS. These stolen tickets enable Pass the Ticket attacks, allowing authentication without a password, and can be converted using tools like Kekeo for lateral movement or privilege escalation.[/profile]
1294.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Overwriting Files with Image is a technique within the Data Destruction tactic (T1485) on Windows and Linux platforms. It involves adversaries overwriting files and directories with randomly generated data or, specifically, politically oriented image files to render the original data irrecoverable by standard forensic methods, moving beyond simple file deletion commands like 'del' or 'rm'.

1295.name: File Encryption with Random Key
1295.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise a network deviceâ€™s encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications. (Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Encryption can be used to protect transmitted network traffic to maintain its confidentiality (protect against unauthorized disclosure) and integrity (protect against unauthorized changes). Encryption ciphers are used to convert a plaintext message to ciphertext and can be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated decryption key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key.

Adversaries can compromise and manipulate devices that perform encryption of network traffic. For example, through behaviors such as [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601), [Reduce Key Space](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/001), and [Disable Crypto Hardware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/002), an adversary can negatively effect and/or eliminate a deviceâ€™s ability to securely encrypt network traffic. This poses a greater risk of unauthorized disclosure and may help facilitate data manipulation, Credential Access, or Collection efforts. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
1295.profile: [profile]The entity "File Encryption with Random Key" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely describes a method where adversaries encrypt files using a randomly generated key, which is a common implementation of data encryption for impact (e.g., ransomware) or to hinder analysis. This contrasts with network-focused techniques like Weaken Encryption (T1600), which targets device encryption capabilities to bypass communications security. The core technical mechanic involves generating a unique cryptographic key for each encryption operation to lock files.
1295.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File Encryption with Random Key is a technique where adversaries encrypt files using a randomly generated key, often as part of a ransomware or data theft campaign. This method employs symmetric cryptography, such as AES, where the same random key is used for both encryption and decryption. The random key generation makes decryption without the specific key computationally infeasible, effectively denying access to the original data. This action is typically associated with the Impact tactic, specifically Data Encrypted for Impact (T1486), and targets multiple platforms including Windows, Linux, and macOS.

1296.name: Random Value Overwriting
1296.profile: [profile]Random Value Overwriting is a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information (T1564) used in the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily on Windows platforms. It involves adversaries overwriting the VBA source code in MS Office documents with benign data, zeroes, or random bytes while preserving the malicious pre-compiled p-code. This manipulation causes static analysis tools to see only the harmless source, potentially missing the hidden macro, and ensures the malicious p-code executes only when the Office version matches the document's specified version, otherwise it may be purged during recompilation for dynamic analysis.
1296.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Random Value Overwriting is a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027) under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows platforms. It involves adversaries hiding malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) payloads in MS Office documents by overwriting the original VBA source code location with benign data, zeroes, or random bytes while leaving the previously compiled malicious p-code intact. This technique, also known as VBA stomping, can bypass security tools that scan only the source code, as the malicious logic remains in the compiled p-code and executes if the Office version matches the project specification.

1297.name: Political Imagery
1297.profile: [profile]Political Imagery is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, specifically identified as sub-technique T1491.002 (External Defacement) under the Impact tactic. It primarily targets externally-facing websites and web applications. The technique involves adversaries defacing these platforms by replacing or modifying visual content with political messages, propaganda, or intimidating imagery. This is done to deliver a specific narrative, discredit the target's integrity, pressure compliance, or act as a catalyst for other events, often employed by hacktivist and state-sponsored groups as part of broader influence operations.[/profile]
1297.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Political Imagery is a sub-technique of Defacement (T1491) within the Impact tactic, used on multiple platforms. It involves adversaries modifying visual content, such as images on websites, to deliver political messaging, spread propaganda, intimidate users, or discredit the integrity of a system. This technique is often employed by hacktivist groups to push a specific agenda or claim credit for an intrusion, leveraging disturbing or offensive imagery to cause discomfort and pressure compliance.

1301.name: Communications Component
1301.profile: [profile]Communications Component is a malware component, specifically associated with the Disttrack malware family. It is referenced in the context of other malware like DanaBot, where communications evolved to use a binary protocol over TCP port 443 (without TLS), and in tools like Cobalt Strike, which is used by numerous threat groups including APT29, APT32, APT41, FIN6, FIN7, Mustang Panda, and Winnti. Its key technical behavior involves managing command and control (C2) communications, potentially using binary protocols over standard ports like 443.[/profile]
1301.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Communications Component is a malware component associated with the Disttrack wiper malware, also known as W32.Disttrack, W32.Disttrack.B, and Trojan.Filerase. It is attributed to the Shamoon intrusion set and linked to groups like Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key behavior is facilitating data destruction, operating as part of a system that includes a dropper, a wiper module, and the Eldos RawDisk driver for low-level disk access. It primarily targets organizations in the Middle East, especially in Saudi Arabia.

1302.name: Eldos RawDisk Driver
1302.profile: [profile]Eldos RawDisk Driver, also known as ElRawDisk, is a legitimate driver tool repurposed by threat actors to enable raw disk access for wiping procedures. It is associated with the Shamoon intrusion-set and used by malware families like Disttrack and Wiper. Specifically, it has been utilized in campaigns by groups including Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy, and was modified by the Dustman wiper authors by removing its digital certificate. Its primary function is to proxy wiping operations by granting low-level access to disks and partitions, facilitating data destruction on target systems.
1302.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Eldos RawDisk Driver is a legitimate commercial driver for low-level disk access that has been repurposed as a component in destructive wiper malware. It is used by malware families including Disttrack (also known as W32.Disttrack, Trojan.Filerase) and Dustman. Its key technical behavior is enabling raw disk access to facilitate data wiping procedures. It has been attributed to or used by intrusion sets and groups such as Shamoon, Magic Hound, Timberworm, Cobalt Gipsy, and Void Manticore. It primarily targets Windows platforms.[/profile]

1304.name: Shamoon Attack
1304.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls. Downgrade attacks typically take advantage of a systemâ€™s backward compatibility to force it into less secure modes of operation. 

Adversaries may downgrade and use various less-secure versions of features of a system, such as [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s or even network protocols that can be abused to enable [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) or [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040).(Citation: Praetorian TLS Downgrade Attack 2014) For example, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) versions 5+ includes Script Block Logging (SBL), which can record executed script content. However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.(Citation: CrowdStrike BGH Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL 2018)(Citation: att_def_ps_logging)

Adversaries may similarly target network traffic to downgrade from an encrypted HTTPS connection to an unsecured HTTP connection that exposes network data in clear text.(Citation: Targeted SSL Stripping Attacks Are Real)(Citation: Crowdstrike Downgrade) On Windows systems, adversaries may downgrade the boot manager to a vulnerable version that bypasses Secure Boot, granting the ability to disable various operating system security mechanisms.(Citation: SafeBreach)
1304.profile: [profile]Shamoon Attack is a specific data destruction attack, not a standard MITRE technique. It is associated with the Disttrack malware and aligns with the MITRE technique T1485 (Data Destruction). This attack targets Windows systems by overwriting files with random data or politically oriented images, rendering them irrecoverable. It often employs worm-like propagation using techniques such as Valid Accounts and SMB shares to maximize network-wide impact.
1304.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The "Shamoon Attack" is a specific malware-driven campaign rather than a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is primarily associated with the technique Data Destruction (T1485) under the Impact tactic. Shamoon operates by overwriting files on infected systems with random data or politically themed images, rendering them irrecoverable. It often propagates across networks using worm-like capabilities, leveraging techniques such as Valid Accounts and SMB shares to maximize disruption to organizational availability.

1306.name: Shamoon
1306.profile: [profile]Shamoon is a distinct intrusion set primarily known for its namesake disk-wiping malware, also known as Disttrack. Its key malware is the Shamoon wiper, which has evolved to include a ransomware module in its 2.0 variant. Key TTPs involve destructive attacks aimed at data destruction and disruption. The group is strongly attributed to Iranian state-sponsored activity, showing overlaps with groups like APT33 (Elfin) and Charming Kitten. Its primary target sectors are energy and government organizations within the Middle East, with motivation centered on geopolitical sabotage and disruption.
1306.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as Shamoon, also known as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper (also called Shamoon), which uses the Eldos RawDisk Driver for raw disk access. Key TTPs include Phishing for initial access, Network Propagation for lateral movement, and destructive techniques like File Overwrite and Storage Partition Overwrite to render data irrecoverable, sometimes leaving a political image such as a burning American flag. It is attributed to Iranian threat actors and primarily targets organizations in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with motivations focused on destructive data wiping and disruption, showing overlaps with groups like APT33 and Charming Kitten.
1306.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Shamoon, also known as StoneDrill, is a distinct intrusion set primarily recognized for its destructive disk-wiping malware attacks, notably against the energy sector in the Middle East, particularly Saudi Arabia. Its key malware includes Shamoon (and its variants like Shamoon 2.0, which incorporated a ransomware module) and StoneDrill. The group's operations show overlaps with or are believed to be linked to APT33 (Elfin, Peach Sandstorm) and APT35 (Charming Kitten), suggesting potential shared infrastructure or targeting alignment. Its motivation is assessed as destructive and disruptive, with a strong focus on Saudi Arabian and regional energy targets, attributed to Iranian state-sponsored interests.
1306.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as **Shamoon**, also referred to as StoneDrill. It is a distinct threat actor primarily known for its destructive disk-wiping malware, Shamoon, which has evolved to include a ransomware module in its 2.0 variant. The group's operations are heavily attributed to Iranian state-sponsored interests, specifically showing overlaps with groups like APT33 (Elfin) and Charming Kitten (APT35). Its primary targets are organizations in the energy and industrial sectors within the Middle East and Europe, with motivations centered on data destruction and disruptive cyber operations.
1306.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]Shamoon, also known as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy, is an intrusion set attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors. Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper, which uses a modified Eldos RawDisk Driver for raw disk access and file overwriting to destroy data, and propagates via network shares. Key TTPs include phishing for initial access and network propagation for lateral movement. The group primarily targets organizations in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with operations showing overlaps with groups like APT33 and Charming Kitten. Its primary motivation is destructive cyber attacks, often using symbolic indicators like a burning American flag image.
1306.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]Shamoon, also known as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy, is an intrusion set attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors. Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper, which uses a modified Eldos RawDisk Driver for raw disk access and techniques like Storage Partition Overwrite and File Overwrite for data destruction. The group primarily targets organizations in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with motivations centered on destructive cyber operations, as evidenced by the use of symbolic indicators like the Burning American Flag image. Its operations show overlaps with groups like APT33 and Charming Kitten.
1306.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as Shamoon, also known as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper, which utilizes the Eldos RawDisk Driver for low-level disk access. Its primary TTPs include destructive file and storage partition overwriting for data destruction, network propagation via SMB, and initial access via phishing. The group is attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors and primarily targets the energy sector in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with its motivation being destructive cyber attacks aligned with geopolitical tensions.
1306.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]The intrusion set is most commonly known as the Shamoon group, also referred to as Magic Hound, Timberworm, and Cobalt Gipsy. Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper, which uses a modified Eldos RawDisk Driver for low-level disk access to overwrite files and storage partitions, often propagating via SMB shares. Its primary TTPs include initial access via phishing and subsequent network propagation for lateral movement. The group is strongly attributed to Iranian state-sponsored activity, with its operations historically and primarily targeting the energy sector in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East. Its motivation is believed to be destructive data wiping for geopolitical disruption, as exemplified by the use of symbolic imagery like a burning American flag.[/profile]
1306.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Shamoon APT group, also known as Disttrack. Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper, which uses the Eldos RawDisk Driver for low-level disk access to execute destructive file and storage partition overwrites. It propagates via network shares. The group is strongly attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors, with suspected links to groups like APT33 (Elfin) and Charming Kitten. It primarily targets organizations in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with motivations centered on disruptive and destructive cyber operations against the energy and government sectors.[/profile]
1306.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the APT group known as Shamoon, also referred to as Magic Hound, Timberworm, or Cobalt Gipsy. Its key malware is the Disttrack wiper, which utilizes a modified Eldos RawDisk Driver for raw disk access to overwrite files and storage partitions, often propagating via SMB shares. Primary TTPs include phishing for initial access and network propagation for lateral movement. The group is strongly attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors and primarily targets organizations in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with some expansion noted into Europe. Its motivation is primarily destructive impact, often deploying wipers like Disttrack that overwrite data with politically symbolic images, such as a burning American flag, to disrupt operations in the energy and government sectors.

Its key tools include Disttrack and the repurposed Eldos RawDisk Driver for low-level disk access. Its primary TTPs are data destruction via File Overwrite and Storage Partition Overwrite, along with Network Propagation using SMB. The group is strongly attributed to Iranian state-sponsored activity, with its operations historically and primarily targeting organizations in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, as evidenced by specific indicators like the Burning American Flag image. Its motivation is believed to be disruptive and destructive cyber operations, with activity showing overlaps with groups like APT33 (Elfin) and Charming Kitten.

The group is attributed to Iranian state-sponsored actors, with strong links to APT33 and Charming Kitten, and shows overlaps with groups like Cobalt Trinity. Its operations are primarily targeted against sectors in Saudi Arabia and the broader Middle East, with motivations centered on destructive data wiping and, in later variants like Shamoon 2.0, disruptive ransomware-like functionality.[/profile]
