It supports commands for file transfer, execution, remote desktop, screenshot capture, reverse shell, and keylogging. It maintains persistence via specific file paths like C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Roaming\Intel\<SOGU CLSID>\ and <drive>:\RECYCLER.BIN\<SOGU CLSID>\ with Base64-encoded filenames. Associated infrastructure includes domains like gougounu[.site.

1376.name: Snugride
1376.uncertain_mes: [SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) is a backdoor that has been used by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) as first stage malware. (Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)
1376.profile: [profile]Snugride, also known as SNUGRIDE (MITRE ATT&CK ID S0159), is a backdoor attributed to the APT group menuPass (also known as APT10). It functions as first-stage malware, establishing initial access for subsequent operations. Its key technical behavior is acting as a backdoor to enable remote control and further payload deployment. Target platforms are not explicitly detailed but are consistent with Windows-based enterprise environments commonly targeted by APT10. Infrastructure and supplementary information reference its use in campaigns documented by FireEye in April 2017.
1376.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Snugride, also known as SNUGRIDE, is a backdoor used as first-stage malware by the APT group menuPass (also known as APT10). Its key behavior is functioning as an initial access and persistence tool for the group's operations. Target platforms are typically Windows systems, as it is deployed in campaigns attributed to this advanced persistent threat actor.

1377.name: Quasarrat
1377.profile: [profile]Quasarrat, also known as QuasarRAT, is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) attributed to the APT10 intrusion set. It is a customized version of the open-source Quasar RAT, with technical behaviors including encrypted C2 communication using a specific key and password, and a configurable reconnect delay. The malware primarily targets Windows platforms and has been associated with other RAT families like AsyncRAT and Venom RAT through shared configuration elements, and has been used in campaigns by groups including APT33, Dropping Elephant, Stone Panda, and the Gorgon Group.
1377.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Quasarrat, also known as AsyncRAT and Venom RAT, is a remote access trojan. It is attributed to the APT10 intrusion set. Key technical behaviors include using a specific configuration with version "1.0.00.r6", a 5000ms reconnect delay, and a hardcoded C2 password "5EPmsqV4iTCGjx9aY3yYpBWD0IgEJpHNEP75pks" for encrypted communication. The malware targets Windows platforms for remote access and data exfiltration.[/profile]

1378.name: Bugjuice
1378.profile: [profile]Bugjuice is a malware attributed to the APT10 intrusion set. Its specific technical behaviors include creating a registry key for persistence to automatically launch a copy on each system startup, monitoring specific applications, and engaging in distinct network interactions for command and control or data exfiltration. The target platform is Windows, as indicated by its use of the Windows registry for persistence mechanisms.[/profile]
1378.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bugjuice is a malware entity with no specific aliases, attributed groups, key TTPs, target platforms, or infrastructure details provided in the available data.

1379.name: Quasarrat (Customized Version)
1379.profile: [profile]Quasarrat (Customized Version) is a variant of the Quasarrat malware, also known as AsyncRAT, Venom RAT, and Quasar RAT. It is attributed to the APT10 intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include using a specific configuration with version "1.0.00.r6", a 5000 millisecond RECONNECTDELAY, and a hardcoded C2 password "5EPmsqV4iTCGjx9aY3yYpBWD0IgEJpHNEP75pks" for encrypted communication. The malware's target platform is Windows. It is also associated with groups like APT33, Dropping Elephant, Stone Panda, and The Gorgon Group through related variants.[/profile]
1379.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Quasarrat (Customized Version), also known as QuasarRAT and venom rat, is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed to APT10. Key technical behaviors include using a specific configuration with a version string "1.0.00.r6", a hardcoded C2 password "5EPmsqV4iTCGjx9aY3yYpBWD0IgEJpHNEP75pks", and a reconnect delay of 5000 milliseconds. It targets Windows platforms and is associated with related intrusion sets APT33, Dropping Elephant, Stone Panda, and The Gorgon Group.[/profile]

1381.name: Stealing Confidential Commercial Data
1381.profile: [profile]Stealing Confidential Commercial Data is a technique where adversaries exfiltrate proprietary business information. This action is part of the Exfiltration tactic. The technical mechanics involve adversaries using existing command and control channels (T1041) or webhook endpoints (T1567.004) to transmit the stolen data, often after staging (T1074) or compressing (T1002) it to evade detection. Groups like APT10 are associated with this activity, which targets data critical to a victim's commercial operations.
1381.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Stealing Confidential Commercial Data is an attack pattern where adversaries illicitly acquire proprietary business information for financial or competitive advantage. This technique is part of the Collection tactic and typically occurs after initial access and discovery. The technical mechanics involve locating and accessing sensitive data stores, such as databases, file shares, or cloud storage, often using legitimate system tools or custom malware. The data is then aggregated and prepared for exfiltration through various channels, including command and control networks or web services.

1382.name: Supply Chain Compromise
1382.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate products or product delivery mechanisms prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise.

Supply chain compromise can take place at any stage of the supply chain including:

* Manipulation of development tools
* Manipulation of a development environment
* Manipulation of source code repositories (public or private)
* Manipulation of source code in open-source dependencies
* Manipulation of software update/distribution mechanisms
* Compromised/infected system images (removable media infected at the factory)(Citation: IBM Storwize)(Citation: Schneider Electric USB Malware) 
* Replacement of legitimate software with modified versions
* Sales of modified/counterfeit products to legitimate distributors
* Shipment interdiction

While supply chain compromise can impact any component of hardware or software, adversaries looking to gain execution have often focused on malicious additions to legitimate software in software distribution or update channels.(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Adversaries may limit targeting to a desired victim set or distribute malicious software to a broad set of consumers but only follow up with specific victims.(Citation: Symantec Elderwood Sept 2012)(Citation: Avast CCleaner3 2018)(Citation: Command Five SK 2011) Popular open-source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications may also be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency.(Citation: Trendmicro NPM Compromise)

In some cases, adversaries may conduct â€œsecond-orderâ€ supply chain compromises by leveraging the access gained from an initial supply chain compromise to further compromise a software component.(Citation: Krebs 3cx overview 2023) This may allow the threat actor to spread to even more victims.
1382.profile: [profile]Supply Chain Compromise is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1195 under the Initial Access tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves manipulating products or delivery mechanisms before they reach the consumer, with specific methods including the malicious modification of development tools, source code repositories, open-source dependencies, and software update channels to insert backdoors. Adversaries may conduct broad distribution followed by selective victim targeting or execute "second-order" compromises to spread further, with groups like Sandworm Team and APT10 linked to this activity.[/profile]
1382.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Supply Chain Compromise is a MITRE ATT&CK technique with ID T1195, categorized under the Initial Access tactic and applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries manipulating products or their delivery mechanisms before they reach the end consumer to compromise data or systems. This can occur at various stages, including tampering with development tools, source code repositories, software update channels, or hardware components to insert backdoors. Attackers may broadly distribute tainted software but only activate payloads for specific targets, and they often leverage access from an initial compromise to conduct "second-order" attacks on further software components.

1383.name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
1383.uncertain_mes:
Windows systems use a common method to look for required DLLs to load into a program. (Citation: Microsoft DLL Search) Adversaries may take advantage of the Windows DLL search order and programs that ambiguously specify DLLs to gain privilege escalation and persistence. 

Adversaries may perform DLL preloading, also called binary planting attacks, (Citation: OWASP Binary Planting) by placing a malicious DLL with the same name as an ambiguously specified DLL in a location that Windows searches before the legitimate DLL. Often this location is the current working directory of the program. Remote DLL preloading attacks occur when a program sets its current directory to a remote location such as a Web share before loading a DLL. (Citation: Microsoft 2269637) Adversaries may use this behavior to cause the program to load a malicious DLL. 

Adversaries may also directly modify the way a program loads DLLs by replacing an existing DLL or modifying a .manifest or .local redirection file, directory, or junction to cause the program to load a different DLL to maintain persistence or privilege escalation. (Citation: Microsoft DLL Redirection) (Citation: Microsoft Manifests) (Citation: Mandiant Search Order)

If a search order-vulnerable program is configured to run at a higher privilege level, then the adversary-controlled DLL that is loaded will also be executed at the higher level. In this case, the technique could be used for privilege escalation from user to administrator or SYSTEM or from administrator to SYSTEM, depending on the program.

Programs that fall victim to path hijacking may appear to behave normally because malicious DLLs may be configured to also load the legitimate DLLs they were meant to replace.
1383.profile: [profile]DLL Search Order Hijacking, known as T1574.001 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a Defense Evasion and Persistence technique targeting Windows. It exploits the Windows DLL search order by placing a malicious DLL with the same name as a legitimate, ambiguously specified library in a directory searched earlier, such as the program's current working directory or a remote Web share. Adversaries may also modify .manifest or .local redirection files to load a different DLL. If the vulnerable program runs with elevated privileges, this technique enables privilege escalation to administrator or SYSTEM levels while the program may appear to behave normally.
1383.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DLL Search Order Hijacking is a technique identified as T1574.001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, falling under the Persistence and Privilege Escalation tactics for Windows platforms. It exploits the standard Windows DLL search order by placing a malicious DLL with the same name as a required library in a directory that is searched before the legitimate one, such as the program's current working directory. This allows the adversary to execute their code when the vulnerable program loads, potentially at a higher privilege level if the host program runs elevated. The malicious DLL can be configured to also load the legitimate library to maintain normal program behavior and evade detection.

1384.name: LNK Files
1384.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may smuggle commands to download malicious payloads past content filters by hiding them within otherwise seemingly benign windows shortcut files. Windows shortcut files (.LNK) include many metadata fields, including an icon location field (also known as the `IconEnvironmentDataBlock`) designed to specify the path to an icon file that is to be displayed for the LNK file within a host directory. 

Adversaries may abuse this LNK metadata to download malicious payloads. For example, adversaries have been observed using LNK files as phishing payloads to deliver malware. Once invoked (e.g., [Malicious File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002)), payloads referenced via external URLs within the LNK icon location field may be downloaded. These files may also then be invoked by [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)/[System Binary Proxy Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218) arguments within the target path field of the LNK.(Citation: Unprotect Shortcut)(Citation: Booby Trap Shortcut 2017)

LNK Icon Smuggling may also be utilized post compromise, such as malicious scripts executing an LNK on an infected host to download additional malicious payloads.
1384.profile: [profile]LNK Icon Smuggling, also known as T1027.012, is a Defense Evasion technique primarily used on the Windows platform. It involves abusing the IconEnvironmentDataBlock metadata field within Windows shortcut (.LNK) files to hide commands, often URLs, that download malicious payloads when the file is executed, bypassing content filters. This method is frequently employed in phishing campaigns and for post-compromise payload retrieval, with associated groups including Mustang Panda, Gamaredon Group, and Kimsuky.[/profile]
1384.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "LNK Files" is a technique for initial access and execution, often mapped to MITRE ATT&CK T1204.002 (Malicious File) under the Execution tactic on Windows platforms. Adversaries use Windows shortcut (.LNK) files as phishing attachments, which when opened by a user execute a malicious payload. The LNK file's target path field can contain commands or references to scripts that download and run malware from remote servers, leveraging the system's default handler for shortcuts to achieve code execution. Groups like Mustang Panda, Gamaredon Group, and Kimsuky have employed this method.

1385.name: Custom Binary Protocol
1385.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use a custom cryptographic protocol or algorithm to hide command and control traffic. A simple scheme, such as XOR-ing the plaintext with a fixed key, will produce a very weak ciphertext.

Custom encryption schemes may vary in sophistication. Analysis and reverse engineering of malware samples may be enough to discover the algorithm and encryption key used.

Some adversaries may also attempt to implement their own version of a well-known cryptographic algorithm instead of using a known implementation library, which may lead to unintentional errors. (Citation: F-Secure Cosmicduke)
1385.profile: [profile]Custom Binary Protocol is a Command and Control technique (T1024) under the Command and Control tactic. It involves adversaries using a custom cryptographic protocol or algorithm to obfuscate C2 traffic, which can range from simple XOR operations with a fixed key to more sophisticated, self-implemented encryption schemes. This method is distinct from using standard application layer protocols and may be employed by groups like APT10. The custom implementation can sometimes contain errors, and the algorithm and key can often be discovered through malware analysis and reverse engineering.[/profile]
1385.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Custom Binary Protocol is a Command and Control technique where adversaries design a non-standard communication protocol, often using raw sockets or mimicking legitimate protocols, to encapsulate and obscure C2 traffic. This method avoids detection by network security tools that rely on known protocol signatures and can be implemented on top of standard TCP/IP stacks. It is distinct from, but can be combined with, custom encryption for additional obfuscation.

1386.name: Reverse Shell
1386.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may backdoor web servers with web shells to establish persistent access to systems. A Web shell is a Web script that is placed on an openly accessible Web server to allow an adversary to access the Web server as a gateway into a network. A Web shell may provide a set of functions to execute or a command-line interface on the system that hosts the Web server.(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)

In addition to a server-side script, a Web shell may have a client interface program that is used to talk to the Web server (e.g. [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020) Web shell client).(Citation: Lee 2013)
1386.profile: [profile]Reverse Shell is a technique for establishing remote command execution. It operates by having a compromised host initiate an outbound connection to an adversary-controlled server, which then provides an interactive command-line interface back to the adversary. This method is commonly used for persistence and remote control, often deployed via web shells on compromised servers to bypass network defenses. It is associated with groups like APT10 and is a core component of command and control operations.
1386.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Reverse Shell is a command and control technique where a compromised host initiates an outbound connection to an adversary-controlled server, providing the adversary with interactive command execution. It is commonly used as a second-stage payload for remote access tools to establish a persistent, interactive channel. This technique is platform-agnostic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS systems, and is often deployed via initial access vectors like web shells or malicious scripts to bypass inbound firewall restrictions.

1391.name: PlugX
1391.uncertain_mes: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) is a remote access tool (RAT) with modular plugins that has been used by multiple threat groups.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Fox Part 2)(Citation: New DragonOK)(Citation: Dell TG-3390)
1391.profile: [profile]PlugX is a modular remote access trojan (RAT) first identified in 2012 and often attributed to Chinese-speaking threat actors. Its aliases include KORPLUG and SOGU. It has been used by numerous groups including APT41, Mustang Panda, Winnti Group, APT3, Axiom, Higaisa, Velvet Ant, Daggerfly, Cinnamon Tempest, Gallium, MenuPass, LuminousMoth, DragonOK, Threat Group-3390, and TA459. Key technical behaviors involve the use of encrypted payloads, including those with THOR magic bytes and XOR headers, and modular plugins for extended functionality. It primarily targets Windows platforms and employs loaders to deploy its encrypted payloads.
1391.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PlugX, a remote access trojan (RAT) identified in 2012, is often attributed to Chinese-speaking threat actors including APT22, APT26, APT31, APT41, Mustang Panda, and numerous other Panda-associated groups. Key technical behaviors involve the use of encrypted payloads, with variants employing XOR headers, unknown encryption, and specific loaders that utilize THOR magic bytes. It primarily targets Windows systems and its infrastructure is supported by tools like the PlugX Extractor for payload analysis.

1392.name: Poison Ivy (Pivy)
1392.uncertain_mes:

1392.profile: [profile]Poison Ivy (Pivy) is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) historically used by various China-nexus threat actors, including groups referenced as Gallium, Molerats, Mustang Panda, Nightshade Panda, Pirate Panda, Stone Panda, TA428, and Temper Panda. It has been deployed in campaigns like Operation Soft Cell targeting telecommunications providers to steal Caller Detail Records (CDR) and in activity targeting Myanmar and other Asian countries. The malware functions as a backdoor for remote system control and data exfiltration, primarily affecting Windows platforms.
1392.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Poison Ivy (Pivy) is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) used by multiple China-nexus state-sponsored threat actors, including Gallium, TA428, and Mustang Panda. It targets Windows platforms to establish backdoor access, enabling data exfiltration and remote control, and has been deployed in campaigns like Operation Soft Cell against telecommunications providers to steal Call Detail Records (CDRs).[/profile]

1393.name: Chches
1393.uncertain_mes: [ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) is a Trojan that appears to be used exclusively by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045). It was used to target Japanese organizations in 2016. Its lack of persistence methods suggests it may be intended as a first-stage tool. (Citation: Palo Alto menuPass Feb 2017) (Citation: JPCERT ChChes Feb 2017) (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)
1393.profile: [profile]ChChes is a first-stage Trojan used exclusively by the menuPass group (also known as Stone Panda) to target Japanese organizations, primarily via spear-phishing emails with icon-disguised executable files in ZIP attachments. It uniquely communicates with its command-and-control servers using HTTP Cookie headers and lacks persistence mechanisms, indicating its role in initial intrusion. The malware's infrastructure and activities were documented in 2016-2017 campaigns.
1393.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ChChes is a malware family that communicates with its command-and-control (C&C) servers using HTTP Cookie headers. It is delivered via spear-phishing emails containing ZIP attachments with icon-disguised executable files. For execution and persistence, it employs DLL Execution techniques, such as DLL sideloading. Its key behaviors include Shell Command Execution and the use of AES Encryption for data obfuscation. It primarily targets Windows platforms and is attributed to the threat actor Stone Panda.

1395.name: Spoofed Email Addresses
1395.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather email addresses that can be used during targeting. Even if internal instances exist, organizations may have public-facing email infrastructure and addresses for employees.

Adversaries may easily gather email addresses, since they may be readily available and exposed via online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Social Media](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/001) or [Search Victim-Owned Websites](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1594)).(Citation: HackersArise Email)(Citation: CNET Leaks) Email addresses could also be enumerated via more active means (i.e. [Active Scanning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595)), such as probing and analyzing responses from authentication services that may reveal valid usernames in a system.(Citation: GrimBlog UsernameEnum) For example, adversaries may be able to enumerate email addresses in Office 365 environments by querying a variety of publicly available API endpoints, such as autodiscover and GetCredentialType.(Citation: GitHub Office 365 User Enumeration)(Citation: Azure Active Directory Reconnaisance)

Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Email Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586/002)), and/or initial access (ex: [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) or [Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) via [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133)).
1395.profile: [profile]Spoofed Email Addresses, identified as T1672 under the Initial Access tactic, involves adversaries modifying email headers like the FROM field to impersonate a legitimate sender. This technique exploits weak or absent email authentication policies such as SPF, DKIM, and DMARC, where a policy like `p=none` instructs servers to take no action on failed checks. Adversaries may also abuse Microsoft 365's Direct Send functionality using internal devices to send unauthenticated spoofed emails, facilitating phishing and impersonation campaigns by making malicious emails appear trustworthy.[/profile]
1395.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spoofed Email Addresses is a technique where adversaries forge a sender's identity by modifying email headers like the FROM field to appear as a trusted source. This technique, often part of Initial Access, exploits weak or absent email authentication protocols such as SPF, DKIM, and DMARC. It is commonly used to enable phishing attacks by concealing social engineering attempts, and can succeed even with configured protocols if DMARC policies are set to take no action, such as `p=none`.

1396.name: Social Engineering
1396.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may search social media for information about victims that can be used during targeting. Social media sites may contain various information about a victim organization, such as business announcements as well as information about the roles, locations, and interests of staff.

Adversaries may search in different social media sites depending on what information they seek to gather. Threat actors may passively harvest data from these sites, as well as use information gathered to create fake profiles/groups to elicit victimâ€™s into revealing specific information (i.e. [Spearphishing Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/001)).(Citation: Cyware Social Media) Information from these sources may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Establish Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1585) or [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [Spearphishing via Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/003)).
1396.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Social Media" with ID T1593.001, categorized under the Reconnaissance tactic and applicable to multiple platforms. It involves adversaries passively harvesting victim data from social media sites to gather information on staff roles, locations, and organizational announcements. This collected intelligence is used to craft targeted lures, create fake profiles for elicitation, and enable follow-on actions like spearphishing or account compromise, with groups such as Kimsuky linked to its use.[profile]
1396.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Social Engineering is a broad technique used across multiple tactics, primarily Initial Access and Reconnaissance, on various platforms. It involves psychological manipulation to deceive individuals into performing actions or divulging confidential information, such as credentials. Specific mechanics include creating fake social media profiles or compromising existing accounts to build trust, and using tailored communications like spearphishing via email, social media services, or voice calls (vishing) with urgent or impersonated pretexts. This technique enables adversaries to gather information or gain initial access to systems.

1397.name: Shell Command Execution
1397.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution. The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems. The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands. The command prompt can be invoked remotely via [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [SSH](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/004).(Citation: SSH in Windows)

Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops. Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple systems.

Adversaries may leverage [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) to execute various commands and payloads. Common uses include [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) to execute a single command, or abusing [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) interactively with input and output forwarded over a command and control channel.
1397.profile: [profile]Windows Command Shell (T1059.003) is an Execution technique on Windows platforms where adversaries abuse cmd.exe, the primary command prompt, to run commands and payloads. It can be invoked locally or remotely via services like SSH, and supports batch files (.bat, .cmd) for scripting repetitive tasks. Common adversarial uses include executing single commands or establishing interactive command-and-control sessions.
1397.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Shell Command Execution is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework under ID T1059, categorized under the Execution tactic and applicable across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries directly invoking system shell interpreters, such as cmd.exe on Windows or sh/bash/zsh on Unix-like systems, to run arbitrary commands. This can be performed locally, through batch or shell scripts for task automation, or remotely via services like SSH, with command input and output often forwarded over a command and control channel.

1398.name: File Upload/Download
1398.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may upload malware to third-party or adversary controlled infrastructure to make it accessible during targeting. Malicious software can include payloads, droppers, post-compromise tools, backdoors, and a variety of other malicious content. Adversaries may upload malware to support their operations, such as making a payload available to a victim network to enable [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105) by placing it on an Internet accessible web server.

Malware may be placed on infrastructure that was previously purchased/rented by the adversary ([Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583)) or was otherwise compromised by them ([Compromise Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584)). Malware can also be staged on web services, such as GitHub or Pastebin; hosted on the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS), where decentralized content storage makes the removal of malicious files difficult; or saved on the blockchain as smart contracts, which are resilient against takedowns that would affect traditional infrastructure.(Citation: Volexity Ocean Lotus November 2020)(Citation: Talos IPFS 2022)(Citation: Guardio Etherhiding 2023)(Citation: Bleeping Computer Binance Smart Chain 2023)

Adversaries may upload backdoored files, such as software packages, application binaries, virtual machine images, or container images, to third-party software stores, package libraries, extension marketplaces, or repositories (ex: GitHub, CNET, AWS Community AMIs, Docker Hub, PyPi, NPM).(Citation: Datadog Security Labs Malicious PyPi Packages 2024) By chance encounter, victims may directly download/install these backdoored files via [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204). Masquerading, including typo-squatting legitimate software, may increase the chance of users mistakenly executing these files.
1398.profile: [profile]Upload Malware is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1608.001 under the Resource Development tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves staging malicious content like payloads or backdoored software packages on internet-accessible infrastructure to enable later tool transfer. This infrastructure includes adversary-controlled web servers, compromised services, third-party platforms like GitHub or PyPi, and decentralized systems such as IPFS or blockchain smart contracts to hinder removal. The technique is used by numerous threat groups including OilRig, FIN7, and Mustang Panda.[/profile]
1398.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "File Upload/Download" is a foundational action within cyber operations, not a distinct MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is a core mechanism enabling multiple techniques, primarily associated with the Command and Control tactic. It operates across various platforms. Technically, it involves the bidirectional transfer of files between adversary-controlled infrastructure and a victim network, facilitating stages like Ingress Tool Transfer (T1105). This action supports the staging and retrieval of malware, tools, and other payloads, often using web servers, cloud storage, or version control services. The related MITRE sub-techniques Upload Malware (T1608.001) and Upload Tool (T1608.002) describe its specific use for hosting malicious content or utilities.

1399.name: DLL Execution
1399.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse dynamic-link library files (DLLs) in order to achieve persistence, escalate privileges, and evade defenses. DLLs are libraries that contain code and data that can be simultaneously utilized by multiple programs. While DLLs are not malicious by nature, they can be abused through mechanisms such as side-loading, hijacking search order, and phantom DLL hijacking.(Citation: unit 42)

Specific ways DLLs are abused by adversaries include:

### DLL Sideloading
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by side-loading DLLs. Side-loading involves hijacking which DLL a program loads by planting and then invoking a legitimate application that executes their payload(s).

Side-loading positions both the victim application and malicious payload(s) alongside each other. Adversaries likely use side-loading as a means of masking actions they perform under a legitimate, trusted, and potentially elevated system or software process. Benign executables used to side-load payloads may not be flagged during delivery and/or execution. Adversary payloads may also be encrypted/packed or otherwise obfuscated until loaded into the memory of the trusted process.

Adversaries may also side-load other packages, such as BPLs (Borland Package Library).(Citation: kroll bpl)

Adversaries may chain DLL sideloading multiple times to fragment functionality hindering analysis. Adversaries using multiple DLL files can split the loader functions across different DLLs, with a main DLL loading the separated export functions. (Citation: Virus Bulletin) Spreading loader functions across multiple DLLs makes analysis harder, since all files must be collected to fully understand the malwareâ€™s behavior.  Another method implements a â€œloader-for-a-loaderâ€, where a malicious DLLâ€™s sole role is to load a second DLL (or a chain of DLLs) that contain the real payload. (Citation: Sophos)

### DLL Search Order Hijacking
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the search order that Windows uses to load DLLs. This search order is a sequence of special and standard search locations that a program checks when loading a DLL. An adversary can plant a trojan DLL in a directory that will be prioritized by the DLL search order over the location of a legitimate library. This will cause Windows to load the malicious DLL when it is called for by the victim program.(Citation: unit 42)

### DLL Redirection
Adversaries may directly modify the search order via DLL redirection, which after being enabled (in the Registry or via the creation of a redirection file) may cause a program to load a DLL from a different location.(Citation: Microsoft redirection)(Citation: Microsoft - manifests/assembly)

### Phantom DLL Hijacking
Adversaries may leverage phantom DLL hijacking by targeting references to non-existent DLL files. They may be able to load their own malicious DLL by planting it with the correct name in the location of the missing module.(Citation: Hexacorn DLL Hijacking)(Citation: Hijack DLLs CrowdStrike)

### DLL Substitution
Adversaries may target existing, valid DLL files and substitute them with their own malicious DLLs, planting them with the same name and in the same location as the valid DLL file.(Citation: Wietze Beukema DLL Hijacking)

Programs that fall victim to DLL hijacking may appear to behave normally because malicious DLLs may be configured to also load the legitimate DLLs they were meant to replace, evading defenses.

Remote DLL hijacking can occur when a program sets its current directory to a remote location, such as a Web share, before loading a DLL.(Citation: dll pre load owasp)(Citation: microsoft remote preloading)

If a valid DLL is configured to run at a higher privilege level, then the adversary-controlled DLL that is loaded will also be executed at the higher level. In this case, the technique could be used for privilege escalation.
1399.profile: [profile]DLL Side-Loading, identified as T1574.001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework under the Persistence and Privilege Escalation tactics, primarily targets Windows systems. This technique involves hijacking the DLL load order by placing a malicious DLL where a legitimate application will load it, such as through search order hijacking, side-loading with a benign executable, or phantom DLL hijacking targeting missing modules. The malicious code executes within the context of the trusted process, enabling evasion, persistence, and potential privilege escalation if the host process runs at a higher privilege level.[/profile]
1399.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DLL Execution is a technique for executing malicious code by abusing dynamic-link libraries. It is associated with the MITRE ATT&CK ID T1574.001, falls under the Persistence tactic, and primarily targets Windows platforms. The technique works by hijacking the standard DLL loading process through methods like DLL sideloading, where a malicious DLL is placed alongside a legitimate application, and DLL search order hijacking, where a trojan DLL is planted in a directory prioritized by Windows' load order. This allows adversaries to run their payloads under the guise of trusted processes, often for persistence, privilege escalation, or defense evasion.

1400.name: MD5 Hashing
1400.profile: [profile]MD5 Hashing is a technique for generating a fixed-size hash from data, often used by adversaries to obfuscate payloads or create identifiers for dynamic API resolution. It can be employed to conceal malware characteristics by storing hashes of function names instead of literal strings, which are then resolved at runtime using functions like GetProcAddress(). This method helps avoid static analysis and changes file signatures, similar to software packing. The technique is associated with groups like Lazarus Group and Mustang Panda.[/profile]
1400.profile_without_enhance: [profile]MD5 Hashing is a technique for generating a fixed-size hash from data, often used to verify file integrity or create unique identifiers. In adversarial contexts, it is employed to obfuscate malware characteristics, such as by storing hashes of API function names instead of literal strings to conceal malicious calls and hinder static analysis. This method is part of dynamic API resolution (T1027.007) and is utilized by groups like Lazarus Group and Mustang Panda.

1401.name: MenuPass
1401.uncertain_mes:
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) is a threat group that has been active since at least 2006. Individual members of [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) are known to have acted in association with the Chinese Ministry of State Security's (MSS) Tianjin State Security Bureau and worked for the Huaying Haitai Science and Technology Development Company.(Citation: DOJ APT10 Dec 2018)(Citation: District Court of NY APT10 Indictment December 2018)

[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has targeted healthcare, defense, aerospace, finance, maritime, biotechnology, energy, and government sectors globally, with an emphasis on Japanese organizations. In 2016 and 2017, the group is known to have targeted managed IT service providers (MSPs), manufacturing and mining companies, and a university.(Citation: Palo Alto menuPass Feb 2017)(Citation: Crowdstrike CrowdCast Oct 2013)(Citation: FireEye Poison Ivy)(Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper April 2017)(Citation: FireEye APT10 April 2017)(Citation: DOJ APT10 Dec 2018)(Citation: District Court of NY APT10 Indictment December 2018)
1401.profile: [profile]MenuPass, also known as APT10, Bronze Riverside, Red Apollo, Potassium, Stone Panda, CVNX, Cicada, and Hogfish, is a Chinese state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2006 and attributed to the Ministry of State Security. Its arsenal includes the use and modification of tools like Impacket, Mimikatz, pwdump, and PowerSploit, and it employs TTPs such as encoding with base64 and XOR obfuscation, compressing files with TAR/RAR before exfiltration, and using native APIs and tools like tcping.exe for reconnaissance. The group has globally targeted sectors including healthcare, defense, aerospace, finance, maritime, biotechnology, energy, and government, with a particular emphasis on Japanese organizations and managed IT service providers, primarily for cyber espionage.
1401.profile_without_enhance: [profile]MenuPass, also known as APT10, Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, Cicada, and Bronze Riverside, is a Chinese state-sponsored threat group attributed to the Ministry of State Security. Its key malware includes ChChes, which uses HTTP Cookie headers for C2 communication and DLL sideloading for execution. The group's TTPs involve spear-phishing for initial access, use of open-source tools like Impacket and Mimikatz for credential access and lateral movement, and tools like tcping.exe for reconnaissance. It primarily targets entities in Japan and other regions, focusing on intellectual property theft and espionage, with campaigns often involving data compression and encryption before exfiltration.
1401.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]MenuPass is an intrusion set attributed to the Chinese state-sponsored APT10 group, also known as Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, Cicada, and CVNX. Its key malware and tools include custom backdoors, alongside modified open-source utilities like Impacket, Mimikatz, and PowerSploit. Notable TTPs involve using native APIs, tools like tcping.exe for reconnaissance, and encoding data with base64 or XOR obfuscation, as well as compressing files with TAR/RAR before exfiltration. The group is believed to operate on behalf of China's Ministry of State Security, primarily targeting government, technology, and managed service provider sectors globally, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and intellectual property theft.]
1401.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]MenuPass is a cyber espionage group, also known as APT10, Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, and Cicada, attributed to Chinese state-sponsored actors. Its key malware and tools include custom backdoors, modified open-source tools like Impacket and Mimikatz, and utilities such as tcping.exe and PowerSploit. Key TTPs involve using native APIs, base64 and XOR obfuscation, encrypting and compressing (TAR/RAR) files before exfiltration, and leveraging tools like Csvde for Active Directory data collection. The group primarily targets sectors including managed IT service providers, government, and technology across North America, Europe, and Asia, with motivations centered on intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering for espionage purposes.]
1401.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]MenuPass is a Chinese state-sponsored APT group, also known as Stone Panda, APT10, Cloud Hopper, and Bronze Riverside. Its key malware includes ChChes, which uses HTTP Cookie headers for C2 and DLL sideloading. The group employs spear-phishing for initial access, and its TTPs involve using tools like Impacket, Mimikatz, PowerSploit, and tcping.exe for lateral movement and reconnaissance, along with data obfuscation via XOR and base64 encoding and compression using TAR/RAR before exfiltration. It is attributed to China and primarily targets entities in Japan and other regions, with motivations believed to be cyber espionage, particularly against government, technology, and telecommunications sectors.
1401.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set MenuPass is a primary alias for the China-nexus APT group widely tracked as APT10 (Stone Panda), also known as Bronze Riverside, Cloud Hopper, and Cicada. Its key malware includes the custom backdoor ChChes, which uses HTTP Cookie headers for C2, and the group frequently employs open-source tools like Impacket, Mimikatz, and PowerSploit. Characteristic TTPs involve spear-phishing for initial access, followed by the use of tools like tcping.exe for reconnaissance, DLL sideloading for execution, and compression with TAR/RAR prior to data exfiltration. The group is attributed to China and has historically targeted entities in Japan and other regions, primarily motivated by cyber espionage against government, technology, and managed service provider sectors to steal intellectual property and strategic intelligence.
1401.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]MenuPass is a cyber espionage intrusion set widely attributed to the Chinese state-sponsored group APT10 (also known as Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, and Bronze Riverside). Its key malware includes ChChes, which uses HTTP Cookie headers for C2 communication and DLL sideloading for execution. The group's TTPs involve spear-phishing for initial access, extensive use of open-source tools like Impacket and Mimikatz for lateral movement, and data exfiltration using compression (TAR/RAR) and encryption. It primarily targets entities in Japan and other regions, focusing on intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering to support Chinese state interests.
1401.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]MenuPass is a cyber espionage group widely attributed to the Chinese state and is considered a primary component or alias of APT10 (also known as Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, and Bronze Riverside). Its key malware includes ChChes, which uses HTTP cookie headers for C2 communication and DLL sideloading. The group's TTPs involve spear-phishing for initial access, extensive use of open-source and living-off-the-land tools like Impacket, Mimikatz, PowerSploit, and Csvde, and employs data obfuscation through AES encryption, base64, and XOR encoding before exfiltration via compressed TAR/RAR archives. It primarily targets entities in Japan and other regions for intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering, aligning with China's state-sponsored cyber espionage objectives.
1401.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]MenuPass is a cyber espionage group, also known as APT10, Stone Panda, and Cloud Hopper, believed to be linked to China. Its key malware includes ChChes, which uses HTTP Cookie headers for C2 communication and DLL sideloading. The group's TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious ZIP attachments, use of open-source tools like Impacket and Mimikatz for credential access, and data exfiltration using compression (TAR/RAR) and encryption. It primarily targets sectors in Japan and other regions, with motivations centered on intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering.
1401.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]MenuPass is a cyber espionage group widely attributed to China and is considered a primary cluster within the broader APT10 (also known as Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, and Bronze Riverside) threat actor. Its operations, which have targeted Japan and other regions, are characterized by the use of custom malware like ChChes, which employs DLL sideloading and cookie-based C2 communication. Key TTPs include spear-phishing for initial access, the use of open-source and living-off-the-land tools such as Impacket, Mimikatz, PowerSploit, and Csvde for lateral movement and data collection, and data exfiltration techniques involving compression (TAR/RAR) and encryption. The group's primary motivation is believed to be intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering.
1401.profile_without_enhance_5_no_hsage: [profile]MenuPass is a Chinese state-sponsored APT group, also known as Stone Panda, APT10, Cloud Hopper, and CVNX. It primarily uses the ChChes malware, delivered via spear-phishing, and leverages tools like Impacket, Mimikatz, PowerSploit, and pwdump. Its key TTPs include DLL sideloading for execution, AES encryption for data obfuscation, and the use of tools like tcping.exe for reconnaissance and TAR/RAR for compressing files before exfiltration. The group is attributed to China and primarily targets entities in Japan and other regions, focusing on intellectual property theft and espionage to support state strategic interests.
1401.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]MenuPass is a cyber espionage group widely tracked as APT10 (also known as Stone Panda, Cloud Hopper, POTASSIUM, and Cicada). It employs custom malware like ChChes and leverages open-source tools such as Impacket, Mimikatz, and PowerSploit for credential access and lateral movement. Key TTPs include spear-phishing for initial access, the use of native APIs and tools like tcping.exe for reconnaissance, and data exfiltration using TAR/RAR compression and AES encryption. The group is attributed to China and has historically targeted entities in Japan and other regions, focusing on intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering to support state interests.
1401.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the group widely known as APT10 (also known as Stone Panda, MenuPass Team, CVNX, Cloud Hopper, and Cicada). Its key malware includes the ChChes malware, which uses HTTP Cookie headers for C2 communication and DLL sideloading. The group's TTPs involve spear-phishing for initial access, the use of open-source tools like Impacket, Mimikatz, and PowerSploit for credential access and execution, and the use of tools like tcping.exe for reconnaissance. It is attributed to China and has historically targeted a wide range of sectors globally, including managed service providers (MSPs) in the Cloud Hopper campaign, with motivations believed to be cyber espionage and intellectual property theft.

1405.name: APT34
1405.uncertain_mes: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) is a suspected Iranian threat group that has targeted Middle Eastern and international victims since at least 2014. The group has targeted a variety of sectors, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications. It appears the group carries out supply chain attacks, leveraging the trust relationship between organizations to attack their primary targets. The group works on behalf of the Iranian government based on infrastructure details that contain references to Iran, use of Iranian infrastructure, and targeting that aligns with nation-state interests.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig April 2017)(Citation: ClearSky OilRig Jan 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig May 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig Oct 2016)(Citation: Unit42 OilRig Playbook 2023)(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)
1405.profile: [profile]APT34, also known as OilRig, Helix Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy, is a suspected Iranian state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2014. Its arsenal includes custom malware and tools, and it is known for supply chain attacks. The group is attributed to Iran based on infrastructure and targeting patterns. It primarily targets sectors in the Middle East and internationally, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications, aligning with Iranian strategic interests.
1405.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group APT34, also known as OilRig, Helix Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy, with suspected overlaps with UNC1860. Its key custom malware includes the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious attachments, DNS-based command and control, and the use of custom scripts for persistence. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets government organizations and financial institutions in the Middle East, for intelligence gathering aligned with state interests.[/profile]
1405.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]APT34, also known as UNC1860 and Lifting Zmiy, is an Iranian state-sponsored threat group attributed to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC). Its operations are primarily motivated by espionage, targeting government, energy, financial, and telecommunications sectors in the Middle East and beyond. The group is distinguished by its use of custom malware families and tools, and it shows overlaps with other clusters, though its core infrastructure and targeting patterns remain distinct.
1405.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]APT34, also known as UNC1860, is an Iranian state-sponsored threat group attributed to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC). It is known for deploying custom malware families such as POWBAT, POISONFROG, and the backdoor CHOPSTICK, and has been observed using tools like Mimikatz and credential dumping techniques. The group primarily targets Middle Eastern governments and organizations in the financial, energy, and telecommunications sectors, with a strong focus on intelligence gathering to support Iranian state interests. Its operations show overlaps with other clusters, and it is believed to conduct long-term espionage campaigns.
1405.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group APT34, also known as OilRig, Helix Kitten, Cobalt Gypsy, and Europiu, is characterized by its use of custom malware like the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. Its key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious attachments (e.g., Office documents with macros), DNS-based command and control, and the use of unique scripts for persistence. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets government, financial, and energy sectors in the Middle East, for intelligence gathering aligned with state interests. It shows overlaps with clusters like UNC1860.[/profile]
1405.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]The Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group APT34, also known as OilRig, Helix Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy, is characterized by its use of custom malware like the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. Its key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious attachments, the use of unique scripts for persistence, and techniques like multilayer encryption for command and control. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets Middle Eastern government organizations and financial institutions, particularly banks, for intelligence gathering aligned with state interests. It shows overlaps with clusters like UNC1860.
