1408.name: Targeted Attacks
1408.profile: [profile]The entity "Targeted Attacks" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; it is a generic term. Based on the retrieved information, it is contextually associated with Denial-of-Service (DoS) techniques. These techniques, such as Endpoint Denial of Service (T1499) and Direct Network Flood (T1498.001), aim to degrade or block service availability by exhausting system resources or saturating networks. They can be executed via methods like resource exhaustion, network flooding using botnets, or IP address spoofing, and are often used for purposes including political attacks, distraction, or extortion.[/profile]
1408.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Targeted Attacks" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; it is a generic term. Based on the retrieved information, the context describes Denial of Service (DoS) techniques. These include Endpoint Denial of Service (T1499), which exhausts system resources like OS, server applications, or web apps to degrade service availability, and Direct Network Flood (T1498.001), which uses high-volume network traffic from single or multiple systems (including botnets) to saturate a target's network. Application Exhaustion Flood (T1499.003) specifically targets resource-intensive application features. Common supplementary methods involve IP address spoofing to obscure attack sources and the use of rented or controlled botnets to generate traffic, making defense difficult.

1409.name: Malicious Attachments
1409.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may rely upon a user opening a malicious file in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to open a file that will lead to code execution. This user action will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001). Adversaries may use several types of files that require a user to execute them, including .doc, .pdf, .xls, .rtf, .scr, .exe, .lnk, .pif, .cpl, .reg, and .iso.(Citation: Mandiant Trojanized Windows 10)

Adversaries may employ various forms of [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) and [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027) to increase the likelihood that a user will open and successfully execute a malicious file. These methods may include using a familiar naming convention and/or password protecting the file and supplying instructions to a user on how to open it.(Citation: Password Protected Word Docs) 

While [Malicious File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002) frequently occurs shortly after Initial Access it may occur at other phases of an intrusion, such as when an adversary places a file in a shared directory or on a user's desktop hoping that a user will click on it. This activity may also be seen shortly after [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534).
1409.profile: [profile]Malicious File, identified as T1204.002, is an Initial Access and Execution technique under the User Execution tactic, primarily targeting Windows platforms. It relies on a user opening a malicious attachment, such as .doc, .pdf, .exe, .lnk, or .iso files, often delivered via spearphishing. Adversaries employ masquerading tactics like double file extensions and password protection to increase success rates, tricking users into executing code that facilitates further intrusion stages. This technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including APT34, and commonly follows delivery methods like Spearphishing Attachment.
1409.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Attachments is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, specifically ID T1193, under the Initial Access tactic, primarily targeting Windows platforms. It involves adversaries sending emails with malware-laden attachments, such as Microsoft Office documents, PDFs, or executables, to trick users into opening them, leading to execution. The technique often employs masquerading tactics like double file extensions (e.g., .txt.exe) to appear benign and may include instructions to bypass security protections.

1410.name: Unique Scripts
1410.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may establish persistence by modifying RC scripts, which are executed during a Unix-like systemâ€™s startup. These files allow system administrators to map and start custom services at startup for different run levels. RC scripts require root privileges to modify. Adversaries may establish persistence by adding a malicious binary path or shell commands to rc.local, rc.common, and other RC scripts specific to the Unix-like distribution.(Citation: IranThreats Kittens Dec 2017)(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019) Upon reboot, the system executes the script's contents as root, resulting in persistence. Adversary abuse of RC scripts is especially effective for lightweight Unix-like distributions using the root user as default, such as ESXi hypervisors, IoT, or embedded systems.(Citation: intezer-kaiji-malware) As ESXi servers store most system files in memory and therefore discard changes on shutdown, leveraging `/etc/rc.local.d/local.sh` is one of the few mechanisms for enabling persistence across reboots.(Citation: Juniper Networks ESXi Backdoor 2022) Several Unix-like systems have moved to Systemd and deprecated the use of RC scripts. This is now a deprecated mechanism in macOS in favor of Launchd.(Citation: Apple Developer Doco Archive Launchd)(Citation: Startup Items) This technique can be used on Mac OS X Panther v10.3 and earlier versions which still execute the RC scripts.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) To maintain backwards compatibility some systems, such as Ubuntu, will execute the RC scripts if they exist with the correct file permissions.(Citation: Ubuntu Manpage systemd rc)
1410.profile: [profile]The technique is MITRE ATT&CK ID T1037.004, named Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: RC Scripts, under the Persistence tactic for Linux and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries modifying Unix-like system RC startup scripts like rc.local or rc.common by inserting malicious binary paths or shell commands, which execute with root privileges upon reboot to establish persistence. This is particularly effective on lightweight systems like ESXi hypervisors, IoT, or embedded devices using root by default, though it is deprecated in modern macOS and some systems in favor of Systemd. Groups such as APT29, VELVET ANT, and UNC3886 have been associated with its use.
1410.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Unique Scripts" is a technique for establishing persistence, likely aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK framework's Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts (T1037). It involves adversaries placing or modifying custom scripts that are automatically executed during system startup or user logon. This allows malicious code to run with the privileges of the executing user or service, enabling persistence on a single system or across a network. The specific mechanics depend on the operating system, utilizing mechanisms like Windows Registry keys for logon scripts, network scripts via Active Directory, or Unix-like RC scripts.

1412.name: Malicious Office Documents
1412.profile: [profile]Malicious Office Documents, also referred to as malicious documents, are a common initial infection vector. They are attributed to intrusion sets like Unknown_Threat_Actor and are used by groups including Fin7, Gold Cabin, and Lunar Spider. The key technique involves embedding macros within Microsoft Office Word documents to execute malicious code on a victim's system upon opening. The primary target platform is Microsoft Windows, and these documents are frequently distributed via email attachments, archive files, or links leading to the document files to deliver payloads like Gravity Rat, Griffon, IcedID, or Emotet.
1412.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Office Documents, also known as malicious documents, are a common infection vector used by various threat actors. They are frequently associated with malware families like Gravity Rat, Griffon, and Icedid, which are linked to groups such as Fin7, Gold Cabin, and Lunar Spider. A primary technique involves embedding malicious macros within Microsoft Office Word documents to execute code on a victim's system. These documents are also distributed via links, archive files, and deceptive installation packages. They are directly linked to specific payloads, such as the 'helminth' script variant used by APT34, which utilizes batch files and scheduled tasks for persistence and execution.[/profile]

1413.name: Macro Malware
1413.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
1413.profile: [profile]Macro Malware, also known as nmass malware, is a .NET-based Remote Access Trojan (RAT). It is delivered via malicious Microsoft Office documents, specifically using Royal Road v7 document templates, and drops an initial executable (e.g., \os03C2.tmp). Its campaigns have used decoy documents about COVID-19 infections in Russia, falsely signed and targeted at Mongolian authorities. This malware exhibits similarities to tools used by groups referenced as Operation LagTime or Tonto Team, though its primary attributed group remains unknown. Its key behaviors include installing a backdoor and it operates on the Windows platform.
1413.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Macro Malware is a type of malware that leverages malicious macros, often within documents, to deploy payloads. It is used as an initial infection vector by various groups and for different final payloads, including the remote access trojan Remcos (associated with APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050), the FlowCloud malware (associated with Stone Panda), and the LookBack malware. Its primary target platform is Microsoft Office applications and Windows systems, exploiting document-based social engineering for initial access.

1415.name: update.vbs
1415.profile: [profile]update.vbs is a VBScript malware, also known as Helminth. It is attributed to the intrusion-set Unknown_Threat_Actor. Its key technical behaviors include being downloaded and executed as part of a chain, where it is fetched via curl from a domain like 360scanner[.]store within a ZIP archive, extracted to a temporary directory, and then run using wscript. The target platform is Windows. It is associated with the actor group wagemole and is delivered via infrastructure involving the domain 360scanner[.]store.
1415.profile_without_enhance: [profile]update.vbs is a VBScript variant of the Helminth backdoor malware, also known as Helminth Trojan. It is attributed to the OilRig (APT34) intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include being delivered via documents like Clayslide, generating subdomains for command and control, and being executed via wscript. The malware targets the Windows platform and uses infrastructure such as C2 servers and IP addresses like 33.33.x.x.[/profile]

1416.name: dns.ps1
1416.profile: [profile]dns.ps1 is a PowerShell script associated with the Helminth malware and used by the intrusion set APT34 (OilRig). Its technical behaviors include issuing DNS queries for command and control (C2) and utilizing specific file paths like %PUBLIC%\\Libraries\\ for its components. The primary target platform is Windows.[/profile]
1416.profile_without_enhance: [profile]dns.ps1 is a PowerShell script variant of the Helminth backdoor malware, which is attributed to the OilRig (APT34) intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include issuing DNS queries for command and control communication. The malware targets the Windows platform and is known to be dropped to paths like %PUBLIC%\Libraries\dns.ps1.[/profile]

1417.name: vbscript
1417.profile: [profile]VBScript is a scripting language used by threat actors like Unknown_Threat_Actor. It is utilized in the deployment of malware families such as Pony, AsyncRAT, and Venom RAT, as evidenced by shared VBScript file hashes. These malware families are associated with groups like Cobalt. Its key technical behavior involves being embedded in documents to download and execute remote access trojans (RATs) on Windows platforms, facilitating initial infection and payload delivery.[/profile]
1417.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VBScript is a scripting language used as a component or delivery mechanism for various malware families, including Pony, AsyncRAT, and Venom RAT. It is associated with threat groups like Cobalt. Its key technical behavior involves being embedded within malicious documents, as indicated by multiple VBScript file hashes found in PDFs. The primary target platform is Windows, leveraging its native scripting engine for execution and initial compromise.

1418.name: Bat Script
1418.profile: [profile]Bat Script is a general file type used as an initial loader or script component by various malware families and threat actors. It is employed by dbatloader, the Black Basta ransomware (with associated Defender removal scripts attributed to groups like Gold Rebellion, STAC5143, STORM-0506, STORM-0826, TA2101, UNC3973, and UNC4393), and the Remcos RAT (linked to APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050). Its primary technical behavior involves executing batch commands to disable security software like Windows Defender and to deploy subsequent payloads, primarily targeting the Windows platform.
1418.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bat Script is a malware entity. It is referenced as an initial script component by other malware families including dbatloader, Black Basta (where it is used as a Defender removal script), and Remcos. It is associated with groups such as Gold Rebellion, Stac5143, STORM-0506, STORM-0826, TA2101, UNC3973, UNC4393, APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050. Its key technical behavior involves disabling Windows Defender. Its target platform is Windows.

1421.name: Base64 Decoding
1421.profile: [profile]Base64 Decoding is a specific technical method within the broader adversary technique of Data Encoding (T1132.001). It is used to make command and control (C2) traffic more difficult to detect by converting binary data into a standard ASCII text format. This allows adversaries to embed malicious payloads or communications within otherwise normal-looking protocol traffic, adhering to common specifications to evade simple detection methods.[/profile]
1421.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Base64 Decoding" is a sub-technique of Data Encoding (T1132.001) within the Command and Control tactic. It operates across multiple platforms and involves adversaries decoding Base64-encoded data, which is a standard binary-to-text encoding scheme, to retrieve original payloads or commands that were obfuscated within network traffic to evade detection. This technique is commonly employed by threat groups such as Hafnium, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group.

1422.name: ASCII Character Encoding
1422.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may encode data with a standard data encoding system to make the content of command and control traffic more difficult to detect. Command and control (C2) information can be encoded using a standard data encoding system that adheres to existing protocol specifications. Common data encoding schemes include ASCII, Unicode, hexadecimal, Base64, and MIME.(Citation: Wikipedia Binary-to-text Encoding)(Citation: Wikipedia Character Encoding) Some data encoding systems may also result in data compression, such as gzip.
1422.profile: [profile]ASCII Character Encoding is a sub-technique (T1132.001) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves encoding C2 traffic using common, protocol-compliant schemes like ASCII, Unicode, hexadecimal, Base64, and MIME to obfuscate content and evade detection, with some schemes like gzip also providing compression. This technique is associated with threat groups including Hafnium, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group.[/profile]
1422.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ASCII Character Encoding is a sub-technique of Data Encoding (T1132.001) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates across multiple platforms. Adversaries use this standard encoding system to obfuscate command and control traffic by converting binary data into a text format using the ASCII character set, adhering to common protocol specifications to evade detection. Groups like HAFNIUM, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group have employed this method.

1423.name: DNS Tunneling
1423.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may tunnel network communications to and from a victim system within a separate protocol to avoid detection/network filtering and/or enable access to otherwise unreachable systems. Tunneling involves explicitly encapsulating a protocol within another. This behavior may conceal malicious traffic by blending in with existing traffic and/or provide an outer layer of encryption (similar to a VPN). Tunneling could also enable routing of network packets that would otherwise not reach their intended destination, such as SMB, RDP, or other traffic that would be filtered by network appliances or not routed over the Internet. 

There are various means to encapsulate a protocol within another protocol. For example, adversaries may perform SSH tunneling (also known as SSH port forwarding), which involves forwarding arbitrary data over an encrypted SSH tunnel.(Citation: SSH Tunneling)(Citation: Sygnia Abyss Locker 2025) 

[Protocol Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572) may also be abused by adversaries during [Dynamic Resolution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1568). Known as DNS over HTTPS (DoH), queries to resolve C2 infrastructure may be encapsulated within encrypted HTTPS packets.(Citation: BleepingComp Godlua JUL19) 

Adversaries may also leverage [Protocol Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572) in conjunction with [Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090) and/or [Protocol or Service Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1001/003) to further conceal C2 communications and infrastructure.
1423.profile: [profile]DNS Tunneling is a specific application of the general Protocol Tunneling technique (T1572) under the Command and Control tactic. It operates by encapsulating command and control traffic within DNS queries and responses, often embedding data in fields like TXT or A records to blend with normal, allowed network traffic and avoid detection. This technique is used by groups like OilRig and malware like BONDUPDATER to establish covert channels, sometimes in conjunction with other methods like multilayer encryption.[/profile]
1423.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DNS Tunneling is a technique under MITRE ATT&CK ID T1071.004 within the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves encapsulating command and control traffic within DNS protocol queries and responses to evade network filtering and detection by blending with legitimate administrative traffic. Adversaries embed data and commands into various DNS record fields, such as TXT or A records, often creating infrequent DNS beacons to further conceal malicious activity within normal network operations. This method is a specific form of Protocol Tunneling (T1572).

1424.name: HTTP POST Request
1424.profile: [profile]HTTP POST Request is a common web protocol technique (T1071.001) used for Command and Control, allowing adversaries to blend malicious communications within normal web traffic by embedding commands and data in the body of HTTP POST requests. This method leverages standard, expected network traffic to avoid detection and network filtering.
1424.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "HTTP POST Request" is a common web protocol technique used for data transmission. It aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1071.001 (Web Protocols) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. Technically, it involves adversaries embedding commands or exfiltrated data within the body of standard HTTP POST requests to blend with normal web traffic, often using services like webhooks for automated data transfer. This method can be combined with non-standard encoding to further obscure the payload.

1425.name: Reconnaissance Activities
1425.profile: [profile]Reconnaissance Activities is a broad, non-specific term that maps to the Reconnaissance tactic (TA0043) within the MITRE ATT&CK framework. It encompasses various techniques for gathering information about a target prior to an attack. Specific techniques include Active Scanning (T1595), which involves probing victim infrastructure via network traffic like ICMP, and gathering information from private threat intelligence vendor data (T1597.001). Information discovered during reconnaissance can enable subsequent techniques for establishing resources or gaining initial access.[/profile]
1425.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Reconnaissance Activities refers to the initial phase of adversary operations, focusing on gathering information about a target. This broad tactic encompasses various techniques, including active scanning (T1595), where adversaries probe victim infrastructure via network traffic like ICMP to gather data for further targeting. It also involves searching private threat intelligence vendor data (T1597.001) to obtain actionable information on trends and TTPs. Additionally, reconnaissance supports other activities, such as discovering security software and file/path exclusions (T1564.012) to identify trusted folders for hiding artifacts. This information gathering is foundational for establishing operational resources and planning subsequent attack stages.

1426.name: Disable Office Macros
1426.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office templates to obtain persistence on a compromised system. Microsoft Office contains templates that are part of common Office applications and are used to customize styles. The base templates within the application are used each time an application starts. (Citation: Microsoft Change Normal Template) Office Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros (Citation: MSDN VBA in Office) can be inserted into the base template and used to execute code when the respective Office application starts in order to obtain persistence. Examples for both Word and Excel have been discovered and published. By default, Word has a Normal.dotm template created that can be modified to include a malicious macro. Excel does not have a template file created by default, but one can be added that will automatically be loaded.(Citation: enigma0x3 normal.dotm)(Citation: Hexacorn Office Template Macros) Shared templates may also be stored and pulled from remote locations.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) Word Normal.dotm location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\Normal.dotm Excel Personal.xlsb location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Excel\XLSTART\PERSONAL.XLSB Adversaries may also change the location of the base template to point to their own by hijacking the application's search order, e.g. Word 2016 will first look for Normal.dotm under C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\, or by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key. By modifying the GlobalDotName registry key an adversary can specify an arbitrary location, file name, and file extension to use for the template that will be loaded on application startup. To abuse GlobalDotName, adversaries may first need to register the template as a trusted document or place it in a trusted location.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) An adversary may need to enable macros to execute unrestricted depending on the system or enterprise security policy on use of macros.
1426.profile: [profile]Office Template Macros (T1137.001) is a Persistence technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, targeting Windows platforms. It involves inserting malicious VBA macros into Microsoft Office base templates, such as Word's Normal.dotm or Excel's Personal.xlsb, to execute code each time the respective application starts. Adversaries may also redirect template loading by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key or hijacking the application's search path, potentially requiring the template to be placed in a trusted location or macros to be enabled for execution. The MuddyWater threat group has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1426.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Disable Office Macros" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it refers to a defensive action or security policy setting, not an adversarial attack pattern. The related information discusses adversarial techniques like Office Template Macros (T1137.001) and Office Application Startup (T1137) for persistence, which often require macros to be enabled. The core technical mechanic involves configuring system or application policies to block the execution of VBA macros within Microsoft Office documents to prevent such malicious code from running. This is a common security control on Windows platforms.

1427.name: Net Commands
1427.profile: [profile]Net Commands, corresponding to the MITRE ATT&CK software entity S0039, is a native Windows command-line utility used for network discovery and system interrogation. It supports techniques like System Network Connections Discovery (T1049) by executing commands such as 'netstat', 'net use', and 'net session' to list connections and sessions, and Domain Account Discovery (T1087.002) via 'net user /domain' and 'net group /domain' to enumerate Active Directory users and groups. It is a tool leveraged by numerous threat groups including APT41, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group for initial reconnaissance within a compromised environment.
1427.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Net Commands" is a software tool (S0039) used within the MITRE ATT&CK framework to support multiple discovery techniques. It is employed across Windows platforms for tactics like Discovery. Specifically, adversaries use its utilities, such as `net user /domain` and `net group /domain`, to enumerate domain accounts (T1087.002), and commands like `netstat`, `net use`, and `net session` to discover system network connections (T1049). This tool provides a native Windows interface for gathering critical system and network information.

1428.name: System Enumeration
1428.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may enumerate system and service logs to find useful data. These logs may highlight various types of valuable insights for an adversary, such as user authentication records ([Account Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1087)), security or vulnerable software ([Software Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1518)), or hosts within a compromised network ([Remote System Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1018)).

Host binaries may be leveraged to collect system logs. Examples include using `wevtutil.exe` or [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) on Windows to access and/or export security event information.(Citation: WithSecure Lazarus-NoPineapple Threat Intel Report 2023)(Citation: Cadet Blizzard emerges as novel threat actor) In cloud environments, adversaries may leverage utilities such as the Azure VM Agentâ€™s `CollectGuestLogs.exe` to collect security logs from cloud hosted infrastructure.(Citation: SIM Swapping and Abuse of the Microsoft Azure Serial Console)

Adversaries may also target centralized logging infrastructure such as SIEMs. Logs may also be bulk exported and sent to adversary-controlled infrastructure for offline analysis.

In addition to gaining a better understanding of the environment, adversaries may also monitor logs in real time to track incident response procedures. This may allow them to adjust their techniques in order to maintain persistence or evade defenses.(Citation: Permiso GUI-Vil 2023)
1428.profile: [profile]System Enumeration, also known as log enumeration (T1654), is a Discovery technique used to gather valuable data from system, service, and security logs. Adversaries leverage host binaries like `wevtutil.exe` or PowerShell on Windows and tools like Azure VM Agent's `CollectGuestLogs.exe` in cloud environments to access and export logs. They target centralized logging infrastructure such as SIEMs, bulk exporting logs for offline analysis to discover user accounts, software, and network hosts, and may monitor logs in real-time to track incident response and evade defenses. Associated threat groups include Volt Typhoon, APT5, Mustang Panda, Ember Bear, and Aquatic Panda.
1428.profile_without_enhance: [profile]System Enumeration is a Discovery technique where adversaries gather detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, architecture, patches, and service packs. This is often performed using native commands and tools like `systeminfo` or `systemsetup` on macOS, and the information gathered helps shape follow-on attack behaviors, such as tailoring payloads or determining whether to fully infect a target.

1429.name: Registry Query
1429.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may interact with the Windows Registry to gather information about the system, configuration, and installed software.

The Registry contains a significant amount of information about the operating system, configuration, software, and security.(Citation: Wikipedia Windows Registry) Information can easily be queried using the [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) utility, though other means to access the Registry exist. Some of the information may help adversaries to further their operation within a network. Adversaries may use the information from [Query Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1012) during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors, including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.
1429.profile: [profile]Registry Query is technique T1012 under the Discovery tactic, targeting the Windows platform. It involves adversaries interacting with the Windows Registry to gather system, configuration, and software information, often using utilities like Reg.exe to perform queries. This collected data is used during automated discovery to inform and shape subsequent adversarial actions.[/profile]
1429.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Registry Query is a technique identified as T1012, falling under the Discovery tactic on Windows platforms. It involves adversaries interacting with the Windows Registry to gather information about system configuration and installed software, often using utilities like Reg.exe. This information is used for automated discovery to inform subsequent attack behaviors.

1434.name: OilRig
1434.uncertain_mes: [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) is a suspected Iranian threat group that has targeted Middle Eastern and international victims since at least 2014. The group has targeted a variety of sectors, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications. It appears the group carries out supply chain attacks, leveraging the trust relationship between organizations to attack their primary targets. The group works on behalf of the Iranian government based on infrastructure details that contain references to Iran, use of Iranian infrastructure, and targeting that aligns with nation-state interests.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig April 2017)(Citation: ClearSky OilRig Jan 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig May 2016)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig Oct 2016)(Citation: Unit42 OilRig Playbook 2023)(Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)
1434.profile: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy, is a suspected Iranian state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2014. Its arsenal includes custom tools like the Helminth backdoor and the use of CHM payloads for execution. The group's TTPs involve supply chain attacks to compromise primary targets. It is attributed to Iran based on infrastructure and targeting aligned with national interests. Primary targets are in the financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications sectors across the Middle East and internationally, with motivation centered on espionage.
1434.profile_without_enhance: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, Cobalt Gypsy, Twisted Kitten, and Hazel Sandstorm, is an Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key custom malware includes the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious documents like Clayslide, the use of malicious macros, and DNS-based command and control. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets government, energy, telecommunications, technology, and financial sectors in the Middle East, with a focus on countries like Israel, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and Turkey. Its core motivation is intelligence gathering.[/profile]
1434.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, Cobalt Gypsy, and Hazel Sandstorm, is an Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key malware includes the Helminth backdoor, and it has used CHM payloads and scripts for host enumeration in campaigns like "Juicy Mix." Its primary targets are organizations in the Middle East, particularly in Saudi Arabia, across sectors like government, energy, and finance, with motivations centered on intelligence gathering and strategic advantage.
1434.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, Cobalt Gypsy, and Hazel Sandstorm, is an Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group (tracked as G0049). Its key malware and tools include the Helminth backdoor and custom scripts like "Juicy Mix," and it frequently uses CHM payloads for initial access. Its primary TTPs involve spear-phishing and credential harvesting to target Middle Eastern governments and sectors like energy and finance, with a consistent motivation of intelligence gathering in alignment with Iranian strategic interests.
1434.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy, is an Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key custom malware includes Helminth, Bondupdater, and Quadagent, often delivered via spear-phishing with malicious Office documents (Clayslide) and CHM files. The group's primary TTPs involve DNS-based command and control, DNS tunneling, and clipboard monitoring for data collection. Attributed to Iran, APT34 primarily targets government, energy, telecommunications, financial, and technology sectors in the Middle East, with specific campaigns against Israeli, Saudi, and Qatari organizations. Its motivation is intelligence gathering through stealthy, long-term operations.[/profile]
1434.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy, is a suspected Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key custom malware includes the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent, often delivered via spear-phishing with malicious attachments like CHM and Office documents (Clayslide). The group employs DNS-based command and control, PowerShell and VBScript for execution, and techniques like scheduled tasks for persistence. Primarily targeting the Middle East, its victims span government, energy, telecommunications, financial, and defense sectors, with operations focused on intelligence gathering aligned with Iranian state interests.[/profile]
1434.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, Cobalt Gypsy, and UNC1860, is an Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key custom malware includes Helminth, Bondupdater, and Quadagent, often delivered via spear-phishing with malicious CHM and Office documents like Clayslide. The group employs DNS tunneling for command and control, uses scheduled tasks for persistence, and leverages vulnerabilities such as CVE-2017-0199. Believed to operate from Iran, it primarily targets government, energy, telecommunications, and financial sectors in the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia, Israel, and Qatar, with a motivation focused on intelligence gathering.[/profile]
1434.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]OilRig, also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, Cobalt Gypsy, and TA452, is an Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group. Its key custom malware includes the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent, often delivered via spear-phishing using malicious CHM and Office documents like Clayslide. The group employs DNS-based command and control, credential theft, and clipboard monitoring. Primarily targeting government, energy, telecommunications, and financial sectors in the Middle East, particularly Israel and Saudi Arabia, its motivation is intelligence gathering through stealthy, long-term operations.[/profile]

Its key malware includes the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious macro documents (like Clayslide) and DNS-based command and control for persistence. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets government, financial, energy, and technology sectors in the Middle East, especially Saudi Arabia, Israel, and Qatar, for intelligence gathering aligned with state interests.[/profile]

Its key custom malware includes Helminth, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. The group employs spear-phishing with malicious attachments like CHM and Office documents (Clayslide), often exploiting vulnerabilities such as CVE-2017-0199, and uses DNS-based command and control. Its key custom malware includes Helminth, Bondupdater, and Quadagent, delivered via spear-phishing with malicious CHM and Office documents like Clayslide. The group employs techniques such as DNS-based command and control, macro exploitation, and Base64 encoding. Attributed to Iran, APT34 primarily targets government, energy, telecommunications, and financial sectors in the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia and Israel, with a motivation focused on intelligence gathering through stealthy, long-term operations.[/profile]

Its key malware includes Bondupdater and the Helminth backdoor, and it employs spear-phishing with malicious macros (e.g., Clayslide) and DNS-based command and control. Its TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious Office document macros (e.g., Clayslide) and DNS-based command and control. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets government, financial, energy, and technology sectors in the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia, Israel, and Qatar, for intelligence gathering aligned with state interests.[/profile]

1436.name: %public%\libraries\tp\chr(xx)chr(yy).bat
1436.profile: [profile]The malware '%public%\\libraries\\tp\\chr(xx)chr(yy).bat' is a script-based threat. It is related to or delivered by Malicious Office Documents. Analysis of related entities indicates it may be associated with the Turla group, as code from the Kopiluwak malware is referenced. Its technical behavior involves creating a scheduled task named "GoogleUpdateTaskMachineUI" to execute a VBS script from the Public directory, a technique also used by the Helminth malware variant linked to APT34. The primary target platform is Windows.
1436.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware entity is a batch script file named '%public%\libraries\tp\chr(xx)chr(yy).bat'. It is a related file created by the malware vector known as Malicious Office Documents, which is used by groups including Fin7. This vector operates by embedding malicious macros within Microsoft Office Word documents to execute code, with the target platform being Windows systems running Microsoft Office.[profile]

1441.name: Helminth
1441.uncertain_mes: [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) is a backdoor that has at least two variants - one written in VBScript and PowerShell that is delivered via a macros in Excel spreadsheets, and one that is a standalone Windows executable. (Citation: Palo Alto OilRig May 2016)
1441.profile: [profile]Helminth, also known as Helminth Trojan, is a backdoor attributed to the OilRig (APT34) threat actor. It has at least two variants: one is a VBScript and PowerShell script delivered via Excel macro documents (Clayslide), and the other is a standalone Windows executable. Key behaviors include generating subdomains for command and control (C2) and using scripts like update.vbs and dns.ps1. Its primary target platform is Microsoft Windows.[profile]
1441.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Helminth, also known as the Helminth Trojan, is a backdoor malware attributed to the APT34 group (also known as OilRig). It exists in multiple variants including a Windows executable, a VBScript version, and a PowerShell script (dns.ps1). Key technical behaviors include command and control via HTTP and DNS queries, with a specific module for logging keystrokes and clipboard data. It is delivered via Clayslide documents and installed by the HerHer Trojan, which establishes persistence on Windows systems. Associated infrastructure includes domains like kernel.ws and mydomain1110.com.[/profile]

1442.name: Hancitor
1442.uncertain_mes:
HANCITOR: Analysing The Main Loader
This post is a follow up for my last one on HANCITOR. If you havenâ€™t checked it out, you can view it here.
In this post, weâ€™ll take a look at the main loader of this malware family, which is used for downloading and launching Cobalt Strike Beacon, information stealers, and malicious shellcode.
1442.profile: [profile]Hancitor, also known as HANCITOR, is a malware loader attributed to the intrusion set OilRig. Its key technical behavior is to download and launch secondary payloads, specifically Cobalt Strike Beacon, information stealers, and malicious shellcode. It operates on Windows platforms and uses command-and-control infrastructure with domains like kitezona[.]ru and mpressmedia[.]net for tasking and communication.
1442.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Hancitor, also known as HANCITOR, is a malware family primarily used as a loader to download and launch payloads such as Cobalt Strike Beacon, information stealers, and malicious shellcode. It has been associated with groups like Scully Spider and operates through command-and-control (C2) infrastructure using URLs for tasks, with examples including hxxp://kitezona[.]ru/wp-content/plugins/redirection/modules/1 and hxxp://xn--hllo-bpa[.]com/guestlist/1. Its technical behaviors involve unpacking and executing downloaded malicious components, targeting various platforms through these C2 communications.

1443.name: .hta file
1443.profile: [profile].hta file, also known as HTA file, is a script file format used by threat actors as a dropper or initial infection vector. It is attributed to groups including OilRig, UAC-0063, Gold Cabin (Mummy Spider, Mealybug), Hellsing, Ice Fog, Pirate Panda, Rancor, TA428, Tick, Tonto Team, and Karma Panda. Key technical behaviors involve executing embedded malicious script code to deploy further payloads like Downex or Emotet, with observed targets including entities related to PK Gov. The infrastructure involves the use of extension-less HTA files in campaigns.[/profile]
1443.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity is a .hta (HTML Application) file, a script-based file format used as a malware dropper or initial infection vector. It is associated with threat groups including UAC-0063, Gold Cabin (Mummy Spider/Mealybug), Hellsing, Ice Fog, Pirate Panda, Rancor, TA428, Tick, Tonto Team, and Karma Panda. It is employed in campaigns like Downex and Emotet, and by malware such as the 8.t dropper, to execute malicious scripts, often targeting entities like PK Gov.

1444.name: Microsoft Word document
1444.profile: [profile]Microsoft Word document is a file type commonly used as a lure or initial payload delivery mechanism by threat actors, including intrusion sets like OilRig. It is frequently associated with malware families such as Cring and Remcos, where malicious documents serve as droppers or contain embedded exploits. These documents often exhibit specific metadata attributes, including creation/modification timestamps, author fields, and embedded objects, which can be used to fingerprint campaigns. The primary target platform is Microsoft Windows systems running Office applications.[/profile]
1444.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Microsoft Word document" is a file type commonly exploited as a delivery mechanism for malware, as indicated by its association with malicious campaigns like those distributing the Remcos RAT, which is attributed to groups such as APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050. These campaigns utilize malicious Word documents with embedded macros or exploits to execute payloads, typically targeting Windows systems. The documents often contain specific metadata, such as creation dates and authoring software details, to appear legitimate and evade detection.

1445.name: Excel and Word files
1445.uncertain_mes:
Introduction
Zscalerâ€™s ThreatLabz threat research team recently has spotted a new variant of the emerging X-FILES infostealer attack with enhanced features to exfiltrate sensitive information. X-FILES is a stealer that aims to steal sensitive information, including logins and financial data.
1445.profile: [profile]The malware is known as X-FILES stealer, also referred to as Excel and Word files. It is attributed to the intrusion sets OilRig and Unknown_Threat_Actor. This infostealer is designed to exfiltrate sensitive information, including logins and financial data, from compromised systems. It primarily targets Windows platforms, leveraging malicious Excel and Word documents, often utilizing Excel 4.0 Macros, to deliver its payload. The malware's infrastructure involves the use of these document types as initial infection vectors to steal data.
1445.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Excel and Word files are file types commonly exploited as delivery vectors for malware. They are notably used by the Emotet malware, which heavily favors Excel files (93% of its malicious documents) over Word files (7%) due to compatibility with Excel 4.0 Macros. These file extensions are also targeted for encryption by ransomware like GandCrab and Filecoder. The associated threat groups include Gold Cabin, Mummy Spider, Mealybug (for Emotet), and Pinchy Spider (for GandCrab).

1446.name: 1.vbs
1446.profile: [profile]1.vbs is a VBScript-based malware. It is attributed to the OilRig intrusion set. Key technical behaviors include the use of VBScript file formats and execution via scripts, as indicated by strings like '$VBSRun ='. It is associated with or delivered by other malware families such as GuLoader and Pony. The target platform is Windows systems, leveraging the VBScript engine.[/profile]
1446.profile_without_enhance: [profile]1.vbs is a VBScript-based malware. It is associated with the GuLoader malware family and has been observed in the context of the Black Basta ransomware operation. Its technical behavior involves executing via VBScript, as indicated by code snippets like "[String] $VBSRun =". It is also linked to other malware families such as DCRAT and Pony, the latter of which is connected to the Cobalt group. The primary target platform is Windows systems, leveraging VBS file formats for execution.

1447.name: 0011.ps1
1447.uncertain_mes: [PS1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0613) is a loader that was used to deploy 64-bit backdoors in the [CostaRicto](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0132) campaign.(Citation: BlackBerry CostaRicto November 2020)
1447.profile: [profile]PS1, also known as 0011.ps1, is a PowerShell script loader attributed to the OilRig intrusion set and used in the CostaRicto campaign. Its key technical behavior is deploying 64-bit backdoors onto target systems. The malware is executed via PowerShell with a remote execution policy, as seen in commands like "powershell.exe -executionpolicy remotesigned -file dd.ps1". Its primary target platform is Windows.[/profile]
1447.profile_without_enhance: [profile]0011.ps1, also known as PS1, is a PowerShell script loader used to deploy 64-bit backdoors. It is associated with the CostaRicto campaign. Key technical behaviors include execution via PowerShell with a remote-signed execution policy, typically from a temporary user directory. Its target platform is Windows, leveraging the PowerShell environment for malicious payload delivery.](profile]

1448.name: dns1.ps1
1448.uncertain_mes: [PS1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0613) is a loader that was used to deploy 64-bit backdoors in the [CostaRicto](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0132) campaign.(Citation: BlackBerry CostaRicto November 2020)
1448.profile: [profile]PS1, also known as dns1.ps1, is a PowerShell loader malware. It is attributed to the APT groups OilRig and APT34, and was used in the CostaRicto campaign. Its key behaviors include deploying 64-bit backdoors, generating obfuscated variants (like Helminth) with randomized variable names to evade detection, and performing DNS tunneling operations for command and control. It targets Windows systems, typically installing scripts in the PublicLibrariesRecordedTV folder.
1448.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DNS1.PS1 is a PowerShell script and variant of the Helminth trojan, also associated with the RogueRobin malware family. It is attributed to the APT34 group. Its key technical behaviors include generating dynamic variants by replacing all variables and function names with random strings to evade detection, and it is installed in the PublicLibrariesRecordedTV folder. The malware performs DNS tunneling operations for command and control. Its target platform is Windows via PowerShell.

1449.name: dne1.ps1
1449.uncertain_mes: [PS1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0613) is a loader that was used to deploy 64-bit backdoors in the [CostaRicto](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0132) campaign.(Citation: BlackBerry CostaRicto November 2020)
1449.profile: [profile]DnE1.Ps1, also known as PS1, is a PowerShell loader malware attributed to the APT34 (OilRig) group. It is used to deploy 64-bit backdoors, specifically creating variants of the Helminth trojan by generating PowerShell and VBS file templates like DnS1.Ps1 and DnE1.Ps1 with randomized variable and function names to evade detection. The malware connects to a command and control server at vpsupdate[.]tk and installs scripts in the PublicLibrariesRecordedTV folder on infected Windows systems.
1449.profile_without_enhance: [profile]dne1.ps1, also known as DnE1.Ps1, is a PowerShell script attributed to APT34 (OilRig) and used in the Helminth campaign. It functions as a loader or template for the Helminth trojan, connecting to a C&C server at vpsupdate[.]tk and performing DNS queries. The script is regenerated on infected systems with randomized variable and function names to evade detection and is typically installed in the PublicLibrariesRecordedTV folder on Windows platforms.

1450.name: backup1.vbs
1450.profile: [profile]The malware entity is named backup1.vbs, which is a variant of the Helminth trojan. It is attributed to the APT34 (OilRig) intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include being a PowerShell or VBS script template that is regenerated on the infected computer with randomized variable and function names to evade detection, and it is typically installed in the PublicLibrariesRecordedTV folder. The target platform is Windows.
1450.profile_without_enhance: [profile]backup1.vbs is a VBScript file associated with the Helminth trojan, attributed to APT34. It is generated as a variant template by a PowerShell script, which regenerates these files on an infected system by randomizing all variable and function names to evade detection. The malware is installed in the PublicLibrariesRecordedTV folder.

1451.name: additional agent
1451.profile: [profile]Additional Agent is a malware tool attributed to the OilRig intrusion set. Its technical behaviors include functioning as a downloader and backdoor, with infrastructure connections indicated by the QUADAGENT hash 1f6369b42a76d02f32558912b57ede4f5ff0a90b18d3b96a4fe24120fa2c300c. It is associated with the APT34 group and shares operational context with the ISMAgent malware family.
1451.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Additional Agent is a malware entity with no directly attributed groups in the provided data. Its technical behavior includes using a file path indicator at 'c:\\program files (x86)\\microsoft idle\\'. It is contextually mentioned in relation to other entities: it is referenced as 'Core Agent' by the Evilnum group and as 'DoubleAgent Connection' by APT15 in the context of BadBazaar. The retrieved data also shows a similar entity named 'ati-agent' which is linked to APT 29, but no direct connection to Additional Agent is established here.

1452.name: bat script
1452.profile: [profile]Bat script is a generic file type often used as an initial loader or utility script by various threat groups. It is associated with groups including OilRig, APT33 (The Gorgon Group), UAC-0050, and ransomware operations like Black Basta (linked to groups such as GOLD REBELLION and UNC4393). Specific technical behaviors include its use by malware families like DbatLoader and Remcos for initial execution, and by Black Basta ransomware for Defender removal via scripts named ILUg69ql1.bat and others. It primarily targets the Windows platform.
1452.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bat script is a malware entity that serves as an initial loader or component for other malware families, including dbatloader, Black Basta ransomware, and Remcos. It is associated with multiple threat groups such as Gold Rebellion, STAC5143, Storm-0506, Storm-0826, TA2101, UNC3973, UNC4393, APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050. A key technical behavior involves the use of specific "Defender Removal Script" batch files to disable security software on Windows platforms.

1458.name: Fileless Attacks
1458.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may store data in "fileless" formats to conceal malicious activity from defenses. Fileless storage can be broadly defined as any format other than a file. Common examples of non-volatile fileless storage in Windows systems include the Windows Registry, event logs, or WMI repository.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)(Citation: SecureList Fileless) Shared memory directories on Linux systems (`/dev/shm`, `/run/shm`, `/var/run`, and `/var/lock`) and volatile directories on Network Devices (`/tmp` and `/volatile`) may also be considered fileless storage, as files written to these directories are mapped directly to RAM and not stored on the disk.(Citation: Elastic Binary Executed from Shared Memory Directory)(Citation: Akami Frog4Shell 2024)(Citation: Aquasec Muhstik Malware 2024)(Citation: Bitsight 7777 Botnet)(Citation: CISCO Nexus 900 Config).

Similar to fileless in-memory behaviors such as [Reflective Code Loading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1620) and [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055), fileless data storage may remain undetected by anti-virus and other endpoint security tools that can only access specific file formats from disk storage. Leveraging fileless storage may also allow adversaries to bypass the protections offered by read-only file systems in Linux.(Citation: Sysdig Fileless Malware 23022)

Adversaries may use fileless storage to conceal various types of stored data, including payloads/shellcode (potentially being used as part of [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003)) and collected data not yet exfiltrated from the victim (e.g., [Local Data Staging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1074/001)). Adversaries also often encrypt, encode, splice, or otherwise obfuscate this fileless data when stored. 

Some forms of fileless storage activity may indirectly create artifacts in the file system, but in central and otherwise difficult to inspect formats such as the WMI (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Wbem\Repository`) or Registry (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Config`) physical files.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)
1458.profile: [profile]Fileless Storage, identified as T1027.011, is a Defense Evasion technique used across Windows, Linux, and Network Device platforms. It involves storing data in non-file formats to evade detection, utilizing locations like the Windows Registry, WMI repository, event logs, or Linux shared memory directories (e.g., /dev/shm) where data is mapped to RAM. This method can bypass antivirus tools and read-only file system protections. Adversaries, including groups like APT32 and Turla, often use it to conceal payloads or staged data, which may be further obfuscated through encryption or encoding.
1458.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Fileless Attacks is a broad technique (not a specific MITRE ID) where adversaries execute malicious code without writing files to disk to evade detection. It operates across multiple tactics like Defense Evasion and Execution, primarily on Windows and Linux platforms. Technical mechanics involve leveraging system-native components like PowerShell, WMI, the Windows Registry, or COM objects to load and run payloads directly in memory. This approach bypasses traditional file-based antivirus scanning and can use shared memory directories on Linux or the Registry for non-volatile storage of payloads or data.

1459.name: Compromised Email Accounts
1459.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise email accounts that can be used during targeting. Adversaries can use compromised email accounts to further their operations, such as leveraging them to conduct [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598), [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566), or large-scale spam email campaigns. Utilizing an existing persona with a compromised email account may engender a level of trust in a potential victim if they have a relationship with, or knowledge of, the compromised persona. Compromised email accounts can also be used in the acquisition of infrastructure (ex: [Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583/001)).

A variety of methods exist for compromising email accounts, such as gathering credentials via [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598), purchasing credentials from third-party sites, brute forcing credentials (ex: password reuse from breach credential dumps), or paying employees, suppliers or business partners for access to credentials.(Citation: AnonHBGary)(Citation: Microsoft DEV-0537) Prior to compromising email accounts, adversaries may conduct Reconnaissance to inform decisions about which accounts to compromise to further their operation. Adversaries may target compromising well-known email accounts or domains from which malicious spam or [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) emails may evade reputation-based email filtering rules.

Adversaries can use a compromised email account to hijack existing email threads with targets of interest.
1459.profile: [profile]Compromised Email Accounts is a resource development technique (T1586.002) within the MITRE ATT&CK framework. Adversaries obtain email accounts through methods like credential phishing, purchasing, or brute-forcing reused passwords. These compromised accounts are then leveraged to conduct phishing campaigns, send spam, or hijack existing email threads, exploiting the inherent trust of the victim's established relationships to increase effectiveness and evade email filtering defenses. Associated threat groups include APT28, APT29, OilRig, and LAPSUS$.
1459.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Compromised Email Accounts, identified as T1586.002 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, falls under the Resource Development tactic and is applicable across multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries gaining unauthorized access to legitimate email accounts through methods such as credential phishing, purchasing from third-party sites, or brute-forcing using passwords from breach dumps. The compromised accounts are then weaponized to conduct phishing campaigns, send spam, hijack existing email threads to enhance social engineering, and can be used to acquire malicious infrastructure, leveraging the inherent trust associated with the legitimate persona.

1460.name: Macros
1460.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office templates to obtain persistence on a compromised system. Microsoft Office contains templates that are part of common Office applications and are used to customize styles. The base templates within the application are used each time an application starts. (Citation: Microsoft Change Normal Template) Office Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros (Citation: MSDN VBA in Office) can be inserted into the base template and used to execute code when the respective Office application starts in order to obtain persistence. Examples for both Word and Excel have been discovered and published. By default, Word has a Normal.dotm template created that can be modified to include a malicious macro. Excel does not have a template file created by default, but one can be added that will automatically be loaded.(Citation: enigma0x3 normal.dotm)(Citation: Hexacorn Office Template Macros) Shared templates may also be stored and pulled from remote locations.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) Word Normal.dotm location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\Normal.dotm Excel Personal.xlsb location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Excel\XLSTART\PERSONAL.XLSB Adversaries may also change the location of the base template to point to their own by hijacking the application's search order, e.g. Word 2016 will first look for Normal.dotm under C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\, or by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key. By modifying the GlobalDotName registry key an adversary can specify an arbitrary location, file name, and file extension to use for the template that will be loaded on application startup. To abuse GlobalDotName, adversaries may first need to register the template as a trusted document or place it in a trusted location.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) An adversary may need to enable macros to execute unrestricted depending on the system or enterprise security policy on use of macros.
1460.profile: [profile]Office Template Macros is the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1137.001 under the Persistence tactic, targeting Windows and Office 365. It involves inserting malicious VBA macros into base Office templates like Word's Normal.dotm or Excel's Personal.xlsb, which execute code when the respective application starts. Persistence can also be achieved by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key to point to a malicious template in a custom location, potentially requiring the template to be placed in a trusted location or registered as a trusted document to bypass macro security policies.
1460.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Macros" is a broad attack pattern often mapped to specific MITRE ATT&CK sub-techniques like T1137.001 (Office Template Macros) for Persistence on Windows. The technical mechanics involve embedding malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) code within Office documents or templates, such as Word's Normal.dotm or Excel's PERSONAL.XLSB, to execute arbitrary code when the application starts. Adversaries may need to enable macro execution or modify registry keys like GlobalDotName to load templates from arbitrary locations. Macros are also commonly delivered via spearphishing attachments as an alternative to exploitation for execution.

1461.name: OLE Embedding
1461.profile: [profile]OLE Embedding is a technique that leverages Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) for inter-process communication and execution. It is historically linked to the Windows Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) protocol, which can be abused to execute arbitrary commands by embedding malicious DDE commands within Microsoft Office documents or CSV files, often delivered via phishing to avoid using macros. This method can also be invoked remotely through services like DCOM. The technique is associated with threat actors such as OilRig and Iranian threat actors.[/profile]
1461.profile_without_enhance: [profile]OLE Embedding is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, specifically identified as T1559.002, under the Execution tactic for the Windows platform. It leverages Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) to embed malicious content, such as Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE) commands, within documents like Microsoft Office files or CSV files. This enables execution of arbitrary commands when the document is opened, often bypassing macro security and facilitating initial access through phishing campaigns.

1466.name: Exploit
1466.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to exploit a weakness in an Internet-facing host or system to initially access a network. The weakness in the system can be a software bug, a temporary glitch, or a misconfiguration.

Exploited applications are often websites/web servers, but can also include databases (like SQL), standard services (like SMB or SSH), network device administration and management protocols (like SNMP and Smart Install), and any other system with Internet-accessible open sockets.(Citation: NVD CVE-2016-6662)(Citation: CIS Multiple SMB Vulnerabilities)(Citation: US-CERT TA18-106A Network Infrastructure Devices 2018)(Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)(Citation: NVD CVE-2014-7169) On ESXi infrastructure, adversaries may exploit exposed OpenSLP services; they may alternatively exploit exposed VMware vCenter servers.(Citation: Recorded Future ESXiArgs Ransomware 2023)(Citation: Ars Technica VMWare Code Execution Vulnerability 2021) Depending on the flaw being exploited, this may also involve [Exploitation for Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1211) or [Exploitation for Client Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1203).

If an application is hosted on cloud-based infrastructure and/or is containerized, then exploiting it may lead to compromise of the underlying instance or container. This can allow an adversary a path to access the cloud or container APIs (e.g., via the [Cloud Instance Metadata API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1552/005)), exploit container host access via [Escape to Host](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1611), or take advantage of weak identity and access management policies.

Adversaries may also exploit edge network infrastructure and related appliances, specifically targeting devices that do not support robust host-based defenses.(Citation: Mandiant Fortinet Zero Day)(Citation: Wired Russia Cyberwar)

For websites and databases, the OWASP top 10 and CWE top 25 highlight the most common web-based vulnerabilities.(Citation: OWASP Top 10)(Citation: CWE top 25)
1466.profile: [profile]Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) is an Initial Access tactic targeting multiple platforms. It involves exploiting software bugs, glitches, or misconfigurations in internet-facing systems like web servers, databases (e.g., SQL), standard services (SMB, SSH), and network device protocols (SNMP, Smart Install) to gain initial network access. This can also target cloud instances, containers, and edge infrastructure lacking robust host defenses, potentially leading to further compromise via cloud APIs or container escape. The technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including OilRig, APT28, and Sandworm Team.
1466.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Exploit" is a foundational concept in cyber operations, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique with its own ID. It refers to the act of leveraging a software bug, vulnerability, or misconfiguration to cause unintended behavior, enabling initial access, privilege escalation, or defense evasion. Adversaries acquire exploits by purchasing, stealing, or developing them, targeting applications like web browsers, office software, or public-facing services. This core action underpins numerous specific techniques such as Exploit Public-Facing Application (T1190) and Exploitation for Client Execution (T1203).

1467.name: Evasion Mechanisms
1467.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers. Debuggers are typically used by defenders to trace and/or analyze the execution of potential malware payloads.(Citation: ProcessHacker Github) Debugger evasion may include changing behaviors based on the results of the checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a debugged environment. Similar to [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497), if the adversary detects a debugger, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for debugger artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary. On Windows, this may involve [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as IsDebuggerPresent() and NtQueryInformationProcess(), or manually checking the BeingDebugged flag of the Process Environment Block (PEB). On Linux, this may involve querying `/proc/self/status` for the `TracerPID` field, which indicates whether or not the process is being traced by dynamic analysis tools.(Citation: Cado Security P2PInfect 2023)(Citation: Positive Technologies Hellhounds 2023) Other checks for debugging artifacts may also seek to enumerate hardware breakpoints, interrupt assembly opcodes, time checks, or measurements if exceptions are raised in the current process (assuming a present debugger would â€œswallowâ€ or handle the potential error).(Citation: hasherezade debug)(Citation: AlKhaser Debug)(Citation: vxunderground debug) Malware may also leverage Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to detect debuggers by throwing an exception and detecting whether the process is suspended. SEH handles both hardware and software expectations, providing control over the exceptions including support for debugging. If a debugger is present, the programâ€™s control will be transferred to the debugger, and the execution of the code will be suspended. If the debugger is not present, control will be transferred to the SEH handler, which will automatically handle the exception and allow the programâ€™s execution to continue.(Citation: Apriorit) Adversaries may use the information learned from these debugger checks during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors. Debuggers can also be evaded by detaching the process or flooding debug logs with meaningless data via messages produced by looping [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as OutputDebugStringW().(Citation: wardle evilquest partii)(Citation: Checkpoint Dridex Jan 2021)
1467.profile: [profile]The entity is Debugger Evasion, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1622 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows and Linux platforms. It involves detecting analysis tools to alter malicious behavior. Specific technical mechanics include checking for debugger artifacts via Windows API calls like IsDebuggerPresent() or querying the Linux /proc/self/status file, leveraging Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to test for process suspension, and evading detection by flooding logs with OutputDebugStringW() calls. The intrusion-set OilRig is associated with this technique.
1467.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Evasion Mechanisms is a broad defensive tactic where adversaries employ various methods to avoid detection and analysis. This includes techniques like Debugger Evasion (T1622), which checks for debugging artifacts using API calls like IsDebuggerPresent() or examining the Process Environment Block, and Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion (T1497), which detects virtual environments by checking for system artifacts or using sleep timers. Other related methods involve exploiting vulnerabilities in security software (T1211) or abusing features like Image File Execution Options injection (T1183) to disable security tools. The primary platform is Windows, though Linux methods like checking /proc/self/status are also used.

1470.name: Iranian threat actor
1470.uncertain_mes: [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) is a Chinese threat group that has extensively used strategic Web compromises to target victims.(Citation: Dell TG-3390) The group has been active since at least 2010 and has targeted organizations in the aerospace, government, defense, technology, energy, manufacturing and gambling/betting sectors.(Citation: SecureWorks BRONZE UNION June 2017)(Citation: Securelist LuckyMouse June 2018)(Citation: Trend Micro DRBControl February 2020)
1470.profile: [profile]The entity is primarily known as Threat Group-3390, also referred to as Iranian threat actor, silverfish, silent librarian, and malkamak. This group is believed to be an Iranian state-sponsored actor, with investigations suggesting possible connections to other Iranian APTs like Chafer (APT39) and Agrius. Its arsenal and key TTPs include the use of strategic web compromises for initial access. The group's victimology primarily targets sectors such as aerospace, government, defense, technology, energy, manufacturing, and gambling/betting, indicating a broad intelligence-gathering and disruptive motivation aligned with Iranian strategic interests.
1470.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This Iranian threat actor is likely associated with or part of the APT34 (OilRig) group, also known as Helminth. It employs custom malware like the Helminth backdoor, delivered via exploits such as CVE-2017-0199 and techniques like OLE embedding in phishing campaigns, and uses tools like Mimikatz for credential access. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets entities in the Middle East and other regions of strategic interest to Iran, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Iranian state-sponsored group known as APT39 (also known as Chafer). It is attributed to Iran and has been linked to or shares overlaps with other Iranian actors such as Agrius APT, MalKamak, and clusters tracked as Silent Librarian, Mabna Institute, and TA407. The group's operations, which date back to at least 2018, have primarily targeted sectors including telecommunications, travel, and IT services across the Middle East and other regions, with motivations centered on cyber espionage and information theft to support Iranian state interests.
1470.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Iranian state-sponsored threat actor known as MalKamak, also referred to as Silverfish. This group is known for its custom malware and has been active since at least 2018. It shows operational overlaps with other Iranian APTs like Chafer (APT39) and Agrius. Its primary motivation is believed to be cyber espionage, aligning with broader Iranian state objectives, though specific target sectors and regions are not detailed in the provided data.
1470.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]This intrusion set is an Iranian state-sponsored threat actor, potentially linked to or overlapping with groups like APT34 (OilRig) and APT39 (Chafer). It is also known by aliases such as SilverFish and MalKamak. Its key malware includes the Helminth backdoor, delivered via documents exploiting vulnerabilities like CVE-2017-0199, and it utilizes tools like Mimikatz for credential access. A core technique is OLE Embedding (T1559.002) for initial execution via malicious documents. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets sectors and regions of strategic interest to the Iranian state, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_20_no_hsage: [profile]This Iranian threat actor is believed to be APT34 (OilRig), also known as Helminth. Its key malware includes the custom Helminth backdoor, delivered via exploits like CVE-2017-0199 and CVE-2014-4114, and it utilizes tools like Mimikatz for credential theft. Core TTPs involve OLE embedding in malicious documents for initial execution. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets sectors such as government, energy, and telecommunications in the Middle East and globally, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft to support Iranian state interests.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_15_no_hsage: [profile]This intrusion set is most likely the Iranian state-sponsored APT group APT34 (OilRig). It is also known by aliases including Helminth and potentially has overlaps with groups like Chafer (APT39) and Agrius. Its key malware includes the custom Helminth backdoor, delivered via exploits like CVE-2017-0199 and CVE-2014-4114, and it utilizes tools like Mimikatz for credential access. Key TTPs involve OLE embedding in malicious documents for initial execution. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets sectors and regions of strategic interest to the Iranian state, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_15: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Iranian state-sponsored APT group known as APT34 (OilRig). Common aliases include Helminth, associated with its custom backdoor malware. Key malware and tools include the Helminth Trojan, delivered via Clayslide documents, and credential theft tools like Mimikatz. Key TTPs involve exploiting vulnerabilities such as CVE-2017-0199 and using OLE Embedding in malicious documents for initial access. The group is attributed to Iran. It primarily targets sectors and regions of strategic interest to Iran, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft. The actor shows possible connections to other Iranian groups like Chafer APT (APT39) and Agrius APT.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_10_no_hsage: [profile]This Iranian threat actor is most likely associated with the APT34 (OilRig) group, also known as Helminth. It employs custom malware such as the Helminth Trojan and credential theft tools like Mimikatz. Key TTPs include exploiting vulnerabilities like CVE-2017-0199 and using OLE embedding in malicious documents for initial access. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets sectors of strategic interest to the Iranian state, with a motivation focused on espionage and data theft. It shows possible connections to other Iranian APT groups like Chafer (APT39) and Agrius.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_5: [profile]This Iranian threat actor is most likely associated with the APT34 (OilRig) group, also known as Helminth. Its key malware includes the Helminth backdoor, delivered via Clayslide documents, and the credential theft tool Mimikatz. Key TTPs involve exploiting vulnerabilities like CVE-2017-0199 and using OLE Embedding in malicious documents for initial access. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets sectors and regions of strategic interest to the Iranian state, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft. It shows possible connections to other Iranian actors like APT39 (Chafer) and the group MalKamak.[/profile]
