Common aliases include Helminth, based on its key malware. Its primary tools are the custom Helminth backdoor, delivered via exploits like CVE-2017-0199 and CVE-2014-4114, and the credential theft tool Mimikatz for lateral movement. Key TTPs include the use of OLE embedding in malicious documents for initial execution. The group is definitively attributed to Iran. Target sectors and regions are not specified in the provided data, but its motivation is consistent with Iranian cyber-espionage objectives. The actor shows possible connections to other Iranian groups like Chafer APT (APT39) and the newly reported MalKamak.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_1: [profile]This intrusion set is likely the Iranian state-sponsored group APT34, also known as OilRig, Helix Kitten, and Cobalt Gypsy. It is attributed to Iran and is known for using custom malware like the Helminth backdoor, which is delivered via malicious documents exploiting vulnerabilities such as CVE-2014-4114 and using OLE embedding techniques. The group primarily targets sectors including government, energy, and telecommunications across the Middle East and other regions, with motivations centered on espionage and data theft to support Iranian state interests.[/profile]
1470.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set is broadly attributed to Iranian state-sponsored cyber operations, also known by aliases such as Silverfish, Silent Librarian (which overlaps with groups like Mabna Institute, TA4900, and TA407), and MalKamak. It employs tools like Mimikatz for credential theft and lateral movement, and leverages exploits such as CVE-2017-0199 via techniques like OLE Embedding (T1559.002) in phishing documents for initial access. Its operations are believed to target various sectors and regions, with motivations aligned with Iranian strategic interests, including espionage and disruptive activities. The group shows possible connections to other Iranian APTs like Chafer (APT39) and Agrius.

1476.name: Bondupdater
1476.uncertain_mes: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). It was first observed in November 2017 during targeting of a Middle Eastern government organization, and an updated version was observed in August 2018 being used to target a government organization with spearphishing emails.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig Sep 2018)
1476.profile: [profile]Bondupdater, also known as BONDUPDATER, is a PowerShell backdoor attributed to the OilRig APT group (also known as APT34). It was first observed in November 2017 targeting a Middle Eastern government organization, with an updated version seen in August 2018 via spearphishing. Its key behaviors include command and control communication, with infrastructure such as the domain withyourface[.]com identified. Associated dropper and updated variant hashes include d5c1822a36f2e7107d0d4c005c26978d00bcb34a587bd9ccf11ae7761ec73fb7 and 7cbad6b3f505a199d6766a86b41ed23786bbb99dab9cae6c18936afdc2512f00. It primarily targets Windows platforms via PowerShell execution.[/profile]
1476.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bondupdater, also known as apppool.vbs, is a VBScript malware attributed to the APT groups OilRig and APT34. It is executed via a macro, establishes persistence by creating a scheduled task that runs every minute, and is dropped to and run from the directory C:\ProgramData\WindowsAppPool\. Its key behaviors include command execution, file upload/download, and DNS tunneling for command and control, with observed infrastructure including the domain withyourface[.]com. The primary target platform is Windows.

1479.name: Macro Exploitation
1479.profile: [profile]Macro Exploitation is a client execution technique where adversaries embed malicious macros within documents, such as Microsoft Word files, to execute arbitrary code when the file is opened by the user. This method is commonly delivered via phishing and exploits the trust in legitimate office applications. The intrusion set OilRig and malware like Bondupdater have been associated with this technique, which operates on Windows and potentially macOS platforms as part of the initial access or execution tactics.[/profile]
1479.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Macro Exploitation is a technique where adversaries embed malicious macros within documents, such as Microsoft Office files, to execute code when the user opens the file and enables macros. This method falls under the Execution tactic, primarily targeting Windows and macOS platforms. The technical mechanics involve crafting documents with embedded VBA (Visual Basic for Applications) scripts that download and run payloads, often delivered via phishing. It is a common vector for initial access, leveraging social engineering to bypass defenses by exploiting the trust in common document formats.

1484.name: Microsoft Word Document
1484.profile: [profile]Microsoft Word Document is a legitimate file format used by Microsoft Office Word, often exploited as a delivery vector for malware. It is referenced in the context of the Remcos malware, which uses .doc files with metadata indicating creation/modification dates (e.g., 2022:04:20) and specific attributes like 'Microsoft Word 97-2003 Document'. These malicious documents are associated with groups such as APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050. The file type is also listed among targeted extensions (like .doc and .docx) in operations linked to the Cring ransomware, indicating its use in initial infection chains for data theft and encryption attacks primarily on Windows systems.
1484.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Microsoft Word Document is a file format used as a delivery vector for malware, notably through Macro Exploitation where embedded VBA scripts execute malicious code when macros are enabled. It is associated with campaigns distributing malware like Remcos, which is attributed to groups including APT33, The Gorgon Group, and UAC-0050. Key technical behaviors involve leveraging social engineering via phishing to gain initial access, with the document often containing crafted metadata and targeting Windows systems. The format is commonly used to deliver payloads that download and run additional malware.

1485.name: File-based Command Handling
1485.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may employ various time-based methods to detect virtualization and analysis environments, particularly those that attempt to manipulate time mechanisms to simulate longer elapses of time. This may include enumerating time-based properties, such as uptime or the system clock. 

Adversaries may use calls like `GetTickCount` and `GetSystemTimeAsFileTime` to discover if they are operating within a virtual machine or sandbox, or may be able to identify a sandbox accelerating time by sampling and calculating the expected value for an environment's timestamp before and after execution of a sleep function.(Citation: ISACA Malware Tricks)
1485.profile: [profile]File-based Command Handling is a technique where adversaries execute commands by reading and processing instructions from a file, often to bypass command-line monitoring. This method involves writing commands to a temporary file and then using a command interpreter to execute the file's contents, separating the malicious intent from the initial execution command. It is associated with malware like Bondupdater and apppool.ps1.
1485.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File-based Command Handling, designated as T1153 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework under the Execution tactic for Linux and macOS platforms, is a technique where adversaries abuse the `source` command (or `.` command) to load and execute files directly within the current shell context. This method allows execution of scripts without requiring the file to have executable permissions, effectively bypassing that restriction. The technique has been deprecated in the ATT&CK framework.

1486.name: apppool.vbs
1486.profile: [profile]AppPool.vbs is a VBScript malware, also known as Bondupdater, attributed to the APT groups OilRig and APT34. Its key behavior involves being dropped and executed by a malicious macro, specifically via the command "wscript C:\\ProgramData\\WindowsAppPool\\AppPool.vbs", to facilitate further malicious activity on Windows platforms.
1486.profile_without_enhance: [profile]apppool.vbs is a VBScript malware, also known as AppPool.vbs, attributed to the APT groups OilRig and APT34. It is executed by the Bondupdater dropper, which places it at C:\ProgramData\WindowsAppPool\AppPool.vbs. A key technical behavior is creating a scheduled task to execute every minute for persistence, as the malware lacks a main execution loop. Its target platform is Windows.[/profile]

1490.name: apppool.ps1
1490.profile: [profile]The malware 'apppool.ps1' is a PowerShell script, with a known instance located at C:\ProgramData\WindowsAppPool\AppPool.ps1. It is associated with the APT groups OilRig and APT34, and is used by the Bondupdater malware. Its technical behavior involves the use of PowerShell commands for execution and potentially leverages utilities like Invoke-WebRequest, set-MpPreference, add-MpPreference, certutil, and bitsadmin for malicious activities, indicating capabilities for downloading payloads and manipulating security settings. The primary target platform is Windows.
1490.profile_without_enhance: [profile]apppool.ps1, also referenced as AppPool.ps1, is a PowerShell script attributed to the APT groups OilRig and APT34. It is deployed via malicious macros and executed through scheduled tasks, using commands like `PowerShell.exe -exec bypass -file C:\ProgramData\WindowsAppPool\AppPool.ps1`. Its technical behavior involves file-based command handling for execution and utilizes indicators such as specific PowerShell process IDs and lock files. The malware targets Windows platforms, with its primary infrastructure involving the file path C:\ProgramData\WindowsAppPool\.

1495.name: Quadagent
1495.uncertain_mes: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). (Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)
1495.profile: [profile]Quadagent is a PowerShell backdoor attributed to the OilRig group (also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, or Greenbug). It is used for backdoor access and command execution on Windows systems, with infrastructure identified through specific file hashes like 1f6369b42a76d02f32558912b57ede4f5ff0a90b18d3b96a4fe24120fa2c300c.[/profile]
1495.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Quadagent, also known as QUADAGENT, is a malware attributed to the APT groups APT34 (also called Helix Kitten, OilRig, or Greenbug). Key technical behaviors include payload persistence, potentially through mechanisms like Office Application Startup, and the use of associated indicators such as the 'office365dcomcheck.ps1' script and VBScript files. Its target sectors are Information Technology, Government, Military, Energy and Power, Communication, Transportation, Financial Services, and the Educational System.[/profile]

1496.name: invoke-obfuscation
1496.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may obfuscate command and control traffic to make it more difficult to detect.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020) Command and control (C2) communications are hidden (but not necessarily encrypted) in an attempt to make the content more difficult to discover or decipher and to make the communication less conspicuous and hide commands from being seen. This encompasses many methods, such as adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, or impersonating legitimate protocols.
1496.profile: [profile]The entity is a tool named Invoke-Obfuscation, which is a specific implementation used for Command Obfuscation (T1027.010) under the Defense Evasion tactic. It operates primarily on the Windows platform. This PowerShell framework is employed by adversaries to obfuscate commands and scripts, making them difficult to detect and analyze through signature-based methods. The tool is notably associated with groups like OilRig and is referenced in the context of broader obfuscation techniques for command execution.
1496.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Invoke-Obfuscation is a specific tool used for command obfuscation, a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027.010) under the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily for Windows. It is a PowerShell framework that employs various methods to make scripts and commands harder to detect and analyze, such as string splitting, encoding, and the insertion of special characters to evade signature-based security controls. The tool has been utilized by multiple threat groups including FIN7, Wizard Spider, and MuddyWater.

1497.name: Helix Kitty
1497.profile: [profile]Helix Kitty is an intrusion set with a suspected connection to the OilRig group. It is also known as APT32, OceanLotus, SeaLotus, APT-C-00, and Cobalt Kitty, based on its association with Operation Cobalt Kitty, a large-scale cyber espionage campaign that targeted a global corporation in Asia to steal proprietary business information. The group is attributed to the OceanLotus Group and is believed to conduct espionage for strategic intelligence gathering.
1497.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group APT34, also known as OilRig, Helix Kitten, and Helix Kitty. Its key custom malware includes the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. Key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious documents like Clayslide, DNS-based command and control, and the use of obfuscation tools like Invoke-Obfuscation. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets government organizations, financial institutions, and the energy and technology sectors in the Middle East, especially Israel, Saudi Arabia, and Qatar, for intelligence gathering aligned with state interests.[/profile]
1497.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set "Helix Kitty" is believed to be a reference to or a campaign by the APT group known as APT32, also commonly identified as OceanLotus, SeaLotus, and APT-C-00. This group is attributed to Vietnam and is known for conducting cyber espionage operations, such as the campaign "Operation Cobalt Kitty," which targeted a global corporation in Asia to steal proprietary business information. Its key tools and TTPs include custom malware and a focus on intelligence gathering, primarily targeting sectors in Southeast Asia and beyond, with motivations centered on economic and strategic espionage.
1497.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set "Helix Kitty" is most likely a reference to or an alias of the APT group widely known as APT32, also known as OceanLotus, SeaLotus, and Cobalt Kitty. This group is attributed to Vietnam and is known for conducting cyber espionage campaigns, such as Operation Cobalt Kitty, which targeted a global corporation in Asia to steal proprietary business information. Its key tools and TTPs include custom malware and a focus on intelligence gathering, primarily targeting sectors in Southeast Asia and beyond with a motivation of state-sponsored espionage.
1497.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]The Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group APT34, also known as OilRig, Helix Kitty, Helix Kitten, Cobalt Gypsy, and Europiu, is characterized by its use of custom malware like the Helminth backdoor, Bondupdater, and Quadagent. Its key TTPs involve spear-phishing with malicious macros in Office documents (e.g., Clayslide) and DNS-based command and control. The group is attributed to Iran and primarily targets government, financial, energy, and technology sectors in the Middle East, especially Saudi Arabia, Israel, and Qatar, for intelligence gathering aligned with state interests.[/profile]

Note: 'Helix Kitty' should not be confused with unrelated groups like APT32 (OceanLotus, Cobalt Kitty) or the ransomware group HelloKitty (Gookie).[/profile]

1498.name: Microsoft .NET Framework-based dropper
1498.uncertain_mes: Lightning Framework is a new undetected Swiss Army Knife-like Linux malware that has modular plugins and the ability to install rootkits.
1498.profile: [profile]The malware is a Microsoft .NET Framework-based dropper, also known as Lightning Framework. It is attributed to the OilRig intrusion set. Its key technical behaviors include acting as a modular, Swiss Army Knife-like malware for Linux with the ability to install rootkits and utilize plugins. The target platform is Linux. Infrastructure or supplementary details are not specified in the provided data.
1498.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Microsoft .NET Framework-based dropper is a first-stage dropper malware. It is referenced in the context of other malware like ATTOR, PXA Stealer, and Jimmy, where it serves as an initial deployment component. Its technical behaviors involve using archive files for initial delivery. The target platform is systems running the Microsoft .NET Framework. Supplementary information includes the use of cryptographic keys and XOR ciphers in related contexts.

1502.name: PE file generated via bat2exe tool
1502.uncertain_mes:
Royal APT - APT15 - Related Information from NCC Group Cyber Defense Operations Research
Among the tools developed by the group for the victim, APT15 created a .net tool to enumerate the victim's sharepoint database. Below is an screen-shot from the decompiled binary.
Decoder scripts for BS2005 and RoyalCLI samples found by NCC Group can be found in the scripts directory.
bs_decoder.py
1502.profile: [profile]PE file generated via bat2exe tool, also known as ms exchange tool, is attributed to the OilRig intrusion set. Its key technical behavior involves being a .NET tool used to enumerate a victim's SharePoint database. The target platform is Windows, as indicated by the PE file format and its development for enumerating Microsoft SharePoint. Infrastructure or supplementary information includes the use of decoder scripts for related samples like BS2005 and RoyalCLI.[/profile]
1502.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PE file generated via bat2exe tool, also known as a PE file without PE signatures, is associated with groups including APT22, APT26, APT31, APT41, Aurora Panda, Calypso Group, DragonOK, Emissary Panda, Hellsing, Hurricane Panda, Leviathan, Mirage, Mustang Panda, Nettraveler, Nightshade Panda, Slime29, Samurai Panda, Stone Panda, UPS, and Violin Panda. Its key technical behavior involves being a 32-bit executable file developed in Microsoft Visual C#. The target platform is Windows, and it is delivered via spear phishing emails impersonating legitimate entities like a US engineering licensing board.

1504.name: script-based backdoors
1504.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may employ various time-based methods to detect virtualization and analysis environments, particularly those that attempt to manipulate time mechanisms to simulate longer elapses of time. This may include enumerating time-based properties, such as uptime or the system clock. 

Adversaries may use calls like `GetTickCount` and `GetSystemTimeAsFileTime` to discover if they are operating within a virtual machine or sandbox, or may be able to identify a sandbox accelerating time by sampling and calculating the expected value for an environment's timestamp before and after execution of a sleep function.(Citation: ISACA Malware Tricks)
1504.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Time Based Checks" (T1497.003) under the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily for Windows platforms. It involves adversaries using time-based system calls like GetTickCount and GetSystemTimeAsFileTime to detect virtual machine or sandbox environments by measuring discrepancies in system uptime or clock speed, particularly to identify if a sandbox is accelerating time to simulate longer execution periods. The intrusion set OilRig has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1504.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Script-based backdoors is a technique where adversaries use scripting languages like JavaScript, JScript, or JXA to create persistent, hidden access points on a compromised system. These backdoors function by executing malicious scripts that can be embedded in various files or delivered via web shells, allowing remote command execution and data exfiltration. The technique is platform-agnostic, affecting Windows, macOS, and web servers, and is commonly associated with groups like Cobalt Group and APT32.

1505.name: malicious macro document
1505.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may rely upon a user opening a malicious file in order to gain execution. Users may be subjected to social engineering to get them to open a file that will lead to code execution. This user action will typically be observed as follow-on behavior from [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001). Adversaries may use several types of files that require a user to execute them, including .doc, .pdf, .xls, .rtf, .scr, .exe, .lnk, .pif, .cpl, .reg, and .iso.(Citation: Mandiant Trojanized Windows 10)

Adversaries may employ various forms of [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) and [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027) to increase the likelihood that a user will open and successfully execute a malicious file. These methods may include using a familiar naming convention and/or password protecting the file and supplying instructions to a user on how to open it.(Citation: Password Protected Word Docs) 

While [Malicious File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002) frequently occurs shortly after Initial Access it may occur at other phases of an intrusion, such as when an adversary places a file in a shared directory or on a user's desktop hoping that a user will click on it. This activity may also be seen shortly after [Internal Spearphishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1534).
1505.profile: [profile]Malicious File (T1204.002) is an Execution technique where adversaries rely on a user opening a malicious file to gain code execution. Common file types include .doc, .pdf, .xls, .rtf, .scr, .exe, .lnk, and .iso. Adversaries increase success by employing Masquerading and Obfuscated Files, such as using familiar naming conventions or password-protecting files with instructions. This technique often follows Spearphishing Attachment (T1566.001) but can also occur later, such as when a file is placed in a shared directory. It is used by numerous threat groups, including OilRig, APT28, and Lazarus Group.
1505.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "malicious macro document" is a technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework under ID T1204.002, categorized under the Execution tactic and applicable to Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. It involves adversaries delivering documents (e.g., .doc, .pdf, .xls) containing malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros that execute when a user opens the file, often following social engineering lures like spearphishing. Attackers may employ obfuscation methods such as VBA stomping, where malicious p-code is preserved while source code is overwritten with benign data to evade detection. This technique is commonly used by numerous threat groups, including APT29, FIN7, and Lazarus Group, to gain initial code execution on a victim's system.

1507.name: spear-phishing email
1507.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
1507.profile: [profile]Spear-phishing email is a targeted social engineering technique (MITRE ATT&CK ID T1566.001) used in the Initial Access tactic, primarily against Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. It involves sending tailored emails to specific individuals or organizations, often containing malicious attachments or embedded links that require user interaction to execute code. Adversaries employ evasive methods like email spoofing, thread hijacking, and manipulating email headers or metadata from compromised accounts to enhance credibility and bypass defenses. The technique is distinct from general phishing due to its precise targeting. The intrusion set OilRig has been associated with this method.[/profile]
1507.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-phishing email is a targeted social engineering technique (T1566.001) under the Initial Access tactic, primarily targeting Windows, macOS, and Linux. It involves sending deceptive emails to specific individuals or organizations to deliver malicious payloads. This is executed by attaching malicious files (like documents or executables) or embedding links to malicious sites, often using social engineering pretexts to trick the user into opening the attachment or clicking the link, leading to code execution.

1508.name: credential theft
1508.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may steal monetary resources from targets through extortion, social engineering, technical theft, or other methods aimed at their own financial gain at the expense of the availability of these resources for victims. Financial theft is the ultimate objective of several popular campaign types including extortion by ransomware,(Citation: FBI-ransomware) business email compromise (BEC) and fraud,(Citation: FBI-BEC) "pig butchering,"(Citation: wired-pig butchering) bank hacking,(Citation: DOJ-DPRK Heist) and exploiting cryptocurrency networks.(Citation: BBC-Ronin) 

Adversaries may [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586) to conduct unauthorized transfers of funds.(Citation: Internet crime report 2022) In the case of business email compromise or email fraud, an adversary may utilize [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656) of a trusted entity. Once the social engineering is successful, victims can be deceived into sending money to financial accounts controlled by an adversary.(Citation: FBI-BEC) This creates the potential for multiple victims (i.e., compromised accounts as well as the ultimate monetary loss) in incidents involving financial theft.(Citation: VEC)

Extortion by ransomware may occur, for example, when an adversary demands payment from a victim after [Data Encrypted for Impact](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486) (Citation: NYT-Colonial) and [Exfiltration](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0010) of data, followed by threatening to leak sensitive data to the public unless payment is made to the adversary.(Citation: Mandiant-leaks) Adversaries may use dedicated leak sites to distribute victim data.(Citation: Crowdstrike-leaks)

Due to the potentially immense business impact of financial theft, an adversary may abuse the possibility of financial theft and seeking monetary gain to divert attention from their true goals such as [Data Destruction](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485) and business disruption.(Citation: AP-NotPetya)
1508.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Financial Theft, ID T1657, under the Impact tactic. It targets any platform where adversaries can steal monetary resources. This is achieved through methods like extortion via ransomware, business email compromise (BEC) fraud, "pig butchering," bank hacking, and cryptocurrency exploitation. Adversaries may compromise accounts to conduct unauthorized fund transfers, use impersonation in social engineering to deceive victims into sending money, or operate dedicated leak sites to threaten data exposure for ransom. Groups like FIN13, Scattered Spider, and Storm-0501 have been associated with this objective.
1508.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Credential Theft is a technique adversaries use to steal account login and credential material, such as passwords or hashes, to gain unauthorized access. This aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1110 (Brute Force) under the Credential Access tactic, primarily targeting Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. Technical mechanics involve extracting credentials from OS memory, caches, or structures using tools like Mimikatz, or through methods like dumping the LSASS process. Stolen credentials enable lateral movement and privilege escalation, as seen in related techniques like OS Credential Dumping (T1003).

1509.name: bat2exe
1509.profile: [profile]Bat2exe is a tool used to convert batch scripts into executable files. It is employed by the intrusion set OilRig and has been utilized to compile downloader malware, such as one designed to deploy the Havoc Demon Agent, which executes a generated batch file to create hidden accounts on victim systems. Its primary target is the Windows platform, facilitating the delivery of other payloads.
1509.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Bat2exe is a tool used to convert batch scripts into executable files. It is utilized by malware such as a downloader for the Havoc Demon Agent, which is packaged as a screen saver file named "character.scr". This tool is also employed to create malware that generates and runs batch files upon execution.

1510.name: payloadâ€™s persistence
1510.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may clear artifacts associated with previously established persistence on a host system to remove evidence of their activity. This may involve various actions, such as removing services, deleting executables, [Modify Registry](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112), [Plist File Modification](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1647), or other methods of cleanup to prevent defenders from collecting evidence of their persistent presence.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm) Adversaries may also delete accounts previously created to maintain persistence (i.e. [Create Account](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1136)).(Citation: Talos - Cisco Attack 2022)

In some instances, artifacts of persistence may also be removed once an adversaryâ€™s persistence is executed in order to prevent errors with the new instance of the malware.(Citation: NCC Group Team9 June 2020)
1510.profile: [profile]The technique is officially known as Clear Persistence with the MITRE ATT&CK ID T1070.009, falling under the Defense Evasion tactic and applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries removing artifacts from previously established persistence mechanisms to eliminate evidence of their activity. Specific technical actions include deleting services or executables, modifying the Windows Registry or macOS Plist files, and removing created user accounts. This cleanup is performed to hinder forensic collection or to prevent errors when deploying new malware instances, as observed with malware like Quadagent.[/profile]
1510.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "payloadâ€™s persistence" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is a general concept referring to the methods adversaries use to maintain long-term access on a compromised host. Related techniques include Office Application Startup (T1137), which abuses features like Outlook rules or add-ins to execute code when Office applications launch, and Add-ins (T1137.006), which specifically uses Office add-in libraries for this purpose. The concept is also associated with the defensive action of clearing these artifacts (T1070.009) to remove evidence.[/profile]

1514.name: systemdiskclean.ps1
1514.profile: [profile]systemdiskclean.ps1 is a PowerShell script attributed to the OilRig intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is the COMMAND_DESTROY_DISK command, which manually opens and writes zeros to the first 512 bytes of each drive to delete the Master Boot Record (MBR). This disk-wiping functionality is a technique also associated with malware families like deadwood and apostle, the latter being linked to Pink Sandstorm. The script targets Windows systems by performing destructive operations on system and user directories.[/profile]
1514.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Name: systemdiskclean.ps1. It is associated with disk destruction commands, specifically the 'COMMAND_DESTROY_DISK' function which writes zeros to the first 512 bytes of a drive to delete the Master Boot Record (MBR). This behavior is shared with or referenced by other malware entities named 'deadwood' and 'apostle'. The 'apostle' malware is linked to the threat group Pink Sandstorm.

1516.name: VBScript file
1516.profile: [profile]VBScript file is a scripting file format used for malicious payloads. It is associated with the intrusion-set OilRig. In related operations, it is used by the Gamaredon Group and Operation Armageddon as a PteroLNK downloader payload. It is also utilized by the Cobalt group in Pony malware samples and by an unknown group in the CSharp-Streamer RAT, where it is executed via wscript.exe from a malicious MSI installer.
1516.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VBScript file is a generic file type used by various malware families. It is employed by the Gamaredon Group (Operation Armageddon) in the PteroLNK downloader payload, which drops files like '~.drv' and uses paths such as '%PUBLIC%\NTUSER.DAT.TMContainer00000000000000000001.regtrans-ms'. It is also utilized by the Cobalt group in the Pony malware and by unknown actors in the CSharp-Streamer RAT, where a malicious VBScript is copied to a variable subdirectory and executed via wscript.exe.

1517.name: malicious macros
1517.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office templates to obtain persistence on a compromised system. Microsoft Office contains templates that are part of common Office applications and are used to customize styles. The base templates within the application are used each time an application starts. (Citation: Microsoft Change Normal Template) Office Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros (Citation: MSDN VBA in Office) can be inserted into the base template and used to execute code when the respective Office application starts in order to obtain persistence. Examples for both Word and Excel have been discovered and published. By default, Word has a Normal.dotm template created that can be modified to include a malicious macro. Excel does not have a template file created by default, but one can be added that will automatically be loaded.(Citation: enigma0x3 normal.dotm)(Citation: Hexacorn Office Template Macros) Shared templates may also be stored and pulled from remote locations.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) Word Normal.dotm location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\Normal.dotm Excel Personal.xlsb location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Excel\XLSTART\PERSONAL.XLSB Adversaries may also change the location of the base template to point to their own by hijacking the application's search order, e.g. Word 2016 will first look for Normal.dotm under C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\, or by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key. By modifying the GlobalDotName registry key an adversary can specify an arbitrary location, file name, and file extension to use for the template that will be loaded on application startup. To abuse GlobalDotName, adversaries may first need to register the template as a trusted document or place it in a trusted location.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) An adversary may need to enable macros to execute unrestricted depending on the system or enterprise security policy on use of macros.
1517.profile: [profile]Office Template Macros, identified as T1137.001 under the Persistence tactic, targets Windows and Microsoft Office. This technique involves inserting malicious VBA macros into base Office templates, such as Word's Normal.dotm or Excel's Personal.xlsb, to execute code automatically when the respective application starts. Adversaries can modify the default template file locations or hijack the application's search order, including altering the GlobalDotName registry key to load a template from a remote or arbitrary location. The group MuddyWater has been associated with this method, which may require enabling macros depending on security policies.[profile]
1517.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malicious Macros, corresponding to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1204.002 (User Execution: Malicious File), is an Initial Access and Execution tactic primarily targeting the Windows platform. It involves adversaries embedding malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) code within Microsoft Office documents (e.g., .doc, .xls) to gain execution when a user is socially engineered into opening the file and enabling macros. The malicious payload is executed by the Office application's scripting engine, often bypassing static analysis through techniques like VBA Stomping, which hides the malicious compiled p-code.

1518.name: Word Delivery
1518.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to make payloads difficult to discover and analyze by delivering files to victims as uncompiled code. Text-based source code files may subvert analysis and scrutiny from protections targeting executables/binaries. These payloads will need to be compiled before execution; typically via native utilities such as ilasm.exe(Citation: ATTACK IQ), csc.exe, or GCC/MinGW.(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)

Source code payloads may also be encrypted, encoded, and/or embedded within other files, such as those delivered as a [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566). Payloads may also be delivered in formats unrecognizable and inherently benign to the native OS (ex: EXEs on macOS/Linux) before later being (re)compiled into a proper executable binary with a bundled compiler and execution framework.(Citation: TrendMicro WindowsAppMac)
1518.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Obfuscated Files or Information: Compile After Delivery (T1027.004) under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves delivering payloads as uncompiled source code (e.g., C#, C++) to evade detection by security tools targeting binaries, requiring on-target compilation using native utilities like csc.exe, ilasm.exe, or GCC. Payloads may be further hidden through encryption, encoding, or embedding within other files like phishing attachments. The intrusion set OilRig has been associated with this technique.
1518.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Word Delivery is a technique where adversaries deliver malicious payloads to victims as uncompiled source code files, such as text-based scripts, to evade detection by security tools that target executable binaries. These payloads require compilation on the victim's system using native utilities like csc.exe or GCC before execution. The method is often used in phishing campaigns and may involve embedding or encrypting the code within other files to further avoid analysis.

1520.name: decoy image
1520.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may rely on a user running a malicious image to facilitate execution. Amazon Web Services (AWS) Amazon Machine Images (AMIs), Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Images, and Azure Images as well as popular container runtimes such as Docker can be backdoored. Backdoored images may be uploaded to a public repository via [Upload Malware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1608/001), and users may then download and deploy an instance or container from the image without realizing the image is malicious, thus bypassing techniques that specifically achieve Initial Access. This can lead to the execution of malicious code, such as code that executes cryptocurrency mining, in the instance or container.(Citation: Summit Route Malicious AMIs)

Adversaries may also name images a certain way to increase the chance of users mistakenly deploying an instance or container from the image (ex: [Match Legitimate Resource Name or Location](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036/005)).(Citation: Aqua Security Cloud Native Threat Report June 2021)
1520.profile: [profile]The entity is a technique known as Malicious Image, with the MITRE ATT&CK ID T1204.003 under the Execution tactic, targeting Cloud and Container platforms. It involves adversaries uploading backdoored Amazon Machine Images (AMIs), Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Images, Azure Images, or Docker container images to public repositories. Users unknowingly download and deploy these images, which can execute malicious code like cryptocurrency miners, bypassing initial access controls. Adversaries may also use deceptive image naming to increase the chance of mistaken deployment. The intrusion set OilRig has been associated with this technique.
1520.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "decoy image" is not a formally defined MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it is a concept related to cloud and container security where adversaries create or modify system images (e.g., AWS AMIs, Docker containers) to appear legitimate. This technique can be used to establish persistence (as in Implant Internal Image, T1525) or to trick users into executing malicious code (as in Malicious Image, T1204.003). The core mechanic involves uploading or implanting a backdoored image, often using deceptive naming to mimic trusted resources, which then executes adversary code when deployed.

1521.name: random case + {} + ticks
1521.profile: [profile]The entity "random case + {} + ticks" is a command and control obfuscation technique. It operates by adding random or meaningless junk data, such as appending, prepending, or inserting characters, to C2 protocol traffic to hinder trivial detection and analysis methods. This behavior is associated with the intrusion set OilRig.[/profile]
1521.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity name "random case + {} + ticks" does not map to a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to be a specific obfuscation method for command and control (C2) traffic, potentially a sub-technique of Data Obfuscation (T1001). The technical mechanic involves inserting random characters, such as junk data or ticks, into protocol fields to hinder detection and analysis by breaking simple pattern matching. This technique is associated with groups like APT28.

1522.name: reorder
1522.profile: [profile]The entity "reorder" is a technique used by adversaries like the intrusion set OilRig. It involves hijacking the search order used by programs to load other executables. When a program calls another without specifying its full path, an adversary can place a malicious file with the same name in the calling program's directory, causing the operating system to execute the adversary's payload instead of the intended legitimate program. This method exploits the order in which Windows searches for executables, similar to DLL search order hijacking.
1522.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'reorder' is a technique for search order hijacking, identified as MITRE ATT&CK T1574.008 under the Defense Evasion tactic, targeting Windows platforms. It exploits how Windows searches for executables when a program calls another without specifying its full path. An adversary places a malicious executable with the same name as the target program in the directory of the calling program, causing the OS to execute the malicious file first. This is distinct from DLL search order hijacking and can be influenced by the PATHEXT environment variable order, where extensions like .com may be prioritized over .exe.

1524.name: reused tools in multiple attacks
1524.profile: [profile]The entity "reused tools in multiple attacks" is a general adversarial behavior where legitimate or malicious tools are employed across different intrusion campaigns. This practice is exemplified by the intrusion set OilRig, which utilizes tools like remote access software for command and control and lateral movement. The behavior involves staging tools on accessible infrastructure, such as web servers or cloud services, to facilitate ingress tool transfer. Its primary function is to enable efficient and redundant access to compromised networks while potentially evading detection by blending in with normal administrative traffic.[/profile]
1524.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "reused tools in multiple attacks" is a technique where adversaries employ legitimate or previously deployed software across different campaigns to blend in with normal activity, enabling command and control, lateral movement, or other malicious actions. This practice, often called "living off the land," leverages tools like remote access software, deployment systems, or administration utilities that are already trusted within a target environment. By reusing these tools, adversaries can avoid detection that might be triggered by deploying unique malware and can efficiently scale their operations across multiple targets or attacks.

1525.name: additional obfuscation
1525.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may obfuscate command and control traffic to make it more difficult to detect.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020) Command and control (C2) communications are hidden (but not necessarily encrypted) in an attempt to make the content more difficult to discover or decipher and to make the communication less conspicuous and hide commands from being seen. This encompasses many methods, such as adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, or impersonating legitimate protocols.
1525.profile: [profile]Data Obfuscation, also known as T1001, is a Command and Control tactic used across multiple platforms. It involves hiding C2 communications to evade detection by adding junk data to protocol traffic, using steganography, or impersonating legitimate protocols. This technique is not encryption but aims to make traffic less conspicuous and commands harder to decipher, as observed in campaigns involving groups like Gamaredon.[/profile]
1525.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "additional obfuscation" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it is a general concept referring to the adversarial practice of applying extra layers of obfuscation to files, data, or commands to evade detection. This can involve techniques like adding junk data to network traffic, using steganography, encoding commands with base64, employing string splitting, or utilizing tools such as Invoke-Obfuscation to hide malicious intent within otherwise normal-looking data or protocols.

1526.name: infrastructure changes
1526.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate network traffic in order to hide and evade detection of their C2 infrastructure. This can be accomplished by identifying and filtering traffic from defensive tools,(Citation: TA571) masking malicious domains to obfuscate the true destination from both automated scanning tools and security researchers,(Citation: Schema-abuse)(Citation: Facad1ng)(Citation: Browser-updates) and otherwise hiding malicious artifacts to delay discovery and prolong the effectiveness of adversary infrastructure that could otherwise be identified, blocked, or taken down entirely.

C2 networks may include the use of [Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090) or VPNs to disguise IP addresses, which can allow adversaries to blend in with normal network traffic and bypass conditional access policies or anti-abuse protections. For example, an adversary may use a virtual private cloud to spoof their IP address to closer align with a victim's IP address ranges. This may also bypass security measures relying on geolocation of the source IP address.(Citation: sysdig)(Citation: Orange Residential Proxies)

Adversaries may also attempt to filter network traffic in order to evade defensive tools in numerous ways, including blocking/redirecting common incident responder or security appliance user agents.(Citation: mod_rewrite)(Citation: SocGholish-update) Filtering traffic based on IP and geo-fencing may also avoid automated sandboxing or researcher activity (i.e., [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497)).(Citation: TA571)(Citation: mod_rewrite)

Hiding C2 infrastructure may also be supported by [Resource Development](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0042) activities such as [Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583) and [Compromise Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584). For example, using widely trusted hosting services or domains such as prominent URL shortening providers or marketing services for C2 networks may enable adversaries to present benign content that later redirects victims to malicious web pages or infrastructure once specific conditions are met.(Citation: StarBlizzard)(Citation: QR-cofense)
1526.profile: [profile]Hide Infrastructure, identified as T1665 under the Resource Development tactic, involves manipulating network traffic to conceal command and control (C2) infrastructure. Technical mechanics include using proxies or VPNs to disguise IP addresses, filtering traffic to block defensive tool user agents or specific IP ranges, and masking malicious domains through techniques like schema abuse or facading to obfuscate the true destination. This activity is often supported by related techniques such as Acquire Infrastructure (T1583) and Compromise Infrastructure (T1584).[/profile]
1526.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Infrastructure Changes" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to adversary actions to modify, provision, or revert infrastructure components to support operations and evade detection. This can involve altering cloud compute instances, virtual machines, or snapshots to bypass defenses or remove forensic evidence, as seen in techniques like Modify Cloud Compute Infrastructure (T1578) and Revert Cloud Instance (T1578.004). The activity is associated with cloud platforms and supports the Defense Evasion tactic.

1527.name: repackaging
1527.profile: [profile]The entity "repackaging" is a technique for evading detection by modifying legitimate software packages to include malicious components, often used by groups like OilRig. It involves altering the original installer or application bundle to embed malware, which is then distributed through compromised or spoofed software sources. This method exploits trust in authentic software to bypass security checks and facilitate initial access or persistence.
1527.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "repackaging" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved information, it is closely related to the technique Software Packing (T1027.002), which involves compressing or encrypting executables to change their file signatures and evade signature-based detection. This is often done using packers like MPRESS or UPX, or through custom packing methods and virtual machine software protection to conceal malicious code.

1528.name: Quadagent payload
1528.uncertain_mes: [QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). (Citation: Unit 42 QUADAGENT July 2018)
1528.profile: [profile]Quadagent, also known as QUADAGENT, is a PowerShell backdoor attributed to the OilRig group (also known as APT34, Helix Kitten, and Greenbug). It targets various sectors including Information Technology, Government, Military, Energy, Communications, Transportation, Financial Services, and Education. The malware is associated with other payloads like Alma Communicator, Bondupdater, and Ismagent, which share its infrastructure and attribution.
1528.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Quadagent payload is a malware associated with the APT34 (also known as Helix Kitten, OilRig, or Greenbug) cybercriminal group. It uses DNS tunneling for command and control, encapsulating malicious communications within DNS protocol traffic to bypass network security. Its infrastructure includes the domain rdppath[.]com. The malware targets sectors such as Information Technology, Government, Military, Energy, Communications, Transportation, Financial Services, and Education.

1529.name: PE file
1529.profile: [profile]PE file is a file format used by Windows executables, often serving as a container for malware payloads. It is notably associated with the PlugX malware family, where it functions as the decompressed payload format, sometimes lacking standard PE signatures. The format is also referenced in Cobalt Strike detection rules as a condition for identifying small, potentially malicious executables. It is linked to malware like a decoy dialog box and is utilized by numerous threat groups including APT22, APT26, APT31, APT41, Mustang Panda, and Leviathan.[/profile]
1529.profile_without_enhance: [profile]PE file is a generic file format used as a container for executable code, serving as a common delivery vector for malware. It is used to deliver components like the Decoy Dialog Box technique associated with the Helminth Trojan and AMOS malware. The format is referenced in descriptions of specific malware families like PlugX, which uses LZ compression and may or may not include PE signatures in its payloads, and Cobalt Strike beacons, which are often distributed as small PE files. It is a foundational target platform for Windows-based malicious payloads across numerous threat groups including APT34, APT29, and Mustang Panda.

1530.name: decoy dialog box
1530.uncertain_mes:
BOtB is a container analysis and exploitation tool designed to be used by pentesters and engineers while also being CI/CD friendly with common CI/CD technologies.
BOtB is a CLI tool which allows you to:
- Exploit common container vulnerabilities
- Perform common container post exploitation actions
- Provide capability when certain tools or binaries are not available in the Container
1530.profile: [profile]Decoy Dialog Box, also known as Break Out the Box (BOtB), is a CLI-based container analysis and exploitation tool used by pentesters and engineers, designed to exploit container vulnerabilities and perform post-exploitation actions. It is delivered via PE files. Related malware campaigns, such as Helminth attributed to APT34, use decoy dialog boxes, like HTML help dialogs, as a deception tactic during installation. Similarly, the AMOS malware employs a fake dialog box in an infinite loop to phish for user credentials. The tool provides capabilities when standard binaries are unavailable in a container environment.[/profile]
1530.profile_without_enhance: [profile]decoy dialog box is a malware tactic involving a deceptive user interface element, such as a fake error message box, to mislead victims. It is associated with malware families like Helminth, used by APT34, where it appears as an HTML help dialog to mask Trojan installation. The technique is also seen in other malware, like amos, which uses a dialog box in an infinite loop to phish for system credentials. This malware primarily targets Windows systems, leveraging PE file formats as its executable container.[/profile]

1531.name: DNS tunnel
1531.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may communicate using the Domain Name System (DNS) application layer protocol to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server. 

The DNS protocol serves an administrative function in computer networking and thus may be very common in environments. DNS traffic may also be allowed even before network authentication is completed. DNS packets contain many fields and headers in which data can be concealed. Often known as DNS tunneling, adversaries may abuse DNS to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network while also mimicking normal, expected traffic.(Citation: PAN DNS Tunneling)(Citation: Medium DnsTunneling)

DNS beaconing may be used to send commands to remote systems via DNS queries. A DNS beacon is created by tunneling DNS traffic (i.e.â€¯[Protocol Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572)). The commands may be embedded into different DNS records, for example, TXT or A records.(Citation: OilRig Uses Updated BONDUPDATER to Target Middle Eastern Government) DNS beacons may be difficult to detect because the beacons infrequently communicate with infected devices.(Citation: DNS Beacons) Infrequent communication conceals the malicious DNS traffic with normal DNS traffic.
1531.profile: [profile]DNS tunnel, also known as Application Layer Protocol: DNS (T1071.004), is a Command and Control tactic used across multiple platforms. It works by embedding adversary commands and data within DNS protocol traffic to blend with normal administrative traffic and bypass network filtering. Data is concealed within various DNS record fields, such as TXT or A records, often using infrequent beaconing to further evade detection. This technique is frequently implemented through protocol tunneling and is associated with groups like OilRig and APT41.[/profile]
1531.profile_without_enhance: [profile]DNS tunnel is a command and control technique (T1071.004) under the Command and Control tactic, operating across multiple platforms. It works by encapsulating and concealing malicious communications within DNS protocol traffic, often embedding commands and data in DNS query and response fields like TXT or A records to bypass network security controls. This tunneling method mimics normal DNS activity to avoid detection.

1532.name: Clayslide
1532.profile: [profile]Clayslide, also known as Helminth, is a malware attributed to the OilRig intrusion set. It is delivered via documents, such as the "New Clayslide Delivery Document," and establishes persistence by creating a Windows registry key for automatic execution on system startup. The malware also performs monitoring of specific applications on the infected system.[/profile]
1532.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Clayslide is a delivery document used by the Helminth backdoor malware, which is attributed to the OilRig (APT34) intrusion set. Its key technical behavior is serving as a delivery mechanism for Helminth, which generates subdomains for command and control. The malware targets the Windows platform.[/profile]

1533.name: VBScript
1533.profile: [profile]VBScript is a default scripting language on Windows, classified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.005 (Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic). It is primarily used for Execution. Adversaries use VBScript to automate malicious commands, often embedding it in spearphishing attachments or HTML Application (HTA) webpages. It can be invoked via tools like Windows Management Instrumentation (wmic) with the /FORMAT switch to execute code from XSL files, a method known as "Squiblytwo," to bypass application controls. The intrusion set OilRig is known to utilize this technique.[/profile]
1533.profile_without_enhance: [profile]VBScript is a default scripting language on Windows, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.005 under Execution. It is used to automate malicious tasks, often embedded in documents like Spearphishing Attachments or HTML Applications (HTAs) for Internet Explorer. Adversaries leverage it to bypass defenses by directly interacting with the OS, and it can be invoked via tools like Windows Management Instrumentation (wmic) with the /FORMAT switch to execute code from XSL files.

1534.name: Excel spreadsheet macro
1534.profile: [profile]Excel spreadsheet macro is a technique used for persistence and execution, often associated with the OilRig intrusion-set. It involves inserting malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros into Excel template files, such as a Personal.xlsb file stored at C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Excel\XLSTART\, which automatically executes code when Excel starts. This method can bypass security policies that restrict macros and is a common vector in phishing campaigns.
1534.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Excel spreadsheet macro is a technique for persistence and execution, mapped to MITRE ATT&CK ID T1137.002 under the Persistence tactic, primarily targeting Windows. It works by embedding malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros into Excel templates, such as the Personal.xlsb file stored at C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Excel\XLSTART\, which automatically loads and executes the macro code when Excel starts. This method can bypass security policies if macros are enabled.

1535.name: DNS queries
1535.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may communicate using the Domain Name System (DNS) application layer protocol to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server. 

The DNS protocol serves an administrative function in computer networking and thus may be very common in environments. DNS traffic may also be allowed even before network authentication is completed. DNS packets contain many fields and headers in which data can be concealed. Often known as DNS tunneling, adversaries may abuse DNS to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network while also mimicking normal, expected traffic.(Citation: PAN DNS Tunneling)(Citation: Medium DnsTunneling)

DNS beaconing may be used to send commands to remote systems via DNS queries. A DNS beacon is created by tunneling DNS traffic (i.e.â€¯[Protocol Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572)). The commands may be embedded into different DNS records, for example, TXT or A records.(Citation: OilRig Uses Updated BONDUPDATER to Target Middle Eastern Government) DNS beacons may be difficult to detect because the beacons infrequently communicate with infected devices.(Citation: DNS Beacons) Infrequent communication conceals the malicious DNS traffic with normal DNS traffic.
1535.profile: [profile]Application Layer Protocol: DNS (T1071.004) is a Command and Control tactic used across multiple platforms. It involves embedding commands and exfiltrated data within standard DNS protocol traffic, such as in TXT or A records, to blend with normal administrative traffic and bypass network filtering. This technique, often implemented as DNS tunneling or infrequent beaconing, is associated with groups like OilRig, APT41, and FIN7.
1535.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "DNS queries" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved information, it is a general reconnaissance activity where adversaries query DNS servers to gather targeting information. This can involve directly querying nameservers or using passive DNS repositories to collect details like registered name servers, subdomain records (A, MX, TXT, SPF), and mail server addresses. A specific method includes performing a DNS zone transfer (query type AXFR) to extract all records from a misconfigured server, revealing internal network information.

1536.name: network beacon
1536.profile: [profile]Network Beacon is a Command and Control technique where malware establishes periodic, often covert, communication with an adversary's server. It functions by sending regular, low-profile signals (beacons) to receive commands or exfiltrate data. A specific implementation involves DNS beaconing, which tunnels traffic through DNS queries (using TXT or A records) to blend with normal network activity and evade detection. This technique is associated with groups like OilRig.[/profile]
1536.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "network beacon" is a technique within the Command and Control tactic, where adversaries establish a covert communication channel with compromised systems. It operates by sending periodic, low-volume signals (beacons) from the infected host to an adversary-controlled server, often using common protocols like HTTP(S) or DNS to blend with legitimate traffic. This beaconing allows the adversary to maintain persistence, receive commands, and exfiltrate data while evading detection through infrequent, seemingly normal network requests.

1537.name: clipboard logging
1537.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may collect data stored in the clipboard from users copying information within or between applications. For example, on Windows adversaries can access clipboard data by using clip.exe or Get-Clipboard.(Citation: MSDN Clipboard)(Citation: clip_win_server)(Citation: CISA_AA21_200B) Additionally, adversaries may monitor then replace usersâ€™ clipboard with their data (e.g., [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002)).(Citation: mining_ruby_reversinglabs) macOS and Linux also have commands, such as pbpaste, to grab clipboard contents.(Citation: Operating with EmPyre)
1537.profile: [profile]Clipboard Data, designated as T1115, is a Collection technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework applicable to Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. It involves adversaries harvesting information users copy to the clipboard, using native commands like `clip.exe` or `Get-Clipboard` on Windows and `pbpaste` on macOS/Linux. This method can also be used to monitor and replace clipboard contents for data manipulation. It has been associated with threat groups including APT38, APT39, and OilRig.
1537.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Clipboard Logging, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1115 under the Collection tactic, operates on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries collecting data users copy within or between applications. On Windows, this is achieved using utilities like `clip.exe` or PowerShell's `Get-Clipboard`, while on macOS and Linux, commands such as `pbpaste` are used to capture clipboard contents.

1538.profile: [profile]DNS-based C2 behavior, identified as T1071.004, is a Command and Control technique under the Application Layer Protocol tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves embedding commands and exfiltrated data within DNS protocol traffic, often using DNS tunneling and beaconing through fields like TXT or A records to blend with normal administrative traffic and evade network filtering. Associated groups include OilRig, APT41, and FIN7.

Adversaries may run their own DNS servers to gain more control over the C2 channel, configure conditional responses, and use methods like DNS calculation to dynamically determine C2 ports or IP addresses from DNS results to bypass network filtering.
