The group employs techniques like using wildcard extensions for defense evasion. It primarily targets law firms and other entities in Southeast Asia for intellectual property theft and strategic intelligence gathering, with infrastructure leveraging services like smtp.outlookssl.com. The group shows overlaps with clusters like Toxic Panda, Numbered Panda, Pitty Panda, and Foxy Panda.
1700.profile_without_enhance_1_no_hsage: [profile]Deep Panda is a Chinese state-sponsored APT group, also known as Shell Crew, WebMasters, KungFu Kittens, and Black Vine. It is attributed to China and believed to be linked to the People's Liberation Army (PLA). The group primarily targets sectors such as government, defense, and financial services in the United States and other Western nations, with motivations centered on espionage and intellectual property theft. Its key tools include the custom backdoor 'Poison Ivy' and the 'NETE' malware, and it employs TTPs like executing payloads directly from memory to evade detection. The group shows overlaps with other clusters like APT19 and is associated with infrastructure such as the domain 'some.trouble'.

1707.name: policy information gathering
1707.profile: [profile]The entity "policy information gathering" is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries collect information about system and domain policies to understand security configurations and identify attack paths. This aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Discovery. Technical mechanics involve querying policy settings, such as using commands like `gpresult` or PowerShell functions like `Get-DomainGPO` to extract Group Policy details from network paths like `\\<DOMAIN>\SYSVOL\<DOMAIN>\Policies\`. This information can reveal privilege escalation opportunities and inform subsequent malicious activities, such as policy modification. The intrusion set Deep Panda has been associated with this behavior.[/profile]
1707.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Policy Information Gathering is a reconnaissance technique (Tactic: Reconnaissance) used to collect details about security policies, such as password or Group Policy settings, within a target environment. Adversaries may use commands like `net accounts`, `gpresult`, or `Get-ADDefaultDomainPasswordPolicy` to discover policy configurations, which helps shape follow-on attacks like privilege escalation or credential access by understanding enforced security rules.

1708.name: command line
1708.profile: [profile]The entity "command line" is a core component of adversary tradecraft, primarily associated with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Command and Scripting Interpreter (T1059). It is a platform-agnostic technique used across the Execution tactic, enabling adversaries to run commands and scripts directly on a system. Technical mechanics involve using native interpreters like cmd.exe, PowerShell, sh, or bash to execute payloads, perform discovery, and move laterally. The intrusion-set Deep Panda is a known user of this method. Supplementary information indicates that adversaries often chain command-line usage with obfuscation (T1027.010) to evade detection and may interact with or clear command history files (T1070.003, T1552.003) to cover their tracks.
1708.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "command line" is a foundational concept for adversary execution, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It refers to the use of command-line interfaces (CLIs) and interpreters like cmd, PowerShell, or bash to execute directives on a system. This method is central to the MITRE technique Command and Scripting Interpreter (T1059) and is a platform-agnostic mechanism for direct system control. Adversaries leverage the command line to run native utilities or delivered payloads for activities such as discovery, lateral movement, and data exfiltration, often employing obfuscation (T1027.010) to evade detection.

1709.name: Deep Panda command and control (C2) infrastructure

1710.name: base64 encoded
1710.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may encrypt or encode files to obfuscate strings, bytes, and other specific patterns to impede detection. Encrypting and/or encoding file content aims to conceal malicious artifacts within a file used in an intrusion. Many other techniques, such as [Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), [Steganography](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003), and [Embedded Payloads](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/009), share this same broad objective. Encrypting and/or encoding files could lead to a lapse in detection of static signatures, only for this malicious content to be revealed (i.e., [Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140)) at the time of execution/use.

This type of file obfuscation can be applied to many file artifacts present on victim hosts, such as malware log/configuration and payload files.(Citation: File obfuscation) Files can be encrypted with a hardcoded or user-supplied key, as well as otherwise obfuscated using standard encoding schemes such as Base64.

The entire content of a file may be obfuscated, or just specific functions or values (such as C2 addresses). Encryption and encoding may also be applied in redundant layers for additional protection.

For example, adversaries may abuse password-protected Word documents or self-extracting (SFX) archives as a method of encrypting/encoding a file such as a [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) payload. These files typically function by attaching the intended archived content to a decompressor stub that is executed when the file is invoked (e.g., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: SFX - Encrypted/Encoded File) 

Adversaries may also abuse file-specific as well as custom encoding schemes. For example, Byte Order Mark (BOM) headers in text files may be abused to manipulate and obfuscate file content until [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) execution.
1710.profile: [profile]Encrypted/Encoded File, identified as T1027.013, is a Defense Evasion technique. It involves obfuscating file content using methods like Base64 encoding or encryption with a hardcoded key to conceal malicious artifacts such as C2 addresses or payloads, thereby evading static signature detection. This can be applied to entire files or specific values and is often layered for additional protection, for example through password-protected documents or self-extracting archives. The technique is associated with numerous threat groups including Lazarus Group and APT28.
1710.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Base64 encoded is a sub-technique of T1027 (Obfuscated Files or Information), specifically T1027.001, under the Defense Evasion tactic. It operates across multiple platforms, including Windows, Linux, and macOS. The technique involves using the Base64 binary-to-text encoding scheme to obfuscate strings, bytes, and other patterns within files or network traffic to impede static signature detection. It is commonly applied to payloads, configuration files, and command and control data, and is frequently used by groups like Lazarus, APT28, and OilRig.

1711.name: wafer
1711.profile: [profile]Wafer is a malware entity associated with the intrusion set Deep Panda. It is linked to the use of stolen code signing certificates, which appear to be taken from a solar and semiconductor grinding wafer products manufacturer in Northwest China, and an expired certificate. Detections for related components include Trojan.Win32.SelfDel.ehlq, Trojan.Win32.Agent.ikad, and Trojan.Win32.Agentb.btlt, indicating behaviors like self-deletion and agent functionality. The primary target platform is Windows.[/profile]
1711.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware known as 'Wafer' is a Windows-based threat, specifically a Trojan detected as Trojan.Win32.SelfDel.ehlq, Trojan.Win32.Agent.ikad, and Trojan.Win32.Agentb.btlt. Its operation involves the use of stolen code signing certificates, which were illicitly obtained from a solar and semiconductor grinding wafer products manufacturer in Northwest China, as well as an expired certificate. This activity is associated with the Lazarus Group.

1712.name: madhatter
1712.profile: [profile]Madhatter is a malware attributed to the Deep Panda intrusion set. It is known for creating a registry key to ensure automatic execution upon system startup, monitoring specific applications, and engaging in characteristic network interactions for command and control or data exfiltration. Its primary target platform is the Windows operating system.[/profile]
1712.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware known as 'madhatter' is a malicious entity. Its specific aliases, attributed groups, key technical behaviors, and target platforms could not be definitively determined from the provided information. The retrieved data references other distinct malware families like 'buterat', 'cmoon', and 'latentbot', but does not contain specific, verifiable context about 'madhatter' itself, its infrastructure, or its supplementary operational details.

1713.name: running them from memory
1713.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may attempt to access credential material stored in the process memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS). After a user logs on, the system generates and stores a variety of credential materials in LSASS process memory. These credential materials can be harvested by an administrative user or SYSTEM and used to conduct [Lateral Movement](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008) using [Use Alternate Authentication Material](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550). As well as in-memory techniques, the LSASS process memory can be dumped from the target host and analyzed on a local system. For example, on the target host use procdump: * procdump -ma lsass.exe lsass_dump Locally, mimikatz can be run using: * sekurlsa::Minidump lsassdump.dmp * sekurlsa::logonPasswords Built-in Windows tools such as `comsvcs.dll` can also be used: * rundll32.exe C:\Windows\System32\comsvcs.dll MiniDump PID lsass.dmp full(Citation: Volexity Exchange Marauder March 2021)(Citation: Symantec Attacks Against Government Sector) Similar to [Image File Execution Options Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/012), the silent process exit mechanism can be abused to create a memory dump of `lsass.exe` through Windows Error Reporting (`WerFault.exe`).(Citation: Deep Instinct LSASS) Windows Security Support Provider (SSP) DLLs are loaded into LSASS process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) The following SSPs can be used to access credentials: * Msv: Interactive logons, batch logons, and service logons are done through the MSV authentication package. * Wdigest: The Digest Authentication protocol is designed for use with Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) and Simple Authentication Security Layer (SASL) exchanges.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection) * Kerberos: Preferred for mutual client-server domain authentication in Windows 2000 and later. * CredSSP: Provides SSO and Network Level Authentication for Remote Desktop Services.(Citation: TechNet Blogs Credential Protection)
1713.profile: [profile]The entity "LSASS Memory" is mapped to MITRE ATT&CK technique T1003.001 under the Credential Access tactic for Windows platforms. It involves accessing credential material stored in the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) process memory after user logon. Technical mechanics include dumping LSASS memory using tools like procdump (`procdump -ma lsass.exe`), Mimikatz (`sekurlsa::Minidump`), or built-in Windows utilities like `comsvcs.dll` via `rundll32.exe`. Adversaries can also abuse the silent process exit mechanism or modify Security Support Provider (SSP) Registry keys to load malicious DLLs for credential harvesting. This technique is associated with numerous threat groups, including APT28, APT41, and MuddyWater.
1713.profile_without_enhance: [profile]This entity, "running them from memory," is a technique for executing malicious code directly from a system's memory to evade file-based detection. It is a sub-technique of Process Injection, T1055, under the Privilege Escalation and Defense Evasion tactics, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS. The core technical mechanic involves writing a payload into a target process's address space using APIs like `WriteProcessMemory` and then triggering execution via functions such as `CreateRemoteThread`, allowing the code to run under the guise of a legitimate process. This method avoids writing malicious files to disk and can bypass security controls like data execution prevention (DEP).

1714.name: webshells
1714.profile: [profile]WebShells are a category of malicious scripts used for remote access to compromised web servers. They are frequently employed by groups like Deep Panda, Gallium, APT39, APT41, and Hafnium. Common variants include Godzilla, ASPXSpy, AntSword, and China Chopper. These tools are deployed on web servers to establish backdoors, enabling file management, command execution, and data exfiltration.
1714.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Webshells are a category of malicious scripts used for remote access and control of compromised web servers. Common examples include Godzilla, ASPXSpy, AntSword, and China Chopper. The ASPXSpy variant has been associated with groups like APT39, APT41, and Hafnium, while the Reshell backdoor is linked to Gallium. These tools are deployed on web servers to establish persistent access, execute commands, and exfiltrate data.

1715.name: reconnaissance commands
1715.profile: [profile]The entity "reconnaissance commands" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it appears to be a general concept for using command-line utilities to gather information, which aligns with techniques like T1083 (File and Directory Discovery). This technique, under the Discovery tactic, involves using native shell commands such as `dir`, `tree`, `ls`, `find`, and `locate` to enumerate files and directories on a host or network share. The intrusion set Deep Panda is associated with this entity, and the technique is widely used by numerous threat groups including APT41, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.[/profile]
1715.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "reconnaissance commands" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to the use of command-line utilities for information gathering, which is a component of several techniques. For example, File and Directory Discovery (T1083) uses commands like dir, tree, ls, find, and locate to enumerate file systems. Similarly, network device CLIs may use commands such as dir, show flash, or nvram for discovery. This activity is a technical sub-procedure within broader reconnaissance and discovery tactics, employed by numerous threat groups including APT28, MuddyWater, and Lazarus Group.

1716.name: tasklist
1716.profile: [profile]Tasklist is a malware component used by intrusion sets like Deep Panda, Lazarus Group, Silent Chollima, and Handala. Its key behaviors include executing system commands such as 'tasklist' and 'findstr' to enumerate running processes, often to identify and avoid security software like Avast, AVG, Sophos, and RSA agents. It also uses netstat to survey network connections and ports (e.g., 445, 3756, 15412) and employs Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) queries to steal detailed process information, user/computer accounts, and regional data, indicating targeting of Windows platforms.
1716.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware 'tasklist' is referenced in the context of other malicious tools like 'hatef', 'bistromath', and 'crat'. It is used for system reconnaissance, specifically to list running processes, often in conjunction with commands like `findstr` to search for and identify security software processes (e.g., avastui.exe, avgui.exe) or specific network ports. This behavior is associated with threat groups including Handala, Lazarus Group, and Silent Chollima, indicating its use in post-compromise information gathering and lateral movement within Windows environments.

1717.name: net view
1717.uncertain_mes: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a copy of [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
1717.profile: [profile]Net Crawler, also known as Net view, is an intranet worm attributed to the Cleaver group. Its key technical behaviors include extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading across a network over SMB by brute-forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using PsExec to execute copies of itself. The malware targets Windows systems, operating within networked environments to propagate and perform credential theft.[/profile]
1717.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "net view" is a reconnaissance command used by malware like IcedID, which is associated with groups Gold Cabin and Lunar Spider, to gather network information via commands such as "net view /all /domain" and "net group Domain Admins /domain" on Windows systems. It is also referenced in infrastructure links related to LimeRAT, which is linked to APT-C-36.

1718.name: net localgroup Administrators
1718.uncertain_mes: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a copy of [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
1718.profile: [profile]The entity is an intranet worm known as Net Crawler (alias net localgroup Administrators). It is attributed to the Cleaver group. Its key behaviors include extracting credentials via credential dumpers and spreading across networks over SMB by brute-forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using PsExec to execute copies of itself. Its target platforms are Windows systems, and it is associated with command-line commands for enumerating domain administrators and groups.[/profile]
1718.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'net localgroup Administrators' is a command-line instruction used for local user and group management on Windows systems, not a malware family. It is referenced in the context of other malware like FakeUpdates, ZLoader, and Conti, where it appears as part of command sequences for privilege escalation or reconnaissance, such as querying domain administrators or local administrator groups. These commands are associated with threat groups including Gold Prelude and Wizard Spider. Its operational use is on Windows platforms as a system administration tool leveraged for malicious purposes.

1719.name: net use
1719.uncertain_mes: [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) is an intranet worm capable of extracting credentials using credential dumpers and spreading to systems on a network over SMB by brute forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a copy of [Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056). (Citation: Cylance Cleaver)
1719.profile: [profile]Net Crawler, also known as Net use, is an intranet worm attributed to the Cleaver group. It extracts credentials using credential dumpers and spreads across network systems over SMB by brute-forcing accounts with recovered passwords and using PsExec to execute copies of itself. Its target platform is Windows networks. The intrusion set Deep Panda is a neighbor in the knowledge graph, but no direct attribution is provided in the context. Retrieved information shows the malware's commands, like net use and net view, are referenced in other entities such as roadsweep and LockBit, indicating its techniques are leveraged in broader attack chains.[/profile]
1719.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'net use' is a command-line utility within the Windows operating system used for managing network connections, such as mapping network drives. It is not a malware family itself but is frequently leveraged by various malicious tools for reconnaissance and lateral movement. For instance, it is referenced in the context of the 'roadsweep' malware for network enumeration and by ransomware like 'LockBit' in scripts for creating or modifying network shares. Its primary platform is Microsoft Windows, and it represents a legitimate system command that is abused as part of adversary tradecraft.

1720.name: nete
1720.profile: [profile]The malware 'nete' is attributed to the intrusion set Deep Panda. Key technical behaviors include persistence via registry key creation for automatic execution on system startup. Its target platform is Windows systems. Infrastructure and supplementary information indicates it may be associated with or share context with the groups Pinchy Spider and TA505, as referenced in related content, though these are not direct attribution claims for nete itself.
1720.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware 'nete' does not have any known aliases, attributed groups, key TTPs, or target platforms specified in the provided data. The retrieved information contains no relevant technical or contextual details about the malware itself, only unrelated mentions of the word 'nete' in other contexts.]

1721.name: Windows tools
1721.uncertain_mes: [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343) is a backdoor used for targeting Windows systems. The Linux version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
1721.profile: [profile]Exaramel for Windows, also known as Windows tools, is a backdoor attributed to the Sandworm Team. It targets Windows systems, with a separate Linux variant tracked as Exaramel for Linux. Its technical behaviors include establishing persistence through Windows registry keys such as those under Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run[OnceEx] and Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\winlogon, and it can monitor system performance via paths like \Microsoft\Windows\PLA\Server Manager Performance Monitor.
1721.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Windows tools is a malware entity with aliases including exaramel for windows and winnti for windows, and is attributed to groups such as sandworm team, winnti group, aquatic panda, and apt41. Key technical behaviors involve backdoor and remote access Trojan (RAT) capabilities for targeting Windows systems, with specific registry manipulations noted in entries like Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\winlogon and Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run[OnceEx]. The primary target platform is Windows, with supplementary infrastructure details indicating modular variants and cross-references to Linux versions in related malware families.

1722.name: leaked credentials
1722.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather credentials that can be used during targeting. Account credentials gathered by adversaries may be those directly associated with the target victim organization or attempt to take advantage of the tendency for users to use the same passwords across personal and business accounts.

Adversaries may gather credentials from potential victims in various ways, such as direct elicitation via [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then add malicious content designed to collect website authentication cookies from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) (Citation: Register Deloitte)(Citation: Register Uber)(Citation: Detectify Slack Tokens)(Citation: Forbes GitHub Creds)(Citation: GitHub truffleHog)(Citation: GitHub Gitrob)(Citation: CNET Leaks) Where multi-factor authentication (MFA) based on out-of-band communications is in use, adversaries may compromise a service provider to gain access to MFA codes and one-time passwords (OTP).(Citation: Okta Scatter Swine 2022)

Credential information may also be exposed to adversaries via leaks to online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Search Engines](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/002), breach dumps, code repositories, etc.). Adversaries may purchase credentials from dark web markets, such as Russian Market and 2easy, or through access to Telegram channels that distribute logs from infostealer malware.(Citation: Bleeping Computer 2easy 2021)(Citation: SecureWorks Infostealers 2023)(Citation: Bleeping Computer Stealer Logs 2023)

Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133) or [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078)).
1722.profile: [profile]Credentials, identified as T1589.001, is a Reconnaissance technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries gathering account credentials through methods like phishing, purchasing from dark web markets, or exploiting publicly leaked data from sources such as breach dumps, code repositories, and search engines. This activity is associated with groups including APT28, Chimera, Leviathan, Lapsus$, and Magic Hound.
1722.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "leaked credentials" aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1589.001 (Gather Victim Identity Information: Credentials) under the Reconnaissance tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries obtaining credentials from publicly available sources such as online data leaks, breach dumps, code repositories, and dark web markets. These leaked credentials are then used for follow-on activities like reconnaissance, establishing operational resources, or gaining initial access via Valid Accounts or External Remote Services.

1723.name: mounting a file share
1723.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may look for folders and drives shared on remote systems as a means of identifying sources of information to gather as a precursor for Collection and to identify potential systems of interest for Lateral Movement. Networks often contain shared network drives and folders that enable users to access file directories on various systems across a network. File sharing over a Windows network occurs over the SMB protocol. (Citation: Wikipedia Shared Resource) (Citation: TechNet Shared Folder) [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) can be used to query a remote system for available shared drives using the net view \\\\remotesystem command. It can also be used to query shared drives on the local system using net share. For macOS, the sharing -l command lists all shared points used for smb services.
1723.profile: [profile]Network Share Discovery, identified as T1135, is a Discovery tactic used on Windows and macOS systems. Adversaries enumerate accessible shared drives and folders to identify information sources for collection or lateral movement. The technique involves using commands like `net view \\remotesystem` and `net share` on Windows or `sharing -l` on macOS to query for SMB shares. It is associated with groups including APT38, Wizard Spider, and FIN13.[/profile]
1723.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Mounting a File Share is a technique for Lateral Movement, where adversaries connect to a remote network share, such as an SMB share, to access files or directories. This can be done using commands like `net use` on Windows to establish a connection to a shared resource on another system. The technique facilitates the transfer of tools or access to sensitive information across the network.

1724.name: 7-zip
1724.profile: [profile]7-Zip is a legitimate file archiver and compressor, but its self-extracting archive (SFX) format is frequently abused by threat actors like Deep Panda to package and deliver malware. It is referenced in the deployment of PlugX, HZ RAT, and AsyncRAT, where malicious payloads are concealed within 7-Zip archives or SFX modules to evade detection. This technique is associated with multiple APT groups, including APT22, APT26, APT31, APT41, Aurora Panda, and Mustang Panda, among others listed in PlugX's related groups. The primary target platform is Windows, where these archives are used to execute final-stage malware like China Chopper web shells.
1724.profile_without_enhance: [profile]7-zip is a legitimate file archiver utility, but its format and self-extracting archives (SFX) are frequently abused by malware families for distribution and evasion. It is notably used by threat actors including APT22, APT26, APT31, APT41, Aurora Panda, Calypso Group, DragonOK, Emissary Panda, Hellsing, Hurricane Panda, Leviathan, Mirage, Mustang Panda, Nettraveler, Nightshade Panda, Slime29, Samurai Panda, Stone Panda, UPS, and Violin Panda. Malware like PlugX, HZ RAT, and AsyncRAT have been observed embedded within or disguised as 7-Zip archives or SFX executables to bypass security controls on Windows systems.

1725.name: compress the data
1725.profile: [profile]The entity is "Compress the Data", which corresponds to the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1002 under the Collection tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries compressing collected data, such as sensitive documents, prior to exfiltration to reduce its size for more efficient and stealthy network transfer. Compression is performed separately from the exfiltration channel using common utilities like 7zip, RAR, ZIP, or zlib, or through custom programs and algorithms.
1725.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "compress the data" is a sub-technique of Data Compression (T1002) under the Collection tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves adversaries compressing collected sensitive data using custom programs, common algorithms, or utilities like 7zip, RAR, ZIP, or zlib prior to exfiltration to reduce size and facilitate network transfer. This action is distinct from the exfiltration channel itself and is often performed as part of staging (T1074) or archiving (T1560) procedures.

1726.name: wildcard extensions
1726.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may abuse internet browser extensions to establish persistent access to victim systems. Browser extensions or plugins are small programs that can add functionality to and customize aspects of internet browsers. They can be installed directly via a local file or custom URL or through a browser's app store - an official online platform where users can browse, install, and manage extensions for a specific web browser. Extensions generally inherit the web browser's permissions previously granted.(Citation: Wikipedia Browser Extension)(Citation: Chrome Extensions Definition) Malicious extensions can be installed into a browser through malicious app store downloads masquerading as legitimate extensions, through social engineering, or by an adversary that has already compromised a system. Security can be limited on browser app stores, so it may not be difficult for malicious extensions to defeat automated scanners.(Citation: Malicious Chrome Extension Numbers) Depending on the browser, adversaries may also manipulate an extension's update url to install updates from an adversary-controlled server or manipulate the mobile configuration file to silently install additional extensions. Adversaries may abuse how chromium-based browsers load extensions by modifying or replacing the Preferences and/or Secure Preferences files to silently install malicious extensions. When the browser is not running, adversaries can alter these files, ensuring the extension is loaded, granted desired permissions, and will persist in browser sessions. This method does not require user consent and extensions are silently loaded in the background from disk or from the browser's trusted store.(Citation: Pulsedive) Previous to macOS 11, adversaries could silently install browser extensions via the command line using the profiles tool to install malicious .mobileconfig files. In macOS 11+, the use of the profiles tool can no longer install configuration profiles; however, .mobileconfig files can be planted and installed with user interaction.(Citation: xorrior chrome extensions macOS) Once the extension is installed, it can browse to websites in the background, steal all information that a user enters into a browser (including credentials), and be used as an installer for a RAT for persistence.(Citation: Chrome Extension Crypto Miner)(Citation: ICEBRG Chrome Extensions)(Citation: Banker Google Chrome Extension Steals Creds)(Citation: Catch All Chrome Extension) There have also been instances of botnets using a persistent backdoor through malicious Chrome extensions for [Command and Control](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0011).(Citation: Stantinko Botnet)(Citation: Chrome Extension C2 Malware) Adversaries may also use browser extensions to modify browser permissions and components, privacy settings, and other security controls for [Defense Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0005).(Citation: Browers FriarFox)(Citation: Browser Adrozek)
1726.profile: [profile]The entity "wildcard extensions" is likely a reference to the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Browser Extensions" (T1176.001) under the Persistence tactic, targeting Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms. The technique involves adversaries installing malicious browser extensions to maintain access. Specific technical mechanics include silently installing extensions on Chromium-based browsers by modifying the Preferences or Secure Preferences files while the browser is closed, or on older macOS systems using the `profiles` command line tool to install `.mobileconfig` files. Once installed, these extensions can steal credentials, browse websites in the background, and act as a backdoor for command and control. The intrusion-set Deep Panda has been associated with this behavior.[/profile]
1726.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Wildcard Extensions is a technique where adversaries use wildcard characters (like * or ?) in file extensions to bypass security controls and execute malicious files. This falls under the Defense Evasion tactic (TA0005) and potentially others like Execution. The method exploits how systems interpret wildcards to match and run files that would otherwise be blocked, allowing execution of scripts or binaries with names that evade static filters. This technique is often used in conjunction with command-line interfaces to launch payloads.

1727.name: ping
1727.profile: [profile]Ping is a malware entity associated with the intrusion set Deep Panda. It is referenced in infrastructure used by other malware families, including Azorult and Redline Stealer, which are linked to The Gorgon Group. Key infrastructure indicators include domains such as chocolatepuma[.]casa, wormbrainteam[.]club, and fartoviypapamojetvse[.]club, which host C2 endpoints at the path /api/ping.[/profile]
1727.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware 'ping' is referenced as a command-and-control (C2) endpoint path (e.g., '/api/ping') used by other malware families, including Azorult and Redline Stealer, with infrastructure domains such as chocolatepuma[.]casa, wormbrainteam[.]club, and fartoviypapamojetvse[.]club. Azorult's use of this endpoint is linked to The Gorgon Group. Its key technical behavior involves serving as a C2 communication check-in point for information stealers, primarily targeting Windows systems through these connected campaigns.[/profile]

1728.name: rar archiver
1728.profile: [profile]RAR Archiver is a legitimate archiving utility that has been exploited by threat actors as a tool within their malware operations. It is referenced in connection with intrusion sets like Deep Panda, Lazarus Group, and APT32. In these malicious contexts, it is used to compress and archive specific file types (e.g., .xls, .doc, .pdf, log files) into RAR archives, often with command-line switches for automation and multi-volume splitting, before the archives are exfiltrated to command-and-control servers and subsequently deleted from the victim system.
1728.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RAR Archiver is a legitimate compression utility, but referenced in malware operations. It is used by threat actors like Lazarus Group and APT32. In CRAT, it archives logs for exfiltration via command-line execution (e.g., `rar a -k -r -s -ibck -m5`). In OXTRAT, a function `rar_it` compresses specific document and image extensions. KerrDown malware is associated with RAR archives. The tool targets Windows platforms and is leveraged for data staging and exfiltration.

1730.name: anti-forensics
1730.profile: [profile]The entity 'anti-forensics' is a broad category of adversary techniques, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID. It encompasses methods to hinder detection and analysis, as illustrated by related techniques. These include Indicator Removal from Tools (T1027.005/T1066), where adversaries modify malware to evade signature-based detection, and Timestomp (T1070.006), which involves altering file timestamps to hide malicious activity and blend with legitimate files. The intrusion-set Deep Panda is associated with these practices.[/profile]
1730.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'anti-forensics' is a broad category of adversary techniques aimed at impeding forensic analysis, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on retrieved information, it encompasses specific methods like Timestomping (T1070.006), which modifies file timestamps using commands like `touch` in Linux or manipulating MFT attributes in Windows to hide file changes, and Indicator Removal from Tools (T1027.005/T1066), where adversaries alter malicious tools, such as by changing file signatures, to evade detection by security software.

1732.name: anti-IOC detection techniques
1732.profile: [profile]The entity "anti-IOC detection techniques" is a general adversarial behavior aimed at evading security tools by identifying and neutralizing Indicators of Compromise (IOCs). This involves modifying malicious tools or malware after detection to remove the specific signatures or behaviors that triggered alerts, such as altering file signatures through software packing. Adversaries may also directly disable or tamper with defensive software, including endpoint detection and response (EDR) systems, antivirus processes, and logging mechanisms like Sysmon, to impair both prevention and detection capabilities. This activity is associated with intrusion sets like Deep Panda and aligns with the broader MITRE ATT&CK tactic of Impair Defenses (T1562).[profile]
1732.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "anti-IOC detection techniques" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it describes adversarial actions to evade detection by security tools. This involves identifying and removing the specific signatures or behaviors (Indicators of Compromise) that triggered detection, such as modifying malware file signatures through Software Packing (T1045) to bypass antivirus, or more broadly disabling or tampering with security software and logging mechanisms like Sysmon to impair defensive capabilities.

1733.name: espionage techniques
1733.profile: [profile]The entity "espionage techniques" is a broad category rather than a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique, lacking a standard T-ID. It encompasses tactics like lateral movement and data theft. Based on related techniques, associated methods include abusing centralized software deployment tools (like SCCM or AWS Systems Manager) for remote command execution, exfiltrating data over existing command and control channels, and disabling security tools (such as EDR agents or Sysmon) by killing processes or modifying configurations to evade detection. The intrusion set Deep Panda is linked to this category of activities.
1733.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "espionage techniques" is a broad, non-specific term not directly mappable to a single MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it may encompass specific techniques like T1072 (Software Deployment Tools), where adversaries abuse enterprise management suites for lateral movement and command execution, and T1562.001 (Disable or Modify Tools), involving the tampering or disabling of security software and logging to evade detection. These actions are commonly associated with espionage-focused threat groups such as Mustang Panda, APT32, and Sandworm Team.

1742.name: Derusbi/Sakula
1742.uncertain_mes: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) is a remote access tool (RAT) that first surfaced in 2012 and was used in intrusions throughout 2015. (Citation: Dell Sakula)
1742.profile: [profile]Derusbi/Sakula, also known simply as Sakula, is a remote access tool (RAT) first seen in 2012. It has been associated with groups including Deep Panda, APT41, APT17, Leviathan, and Stone Panda. Its technical behaviors involve unpacking a downloader component named Shyape, which subsequently fetches and executes the Derusbi DLL payload. The malware was used in campaigns such as the 2011 Mitsubishi hack, the 2013 ShellCrew campaign, and the 2014 Anthem breach.[/profile]
1742.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Derusbi/Sakula, also known as Sakula, is a remote access tool (RAT) first seen in 2012. It has been attributed to groups including Deep Panda, APT41, APT17, Leviathan, and Stone Panda. Key behaviors involve a downloader component named Shyape and the use of a Derusbi DLL, with a possible infection routine. It has been used in campaigns such as the 2011 Mitsubishi Hack, the 2013 ShellCrew Campaign, and the 2014 Anthem Breach.

1749.name: mirror legitimate remote infrastructure
1749.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate network traffic in order to hide and evade detection of their C2 infrastructure. This can be accomplished by identifying and filtering traffic from defensive tools,(Citation: TA571) masking malicious domains to obfuscate the true destination from both automated scanning tools and security researchers,(Citation: Schema-abuse)(Citation: Facad1ng)(Citation: Browser-updates) and otherwise hiding malicious artifacts to delay discovery and prolong the effectiveness of adversary infrastructure that could otherwise be identified, blocked, or taken down entirely.

C2 networks may include the use of [Proxy](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090) or VPNs to disguise IP addresses, which can allow adversaries to blend in with normal network traffic and bypass conditional access policies or anti-abuse protections. For example, an adversary may use a virtual private cloud to spoof their IP address to closer align with a victim's IP address ranges. This may also bypass security measures relying on geolocation of the source IP address.(Citation: sysdig)(Citation: Orange Residential Proxies)

Adversaries may also attempt to filter network traffic in order to evade defensive tools in numerous ways, including blocking/redirecting common incident responder or security appliance user agents.(Citation: mod_rewrite)(Citation: SocGholish-update) Filtering traffic based on IP and geo-fencing may also avoid automated sandboxing or researcher activity (i.e., [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497)).(Citation: TA571)(Citation: mod_rewrite)

Hiding C2 infrastructure may also be supported by [Resource Development](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0042) activities such as [Acquire Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1583) and [Compromise Infrastructure](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1584). For example, using widely trusted hosting services or domains such as prominent URL shortening providers or marketing services for C2 networks may enable adversaries to present benign content that later redirects victims to malicious web pages or infrastructure once specific conditions are met.(Citation: StarBlizzard)(Citation: QR-cofense)
1749.profile: [profile]The technique "Hide Infrastructure" (T1665) is part of the Resource Development tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves manipulating network traffic to conceal C2 infrastructure by using proxies or VPNs to disguise IP addresses and blend with normal traffic, filtering traffic to block defensive tool user agents or based on IP/geolocation to evade sandboxes, and masking malicious domains to obfuscate the true destination from scanners. This activity is often supported by related techniques like Acquire Infrastructure (T1583) and Compromise Infrastructure (T1584).
1749.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "mirror legitimate remote infrastructure" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is a method where adversaries abuse native traffic mirroring features of network or cloud devices to duplicate and redirect a victim's network traffic through infrastructure they control. This technique, related to T1020.001 (Traffic Duplication), enables automated data exfiltration and supports activities like network sniffing or adversary-in-the-middle attacks by leveraging compromised or acquired infrastructure to blend malicious activity with legitimate traffic.

1750.name: employee benefits resources
1750.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather employee names that can be used during targeting. Employee names be used to derive email addresses as well as to help guide other reconnaissance efforts and/or craft more-believable lures.

Adversaries may easily gather employee names, since they may be readily available and exposed via online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Social Media](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593/001) or [Search Victim-Owned Websites](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1594)).(Citation: OPM Leak) Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Compromise Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1586)), and/or initial access (ex: [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566) or [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078)).
1750.profile: [profile]Employee Names is a reconnaissance technique under MITRE ATT&CK ID T1589.003, aligned with the Reconnaissance tactic and applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries gathering employee names from publicly accessible sources like social media or victim-owned websites to derive email addresses, guide further reconnaissance, and craft more believable phishing lures. This information can facilitate subsequent operations such as credential compromise or initial access via phishing. Threat groups like Silent Librarian, Sandworm Team, and Kimsuky have been associated with this technique.
1750.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Employee Benefits Resources is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries gather information about an organization's employee benefits, compensation, or related HR data to identify key personnel, understand organizational structure, and craft targeted lures. This data, often exposed via social media, victim-owned websites, or purchased from data sources, can reveal high-value targets and inform subsequent attacks like phishing or credential compromise. It is associated with the Reconnaissance tactic and is used by groups like Silent Librarian, Sandworm Team, and Kimsuky.

1751.name: httpbrowser
1751.uncertain_mes: [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) is malware that has been used by several threat groups. (Citation: ThreatStream Evasion Analysis) (Citation: Dell TG-3390) It is believed to be of Chinese origin. (Citation: ThreatConnect Anthem)
1751.profile: [profile]HTTPBrowser is a malware family believed to be of Chinese origin. Its aliases include pisloader, which is considered a variant. It has been used by threat groups including Threat Group-3390, APT18, Wekby, and Emissary Panda. Key technical behaviors involve commands like 'list', 'drive', and 'upload' with formatted responses, and it uses HTTP for communication with specific URI patterns such as '/br.js' for GET requests and '/es' for POST requests. The malware is associated with data breaches like the Anthem incident.[/profile]
1751.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTPBrowser is a malware family also known as Roseam. It is attributed to the Wekby group, also known as Emissary Panda. Key technical behaviors include using specific commands like 'list', 'drive', and 'upload' with formatted responses, and it communicates via HTTP with GET requests to '/br.js' and POST requests to '/es', where server output involves prepending characters, base64 encoding, and masking. Its target platform is Windows. Infrastructure analysis links it to the Anthem breach incident in 2015.

1752.name: httpdump
1752.profile: [profile]HttpDump is a malware implant also known as HttpBrowser, associated with threat groups including Wizard Spider (via Conti), Wekby, and Emissary Panda. It communicates via HTTP GET and POST requests to specific URIs (/posting and /extension) and uses base64 encoding for data exfiltration. The malware targets Windows systems and has been observed in campaigns using digitally signed payloads, such as those from DTOPTOOLZ Co.
1752.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HttpDump, also known as HttpBrowser, is a malware implant. It has been associated with groups including Wizard Spider (via Conti), Wekby, and Emissary Panda. Its key technical behaviors involve using HTTP for command and control, with specific GET requests to "/posting" and POST requests to "/extension", and it employs base64 and base64url encoding for server output. The malware was observed targeting systems as early as December 2013, delivered via a signed file named OpenOfficePlugin.exe.

1756.name: character replacement technique
1756.profile: [profile]Character Replacement Technique is a sub-technique of Masquerading (T1036.002) within the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily affecting Windows systems. It specifically abuses the right-to-left override (RTLO) Unicode character (U+202E) to reverse the display order of subsequent characters, disguising malicious file names like "March 25 \u202Excod.scr" to appear as a benign "March 25 rcs.docx" document. This technique is used to trick users into executing malicious files delivered via spearphishing and has been employed by groups like Ferocious Kitten and BlackTech.[/profile]
1756.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "character replacement technique" is a specific implementation of the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Right-to-Left Override" (T1036.002) under the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily for Windows. It involves abusing the non-printing Unicode right-to-left override (RTLO) character (U+202E) to reverse the display order of subsequent characters, disguising malicious file names like making "March 25 \u202Excod.scr" appear as "March 25 rcs.docx" to trick users into executing them, commonly observed in spearphishing and malware distribution campaigns.

1757.name: Chinese APT espionage campaign
1757.profile: [profile]Chinese APT espionage campaign is a threat activity. It has been associated with the use of software deployment tools like SCCM and network configuration management tools for lateral movement and remote code execution, as referenced in operations by suspected Chinese actors. The campaign also involves disabling security tools, including tampering with network device firmware verification to avoid detection. A connected intrusion set is identified as Unknown_Threat_Actor.
1757.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Chinese APT espionage campaign" is a campaign, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on retrieved information, this campaign has been observed using multiple techniques, including Software Deployment Tools (T1072) for lateral movement and remote code execution, Junk Data (T1001.001) to obfuscate command and control traffic, and Disable or Modify Tools (T1562.001) to evade security software. These activities are associated with threat groups like Putter Panda and UNC3886, and have targeted network infrastructure devices and cloud environments.

1758.name: VAEIT APT
1758.uncertain_mes: On May 6 and May 11, 2015, Unit 42 observed two targeted attacks, the first against the U.S. government and the second on a European media company. Threat actors delivered the same document via spear-phishing emails to both organizations.
1758.profile: [profile]VAEIT APT, also known as APT.3102, is a threat actor believed to be linked to Iranian state-sponsored operations, with potential overlaps or connections to groups like Cleaver (APT34, OilRig). Its arsenal is not explicitly detailed in the provided data, but its key TTPs include spear-phishing campaigns delivering malicious documents. The group has primarily targeted the U.S. government and European media organizations, indicating a motivation for espionage and information gathering aligned with broader Iranian cyber interests.
1758.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set VAEIT APT, likely a Chinese state-sponsored group, is also known as VAE, Inc. and uses the Derusbi/Sakula remote access tool (RAT) as a key piece of malware. Its primary initial access technique is spear-phishing, and it operates infrastructure using domains such as sharepoint-vaeit.com and www.we11point.com, often themed around the fake company "VAE, Inc." The group is believed to be based in China and shows potential overlaps with other threat clusters, but its specific target sectors and primary motivations remain unclear from the available data.
1758.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]VAEIT APT is a suspected Iranian state-sponsored threat group, also known as Reckless Rabbit and Ruthless Rabbit, based on its operational infrastructure overlaps. 1763.name: spear-phishing attack
1763.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may send phishing messages to gain access to victim systems. All forms of phishing are electronically delivered social engineering. Phishing can be targeted, known as spearphishing. In spearphishing, a specific individual, company, or industry will be targeted by the adversary. More generally, adversaries can conduct non-targeted phishing, such as in mass malware spam campaigns.

Adversaries may send victims emails containing malicious attachments or links, typically to execute malicious code on victim systems. Phishing may also be conducted via third-party services, like social media platforms. Phishing may also involve social engineering techniques, such as posing as a trusted source, as well as evasive techniques such as removing or manipulating emails or metadata/headers from compromised accounts being abused to send messages (e.g., [Email Hiding Rules](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564/008)).(Citation: Microsoft OAuth Spam 2022)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 VBA Infostealer 2014) Another way to accomplish this is by [Email Spoofing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1672)(Citation: Proofpoint-spoof) the identity of the sender, which can be used to fool both the human recipient as well as automated security tools,(Citation: cyberproof-double-bounce) or by including the intended target as a party to an existing email thread that includes malicious files or links (i.e., "thread hijacking").(Citation: phishing-krebs)

Victims may also receive phishing messages that instruct them to call a phone number where they are directed to visit a malicious URL, download malware,(Citation: sygnia Luna Month)(Citation: CISA Remote Monitoring and Management Software) or install adversary-accessible remote management tools onto their computer (i.e., [User Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204)).(Citation: Unit42 Luna Moth)
1763.profile: [profile]Spear-phishing Attack, identified as T1566, is an Initial Access technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework applicable to multiple platforms. It involves sending targeted electronic messages to specific individuals or organizations to deliver malicious content, such as attachments or links, which rely on user interaction for execution. Evasive methods include email spoofing, thread hijacking, and manipulating email metadata. Associated groups include Sea Turtle, Kimsuky, and Axiom.[/profile]
1763.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Spear-phishing attack is a targeted social engineering technique, identified as T1566.001 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework under the Initial Access tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves sending tailored electronic messages, typically emails, to a specific individual, company, or industry to gain access or elicit information. The attack mechanics often include malicious attachments (like Office documents or executables requiring user execution) or embedded links to malicious websites, frequently employing social engineering pretexts, email spoofing, and URL obfuscation to enhance credibility and evade detection.

1773.name: comic book themed naming convention
1773.profile: [profile]The entity "comic book themed naming convention" is a sub-technique of Masquerading (T1036) within the Defense Evasion tactic. It involves adversaries naming malicious files, directories, or other resources after characters or themes from comic books to blend in and avoid detection. This technique is used by groups like Deep Panda. The naming is a specific application of matching or approximating legitimate resource names to appear benign within a target environment.
1773.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "comic book themed naming convention" is a sub-technique of T1036 (Masquerading) within the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries naming malicious files, directories, or resources after characters, themes, or titles from comic books to blend in and avoid detection by appearing as benign, user-generated content. This specific naming strategy is a form of masquerading distinct from matching legitimate resource names or masquerading account names.

1774.name: infoadmin/kakfum
1774.profile: [profile]The malware known as InfoAdmin or Kakfum is a subvariant of the Derusbi backdoor. It is associated with the intrusion set Deep Panda. Its key technical behaviors include using malicious infrastructure such as the domains images.googlewebcache[.]com and smtp.outlookssl[.]com for command and control. The malware has also been linked to infrastructure like the domain kat0x[.]net, which has been associated with targeting Pakistani government and higher education sectors.
1774.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The malware is known as InfoAdmin, also referred to as Kakfum. It is a Derusbi backdoor subvariant. It has been associated with threat groups including Deep Panda, Wekby, and Emissary Panda. Its malicious infrastructure has utilized the domains images.googlewebcache[.]com and smtp.outlookssl[.]com for command and control.

1779.name: sakula
1779.uncertain_mes: [Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) is a remote access tool (RAT) that first surfaced in 2012 and was used in intrusions throughout 2015. (Citation: Dell Sakula)
1779.profile: [profile]Sakula, also known as Sakula RAT, is a remote access tool (RAT) first observed in 2012 and used in intrusions through 2015. It is attributed to the threat group Deep Panda. Its key technical behaviors include establishing persistence via Windows Registry keys. It targets the Windows platform and has been used in spear-phishing campaigns against government entities.[/profile]
1779.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Sakula, also known as Sakula RAT, is a remote access tool (RAT) first observed in 2012 and used in intrusions through 2015. It is attributed to the Deep Panda group. Key technical behaviors include using a persistence mechanism via a registry key for automatic startup and it is associated with the 'dtoptoolz signature' indicator. Its target platform is Windows systems.

1781.name: scanbox framework
1781.profile: [profile]Scanbox Framework is a reconnaissance framework used by threat actors like APT28 and Hafnium. It operates under the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1592.004 for gathering client configurations, falling within the Reconnaissance tactic. The framework is deployed via malicious web pages to actively scan visiting clients, collecting detailed system information such as operating system, browser plugins, and language settings to profile victims and enable further targeted attacks.
1781.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Scanbox Framework is a reconnaissance tool used for client-side information gathering, aligning with the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1592.004 (Gather Victim Host Information: Client Configurations) under the Reconnaissance tactic. It operates by compromising websites to host malicious JavaScript that collects detailed victim client data upon visitor interaction, including operating system, browser version, language, and time zone. This information is then exfiltrated to support further targeting activities, such as spear-phishing or capability development.

1782.name: derusbi
1782.uncertain_mes: [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is malware used by multiple Chinese APT groups.(Citation: Novetta-Axiom)(Citation: ThreatConnect Anthem) Both Windows and Linux variants have been observed.(Citation: Fidelis Turbo)
1782.profile: [profile]Derusbi, also known as Sakula, is a Remote Administration Tool (RAT) used by multiple Chinese APT groups including APT41, Deep Panda, Axiom, Leviathan, APT17, and Stone Panda. It has variants for both Windows and Linux platforms, with observed campaigns like the Anthem Breach (2014). Key technical behaviors include using a DLL component (TXPFProxy.dll) and sharing a similar method for constructing identifiers with related malware like Shyape.[/profile]
1782.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Derusbi, also known as Shyape and TXPFProxy.dll, is a remote administration tool (RAT) malware. It has been attributed to groups including APT41, APT17, Leviathan, and Stone Panda. Key technical behaviors involve creating a registry key for persistence and using a specific method for constructing identifiers. It has been associated with campaigns such as the Anthem Breach (2014) and ShellCrew (2013).

1785.name: kakfum
1785.profile: [profile]Kakfum, also known as InfoAdmin, is a Derusbi backdoor subvariant. It is attributed to the threat groups Wekby and Emissary Panda (also referenced as Deep Panda). Its technical behavior involves using malicious infrastructure such as the domains images.googlewebcache[.]com and smtp.outlookssl[.]com. The malware is associated with the capability usage of the ScanBox reconnaissance framework. Its target platform is not specified in the provided data.[/profile]

1786.name: infoadmin
1786.profile: [profile]Infoadmin, also known as Milestone, is a remote access trojan (RAT) based on modified Gh0st RAT code. It has been attributed to the threat actor Deep Panda (also known as APT19, Shell Crew, or Stone Panda) and was used in the early 2010s. Its key technical behavior involves incorporating specific, identical modifications to the Gh0st RAT source code that distinguish it from other variants. The malware targets Windows platforms and functions as a backdoor for system access and data exfiltration.[/profile]
1786.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Infoadmin, also known as Milestone, is a remote access trojan (RAT) based on modified Gh0st RAT code, with unique modifications distinguishing it from other variants. It has been historically attributed to the Deep Panda threat actor and is associated with groups like Emissary Panda, Hurricane Panda, and Stone Panda. Its technical behaviors include comprehensive system enumeration, administrator and user discovery, and extraction of employee information and password policies. The malware primarily targets Windows platforms and was notably active in the early 2010s.

1792.name: cryptography
1792.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may employ a known symmetric encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol. Symmetric encryption algorithms use the same key for plaintext encryption and ciphertext decryption. Common symmetric encryption algorithms include AES, DES, 3DES, Blowfish, and RC4.
1792.profile: [profile]This technique, Symmetric Cryptography (T1573.001), is used for Command and Control under the Command and Control tactic on Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves using a known symmetric encryption algorithm, such as AES, DES, 3DES, Blowfish, or RC4, to conceal C2 traffic by encrypting plaintext and decrypting ciphertext with the same key. It has been associated with threat groups including MuddyWater, APT28, Lazarus Group, and Volt Typhoon.
1792.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'cryptography' is a broad attack pattern for using encryption to conceal malicious activity, encompassing both symmetric (e.g., AES, DES) and asymmetric (e.g., RSA) algorithms. It is used for tactics like Command and Control (T1573) and Exfiltration (T1048.002). Technical mechanics involve employing these algorithms to encrypt C2 traffic or exfiltrated data, with symmetric using a single key and asymmetric using a public/private keypair. Adversaries may also implement custom or flawed cryptographic protocols to evade detection.

1794.name: penetration testing
1794.profile: [profile]Penetration testing is a legitimate security assessment practice, not a MITRE ATT&CK attack pattern. It involves authorized simulation of cyberattacks to evaluate system defenses. The retrieved information describes actual adversarial techniques like Internet Connection Discovery (T1016.001), Password Guessing (T1110.001), and XSL Script Processing (T1220), which are distinct from the authorized testing activity.
1794.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Penetration testing is a legitimate security assessment methodology, not a MITRE ATT&CK attack pattern. The retrieved information describes specific adversary techniques such as Internet Connection Discovery (T1016.001), Password Guessing (T1110.001), and XSL Script Processing (T1220), which are distinct, malicious procedures used to discover network connectivity, gain unauthorized access, and bypass application controls, respectively.

1795.name: computer network security
1795.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather information about the victim's network security appliances that can be used during targeting. Information about network security appliances may include a variety of details, such as the existence and specifics of deployed firewalls, content filters, and proxies/bastion hosts. Adversaries may also target information about victim network-based intrusion detection systems (NIDS) or other appliances related to defensive cybersecurity operations.

Adversaries may gather this information in various ways, such as direct collection actions via [Active Scanning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598).(Citation: Nmap Firewalls NIDS) Information about network security appliances may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets (ex: [Search Victim-Owned Websites](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1594)). Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596) or [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133)).
1795.profile: [profile]Network Security Appliances, identified as T1590.006 within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, is a reconnaissance technique under the Reconnaissance tactic applicable to multiple platforms. It involves gathering intelligence on a victim's defensive infrastructure, including firewalls, intrusion detection systems (NIDS), proxies, and content filters. This information is collected via methods like Active Scanning (T1595) or Phishing for Information (T1598) and can be used to identify vulnerabilities for follow-on actions such as initial access. The group Volt Typhoon has been associated with this activity.
1795.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "computer network security" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved information, it appears to be a broad conceptual category. The provided similar entities describe specific adversarial techniques for reconnaissance and defense evasion, such as gathering information on network security appliances (T1590.006) via active scanning or phishing, and discovering security software (T1063) using commands like `netsh` or `reg query`. These techniques are used by groups including Volt Typhoon to identify security configurations and potential vulnerabilities within a target network.

1800.name: Malware
1800.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
1800.profile: [profile]The malware 'nmass' is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) targeting entities in Mongolia. Its key technical behaviors include being deployed via a Royal Road v7 (RTF) document lure about COVID-19 infections in Russia, which drops an initial executable (os03C2.tmp). It shares similarities with campaigns historically associated with Operation LagTime or Tonto Team. The attributed threat actor is currently unknown.[/profile]
1800.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Malware, also known as nmass, is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) and backdoor. It is associated with the Operation LagTime or Tonto Team campaigns. Its key technical behaviors include being delivered via a malicious Royal Road (v7) decoy document, dropping an initial executable file named 'os03C2.tmp', and targeting entities in Mongolia with a lure document about COVID-19 infections in Russia. The primary target platform is Windows.

1803.name: remote access
1803.uncertain_mes:
An adversary may use legitimate remote access tools to establish an interactive command and control channel within a network. Remote access tools create a session between two trusted hosts through a graphical interface, a command line interaction, a protocol tunnel via development or management software, or hardware-level access such as KVM (Keyboard, Video, Mouse) over IP solutions. Desktop support software (usually graphical interface) and remote management software (typically command line interface) allow a user to control a computer remotely as if they are a local user inheriting the user or software permissions. This software is commonly used for troubleshooting, software installation, and system management.(Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)(Citation: CrowdStrike 2015 Global Threat Report)(Citation: CrySyS Blog TeamSpy) Adversaries may similarly abuse response features included in EDR and other defensive tools that enable remote access.

Remote access tools may be installed and used post-compromise as an alternate communications channel for redundant access or to establish an interactive remote desktop session with the target system. It may also be used as a malware component to establish a reverse connection or back-connect to a service or adversary-controlled system.

Installation of many remote access tools may also include persistence (e.g., the software's installation routine creates a [Windows Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/003)). Remote access modules/features may also exist as part of otherwise existing software (e.g., Google Chromeâ€™s Remote Desktop).(Citation: Google Chrome Remote Desktop)(Citation: Chrome Remote Desktop)
1803.profile: [profile]Remote Access Tools, designated as T1219 under the Command and Control tactic, operates across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms by abusing legitimate software like desktop support or remote management tools to establish interactive sessions, including graphical interfaces, command-line interactions, or protocol tunnels such as KVM over IP. It is often installed post-compromise to create redundant command channels or reverse connections, with installation routines potentially adding persistence via Windows Services, and is associated with groups like Carbanak and MuddyWater.[/profile]
1803.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'remote access' is a broad concept, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is a foundational capability that adversaries achieve by abusing legitimate tools and services. This includes using remote access software (like TeamViewer or Chrome Remote Desktop) or hardware (like KVM-over-IP devices) to establish interactive command and control sessions, often for persistence and lateral movement. Adversaries also leverage remote services such as RDP, SSH, and VNC with valid credentials to log into systems across a network, executing actions with the permissions of the authenticated user.

1804.name: browse network
1804.profile: [profile]The entity "browse network" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to a reconnaissance activity where an adversary explores or enumerates network resources, shares, or topology to gather information. This can involve using commands like `net view` to discover shared drives or analyzing network configurations to understand the environment's layout. It is often a precursor to lateral movement or data collection, and may be performed by threat actors as part of initial discovery.
1804.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "browse network" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it likely refers to the reconnaissance activity of exploring network resources to gather information. This can involve using commands like `net view` to discover shared drives on remote systems, which is a component of the Network Share Discovery technique (T1135). The activity supports initial targeting by identifying accessible information sources and potential paths for lateral movement within a network.

1806.name: topsec
1806.profile: [profile]Topsec, also known as Beijing Topsec Network Security Technology Co., is a Chinese networking and security firm. It is referenced in the context of a joint research venture with a university. The entity is mentioned in relation to threat groups including Wekby and Emissary Panda. Its specific malware behaviors, target platforms, and infrastructure details are not detailed in the provided information.[/profile]
