1807.name: Human Intelligence Targeting
1807.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may obtain access to generative artificial intelligence tools, such as large language models (LLMs), to aid various techniques during targeting. These tools may be used to inform, bolster, and enable a variety of malicious tasks, including conducting [Reconnaissance](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0043), creating basic scripts, assisting social engineering, and even developing payloads.(Citation: MSFT-AI) 

For example, by utilizing a publicly available LLM an adversary is essentially outsourcing or automating certain tasks to the tool. Using AI, the adversary may draft and generate content in a variety of written languages to be used in [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566)/[Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) campaigns. The same publicly available tool may further enable vulnerability or other offensive research supporting [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587). AI tools may also automate technical tasks by generating, refining, or otherwise enhancing (e.g., [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027)) malicious scripts and payloads.(Citation: OpenAI-CTI) Finally, AI-generated text, images, audio, and video may be used for fraud, [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656), and other malicious activities.(Citation: Google-Vishing24)(Citation: IC3-AI24)(Citation: WSJ-Vishing-AI24)
1807.profile: [profile]The entity "Human Intelligence Targeting" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided data, the relevant technique is "Obtain Capabilities: Artificial Intelligence" (ID: T1588.007) under the Resource Development tactic. It involves adversaries accessing generative AI tools like LLMs to automate and enhance malicious tasks. Specific technical mechanics include using LLMs to draft multilingual phishing content, generate or refine malicious scripts and payloads (including obfuscation), and create synthetic media for impersonation and fraud. The technique supports various phases like reconnaissance, capability development, and social engineering.
1807.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Human Intelligence Targeting is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries gather information through direct human interaction, such as elicitation, interviews, or social engineering. It is part of the Reconnaissance tactic (TA0043) and applies to multiple platforms. This method involves engaging with individuals to extract sensitive data about an organization, its personnel, or its systems, often to inform subsequent attack stages like initial access or weaponization.

1808.name: Extortion
1808.profile: [profile]Extortion is a technique (T1657) within the Impact tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves adversaries demanding payment from victims, often following actions like Data Encrypted for Impact and data exfiltration, threatening to leak stolen data unless a ransom is paid, with dedicated leak sites sometimes used for distribution. This is a primary objective in ransomware campaigns and can be used to divert attention from other goals like data destruction.
1808.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Extortion is a financial theft technique (T1657) under the Impact tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves coercing victims into making payments, often by threatening to leak exfiltrated sensitive data unless a ransom is paid, a common practice in ransomware campaigns where dedicated leak sites may be used to distribute victim data.

1809.name: Asset Recruitment
1809.profile: [profile]Asset Recruitment is a technique where adversaries recruit assets, such as individuals or organizations, to support their operations. This can involve developing capabilities in-house or through contractors, as seen in activities like building malware or exploits. It may also involve searching open websites and domains for victim information to facilitate further targeting. The technique is associated with groups like Contagious Interview, Moonstone Sleet, and Kimsuky, and is linked to broader adversarial lifecycle phases including reconnaissance and initial access preparation.
1809.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Asset Recruitment is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries identify and co-opt existing, legitimate resources (like websites, servers, or accounts) to support their operations, rather than building or stealing new capabilities. This process involves searching for suitable assets that can be hijacked or repurposed to establish infrastructure, host malicious content, or blend in with normal traffic, thereby making their activities harder to detect and attribute.

1810.name: Beijing Topsec Technology Co., Ltd.
1810.profile: [profile]Beijing Topsec Technology Co., Ltd., also known as the "beijing group," is a Chinese intrusion set. Its arsenal includes malicious drivers and tools associated with blocklisted sequences from Chinese security firms like Beijing Huorong and Qihoo 360, as seen in the Water Orthrus campaign. The group's operations show overlaps with clusters tracked as APT40, Greenspot (APT-Q-20/Poisonvine), and other China-nexus groups, indicating shared infrastructure or targeting patterns. It is believed to be state-sponsored, primarily targeting entities for cyber espionage, with a focus on sectors and regions of strategic interest to China.

1811.name: Technical Targeting Operations
1811.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may purchase technical information about victims that can be used during targeting. Information about victims may be available for purchase within reputable private sources and databases, such as paid subscriptions to feeds of scan databases or other data aggregation services. Adversaries may also purchase information from less-reputable sources such as dark web or cybercrime blackmarkets.

Adversaries may purchase information about their already identified targets, or use purchased data to discover opportunities for successful breaches. Threat actors may gather various technical details from purchased data, including but not limited to employee contact information, credentials, or specifics regarding a victimâ€™s infrastructure.(Citation: ZDNET Selling Data) Information from these sources may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) or [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133) or [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078)).
1811.profile: [profile]Purchase Technical Data, identified as T1597.002 under the Reconnaissance tactic, involves adversaries acquiring victim technical information from paid sources like subscription databases or dark web markets to enable further targeting. This purchased data, which can include employee contact details, credentials, and infrastructure specifics, is used to inform and enable subsequent techniques such as Phishing for Information, Search Open Websites/Domains, and establishing initial access via Valid Accounts.
1811.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Technical Targeting Operations, identified as T1597 in the MITRE ATT&CK framework, falls under the Reconnaissance tactic and is applicable across multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries acquiring technical data about victims to enable further targeting. This can be achieved by purchasing information from private data feeds or illicit markets, or by searching freely available open technical databases and websites. The gathered technical details, such as infrastructure specifics or employee credentials, are then used to inform and enable subsequent attack phases like initial access or capability development.

1812.name: vulnerability discovery
1812.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may scan victims for vulnerabilities that can be used during targeting. Vulnerability scans typically check if the configuration of a target host/application (ex: software and version) potentially aligns with the target of a specific exploit the adversary may seek to use.

These scans may also include more broad attempts to [Gather Victim Host Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1592) that can be used to identify more commonly known, exploitable vulnerabilities. Vulnerability scans typically harvest running software and version numbers via server banners, listening ports, or other network artifacts.(Citation: OWASP Vuln Scanning) Information from these scans may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or initial access (ex: [Exploit Public-Facing Application](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190)).
1812.profile: [profile]Vulnerability Scanning, identified as T1595.002, is a reconnaissance technique within the Reconnaissance tactic. It operates across multiple platforms by scanning target hosts or applications to check configurations, such as software and version numbers, against known exploit targets. This is typically achieved by harvesting information from server banners, listening ports, and other network artifacts to identify potential vulnerabilities that can inform follow-on actions like exploitation or further information gathering. It is associated with groups including APT28, APT29, and Sandworm Team.[/profile]
1812.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Vulnerability Discovery is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries acquire information about software or hardware weaknesses that can be exploited. This involves searching open vulnerability databases like the National Vulnerability Database or accessing closed sources to find details on existing or newly discovered flaws. The gathered intelligence is used to identify potential exploits for initial access or privilege escalation, as seen in activities by groups like Sandworm Team and Volt Typhoon.

1813.name: software code analysis
1813.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may gather information about the victim's host software that can be used during targeting. Information about installed software may include a variety of details such as types and versions on specific hosts, as well as the presence of additional components that might be indicative of added defensive protections (ex: antivirus, SIEMs, etc.).

Adversaries may gather this information in various ways, such as direct collection actions via [Active Scanning](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595) (ex: listening ports, server banners, user agent strings) or [Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598). Adversaries may also compromise sites then include malicious content designed to collect host information from visitors.(Citation: ATT ScanBox) Information about the installed software may also be exposed to adversaries via online or other accessible data sets (ex: job postings, network maps, assessment reports, resumes, or purchase invoices). Additionally, adversaries may analyze metadata from victim-owned files (e.g., PDFs, DOCs, images, and sound files hosted on victim-owned websites) to extract information about the software and hardware used to create or process those files. Metadata may reveal software versions, configurations, or timestamps that indicate outdated or vulnerable software. This information can be cross-referenced with known CVEs to identify potential vectors for exploitation in future operations.(Citation: Outpost24)

Gathering this information may reveal opportunities for other forms of reconnaissance (ex: [Search Open Websites/Domains](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1593) or [Search Open Technical Databases](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1596)), establishing operational resources (ex: [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587) or [Obtain Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1588)), and/or for initial access (ex: [Supply Chain Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1195) or [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133)).
1813.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Software, ID T1592.002, under the Reconnaissance tactic and applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves gathering information about a victim's installed software, including types, versions, and security components like antivirus or SIEMs. Adversaries collect this data through methods such as active scanning of server banners, phishing, analyzing metadata from victim-hosted files like PDFs and images, or harvesting it from public sources like job postings and resumes. This intelligence is used to identify outdated software and cross-reference CVEs for potential exploitation, supporting follow-on actions like developing capabilities or gaining initial access. Associated threat groups include Andariel, Sandworm Team, and Magic Hound.
1813.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Software Code Analysis is a reconnaissance technique (T1592.002) under the Reconnaissance tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves gathering information about a victim's installed software, including types, versions, and security components like antivirus or SIEMs, to identify potential vulnerabilities and vectors for exploitation. This can be achieved through active scanning, phishing, metadata analysis of victim files, or by searching online datasets and public code repositories for leaked credentials or API keys.

1814.name: threat intelligence
1814.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may obtain access to generative artificial intelligence tools, such as large language models (LLMs), to aid various techniques during targeting. These tools may be used to inform, bolster, and enable a variety of malicious tasks, including conducting [Reconnaissance](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0043), creating basic scripts, assisting social engineering, and even developing payloads.(Citation: MSFT-AI) 

For example, by utilizing a publicly available LLM an adversary is essentially outsourcing or automating certain tasks to the tool. Using AI, the adversary may draft and generate content in a variety of written languages to be used in [Phishing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566)/[Phishing for Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598) campaigns. The same publicly available tool may further enable vulnerability or other offensive research supporting [Develop Capabilities](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587). AI tools may also automate technical tasks by generating, refining, or otherwise enhancing (e.g., [Obfuscated Files or Information](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027)) malicious scripts and payloads.(Citation: OpenAI-CTI) Finally, AI-generated text, images, audio, and video may be used for fraud, [Impersonation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1656), and other malicious activities.(Citation: Google-Vishing24)(Citation: IC3-AI24)(Citation: WSJ-Vishing-AI24)
1814.profile: [profile]Artificial Intelligence (T1588.007) is a Resource Development technique where adversaries obtain generative AI tools like LLMs to automate and enhance malicious tasks. These tools are used to draft multilingual phishing content, conduct vulnerability research, generate or obfuscate malicious scripts and payloads, and create synthetic media for impersonation and fraud, thereby supporting various phases of an attack. The technique is associated with the intrusion set 'Contagious Interview'.
1814.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "threat intelligence" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved information, it appears to be a general concept. The related techniques describe how adversaries exploit threat intelligence. Adversaries may search private data from threat intelligence vendors (T1597.001) to gather trends on target industries and successful TTPs. They also perform reconnaissance on their own published activity via "Search Threat Vendor Data" (T1681), where they have been observed replacing exposed indicators like malware hashes or taking down their own domains mentioned in reports to evade detection. This intelligence gathering supports planning and adapting future operations.

1815.name: encryption research and development
1815.uncertain_name: compromise software dependencies and development tools
1815.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate software dependencies and development tools prior to receipt by a final consumer for the purpose of data or system compromise. Applications often depend on external software to function properly. Popular open source projects that are used as dependencies in many applications, such as pip and NPM packages, may be targeted as a means to add malicious code to users of the dependency.(Citation: Trendmicro NPM Compromise)(Citation: Bitdefender NPM Repositories Compromised 2021)(Citation: MANDVI Malicious npm and PyPI Packages Disguised) This may also include abandoned packages, which in some cases could be re-registered by threat actors after being removed by adversaries.(Citation: The Hacker News PyPi Revival Hijack 2024) Adversaries may also employ "typosquatting" or name-confusion by choosing names similar to existing popular libraries or packages in order to deceive a user.(Citation: Ahmed Backdoors in Python and NPM Packages)(Citation: Meyer PyPI Supply Chain Attack Uncovered)(Citation: Checkmarx-oss-seo)

Additionally, CI/CD pipeline components, such as GitHub Actions, may be targeted in order to gain access to the building, testing, and deployment cycles of an application.(Citation: Unit 42 Palo Alto GitHub Actions Supply Chain Attack 2025) By adding malicious code into a GitHub action, a threat actor may be able to collect runtime credentials (e.g., via [Proc Filesystem](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003/007)) or insert further malicious components into the build pipelines for a second-order supply chain compromise.(Citation: OWASP CICD-SEC-4) As GitHub Actions are often dependent on other GitHub Actions, threat actors may be able to infect a large number of repositories via the compromise of a single Action.(Citation: Palo Alto Networks GitHub Actions Worm 2023)

Targeting may be specific to a desired victim set or may be distributed to a broad set of consumers but only move on to additional tactics on specific victims.
1815.profile: [profile]Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools (T1195.001) is a Supply Chain Compromise technique under the Initial Access tactic, targeting various platforms. It involves manipulating software dependencies like pip and NPM packages or CI/CD pipeline components such as GitHub Actions to introduce malicious code. Specific mechanics include typosquatting with similar package names, re-registering abandoned packages, and injecting code into GitHub Actions to harvest credentials or propagate further compromise across dependent repositories.[/profile]
1815.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "encryption research and development" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it relates to adversaries developing or employing cryptographic methods. This includes using symmetric encryption algorithms like AES or RC4 to conceal command and control traffic, implementing multilayer encryption by tunneling custom schemes within protocols like HTTPS, and exfiltrating data over symmetrically encrypted non-C2 channels, which may involve manually shared keys and create multiple encryption layers.

1828.name: Turla
1828.uncertain_mes: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is a cyber espionage threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB).  They have compromised victims in over 50 countries since at least 2004, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns, and leveraging in-house tools and malware, such as [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022).(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)
1828.profile: [profile]Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, Venomous Bear, and Waterbug, is a Russian cyber espionage group attributed to the FSB. Its key malware includes the Snake rootkit and the Uroburos backdoor. Known TTPs involve spearphishing, watering hole attacks, and the repurposing of tools from other threat actors like OilRig. The group has targeted government, military, diplomatic, and research sectors across more than 50 countries, primarily for intelligence collection.
1828.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most commonly known as Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, Krypton, Iron Hunter, and UNC4210. Its key malware includes the sophisticated Snake/Uroburos rootkit and backdoors like KopiLuwak, LunarWeb, and LunarMail. Its TTPs are characterized by spear-phishing with embedded macros, watering hole attacks, and the distinctive practice of hijacking and reusing malware and infrastructure from other threat groups. The group is widely attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically linked to the FSB. It primarily targets government, diplomatic, military, and media organizations across Europe, the Middle East, and Central Asia, with motivations centered on long-term strategic espionage.[/profile]
1828.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, and Group 88, is a sophisticated cyber espionage group attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors. Its key malware includes the Snake/Uroburos rootkit, along with tools like Mimikatz and PowerSploit, and it has been known to repurpose malware from other threat actors like OilRig. Key TTPs involve using the Windows Registry for payload storage, employing encryption, and leveraging spear-phishing with decoy links (e.g., fake Adobe domains). The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors in Europe and Central Asia, with motivations centered on long-term intelligence gathering and strategic espionage.

Its TTPs involve using encrypted payloads stored in the Registry, spear-phishing with decoy links (e.g., fake Adobe domains), and conducting detailed system reconnaissance. The group primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors across Europe and Central Asia, with motivations centered on espionage and intelligence gathering aligned with Russian strategic interests.

1837.name: Air Gap Evasion
1837.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may employ various means to detect and avoid debuggers. Debuggers are typically used by defenders to trace and/or analyze the execution of potential malware payloads.(Citation: ProcessHacker Github) Debugger evasion may include changing behaviors based on the results of the checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a debugged environment. Similar to [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497), if the adversary detects a debugger, they may alter their malware to disengage from the victim or conceal the core functions of the implant. They may also search for debugger artifacts before dropping secondary or additional payloads. Specific checks will vary based on the target and/or adversary. On Windows, this may involve [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as IsDebuggerPresent() and NtQueryInformationProcess(), or manually checking the BeingDebugged flag of the Process Environment Block (PEB). On Linux, this may involve querying `/proc/self/status` for the `TracerPID` field, which indicates whether or not the process is being traced by dynamic analysis tools.(Citation: Cado Security P2PInfect 2023)(Citation: Positive Technologies Hellhounds 2023) Other checks for debugging artifacts may also seek to enumerate hardware breakpoints, interrupt assembly opcodes, time checks, or measurements if exceptions are raised in the current process (assuming a present debugger would â€œswallowâ€ or handle the potential error).(Citation: hasherezade debug)(Citation: AlKhaser Debug)(Citation: vxunderground debug) Malware may also leverage Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to detect debuggers by throwing an exception and detecting whether the process is suspended. SEH handles both hardware and software expectations, providing control over the exceptions including support for debugging. If a debugger is present, the programâ€™s control will be transferred to the debugger, and the execution of the code will be suspended. If the debugger is not present, control will be transferred to the SEH handler, which will automatically handle the exception and allow the programâ€™s execution to continue.(Citation: Apriorit) Adversaries may use the information learned from these debugger checks during automated discovery to shape follow-on behaviors. Debuggers can also be evaded by detaching the process or flooding debug logs with meaningless data via messages produced by looping [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function calls such as OutputDebugStringW().(Citation: wardle evilquest partii)(Citation: Checkpoint Dridex Jan 2021)
1837.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique Debugger Evasion (T1622) under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows and Linux platforms. It involves malware detecting debuggers to alter its behavior, using specific checks like Windows API calls (IsDebuggerPresent, NtQueryInformationProcess) or Linux /proc/self/status queries for TracerPID, and employing Structured Exception Handling (SEH) to test for process suspension. Evasion methods include detaching the process or flooding logs with OutputDebugStringW calls. The intrusion set Turla has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1837.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Air Gap Evasion is a defense evasion technique used by adversaries to bypass physical air-gapped networks, which are isolated from unsecured networks like the internet. This technique involves methods to bridge the air gap, often by using removable media such as USB drives to transfer data or malware between disconnected systems. It may also involve leveraging other physical or unconventional communication channels to establish a covert connection for command and control or data exfiltration from the isolated environment.

1838.name: Brute Force Scanning
1838.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use brute force techniques to gain access to accounts when passwords are unknown or when password hashes are obtained.(Citation: TrendMicro Pawn Storm Dec 2020) Without knowledge of the password for an account or set of accounts, an adversary may systematically guess the password using a repetitive or iterative mechanism.(Citation: Dragos Crashoverride 2018) Brute forcing passwords can take place via interaction with a service that will check the validity of those credentials or offline against previously acquired credential data, such as password hashes.

Brute forcing credentials may take place at various points during a breach. For example, adversaries may attempt to brute force access to [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) within a victim environment leveraging knowledge gathered from other post-compromise behaviors such as [OS Credential Dumping](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1003), [Account Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1087), or [Password Policy Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1201). Adversaries may also combine brute forcing activity with behaviors such as [External Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1133) as part of Initial Access. 

If an adversary guesses the correct password but fails to login to a compromised account due to location-based conditional access policies, they may change their infrastructure until they match the victimâ€™s location and therefore bypass those policies.(Citation: ReliaQuest Health Care Social Engineering Campaign 2024)
1838.profile: [profile]Brute Force, identified as T1110 under the Credential Access tactic, is a technique where adversaries systematically guess passwords through repetitive mechanisms. This can be executed online by interacting with authentication services or offline against acquired password hashes. It is often combined with other techniques like External Remote Services for initial access or OS Credential Dumping for post-compromise credential harvesting. The Turla intrusion-set is among the groups known to use this method.[/profile]
1838.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Brute Force Scanning is a reconnaissance technique for identifying accessible infrastructure, not for credential discovery. It involves systematically probing networks, services, or web directories using iterative, brute-force methods. This can be performed using tools like Dirb or GoBuster with generic or custom wordlists to enumerate pages, directories, or cloud storage buckets, revealing potential targets for further exploitation.

1839.name: BGP Hijacking
1839.profile: [profile]BGP Hijacking is a network-based technique where adversaries manipulate the Border Gateway Protocol to illegitimately redirect internet traffic. This is achieved by announcing false network routes, causing other Autonomous Systems to send data through the adversary-controlled path, enabling traffic interception, man-in-the-middle attacks, or denial of service. The intrusion-set Turla has been associated with employing this method.
1839.profile_without_enhance: [profile]BGP Hijacking is a network manipulation technique where adversaries illicitly alter Border Gateway Protocol routing information to redirect internet traffic. This is achieved by announcing unauthorized IP prefixes or manipulating AS_PATH attributes, causing traffic intended for a legitimate network to be routed through the adversary-controlled systems. The technique enables traffic interception, man-in-the-middle attacks, and denial-of-service by exploiting the trust-based nature of BGP in core internet routing.

1842.name: Shared Codebase
1842.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may execute malicious payloads via loading shared modules. Shared modules are executable files that are loaded into processes to provide access to reusable code, such as specific custom functions or invoking OS API functions (i.e., [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106)).

Adversaries may use this functionality as a way to execute arbitrary payloads on a victim system. For example, adversaries can modularize functionality of their malware into shared objects that perform various functions such as managing C2 network communications or execution of specific actions on objective.

The Linux & macOS module loader can load and execute shared objects from arbitrary local paths. This functionality resides in `dlfcn.h` in functions such as `dlopen` and `dlsym`. Although macOS can execute `.so` files, common practice uses `.dylib` files.(Citation: Apple Dev Dynamic Libraries)(Citation: Linux Shared Libraries)(Citation: RotaJakiro 2021 netlab360 analysis)(Citation: Unit42 OceanLotus 2017)

The Windows module loader can be instructed to load DLLs from arbitrary local paths and arbitrary Universal Naming Convention (UNC) network paths. This functionality resides in `NTDLL.dll` and is part of the Windows [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) which is called from functions like `LoadLibrary` at run time.(Citation: Microsoft DLL)
1842.profile: [profile]Shared Codebase, known as T1129 within MITRE ATT&CK, is a Defense Evasion and Execution technique applicable to Linux, macOS, and Windows. It involves adversaries executing malicious payloads by loading shared modules like DLLs or shared objects. This is achieved using platform-specific loaders: the Windows Native API via functions like `LoadLibrary` to load from local or UNC paths, and the Linux/macOS `dlfcn.h` functions `dlopen`/`dlsym` to load `.so` or `.dylib` files from arbitrary local paths, allowing modular malware functionality such as C2 communications.
1842.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Shared Codebase is a technique where adversaries leverage a common underlying code foundation across multiple malware variants or tools to enable consistent functionality, rapid development, and shared indicators. This practice allows for modular malware design, where core components like command-and-control communications or payload execution are reused, increasing efficiency for threat actors. The shared elements can facilitate detection through code similarity analysis across different attacks.

1843.name: Outlook Add-in Persistence
1843.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office add-ins to obtain persistence on a compromised system. Office add-ins can be used to add functionality to Office programs. (Citation: Microsoft Office Add-ins) There are different types of add-ins that can be used by the various Office products; including Word/Excel add-in Libraries (WLL/XLL), VBA add-ins, Office Component Object Model (COM) add-ins, automation add-ins, VBA Editor (VBE), Visual Studio Tools for Office (VSTO) add-ins, and Outlook add-ins. (Citation: MRWLabs Office Persistence Add-ins)(Citation: FireEye Mail CDS 2018)

Add-ins can be used to obtain persistence because they can be set to execute code when an Office application starts.
1843.profile: [profile]Outlook Add-in Persistence is a sub-technique under T1137.006, categorized under the Persistence tactic and applicable to the Windows platform. It involves adversaries abusing Microsoft Outlook add-ins to execute malicious code automatically when Outlook starts, thereby maintaining persistence on a compromised system. This method is a specific type of Office application startup abuse, and the intrusion-set Turla has been associated with such persistence mechanisms.
1843.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Outlook Add-in Persistence, identified as sub-technique T1137.006 under the Office Application Startup (T1137) technique, falls under the Persistence tactic and targets the Windows platform. It involves adversaries abusing Microsoft Outlook add-ins, which are components that extend functionality, by configuring malicious add-ins to automatically execute code whenever the Outlook application starts, thereby maintaining a foothold on the compromised system. This method is a specific type of Office add-in abuse alongside other Outlook-based persistence mechanisms like rules and forms.

1844.name: Mimic Legitimate Requests
1844.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may rename legitimate / system utilities to try to evade security mechanisms concerning the usage of those utilities. Security monitoring and control mechanisms may be in place for legitimate utilities adversaries are capable of abusing, including both built-in binaries and tools such as PSExec, AutoHotKey, and IronPython.(Citation: LOLBAS Main Site)(Citation: Huntress Python Malware 2025)(Citation: The DFIR Report AutoHotKey 2023)(Citation: Splunk Detect Renamed PSExec) It may be possible to bypass those security mechanisms by renaming the utility prior to utilization (ex: rename rundll32.exe).(Citation: Elastic Masquerade Ball) An alternative case occurs when a legitimate utility is copied or moved to a different directory and renamed to avoid detections based on these utilities executing from non-standard paths.(Citation: F-Secure CozyDuke)
1844.profile: [profile]The entity "Mimic Legitimate Requests" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Masquerading: Rename Legitimate Utilities" (ID: T1036.003) under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves adversaries renaming trusted system utilities or tools (e.g., `rundll32.exe`, PSExec, AutoHotKey) to bypass security controls that monitor for the execution of specific known binaries. An alternative method is copying a legitimate utility to a non-standard directory and renaming it to avoid path-based detections. It has been associated with groups including APT38, Gallium, APT32, Daggerfly, Menupass, and Lazarus Group.[/profile]
1844.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Mimic Legitimate Requests" is a technique where adversaries disguise malicious network traffic to appear as normal, legitimate requests from trusted protocols or services, such as HTTPS, to evade detection and blend in with regular network activity. This method is used to conceal command and control communications and can involve manipulating HTTP headers, URI endpoints, or SSL certificates to impersonate services like Gmail or Google Drive.

1846.name: polymorphic obfuscation techniques
1846.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may utilize polymorphic code (also known as metamorphic or mutating code) to evade detection. Polymorphic code is a type of software capable of changing its runtime footprint during code execution.(Citation: polymorphic-blackberry) With each execution of the software, the code is mutated into a different version of itself that achieves the same purpose or objective as the original. This functionality enables the malware to evade traditional signature-based defenses, such as antivirus and antimalware tools.(Citation: polymorphic-sentinelone) 
Other obfuscation techniques can be used in conjunction with polymorphic code to accomplish the intended effects, including using mutation engines to conduct actions such as [Software Packing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002), [Command Obfuscation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/010), or [Encrypted/Encoded File](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/013).(Citation: polymorphic-linkedin)(Citation: polymorphic-medium)
1846.profile: [profile]Polymorphic Obfuscation Techniques, also known as polymorphic code and identified as T1027.014, is a Defense Evasion technique used across multiple platforms. Its core technical mechanic involves a mutation engine that alters the software's runtime footprint with each execution, creating a functionally equivalent but structurally different version to evade signature-based detection. It is often used in conjunction with other obfuscation sub-techniques like Software Packing or Command Obfuscation. The intrusion set Turla has been associated with related obfuscation methods.[/profile]
1846.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Polymorphic Obfuscation Techniques is a sub-technique of Obfuscated Files or Information (T1027) within the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It involves using code that mutates its runtime footprint with each execution to evade signature-based detection, often in conjunction with other methods like software packing or command obfuscation. This technique enables malware to maintain its functionality while altering its observable characteristics.

1847.name: embedded macros in office documents
1847.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office templates to obtain persistence on a compromised system. Microsoft Office contains templates that are part of common Office applications and are used to customize styles. The base templates within the application are used each time an application starts. (Citation: Microsoft Change Normal Template) Office Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros (Citation: MSDN VBA in Office) can be inserted into the base template and used to execute code when the respective Office application starts in order to obtain persistence. Examples for both Word and Excel have been discovered and published. By default, Word has a Normal.dotm template created that can be modified to include a malicious macro. Excel does not have a template file created by default, but one can be added that will automatically be loaded.(Citation: enigma0x3 normal.dotm)(Citation: Hexacorn Office Template Macros) Shared templates may also be stored and pulled from remote locations.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) Word Normal.dotm location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\Normal.dotm Excel Personal.xlsb location:
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Excel\XLSTART\PERSONAL.XLSB Adversaries may also change the location of the base template to point to their own by hijacking the application's search order, e.g. Word 2016 will first look for Normal.dotm under C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Office\root\Office16\, or by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key. By modifying the GlobalDotName registry key an adversary can specify an arbitrary location, file name, and file extension to use for the template that will be loaded on application startup. To abuse GlobalDotName, adversaries may first need to register the template as a trusted document or place it in a trusted location.(Citation: GlobalDotName Jun 2019) An adversary may need to enable macros to execute unrestricted depending on the system or enterprise security policy on use of macros.
1847.profile: [profile]Office Template Macros (T1137.001) is a Persistence technique for Windows platforms where adversaries insert malicious VBA macros into base Office templates like Word's Normal.dotm or Excel's Personal.xlsb, which execute code when the respective application starts. Persistence can also be achieved by modifying the GlobalDotName registry key to point to a remote or alternate template location, potentially requiring the template to be placed in a trusted location. The intrusion-set Turla has been associated with this technique.
1847.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Embedded Macros in Office Documents is a technique where adversaries insert malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macros into Office files (like .doc, .xls) to execute code when the document is opened. This technique, often used for initial access and execution, operates on the Windows platform. Attackers may hide the malicious VBA source code through methods like VBA stomping, leaving only the compiled p-code to evade static analysis, while the payload executes if the Office version matches. The method relies on users enabling macros, and it is commonly associated with phishing campaigns to deliver the malicious documents.

1848.name: kopiluwak
1848.uncertain_mes: [KOPILUWAK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1075) is a JavaScript-based reconnaissance tool that has been used for victim profiling and C2 since at least 2017.(Citation: Mandiant Suspected Turla Campaign February 2023)
1848.profile: [profile]KOPILUWAK, also known as kopiluwak, is a JavaScript-based reconnaissance tool attributed to the Turla intrusion set. It has been used for victim profiling and command and control (C2) since at least 2017. The malware is delivered via malicious documents, such as a doc file mimicking an embassy event agenda, distributed through phishing emails. Its primary function is reconnaissance, and it operates on platforms supporting JavaScript.[/profile]
1848.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Kopiluwak, also known as KopiLuwak, is a malware attributed to the Turla group. It functions as a dropper, with variants including an MSIL dropper and JavaScript droppers such as "Scr.js" and "appidpolicyconverter.js." It is delivered via malicious documents, often PDF decoys like "Save the Date G20 Digital Economy Taskforce 23 24 October.pdf," mimicking event agendas in phishing emails. Its key behaviors include initial reconnaissance and dropping payloads.

1849.name: uninstall command
1849.profile: [profile]The entity "uninstall command" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is a specific action used by adversaries, notably the Turla intrusion set, to remove software or components from a compromised system. This command execution is a technical mechanic for defense evasion or persistence removal, typically performed via command-line interpreters or utilities like InstallUtil for .NET binaries. The technique is platform-agnostic, applicable where command execution is possible, and serves to eliminate traces or unwanted tools post-intrusion.
1849.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "uninstall command" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it refers to adversaries using legitimate uninstall commands or utilities, such as the Windows Installer tool `msiexec.exe` with the `/x` or `/uninstall` option, to remove software. This can be used for defense evasion to delete traces of malicious tools or for impact to disrupt system services by uninstalling critical applications. The technique is platform-agnostic but commonly associated with Windows.

1850.name: sleep command
1850.profile: [profile]The entity "sleep command" is a technique used for delay execution, aligning with MITRE ATT&CK Tactic Execution (TA0002) and potentially Defense Evasion (TA0005). It functions by employing programmatic sleep commands or native system scheduling to pause malware execution, often to evade automated analysis environments that have time thresholds. This behavior can be implemented using loops of benign commands like `ping` or through API hammering to overload sandboxes. The intrusion-set Turla has been associated with related command obfuscation techniques.
1850.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "sleep command" is a technique used by adversaries to delay malware execution, often for evasion or to ensure proper timing of prior commands. It is associated with the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1678, "Delay Execution," under the tactic Execution. This technique involves using programmatic sleep commands or native system scheduling to pause execution, which can help bypass time-based sandbox detection by exceeding analysis thresholds. Adversaries may also use benign loops, like repeated ping commands, to achieve similar delays, as seen in campaigns by groups like Mustang Panda.

1851.name: file deletion
1851.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity. Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary (ex: [Ingress Tool Transfer](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105)) may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how. Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint. There are tools available from the host operating system to perform cleanup, but adversaries may use other tools as well.(Citation: Microsoft SDelete July 2016) Examples of built-in [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059) functions include del on Windows, rm or unlink on Linux and macOS, and `rm` on ESXi.
1851.profile: [profile]File Deletion, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.004 under the Defense Evasion tactic, is a post-intrusion cleanup method used across Windows, Linux, macOS, and ESXi platforms. Adversaries employ this technique to remove traces of their activity, such as dropped malware or tools, by using native command-line utilities like `del` on Windows or `rm`/`unlink` on Unix-based systems, as well as specialized tools like SDelete. This action minimizes forensic evidence and is associated with numerous threat groups including Turla, APT29, and Lazarus Group.[/profile]
1851.profile_without_enhance: [profile]File Deletion, identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1070.004 (File Deletion), is a Defense Evasion tactic used across Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. It involves adversaries removing non-native files, such as malware or tools, to erase forensic traces. This is commonly performed using native OS commands like `del` on Windows or `rm`/`unlink` on Linux/macOS, or with utilities like Windows Sysinternals SDelete, during or after an intrusion to minimize their footprint.

1852.name: WScript.Shell.Run()
1852.profile: [profile]WScript.Shell.Run() is a method for executing commands and scripts, often used by adversaries like Turla for initial execution. It maps to the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.003 (Windows Command Shell) under the Execution tactic on Windows platforms. This method allows scripts to run commands via the Windows command shell (cmd.exe), enabling the execution of payloads and other malicious activities directly from script contexts, facilitating evasion and automation in attacks.
1852.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "WScript.Shell.Run()" is a method for execution, likely mapped to the MITRE ATT&CK technique T1059.005 (Visual Basic) under the Execution tactic on Windows platforms. It functions by using the Windows Script Host's WScript.Shell object to run commands or scripts, providing a mechanism for adversaries to execute payloads without invoking a standard command prompt, thereby aiding in defense evasion. This method is commonly leveraged within malicious scripts and macros.

1853.name: POST request
1853.profile: [profile]The entity "POST request" is a fundamental web protocol action, not a distinct MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is a common method for sending data to a server over HTTP/S. In a threat context, adversaries frequently abuse POST requests within various techniques, such as for data exfiltration to web services (T1567.004) or command and control communication. The intrusion-set Turla is known to utilize such web-based mechanisms in their operations.
1853.profile_without_enhance: [profile]POST request is a foundational network technique used within the Exfiltration Over Web Service (T1567) tactic, applicable across multiple platforms. It functions as the primary HTTP method for sending data from a client to a server, making it a common mechanism for adversaries to manually exfiltrate staged data to a specified URL endpoint, such as a webhook. This method leverages standard HTTPS traffic, which can help the activity blend with normal network communications to a common service.

1854.name: mailform.pif
1854.profile: [profile]mailform.pif is a file created and executed by the KopiLuwak malware, which is attributed to the Turla intrusion set. The malware uses the file to run arbitrary commands via Wscript.shell.run(). The file is written after the malware RC4 encrypts C2 response data using the key "2f532d6baec3d0ec7b1f98aed4774843". After execution, the file is deleted following a 30-second sleep period.
1854.profile_without_enhance: [profile]mailform.pif is a component or payload file associated with the Kopiluwak malware, which is attributed to the Turla group. Its key technical behaviors involve being written to disk after RC4 encryption with the key "2f532d6baec3d0ec7b1f98aed4774843" and being executed via Wscript.shell.run() for arbitrary command execution. It is subsequently deleted by the malware's scripts, and its presence is checked and managed during C2 communication via HTTP POST requests.

1855.name: 2008 attack on US Central Command
1855.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls. Downgrade attacks typically take advantage of a systemâ€™s backward compatibility to force it into less secure modes of operation. 

Adversaries may downgrade and use various less-secure versions of features of a system, such as [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s or even network protocols that can be abused to enable [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) or [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040).(Citation: Praetorian TLS Downgrade Attack 2014) For example, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) versions 5+ includes Script Block Logging (SBL), which can record executed script content. However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.(Citation: CrowdStrike BGH Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL 2018)(Citation: att_def_ps_logging)

Adversaries may similarly target network traffic to downgrade from an encrypted HTTPS connection to an unsecured HTTP connection that exposes network data in clear text.(Citation: Targeted SSL Stripping Attacks Are Real)(Citation: Crowdstrike Downgrade) On Windows systems, adversaries may downgrade the boot manager to a vulnerable version that bypasses Secure Boot, granting the ability to disable various operating system security mechanisms.(Citation: SafeBreach)
1855.profile: [profile]Downgrade Attack, identified as T1562.010 under the Impair Defenses tactic, is a technique that exploits system backward compatibility to force less secure operational modes, primarily on Windows platforms. Adversaries execute this by downgrading features like PowerShell to versions lacking security controls such as Script Block Logging, downgrading network connections from HTTPS to unencrypted HTTP to facilitate sniffing, or downgrading the Windows boot manager to bypass Secure Boot and disable OS security mechanisms. The intrusion set Turla has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1855.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "2008 attack on US Central Command" is a specific historical incident rather than a standardized MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, this attack involved a Denial-of-Service (DoS) component, potentially degrading or blocking service availability, and may have been conducted for political purposes. The attack likely targeted endpoint resources to deny service availability.

1856.name: satellite-based C&C registrations
1856.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may employ various time-based methods to detect virtualization and analysis environments, particularly those that attempt to manipulate time mechanisms to simulate longer elapses of time. This may include enumerating time-based properties, such as uptime or the system clock. 

Adversaries may use calls like `GetTickCount` and `GetSystemTimeAsFileTime` to discover if they are operating within a virtual machine or sandbox, or may be able to identify a sandbox accelerating time by sampling and calculating the expected value for an environment's timestamp before and after execution of a sleep function.(Citation: ISACA Malware Tricks)
1856.profile: [profile]Time Based Checks, designated T1497.003 under the Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion tactic, is a technique used to detect analysis environments by sampling and calculating timestamps. Adversaries, such as the Turla group, employ API calls like GetTickCount and GetSystemTimeAsFileTime to measure system uptime or clock progression, identifying discrepancies that indicate a sandbox accelerating time to simulate longer execution periods.[/profile]
1856.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "satellite-based C&C registrations" is a command and control technique. It involves adversaries establishing communication channels by registering malicious domains or infrastructure that leverage satellite-based internet services, which can provide resilience and evade traditional geolocation-based blocking. This method is part of the broader Command and Control tactic.

1858.name: network reconnaissance
1858.profile: [profile]Network Reconnaissance is a general reconnaissance technique for gathering information about a victim's network environment, including its topology, devices, and security appliances. This information is collected through methods like active scanning or phishing for information and is used by groups like Turla and UNC4210 to identify opportunities for subsequent attacks, such as establishing operational resources or gaining initial access.[/profile]
1858.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Network Reconnaissance is a general reconnaissance technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework, primarily associated with the Reconnaissance tactic. It involves gathering information about a victim's network infrastructure to support subsequent targeting. This can be achieved through various direct methods like active scanning, which probes victim infrastructure via network traffic, or by collecting data on network topology, devices, and security appliances. The gathered intelligence, such as IP addresses, hostnames, running services, and firewall configurations, is used to identify opportunities for initial access, lateral movement, and establishing operational resources.

1859.name: victim profiling
1859.profile: [profile]Victim Profiling is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries gather comprehensive information about a target to inform subsequent attack stages. This involves collecting data on the victim's identity (T1589), organization (T1591), network (T1590), and host systems (T1592) through methods like phishing, active scanning, and searching victim-owned websites (T1594). The gathered intelligence, which can include personal details, network topology, and software configurations, is used to craft targeted lures, establish operational resources, and identify initial access vectors.[/profile]
1859.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Victim Profiling is a reconnaissance technique where adversaries gather detailed information about a target individual or organization to inform and enable subsequent attack stages. This involves collecting data such as personal identities (names, emails), organizational structure (departments, key roles), network details (IP ranges, domains), and host configurations (OS, software) from sources like social media, victim-owned websites, phishing, or technical databases. The gathered intelligence is used to craft targeted lures, establish operational resources, and identify initial access vectors like phishing or trusted relationships.

1860.name: Adobe Flash Installer (Fake)
1860.profile: [profile]Adobe Flash Installer (Fake), also known as holcus installer (adware), is a malvertising tool attributed to the Turla intrusion set. It masquerades as a legitimate Adobe Flash installer to deceive users, often downloading a real installer from a source like Google Drive to appear legitimate. Its primary target platform is systems where users are tricked into installing the fake software, typically through malvertising campaigns. Infrastructure includes the use of Google Drive for hosting components.
1860.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Adobe Flash Installer (Fake) is a malware family that masquerades as a legitimate Adobe Flash Player installer. It is associated with the Turla group and uses a deceptive technique where it downloads and executes a genuine Adobe installer from a Google Drive URL to create a false sense of security for the victim. This malware is known for targeting users through malvertising and fake update schemes.

1861.name: Data-Stealing Malware
1861.uncertain_mes:
A .NET rat targets Mongolia
A new document royal road v7 installs a backdoor in .NET. a first executable is dropped \os03C2.tmp. This exe has many similarities with older campaigns using by Operation LagTime or Tonto Team.
Document
The decoy document is a document about infection of covid19 in Russia send to the Mongolia Authorities. The document is fake signed A. Amarsaikhan.
1861.profile: [profile]The malware, known as nmass, is a .NET-based remote access trojan (RAT) and data stealer. It is attributed to the Turla intrusion set, based on similarities to older campaigns. Its key TTPs include deployment via a Royal Road v7 document lure (a fake COVID-19 report for Mongolian authorities) and dropping an initial executable (os03C2.tmp). The malware's primary target platform is Windows, and it functions to establish a backdoor for persistent access and data exfiltration.[/profile]
1861.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Name: Data-Stealing Malware. Aliases: Not specified. Attributed Groups: Not specified. Key TTPs/Technical Behaviors: Steals passwords, cookies, autofill data, browser history from Chromium and Mozilla browsers; collects files from specified paths; captures screens; steals system information, Telegram session files, Steam application data, and Electrum wallet data; can load and execute additional modules; uses multithreading for operations like file theft and data harvesting. Target Platforms: Windows systems. Infrastructure/Supplementary Info: Associated with generic data-stealing capabilities as seen in related entities like PurpleWave and Pennywise stealer.

1864.name: Man-in-the-Middle Attack
1864.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique to support follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040), [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002), or replay attacks ([Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212)). By abusing features of common networking protocols that can determine the flow of network traffic (e.g. ARP, DNS, LLMNR, etc.), adversaries may force a device to communicate through an adversary controlled system so they can collect information or perform additional actions.(Citation: Rapid7 MiTM Basics)

For example, adversaries may manipulate victim DNS settings to enable other malicious activities such as preventing/redirecting users from accessing legitimate sites and/or pushing additional malware.(Citation: ttint_rat)(Citation: dns_changer_trojans)(Citation: ad_blocker_with_miner) Adversaries may also manipulate DNS and leverage their position in order to intercept user credentials, including access tokens ([Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)) and session cookies ([Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)).(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)(Citation: Token tactics) [Downgrade Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/010)s can also be used to establish an AiTM position, such as by negotiating a less secure, deprecated, or weaker version of communication protocol (SSL/TLS) or encryption algorithm.(Citation: mitm_tls_downgrade_att)(Citation: taxonomy_downgrade_att_tls)(Citation: tlseminar_downgrade_att)

Adversaries may also leverage the AiTM position to attempt to monitor and/or modify traffic, such as in [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). Adversaries can setup a position similar to AiTM to prevent traffic from flowing to the appropriate destination, potentially to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) and/or in support of a [Network Denial of Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498).
1864.profile: [profile]Adversary-in-the-Middle (AiTM) is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1557 under the Collection tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It works by positioning a system between networked devices to intercept or manipulate traffic, achieved by abusing protocols like ARP, DNS, or LLMNR to redirect communication. This enables follow-on actions such as network sniffing, credential theft by capturing tokens and cookies, and data manipulation. It can also be established via downgrade attacks on protocols like SSL/TLS. The intrusion-set Turla has been associated with this technique.[/profile]
1864.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Man-in-the-Middle Attack is a foundational network attack technique where an adversary positions themselves between two communicating parties to intercept, monitor, or manipulate traffic. It is often implemented by abusing network protocols like ARP, DNS, or LLMNR to redirect traffic through an adversary-controlled system. This position enables follow-on actions such as network sniffing, credential theft via intercepted tokens or cookies, and data manipulation. Downgrade attacks on protocols like SSL/TLS can also be used to establish a weaker, interceptable connection.

1866.name: Downloading Over HTTP
1866.profile: [profile]Downloading Over HTTP is a technique used in the Command and Control tactic, where adversaries download malicious files or tools over the unencrypted HTTP protocol. This method allows them to blend with normal web traffic and avoid detection by network security tools that may not inspect HTTP traffic as thoroughly as encrypted HTTPS. The technique is commonly used by groups like Turla. It is a sub-technique of Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol, sharing the use of standard web ports to facilitate data transfer without encryption.
1866.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Downloading Over HTTP is a technique within the Command and Control tactic, where adversaries download malicious files or tools over the HTTP protocol. This method often uses standard ports like TCP:80 to blend with normal web traffic and evade detection. The technique is applicable across multiple platforms, including Windows, Linux, and macOS.

1867.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Skipper/WhiteAtlas, also known as skipper, is a malware attributed to the Turla group. It is delivered via .JS attachments, often alongside other malware like WhiteBear, as part of campaigns such as Cobra Carbon System, Gazer, and Mosquito.

1869.name: Uroburos
1869.uncertain_mes: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is a cyber espionage threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB).  They have compromised victims in over 50 countries since at least 2004, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns, and leveraging in-house tools and malware, such as [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022).(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)
1869.profile: [profile]Turla, also known as Uroburos, Snake, Venomous Bear, and Waterbug, is a cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB). It is distinguished by its use of the sophisticated rootkit and backdoor malware also named Uroburos (or Snake). The group primarily conducts watering hole and spearphishing campaigns, targeting a wide range of sectors across over 50 countries, including government, military, embassies, and research organizations, with motivations centered on long-term intelligence gathering.
1869.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity 'Uroburos' is a sophisticated cyber espionage group, most accurately standardized as **Turla**. It is also known by numerous aliases including Snake, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, Krypton, UNC4210, and Pfinet. Its key malware is the custom Snake/Uroburos rootkit, alongside tools like the KopiLuwak dropper and the Lunar suite. Distinctive TTPs involve spear-phishing, watering hole attacks, and the unique practice of hijacking and repurposing other threat actors' malware and infrastructure. The group is widely attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically linked to the FSB. It primarily targets government, diplomatic, military, and media sectors across Europe, the Middle East, and Central Asia for long-term strategic intelligence gathering.[/profile]
1869.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set 'Uroburos' is a highly sophisticated cyber espionage group, most commonly attributed to the Russian-linked APT Turla (also known as Snake, Venomous Bear, and Waterbug). It is distinguished by its use of the complex, modular rootkit malware also named Uroburos (or Snake). The group's operations are characterized by advanced stealth techniques and a focus on long-term intelligence gathering, primarily targeting government, diplomatic, and military sectors across Europe and the Middle East. Its activities are believed to be state-sponsored and motivated by strategic geopolitical espionage.
1869.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]Uroburos is a highly sophisticated cyber espionage rootkit and malware platform, which is a core component of the advanced persistent threat (APT) group widely known as Turla (also aliased as Snake, Waterbug, Venomous Bear, and Group 88). The group's key malware includes the Uroburos rootkit itself, along with associated tools like Pfinet. Its Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) are characterized by complex, multi-stage infections and stealthy, persistent network access. The group is strongly attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, with technical analyses indicating "Russian roots." Its primary motivation is cyber espionage, targeting government, diplomatic, and military sectors globally, with a historical focus on entities in Eastern Europe, Central Asia, and NATO countries.
1869.profile_without_enhance_20: [profile]Turla, also known as Uroburos, Snake, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, Krypton, UNC4210, and numerous other aliases, is a sophisticated cyber espionage group widely attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically linked to the FSB. Its key malware includes the Snake/Uroburos rootkit, the KopiLuwak dropper, and the Lunar suite. Distinctive TTPs involve spear-phishing, watering hole attacks via compromised websites, and the unique practice of repurposing malware stolen from other threat actors. It primarily targets government, diplomatic, and military sectors across Europe, Central Asia, and the Middle East for long-term strategic intelligence gathering.

1870.name: Poison Bear
1870.profile: [profile]Poison Bear, also known as Poison Carp, is an intrusion set attributed to or showing overlaps with the Russian-linked Turla group. Its arsenal includes the Poison Ivy remote access trojan, as indicated by multiple associated SHA256 hashes. The group's aliases and tools suggest a focus on espionage, with its activities and malware deployment aligning with patterns of state-sponsored cyber operations targeting strategic information. Its victimology and specific campaigns require further detailed analysis for precise sector and regional attribution.
1870.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Poison Bear is an intrusion set strongly believed to be a sub-group or alias of the Russian state-sponsored Turla APT (also known as Snake, Venomous Bear). Its key malware includes the Poison Ivy remote access trojan, as indicated by related hash data. The group's TTPs and targeting are consistent with its parent group, focusing on cyber espionage against government, diplomatic, and military sectors, primarily in Europe, the Middle East, and Central Asia, for strategic intelligence collection.[/profile]
1870.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set known as 'Poison Bear' is likely associated with the Russian-linked group tracked as TA2101, also known as Pinchy Spider, Tunnel Spider, and Storm-0216. This group is distinguished by its use of the Poison Ivy remote access trojan (RAT) for backdoor access. Its operations are primarily attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and it focuses on intelligence collection, targeting government, diplomatic, and think-tank sectors in Europe and North America. The group's activities show overlaps with other clusters like TA428 (Colourful Panda) and Mimic Spider, indicating a complex and potentially collaborative espionage ecosystem.
1870.profile_without_enhance_0_no_hsage: [profile]The intrusion set known as 'Poison Bear' is a suspected cyber espionage group. It is believed to be linked to or an alias for the threat actor tracked as TA428, also known as Colourful Panda and Bronze Dudley. This group is associated with the use of the Poison Ivy remote access trojan (RAT) as a key tool in its operations. Its activities are primarily attributed to Chinese state-sponsored interests, with a focus on cyber espionage targeting government and diplomatic entities, particularly in East Asia and Europe. The group's motivation is intelligence gathering to support national strategic objectives.
