1887.name: Packet Spoofing
1887.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.(Citation: rfc2131) The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 1. The client broadcasts a `DISCOVER` message. 2. The server responds with an `OFFER` message, which includes an available network address. 3. The client broadcasts a `REQUEST` message, which includes the network address offered. 4. The server acknowledges with an `ACK` message and the client receives the network configuration parameters. Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.(Citation: new_rogue_DHCP_serv_malware)(Citation: w32.tidserv.g) Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network. DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a INFORMATION-REQUEST (code 11) message to the All_DHCP_Relay_Agents_and_Servers multicast address.(Citation: rfc3315) Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations. Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, [Service Exhaustion Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002)) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a networkâ€™s DHCP allocation pool.
1887.profile: [profile]DHCP Spoofing is MITRE ATT&CK technique T1557.003 under the Credential Access tactic, applicable to Network platforms. It involves an adversary deploying a rogue DHCP server on a victim network to intercept and respond to client DHCP requests (like DISCOVER or INFORMATION-REQUEST messages) with malicious network configurations, such as adversary-controlled DNS servers. This establishes an adversary-in-the-middle position to redirect and collect network traffic, including unencrypted credentials, and can also enable follow-on network sniffing or be abused for DHCP exhaustion attacks. The intrusion-set Turla has been associated with this technique.
1887.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Packet Spoofing is a network-based technique where adversaries forge or manipulate packet header information, such as the source IP address, to conceal the origin of traffic, bypass access controls, or enable man-in-the-middle attacks. This technique is foundational to various specific spoofing sub-techniques like DHCP Spoofing (T1557.003), which involves acting as a rogue server to redirect traffic. The core mechanic involves crafting and sending network packets with falsified fields to deceive network systems and security measures.

1888.name: MITM Attack
1888.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls. Downgrade attacks typically take advantage of a systemâ€™s backward compatibility to force it into less secure modes of operation. 

Adversaries may downgrade and use various less-secure versions of features of a system, such as [Command and Scripting Interpreter](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059)s or even network protocols that can be abused to enable [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) or [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040).(Citation: Praetorian TLS Downgrade Attack 2014) For example, [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) versions 5+ includes Script Block Logging (SBL), which can record executed script content. However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.(Citation: CrowdStrike BGH Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL 2018)(Citation: att_def_ps_logging)

Adversaries may similarly target network traffic to downgrade from an encrypted HTTPS connection to an unsecured HTTP connection that exposes network data in clear text.(Citation: Targeted SSL Stripping Attacks Are Real)(Citation: Crowdstrike Downgrade) On Windows systems, adversaries may downgrade the boot manager to a vulnerable version that bypasses Secure Boot, granting the ability to disable various operating system security mechanisms.(Citation: SafeBreach)
1888.profile: [profile]Downgrade Attack, identified as T1562.010 under the Impair Defenses tactic, operates on multiple platforms by exploiting system backward compatibility to force less secure modes. Technical mechanics include executing older PowerShell versions to bypass Script Block Logging, downgrading HTTPS to unencrypted HTTP to expose data, and manipulating a system's boot manager to bypass Secure Boot. This technique can facilitate adversary-in-the-middle positions and is associated with groups like Turla.[/profile]
1888.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "MITM Attack" aligns with the MITRE ATT&CK technique Adversary-in-the-Middle (AiTM), identified as T1557 under the Collection tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves positioning between networked devices by abusing protocols like ARP, DNS, or LLMNR to intercept and potentially manipulate traffic. It can facilitate credential theft, data manipulation, and network sniffing, and may be established through methods like Downgrade Attacks to force less secure communication modes or by deploying rogue Wi-Fi access points in Evil Twin attacks.

1893.name: Commercial Hacking Tools
1893.uncertain_mes: [Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0047) is a rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team as a method of persistence for remote access software. (Citation: TrendMicro Hacking Team UEFI)
1893.profile: [profile]The entity is the Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit, a rootkit developed by the commercial company Hacking Team. It functions as a persistence mechanism for remote access software by infecting the UEFI/BIOS firmware of a system. It has been used by the Turla intrusion set. Its target platform is systems with UEFI firmware.
1893.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Commercial Hacking Tools is a category of malware encompassing various customized or commercially developed offensive tools, such as the Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit, BypassBoss, Stowaway, and JuicyPotato. These tools are often developed by private companies like Hacking Team for purposes like persistence and remote access, and are utilized by diverse threat actors for specific exploitation and privilege escalation tasks across multiple platforms.

1894.name: Email-based C&C Communication
1894.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
1894.profile: [profile]Email-based C&C Communication, identified as T1071.003 (Mail Protocols), falls under the Command and Control tactic and is applicable to multiple platforms. This technique involves adversaries using standard email protocols like SMTP/S, IMAP, or POP3/S to blend command and control traffic with legitimate electronic mail delivery, embedding commands and exfiltrated data within protocol headers or email message fields to avoid network filtering. The intrusion-set Turla has been associated with its use.
1894.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Email-based C&C Communication is a technique where adversaries use email protocols like SMTP/S, POP3/S, or IMAP to blend command and control traffic with normal electronic mail delivery, embedding commands and exfiltrated data within email packets or message content to avoid network detection. This method leverages common, encrypted traffic to hide malicious communications.

1895.name: DNS Domain Name Decryption
1895.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may communicate using the Domain Name System (DNS) application layer protocol to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic. Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server. 

The DNS protocol serves an administrative function in computer networking and thus may be very common in environments. DNS traffic may also be allowed even before network authentication is completed. DNS packets contain many fields and headers in which data can be concealed. Often known as DNS tunneling, adversaries may abuse DNS to communicate with systems under their control within a victim network while also mimicking normal, expected traffic.(Citation: PAN DNS Tunneling)(Citation: Medium DnsTunneling)

DNS beaconing may be used to send commands to remote systems via DNS queries. A DNS beacon is created by tunneling DNS traffic (i.e.â€¯[Protocol Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572)). The commands may be embedded into different DNS records, for example, TXT or A records.(Citation: OilRig Uses Updated BONDUPDATER to Target Middle Eastern Government) DNS beacons may be difficult to detect because the beacons infrequently communicate with infected devices.(Citation: DNS Beacons) Infrequent communication conceals the malicious DNS traffic with normal DNS traffic.
1895.profile: [profile]DNS (Domain Name System) is a Command and Control technique under ID T1071.004 within the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves embedding commands and data within DNS protocol traffic, often using DNS tunneling and beaconing, to blend with normal administrative traffic and avoid detection. Commands are concealed in various DNS record types, such as TXT or A records, and communication can be infrequent to further mimic legitimate traffic. This technique is associated with groups like OilRig and Turla.
1895.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "DNS Domain Name Decryption" is not a standard technique in the MITRE ATT&CK framework. Based on the provided context, the name likely refers to a specific adversarial technique for command and control (C2) or data exfiltration. This technique involves concealing data within DNS traffic, often by embedding commands or exfiltrated information into DNS query and response fields, such as TXT or A records. This process, known as DNS tunneling, abuses the DNS protocol to bypass network security controls by making malicious communications blend with normal, expected DNS traffic. The technique is associated with threat groups including OilRig, APT41, and Cobalt Group.[/profile]

1896.name: work command
1896.profile: [profile]The entity "work command" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided context, it is directly associated with the intrusion set Turla. The retrieved similar entities describe various command execution and obfuscation techniques (T1027.010, T1202, T1569), but no specific technical mechanics for "work command" are detailed in the input. Therefore, the profile is limited to its known association with the Turla threat actor.
1896.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "work command" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the retrieved context, it is likely a generic or campaign-specific term for command execution, potentially related to system services (T1569) or command obfuscation (T1027.010). Technical mechanics involve abusing services or daemons to run malicious programs, which can be obfuscated using syntax tricks, string splitting, or encoding to evade detection. This behavior is associated with groups like Lazarus and MuddyWater.

1899.name: wscript.shell.run
1899.profile: [profile]The entity is the Windows Script Host (WSH) method `WScript.Shell.Run`, a technique for execution (T1059.005). It operates on Windows platforms and is used to run commands, scripts, or executables from within a scripting environment like VBScript or JScript. This method provides a programmatic way to launch processes, often leveraged for indirect command execution to bypass security controls that monitor direct command-line interpreter usage. The intrusion set Turla is known to utilize this technique.[/profile]
1899.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "wscript.shell.run" is a command execution technique that leverages the Windows Script Host's WScript.Shell object to run commands or scripts. It is a sub-technique of Windows Command Shell (T1059.003) within the Execution tactic, targeting Windows platforms. This method allows adversaries to execute arbitrary commands directly from scripting environments like VBScript or JScript, often to bypass application control or for indirect command execution, as seen in techniques like T1202. It is commonly used by threat groups such as Lazarus Group and Redcurl for defense evasion and payload delivery.

1900.name: JavaScript payload
1900.profile: [profile]JavaScript payload is a malware component. It is associated with the Turla intrusion set. It is used by groups like Gold Cabin and Lunar Spider in IcedID campaigns, and by DarkHydrus in RogueRobin .NET payloads. It is also utilized by numerous threat actors, including APT29, APT32, APT41, FIN7, and Mustang Panda, in conjunction with Cobalt Strike for testing and deployment. Its key behavior is acting as a delivery or execution script for various malware families across Windows platforms.
1900.profile_without_enhance: [profile]JavaScript payload is a generic malware type, not a specific family. It is referenced in the context of IcedID campaigns, where it serves as an initial downloader. It is also associated with the RogueRobin .NET payload and is used as a test payload by various threat groups employing Cobalt Strike, including APT29, APT32, APT41, DarkHydrus, FIN7, and Mustang Panda.

1901.name: attack on Ruag
1901.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may downgrade or use a version of system features that may be outdated, vulnerable, and/or does not support updated security controls. Downgrade attacks typically take advantage of a systemâ€™s backward compatibility to force it into less secure modes of operation.

However, adversaries may attempt to execute a previous version of PowerShell that does not support SBL with the intent to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) while running malicious scripts that may have otherwise been detected.(Citation: CrowdStrike BGH Ransomware 2021)(Citation: Mandiant BYOL 2018)(Citation: att_def_ps_logging)

1901.profile: [profile]Downgrade Attack is identified as MITRE ATT&CK technique T1562.010 under the Defense Evasion tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. The intrusion-set Turla has been associated with this technique.

The provided similar and related entities describe general adversarial techniques, including downgrade attacks (T1562.010) to use less secure system features, building container images on a host (T1612) to bypass defenses, and various denial-of-service methods like reflection amplification (T1498.002) and service exhaustion floods (T1499.002). The context suggests the "attack on Ruag" likely involved one or more of these technical mechanics, such as protocol manipulation or resource exhaustion, but the precise technical execution for this specific event is not detailed in the provided data.

1904.name: C2 communication
1904.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel. Compromised systems may leverage popular websites and social media to host command and control (C2) instructions. Those infected systems can then send the output from those commands back over that Web service channel. The return traffic may occur in a variety of ways, depending on the Web service being utilized. For example, the return traffic may take the form of the compromised system posting a comment on a forum, issuing a pull request to development project, updating a document hosted on a Web service, or by sending a Tweet. 

Popular websites and social media acting as a mechanism for C2 may give a significant amount of cover due to the likelihood that hosts within a network are already communicating with them prior to a compromise. Using common services, such as those offered by Google or Twitter, makes it easier for adversaries to hide in expected noise. Web service providers commonly use SSL/TLS encryption, giving adversaries an added level of protection.
1904.profile: [profile]The entity is the MITRE ATT&CK technique "Bidirectional Communication" (T1102.002) under the Command and Control tactic, applicable to multiple platforms. It involves using legitimate web services like social media or cloud platforms for two-way command and control, where compromised systems both receive commands and send output back over the same channel, for example by posting comments or updating documents. This method provides cover by blending with normal, often SSL/TLS-encrypted, traffic to services like Google or Twitter, and has been associated with groups including Turla, UNC4210, and Lazarus Group.[profile]
1904.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "C2 communication" is a core concept in adversary behavior, referring to the establishment of command and control channels between compromised systems and attacker infrastructure. This activity falls under the Command and Control tactic. It enables remote manipulation, data exfiltration, and persistence. Adversaries often employ techniques like using legitimate web services (e.g., social media) for covert channels, implementing fallback channels for resilience, and obfuscating traffic to blend with normal network noise and evade detection.

1909.name: Hijacked BGP
1909.profile: [profile]Hijacked BGP is a network manipulation technique where adversaries maliciously alter Border Gateway Protocol routing information to redirect internet traffic. This can be used to intercept, monitor, or disrupt communications by poisoning routing tables, effectively allowing attackers to man-in-the-middle or deny service to targeted network segments. The intrusion set Turla has been associated with the use of this technique.
1909.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "Hijacked BGP" is a network attack pattern. Based on the provided context, it involves adversaries manipulating the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) to redirect internet traffic. This technique can be used for interception, denial of service, or man-in-the-middle attacks by poisoning routing tables. The retrieved information, while containing other hijacking techniques (like execution flow or COM hijacking), does not provide a specific MITRE ATT&CK ID, tactic, or platform for BGP hijacking, so this profile is synthesized from the core concept described.

1910.name: HTTP Manipulation
1910.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain and/or elevate access to victim systems. Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves or modifies adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups.(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021) These actions could also include account activity designed to subvert security policies, such as performing iterative password updates to bypass password duration policies and preserve the life of compromised credentials. 

In order to create or manipulate accounts, the adversary must already have sufficient permissions on systems or the domain. However, account manipulation may also lead to privilege escalation where modifications grant access to additional roles, permissions, or higher-privileged [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078).
1910.profile: [profile]The entity "HTTP Manipulation" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique. Based on the provided data, the core information aligns with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1098 "Account Manipulation" under the Persistence tactic for Windows, Linux, and macOS platforms. This technique involves actions like modifying account credentials or permission groups to maintain access, including iterative password updates to bypass security policies. The intrusion set Turla is associated with this behavior. The retrieved information on "web protocols" and "IIS components" describes distinct techniques and is not directly applicable to the technical mechanics of account manipulation.[/profile]
1910.profile_without_enhance: [profile]HTTP Manipulation is a technique where adversaries modify HTTP traffic to conceal malicious activity. It is often used for command and control (C2) communication, embedding commands and exfiltrated data within standard HTTP/S request and response headers and fields to blend with normal web traffic. This can be implemented by installing malicious ISAPI extensions or filters on Internet Information Services (IIS) web servers to observe and alter HTTP requests and responses.

1911.name: Fake Flash Player Installer
1911.profile: [profile]Fake Flash Player Installer, also known as holcus installer (adware), is associated with the intrusion set Turla. It operates via malvertising campaigns, often described as "Made in China," and uses deceptive techniques such as creating iframes from domains like lopiax[.]us to deliver fake Flash Player update recommendations, which can lead to the installation of additional malware like Magecart skimmers or NetSupportManager RAT. Its primary target is users tricked into updating Adobe Flash Player, typically on Windows systems, through compromised or malicious websites.]
1911.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Fake Flash Player Installer, also known as Flashback, is a malware that disguises itself as an Adobe Flash Player installer or update. It is associated with groups like Magecart and FIN6, and operates through malvertising campaigns that create iframes from domains like lopiax[.]us to deliver fake update recommendations. Its primary target platform is systems seeking Flash Player installations, often for data theft purposes.

1913.name: Snake
1913.uncertain_mes: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is a cyber espionage threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB).  They have compromised victims in over 50 countries since at least 2004, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns, and leveraging in-house tools and malware, such as [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022).(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)
1913.profile: [profile]The primary intrusion set is Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, and Secret Blizzard. Its arsenal prominently features the custom rootkit and backdoor malware Uroburos. The group is attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) and has been active since at least 2004. It conducts long-term cyber espionage campaigns using watering hole attacks and spearphishing, targeting a wide range of sectors across over 50 countries, with a focus on government, military, embassies, and research institutions.
1913.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, Krypton, and UNC4210, is a sophisticated cyber espionage group widely attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically linked to the FSB. Its key malware includes the Snake/Uroburos rootkit, the KopiLuwak dropper, and the Lunar suite (LunarWeb, LunarMail). Distinctive TTPs involve spear-phishing, watering hole attacks, and the unique practice of hijacking and repurposing malware and infrastructure from other threat actors. It primarily targets government, diplomatic, military, and media sectors across Europe, the Middle East, and Central Asia for long-term strategic intelligence gathering.[/profile]

It is distinguished by its sophisticated, custom malware framework historically named "Snake" or "Uroburos," which utilizes complex rootkit and kernel-level capabilities for persistent espionage. The group's operations are attributed to Russian intelligence services, primarily targeting government, diplomatic, and military sectors in Eastern Europe, Central Asia, and NATO member states for strategic intelligence collection. Its activities show overlaps with other reported clusters, and it is believed to maintain a distinct, long-running cyber espionage program.

1914.uncertain_mes: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is a cyber espionage threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB).  They have compromised victims in over 50 countries since at least 2004, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns, and leveraging in-house tools and malware, such as [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022).(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)
1914.profile: [profile]UNC4210, also known as Turla, Snake, Uroburos, VENOMOUS BEAR, and Summit, is a cyber espionage group attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB). It is known for its custom malware arsenal, including the Uroburos rootkit, and employs tactics such as watering hole attacks and spearphishing. The group has targeted a wide range of sectors globally, including government, military, embassies, education, and pharmaceutical companies, across over 50 countries since at least 2004, primarily for intelligence gathering.
1914.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set UNC4210 is an alias for the sophisticated cyber espionage group Turla, also known as Snake, Uroburos, Venomous Bear, Waterbug, and Krypton. Its key malware includes the custom backdoors KOPILUWAK and QUIETCANARY, and it has been observed using the ANDROMEDA malware family. Distinctive TTPs involve process injection (ANDROMEDA injected process), network reconnaissance, and data exfiltration via command and control (C2) communication, often using infrastructure like yelprope.cloudns[.]cl. The group is widely attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically linked to the FSB. It primarily targets government, diplomatic, military, and media sectors across Europe, the Middle East, and Central Asia for long-term strategic intelligence gathering.

Its primary tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) involve long-term espionage campaigns. The group is attributed to Russian intelligence services and primarily targets government, diplomatic, and defense sectors globally, with a core motivation of strategic intelligence collection.

1915.name: GET request
1915.profile: [profile]The entity "GET request" is a fundamental web protocol technique, not a specific MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is used by adversaries like UNC4210 for initial network interaction and reconnaissance. The retrieved information describes how adversaries may spoof browser attributes like the User-Agent string within HTTP GET requests to blend in with legitimate traffic and evade detection. This activity is a component of broader techniques such as Impersonation (T1036) and Application Layer Protocol (T1071).
1915.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "GET request" is a fundamental network communication method, not a distinct MITRE ATT&CK technique. It is the standard HTTP method used to retrieve data from a web server. This basic action is inherent to numerous ATT&CK techniques, such as when adversaries use it for command and control (e.g., T1071.001), to exfiltrate data (T1048.003), or to interact with cloud APIs for discovery or credential access (T1580, T1555.006). Its technical mechanics involve sending a simple HTTP request to a specified URI, and it is universally applicable across all platforms that use web protocols.

1916.name: ANDROMEDA injected process
1916.profile: [profile]ANDROMEDA injected process is a specific implementation of the Process Injection (T1055) technique, primarily associated with the UNC4210 intrusion set. It operates within the Defense Evasion tactic on Windows platforms. The technique involves creating a legitimate process in a suspended state, hollowing out its memory, and replacing it with malicious code. This is achieved using Windows API calls like CreateProcess, ZwUnmapViewOfSection, WriteProcessMemory, and ResumeThread to mask execution under a benign process, evading detection.
1916.profile_without_enhance: [profile]ANDROMEDA injected process is a specific implementation of the Process Injection (T1055) technique, falling under the Defense Evasion tactic, primarily targeting Windows platforms. It operates by injecting malicious code into a legitimate process's address space to mask execution. The technique involves creating a process in a suspended state, hollowing out its memory using APIs like NtUnmapViewOfSection, and then writing and executing malicious code via VirtualAllocEx, WriteProcessMemory, SetThreadContext, and ResumeThread, thereby evading detection by running under a legitimate process's guise.

1917.name: Zebrocy
1917.profile: [profile]Zebrocy, also known as Sofacy, is an intrusion set attributed to the Russian state-sponsored group APT28 (Fancy Bear). Its key malware includes custom MSIL components, such as the file-stealing Covfacy modules, with versioning around 7.0 and 7.1. The group's TTPs involve deploying VB.NET variants and other Zebrocy modules as part of its toolset. Zebrocy primarily targets sectors and regions of strategic interest to its operators, with motivations aligned with espionage and information gathering on behalf of its state sponsor.
1917.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is definitively identified as APT28, also known as Fancy Bear, Sednit, Strontium, Pawn Storm, and Tsar Team. Its key custom malware includes the modular X-Agent (CHOPSTICK) backdoor, X-Tunnel, Seduploader, Zebrocy, and variants like JhuHugit (based on Carberp), Coreshell, and AdvStoreShell. Key TTPs involve sophisticated spear-phishing, exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities in Adobe Flash and Microsoft Office, and data exfiltration via tools like USBStealer. The group is attributed to Russia's GRU military intelligence, specifically Units 26165 and 74455. It primarily targets government, military, political, and diplomatic organizations in NATO countries, Europe, Ukraine, and North America, motivated by strategic cyber espionage and information operations to support Russian state interests.[/profile]
1917.profile_without_enhance_0: [profile]The intrusion set is most commonly tracked as Zebrocy, a sub-group or distinct toolset closely associated with APT28 (also known as Fancy Bear, Sofacy, and STRONTIUM). Its key malware is the eponymous Zebrocy backdoor, deployed in variants including a VB.NET version. Its primary TTPs involve heavy, targeted deployments of this custom malware. The group is attributed to Russian state-sponsored actors, specifically the GRU, and shows overlaps with APT28's operations. Its targeting has focused on sectors and regions including Turkey (TR), Kazakhstan (KZ), Armenia (AM), Kyrgyzstan (KG), Jordan (JO), the United Kingdom (UK), and Uzbekistan (UZ), aligning with strategic intelligence-gathering and espionage motivations.

The group's operations show a focus on post-Soviet and Central Asian regions, with targeting reported in countries including Turkey (TR), Kazakhstan (KZ), Armenia (AM), Kyrgyzstan (KG), Jordan (JO), the UK, and Uzbekistan (UZ). Its activities are attributed to Russian state-sponsored interests, primarily motivated by espionage and intelligence gathering against governmental and diplomatic entities.]

1918.name: recordtofile file stealer method
1918.uncertain_mes: An adversary may compress or encrypt data that is collected prior to exfiltration using a custom method. Adversaries may choose to use custom archival methods, such as encryption with XOR or stream ciphers implemented with no external library or utility references. Custom implementations of well-known compression algorithms have also been used.(Citation: ESET Sednit Part 2)
1918.profile: [profile]Archive via Custom Method, also known as T1560.003, is a Collection technique within the MITRE ATT&CK framework applicable to multiple platforms. It involves compressing or encrypting collected data using bespoke algorithms like XOR or stream ciphers, or custom implementations of standard compression routines, to obfuscate the data prior to exfiltration. This method is employed by groups including FIN6, Lazarus Group, and UNC3886 to evade detection by avoiding common archival utilities.[/profile]
1918.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The entity "recordtofile file stealer method" is a data theft technique. It functions by using the Windows `RecordToFile` API to capture and save audio data, which adversaries then exfiltrate. This method is part of the Exfiltration tactic and targets the Windows platform. The technique is notably used by the Lazarus Group to steal sensitive information from compromised systems.

1919.name: rc4-like encryption
1919.uncertain_mes:
Adversaries may compromise a network deviceâ€™s encryption capability in order to bypass encryption that would otherwise protect data communications. (Citation: Cisco Synful Knock Evolution)

Encryption can be used to protect transmitted network traffic to maintain its confidentiality (protect against unauthorized disclosure) and integrity (protect against unauthorized changes). Encryption ciphers are used to convert a plaintext message to ciphertext and can be computationally intensive to decipher without the associated decryption key. Typically, longer keys increase the cost of cryptanalysis, or decryption without the key.

Adversaries can compromise and manipulate devices that perform encryption of network traffic. For example, through behaviors such as [Modify System Image](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1601), [Reduce Key Space](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/001), and [Disable Crypto Hardware](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1600/002), an adversary can negatively effect and/or eliminate a deviceâ€™s ability to securely encrypt network traffic. This poses a greater risk of unauthorized disclosure and may help facilitate data manipulation, Credential Access, or Collection efforts. (Citation: Cisco Blog Legacy Device Attacks)
1919.profile: [profile]The entity "rc4-like encryption" is not a standard MITRE ATT&CK technique; based on the provided context, it likely refers to the use of RC4, a symmetric encryption algorithm. RC4 is a stream cipher that uses a variable key size to generate a pseudo-random keystream, which is then XORed with plaintext for encryption. It is known for its simplicity and speed but has significant cryptographic weaknesses, making it vulnerable to attacks. This algorithm can be employed by adversaries in techniques like T1573.001 (Symmetric Cryptography) for command and control or T1048.001 (Exfiltration Over Symmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol) for data theft, often as part of multilayer encryption schemes to obscure malicious traffic.
1919.profile_without_enhance: [profile]RC4-like encryption is a symmetric encryption algorithm used to conceal command and control traffic or exfiltrated data, often implemented manually within other protocols like HTTP or HTTPS to add an extra layer of obfuscation. It functions by using a shared secret key for both encryption and decryption, generating a pseudo-random stream of bits (a keystream) that is combined with the plaintext. This technique is associated with threat groups like APT28, Lazarus Group, and MuddyWater.

1920.name: exfiltration
1920.profile: [profile]Exfiltration is the adversary technique of stealing data from a network. The specific MITRE ATT&CK ID and Tactic are not defined in the provided data, but the technique involves transferring collected data out of a compromised environment. Technical mechanics include using automated processing, scheduling transfers at specific times, and employing various channels such as USB devices, Bluetooth, web services, or webhooks to move the data. Groups like Zebrocy, Tropic Trooper, and Mustang Panda have been associated with these methods.
1920.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Exfiltration is the adversary technique of stealing data from a network, categorized under the Exfiltration tactic (TA0010) and applicable across multiple platforms. It involves the unauthorized transfer of collected information using various methods, including command and control channels, alternative network protocols, or physical media like USB devices. Specific sub-techniques, such as Automated Exfiltration (T1020) and Scheduled Transfer (T1029), detail automated or timed data transfers, often employed by groups like Gamaredon and Tropic Trooper.

1921.name: network drive monitoring
1921.uncertain_mes: Adversaries may search network shares on computers they have compromised to find files of interest. Sensitive data can be collected from remote systems via shared network drives (host shared directory, network file server, etc.) that are accessible from the current system prior to Exfiltration. Interactive command shells may be in use, and common functionality within [cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) may be used to gather information.
1921.profile: [profile]Network Drive Monitoring, also known as Data from Network Shared Drive (T1039), is a Collection tactic used on Windows systems. Adversaries search accessible network shares and shared drives on compromised computers to locate and gather sensitive files of interest prior to exfiltration. This activity is often performed using interactive command shells and common utilities like cmd.exe. The intrusion set Zebrocy has been observed using this technique.
1921.profile_without_enhance: [profile]Network Drive Monitoring is a technique for Discovery, likely on Windows platforms, where adversaries search network shares on compromised systems to find files of interest. This involves using command shells and utilities like `cmd` to gather information from accessible remote systems, shared directories, or network file servers, often as a precursor to data exfiltration.

1922.name: MSIL components
1922.profile: [profile]MSIL components are a set of .NET-based malware modules deployed by the intrusion set Zebrocy (attributed to APT28). These components, including versions 7.0 and 7.1, are used to drop file-stealing modules known as Covfacy, representing an unexpected inclusion in the Zebrocy toolset for data exfiltration. The target platform is Windows.
1922.profile_without_enhance: [profile]MSIL components are .NET-based modules deployed by the Zebrocy malware (attributed to APT28) as part of its toolset, specifically used to drop file-stealing modules known as Covfacy. These components represent an unexpected inclusion in Zebrocy's arsenal, with observed versioning around 7.0 and 7.1, and they target the Windows platform.

1923.name: Lin Yong
1923.profile: [profile]Lin Yong is an individual believed to be a founder of the Honker Union of China, also known as Lion. He is notably linked to the intrusion set APT41 (also known as Bronze Atlas, Winnti, and Wicked Panda), having been recruited by the company Topsec. His connections suggest an origin and operational context within Chinese patriotic or commercial hacking spheres, including associations with groups like the China Red Hacker Alliance and Beijing Tianrongxin. His activities are primarily characterized by this affiliation with a major advanced persistent threat group known for cyber espionage and financially motivated operations.
1923.profile_without_enhance: [profile]The intrusion set is most likely the Chinese state-aligned group known as Beijing Tianrongxin or Water Orthrus. It is also known as APT41, UNC302, UNC5174 (UTEUS), and is directly linked to the patriotic hacker figure and China Red Hacker Alliance founder Lin Yong (aka Lion). Its key malware is the custom family Water Orthrus, which uniquely uses blocklisted drivers to disable specific Chinese security software. The group is attributed to Chinese state interests, believed to be linked to MSS contractors. It primarily targets sectors and regions of geopolitical interest to China, driven by espionage and strategic motivations.

The profile shows a direct link to the APT group APT41 (also known as TA415, Amoeba, Winnti, and Leopard Typhoon), as Topsec's recruitment of Lin Yong is documented in the context of APT41's historical formation and its absorption of early patriotic hackers. Based on this connection and the context of Chinese state-aligned cyber activity, the entity is assessed to be a person associated with or subsumed within the broader APT41 collective. The primary motivation is likely aligned with Chinese state interests, including cyber espionage and intellectual property theft.

1924.uncertain_mes:
About C.A.S
C.A.S (Cyber Anarchy Squad) is a hacktivist group that has been attacking organizations in Russia and Belarus since 2022. Besides data theft, its goal is to inflict maximum damage, including reputational. To this end, the groupâ€™s attacks exploit vulnerabilities in publicly available services and make extensive use of free tools.

1925.profile: [profile]Beijing Tianrongxin, also known as the Beijing group, is an intrusion set with suspected links to the Chinese state-sponsored actor APT41, as indicated by shared infrastructure within the China Unicom Beijing Network. Its operational profile includes connections to the individual Lin Yong. While its specific malware and TTPs are not detailed in this data, its targeting appears to involve the cybersecurity sector, as suggested by associations with entities like Water Orthrus, which focuses on security software firms in Beijing. The group's primary motivation is believed to be aligned with Chinese strategic intelligence objectives.

This group shows overlaps with other Chinese APT clusters, sharing infrastructure and TTPs, and is believed to operate in support of Chinese strategic intelligence-gathering objectives, likely focusing on technology and government sectors.

It is attributed to China and is known for its dual espionage and financially motivated operations. The group employs a wide arsenal of custom malware and tools, including the Winnti backdoor, and utilizes sophisticated TTPs such as supply chain compromises and living-off-the-land techniques. Its targets span multiple sectors globally, including technology, telecommunications, and government entities, primarily for intelligence gathering and intellectual property theft, though it also conducts cybercrime for profit.
